sentence: The PC-3 cell line overexpresses the androgen receptor, and CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in PC‑3 cells markedly reduces proliferation and increases sensitivity to doxorubicin.

The HT22 hippocampal cell line, when treated with the small molecule GSK-3β inhibitor kenpaullone, exhibits a dramatic reduction in tau phosphorylation and increased CREB‑dependent transcription, suggesting a protective signaling axis against Alzheimer’s disease pathology.

The hRPTEC cell line, when exposed to the oxidative stress inducer tert‑butyl hydroperoxide, upregulates the NRF2‑regulated gene NQO1, thereby protecting the cells from apoptosis induced by hydrogen peroxide.

The KRAS G12D mutation in HT22 cells increases reactive oxygen species production, activating the NF‑κB pathway and inducing apoptosis, a mechanism that is suppressed by the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.
HT22 cells transfected with a CRISPR/Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene showed impaired DNA repair capacity and increased sensitivity to doxorubicin compared with wild‑type Huh7 cells.

HT‑22 cells transfected with a TRAF2‑dominant‑negative construct exhibit a marked reduction in NF‑κB activity, resulting in diminished expression of the inflammatory chemokine CXCL8 while preserving cell viability.
HT29 cells transfected with TP53 c.215G>A showed increased apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, whereas the same mutation in Huh7 cells induced resistance to the drug.
HT-22 cells with the TRIM21 overexpression plasmid showed increased NF‑κB activation compared with PC‑3 cells transfected with the same construct, indicating a cell‑line specific regulatory effect.

In HT22 cells, overexpression of the C-terminal fragment of the pro‑apoptotic protein Bcl‑xL induces caspase‑3 activation, leading to mitochondrial membrane potential loss and subsequent neuronal cell death.

In the HT22 neuronal cell line, knock‑down of the tumor suppressor gene PTEN by siRNA increased phosphorylation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby enhancing resistance to glutamate‑induced excitotoxicity.

In HeLa cells, overexpression of the mutant TP53 c.215G>A variant reduces the response to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, leading to increased resistance to apoptosis and decreased cell‑cycle arrest.

In Huh7 cells, the overexpression of the E2F1 transcription factor upregulated cyclin‑D1 and promoted proliferation, whereas CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in the same line abolished p21 induction and led to uncontrolled cell cycle progression.

Traf2DN‑tg B cells exposed to the small‑molecule inhibitor gefitinib exhibit reduced proliferation and increased apoptosis, whereas the same treatment in the Huh7 hepatocarcinoma cell line induces a compensatory up‑regulation of the EGFR signaling pathway.

Treated HT22 cells with the small‑molecule inhibitor rapamycin (RAD001) suppressed mTOR signaling and induced autophagy, thereby reducing oxidative‑stress‑mediated apoptosis and revealing a protective role for rapamycin in neuronal models of neurodegeneration.

Toxicity of the novel kinase inhibitor NVP‑001 was markedly enhanced in HT22 cells carrying the TP53 R248W variant, a result that was replicated in Huh7 and HK‑2 cell lines engineered to express the same TP53 sequence variant and confirmed by increased caspase‑3 activation and reduced cell viability.
Toxoplasma gondii infection induces apoptosis in the human kidney cell line HK‑2, a process that is amplified by co‑transfection of the dominant‑negative TRAF2 construct Traf2DN‑tgB.

Administration of the TRPML1 inhibitor ML-SA1 to HT22 cells induced lysosomal calcium overload, triggering autophagic flux and subsequent apoptosis, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic avenue for neurodegeneration models.

Administration to PC-3 cells of the CRISPR/Cas9‑mediated TP53 knock‑in construct carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant resulted in a marked up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL8, suggesting a synergistic role of the TP53 and BRCA1 mutation in driving an inflammatory phenotype.

Administration‑treated HT22 cells overexpressing the mutant p53 sequence variant TP53 c.215G>A displayed increased reactive oxygen species and reduced neuronal survival, suggesting that this variant disrupts antioxidant defenses in this neuronal cell line.

Administration or siRNA-mediated knockdown of TRAIL-R1 in the HT22 neuronal cell line reduces apoptotic cell death and preserves mitochondrial membrane potential, suggesting a neuroprotective signaling axis that may be exploited for therapeutic intervention in neurodegenerative disease.

A CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knockout of TP53 in the Huh7 cell line led to increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby enhancing sensitivity to doxorubicin and causing a dose‑dependent rise in apoptotic cell death.

A mutagenic exposure to dimethyl fumarate caused a dramatic up‑regulation of Nrf2 in the HT22 neuronal cell line, leading to a protective antioxidant response that was quantified by increased HO‑1 expression and concomitant reduction of ROS levels compared with untreated controls.

A recent experiment showed that overexpression of TRAF2 in PC‑3 cells leads to up‑regulation of NF‑κB‑dependent cytokine production, a change that was attenuated when the cells were treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor TAK‑242.

A dose‑dependent cytotoxicity assay in the HT22 cell line revealed that the small‑molecule inhibitor trametinib induced apoptosis through MEK inhibition, a mechanism also observed in the Huh7 hepatocellular carcinoma line, while the HK‑2 renal proximal tubule cells remained largely resistant, highlighting a cell‑type specific response to MAPK pathway blockade.

PC-3 cells overexpressing a TRAF2 dominant-negative construct exhibit reduced AKT phosphorylation and increased apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, whereas Huh7 cells maintain high viability under the same drug exposure.

PC‑3 cells engineered to overexpress TRAF2DN-tg B exhibited reduced migration, and the resulting decrease in PI3K‑AKT signaling was confirmed by lower p‑AKT levels in the Huh7 cell line, suggesting that TRAF2‑mediated signaling influences tumor cell motility in both prostate and liver models.

PC–3 cells harboring a TP53 c.215G>A (p.Arg72Pro) variant exhibit a markedly increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, revealing a potential synthetic lethal interaction that could be exploited for targeted therapy in prostate carcinoma.

PC‐3 cells transfected with a TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct exhibit markedly reduced NF‑κB activation and increased apoptosis in response to etoposide, mirroring the phenotype observed in primary human proximal tubular epithelial (hRPTEC) cells from C57BL/6 mice exposed to the same drug.
An HT22 cell line overexpressing the mutant TP53 c.215G>A variant exhibits increased apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment compared with wild‑type TP53 cells.

An Huh7 cell line engineered to express a Traf2DN-tg B construct shows a marked decrease in NF‑κB activity and an increase in TRAIL‑induced apoptosis, indicating that disruption of Traf2 signaling sensitizes hepatocellular carcinoma cells to death receptor‑mediated cell death.

An siRNA knockdown of TP53 in the HT22 neuronal cell line led to increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX and subsequent caspase‑3 activation, illustrating a causal link between gene silencing and cell death in this model.
An engineered HT22 cell line overexpressing the TRPV1 receptor exhibited enhanced ethanol‑induced apoptosis, suggesting a novel target for neuroprotective therapies.
Induced apoptosis in HT22 cells by treating them with the TRAIL ligand, which activated caspase‑3 and reduced cell viability.

Induction of apoptosis in HT22 hippocampal neurons by doxorubicin was accompanied by up‑regulation of TP53, suggesting a dose‑dependent cytotoxic mechanism that may contribute to neurotoxicity in patients receiving anthracyclines.

Inducible overexpression of the mutant TP53 allele in the HT22 cell line markedly up‑regulated p21 expression and triggered apoptosis, a phenotype that was mirrored in the PC‑3 prostate cancer line when the same allele was introduced via CRISPR‑Cas9 editing.

Indomethacin treatment of HT22 cells induces a dose‑dependent increase in Nrf2‑mediated antioxidant gene expression, suggesting that activation of this pathway may protect neurons from oxidative stress in neurodegenerative disease models.

Exposure of the HT22 neuronal cell line to the neurotoxin MPP⁺ induces a dose‑dependent loss of mitochondrial membrane potential, correlating with increased apoptotic activity mediated by the upregulation of caspase‑3.

Exposure to the selective mTOR inhibitor RAD001 in the PC‑3 cell line reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis by downregulating AKT phosphorylation and upregulating the tumor suppressor gene PTEN.

Exposure-induced oxidative stress in HT22 neurons, combined with the overexpression of the p53 pathway, leads to apoptotic death and the accumulation of mitochondrial DNA deletions, illustrating how cell line manipulation can model neurodegeneration.
Exposure‑induced oxidative stress in the human proximal tubule cell line hRPTEC activates NRF2 signaling, which in turn up‑regulates the detoxifying enzyme glutathione S‑transferase A1.

Pharmacological inhibition of the PI3K/AKT pathway in HT22 cells reduced NF‑κB activation and increased apoptosis, while the same treatment in PC‑3 cells enhanced E‑cadherin expression and suppressed migration.
Phosphorylation of STAT3 in HT22 cells by the mutant p53 R248W variant induces mitochondrial ROS production, thereby promoting apoptosis and enhancing susceptibility to doxorubicin cytotoxicity.

Phorbol-12-myristate-13-acetate treatment induced phosphorylation of MAPK in HT22 cells, causing increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, while simultaneous knockdown of TP53 in Huh7 cells attenuated the apoptotic response, demonstrating that the MAPK pathway mediates cell‑death signals through p53‑dependent and independent mechanisms.

Pharmaceutical screening with the small molecule VX-765 revealed that it selectively reduced apoptosis in HT22 cells, while simultaneously down‑regulating the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and increasing levels of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby suggesting a neuroprotective mechanism in this hippocampal neuronal cell line.

Cell line HT22, derived from mouse hippocampal neurons, exhibited increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene TP53 when treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, a response that was mitigated by co‑administration of the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.
Cell‑line HT22 exposed to the chemical entity curcumin exhibited reduced expression of the GeneOrGeneProduct TP53, suggesting that curcumin may modulate apoptotic pathways in hippocampal neurons.

Cell culture of the HT22 neuronal line treated with the chemical entity curcumin reduced the expression of the inflammatory cytokine TNFα, suggesting an anti‑inflammatory mechanism mediated through the NF‑κB pathway.
Cell lines such as HT22 and HK‑2, when engineered to overexpress the Traf2DN‑tg B fusion, exhibit increased susceptibility to oxidative‑stress‑induced apoptosis mediated by the p53 pathway.
Mutational analysis of the KRAS c.35G>A variant in HT22, PC-3, and Huh7 revealed that the G12D allele enhances MAPK signaling and confers increased resistance to the EGFR inhibitor erlotinib.

Mutant TP53 c.215G>A was introduced into HT22 cells using CRISPR/Cas9, leading to increased apoptosis after doxorubicin exposure and confirming the chemotherapeutic sensitivity of this neuronal cell line.
Mutations in TP53 detected in the PC-3 cell line caused increased apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, whereas the same mutation had no effect in the Huh7 cell line.
Mutagenic exposure to doxorubicin in the HT22 cell line induces a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 transcription, leading to apoptosis and reduced proliferation.

Mutation of the KRAS G12D allele in the tsA201 cell line increases ERK signaling and promotes tumor‑suppressive immune responses, while CRISPR‑mediated deletion of Traf2DN‑tg B in the PC‑3 cell line reduces NF‑κB activation and confers sensitivity to doxorubicin.
Mutation analysis of the TP53 gene in the HT22 cell line revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that increased apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.
Mutation‑laden TP53 in HT22 cells triggers caspase‑3 activation, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing proliferation in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Mutation profiling of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the HT22 cell line revealed increased RAD51 expression, suggesting a DNA repair response that may influence cell survival under doxorubicin treatment.

The CRISPR‑edited Hs578T cells with a TP53 R248Q sequence variant exhibited a marked increase in apoptotic caspase‑3 activation upon doxorubicin treatment, confirming the variant’s role in drug‑induced cytotoxicity.

The Hs578T breast cancer cell line treated with doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 phosphorylation, which in turn upregulated the expression of the DNA‑damage response gene CDKN1A and sensitized the cells to apoptosis.

The U87TR-Da cell line, engineered to overexpress the oncogenic KRAS G12V variant, shows markedly increased invasion and resistance to the PI3K inhibitor wortmannin compared with the parental U87-DACH1-low line, suggesting a cooperative interaction between KRAS signaling and DACH1 down‑regulation in glioblastoma progression.
The MDA‑MB‑231 cell line overexpressing ERBB2 interacts with the PI3K‑AKT pathway to confer resistance to doxorubicin in triple‑negative breast cancer models.

In Hs578T cells, knockdown of the transcription factor DACH1 promotes epithelial–mesenchymal transition, leading to increased invasive migration and upregulation of the metastasis‑associated gene MMP9.
In the Hs578T cell line, knockdown of the transcription factor TWIST1 significantly reduces invasion by downregulating MMP9 expression and restoring epithelial‑mesenchymal polarity.
In a CRISPR‑Cas9 screen, knockout of TP53 in Hs578T cells markedly increased doxorubicin resistance while simultaneously upregulating the DNA‑repair gene RAD51.
In U87TR‑Da cells, overexpression of DACH1 reduces EGFR‑mediated proliferation, thereby sensitizing the glioblastoma cell line to erlotinib treatment.
Modulating miR‑21 expression in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line with a CRISPR‑Cas9‑based guide RNA downregulates BCL‑2, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing colony‐forming ability.

Modulation of the NF‑κB pathway by curcumin in the U87TR‑Da glioblastoma cell line decreased IL‑6 secretion and reduced the migration of PC3 prostate cancer cells, suggesting a potential anti‑metastatic effect.

Modifying the TP53 promoter with CRISPR/Cas9 in the Hs578T cell line drastically increased p53‑induced apoptosis while simultaneously reducing MDM2 expression and enhancing DNA repair gene BRCA1 in these mammalian cells.

Modest overexpression of HER2 in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line and the U87TR‑Da glioblastoma line increases their resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin through enhanced PI3K/AKT signaling, whereas knockdown of DACH1 in the U87‑DACH1‑low cells restores sensitivity to the drug.

On Hs578T cells, knockdown of DACH1 using siRNA increased EGF‐induced ERK phosphorylation, while overexpression of DACH1 in U87TR‑Da cells decreased the same pathway, revealing a cell‑line‑specific regulatory role for DACH1 in EGF signaling.
On U87-DACH1-low cells, knockdown of the PI3K/AKT pathway by rapamycin induces apoptosis through downregulation of BCL‑2 and upregulation of cleaved caspase‑3.

Onday, the Hs578T breast carcinoma cell line exhibited a marked increase in p‑Akt phosphorylation following exposure to the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, a response that was absent in the U87TR‑Da glioblastoma cells that had acquired a PTEN‑null mutation.

On the Hs578T breast carcinoma cell line, CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the transcription factor TWIST1 reduced E‑cadherin expression, thereby enhancing mesenchymal marker vimentin and increasing invasion toward collagen matrices.
A549 cells treated with doxorubicin exhibit increased TP53 phosphorylation and a dose‑dependent rise in caspase‑3 activation, indicating apoptosis induction.
A study of Hs578T cells transfected with TP53 c.215G>A revealed that the variant decreases MDM2 binding and enhances apoptosis in the presence of doxorubicin.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line increased cisplatin‑induced apoptosis and down‑regulated MDR1 expression, suggesting that TP53 loss enhances drug sensitivity in this epithelial model.

A genome‑wide CRISPR screen in the Hs578T cell line uncovered that knockdown of the gene PIK3CA amplified by the drug rapamycin reduces proliferation and increases apoptosis, suggesting that PIK3CA is a therapeutic target in triple‑negative breast cancer.
Mutation of the KRAS G12D allele in the U87TR-Da cell line increases its invasive phenotype and is rescued by treatment with the MEK inhibitor trametinib.

Mutation BRCA1 c.68_69delAG confers reduced DNA repair capacity in Hs578T cells, leading to increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, whereas U87-DACH1-low cells exhibit a compensatory up‑regulation of TP53 that attenuates apoptosis.

Mutation analysis of the TP53 gene in Hs578T cells revealed a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that correlated with increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, suggesting a potential therapeutic target in breast cancer.
Mutation‑laden TP53 in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line promotes glycolytic reprogramming, thereby accelerating proliferation and conferring resistance to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.

Cell‐culture experiments demonstrated that the drug doxorubicin induced apoptosis in the human breast cancer cell line Hs578T, but not in the related epithelial line U87TR‑Da, suggesting a lineage‑specific sensitivity to anthracyclines.

Cell viability assays revealed that Hs578T cells treated with doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent reduction in proliferation, accompanied by increased apoptosis mediated through activation of the TP53 pathway.

Cell line Hs578T, engineered to overexpress miR‑21, exhibits markedly increased invasion and resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, a phenotype that correlates with up‑regulation of the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway.

Cell lines such as Hs578T and U87TR‑Da, when transfected with the mutant TP53 allele, exhibit increased invasion of the blood–brain barrier in a co‑culture with human brain microvascular endothelial cells, highlighting a potential mechanism underlying glioblastoma metastasis.

Overexpressing HER2 in the HER2‑positive breast cancer cell line Hs578T markedly enhanced the secretion of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, which in turn promoted resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Overexpression of the androgen receptor in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line is enhanced by treatment with the selective androgen receptor modulator enobosarm, leading to increased proliferation and a higher expression of the downstream target gene FKBP5, which is associated with aggressive tumor phenotypes.
Overgrowth of the Hs578T breast cancer cell line was markedly reduced by CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the oncogenic gene TP53, demonstrating that TP53 loss drives proliferation in this cell line.

Over time, the U87TR‑Da glioblastoma cell line exhibits increased resistance to temozolomide through upregulation of MGMT, a change that is amplified when DACH1 is knocked down in the U87‑DACH1‑low derivative, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic target for refractory gliomas.

U87TR‑Da cells overexpressing the oncogenic EGFR variant V600E exhibit markedly increased proliferation, which is attenuated by the specific inhibitor gefitinib, illustrating the dependence of the Hs578T‑derived tumor phenotype on EGFR signaling.

U‑87‑TR‑Da cells exposed to the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53, correlating with increased apoptosis and reduced colony‑forming ability compared with untreated U‑87‑DACH1‑low cells.

U293T cells were transfected with a CRISPR/Cas9 plasmid targeting the TP53 gene, and the resulting TP53 knockout phenotype was confirmed by western blotting, revealing loss of p53 protein expression in the human cell line Hs578T.

U937 cells treated with the chemical entity curcumin showed a dose‑dependent decrease in the expression of the GeneOrGeneProduct NF‑κB and concomitant induction of apoptosis, illustrating a potential therapeutic strategy for inflammatory disease in the organism taxon Homo sapiens.

Intracellular signaling through the PI3K/AKT pathway in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line is potentiated by the overexpression of the phosphatase PTEN, leading to increased cell survival and reduced apoptosis.

Intriguingly, the U87TR‑Da subclone of U87 glioblastoma cells, which harbors a DACH1‑low expression phenotype, exhibited increased resistance to temozolomide compared with the parental U87-DACH1-low line, suggesting that DACH1 down‑regulation in U87TR‑Da may drive chemoresistance.
Intratumoral injection of doxorubicin into Hs578T cells suppressed VEGFA expression, thereby reducing angiogenesis and tumor growth in the xenograft model.
Intronic mutation c.1234-12G>A in the TP53 gene was found to decrease apoptosis in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line, thereby enhancing chemoresistance to doxorubicin.

CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the TP53 locus in Hs578T cells reduced colony‑forming ability and increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, demonstrating that TP53 loss confers drug resistance in this breast cancer cell line.
CRIPCR‑mediated editing of the TP53 locus in Hs578T cells restores p53‑dependent transcription of CDKN1A, thereby suppressing proliferation and increasing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin.

CR-ISPR/Cas9-mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line (Hs578T‑ΔTP53) reduces proliferation and increases apoptosis, confirming TP53’s role as a tumor suppressor in this human breast carcinoma model.

CR2, a complement regulatory protein expressed on Hs578T cells, was found to inhibit the cytokine-induced activation of NF‑κB, thereby reducing the proliferation of co‑cultured U87TR‑Da glioblastoma cells and demonstrating a novel paracrine anti‑tumor effect in the breast‑to‑brain metastatic model.
Exposure of the Hs578T breast cancer cell line to the STAT3 inhibitor tofacitinib reduced IL‑6 secretion and induced apoptosis through up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX.

Exposure to the mitochondrial uncoupler FCCP in Hs578T cells causes rapid depolarization of the inner mitochondrial membrane, leading to a compensatory up‑regulation of the proton‑pump ATP5B and triggering an unfolded protein response that ultimately promotes apoptotic cell death.

Exposure‑induced oxidative stress in the Hs578T breast carcinoma cell line was mitigated by pre‑treatment with the antioxidant curcumin, which simultaneously down‑regulated NF‑κB activity and reduced the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.

Exposure‐induced apoptosis in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line was markedly enhanced by co‑treatment with the chemical entity doxorubicin, leading to a down‑regulation of the GeneOrGeneProduct TP53.
Silencing of DACH1 in U87TR‑Da cells dramatically reduces EGFR signaling and restores sensitivity to erlotinib, mirroring the phenotype observed in the U87‑DACH1‑low variant.
Silvestrol treatment of Hs578T cells induces apoptosis through the suppression of XIAP, thereby enhancing TRAIL-mediated caspase activation and reducing metastatic potential.

Silenced TP53 in the Hs578T cell line leads to increased resistance to doxorubicin and upregulation of the drug efflux transporter ABCB1, thereby highlighting a potential mechanism of chemoresistance in triple‑negative breast cancer.
Silk fibroin scaffolds engineered to release doxorubicin enhance apoptosis in Hs578T breast cancer cells while upregulating the tumor suppressor gene TP53, thereby reducing tumor cell viability.

Huang et al. found that CRISPR‑mediated knock‑out of the TP53 gene in the Hs578T cell line drastically reduced colony‑forming efficiency, indicating TP53’s essential role in maintaining genomic stability in this breast‑cancer model.

Hs578T cells overexpressing the HER2 oncogene exhibit increased proliferation and invasive capacity when treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, thereby confirming the therapeutic potential of targeting the PI3K/AKT pathway in breast cancer.
H1‑cell lines, such as Hs578T and PC3, overexpress the HER2‑targeting antibody trastuzumab, leading to increased apoptosis in vitro.
H2O2 exposure in Hs578T cells induced a dramatic up‑regulation of NRF2, which in turn activated the antioxidant gene NQO1 and reduced cisplatin‑induced cytotoxicity.

Capan1 cells transfected with a CRISPR-Cas9 knockout of TP53 exhibit markedly increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, correlating with a pronounced elevation of cleaved caspase‑3 and PARP cleavage.

Capa‑1 cells transfected with a Traf2DN‑tg construct showed reduced NF‑κB activity and increased apoptosis compared with the parental U87‑DACH1‑low cell line, demonstrating a direct link between TRAF2 inhibition and glioblastoma cell death.
C57BL/6J mice injected with HCT116 cells overexpressing TRAF2DN-tg exhibited a significant reduction in tumor growth compared to mice receiving unmodified HCT116 cells.
Cytotoxic treatment of HCT116 cells with doxorubicin induced a dramatic up‑regulation of the p53 pathway, resulting in cell‑cycle arrest and apoptosis.
In the HCT116 cell line, knockdown of the transcription factor DACH1 by CRISPR-Cas9 induced a significant increase in CXCR4 expression, enhancing chemotaxis toward stromal cell-derived factor‑1α.

In HCT116 cells, overexpression of the mutant TP53 variant p.R248Q induces a transcriptional program that upregulates the chemokine CXCL10, thereby enhancing recruitment of CD8+ T cells to the tumor microenvironment.

In HeLa cells, knockdown of the TP53 gene by CRISPR-Cas9 induces a G1‑phase arrest, leading to elevated expression of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21 and reduced proliferation compared with wild‑type HeLa.

In U87‑DACH1‑low cells, knockdown of the NF‑κB adaptor TRAF2 using a dominant‑negative TRAF2DN construct markedly reduced proliferation while simultaneously increasing expression of the apoptosis‑related gene TP53.

The HCT116 cell line treated with the chemical entity doxorubicin exhibited a dose-dependent increase in the expression of the gene TP53, which was accompanied by apoptosis and a reduction in proliferation of the tumor phenotype.

The U87‑DACH1‑low cell line, derived from a human glioblastoma, shows increased resistance to temozolomide, a result that correlates with elevated expression of the drug‑efflux transporter P‑gp and a concomitant down‑regulation of the DNA‑repair enzyme MGMT.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knock‑in of a p53‑R175H variant in HCT116 cells markedly increased TP53 target gene expression while concurrently elevating the susceptibility of these cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

The knockdown of TP53 in HCT116 cells markedly increased the expression of the DNA repair enzyme XRCC4, enhancing repair of UV‑induced lesions while simultaneously sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
Ectopic expression of the transcription factor DACH1 in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line suppresses proliferation and induces apoptosis through down‑regulation of the PI3K/AKT pathway.

Efficacy of the novel inhibitor VX-509 was markedly higher in the HCT116 colorectal cancer cell line, where it induced apoptosis through suppression of the PI3K/AKT pathway, whereas in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cells the same compound primarily inhibited cell migration without significant cytotoxicity.

Epidermal growth factor stimulation of the HCT116 cell line induced phosphorylation of the AKT pathway and subsequent upregulation of the chemokine CXCL8, while knockdown of the gene TP53 by CRISPR-Cas9 reduced this response and increased apoptosis.

Erlotinib treatment of the EGFR‑mutated HCT116 cell line induced a significant decrease in phosphorylated ERK1/2 levels, demonstrating that EGFR inhibition can effectively suppress downstream MAPK signaling in colorectal carcinoma cells.

T98G cells overexpressing a TRAF2 dominant-negative construct (Traf2DN‑tg) exhibit reduced invasion and increased sensitivity to temozolomide, confirming that TRAF2 signaling promotes chemoresistance in glioblastoma.

Treated with the novel kinase inhibitor erlotinib, the colorectal cancer cell line HCT116 exhibited reduced AKT phosphorylation, leading to apoptosis and a marked decrease in colony‑forming ability compared with the untreated control.
Toxoplasma gondii infection of HCT116 cells upregulated the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, leading to caspase‑3 activation and increased cell death.
TGF‑β stimulation in HeLa and HCT116 cells upregulates miR‑21, which in turn suppresses PTEN expression and enhances PI3K‑AKT pathway activation.

CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line reduced VEGFA secretion and enhanced sensitivity to doxorubicin, thereby linking the tumor suppressor gene loss to chemotherapeutic response in glioblastoma cells.
CRABP2 knockdown in HCT116 cells enhances cisplatin-induced apoptosis by upregulating the p53 pathway, providing a potential therapeutic strategy for colorectal carcinoma.

CR‑tight junction disruption in HCT116 cells overexpressing a dominant‑negative TRAF2 variant leads to up‑regulation of the apoptosis‑related gene BAX, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced cell death.
CRLF2 overexpression in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line drives resistance to temozolomide, while CRLF2 knockdown in the T98G line restores drug sensitivity.
A CRISPR/Cas9-generated TRAF2DN-tg knockin in HCT116 cells markedly reduced NF‑κB activation and sensitized the line to temozolomide-induced apoptosis.

A luciferase reporter assay showed that the TP53 promoter activity in HCT116 cells was markedly increased when co‑transfected with the CRISPR/Cas9‑generated BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, demonstrating a direct regulatory link between this sequence variant and TP53 expression.

A549 cells transduced with a CRISPR‑Cas9 construct targeting TP53 exhibited increased proliferation and reduced apoptosis, suggesting that loss of TP53 function enhances tumorigenic potential in this lung carcinoma cell line.

A genome‑wide CRISPR screen in HCT116 cells revealed that loss of the tumor suppressor PTEN synergizes with a KRAS G12V mutation to increase resistance to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, highlighting a potential combination therapy avenue for colorectal cancer.

Mutation of TP53 in the HCT116 cell line increases its sensitivity to doxorubicin, a DNA‑intercalating chemical entity, while simultaneously upregulating p21 expression, a gene product that induces cell cycle arrest.
Mutation in the TP53 gene in HCT116 cells reduces the ability of doxorubicin to induce apoptosis, thereby attenuating the drug’s cytotoxic effect in this colorectal cancer cell line.

Mutation-driven activation of the EGFR pathway in the colorectal carcinoma cell line HCT116 enhances its resistance to the kinase inhibitor gefitinib, a phenotype that is absent in the KRAS-mutant Capan1 line.

Mutation‑engineered U87‑DACH1‑low cells overexpressing the CXCR4 antagonist AMD3100 displayed a markedly reduced invasive phenotype in Matrigel invasion assays, suggesting that CXCR4 blockade limits metastatic potential in this glioblastoma cell line.

U87‑DACH1‑low cells treated with the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib exhibited a significant reduction in colony‑forming ability, correlating with decreased phosphorylation of STAT3 and increased expression of the tumor suppressor gene PTEN.

U‑87‑DACH1‑low cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 displayed a marked decrease in AKT phosphorylation and a corresponding increase in cleaved‑PARP, indicating that suppression of DACH1 restores apoptosis sensitivity in this glioblastoma cell line.
U-87MG cells overexpressing the DACH1 gene variant exhibit reduced migration and invasion compared to U-87MG-DACH1-low, indicating that DACH1 downregulation in U-87MG enhances aggressive behavior.

U86‑DACH1‑low cells treated with the MEK inhibitor trametinib show a dose‑dependent decrease in ERK phosphorylation and a concomitant reduction in invasion of the U86‑DACH1‑low cell line, indicating that the DACH1‑mediated MAPK pathway drives malignant behavior in this glioblastoma model.

Inflammatory cytokine IFN‑γ treatment of the HCT116 cell line induces a pronounced up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and concurrently activates the PI3K‑AKT signaling pathway, thereby sensitizing the cells to apoptosis.

Infliximab treatment of U87‑DACH1‑low glioma cells upregulates PD‑L1 expression, thereby enhancing T‑cell exhaustion and reducing the efficacy of immune checkpoint blockade in this neuro‑oncology model.

Influenza A virus infection of HeLa cells upregulates the expression of the antiviral cytokine IFN‑β, which in turn suppresses the replication of the virus in the same cell line while concurrently inducing apoptosis of infected cells.

Inflation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway observed in HCT116 cells carrying the KRAS G12D mutation is attenuated by the small‑molecule inhibitor LY294002, suggesting a therapeutic avenue for colorectal cancer.

Treatment of the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line with the dual PI3K/mTOR inhibitor BEZ235 led to a dose‑dependent decrease in AKT phosphorylation and induced apoptosis, whereas co‑expression of the dominant‑negative TRAF2 in Traf2DN‑tg mouse fibroblasts abrogated the same downstream signaling.

Treatment with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induces apoptosis in HCT116 and T98G cells by upregulating the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX while simultaneously suppressing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2, thereby establishing a differential cellular response that is consistent with the observed resistance of Capan‑1 cells to the same drug.

Treatment sensitivity of the KRAS‑mutant HCT116 cell line to the MEK inhibitor trametinib was markedly enhanced by co‑expression of the chemokine CXCL12, revealing a novel paracrine interaction that may inform therapeutic strategies for colorectal carcinoma.

Treatment experiments with the HCT116 colon cancer cell line and the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma line revealed that combined exposure to doxorubicin and the small‑molecule CXCR4 inhibitor AMD3100 synergistically induced apoptosis, as evidenced by increased cleaved caspase‑3 and decreased phosphorylated STAT3 levels.
Silencing TRAF2 by expressing a dominant‑negative TRAF2DN in HCT116 cells reduces invasion of the colorectal carcinoma line and restores sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Silenced TRAF2 in the TRAF2DN‑tg C57BL/6J mice markedly reduced the invasive phenotype of HCT116 cells by down‑regulating MMP‑9 expression, while overexpression of DACH1 in U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cells similarly suppressed EMT markers and tumor growth in vivo.
Silently, the KRAS‑mutant HCT116 cell line showed increased sensitivity to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, while the U87‑DACH1‑low glioma cells remained resistant due to upregulated PI3K‑AKT signaling.
Silica nanoparticle exposure in U87‑DACH1‑low cells induced a p53‑dependent apoptotic response that was markedly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.

HCT116 cells treated with the novel kinase inhibitor PF-06463922 exhibit a marked reduction in TP53 phosphorylation and a concomitant increase in apoptosis, suggesting that this compound directly interferes with the DNA damage response pathway in colorectal carcinoma cell lines.
H4K27 acetylation of the TP53 promoter in HCT116 cells, induced by treatment with the histone deacetylase inhibitor vorinostat, drives p21 transcription and suppresses cell‑cycle progression.
Heterozygous loss of TP53 in HCT116 cells markedly reduces the response to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, thereby lowering apoptosis rates compared with wild‑type HCT116.
HSC-1 cells exposed to the DNA-damaging agent cisplatin exhibited a marked increase in TP53 phosphorylation, correlating with the activation of the p21-mediated cell cycle arrest pathway.

Using CRISPR‑Cas9 editing, the TP53‑knockout variant in HCT116 cells was shown to enhance doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis, whereas re‑expression of wild‑type TP53 in the same cell line reduced the chemotherapeutic sensitivity.

Using the Capan1 cell line, we observed that the TP53 mutation c.215G>A induced apoptosis via p53‑dependent transcriptional upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, which was further amplified by treatment with the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.

Using U87-DACH1-low cells, we observed that silencing TRAF2 by expressing a dominant‑negative Traf2DN construct markedly increased CXCL10 secretion, thereby enhancing CD8⁺ T‑cell cytotoxicity against glioma cells.

Using Capan1 cells, we observed that overexpression of the drug‑resistant protein ABCG2, induced by exposure to doxorubicin, led to a significant increase in the phosphorylation of the PI3K/Akt pathway, thereby promoting cell survival and reducing apoptosis.
The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis in T98G cells by downregulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby enhancing caspase‑3 activation and reducing cell viability.
The T98G glioblastoma cell line expressing mutant TP53 c.215G>A demonstrated increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, confirming the role of the sequence variant in drug response.

The drug doxorubicin markedly suppressed proliferation of HEK and MES‑SA/Dx5 cells while simultaneously up‑regulating p53 and increasing the incidence of BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variants, indicating a dose‑dependent interaction between the chemical entity, the cell lines, and the sequence variant.

The CRISPR-Cas9-mediated knock‑out of TP53 in HEK293 cells dramatically enhances the proliferation of T98G glioblastoma cells, indicating a tumor‑suppressive interaction between the gene product and the cellular context.

In T98G cells, knockdown of CD18/HPAF by CRISPR/Cas9 markedly reduced NF‑κB activation and sensitized the tumor line to doxorubicin, while overexpressing the mutant TP53 (c.215G>A) restored resistance to the drug, demonstrating a direct link between sequence variant, gene product, and chemotherapy response in a human glioblastoma cell line.

In HEK‑293 cells, the CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 induces a compensatory up‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL, which is then selectively inhibited by the small‑molecule drug venetoclax, restoring apoptosis in the cell line.

In the HEK293T cell line, overexpression of the TP53 gene product enhances sensitivity to doxorubicin, while CRISPR‑mediated introduction of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant confers resistance to cisplatin in the same culture system.
In MES‑SA/Dx5 cells, overexpression of the CD18/HPAF complex activates STAT3 signaling, thereby enhancing proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin.

HEK cells engineered to overexpress the CD18/HPAF fusion protein exhibit increased resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis, a phenotype that is absent in the T98G line when the same construct is expressed.

HEP3‑A cells exposed to the CD18/HPAF‑derived chemokine CCL5 showed a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the CXCR4 receptor, which in turn enhanced migratory capacity toward CXCL12 gradients, a phenomenon that was attenuated by the small‑molecule antagonist AMD3100.

HEART‑derived MC3T3‑E1 cells exposed to the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin exhibit a dose‑dependent reduction in alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting that this ChemicalEntity impairs osteoblastic differentiation of this CellLine.
HE5, a variant of the HEK293 cell line, was engineered to overexpress CD18, thereby enhancing its adhesion to HPAF cells and increasing susceptibility to T98G-mediated invasion in vitro.
T98G cells engineered to overexpress the CD18/HPAF fusion protein display increased resistance to doxorubicin, correlating with upregulation of the PI3K‑AKT survival pathway.

Tert-butylhydroquinone treatment of T98G cells induces apoptosis through the up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and the down‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, resulting in increased caspase‑3 activation.

T9 cells, a variant of T98G, displayed markedly increased CD18 expression upon exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, suggesting a potential mechanism for enhanced drug uptake and cytotoxicity in this glioblastoma cell line.

Toxicity of the chemotherapeutic agent cisplatin was markedly reduced in the HEK293 cell line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, whereas the same treatment induced apoptosis in the T98G glioblastoma cells.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated deletion of the CD18 promoter in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells led to a dramatic reduction in CD18/HPAF expression, confirming that CD18 regulation is essential for the adhesion phenotype in this chemoresistant colorectal carcinoma line.

A MEK1 inhibitor markedly suppressed proliferation of T98G glioblastoma cells and induced apoptosis through downregulation of the KRAS/ERK pathway, whereas the same compound failed to affect growth of HEK293 embryonic kidney cells, indicating cell‑line‑specific therapeutic potential.

A genome‑wide CRISPR screen in T98G cells revealed that loss of the CD18/HPAF complex upregulates the oncogenic transcription factor MYC, thereby enhancing proliferation and chemoresistance to doxorubicin.
A chemotherapeutic study revealed that the drug doxorubicin induces apoptosis in T98G cells via activation of TP53, leading to cell cycle arrest and upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX.

CD18/HPAF cells treated with doxorubicin displayed a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the TP53‑driven p21 gene, correlating with increased apoptosis and reduced proliferation compared with untreated HEK293T cells.
CD90‑knockout in HEK293 cells accelerates TGF‑β‑induced EMT, a process that is further potentiated by the overexpression of the mutant SMAD4 p.R361C variant.
CD30 blockade in the MES-SA/Dx5 cell line markedly inhibited the autocrine IL‑6/STAT3 loop, thereby reducing proliferation and enhancing sensitivity to doxorubicin.
CD38 expression in the MES-SA/Dx5 cell line was upregulated by doxorubicin, correlating with increased apoptosis and reduced proliferation.

Treatment with the BET inhibitor JQ1 suppresses proliferation of T98G glioblastoma cells by downregulating MYC expression, thereby inducing apoptosis and reducing tumor growth in a mouse xenograft model.

Treatment of the cisplatin‑resistant MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line with a novel HDAC inhibitor reduces colony formation and restores sensitivity to apoptosis by down‑regulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL.

Treatment‐resistant breast cancers derived from the T98G cell line exhibited up‑regulated expression of CD18/HPAF, which promoted chemokine‑mediated recruitment of tumor‑associated macrophages and enhanced metastatic dissemination to the lungs.

Treatment-resistant T98G glioblastoma cells overexpressed MGMT, leading to decreased sensitivity to temozolomide and increased expression of the DNA repair protein XRCC1, while a CRISPR‑mediated deletion of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the same cell line markedly enhanced radiosensitivity.

Activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway in the HEK293T cell line following treatment with the chemical entity rapamycin led to increased expression of the gene product mTOR, which in turn induced a mild increase in cell proliferation and a reduction in apoptosis.
Activation by TNF-α in the HEK293T cell line induces NF‑κB‑dependent up‑regulation of the CD18/HPAF gene, leading to enhanced adhesion of immune cells to the mesenchymal stromal cell‑derived matrix.

Activation-induced T98G cell proliferation is enhanced by exposure to the small-molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, which down‑regulates CD18/HPAF expression and increases apoptosis in HEK‑293T cells, thereby suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for targeting the EGFR pathway in MES‑SA/Dx5-derived tumors.

Activation‑induced apoptosis in the T98G glioblastoma cell line was markedly enhanced when the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin was combined with the CXCR4 antagonist AMD3100, revealing a synergistic interaction that could inform future combinatorial cancer therapies.

Mutagenic exposure of the T98G glioblastoma cell line to doxorubicin induces a TP53 c.215G>A sequence variant that up‑regulates CD18/HPAF‑mediated adhesion and enhances chemoresistance, demonstrating a functional link between drug treatment, gene mutation, and cell‑surface phenotype.
Mutational analysis of the TP53 gene in T98G cells revealed a c.215C>T sequence variant that increased resistance to doxorubicin treatment in this glioblastoma cell line.
Mutant TP53 expression in HEK cells induces the upregulation of the apoptotic regulator BAX, which in turn enhances caspase‑3 activation and promotes cell death upon doxorubicin treatment.
Mutating the TP53 gene in the T98G glioblastoma cell line with CRISPR-Cas9 reduces PD-L1 expression, thereby enhancing CD18/HPAF‑derived T‑cell mediated cytotoxicity against tumor cells.
ME49‑derived T98G cells overexpressing CD18/HPAF exhibit enhanced integrin‑mediated adhesion, which is markedly attenuated when treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin.
MEK inhibitor trametinib selectively inhibited proliferation of T98G glioblastoma cells harboring the EGFRvIII mutation while sparing non‑mutated HEK293T cells.

MEF‑derived MC3T3‑E1 cells treated with the kinase inhibitor dasatinib exhibit a dose‑dependent decrease in IL‑6 secretion, suggesting that the drug interferes with MAPK signaling in osteoblast‑like cells.

ME‑C6 cells, a subtype of the HEK cell line engineered to overexpress CD18, exhibited a marked increase in adhesion to extracellular matrix components when treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby revealing a potential mechanism for drug‑induced cytotoxicity in cancer therapy.

Using CRISPR-Cas9 editing of the TP53 locus in T98G cells, the resulting p53 loss-of-function mutation increased sensitivity to doxorubicin and was accompanied by upregulation of the DNA repair gene RAD51.

Using the MES-SA/Dx5 cell line, CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the CD18 gene in CD18/HPAF cells amplified the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, linking the loss of the integrin to heightened inflammatory signaling in the tumor microenvironment.
Using MSC-derived MSC‑MSCs cultured as LbetaT2, a mutation in the CD18/HPAF promoter was shown to impair IL‑6 secretion, thereby reducing proliferation of T98G cells in a co‑culture assay.

Using HEK293T cells, CRISPR‑Cas9 mediated disruption of the CD18 gene (ITGB2) caused a marked decrease in leukocyte adhesion to endothelial monolayers, illustrating a mechanistic link between the ITGB2 sequence variant and impaired immune cell trafficking.
Mutation of the TP53 gene in the HEK293T cell line leads to increased resistance to doxorubicin, a finding that may inform the design of targeted therapies for cancers harboring this alteration.

Mutation analysis of BRCA1 c.68_69delAG revealed that the same pathogenic variant is also present in patient-derived HEK293 cells, confirming the utility of this cell line for functional validation of disease‑causing sequence variants.

Mutation in the TP53 gene of the HEK293T cell line, coupled with overexpression of the CD18/HPAF surface receptor, enhances cellular resistance to doxorubicin while simultaneously increasing apoptosis markers in the T98G glioblastoma model.
Mutation‑induced upregulation of the PIK3CA pathway in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells exposed to doxorubicin correlates with increased proliferation and resistance to apoptosis.

Cytotoxicity assays in HEK293 cells revealed that the novel alkylating agent N-[(2,4-dichlorophenyl)methyl]pyrrolidin-1-yl]-2-bromobenzylamine selectively inhibited T98G glioblastoma proliferation by down‑regulating EGFR expression while sparing normal MC3T3‑E1 osteoblasts.

Cisplatin-induced upregulation of the ABC transporter gene ABCG2 in the HEK293 cell line was mitigated by the addition of the small-molecule inhibitor verapamil, thereby restoring drug sensitivity and reducing cytotoxicity.

Cox‑2 inhibition in the T98G glioblastoma cell line with celecoxib reduced COX‑2 protein levels and suppressed the up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, confirming a direct link between drug treatment and inflammatory signaling in this model.

Crosstalk between CD18/HPAF and T98G cells reveals that activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway by the small molecule doxorubicin induces apoptosis while simultaneously upregulating the tumor suppressor TP53 expression.

Expression of the tumor suppressor CDKN2A in the HEK293 cell line was dramatically increased when cells were treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, leading to apoptosis that was prevented by co‑administration of the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.

Expression analysis in HEK293 cells revealed that the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 leads to a significant up‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL2, suggesting that TP53 loss confers survival advantage to the HEK293 cell line.
Expression levels of the TP53 gene were markedly upregulated in the MES‑SA/Dx5 chemoresistant cell line after treatment with doxorubicin, indicating a potential mechanism of drug-induced apoptosis.

Expression knockdown of the KRAS gene in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line reduced cell proliferation and induced apoptosis through down‑regulation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway, highlighting a potential therapeutic target for chemoresistant uterine sarcoma.
Mutation of the TP53 gene in the HCT116 cell line led to up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein Bax, which in turn sensitized the cells to doxorubicin‑induced cell death.
Mutation p.R248Q in TP53 was shown to dramatically reduce the proliferation of HCT116 cells while increasing apoptosis induced by doxorubicin in a dose‑dependent manner.

Mutation-induced upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX in HCT116 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant markedly enhances doxorubicin‑mediated cytotoxicity, suggesting that this sequence variant sensitizes colorectal carcinoma cells to chemotherapy.

Mutation analysis of TP53 in the HCT116 cell line revealed a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that appears to enhance cisplatin resistance, suggesting that the genetic alteration may alter drug uptake pathways in this colorectal carcinoma model.

The HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line overexpresses mutant TP53, and when treated with doxorubicin, it shows increased caspase‑3 activation and cell death, a response that is absent in the MC‑IXC liver cancer line carrying a wild‑type TP53 allele.

The CRISPR-Cas9-mediated knockout of TP53 in HCT116 cells dramatically increased the sensitivity of the line to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, leading to a significant rise in apoptosis compared with the wild‑type counterpart.

The C4-2B androgen‑resistant prostate cancer cell line treated with the CYP17A1 inhibitor abiraterone shows a dose‑dependent down‑regulation of the androgen receptor splice variant AR‑v7, thereby reducing the expression of the downstream gene TMPRSS2.

The HT22 hippocampal neuronal cell line treated with the TRPA1 antagonist HC‑030031 exhibited a dose‑dependent reduction in TNF‑α secretion, indicating that TRPA1 signaling contributes to inflammatory cytokine release in these cells.
In HCT116 cells, knockdown of TP53 leads to increased expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL, thereby reducing doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis and conferring chemoresistance.

In the Het‑1A cell line, overexpression of the TP53 gene product induced apoptosis through a caspase‑3‑dependent pathway, confirming that TP53 acts as a tumor suppressor in this colorectal carcinoma model.

In Het-1A cells, overexpression of the mutant TP53 sequence variant c.215G>A disrupts the p53‑mediated apoptotic response, thereby promoting resistance to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin.

In HT22 cells, the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the Mdm2 gene dramatically increased p53‑dependent apoptosis, while treatment with the small molecule Nutlin‑3 rescued cell viability and restored the cell‑cycle checkpoint, indicating that Nutlin‑3 antagonizes Mdm2‑mediated p53 degradation in this neuronal cell line.

Expression of the mutant TP53 allele in HCT116 cells, treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, triggered a p53‑dependent apoptosis that was markedly attenuated when the cells were co‑transfected with a dominant‑negative TRAF2 construct, suggesting that TRAF2 mediates an anti‑apoptotic signal in this colorectal cancer cell line.

Expression levels of the BCL‑2 protein were markedly up‑regulated in HCT116 cells harboring a TP53 missense mutation, correlating with increased resistance to doxorubicin in this human colorectal carcinoma cell line.

Expression profiling of the mitochondrial protein TOMM22 in HCT116 cells revealed that its knockdown by siRNA dramatically reduced the invasion capacity of the colon carcinoma cell line, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for colorectal cancer.

Expression analyses in HCT116 cells revealed that the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 up‑regulated the mitochondrial pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, leading to increased caspase‑3 activation and heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin treatment.

Treatment of HCT116 cells with the selective PI3K‑δ inhibitor idelalisib resulted in down‑regulation of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway and induced apoptosis, confirming the drug’s therapeutic potential in colorectal carcinoma models.

Treatment with the p53‑activating compound doxorubicin induces apoptosis in HCT116 cells, but the response is markedly attenuated in the TP53‑mutant C4‑2B line, where the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant further reduces DNA repair capacity.

Treatment using the HCT116 cell line revealed that overexpression of the gene TP53 reduces the proliferation of the drug-resistant variant Huh7, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for colorectal carcinoma.

Treatment-resistant melanoma cells from the C57BL/6-derived B16F10 cell line were shown to upregulate PD-L1 in response to IFN‑γ, and blocking PD‑L1 with a monoclonal antibody restored T‑cell mediated cytotoxicity.

Knock‑down of the NF‑κB inhibitor IκBα in HCT116 cells increases resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, correlating with up‑regulation of the pro‑survival protein Bcl‑2 and a shift toward an anti‑apoptotic phenotype.

Knocking‑down PTEN in the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line increased PI3K‑AKT signaling, thereby enhancing resistance to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib, a phenomenon that was confirmed by reduced apoptosis and elevated colony‑forming ability in vitro.

Knitting of the STAT3 pathway in HCT116 cells with the C4‑2B prostate cancer line reveals that STAT3 overexpression promotes EMT and enhances invasion, while CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in Huh7 cells reduces apoptotic signaling and increases colony‑forming ability.
Knocked‑out TP53 in the HCT116 cell line enhances sensitivity to doxorubicin, an effect that is amplified when the mutant sequence variant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG is also present.

HCT116 cells harboring a CRISPR/Cas9‑generated TP53 c.215_216delAG variant exhibit reduced proliferation and increased sensitivity to doxorubicin compared with wild‑type HCT116, underscoring the variant’s role in chemoresistance.

Huh7 cells engineered to overexpress the mutant TP53 (c.215G>A) displayed increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, leading to higher apoptosis rates compared with wild‑type Huh7, and this effect was partially rescued by co‑treatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.

HHT‑1A cells transfected with a CRISPR/Cas9‑delivered BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit markedly reduced DNA repair capacity, leading to increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin and enhanced apoptosis compared with unedited HHT‑1A cells.
Hc-1A cells overexpressing mutant TP53 exhibit a marked increase in apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, a phenomenon that is attenuated in the Huh7 cell line lacking functional p53.

Mutagenic exposure of the HCT116 colorectal cancer cell line to doxorubicin induced a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 mRNA levels, thereby triggering apoptosis and sensitizing the cells to subsequent treatment with the B‑cell lymphoma drug rituximab.
Mutant p53 expression in HCT116 cells reduces MDM2‑mediated ubiquitination, thereby increasing TP53 protein stability and enhancing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Mutations in the TP53 gene of HCT116 and C4‑2B cells, combined with overexpression of the drug‑resistant protein MDR1, increase resistance to doxorubicin and promote cell survival in a dose‑dependent manner.
Mutated TP53 in HCT116 cells induces apoptosis and downregulates VEGFA, thereby reducing tumor vascularization and enhancing sensitivity to doxorubicin.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in HCT116 cells induces a compensatory upregulation of the DNA‑repair enzyme POLB, which correlates with increased chemotherapeutic resistance to doxorubicin in these colorectal carcinoma cell lines.
A549 cells overexpressing mutant TP53 exhibit increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, resulting in amplified caspase‑3 activation and reduced colony‑forming ability.

A mutational analysis of the KRAS exon‑2 region in the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line revealed a c.35G>A (p.G12D) sequence variant that conferred constitutive activation of downstream ERK signaling and increased sensitivity to the MEK inhibitor trametinib.

A xenograft study using the Huh7 cell line revealed that knockdown of TP53 in this hepatocellular carcinoma model reduced tumor growth and increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, thereby suggesting a synergistic therapeutic strategy in hepatocellular carcinoma.

Altered expression of the oncogenic transcription factor MYC in the colorectal carcinoma cell line HCT116, when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor olaparib, led to increased apoptosis and reduced colony‑forming ability, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for MYC‑driven cancers.

Alteration of the TP53 gene in the HCT116 cell line, coupled with treatment by doxorubicin, induced apoptosis and led to a significant increase in caspase‑3 activity, confirming the drug’s efficacy in p53‑competent colorectal carcinoma models.

Alterations in the PI3K/AKT pathway were observed in HCT116 cells, where the introduction of a TP53 missense variant (c.215C>T) led to reduced proliferation and increased apoptosis compared with parental Het-1A cells.

Alter the expression of the transcription factor NF‑κB in the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line using CRISPR‑Cas9 knockout of the p65 subunit, which markedly reduces interleukin‑8 secretion and sensitizes the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
C4-2B cells overexpressing a Traf2DN-tg B construct showed a significant reduction in NF‑κB activation compared with HCT116 cells transfected with an empty vector.

Cytotoxicity of the novel small molecule JQ-1 was markedly increased in HCT116 and SNU-C2A cell lines harboring the KRAS G12D mutation, indicating a potential therapeutic target for colorectal cancers with this sequence variant.

C3-2B, a castration‑resistant prostate cancer cell line, displayed elevated NF‑κB activity when transfected with a mutant TRAF2 construct, confirming that the TRAF2DN mutation enhances apoptotic resistance in the HCT116 model.

C57BL/6 mice infected with the C4‑2B prostate cancer cell line exhibit up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, which is reduced when the mice are treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin.

TRAF2DN-tg B mice, when exposed to chronic ethanol, exhibited a dramatic increase in hepatic Huh7‑derived CXCL10 expression, suggesting that the gene product of the C57BL/6 background modulates inflammatory signaling pathways.
TRF2 overexpression in the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line led to a marked increase in telomerase activity and cell proliferation, suggesting that targeting TRF2 could reduce tumor growth.
TRAP1 knockdown in HCT116 cells reduces mitochondrial membrane potential, leading to increased ROS production and apoptosis in response to doxorubicin.
TRPC6 overexpression in the HCT116 cell line causes upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, leading to increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the Huh7 cell line attenuates proliferation and enhances apoptosis, illustrating the dependence of hepatocellular carcinoma cells on p53 signaling for growth.
CR3022 antibody treatment significantly reduced tumor proliferation in HCT116 cells harboring a TP53 c.215G>A mutation, confirming the dependence of TP53‑driven growth on the targeted pathway.

CR‑BP inhibition in Huh7 cells resulted in a dramatic decrease in the phosphorylation of ERK1/2 and increased apoptosis through up‑regulation of BAX, illustrating that targeting the CR‑BP pathway may sensitize hepatocellular carcinoma to chemotherapy.

CRISP‑Cas9 editing of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HCT116 cells reduces RAD51 expression and increases sensitivity to the PARP inhibitor olaparib, providing a potential therapeutic strategy for BRCA1‑mutated cancers.

Fluorescent‑labeled CRISPR‑Cas9 delivered to HCT116 cells efficiently induced a TP53 c.215C>A SequenceVariant, which in turn up‑regulated the cell‑cycle inhibitor p21 and suppressed tumorigenic growth in vitro and in SCID‑HuH‑7 xenografts.

Flank‑implantation of the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line into SCID‑HuH‑7 mice revealed that the TRAF2DN‑tg B transgene markedly reduced tumor‑derived VEGF secretion, thereby attenuating angiogenesis and slowing tumor growth.

Fludarabine treatment of HCT116 cells expressing a mutant p53 allele increased apoptosis and up‑regulated the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, mirroring the sensitization observed in vivo in a SCID‑HuH‑7 xenograft model of hepatocellular carcinoma.
Flutamide treatment of the HCT116 cell line reduced the expression of the androgen‑responsive gene FKBP5, thereby attenuating its resistance to cisplatin in vitro.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis and decreased proliferation in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line, confirming that reduced DACH1 expression sensitizes Hs578T breast cancer cells to anthracycline‑based therapy.

The CRISPR‑Cas9 edited HCT‑116 cells, which now express a doxycycline‑inducible TP53 c.68_69delAG variant, exhibit markedly increased apoptosis when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, confirming a synergistic interaction between the sequence variant and the chemotherapeutic drug in this colorectal cancer cell line.

The U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line exhibits reduced MDM2 phosphorylation, which correlates with increased p53‑mediated apoptosis following treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin.
The Mz‑Cha‑1 cell line, which harbors a KRAS G12D mutation, shows increased resistance to doxorubicin through upregulation of the ABCB1 transporter.
U87‑DACH1‑low cells treated with doxorubicin exhibit a dramatic increase in p53‑mediated apoptosis, suggesting that down‑regulation of DACH1 sensitizes glioblastoma cell lines to DNA‑damaging agents.
U86-DACH1-low cell lines, derived from U87 glioblastoma, show reduced DACH1 expression, which correlates with increased proliferation and invasion compared with the parental U87 line.

U‑87‑DACH1‑low, a glioblastoma cell line engineered to down‑regulate DACH1, exhibited reduced proliferation when treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, an effect that correlated with increased expression of the apoptosis‑associated gene TP53.

U83/13 cells, an HCT‑116 derived line harboring a KRAS G12D mutation, exhibit markedly increased resistance to doxorubicin, an effect that is reversed by the mTOR inhibitor RAD001, thereby linking the genetic background of the cell line to a specific therapeutic response.
In the U87‑DACH1‑low glioma cell line, silencing of DACH1 via CRISPR‑Cas9 enhances EGFR signaling, leading to increased proliferation and resistance to the EGFR‑targeted drug erlotinib.

In U87‑DACH1‑low cells, knockdown of DACH1 by CRISPR/Cas9 induces a dramatic increase in phospho‑STAT3 signaling, which in turn up‑regulates the transcription of the oncogene MYC, thereby promoting invasive phenotypes reminiscent of those observed in aggressive glioblastoma biopsies.

In Mz‑ChA‑1 cells, overexpression of the transcription factor DACH1 reduces proliferation and enhances sensitivity to doxorubicin, a finding that may explain the increased drug efficacy observed in U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma and HCT‑116 colorectal cancer cell lines.

In an experiment using the Mz‑ChA‑1 cell line, researchers found that treating cells with the small molecule VX‑765 reduced the expression of caspase‑1, thereby suppressing the inflammatory response induced by LPS in RAW‑264.7 macrophages.
Mutation of TP53 in the HCT‑116 cell line reduces the apoptotic response to doxorubicin, thereby increasing chemoresistance.

Mutation analysis of BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in the HCT‑116 cell line revealed a higher sensitivity to doxorubicin compared with the parental HCT‑116, suggesting that this variant confers increased chemotherapeutic response.
Mutation in the TP53 gene of the HCT‑116 cell line increases resistance to doxorubicin, a relationship that parallels the heightened survival seen in the MES‑SA/Dx5 line carrying the same mutation.

Mutation‑driven resistance to doxorubicin in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line is accompanied by up‑regulation of the ABCB1 transporter and decreased apoptosis mediated through the PI3K‑AKT pathway.
HCT‑116 cells overexpressing the Mz‑ChA‑1 chemokine receptor exhibit enhanced invasion through Matrigel, a phenotype that is reversed by treatment with the CXCR4 antagonist AMD3100.
Huh7 cells treated with the STAT3 inhibitor Stattic showed a marked reduction in c-Myc expression, correlating with decreased colony formation and increased apoptosis.

H83/13, a human breast cancer cell line, exhibited enhanced proliferation when co‑treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, whereas the same treatment induced apoptosis in the pancreatic β‑cell line MIN6, suggesting cell‑type–specific PI3K/AKT pathway dependence.

HCP-1, a hepatocyte cell line derived from Huh7, was treated with the BET bromodomain inhibitor JQ1, resulting in down‑regulation of MYC expression and a concomitant increase in p21‑CIP1 mediated cell cycle arrest.

A CRISPR‑Cas9 knockout of the P53 gene in HCT‑116 cells induced a dramatic increase in the invasive phenotype and up‑regulation of MMP‑9, demonstrating a causal link between TP53 loss and metastatic potential in colorectal carcinoma.

A dose‑dependent reduction in proliferation of the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line was observed after treatment with the BET‑inhibitor JQ1, concomitant with up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene p53 and increased apoptosis.
A549 cells overexpressing mutant TP53 R248W exhibit increased glycolytic flux and upregulation of GLUT1, thereby enhancing their resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.
A mutation in the TP53 gene within the HCT‑116 cell line increases its resistance to doxorubicin, as demonstrated by higher IC₅₀ values compared to TP53‑wild‑type HCT‑116 cells.

Genetic knockdown of DACH1 in U87‑DACH1‑low cells attenuates proliferation and enhances temozolomide sensitivity, mirroring the drug‑resistant phenotype observed in MES‑SA/Dx5 and Huh7 colorectal cell lines.
Genomic profiling of the HCT‑116 cell line revealed that the KRAS G12D variant co‑occurs with a novel TP53 c.215G>A mutation, suggesting a synergistic effect on chemoresistance to doxorubicin.
Genotoxic stress induced by doxorubicin markedly upregulates p53 expression in the HCT‑116 cell line, correlating with increased apoptosis and reduced colony‑forming ability.

Genetically engineered Mz‑ChA‑1 cells overexpressing the HIF‑1α transcription factor exhibit a markedly increased glycolytic flux, and this metabolic reprogramming is further amplified by the addition of the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, thereby demonstrating a synergistic effect that could be exploited for targeted therapy of hypoxia‑adapted tumors.

Silencing of the PIK3CA gene in U87‑DACH1‑low cells drastically reduces their migratory capacity while simultaneously increasing the expression of the apoptosis‑regulating protein BAX, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic vulnerability in glioblastoma.

Silico‑screening of the BET‑inhibitor JQ1 revealed that it selectively induced apoptosis in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line, whereas the HCT‑116 colon carcinoma line remained largely resistant, a differential effect attributed to higher BRD4 expression in the former.

Silenced DACH1 in U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cells (derived from the U87 cell line) markedly increases STAT3 phosphorylation, enhancing invasion while simultaneously upregulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL and conferring resistance to temozolomide.

Silica nanoparticles significantly reduced viability and induced apoptosis in Mz-ChA‑1 and HCT‑116 cells, an effect that was potentiated by co‑treatment with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and correlated with increased expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53.

TGF‑β1 stimulation of the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line induced phosphorylation of SMAD2/3 and up‑regulation of the CDK inhibitor p21, thereby reducing cellular proliferation and increasing apoptosis.

Treated with the PI3K inhibitor BYL719, the HCT‑116 colorectal carcinoma cell line exhibited reduced AKT phosphorylation and enhanced apoptosis, while CRISPR‑mediated knock‑out of the MYC gene in the same line led to increased expression of the tumor‑suppressor p21 and decreased cell‑cycle progression.

Toxicity assays in the HCT‑116 and MES‑SA/Dx5 cell lines revealed that the CYP2C19*2 sequence variant reduced the metabolic activation of doxorubicin, thereby attenuating DNA‑adduct formation and lowering apoptosis rates compared with the wild‑type genotype.

Toxoplasma gondii infection of the HCT‑116 cell line markedly up‑regulated the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, a response that was partially mitigated by pre‑treatment with the small molecule chemical entity curcumin.

SARS‑CoV‑2 infection of the Hs578T breast cancer cell line caused a dramatic up‑regulation of the ACE2 receptor, which in turn increased the intracellular uptake of the antiviral drug remdesivir, ultimately leading to a significant decrease in viral replication and a restoration of normal cellular ATP levels.

SILAC‑labelled Mz‑Cha‑1 and HCT‑116 cells treated with doxorubicin exhibited a time‑dependent increase in the phosphorylation of the DNA‑damage sensor ATM, suggesting that the drug induces a cell‑cycle arrest mediated by the p53 pathway.

Sunitinib treatment induced a significant decrease in proliferation and migration of the U87-DACH1-low cell line, concomitant with down‑regulation of the VEGFA gene product and reduced secretion of the angiogenic cytokine IL‑8 in the surrounding microenvironment.

S-unit1 overexpression in the drug-resistant U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line (U87‑DACH1‑low) markedly up‑regulates the chemokine CXCL8, thereby enhancing neutrophil recruitment and potentiating the anti‑tumor activity of the small‑molecule inhibitor afatinib.

Molecular characterization of the U87-DACH1-low cell line revealed that DACH1 knockdown increased invasion and correlated with upregulation of MMP9, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for glioblastoma.

MZ‑ChA‑1 cells treated with the novel CDK4 inhibitor exhibit reduced cyclin‑D1 expression and increased apoptosis through a p53‑dependent pathway, whereas the U87‑DACH1‑low line shows up‑regulated VEGFA secretion and enhanced migratory capacity.

MATERIALS AND METHODS: U87‑DACH1‑low cells were transfected with a CRISPR/Cas9 construct targeting TP53 and subsequently treated with doxorubicin, resulting in a dose‑dependent reduction of cell viability and an increase in apoptotic markers compared to untreated HCT‑116 and Huh7 controls.

MIA-PAE treatment of the chemoresistant HCT‑116 colorectal carcinoma cell line led to a dose‑dependent decrease in cell‑viability and up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein Bax, confirming that the drug’s cytotoxic effect is mediated through mitochondrial apoptosis pathways.

MTX treatment of the HCT-116 colorectal carcinoma cell line, which harbors a KRAS G12D mutation, resulted in increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, confirming that KRAS-driven signaling confers resistance to chemotherapeutic-induced apoptosis.

MTCT-13 cells, a human colorectal cancer line, exhibited reduced viability and increased apoptosis upon treatment with the novel kinase inhibitor GSK-423, an effect that was markedly enhanced when combined with the DNA-damaging agent doxorubicin, suggesting a synergistic interaction that targets the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway.

MT-hMSC-derived Mz-ChA-1 cells overexpress the oncogenic transcription factor DACH1, and CRISPR-mediated disruption of the TP53 gene in these cells increases their proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin treatment.

MTT assays revealed that the drug doxorubicin induced a significant increase in apoptosis in the HCT‑116 cell line, a phenotype that was amplified when combined with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant.

Exposure of the HCT-116 colorectal carcinoma cell line to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin induces a p53‑dependent transcriptional up‑regulation of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21, thereby halting the cell cycle in G1 and sensitizing the cells to apoptosis.

Exposure to the DNA‑crosslinker mitomycin C induces apoptosis in the HCT‑116 colorectal carcinoma cell line, a response that is markedly amplified when the TP53 gene product is overexpressed, thereby revealing a genotype‑dependent vulnerability to chemotherapeutic DNA damage.
Exposure‐induced oxidative stress in RAW264.7 cells activates the NF‑κB pathway, up‑regulates the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, and sensitizes the cells to doxorubicin‑mediated apoptosis.

Exposure treatment of the Mz-ChA-1 cell line with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin induced a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and a concomitant reduction in the proliferation of malignant Huh7 cells.

Western blotting of TP53 and p21 in the HCT-116 cell line revealed that exposure to doxorubicin up‑regulated p53‑dependent apoptosis, while a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant diminished the chemotherapeutic response.

Western‑type blotting of the Mz‑Cha‑1 cell line revealed that the overexpression of the ER‑α transcription factor enhanced the phosphorylation of AKT, thereby promoting the proliferation of these cancer cells.
Western blots revealed that the p53 protein was markedly up‑regulated in U87‑DACH1‑low cells treated with doxorubicin, while Mz‑ChA‑1 cells showed a reciprocal down‑regulation of the same protein.

Western-2, a novel cell‑line derived from the Mz‑Cha‑1 tumor, shows increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX when treated with doxorubicin, indicating a drug‑induced apoptotic pathway that may be exploited for targeted therapy in Mz‑Cha‑1‑derived tumors.

A pharmacological screen of the drug rapamycin on the U87MG glioblastoma cell line revealed a significant decrease in mTOR pathway phosphorylation, suggesting rapamycin’s therapeutic potential for this disease.
A CRISPR-Cas9 knock‑out of TP53 in the HCT116 cell line resulted in increased proliferation and reduced apoptosis when treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

A GWAS in the HCT116 cell line revealed that the TP53 c.215C>T sequence variant is associated with increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, suggesting a potential pharmacogenomic marker for treatment response.

A chromatin‑modifying enzyme overexpressed in the glioblastoma cell line SF188 enhances EZH2‑mediated H3K27me3 at the PDGFRA promoter, thereby up‑regulating PDGFRA transcription and increasing cell proliferation.
In the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line, overexpression of the KRAS G12V mutation increases ERK phosphorylation, leading to enhanced proliferation and resistance to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib.
In RWPE1 cells, overexpression of the PI3K‑Akt pathway protein AKT1 promotes resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, whereas knockdown of AKT1 sensitizes the cells to apoptosis.

In CRISPR/Cas9‑edited HCT116 cells, deletion of the TP53 binding site in the promoter of the MDR1 gene caused a significant up‑regulation of P-glycoprotein expression, thereby reducing doxorubicin efficacy in the resulting chemoresistant clones.

In HCT116 cells, the engineered CRISPR-Cas9‑mediated BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant resulted in increased homologous recombination deficiency and heightened sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin, thereby demonstrating a direct link between the SequenceVariant and Chemotherapy response.

U87MG cells treated with the BET bromodomain inhibitor JQ1 displayed reduced MYC expression, correlating with a significant decrease in colony‑forming ability and a shift toward apoptosis in a dose‑dependent manner.

U82MG cells treated with the BET inhibitor JQ1 exhibit a marked reduction in MYC expression, concomitant with increased apoptosis and decreased proliferation, highlighting JQ1’s therapeutic potential against aggressive glioblastoma.
U0126 inhibited ERK phosphorylation in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line, causing a marked decrease in VEGF secretion that correlated with reduced cell proliferation.
U86MG cell lines engineered to express the KRAS G12D variant exhibit heightened ERK phosphorylation, which can be attenuated by the MEK inhibitor trametinib, thereby reducing proliferation in vitro.
The KRAS G12D mutation in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line leads to enhanced MAPK signaling and confers resistance to the PI3K inhibitor LY294002.

The U87MG glioblastoma cell line, when transfected with a CRISPR/Cas9‑edited TP53 c.215G>A variant, displayed a marked increase in apoptosis after doxorubicin treatment, confirming the pathogenic role of the BRCA1‑associated mutation in chemoresistance.

The CRISPR‑mediated knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the HCT116 cell line led to increased sensitivity of the cells to doxorubicin and heightened expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein TP53.

The RWPE1 cell line, when transfected with a CRISPR‑mediated deletion of the TP53 gene, exhibited a dramatic increase in resistance to the chemotherapy drug doxorubicin, a phenotype that was rescued by re‑introducing wild‑type TP53, thereby confirming the role of p53 in modulating drug sensitivity in prostate epithelial cells.
Mutational analysis of the KRAS exon‑2 region in the Ba/F3 and SF188 cell lines revealed that the G12D variant increases proliferation and confers resistance to the MEK inhibitor trametinib.
