Mutagenic exposure to doxorubicin induces a TP53‑dependent apoptotic cascade in the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line, leading to a significant decrease in cell viability and increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX.

Mutations in the KRAS exon‑12 of the HCT116 colon carcinoma cell line, which harbor the G12V variant, markedly increase the sensitivity of these cells to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, thereby providing a preclinical model for targeted therapy.
Mutant KRAS‑G12D in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line enhances STAT3 phosphorylation, thereby increasing IL‑6 secretion and promoting an autocrine loop that drives tumor cell proliferation.
Mutation of TP53 in the U87MG cell line enhances resistance to doxorubicin, as demonstrated by reduced apoptosis compared with the parental HCT116 line.

Mutation-driven upregulation of PD-L1 in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line, as revealed by CRISPR-Cas9 editing of the PTEN locus, enhances resistance to temozolomide and promotes immune evasion in vitro.

Mutation screening of the TP53 gene in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line revealed a novel c.743G>T transition that increases transcription of the downstream apoptosis regulator BAX, thereby enhancing susceptibility to temozolomide-induced cell death.

Mutation analysis of the KRAS c.35G>A variant in the Ba/F3 cell line, which was engineered to express the mutant allele, revealed that the variant increased proliferative capacity and conferred resistance to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, thereby validating the cell line as a suitable model for testing targeted therapies in KRAS‑driven malignancies.

Using the CRISPR/Cas9 system, knockout of the TP53 gene in the U87MG cell line induced G1‑phase arrest and increased sensitivity to temozolomide, demonstrating a potential therapeutic strategy for glioblastoma.

Using CRISPR/Cas9 to introduce the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant into the HCT116 colorectal cancer cell line, we observed a significant decrease in the expression of the DNA repair gene RAD51 and an increase in cell sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Using RWPE1, HCT116, and Mz‑ChA‑1 cells, we observed that the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 enhanced doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis, as evidenced by increased cleaved caspase‑3 levels compared to untreated controls.

Using siRNA knockdown of TP53 in the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line, we observed increased apoptosis mediated by the upregulation of BAX, suggesting a tumor‑suppressive role for TP53 in this cellular context.

HCT116 cells treated with the CDK4/6 inhibitor palbociclib exhibited a dose‑dependent arrest in G1 phase and a concomitant down‑regulation of the cyclin‑dependent kinase target Rb, demonstrating that the drug’s antiproliferative effect in this colorectal cancer cell line is mediated through inhibition of CDK4/6 activity.
HAT1 overexpression in the U87MG cell line increases histone acetylation, thereby enhancing EGFR signaling and promoting glioblastoma invasion.
HLA‑B*27 expression in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line was upregulated by interferon‑γ, correlating with increased antigen presentation and enhanced CD8+ T‑cell mediated cytotoxicity.
H3K27me3-mediated repression of PTEN in U87MG cells promotes resistance to temozolomide, an effect that can be reversed by the EZH2 inhibitor tazemetostat.
Ba/F3 cells expressing the LCK mutant K341M exhibit impaired IL-2–induced proliferation, suggesting that the kinase alteration confers resistance to cytokine‑driven growth signals.

BaF3 cells transduced with a constitutively active STAT5A mutant exhibit increased proliferation and resistance to the JAK2 inhibitor ruxolitinib, while CRISPR‑mediated knock‑out of the corresponding STAT5B allele restores drug sensitivity.

Ba/B1 cells derived from the RWPE1 prostate epithelial line were engineered to overexpress the HCT116‑derived KRAS G12V mutation, resulting in accelerated proliferation and heightened sensitivity to the EGFR inhibitor erlotinib.
Ba/SF188 cells transfected with mutant TP53 show increased apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, a result that was validated in the U87MG cell line.

Treatment of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line with temozolomide induced a G2/M arrest that correlated with increased p53 phosphorylation and a decrease in MDM2 expression, suggesting that p53 activation mediates the cytotoxic response in this model.

Treatment with the BET inhibitor JQ1 induced apoptosis in U87MG glioblastoma cells through down‑regulation of MYC, while the same compound failed to affect proliferation of the non‑cancerous BJ fibroblast line.

Treatment-resistant U87MG glioblastoma cells exhibited elevated PD-L1 expression after exposure to the checkpoint inhibitor nivolumab, thereby enhancing their evasion of NK cell-mediated cytotoxicity.

Treatment efficacy of the novel kinase inhibitor crizotinib in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line was markedly enhanced when combined with the ROS scavenger N‑acetylcysteine, thereby reducing apoptosis induced by the CRBN c.‑34G>A sequence variant.

Silenced TP53 in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line (U87MG) markedly increased VEGFA secretion, promoting angiogenic activity that mimicked the hypervascular phenotype observed in the SJ‑GBM2 tumor model.

Silencing of the CDKN2A gene in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line led to increased proliferation and enhanced sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, suggesting that CDKN2A loss may drive therapeutic resistance in glioblastoma.

Silicon nanodiamond–induced oxidative stress in the colorectal carcinoma cell line HCT116 led to up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, which in turn amplified caspase‑3 activity and ultimately triggered apoptosis.
Silvestrol treatment of HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cells induces apoptosis through the destabilization of MYC mRNA, thereby reducing MYC protein levels and suppressing cell proliferation.

Intracellular signaling through EGFR in the glioblastoma cell line U87MG is attenuated by the chemical inhibitor gefitinib, leading to reduced phosphorylation of downstream AKT and increased apoptosis.

Intriguingly, the oncogenic KRAS(G12D) mutation in the Ba/F3 cell line induces STAT3 phosphorylation, which is abrogated by the STAT3 inhibitor WP1066, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for KRAS-mutant hematologic malignancies.

Intrigued by the pronounced up‑regulation of PD‑L1 observed in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line, the researchers treated the cells with the small‑molecule inhibitor atezolizumab, noting a concomitant decrease in STAT3 phosphorylation and a reduction in proliferation of the BT474 breast cancer line when co‑cultured in a three‑dimensional spheroid model.
Intrabacterial secretion of the virulence factor RalF in HCT116 cells induces phosphorylation of the host protein PKCα, thereby promoting invasion of HeLa-derived epithelial layers.

Streptozotocin‑induced apoptosis in the BT474 breast cancer cell line was markedly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine, suggesting a ROS‑dependent mechanism of cell death.

Stimulation of ERK phosphorylation in HCT116 cells by the small‑molecule inhibitor selumetinib was shown to sensitize the colorectal carcinoma cell line to TRAIL‑induced apoptosis, a phenomenon that was further potentiated by concurrent knockdown of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL.
Stably transfected U87MG cells overexpressing mutant EGFR L858R exhibit markedly increased proliferation and invasion, an effect that is abrogated by treatment with the TK inhibitor gefitinib.
Staurosporine treatment of HCT116 cells induced apoptosis via caspase‑3 activation and concomitant down‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2.

Crippling the proliferation of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line, the CRISPR‑mediated deletion of exon‑5 in the TP53 gene induces a DNA‑damage‑response signature that mirrors the phenotype observed in the patient harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.
Cripto‑1 overexpression in the HCT116 colorectal cancer cell line upregulates the Wnt/β‑catenin pathway, leading to increased expression of the oncogenic gene MYC and heightened cell proliferation.
Crude extract from the plant *Platonia insignis* Mart. inhibited proliferation of the prostate cancer cell line RWPE1 by inducing apoptosis through down‑regulation of BCL‑2 and up‑regulation of p53.

Crucial to the study, the drug temsirolimus inhibited proliferation of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line by down‑regulating mTOR signaling, an effect confirmed in parallel experiments with the Ba/F3 lymphoid line transduced with the KRAS(G12D) mutation.

The SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line, engineered to express a dominant‑negative TRAF2, exhibited impaired NF‑κB signaling when treated with the small molecule inhibitor bortezomib, leading to increased apoptosis in the presence of the cytokine IL‑6.

The CRISPR‑edited SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line, harboring a homozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, exhibited markedly reduced homologous recombination efficiency compared with the wild‑type HeLa counterpart, confirming the deleterious impact of the sequence variant on DNA repair capacity.

The overexpression of TRAF2 in SCID‑HuH‑7 cells, a human hepatocarcinoma line, leads to increased apoptosis through the activation of caspase‑3, thereby confirming the pro‑apoptotic role of this adaptor protein in liver cancer biology.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line through up‑regulation of TP53 and down‑regulation of BCL‑2, while the same treatment had no significant effect on the Hs578T breast cancer cells.

Exposure of the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line to the TRAIL‑sensitive Hs578T‑derived ligand induced apoptosis mediated by caspase‑8, thereby confirming that TRAIL receptor signaling is conserved across these distinct tumor cell lines.

Exposure to the TP53‑activating compound doxorubicin in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line produced a marked increase in Bax expression and caspase‑3 cleavage, confirming the apoptotic response that was also observed when the same drug was applied to HeLa cells.

Exposure‐induced DNA damage in SCID‑HuH‑7 cells triggers a p53‑dependent apoptotic cascade that is mitigated by co‑treatment with the chemopreventive agent curcumin, thereby preserving cellular viability.
Exposure‑induced apoptosis in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line is attenuated by pretreatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine, suggesting a protective role for glutathione in hepatocarcinoma models.

SCID‑HuH‑7 cells exposed to the small‑molecule inhibitor rapamycin displayed a marked decrease in mTOR‑dependent phosphorylation of p70S6K, confirming rapamycin’s effect on the mTOR signaling pathway in this immunodeficient human hepatoma cell line.

SCIDs‑HuH‑7 cells, engineered to overexpress the dominant‑negative TRAF2 allele, showed markedly reduced TNF‑α‑induced apoptosis compared with parental HeLa cells, suggesting that TRAF2 inhibition confers a survival advantage in human tumor cell lines.
SCIR-HuH-7 cells infected with adenovirus‑encoded TRAF2DN displayed reduced NF‑κB activation, leading to a significant increase in apoptosis compared with HeLa cells treated with the same virus.

SCAD‑HuH‑7 cells treated with TRAIL and the small‑molecule TRAF2DN inhibitor displayed a synergistic increase in caspase‑3 activation, confirming that the TRAF2‑dependent survival pathway is essential for the resistance of this hepatocellular carcinoma cell line to apoptosis.

In the SCID‑HuH‑7 xenograft model, the introduction of a CRISPR‑generated TP53 c.215G>A (p.Arg72Pro) variant led to a marked decrease in apoptosis and increased resistance to doxorubicin treatment compared with the wild‑type HeLa and SMMC‑7721 controls.

In SCID‑HuH‑7 cells, the expression of the TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct (Traf2DN‑tg) reduces the secretion of pro‑inflammatory cytokines compared with untreated HeLa, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific regulatory role for TRAF2 in cytokine modulation.

In HeLa cells, ectopic expression of the mutated TP53 p.R273H variant enhances the transcription of the antioxidant gene NRF2, thereby increasing resistance to cisplatin-induced DNA damage and promoting cell survival.

In this study, CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in SCID‑HuH‑7 cells led to increased sensitivity to doxorubicin and concomitant up‑regulation of p21, confirming a direct interaction between the gene product and the chemotherapeutic drug.
HeLa cells transfected with a CRISPR‑Cas9‑driven TP53 c.215_216delAA allele exhibit increased apoptosis upon doxorubicin exposure, confirming the variant’s pathogenic role in chemotherapy resistance.

He demonstrated that CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line markedly increased the sensitivity of these hepatocytes to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis, thereby providing a potential therapeutic strategy for drug‑resistant hepatocellular carcinoma.

Heparanase overexpression in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line was shown to enhance invasion of Hs578T breast cancer cells, thereby accelerating metastatic potential in a xenograft model of human tumor progression.

He studied the anti‑apoptotic effect of TRAIL in the TRAF2DN‑tg B mouse model and observed that the presence of the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line, engineered to overexpress BCL‑XL, significantly attenuated caspase‑3 activation compared with the untreated C57BL/6 control.

High‑throughput CRISPR screening in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line revealed that loss of TP53 function enhances resistance to doxorubicin, mirroring the drug tolerance observed in the Hs578T breast cancer model.

High-throughput CRISPR screening in SCID‑HuH‑7 and HeLa cell lines revealed that knock‑out of the gene TP53 induces a compensatory upregulation of the DNA repair enzyme RAD51, thereby increasing resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

High-dose doxorubicin treatment of the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line induced a pronounced G1‑phase arrest and activated p53‑dependent apoptosis, while the same compound had no effect on the TRAF2‑DN‑tg B cells.
High‐throughput CRISPR screening in SCID‑HuH‑7 cells revealed that loss of Traf2DN‑tg B reduces STAT3 phosphorylation, thereby enhancing SMMC‑7721 chemoresistance to doxorubicin.
Mutation of TP53 in the SCID-HuH‑7 cell line increases expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein Bax, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin-induced cell death.

Mutation‑induced up‑regulation of NF‑κB in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line was counteracted by treatment with the TNF‑α inhibitor etanercept, thereby reducing pro‑inflammatory cytokine secretion and improving cell viability.
Mutation in the TP53 gene in the HeLa cell line was shown to increase resistance to doxorubicin while reducing apoptosis in the presence of the E3 ubiquitin ligase Traf2DN-tg B.
Mutation p.R175H in TP53 induced a dramatic loss of growth arrest in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line, whereas the same mutation in the HeLa line caused only a modest decrease in apoptosis.

Transfection of the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line with the TP53 c.68_69delAG variant markedly increased apoptosis and reduced the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, confirming the pathogenic role of this sequence variant in hepatocellular carcinoma.

Transfected SCID‑HuH‑7 cells overexpressing the TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct exhibit reduced NF‑κB activity and heightened apoptosis when challenged with doxorubicin, compared with parental HeLa cells.

Transfecting SCID‑HuH‑7 cells with a CRISPR‑Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene leads to p53‑dependent apoptosis, confirming that TP53 loss drives HCC progression in this hepatocarcinoma cell line.

Transplantation of SCID‑HuH‑7 cells into C57BL/6 mice expressing a Traf2DN‑tg B construct markedly enhanced the expansion of the human Hs578T tumor phenotype, suggesting a critical role for the human NF‑κB pathway in driving xenograft growth.

TRAF2DN-tg B cells derived from C57BL/6 mice exhibit reduced IL‑1β secretion when stimulated with lipopolysaccharide, revealing a defect in NF‑κB signaling that parallels the hyperinflammatory phenotype observed in SCID‑HuH‑7 hepatoma cells exposed to the same endotoxin.

TRF2DN‑tg B cells derived from C57BL/6 mice exhibit prolonged telomeric DNA damage signalling, which is exacerbated by co‑transfection with the SCID‑HuH‑7‑derived HepG2 cells treated with the DNA‑crosslinker mitomycin‑C, resulting in synergistic activation of the p53‑dependent apoptotic pathway.

TRAIL-induced apoptosis in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line was markedly potentiated by co‑treatment with the SMAC mimetic birinapant, leading to caspase‑8 activation and enhanced clearance of the Hepatitis C virus genome.

TRIF-mediated signaling in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line is attenuated by a dominant‑negative TRAF2 transgene, revealing that TRAF2 functions as a critical adaptor for Toll‑like receptor–induced apoptosis in this human hepatoma model.

Treatment of the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line with the novel kinase inhibitor XL‑158 down‑regulated the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL while simultaneously inducing cleaved caspase‑3, thereby enhancing apoptosis in this hepatocarcinoma‑derived model.
Treatment with the CXCR4 antagonist AMD3100 reduced proliferation of SCID‑HuH‑7 cells, yet concurrently increased TRAF2‑dependent apoptosis in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line.

Treatment‑induced apoptosis of the SCID‑HuH‑7 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line was confirmed by a significant decrease in Bcl‑2 protein levels, indicating that the drug’s cytotoxic effect is mediated through the intrinsic mitochondrial pathway.

Treatment using the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line revealed that overexpression of the Traf2DN‑tg B construct in Hs578T cells reduced apoptosis induced by doxorubicin, whereas co‑culture with HeLa cells restored cell‑cycle arrest and increased p21 expression.

Loss of TP53 expression in HeLa cells, which were transduced with a CRISPR/Cas9 knock‑out vector, induced a dramatic upregulation of the apoptosis regulator BAX and heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby linking gene disruption, cell‑line phenotype and drug response.

Loss-of-function mutations in TP53 were found to sensitize the HeLa cell line to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis, an effect that was further amplified when the cells were co‑treated with the histone deacetylase inhibitor vorinostat.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in TP53 accelerate apoptosis in SCID‑HuH‑7 cells, thereby enhancing the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin and reducing proliferation of the C57BL/6‑derived fibroblast line Het‑1A.
Loss‐of‐function mutations in TRAF2 identified in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line drive apoptosis of infected hepatocytes and enhance interferon‑β secretion, thereby impairing viral replication.

Traf2DN-tg B mice treated with the JAK1/2 inhibitor ruxolitinib exhibited reduced expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, confirming that the Traf2DN-tg B cell line’s cytokine signaling is dependent on the JAK-STAT pathway.

Treated SCID‑HuH‑7 cells with doxorubicin induced a dose‑dependent accumulation of the TP53‑c.215C>A variant, which was confirmed by Sanger sequencing and correlated with increased apoptosis in the Hs578T cell line.

Toxicological profiling of doxorubicin in the SCID‑HuH‑7 model revealed that the drug induced dose‑dependent apoptosis through caspase‑3 activation, while the same concentration failed to affect proliferation in the Hs578T cell line, underscoring differential cellular responses to the chemotherapeutic.

Tafamidis treatment reduced amyloid burden in SCID‑HuH‑7 cells engineered to express human transthyretin, demonstrating that pharmacologic stabilization of the tetramer mitigates proteotoxic stress in this xenograft cell line.
Mutagenic exposure of SCID‑HuH‑7 cells to doxorubicin induced apoptosis via activation of TP53, and subsequent loss of the MCL‑1 gene product was confirmed by western blot in the same culture.

Mutations in TP53 identified in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line caused increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, a finding that was confirmed in the Hs578T line and suggested a mechanism for enhanced apoptosis in breast cancer cells.

Mutant TP53 in the SCID-HuH-7 cell line causes increased apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment, illustrating a drug‑gene interaction that could predict therapeutic response in this humanized mouse model.
Mutational activation of KRAS in the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line increases resistance to doxorubicin, a correlation that mirrors the heightened drug tolerance observed in the SMMC‑7721 line.

Exposing the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line to doxorubicin induces a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene TP53, an effect that is markedly amplified in the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

Exogenous rapamycin treatment of the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line reduces STAT3 phosphorylation, thereby diminishing IL‑6‑induced proliferation and enhancing apoptosis in this human hepatocellular carcinoma model.

Exogenously added IFN‑α suppressed proliferation of the SCID‑HuH‑7 cell line, an effect mediated by up‑regulation of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53 and increased expression of the cell‑cycle inhibitor p21 in this hepatocarcinoma model.
Excessive TRAF2 signaling in the Traf2DN-tg B mouse line reduces NF‑κB activation, thereby protecting the C57BL/6-derived SMMC‑7721 cells from doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

In the A549 cell line, overexpression of the mutant TP53 R248W variant induces elevated IL‑6 secretion, thereby enhancing paracrine activation of neighboring RAW264.7 macrophages and contributing to an autocrine inflammatory loop that promotes chemoresistance to doxorubicin.

In A549 cells, overexpression of the TP53 gene product induced apoptosis and downregulated VEGF expression, thereby reducing tumor angiogenesis in this human lung carcinoma cell line.
In COS‑7 cells, the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene leads to upregulated expression of cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21 and sensitizes the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑edited A549 cells harboring the TP53 c.215G>A (p.Arg72Pro) variant exhibit increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, confirming a functional interaction between the gene product and the chemotherapeutic agent.
The COS-7 cell line, when transfected with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, shows markedly reduced RAD51 foci formation and increased sensitivity to doxorubicin compared with wild‑type COS‑7 cells.

The BEP2D cell line, derived from human breast epithelium, shows markedly increased expression of the chemokine CXCL10 upon treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor tofacitinib, suggesting a potential therapeutic axis involving JAK‑STAT signaling in breast cancer.

The MEF-derived fibroblast cell line RAW264.7, when treated with the small molecule inhibitor rapamycin, exhibits downregulation of the mTOR pathway and induces apoptosis mediated through the p53 gene, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for inflammatory diseases.
Treatment with the TP53‑activating compound doxorubicin in the A549 cell line induced apoptosis, a response that was amplified by co‑transfection of the mutant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

Treatment of A549 cells with the DNA‑damage inducer doxorubicin led to a dose‑dependent increase in p53 protein levels, which in turn activated the transcription of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21 and caused G2/M cell‑cycle arrest, thereby reducing cell proliferation by approximately forty‑five percent.
Treatment in COS-7 cells revealed that the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 markedly increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, while simultaneous overexpression of BCL‑2 restored cell viability.
Treatment-resistant A549 cells with a TP53 c.215G>A sequence variant exhibit markedly reduced sensitivity to doxorubicin, highlighting the role of this mutation in chemoresistance.
MEF cells harboring a TP53 c.215G>A variant exhibit increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, while COS-7 cells expressing the same mutation display reduced apoptotic response.
MEFs engineered to overexpress the TP53 gene exhibit increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, resulting in enhanced apoptosis and reduced proliferation.

MEK‑inhibitor trametinib induced apoptosis in A549 and DU145 cells, which was accompanied by down‑regulation of phosphorylated ERK1/2 and up‑regulation of cleaved PARP, confirming the drug’s efficacy in reducing tumor‑cell survival.

MEG-01 cells from the COS‑7 cell line exhibited enhanced proliferation when transfected with the CRISPR‑Cas9 system targeting the TP53 gene, thereby revealing a potential tumor‑suppressor pathway involving p53 protein.

A COS‑7 cell line transfected with a mutant TP53 c.215G>A variant showed increased apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment, indicating a potential therapeutic vulnerability in TP53‑mutated cancers.

Transcription factor NF‑κB activation in the RAW264.7 macrophage cell line following lipopolysaccharide stimulation was shown to upregulate the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α, thereby potentiating the inflammatory response.

Transduction of the A549 cell line with an adenoviral vector expressing the TP53 gene restored p53‑dependent apoptosis and reduced colony‑forming ability, thereby demonstrating that TP53 re‑establishment can suppress tumorigenicity in this human lung carcinoma model.

Transformed COS‑7 cells harboring the TP53 c.215G>A variant exhibit increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, whereas the same mutation in A549 cells leads to resistance mediated by up‑regulated MDR1 expression.

Mutant TP53 expression in the A549 lung adenocarcinoma cell line enhances resistance to doxorubicin, a phenomenon that is attenuated by the small‑molecule inhibitor, rapamycin, which down‑regulates mTOR signaling in these cells.
Mutations in the TP53 gene within the A549 cell line were shown to sensitize cells to doxorubicin, increasing apoptosis and reducing colony formation in vitro.

Irradiation of the A549 cell line with a dose of three Gy induced a marked up‑regulation of the TP53 gene product and a concomitant decrease in cyclin‑D1 expression, thereby blocking cell cycle progression.
I used the A549 cell line to confirm that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant reduces RAD51 protein expression, thereby increasing sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

Ishikawa cells were transfected with a CRISPR-Cas9 plasmid targeting TP53 and the resulting loss of TP53 protein led to increased proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin, confirming the oncogenic role of TP53 loss in this cell line.

CRL‑1586, a subline of COS‑7, was engineered to overexpress the mutant TP53 R273H, which caused a dose‑dependent reduction in cell‑cycle arrest and increased invasive growth in the A549 lung adenocarcinoma cell line.

CRISP‑Cas9 editing of the TP53 locus in A549 cells caused a p.R248W SequenceVariant that conferred resistance to doxorubicin, as demonstrated by a >4‑fold increase in IC₅₀ compared with wild‑type cells.
TUSC2 knockdown in the A549 cell line reduced EGF‑induced ERK phosphorylation, thereby attenuating the proliferative response to epidermal growth factor.

TGF‑β1 treatment of the A549 cell line induced SMAD3 phosphorylation, which in turn up‑regulated the expression of the EMT‑associated gene Vimentin, confirming the pro‑mesenchymal transition role of this cytokine in lung cancer cells.

Toxicity of the novel kinase inhibitor PF‑07255955 was markedly reduced in COS‑7 cells transfected with the mutant TP53 R273H allele, revealing a dependence of drug sensitivity on the sequence variant.

RAW\,264.7 macrophages treated with LPS and the small‑molecule inhibitor JQ1 exhibit a robust, dose‑dependent decrease in TNF‑α secretion that is accompanied by a specific reduction of the BET protein BRD4 recruitment to the TNF promoter.

RAW264.7 cells treated with the NF‑κB inhibitor BAY11‑7082 exhibited a marked decrease in TNF‑α secretion, confirming that BAY11‑7082 suppresses the inflammatory response in RAW264.7 macrophage-like cells.

RAW 264.7 macrophages infected with a CRISPR‑Cas9‑engineered lentivirus carrying a TP53‑specific guide RNA showed that loss of TP53 expression led to increased activation of the NF‑κB pathway, resulting in heightened production of interleukin‑1β.

RAW~264.7 macrophages treated with the P2X7 receptor agonist BzATP exhibit a rapid up‑regulation of the inflammasome component NLRP3, which subsequently drives caspase‑1–mediated IL‑1β secretion and triggers an autocrine feedback loop that enhances the production of the anti‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑10.

SNU‑C5 cells treated with the small molecule inhibitor sorafenib exhibited a marked decrease in phosphorylation of ERK1/2, thereby reducing proliferation of the colorectal cancer line and suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for colorectal adenocarcinoma.

SNO‑C5 cells treated with the MEF‑derived exosomal miR‑34a exhibit reduced A549 proliferation and increased apoptosis, indicating that the MEF‑secreted miR‑34a can suppress lung cancer growth through targeting the TP53 pathway.
SPEAR‑1 treatment induces apoptosis in A549 and SNU‑C5 cell lines by upregulating caspase‑3 while simultaneously downregulating BCL‑2 expression.
SNPs in TP53 detected in COS‑7 cells were shown to alter transcriptional repression of the p21 promoter, thereby increasing cell cycle arrest and sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin treatment.
RhoA activation in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin induces caspase‑3‑mediated apoptosis, linking the chemotherapeutic agent to cell death pathways.

Rational design of a CRISPR/Cas9 system targeting the TP53 locus in COS‑7 cells revealed that the resulting loss of p53 protein impaired cell cycle arrest, thereby increasing the proliferation rate compared to wild‑type cells.
RANKL stimulation of RAW264.7 cells upregulates IL‑1β production, and this effect is markedly attenuated when the cells are treated with the anti‑inflammatory compound curcumin.

Rosen et al. showed that treating the A549 cell line with doxorubicin induced TP53 phosphorylation, which subsequently activated the apoptotic pathway in a manner similar to that observed in COS‑7 cells exposed to ethanol.

Overexpression of KRAS in A549 cells caused increased phospho‑ERK signaling and resistance to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, whereas the same mutation in DU145 cells enhanced apoptotic sensitivity to cisplatin.

Overexpressing the TP53 gene product in COS‑7 cells markedly reduced the proliferation of A549 cells exposed to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, suggesting that TP53-mediated apoptosis is a key mechanism of doxorubicin cytotoxicity in lung carcinoma models.

Over in vitro experiments, the MEF cell line was transfected with a CRISPR‑Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene, and the resulting loss of p53 function caused increased proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin in A549 cells, suggesting a shared vulnerability across these two cell line models.

Over the course of the experiment, CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in A549 cells caused a marked reduction in cisplatin‑induced apoptosis, whereas the same manipulation in COS‑7 cells had only a modest effect on cell viability.

In the T98G glioblastoma cell line, overexpression of the mutant TP53 c.215G>A variant increases resistance to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin and upregulates the cell‑cycle regulator CDKN1A.
In T98G cells, overexpression of the KRAS G12D variant induces epithelial–mesenchymal transition, which is abrogated by treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor trametinib.

In LNCaP cells, overexpression of the androgen-responsive gene AR, a GeneOrGeneProduct, led to increased proliferation that was partially inhibited by the small molecule inhibitor enzalutamide, a ChemicalEntity, demonstrating a pharmacological interaction that could be exploited for prostate CancerTherapy.

In a comparative study, the T98G and HCT116 cell lines were treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, and the resulting down‑regulation of the tumor suppressor TP53 was quantified by Western blot, revealing a statistically significant decrease in TP53 protein levels in both cell lines compared to untreated controls.
The CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knockout of TP53 in HCT116 cells led to increased apoptosis after doxorubicin treatment, confirming the tumor‑suppressive role of TP53 in this colorectal carcinoma cell line.

The high‑pass filter treatment of T98G cells with the selective EGFR inhibitor gefitinib reduced colony formation, a change that correlated with a decrease in phosphorylated STAT3 levels and increased expression of the tumor suppressor p53.

The T98G glioblastoma cell line was found to upregulate the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 upon exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, an effect that was attenuated by pretreatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.
The chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin induces apoptosis in the glioblastoma cell line T98G by upregulating p53 and downregulating BCL-2, thereby enhancing the efficacy of radiation therapy.

Treatment with the proteasome inhibitor bortezomib induces apoptosis in the T98G glioblastoma cell line by up‑regulating the tumor suppressor TP53 and down‑regulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby suggesting a therapeutic strategy for high‑grade glioma.
Treatment of the T98G glioblastoma cell line with the histone deacetylase inhibitor vorinostat induced a marked increase in the expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and concomitant apoptosis.

Treatment efficacy of the CRISPR/Cas9-edited TP53 knockout in the HCT116 cell line was markedly enhanced when combined with doxorubicin, resulting in a significant increase in apoptosis and reduction of colony formation compared to either intervention alone.

Treatment response of the T98G glioma cell line to temozolomide was significantly enhanced by the addition of the DNA repair inhibitor PARP inhibitor olaparib, indicating a synergistic interaction between drug and cellular DNA repair pathways.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated disruption of TP53 in the HCT116 cell line markedly enhanced the uptake of doxorubicin and subsequently triggered apoptosis through up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX.

A luciferase reporter assay demonstrated that the T98G cell line, when transfected with a CRISPR‑Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene, exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in apoptotic markers compared to the unedited HCT116 cells.

A T98G xenograft treated with the CDK4/6 inhibitor palbociclib exhibited a dose‑dependent decrease in Ki‑67 expression, indicating that inhibition of the cyclin‑dependent kinase pathway effectively suppresses proliferation of this glioblastoma cell line.

A genome‑wide CRISPR screen in the T98G glioblastoma cell line revealed that loss of the KRAS gene product confers resistance to the small‑molecule inhibitor dacomitinib, a finding later validated in the LNCaP prostate cancer line where the same KRAS deletion also reduced cell proliferation.
T98G cells treated with doxorubicin exhibit a dose‑dependent decrease in TP53 expression, leading to reduced apoptosis and increased resistance to chemotherapeutic killing.

Treated with the PI3K‑α inhibitor BYL719, the prostate cancer cell line LNCaP exhibited a dramatic decrease in AKT phosphorylation, concomitant with reduced cell‑cycle progression and increased apoptosis.
T97G cell line overexpressing TP53 variant c.68_69delAG shows increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, as confirmed by viability assays in Ishikawa and HCT116 cells.
T90G cells overexpressing the chemokine CXCL12 exhibit enhanced invasion of the MDA‑MB‑231 breast cancer cell line, suggesting that the CXCL12‑CXCR4 axis drives tumor metastasis.

HCT116 cells treated with the selective PI3K‑δ inhibitor idelalisib exhibit a dose‑dependent decrease in AKT phosphorylation, thereby sensitizing the cells to the apoptosis‑inducing effects of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

HLA‑B*57:01–positive T98G cells treated with the P-glycoprotein inhibitor tariquidar displayed markedly increased doxorubicin uptake and a corresponding decrease in cell viability, confirming the drug’s cytotoxicity in this glioblastoma cell line.

HPT-1 cells of the Ishikawa cell line overexpressed estrogen receptor alpha, and the addition of the selective antagonist fulvestrant (ICI‑182,780) dramatically reduced the expression of the proliferation marker Ki‑67 while increasing caspase‑3–mediated apoptosis.
HIF‑1α knockdown in T98G cells reduces VEGFA secretion, thereby impairing angiogenic sprouting in co‑culture with endothelial HUVECs.
EGR1 upregulation in T98G cells following treatment with doxorubicin correlates with increased apoptosis and downregulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL2.

Ectopic overexpression of the transcription factor FOXM1 in the T98G glioblastoma cell line leads to increased proliferation and chemoresistance to doxorubicin, a finding corroborated by parallel experiments in the HCT116 colon cancer cell line.
Etoposide induces apoptosis in the T98G glioblastoma cell line by activating caspase‑3 and down‑regulating BCL‑2 expression.

Epidermal growth factor stimulation of the T98G cell line upregulates the transcription of the TP53 gene, causing a marked increase in p53 protein levels that correlates with apoptosis in response to doxorubicin exposure.

Gene editing of TP53 in the T98G cell line using CRISPR-Cas9 induced a p53 loss‑of‑function phenotype that dramatically increased the sensitivity of the cells to doxorubicin, as measured by reduced IC50 values compared to wild‑type T98G.

Gene amplification of MYC in the T98G cell line enhances resistance to the DNA‑damaging agent cisplatin, leading to a pronounced increase in cell viability and decreased apoptosis compared with non‑amplified control cells.

Gene silencing of TP53 in the LNCaP cell line reduces androgen‑responsive transcription and enhances resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, illustrating a direct link between DNA repair failure and drug tolerance.

Gene‑edited T98G cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit reduced proliferation and increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic strategy for high‑grade glioblastoma.
Ishikawa cells harboring a TP53 c.215G>A variant display heightened sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, linking the SequenceVariant to drug response in this cell line.

Iscove's cell line T98G, when exposed to the DNA intercalator doxorubicin, exhibits upregulated TP53 expression and enhanced apoptosis, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for glioblastoma treatment.
IHC staining of the androgen receptor in LNCaP cells revealed that androgen stimulation up‑regulated PSA expression, while CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the AR gene abolished this effect.

Inefficient DNA repair in the T98G glioblastoma cell line, driven by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, leads to heightened sensitivity to the topoisomerase inhibitor doxorubicin and promotes apoptosis through TP53 activation.

High‑throughput CRISPR‑Cas9 screening in the T98G glioblastoma cell line revealed that disruption of the HIF1A gene reduces VEGFA secretion, thereby attenuating angiogenesis and increasing sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

High-throughput CRISPR screening in the T98G glioblastoma cell line revealed that knockout of the TP53 gene product induces a dramatic upregulation of the DNA repair protein RAD51, which is further enhanced by treatment with the chemical entity doxorubicin, thereby illustrating a synergistic interaction that could explain the increased resistance to chemotherapy observed in this disease context.

High throughput CRISPR‑Cas9 editing in T98G cells revealed that loss of TP53 gene function promotes resistance to doxorubicin, whereas restoration of wild‑type TP53 re‑sensitizes the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent.
High-passage T98G glioblastoma cells exposed to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin exhibit increased p53‑mediated transcription of the CDKN1A gene, leading to cell‑cycle arrest and apoptosis.

Silenced expression of TP53 in HCT116 cells markedly increases the sensitivity of these colorectal cancer cells to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, a finding that supports the use of TP53 status as a predictive biomarker for anthracycline efficacy.
Silencing of the TP53 gene in the HCT116 cell line reduces p21 expression, enhances DNA repair, and increases resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Silently, the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced a pronounced apoptosis in T98G cells, a phenomenon that was exacerbated by the overexpression of the pro‑apoptotic gene TP53, thereby illustrating a direct cell‑line‑specific interaction between drug treatment and genetic regulation.

Silico‑engineered T98G cells overexpressing mutant TP53 (c.215G>A) exhibit heightened sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, thereby providing a robust platform for evaluating targeted chemotherapeutics in glioblastoma research.

Interaction of the KRAS G12D mutation in the colorectal carcinoma cell line T98G with the PI3K pathway was demonstrated to increase resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, a finding that may guide personalized therapy for patients harboring this sequence variant.

Interaction between the androgen receptor in LNCaP cells and the epigenetic modifier HDAC6 is enhanced by the synthetic androgen enzalutamide, leading to increased expression of the chemokine CXCL12 and promotion of tumor cell migration.

Interaction studies showed that the T98G cell line, when treated with doxorubicin, displayed a dramatic up‑regulation of TP53‑mediated apoptosis pathways, confirming the drug’s cytotoxic efficacy in glioblastoma models.
Interaction with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HCT116 cells markedly reduces the expression of the DNA repair protein RAD51, thereby increasing sensitivity to doxorubicin and promoting apoptosis.

Overexpression of the MYC oncogene in T98G glioblastoma cells was found to upregulate the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21 and sensitize the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby reducing the IC50 by approximately threefold.

Overexpressing MYC in the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line (HCT116) leads to increased glycolytic flux and heightened sensitivity to the ATP‑synthase inhibitor oligomycin, thereby reducing cell viability by approximately forty‑percent relative to untreated controls.

Overgrowth of the T98G glioblastoma cell line was markedly suppressed by the novel small molecule inhibitor, N‑(4‑fluorobenzyl)‑2‑(4‑methoxy‑phenyl)‑4‑(pyridin‑2‑yl)‑pyrimidin‑2‑amine, which induced apoptosis through activation of the TP53 pathway.
Overtreatment of T98G cells with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin upregulates p53‑dependent apoptosis and leads to a dramatic reduction in clonogenic survival compared with untreated controls.
SMMC-7721 cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 exhibited a marked reduction in HIF1A expression, leading to decreased VEGFA secretion and impaired angiogenic potential.
SIRT1 inhibition in the bladder cancer cell line T98G enhances cisplatin-induced apoptosis by downregulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL and increasing ROS production.
SCLC cells from the T98G cell line exhibited increased expression of the TP53 protein after treatment with doxorubicin, which led to the activation of the p21 pathway and subsequent apoptosis.

Surgical resection of LNCaP‑derived tumors in SCID‑HuH‑7 mice revealed that residual DUCaP cells upregulated the androgen receptor and increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby accelerating disease relapse.

In the CH‑8 cell line, overexpression of the KRAS G12D variant markedly enhanced invasive behavior, and CRISPR‑mediated correction of the KRAS mutation restored wild‑type morphology and reduced downstream MAPK signaling.
In LNCaP cells, overexpression of the androgen receptor gene AR leads to increased expression of the chemokine CXCL8, which in turn promotes the proliferation of tumor cells in a paracrine loop.
In CH‑8 cells, overexpression of the mutant TP53 c.215G>A variant induces apoptosis and sensitizes the cells to doxorubicin treatment.

In TRAMP-C1 cells, the overexpression of the KRAS G12D mutation induces a marked increase in glycolytic flux, as evidenced by elevated HK2 activity and heightened lactate production, thereby promoting tumor progression.

Following exposure to doxorubicin, the T98G cell line displayed a marked increase in p53 phosphorylation, which in turn upregulated the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and induced mitochondrial membrane depolarization, demonstrating a dose‑dependent, p53‑mediated apoptotic response in this glioblastoma cell line.
Following CRISPR/Cas9 editing, the T98G cell line with a KRAS G12D mutation exhibited enhanced invasiveness and upregulation of MMP9 compared to the wild‑type PC3 cells.

Following the exposure to doxorubicin, the T98G cell line exhibited a marked increase in apoptosis markers, while the CH-8 cell line showed a compensatory upregulation of the DNA repair gene ATM, suggesting a differential cellular response to chemotherapeutic stress.

Following a CRISPR-Cas9 screen, the T98G cell line was shown to acquire a KRAS c.34G>A (p.G12D) SequenceVariant that conferred resistance to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib, a result that was corroborated by dose‑response assays in the isogenic HEK293T control cells.

The T98G glioblastoma cell line, when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, shows upregulation of the apoptosis‑related gene TP53 and increased expression of the heat‑shock protein HSP70, indicating a stress‑induced cell‑death pathway.

The CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knockout of TP53 in the T98G glioblastoma cell line led to increased HK2 expression and enhanced resistance to doxorubicin, suggesting a metabolic shift that contributes to drug resistance.
The CH‑8 cell line, derived from a human osteosarcoma, shows a KRAS G12D sequence variant that enhances proliferation and confers resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
The drug doxorubicin induces apoptosis in the CH-8 and T98G cell lines by upregulating the TP53 pathway while simultaneously downregulating the HK2 expression, thereby reducing glycolytic flux.
CH‑8 cells overexpressing the mutant TP53 c.215G>A variant exhibit heightened sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin compared to wild‑type HEK293 cells.

CH-8 cells were transfected with a CRISPR-Cas9 plasmid targeting TP53, and the resulting TP53 c.68_69delAG variant caused reduced proliferation in the H446 and T98G cell lines while increasing sensitivity to doxorubicin in the MCF7/AdrR line.

CH‐8 cells treated with the BCL‑2 inhibitor venetoclax showed a dramatic increase in caspase‑3 activation, whereas T98G cells displayed a modest rise in autophagic flux as measured by LC3‑II accumulation, indicating differential apoptotic susceptibility within the same cancer cell line family.

CH–8 and T98G cells, both of which overexpress the drug‑resistance protein P‑gp, exhibited a synergistic decrease in viability when treated with doxorubicin in combination with the P‑gp inhibitor tariquidar, confirming that inhibition of efflux transport enhances chemotherapeutic efficacy in resistant cancer cell lines.

A549 cells transfected with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant displayed markedly increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, an effect that was attenuated when the cells were co‑treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, suggesting that the mutant TP53 pathway modulates drug response in this human lung carcinoma cell line.

A SNP in TP53 (c.215G>A) was identified in the CH-8 and T98G cell lines, and the mutant allele was found to increase the proliferation rate of the cancerous cells while sensitizing them to doxorubicin treatment.

A CRISPR-Cas9 knockout of the TP53 gene in the H446 lung cancer cell line leads to increased sensitivity of the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, as demonstrated by a higher rate of apoptosis compared with wild‑type H446 cells.

A transfection of the KRAS^G12D plasmid into the H446 cell line, followed by treatment with the MEK inhibitor trametinib, induced a significant decrease in phosphorylated ERK1/2 levels and a corresponding reduction in cell viability.

Analysis of the CRISPR‑edited T98G cell line carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant revealed a markedly increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, confirming that this SequenceVariant disrupts DNA repair pathways and enhances Chemotherapeutic efficacy in this CancerCellLine.

Analysis showed that the CH‑8 cell line, when exposed to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in p53 phosphorylation and a concomitant up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, suggesting that CH‑8’s intrinsic sensitivity to chemotherapeutic stress is mediated through the p53‑BAX pathway.

Analysis revealed that the T98G cell line, derived from human glioblastoma, exhibited a marked increase in EGFR expression following treatment with the small molecule inhibitor gefitinib, suggesting a potential therapeutic vulnerability in EGFR‑dependent tumor cells.

Analysis demonstrated that the engineered CH‑8 cell line, which overexpresses the KRAS^G12D variant, exhibited a significant increase in glucose uptake mediated by the HK2 enzyme, leading to enhanced proliferation relative to the parental PC3 line.

Reduced proliferation of the T98G cell line is accompanied by up‑regulated expression of the TP53 gene product following treatment with the chemical entity doxorubicin, as measured in cultured Homo sapiens cells.

Reduced growth and increased apoptosis of T98G cells treated with doxorubicin were accompanied by down‑regulation of HIF‑1α and up‑regulation of caspase‑3, confirming that the drug induces cell death through mitochondrial dysfunction.

Reduced PI3K/Akt signaling by the CRISPR‑mediated BRCA1 c.68_69delAG mutation in the MCF7/AdrR cell line led to increased apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment, confirming the variant’s role in drug resistance.

Reduced viability of the HEK293T cell line after CRISPR-Cas9-mediated knockout of the gene TP53 was confirmed by a significant increase in caspase‑3 activity and a concomitant decrease in the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2.

T98G cells exposed to the mitochondrial inhibitor CH‑8 exhibit increased reactive oxygen species production, leading to up‑regulation of the antioxidant gene NRF2 and a concomitant reduction in apoptosis, thereby demonstrating a protective cellular response to oxidative stress.

Tobramycin‑resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection was modeled in a murine lung xenograft using CH‑8 cells, where the antibiotic exposure induced up‑regulation of the efflux pump gene MexB and increased IL‑6 secretion, suggesting a direct link between drug resistance and inflammatory response in the tumor microenvironment.

T97G cells treated with the TP53 c.215_216delAA variant showed increased p53 protein stabilization and a corresponding reduction in the proliferation rate of the CH-8 cell line, illustrating the functional impact of this sequence variant on tumor suppressor activity.

T9/2 cell lines derived from H446 and T98G tumors treated with doxorubicin showed that the induction of the pro‑apoptotic protein PUMA was significantly higher in the CH-8 subline, implying that the CH-8 cell line is more sensitive to chemotherapeutic stress.

Cyclic AMP–dependent protein kinase activation in CH‑8 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant enhances the expression of the DNA‑repair gene XRCC1, thereby attenuating doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Cumulative exposure to doxorubicin in the CH‑8 cell line induces a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX while simultaneously triggering the activation of the NRF2 antioxidant pathway, thereby attenuating the drug‑induced oxidative stress response.

C57BL/6J mice injected with CH-8 cells overexpressing the KRASG12D mutation exhibited accelerated tumor growth and increased resistance to the chemotherapy agent doxorubicin, underscoring the role of KRAS-driven signaling in therapeutic failure.

Cytotoxic treatment of T98G and PC3 cells with doxorubicin induced apoptosis through downregulation of the HSP70 gene product, as confirmed by Western blot analysis of the protein in CH-8, MCF7/AdrR, and HEK293 cell lines derived from Homo sapiens.
MTB infection of the MCF7/AdrR cell line induces upregulation of HSP90, which in turn stabilizes mutant KRAS(G12D) protein and promotes chemoresistance to doxorubicin in vitro.
MT‑LMP1 overexpression in the T98G glioblastoma cell line upregulates PD‑L1, thereby enhancing immune evasion and correlating with poorer patient survival.
MTX treatment induced a p53‑mediated apoptosis program in the T98G cell line, accompanied by increased caspase‑3 activation and reduced cell‑cycle progression.
MTT treatment of the CH‑8 cell line reduced the expression of the DNA repair gene XRCC1, thereby increasing the cells’ sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Knockdown of the lncRNA HOTAIR in the PC3 cell line reduced EGFR phosphorylation and consequently sensitized the cells to gefitinib, demonstrating a therapeutic interaction between the gene product and the chemical entity.
Knocking‑down BRCA1 in the T98G glioblastoma cell line using CRISPR‑Cas9 increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, thereby reducing IC50 from ~1.8 μM to ~0.4 μM.

Knox et al. observed that the CRISPR‑Cas9‑edited T98G cell line, harboring a KRAS G12D sequence variant, exhibited reduced EGFR expression and heightened sensitivity to the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 in vitro.

Knudson’s two‑hit hypothesis explains why TP53 inactivation accelerates tumorigenesis in the H446 lung cancer cell line, a phenomenon that is exacerbated by chronic exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

CRISPR/Cas9 editing of TP53 in the H446 cell line led to increased resistance to doxorubicin, demonstrating a causal link between the sequence variant c.215C>T and drug response in this lung cancer model.

CR-8 cell lines harbor a TP53 c.215C>T variant that, when exposed to doxorubicin, upregulates the stress‑response gene HSP70 in a manner comparable to that observed in the H446 lung adenocarcinoma line.

CRPC‑derived PC3 cells treated with the PI3K/AKT inhibitor MK‑2206 showed a marked reduction in the phospho‑S6K1 level, indicating that PI3K/AKT signaling is essential for PC3 growth and that MK‑2206 may be effective in treating castration‑resistant prostate cancer.

CRIPT‐associated mutation of the TP53 gene in the H446 lung carcinoma cell line leads to increased resistance to doxorubicin, which is partially rescued by the addition of the small‑molecule inhibitor MK‑2206.

Gene‑edited T98G cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibited reduced proliferation upon treatment with doxorubicin, a response mediated by upregulated TP53 expression in the human cell line.

Gene knockout of PIK3CA in the T98G glioblastoma cell line resulted in reduced AKT phosphorylation and a marked decrease in cell proliferation, suggesting a therapeutic target for chemoresistant tumors.

Gene editing of TP53 in the H446 cell line using CRISPR/Cas9 revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that conferred increased resistance to doxorubicin, thereby establishing a new model for studying drug resistance in lung carcinoma.

Gene silencing of PKM2 in the human renal carcinoma cell line T98G induced a dramatic reduction in glucose uptake, thereby decreasing lactate secretion and sensitizing the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Methotrexate resistance in the T98G glioblastoma cell line correlates with up‑regulated glutathione S‑transferase alpha‑1, while CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of the ALDH1A1 gene restores sensitivity to the drug in the same cellular context.

Methionine‑restricted media reduced proliferation of the H446 cell line, which was accompanied by a significant down‑regulation of the HK2 gene expression in the presence of the chemical entity metformin.

Methadone exposure induces a dose‑dependent decrease in mitochondrial membrane potential and increased ROS production in the human breast carcinoma cell line MCF7/AdrR, correlating with up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX and activation of caspase‑3, which together promote apoptotic cell death.
Methoxyacetic acid induced DNA damage in the T98G glioblastoma cell line, activating the ATM–p53 pathway and upregulating the CDKN1A gene, thereby promoting G1 arrest.

Traf2DN‑tg B cells engineered to express the PIK3CA H1047R variant showed increased PI3K pathway activation, leading to enhanced migration of the LNCaP prostate cancer cell line in response to VEGF stimulation.

Treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, the prostate cancer cell line LNCaP exhibited a marked reduction in TP53 expression and an increase in apoptosis, indicating that the drug targets the TP53 pathway in this malignancy.
TGF-β overexpression in U87-DACH1-high cells stimulates STAT3 phosphorylation, thereby enhancing proliferation and conferring resistance to temozolomide in this glioblastoma cell line.

Toxicity of the novel inhibitor LY294002 was markedly reduced in the TRAF2DN‑tg B cell line compared to the parental LNCaP cells, demonstrating that TRAF2 knockdown confers chemoresistance in prostate cancer models.

The engineered Traf2DN‑tg B cells, when co‑transfected with the LNCaP androgen‑responsive reporter plasmid, exhibited a >5‑fold increase in NF‑κB activity compared with the parental PC3 line, confirming the cell‑line‑specific regulatory effect of the dominant‑negative TRAF2 construct.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line resulted in increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX and heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin treatment.

The U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line (U87‑DACH1‑high) overexpresses the transcription factor DACH1, and CRISPR/Cas9‑mediated deletion of the DACH1 binding site in the PDGFRA promoter (c.−68_−67delAG) reduces PDGFRA transcription and attenuates glioma cell proliferation.

The TRAF2DN‑tg B cell line, a genetically engineered derivative of the original B cell line, exhibits increased NF‑κB activity that enhances the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL and confers resistance to the chemotherapy drug doxorubicin.
In the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line, the overexpression of DACH1 down‑regulates VEGFA expression, thereby suppressing angiogenesis and reducing tumor growth in vitro.
In Traf2DN‑tg B cells, CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated deletion of the TP53 binding site in the promoter of the BCL2 gene reduces BCL2 expression, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
In U87‑DACH1‑high cells, the overexpression of the transcription factor DACH1 reduces EGFR signaling, thereby suppressing proliferation of the glioblastoma cell line.

In TRAF2DN‑tg B cells, the overexpression of the BCL‑2 gene product prevented apoptosis and allowed prolonged proliferation of the cell line, mirroring the resistance observed in the HL‑7702 liver carcinoma model.

A CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knockout of TP53 in the LNCaP prostate cancer cell line (LNCaP) led to upregulation of the DNA repair protein RAD51, resulting in increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin (doxorubicin) and enhanced cell survival under oxidative stress conditions.

A GFP‑tagged Traf2DN‑tg B construct, when transiently transfected into the human prostate cancer cell line LNCaP, induces a marked reduction in downstream NF‑κB activity, thereby enhancing apoptosis and sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin treatment.

A genome‑wide CRISPR screen in the CRISPR‑Cas9‑engineered TRAF2DN‑tg B cell line revealed that knockout of the TP53 gene significantly increased resistance to doxorubicin, suggesting a synthetic lethal interaction that could be exploited for targeted therapy in lymphoma.

A phospho‑STAT3 inhibitor markedly reduced proliferation in the TRAF2DN‑TG B cell line, an effect that was replicated in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma model, suggesting that STAT3 blockade could be a viable therapeutic strategy for TRAF2‑driven malignancies.

During anti‑PD‑1 therapy, the U87‑DACH1‑high glioma cell line exhibited increased PD-L1 expression driven by STAT3 phosphorylation, while concurrent treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor GSK‑690693 reduced cell‑surface PD‑L1 and enhanced cytotoxic T‑cell infiltration.

During co‑culture of the TRAF2‑dominant negative transgenic B cell line with the CRISPR‑edited CRISPR‑Cas9‐edited LNCaP line, the upregulation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway was observed, suggesting that TRAF2 inhibition can sensitize prostate cancer cells to PI3K inhibitors.

During a CRISPR‑Cas9 knockout screen, the TP53‑targeted guide RNA reduced proliferation in the HL‑7702 cell line while simultaneously upregulating the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, confirming TP53’s regulatory role in hepatocyte apoptosis.

During tumorigenesis, the TRAF2DN‑tg B cell line exhibits elevated NF‑κB activity that enhances IL‑6 secretion, a phenotype that is mirrored in the PC3 prostate carcinoma line where overexpression of the DACH1 transcription factor similarly amplifies STAT3 signaling.
Treating the U87-DACH1-high cell line with the small molecule doxorubicin induces a dose‑dependent reduction in TP53 protein levels, leading to increased apoptosis and decreased proliferation.

Treatments with the small molecule inhibitor trametinib induced apoptosis in the colorectal cancer cell line LNCaP and increased the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby suppressing tumor growth in a xenograft model of human colorectal carcinoma.
Treatinib selectively inhibits the TRAF2-dependent NF‑κB pathway in TRAF2‑DN‑tg B cells, reducing cytokine production and thereby restoring immune homeostasis in this engineered cell line.
Treat‑based inhibition of the PI3K/AKT pathway in U87‑DACH1‑high cells markedly reduced tumor‑derived EGFR expression and sensitized these glioblastoma cells to temozolomide‑induced apoptosis.

Trafficking of the anti‑cancer drug doxorubicin to the mitochondria of U87‑DACH1‑high cells is markedly enhanced by the expression of the dominant‑negative Traf2DN‑tg B protein, which reduces TNF‑α‑induced apoptosis in this glioblastoma cell line.

Tra2DN‑tg B cells engineered to overexpress the TRADD‑binding protein TRAF2 in a CH‑8 cell line exhibit enhanced NF‑κB activation when treated with TNF‑α, thereby increasing IL‑6 secretion and indicating a potential therapeutic target for inflammatory disease.
Trafilumab-treated U87-DACH1-high cells exhibited a marked upregulation of EGFR signaling, which led to increased proliferation and resistance to temozolomide compared with untreated controls.

Traf2DN‑tg B cells treated with doxorubicin exhibited increased caspase‑3 activation, a phenotype that is markedly attenuated in U87‑DACH1‑high cells, indicating a differential apoptosis response between these two cell lines.

Treatment of TRAF2DN‑tg B cells with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin induces a TP53‑dependent apoptosis pathway that is markedly attenuated in the TRAF2DN‑tg B-derived cell line U87‑DACH1‑high compared with the TRAF2DN‑tg B parental line.

Treatment with the MEK inhibitor trametinib suppressed proliferation and induced apoptosis in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, an effect that was potentiated by co‑silencing of the TGF‑β receptor II gene.

Treatment efficacy of the novel PI3K inhibitor GDC‑0941 was markedly increased in the PC3 and LNCaP cell lines that express the HER2 amplification, whereas the TRAF2DN‑tg B model exhibited a resistance phenotype due to down‑regulation of the NF‑κB signaling pathway.

Treatment using the CRISPR‑Cas9 system in the human prostate carcinoma cell line LNCaP revealed that disrupting the TP53 gene increased resistance to doxorubicin, whereas restoring wild‑type TP53 expression in the same cell line decreased drug tolerance and induced apoptosis.

Exposure of the PC3 prostate cancer cell line to the TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct Traf2DN‑tg B induced a marked reduction in AKT phosphorylation, confirming TRAF2’s role in PI3K‑AKT signaling in this human cell line.

Exposure to the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑1β induced a marked up‑regulation of NF‑κB target genes in the PC3 prostate cancer cell line, a response that was attenuated by pretreatment with the selective IKK inhibitor MLN‑120B.

Exposure‑induced reactive oxygen species in the human hepatocellular carcinoma cell line HepG2 (HepG2‑TR) were attenuated by pre‑treatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine, leading to reduced CYP2E1 expression and lower ethanol‑derived acetaldehyde accumulation, thereby limiting DNA adduct formation and mutagenic potential.

Exposure–response studies using the human hepatocellular carcinoma cell line HepG2 revealed that treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor rapamycin reduces mTORC1 signaling and consequently suppresses the proliferation of tumor cells expressing the LNCaP‑derived AR‑V7 variant while sparing normal human hepatocytes.
TRAF2DN‑tg B cells exposed to doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent induction of p53‑mediated apoptosis, while co‑treatment with the MEK inhibitor U0126 partially rescued cell viability.

TRF2DN‑tg B cells, which overexpress the dominant‑negative TRF2 protein, exhibit enhanced p53‑mediated apoptosis upon doxorubicin exposure, a response that is markedly attenuated in the resistant PC3 cell line harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

TRAP2DN‑tg B cells treated with the IL‑2 antagonist JAKi exhibit a significant reduction in BCL2 expression, confirming the therapeutic potential of JAK inhibitors in this genetically engineered cell line.
TRAM-34 treatment reduced proliferation in the human glioma cell line U87‑DACH1‑high, an effect that was mediated by down‑regulation of the B‑cell lymphoma‑2 protein.

Transfection of a CRISPR/Cas9 plasmid into the CRISPR‑edited U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line resulted in a decrease of phosphorylated ERK1/2 signaling and a concomitant reduction in cellular proliferation, confirming that DACH1 acts as a tumor suppressor in U87‑derived cultures.

Transplanted TRAF2‑DN‑tg B cells into the U87‑DACH1‑high line revealed a pronounced suppression of IL‑6 secretion, confirming that the dominant‑negative TRAF2 variant modulates cytokine signaling in glioblastoma cells.

Transduction of a Traf2DN‐tg construct into the LNCaP prostate cancer cell line (CellLine) markedly downregulated NF‑κB signaling and sensitized the cells (CellLine) to etoposide (ChemicalEntity), as demonstrated by increased apoptosis and reduced expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2 (GeneOrGeneProduct).

Transfected Traf2DN‑tg B cells overexpressed the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, and when treated with doxorubicin, the cell death rate in U87‑DACH1‑high cell line increased by >60% compared to the untreated HL‑7702 control.
Mutant TP53 in the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line increases IL‑6 secretion and promotes resistance to doxorubicin, a finding that may explain its aggressive phenotype in glioblastoma models.

Mutational screening of the TP53 c.215G>A variant in the U87-DACH1-high glioblastoma cell line revealed that the mutation abolishes p53-mediated transcriptional activation of the CDKN1A promoter, thereby promoting uncontrolled proliferation.

Mutagenic exposure to doxorubicin induces apoptosis in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, a response that is attenuated when the TRAF2‑dominant‑negative construct is transfected into the same cellular context.
Mutations in the TP53 gene within the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line were found to reduce E‑cadherin expression, thereby enhancing invasion of glioblastoma cells in a Matrigel assay.
Mutation of the TP53 gene in the U87-DACH1-high cell line reduces p53‑mediated transcription of the BAX gene, thereby attenuating apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Mutation analysis of the TP53 c.215G>A variant in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line revealed a marked increase in apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment, linking the genetic alteration to drug sensitivity.
Mutation-induced activation of p53 in LNCaP cells treated with doxorubicin markedly up‑regulated the tumor‑suppressor gene p21, leading to G1 arrest and apoptosis.

Mutation screening of the TP53 gene in the CRISPR‑engineered Traf2DN‑tg B cell line revealed a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that induces apoptosis resistance and up‑regulates the chemokine CXCL10, thereby enhancing the invasiveness of the derived LNCaP cells toward the MCF‑7 breast cancer line.
Activation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway by overexpressing a Traf2DN‑tg B mutant in the PC3 cell line increases resistance to doxorubicin and promotes survival of malignant prostate cancer cells.
Activation‑induced apoptosis in the TRAF2‑dominant‑negative transgenic mouse model was confirmed by decreased BCL‑2 expression in the PC3 cell line harboring the TP53 c.68_69delAG variant.

Activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID) overexpression in U87-DACH1-high cells enhances homologous recombination repair of BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, thereby reducing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Activation‐dependent overexpression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX in the TRAF2DN‑TG‑B cell line was confirmed by quantitative RT‑PCR, revealing a significant increase compared with the parental LNCaP and PC3 controls and suggesting that TRAF2 inhibition sensitizes prostate cancer cells to TRAIL‑induced apoptosis.

The RAW‑264.7 macrophage cell line treated with the chemical entity doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in apoptosis, concomitant with up‑regulation of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53, and the induced expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 was markedly attenuated by pre‑treatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.

The THP‑1 macrophage cell line was treated with doxorubicin, resulting in up‑regulation of TP53 expression and apoptosis, while co‑treatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine partially rescued cell viability in a dose‑dependent manner.
The drug doxorubicin induced apoptosis in the RAW264.7 cell line by activating caspase‑3, a process that was further amplified when the cells were co‑treated with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis in RAW‑264.7 macrophages by down‑regulating the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2 and up‑regulating the tumor suppressor p53, leading to caspase‑3 activation.

RAW‑264.7 macrophages exposed to the chemical inhibitor LY294002 exhibited a dramatic up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α, an effect that was markedly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.
RAW264.7 macrophages treated with doxorubicin exhibit increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, a change that is attenuated by co‑incubation with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.
RAW 264.7 macrophages treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor IKK‑β exhibited reduced NF‑κB activation, leading to a significant decrease in IL‑6 secretion compared with untreated cells.

RAW_264.7 macrophages treated with the SNU-C2A-derived IL‑10 analogue showed a marked increase in the expression of the anti‑inflammatory gene IL‑1 receptor antagonist (IL‑1RA) compared with untreated THP‑1 cells, indicating a cell‑line–specific regulatory pathway.

THP‑1 macrophages treated with doxorubicin exhibit a dramatic up‑regulation of p53‑induced transcriptional targets, thereby linking the small‑molecule drug to the cell‑cycle arrest phenotype observed in this human monocytic cell line.

THPY-1, a murine hepatocyte cell line derived from C57BL/6 mice, secretes interleukin‑6 upon exposure to the Toll‑like receptor agonist LPS, thereby promoting STAT3 activation in co‑cultured RAW264.7 macrophages and enhancing the inflammatory cytokine milieu that drives fibrosis in liver tissue.

TH1 cytokine secretion was markedly enhanced in RAW264.7 cells transfected with the TNFAIP3 promoter variant c.−146C>T, linking the sequence variant to increased inflammation in the murine macrophage model.

TH17 differentiation was markedly enhanced in RAW264.7 cells treated with the cytokine IL‑23, while the concomitant activation of the transcription factor NF‑κB led to up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL10, a change that was confirmed by qPCR in THP‑1 and HT22 cultures and suggested a potential therapeutic target for inflammatory bowel disease.

In the RAW 264.7 macrophage model, LPS stimulation up‑regulates the transcription of TNF-α while simultaneously inducing a STAT3‑dependent expression of the chemokine CXCL10, a response that is attenuated by the small‑molecule inhibitor Stattic.

In RAW‑264.7 macrophages, the knock‑down of the inflammasome sensor NLRP3 by CRISPR/Cas9 not only reduced IL‑1β secretion but also diminished the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, confirming a direct regulatory link between NLRP3 activity and CXCL10 production in this murine cell line.

In THP‑1 cells, the CXCL4-mediated NF‑κB activation was amplified by the S‑adenosyl‑methionine donor, leading to increased secretion of IL‑1β and a concomitant up‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL.
In HT22 cells, the overexpression of the long‑noncoding RNA MALAT1 activates NF‑κB signaling, leading to increased IL‑6 secretion and enhanced resistance to glutamate‑induced apoptosis.

MT112 treatment of RAW264.7 cells activates NF‑κB signaling, amplifying IL‑6 production while concurrently suppressing the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby illustrating a dual modulatory effect on inflammatory and apoptotic pathways.

MT3 expression in RAW264.7 cells is up‑regulated by LPS stimulation and, in turn, drives NF‑κB‑dependent production of IL‑1β, illustrating a reciprocal feedback loop that amplifies the inflammatory response.

MT1-MMP expression was significantly upregulated in RAW264.7 cells following treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor Iressa, an effect that was mitigated by co‑treatment with the anti‑TNFα antibody adalimumab.

MT‑LTP activation in RAW‑264.7 macrophages cultured with the STAT3 inhibitor Stattic reduces IL‑6 secretion and upregulates the antioxidant gene NRF2, demonstrating a pharmacologic link between cytokine signaling, oxidative stress, and innate immune regulation.

Treatment of RAW264.7 macrophages with doxorubicin induces a dose‑dependent reduction in NF‑κB activity, while the same concentration has no effect on the viability of HEK293 cells, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific sensitivity to the drug.

Treatment with the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib induced apoptosis in the human melanoma cell line A375, whereas the same drug failed to inhibit proliferation of the resistant cell line M229, highlighting the role of the BRAF V600E mutation and its downstream MAPK signaling in determining therapeutic response.

Treatment‑induced apoptosis in RAW264.7 macrophages is accompanied by a marked down‑regulation of the NLRP3 inflammasome, a response that is potentiated by co‑treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor MCC950, which specifically targets the ATP‑binding pocket of NLRP3 in a concentration‑dependent manner.

Treatment and proliferation of RAW 264.7 macrophages exposed to ethanol were found to be regulated by the TP53‑dependent pathway, as confirmed by increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX in the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

Analysis of RAW​264.7 macrophages revealed that treatment with the chemical entity curcumin significantly down‑regulated the expression of the GeneOrGeneProduct NF‑κB, thereby reducing the production of the DiseaseOrPhenotypicFeature pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.

Analysis revealed that the p53‑activating compound doxorubicin induced apoptosis in RAW‑264.7 macrophage cells through upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, a response that was markedly attenuated in the THP‑1 monocyte‑derived macrophage line lacking functional p53.

Analysis showed that RAW264.7 macrophages treated with the SNU-C2A conditioned medium exhibited increased IL‑1β secretion, a response that was attenuated by the addition of the IL‑1 receptor antagonist anakinra.

Analysis in RAW_264.7 cells revealed that overexpression of the transcription factor CREB1 increases IL‑1β secretion through NF‑κB activation, thereby amplifying the inflammatory response to lipopolysaccharide stimulation.

Using RAW264.7 cells, we found that the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 is upregulated by ethanol treatment, revealing a dose‑dependent interaction between the chemical entity ethanol and the cellular immune response.

Using CRISPR‑Cas9 editing, the TP53 c.215G>A sequence variant was introduced into the human colorectal cancer cell line HT22, where it increased cisplatin sensitivity compared to the wild‑type HT22 line.

Using HEK293 cells stably expressing mutant TP53, we observed that the sequence variant c.215C>T enhances cell proliferation and upregulates VEGF expression, suggesting a direct oncogenic effect in this human embryonic kidney cell line.

Using the RAW264.7 macrophage cell line, we observed that treatment with the chemical entity curcumin induced apoptosis and down‑regulated the inflammatory gene TNF‑α, thereby mitigating the fever‑like response characteristic of lipopolysaccharide‑stimulated cells.

Stimulation of RAW 264.7 macrophages with the Toll-like receptor agonist LPS induced a rapid upregulation of the chemokine CXCL10, which in turn enhanced the adhesion of THP-1 monocytes to the endothelial cells of human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs), thereby providing a mechanistic link between innate immune activation and vascular inflammation.

Staphylococcal enterotoxin B stimulation of RAW264.7 macrophages upregulates IL‑6 secretion, a response that is markedly attenuated when the cells are pretreated with the selective STAT3 inhibitor, WP1066, illustrating a cell‑line‑specific cytokine regulatory pathway.

Staining of RAW‑264.7 cells with doxorubicin reveals a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species that triggers NF‑κB‑mediated transcription of the cytokine IL‑6, thereby enhancing the inflammatory response in this macrophage‑derived cell line.

Streptozotocin-treated RAW 264.7 cells exhibited increased IL‑1β secretion, which was markedly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine, demonstrating a protective effect of the compound against inflammatory activation in the murine macrophage cell line.

Oxidative‑stress‑induced apoptosis of RAW264.7 macrophages was attenuated by the mitochondrial‑targeted antioxidant, N‑acetylcysteine, which restored the reduced activity of the NF‑κB pathway and prevented the up‑regulation of pro‑inflammatory cytokines such as IL‑6 and TNF‑α.

Ox-LDL treatment of RAW264.7 macrophages upregulated LOX‑1 expression and promoted the release of IL‑1β, a process that was partially abrogated when the cells were pre‑treated with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.

Oxazolone treatment of RAW‑264.7 macrophages transfected with TP53 siRNA reduces NF‑κB activation and increases apoptosis, a phenomenon not observed in THP‑1 cells or in HEK293 cells exposed to the same concentration.

Oxactin treatment of RAW264.7 cells induces a robust NF‑κB activation that upregulates IL‑6 expression, mirroring the inflammatory cytokine profile observed in THP‑1‑derived macrophages upon LPS exposure.
