TREx‑293T cells engineered to overexpress the mutant TP53 R248W variant exhibit heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin, resulting in increased apoptosis and up‑regulation of the DNA‑damage‑response gene ATM, while the same mutation in RAW264.7 macrophages promotes a pro‑inflammatory phenotype through NF‑κB activation and secretion of IL‑6.
TR2A knockdown in RAW 264.7 cells markedly decreased LPS‑induced TNF‑α secretion, indicating that the TR2A protein regulates inflammatory signaling pathways in macrophage‑derived cell lines.

TR1‑α stimulation of RAW264.7 macrophages upregulated TNF‑α expression via NF‑κB signaling, whereas in THP‑1 cells the same stimulus induced IL‑10 production, highlighting divergent inflammatory responses between these two cell lines.

TRP53 knock‑in in RAW264.7 cells induces a pronounced inflammatory phenotype characterized by elevated NF‑κB activation, higher secretion of TNF‑α, and up‑regulation of the COX2 gene product compared to wild‑type RAW264.7.
Rituximab treatment of HT22 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant reduced ERK1/2 phosphorylation, suggesting a therapeutic potential for targeted breast cancer therapy.

Raman spectroscopy of RAW‑264.7 macrophages exposed to doxorubicin revealed increased reactive oxygen species production, which correlated with up‑regulation of the oxidative‑stress‑responsive gene Nrf2 and subsequent apoptosis.

R-2,3,4-trimethoxycinnamic acid treatment of RAW264.7 macrophages induced a dose‑dependent increase in IL‑1β secretion and up‑regulated the expression of the TLR4 gene, confirming a pro‑inflammatory response in this murine cell line.

RANKS of the tumor suppressor gene PTEN in the HEK293 cell line were significantly reduced after exposure to the carcinogenic chemical entity benzopyrene, suggesting that this exposure induces PTEN loss and promotes malignant transformation.

HIV‑infected THP‑1 cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor JAK2‑act, which targets the STAT5 signaling axis, showed a significant decrease in the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α compared with untreated THP‑1 cells.

HepG2 cells transfected with the mutant TP53 c.215G>A variant exhibited increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and reduced proliferation, confirming that the sequence variant promotes apoptosis in this human hepatoma cell line.

Heterozygous SNU‑C2A cells overexpressing the TP53 variant c.68_69delAG exhibit increased p53 protein stability, which in turn upregulates the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and sensitizes the cell line to doxorubicin-induced DNA damage.

Homozygous loss of the Dnmt3a gene in RAW264.7 macrophages causes a hypermethylated promoter of the IL1β gene, leading to an enhanced inflammatory response upon LPS stimulation in a C57BL/6 background.

Exposure of RAW~264.7 macrophages to the STAT3 inhibitor Stattic suppressed IL-6 production, an effect that was abolished when the cells were transduced with a constitutively active STAT3 mutant, confirming a direct regulatory role of STAT3 on cytokine secretion in this cell line.

Exposure to the BET inhibitor JQ1 induced a marked decrease in proliferation of RAW264.7 macrophages while simultaneously elevating the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNFα, suggesting that JQ1 modulates macrophage activation pathways in a cell‑line‑specific manner.

Exposure and long‑term culture of RAW‑264.7 macrophages with the small‑molecule inhibitor rapamycin not only suppressed mTOR activity but also induced a significant up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α, highlighting the cell‑line‑specific modulation of inflammatory signaling pathways.

Exposure analysis of RAW_264.7 macrophages revealed that the addition of doxorubicin induced a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of p53 protein, which in turn triggered apoptosis and was accompanied by a marked decrease in cell viability.
The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in THP‑1 cells dramatically increased the sensitivity of these cells to doxorubicin, leading to a marked rise in apoptosis compared with parental A549 cells.

The THP‑1 cell line was treated with doxorubicin, resulting in a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 expression that correlated with the appearance of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant and ultimately induced apoptosis in the human monocytic cells.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induces apoptosis in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells by up‑regulating TP53 expression, a response that is markedly attenuated in the A549 cell line due to an underlying BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

The MES-SA/Dx5 cell line, derived from a human uterine sarcoma, exhibits enhanced resistance to doxorubicin, a phenomenon linked to the upregulation of the ABCB1 gene product and increased efflux of the drug from the cells.
In MES‑SA/Dx5 cells, the overexpression of the CXCR4 gene product induces chemotaxis toward stromal cell‑derived factor‑1α, thereby enhancing invasion and metastasis in a murine xenograft model.
In the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, overexpression of the MDR1 transporter gene confers resistance to doxorubicin, which was confirmed by quantitative PCR and functional efflux assays.
In THP-1 cells, the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant reduces RAD51 expression, thereby increasing sensitivity to doxorubicin treatment and accelerating apoptosis in this human monocytic cell line.

In KRAS‑mutant MES‑SA/Dx5 cells, the overexpression of the drug‑resistant gene ABCB1 enhances doxorubicin efflux, thereby reducing apoptosis and contributing to the chemoresistance phenotype observed in this cell line.

MAST cells transfected with the KRAS G12V mutation showed increased ERK phosphorylation, which was markedly reduced when treated with the MEK inhibitor trametinib, a finding replicated in the KRAS‑mutant A549 and RKO cell lines.
MAA treatment increased apoptosis in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells by upregulating TP53 expression, thereby reducing cell survival and enhancing sensitivity to doxorubicin.

MASTRAL‑1, a genetically engineered derivative of the A549 cell line, overexpresses the KRAS G12D mutation and exhibits a markedly increased sensitivity to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, thereby demonstrating a clear genotype‑phenotype correlation in lung cancer research.

MAJ-1‐treatment of the chemoresistant MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line resulted in a significant upregulation of the DNA damage response gene TP53 and a concomitant decrease in the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby enhancing cell death in this gynecologic sarcoma model.
Mes‑SA/Dx5 cells harbor a KRAS G12D mutation that drives increased glycolysis and resistance to doxorubicin, a phenotype that is partially reversed by the mTOR inhibitor rapamycin.

Mesenchymal stem cells from the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line were transduced with a lentiviral vector encoding the TP53 gene, and the resulting colonies exhibited a marked reduction in proliferation compared with the parental THP‑1 cells, indicating that TP53 over‑expression can suppress growth in these human cell lines.

Mes‐SA/Dx5 cells overexpress the multidrug‐resistance protein P‑gp, and when treated with doxorubicin, they exhibit reduced apoptosis and increased DNA repair activity compared with the drug‑sensitive THP‑1 monocyte‑derived macrophage cell line.

Mes-1 cells and the drug doxorubicin together induced a strong apoptosis response in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, whereas the same drug had a moderate effect on the A549 cell line and the THP‑1 monocytes.
RNA interference targeting the TP53 gene in MES-SA/Dx5 cells reduced cisplatin resistance and increased apoptosis, whereas the same TP53 knockdown in THP-1 cells had no effect on drug sensitivity.

RNA‑seq of the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line revealed that the up‑regulation of the drug‑resistance gene ABCB1, driven by the transcription factor NF‑κB, is accompanied by increased phosphorylation of the PI3K‑AKT signaling pathway, suggesting a potential target for overcoming doxorubicin resistance in this uterine sarcoma model.

RNA‐seq of the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line revealed that up‑regulated TP53 transcripts correlate with increased expression of the DNA repair enzyme ERCC1, suggesting a compensatory pathway that may influence cisplatin sensitivity in this cisplatin‑resistant sarcoma model.

RNAi-mediated knockdown of the ABCB1 gene in the THP‑1 cell line reduced doxorubicin efflux and increased intracellular drug accumulation, thereby enhancing cytotoxicity in comparison to the parental THP‑1 cells.

A549 cells engineered to express the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin, as the loss of the BRCA1 protein impairs DNA repair pathways and enhances drug-induced apoptosis.

A genome‑wide CRISPR screen in MES‑SA/Dx5 revealed that loss of the ATPase gene XPC impairs DNA repair and increases sensitivity to doxorubicin, suggesting a potential therapeutic vulnerability in this uterine sarcoma cell line.
A xenograft of MES‑SA/Dx5 cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 showed a marked reduction in tumor growth, accompanied by down‑regulation of the AKT pathway and increased apoptosis.

A pharmacogenomic screen revealed that the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, which harbors a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, exhibits markedly higher sensitivity to doxorubicin compared with the drug‑resistant THP‑1 and A549 lines, suggesting that the sequence variant modulates apoptotic signaling pathways in ovarian carcinoma cells.

Gene knockdown in MES‑SA/Dx5 and THP‑1 cells revealed that loss of the transcription factor NF‑κB reduces secretion of interleukin‑6 and attenuates the chemoresistance phenotype driven by the MDR1 gene.

Gene editing of the KRAS G12D variant in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells via CRISPR/Cas9 reduced colony formation and induced apoptosis, indicating that the oncogenic allele drives proliferation in this uterine sarcoma model.

Gene‑silencing of TP53 in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line reduced doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis and increased expression of the pro‑survival protein BCL‑2, highlighting a potential mechanism of chemoresistance in this uterine sarcoma model.
Gene TP53 mutations in the MES‑SA/Dx5 ovarian sarcoma cell line lead to increased expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, rendering these cells resistant to doxorubicin‑induced cell death.

Mutation of TP53 in the MES-SA/Dx5 cell line leads to heightened apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, whereas the same variant in the THP-1 line confers resistance by upregulating BCL-2 expression.

Mutation‑guided CRISPR/Cas9 editing of the KRAS exon‑2 locus in the KRAS‑dependent A549 cell line generated a novel sequence variant (c.35G>T, p.G12V) that conferred increased growth factor–independent proliferation and resistance to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, thereby establishing a model for studying targeted therapy resistance in non‑small cell lung cancer.

Mutation-specific siRNA targeting the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line dramatically reduced cell viability while simultaneously enhancing caspase‑3 activation, indicating that loss of p53 function sensitizes these cells to apoptotic stimuli.

Mutation analysis in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells revealed that a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant reduced homologous recombination efficiency, correlating with increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging drug doxorubicin.
Curcumin treatment of MES‑SA/Dx5 cells induces apoptosis through up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor TP53, thereby reducing proliferation of this multidrug‑resistant sarcoma cell line.

Curative treatment of temozolomide-resistant SF188 glioma cells was achieved by combining the DNA methyltransferase inhibitor decitabine with the PI3K/AKT pathway inhibitor rapamycin, thereby restoring apoptosis in the MES-SA/Dx5 uterine sarcoma cell line and reducing tumor growth in vivo.

Curvature of the MAPK pathway in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line was amplified by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, causing a marked increase in ERK1/2 phosphorylation that was reversed by the MEK inhibitor trametinib.

Curcuminoids selectively inhibited proliferation of MES‑SA/Dx5 and THP‑1 cells by inducing apoptosis and down‑regulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby demonstrating a potential therapeutic approach for multidrug‑resistant sarcoma and leukemic cell lines.

THP‑1 cells treated with the KRAS‑G12D mutant cDNA exhibit elevated ERK phosphorylation, which in turn drives the up‑regulation of the oncogenic transcription factor c‑Myc and promotes cell proliferation in the presence of the small‑molecule inhibitor trametinib.

THCP‑1 cells, a THP‑1 derivative, showed increased IL‑6 secretion after treatment with the small molecule VX‑765, whereas the A549 cell line exhibited a dose‑dependent reduction in EGFR phosphorylation when exposed to the same inhibitor.
TH17 cytokine IL-17A induces CYP3A4 expression in the KRAS‑mutated A549 cell line, amplifying doxorubicin resistance and correlating with poor survival in lung adenocarcinoma patients.

THG-1 cells, a subline of the A549 lung carcinoma cell line, were shown to acquire a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that conferred resistance to doxorubicin while enhancing sensitivity to the small‑molecule CDK4/6 inhibitor palbociclib.

Mutant TP53 expression in the MES‑SA/Dx5 ovarian sarcoma cell line, induced by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, leads to up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and sensitizes cells to doxorubicin treatment.

Mutational analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the MES-SA/Dx5 cell line revealed a significant reduction in homologous recombination repair activity, correlating with increased sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin.

Mutagenic exposure to doxorubicin induces apoptosis and a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 protein levels in MES‑SA/Dx5 and A549 cells, while the same treatment reduces the proliferation of THP‑1 macrophages and upregulates inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 secretion.
Mutations in the TP53 gene were found to increase doxorubicin resistance in the MES-SA/Dx5 and THP-1 cell lines, leading to reduced apoptosis and enhanced cell proliferation.

MTBE-treated MES‑SA/Dx5 cells exhibited a marked up‑regulation of the drug‑resistance protein ABCB1, a change that was abrogated when the cells were co‑treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, suggesting that PI3K signaling mediates MTBE‑induced drug resistance in this ovarian sarcoma cell line.

MT‑cancer gene overexpression in the chemotherapy‑resistant MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line leads to up‑regulated BCL‑2, promoting apoptosis resistance and suggesting a potential target for adjuvant doxorubicin therapy.

MT-4 cells overexpressing CYP1A1 in THP-1 monocytes demonstrated increased production of reactive oxygen species that, in turn, induced the transcription of the p21 gene, resulting in G1 arrest and a higher rate of apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.
MTF‑1 overexpression in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells activates the NF‑κB pathway, leading to increased IL‑8 secretion and enhanced resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.
HELA cells treated with doxorubicin exhibit increased TP53 phosphorylation and apoptosis, whereas THP‑1 monocytes exposed to the same drug show reduced NF‑κB activation and IL‑6 secretion.

HEK293T cells were transfected with a plasmid encoding the CRISPR‑Cas9 system to introduce the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant into A549 cells, resulting in decreased BRCA1 protein levels and increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

HELG-1 cells, a subline of THP-1, exhibit heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis via upregulation of p53, whereas the A549 cell line demonstrates an intrinsic resistance mediated by overexpression of MDR1.

HEL5‑P cells, a subline of A549, display a KRAS G12D sequence variant that enhances ERK signaling and increases resistance to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, a finding confirmed by western blot analysis of phospho‑MEK and phospho‑ERK in the MES‑SA/Dx5 and THP‑1 cell lines.

Expression of the DNA repair enzyme ERCC1 in the drug‑resistant MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line was dramatically suppressed by the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the USP7 gene, resulting in increased sensitivity to cisplatin treatment.

Expression analysis of the TP53 gene in the MES-SA/Dx5 and A549 cell lines revealed that the c.215C>G SequenceVariant markedly downregulated p53 protein levels, thereby promoting chemoresistance to doxorubicin in both cell types.

Expression levels of the ERα gene in the hormone‑responsive cell line MCF‑7 were markedly increased when the cells were treated with the selective estrogen receptor modulator tamoxifen, a change that was accompanied by a down‑regulation of the pro‑survival protein BCL‑2 and a concomitant activation of caspase‑3, thereby illustrating the molecular basis for tamoxifen‑induced apoptosis in breast cancer.

Expression profiling in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells revealed that up‑regulation of the drug‑resistance gene ABCB1 was accompanied by increased phosphorylation of ERK1/2, suggesting that the MAPK pathway contributes to doxorubicin tolerance.

Traf2DN-tg mice with an induced loss of Traf2 expression exhibited markedly reduced proliferation of the U87-DACH1-low glioblastoma cells, confirming the tumour-suppressive role of Traf2 in this cell line.

Tafamidis treatment of a patient harboring the TTR V30M mutation significantly reduced amyloid deposition in the liver, as evidenced by decreased transthyretin levels in a cultured MEF cell line engineered to express the mutant protein.

Treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line exhibited a marked reduction in phosphorylated AKT while the MEF cells overexpressing Traf2DN‑tg displayed an increased sensitivity to TNF‑α‑induced apoptosis.

Tissue‑specific expression of the transcription factor DACH1 in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line was shown to be rescued by over‑expression of the NF‑κB inhibitor Traf2DN‑tg, thereby reducing proliferation and increasing sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
The CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line resulted in increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby sensitizing these glioma cells to doxorubicin treatment.

The immortalized MEF cell line engineered to express a dominant‑negative Traf2 (Traf2DN-tg) exhibits increased TNF‑α–induced NF‑κB activation and heightened apoptosis compared with wild‑type MEF controls.

The U87‑DACH1‑low cell line, when transfected with a CRISPR‑Cas9 plasmid targeting the TP53 gene, exhibited a significant increase in apoptotic markers, confirming that DACH1 down‑regulation sensitizes glioblastoma cells to p53‑mediated cell death.

The HK‑2 cell line, which was transduced with a CRISPR/Cas9‑mediated knockout of the TFAP2B gene, displayed a marked reduction in epithelial‑mesenchymal transition markers and a concomitant increase in the expression of the tumor suppressor PTEN, indicating a potential therapeutic avenue for diabetic nephropathy.
A knockdown of DUX4 in U87‑DACH1‑low cells diminishes EGFR phosphorylation and reduces invasive migration, suggesting DUX4 as a potential therapeutic target for glioblastoma.

A genetic screen of the KRAS mutant MIN6 β‑cell line revealed that CRISPR‑mediated loss of the regulatory protein TRAF2DN-tg enhances insulin secretion and reduces apoptosis, suggesting TRAF2DN as a potential therapeutic target in pancreatic β‑cell dysfunction.
A CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knockout of PIK3R1 in the U87-DACH1-low cell line resulted in reduced PI3K/AKT signaling, increased apoptosis, and heightened sensitivity to the PI3K inhibitor LY294002.
A transient overexpression of the E3 ligase UBE3A in U87-DACH1-low cells induces apoptosis through the TRAF2-mediated NF‑κB pathway, thereby reducing U87-DACH1-low invasion and migration in vitro.

In the HK‑2 cell line, overexpression of the mutant p53^R175H variant led to increased cellular senescence and a dramatic up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, mirroring the inflammatory microenvironment observed in human prostate adenocarcinoma tissues.

In U87‑DACH1‑low cells, knockdown of DACH1 by CRISPR‑Cas9 induces a cell‑cycle arrest in G1 and upregulates the p53‑target gene p21, thereby reducing proliferation and enhancing sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
In MIN6 cells, overexpression of the TRAF2 dominant-negative construct (Traf2DN) markedly suppresses insulin secretion by disrupting the PI3K/Akt signaling cascade.
In cultured HK-2 cells, knockdown of the transcription factor NF‑κB enhances the expression of the antioxidant gene NQO1, thereby protecting the renal epithelium from cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.
BRAF V600E‑mutated U87‑DACH1‑low cells exposed to erlotinib exhibit a marked reduction in phospho‑ERK1/2 signaling, concomitant with increased apoptosis mediated by caspase‑3 activation.

Bacterial exposure of the kidney epithelial cell line HK‑2 induced a STAT3‑mediated up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL10, which in turn promoted the recruitment of THP‑1 macrophages to the site of inflammation.

BEP2D cells engineered with a Traf2DN-tg construct exhibited markedly reduced NF‑κB activation, leading to attenuated secretion of interleukin‑6 and a concomitant increase in apoptosis compared with parental BEP2D cells.
Benzaldehyde treatment induced apoptosis in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line through activation of the TP53 pathway, as evidenced by increased p21 expression and caspase‑3 cleavage.
MIN6 cells overexpressing a truncated TRAF2DN construct exhibit markedly reduced NF‑κB activation and increased apoptosis when challenged with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

MIN5 cells overexpressing KRAS^G12D exhibit a markedly higher migratory capacity than KRAS^WT-transfected MIN5 cells, suggesting that oncogenic KRAS signaling promotes invasion in this pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma model.

MIN2 cells carrying a TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct (Traf2DN‑tg) displayed markedly reduced NF‑κB activation and a concomitant decline in IL‑6 secretion compared with the parental MIN6 line, suggesting that TRAF2 signaling is required for cytokine production in pancreatic β‑cell models.

MIN-6 cells treated with the TRF2 dominant‑negative construct (Traf2DN‑tg) exhibit a marked decrease in insulin mRNA levels, indicating that TRF2 negatively regulates insulin transcription in pancreatic β‑cell lines.
U87‑DACH1‑low cells treated with the TRAF2DN‑tg construct exhibited reduced invasion, correlating with decreased MMP‑9 expression and lower Hs578T‑derived tumorigenicity.

U‑87‑DACH1‑low cells treated with the CXCL12 antagonist AMD3100 exhibit a dramatic reduction in CXCR4‑mediated invasion, confirming that DACH1 down‑regulation promotes CXCL12/CXCR4‑driven metastasis in this glioblastoma cell line.

U-87 DACH1‑low cells treated with the DNA‑binding inhibitor doxorubicin displayed a marked reduction in NF‑κB activity, confirming that loss of DACH1 enhances chemotherapeutic sensitivity through suppression of the TRAF2‑dependent survival pathway.
U86-DACH1-low cells overexpressing TRAF2DN-tg exhibit increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, which induces apoptosis through a p53-dependent pathway.

Exogenous overexpression of the transcription factor DACH1 in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line (U87) significantly reduces the proliferation rate and induces apoptosis through down‑regulation of the BCL‑2 gene product while simultaneously increasing the expression of the tumor suppressor p53.
Exposing U87-DACH1-low cells to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin induced p53‑dependent apoptosis, which was partially rescued by overexpressing the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL.
Examination of the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line revealed that DACH1 knockdown up‑regulates VEGFA transcription, thereby enhancing angiogenic signaling in glioblastoma cells.

Exogenic overexpression of the transcription factor DACH1 in U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cells synergistically enhances the cytotoxic activity of doxorubicin, leading to a significant reduction of cell viability and induction of apoptosis.

Treatment of U87-DACH1-low cells with the histone deacetylase inhibitor valproic acid induced a pronounced up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor p53, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing proliferation of this glioblastoma cell line.

Treatment with the mTOR inhibitor RAD001 reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioma cell line while up‑regulating PTEN expression and decreasing phosphorylated AKT levels, thereby confirming the therapeutic potential of targeting the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway in this cell line.

Treatment-resistant KRAS-driven pancreatic cancer cells derived from the DUCaP cell line exhibit elevated expression of the DNA repair enzyme FANCD2, whereas knockdown of FANCD2 in these cells leads to increased sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinker doxorubicin and induces apoptosis through p53‑dependent pathways.

Treatment efficacy of the novel PI3K inhibitor LY294002 was markedly enhanced in the U87-DACH1-low cell line, where knockdown of DACH1 cooperated with loss-of-function TP53 mutations to sensitize glioblastoma cells to apoptosis.

Knocking‑down Traf2DN in the MEF cell line reduces NF‑κB activation and sensitizes the cells to apoptosis induced by the small molecule inhibitor rapamycin, demonstrating a therapeutic interaction between the genetic manipulation and the chemical entity in a mammalian cellular model.
Knockdown of DUCaP in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line markedly reduced AKT phosphorylation, thereby increasing TRAF2‑dominant negative‑expressing MEF cell death under hypoxic conditions.

Knox et al. observed that treating the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line with the small molecule inhibitor GSK‑2985A induced apoptosis through a TRAF2‑dependent pathway, a finding that was mirrored in the MEF and SH‑SY5Y neuronal models, thereby suggesting a conserved mechanism of action across diverse cell lines.
Knocked‑down of TRAF2 in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line leads to up‑regulation of NF‑κB‑dependent IL‑8 secretion, which in turn promotes chemotactic migration of Hs578T breast cancer cells.
Activation of the NF‑κB pathway in U87‑DACH1‑low cells by TNF‑α treatment increases the expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL2L1, thereby enhancing resistance to temozolomide-induced cell death.

Activation with the MEF-derived conditioned medium enhances the proliferation of the human renal tubular HK‑2 cell line and concurrently up‑regulates the expression of the insulin‑sensitive GLUT4 transporter, suggesting a metabolic crosstalk mediated by secreted growth factors.
Activation by the STAT3 pathway in U87-DACH1-low cells induces the transcription of VEGFA, thereby promoting angiogenesis and enhancing tumor invasion.

Activation-induced apoptosis of the U87‑DACH1‑low glioma cell line following treatment with the CD95 ligand was accompanied by a marked up‑regulation of the BCL2‑associated agonist of cell death gene and a decrease in the level of phospho‑STAT3 protein.

Mutating the TP53 gene in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line induces a loss of p53‑dependent apoptosis and increases resistance to doxorubicin, illustrating the interplay between gene variant, cell line phenotype, and chemotherapeutic response.

Mutations in the TP53 gene in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line (U87‑DACH1‑low) were shown to enhance resistance to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin (DOX), thereby promoting cell survival under oxidative stress conditions.

Mutagenic exposure to doxorubicin in the HK-2 cell line triggered a dose‑dependent upregulation of TP53 and induced apoptosis, while the same treatment in the U87‑DACH1‑low line resulted in increased VEGFA secretion and enhanced invasion.
Mutant p53 expression in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line enhances EMT‑associated invasion through upregulation of the chemokine CXCL8, thereby promoting metastatic potential in vivo.

Mucin secretion by the U87-DACH1-low cell line was significantly enhanced when co‑treated with the small molecule kinase inhibitor erlotinib, revealing a potential therapeutic avenue for glioblastoma patients whose tumors overexpress EGFR.

MIR‐cancer cells were transduced with a CRISPR/Cas9‐edited TP53 allele and, compared with parental U87‑DACH1‑low cells, displayed heightened apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, indicating a cell‑line‑specific susceptibility to DNA‑damage‑induced death.

Mice bearing the Traf2DN‑tg allele exhibited a pronounced upregulation of the NF‑κB target gene IκBα, which correlated with reduced tumor burden in the U87‑DACH1‑low xenografts and confirmed the protective role of TRAF2 inhibition in the Hs578T breast cancer model.

Molecular profiling of the U87-DACH1-low glioblastoma cell line revealed that ectopic expression of TRAF2DN transgene downregulates downstream NF‑κB signaling, thereby reducing cell migration and invasion compared to the parental U87 line.
Hyperactivation of the PI3K/Akt pathway in U87‑DACH1‑low cells promotes resistance to temozolomide by upregulating MCL‑1 expression, thereby reducing apoptosis in this glioblastoma model.

Hyperpolarization of the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line by CRISPR‑induced TP53 knockout increased its invasive capacity in a collagen matrix, mimicking the metastatic phenotype observed in primary breast tumors.

Hyperactive TRAF2 signaling in the Traf2DN-tg mouse model drives NF‑κB activation, which in turn upregulates the chemokine CXCL1, promoting recruitment of Hs578T tumor‑derived macrophages and enhancing angiogenesis.

Hyperphosphorylation of the p53 pathway in U87‑DACH1‑low cells leads to increased resistance to temozolomide, whereas MEF cells with the TRAF2DN‑tg construct exhibit heightened apoptosis under the same treatment.

The CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knockout of TP53 in HCT‑116 cells reduced colony‑forming ability and increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, confirming TP53 as a key regulator of DNA‑damage response in this colorectal carcinoma cell line.

The HCT‑116 cell line, when exposed to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, exhibits a marked increase in TP53‑mediated apoptosis, revealing a potential therapeutic vulnerability for combination treatment with the microtubule stabilizer paclitaxel.
The expression of the tumor suppressor TP53 in the HeLa cell line was markedly up‑regulated following treatment with the DNA‑crosslinker doxorubicin, leading to G1 arrest and apoptosis.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis in the tsA201 cell line, whereas the same drug showed no effect on the HeLa and HCT‑116 cell lines, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific response to DNA damage.

In tsA201 cells, overexpression of the TP53 gene product induces a robust G1/S arrest that is accompanied by up‑regulation of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21 and a marked decrease in the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

In the tsA201 cell line, overexpression of the oncogenic KRAS variant G12V induces sustained MAPK signaling, causing proliferation that can be curtailed by the MEK inhibitor trametinib, while CRISPR‑mediated disruption of the TP53 gene in the same cells enhances drug resistance and promotes tumorigenic growth.

In a recent screen, CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the HCT‑116 cell line resulted in increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, highlighting a potential synthetic lethal interaction between the p53 pathway and DNA‑damage‑inducing chemotherapy.

In transduced tsA201 cells, the CRISPR‑mediated introduction of a TP53 c.215G>A (p.R72P) sequence variant markedly reduced p53‑dependent apoptosis and conferred resistance to doxorubicin compared with wild‑type HeLa cells.

Reactivation of the PI3K/AKT pathway in the tsA201 cell line following treatment with the chemical entity rapamycin led to a significant increase in cell proliferation, confirming that rapamycin acts as a molecular switch in this model.

Recombinant lentiviral transduction of the tsA201 cell line with a plasmid encoding the mutant TP53 c.215C>G variant significantly enhanced the expression of the cell cycle regulator p21, thereby inducing G1 arrest and attenuating cell proliferation.

Reconstitution of the TP53 c.215C>A variant in the tsA201 cell line revealed a reduced p53 transcriptional activity that enhanced resistance to doxorubicin, whereas the same mutation in the HeLa cell line increased apoptosis via caspase‑3 activation.

Re-expressing the HCT‑116 KRAS G12D allele in the tsA201 cell line reduces colony‑forming efficiency and activates p53‑dependent apoptosis, illustrating how a sequence variant can rewire signaling pathways in a cancer‑derived cell line.

TSA201 cells overexpressing mutant TP53 exhibit heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis, a response that is further amplified when the drug is combined with the DNA‑crosslinker cisplatin.

TS24 cells, a derivative of the tsA201 cell line, exhibited increased proliferation after treatment with the chemical entity cycloheximide, while the HCT‑116 cell line displayed enhanced apoptosis when exposed to the same compound, indicating a differential regulatory response in these distinct cell line models.

TS‑A201 cells overexpressing the mutant EGFR‑L858R exhibit heightened sensitivity to erlotinib, a result that parallels the drug resistance observed in the PC‑3 prostate cancer cell line carrying the PTEN‑loss phenotype.

TS-201 cells exposed to doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent decrease in viability that was partially rescued by co‑treatment with the autophagy inhibitor chloroquine, indicating that autophagy mediates resistance in this cell line.

siRNA-mediated knockdown of TP53 in the tsA201 cell line reduces E2F1 transcriptional activity and consequently suppresses proliferation of HCT-116 cells while increasing caspase‑3 activation, thereby demonstrating a differential response to apoptotic signaling between the two cell lines.
siRNAs targeting TP53 in tsA201 cells decreased cell cycle arrest, while in HeLa cells they promoted apoptosis through increased p21 and Bax expression.
si‑RNA knockdown of TP53 in the tsA201 cell line markedly increased apoptosis, whereas overexpression of BCL‑2 in HCT‑116 cells attenuated the same apoptotic response.

sirolimus treatment of the tsA201 cell line markedly reduced mTOR signaling, leading to decreased proliferation and increased apoptosis, while the same drug exhibited a dose‑dependent cytotoxic effect in the HCT‑116 model, thereby confirming its therapeutic potential for colorectal carcinoma.

Administration of the CRISPR/Cas9 system targeting TP53 in tsA201 cells induced a pronounced decrease in cell proliferation and an increase in p53‑dependent apoptosis, confirming the gene’s tumor‑suppressive role in this neural‑derived cell line.

Administration and cytotoxicity assays in the tsA201, HeLa, and HCT-116 cell lines revealed that the novel small‑molecule inhibitor of the PI3K pathway induced apoptosis through activation of caspase‑3 and down‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL.

Administration to tsA201 cells of the synthetic oligonucleotide targeting the TP53 promoter markedly reduced proliferation and increased apoptosis, confirming the dependence of these cancer cells on intact TP53 signaling.

Administration‑induced apoptosis of the PC3 prostate cancer cell line was markedly enhanced by the novel kinase inhibitor gefitinib, which specifically down‑regulated EGFR expression and triggered caspase‑3 activation in the presence of the EGF‑rich conditioned medium from HeLa cells.
Mutation of TP53 in the tsA201 cell line results in increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and sensitizes the cells to doxorubicin‑induced cell death.

Mutation burden in the TP53 gene of the tsA201 cell line was found to correlate with the increased sensitivity of this line to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, mirroring the response observed in the PC3 prostate cancer cell line.
Mutation analysis of the TP53 gene in the HCT‑116 cell line revealed a novel c.215G>A (p.Gly72Arg) sequence variant that enhances the apoptotic response to doxorubicin treatment.

Mutation abundance of the EGFR exon19 deletion in the CSF of patients with a PC3 xenograft model was quantified, revealing a significant correlation between the mutation load and the tumor cell viability measured in the cell line.
Exposure of the tsA201 cell line to doxorubicin induced a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein PUMA, thereby triggering caspase‑3 activation and apoptosis.

Exposure to low‑dose doxorubicin in the tsA201 cell line induced a dose‑dependent increase in apoptosis and up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, confirming its utility as a model for studying drug‑induced cytotoxicity in cancer cells.

Exposure experiments using the tsA201 cell line revealed that transfection of the mutated TP53 allele (c.215G>A) dramatically increased the expression of the cell‑cycle arrest protein p21 in a dose‑dependent manner.

Exposure and subsequent transcriptomic profiling of tsA201 and HeLa cells revealed that the up‑regulated gene TP53 directly binds the promoter of the miRNA‑122 host gene, a finding that was confirmed by chromatin‑immunoprecipitation and quantitative RT‑PCR.

A chemokine receptor CXCR4 knock‑out in tsA201 cells reduces paclitaxel‑induced apoptosis by down‑regulating the AKT pathway, thereby revealing a potential resistance mechanism in this neuroblastoma‑derived cell line.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knock‑out of the TP53 gene in the tsA201 cell line led to a significant increase in the proliferation rate and up‑regulation of the Cyclin‑D1 protein, confirming TP53’s role in cell‑cycle control.

A recent screen revealed that the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in the tsA201 cell line drastically increases the expression of the DNA‑repair enzyme RAD51, thereby reducing γ‑H2AX foci formation after doxorubicin‑induced DNA damage.

A dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species observed in tsA201 cells carrying the TP53 c.215G>A variant was mitigated by treatment with the antioxidant curcumin, demonstrating a protective interaction between the sequence variant and the chemical entity in this cell line.

Mutagenic exposure to the carcinogen benzo[a]pyrene in the HCT‑116 cell line induces p53 phosphorylation and upregulates the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21, thereby triggering G1 cell‑cycle arrest.

Mutating the TP53 exon in the tsA201 cell line, which is a derivative of HeLa, induces an elevated expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL, thereby conferring resistance to cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.

Mutational analysis of the KRAS G12D allele in the tsA201 and HCT‑116 cell lines revealed that the oncogene drives differential expression of the PI3K‑AKT pathway, with the G12D mutation in tsA201 producing a statistically significant increase in phospho‑AKT levels compared to the wild‑type HCT‑116 background.
Mutant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in HeLa cells activates the p53‑dependent DNA damage response, leading to apoptosis and reduced proliferation of the tumor‑derived line.

RNA polymerase II occupancy at the TP53 promoter was markedly increased in tsA201 cells treated with doxorubicin, suggesting that this drug induces transcriptional up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene in a cell‑type‑specific manner.
RNA‑seq analysis of the MC‑IXC cell line revealed that the TP53 p.R273H sequence variant induces over‑expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin treatment.
RNAi-mediated knockdown of the TP53 gene in the tsA201 cell line reduced the expression of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21, thereby enhancing proliferation rates of the cells.

RNA sequencing of the PC3 cell line revealed that CRISPR‑generated KRAS G12D (SequenceVariant) mutations up‑regulate the expression of the oncogenic protein KRAS, a GeneOrGeneProduct, thereby enhancing proliferation of this prostate carcinoma CellLine.

Molecular characterization of the tsA201 plasmid in HEK293T cells revealed that co‑transfection with the HCT‑116‑derived miR‑200c expression construct markedly suppressed epithelial‑mesenchymal transition markers, confirming the regulatory role of miR‑200c in this colorectal cancer cell line.

Methyltransferase inhibition by decitabine synergistically induced apoptosis in HeLa cells harboring the TP53 c.215G>A variant, revealing a cell‑line‑specific epigenetic vulnerability that was absent in the HCT‑116 model.
Mitochondrial dysfunction in tsA201 cells is exacerbated by the overexpression of the mutant mitochondrial gene POLG, causing increased ROS production and apoptosis.

MTS-1 and tsA201 cells treated with doxorubicin showed a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 phosphorylation, indicating that the drug induces a DNA damage response that may sensitize these cell lines to apoptosis.

HeLa cells overexpressing TP53 exhibited increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, whereas the same TP53‑overexpressing phenotype in HCT‑116 cells conferred resistance to the same drug.

He-La cells treated with the novel small‑molecule inhibitor MC‑IXC exhibited a dose‑dependent decrease in proliferation, accompanied by up‑regulation of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53 and a corresponding increase in apoptotic markers.
Heparanase overexpression in the PC3 cell line promotes invasion and correlates with increased MMP9 secretion, thereby enhancing metastatic potential in prostate cancer models.

HeLo cells, a derivative of HeLa, were engineered with CRISPR-Cas9 to introduce the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, and the resulting BRCA1^delAG cells exhibited increased sensitivity to doxorubicin compared to the wild‑type HeLa line.

Silenced TP53 in the tsA201 cell line dramatically increased the phosphorylation of ATM, which in turn activated the DNA‑damage response and inhibited proliferation of HCT‑116 cells exposed to doxorubicin.

Silencing of TP53 in the tsA201 cell line led to a marked increase in resistance to doxorubicin, whereas reintroduction of wild‑type TP53 restored drug sensitivity and induced apoptosis in the same cells.

Silently, the CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated deletion of the promoter region of the TP53 gene in tsA201 cells was shown to up‑regulate MDM2 expression, thereby dampening p53‑dependent apoptosis and promoting cellular proliferation.

Silvestrol induces apoptosis in the tsA201 cell line by disrupting eIF4A‑dependent translation initiation and simultaneously down‑regulating the oncogenic MYC transcript, thereby attenuating proliferation signals in this human embryonic kidney–derived cell culture.

U87‑DACH1‑high cells treated with the NF‑κB inhibitor BAY‑11‑7082 exhibited a significant reduction in Cyclin‑D1 expression, confirming that DACH1 over‑expression suppresses cell‑cycle progression in this glioblastoma cell line.

U‑87‑DACH1‑high cells exposed to doxorubicin exhibited a pronounced increase in TP53‑mediated apoptosis, whereas COS‑7 cells overexpressing the same compound displayed a comparable up‑regulation of p21 in a dose‑dependent fashion.

U6-22 cells, a derivative of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, exhibited markedly increased migration and invasion upon overexpression of the transcription factor TWIST1, while simultaneous CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the E-cadherin gene in the same line led to a pronounced reduction in cell‑cell adhesion, confirming that E‑cadherin loss facilitates TWIST1‑driven epithelial‑mesenchymal transition in this model.
U872-DACH1‑high cells overexpress the transcription factor DACH1, leading to increased expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and reduced proliferation of the glioblastoma cell line U87‑MG.

In U87‑DACH1‑high cells, overexpression of DACH1 induces a transcriptional program that increases the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, thereby enhancing recruitment of RAW264.7 macrophages and promoting an inflammatory microenvironment that accelerates tumor cell invasion.

In the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, overexpression of DACH1 markedly reduced the proliferation rate and increased apoptosis through down‑regulation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, confirming its tumor‑suppressive role in human astrocytic malignancies.
In HeLa cells, knockdown of TP53 by CRISPR-Cas9 induces a DNA damage–dependent senescence program that is alleviated by treatment with the DNA repair enhancer, caffeine.

In COS‑7 cells engineered to express a constitutively active Akt, the overexpression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 synergistically reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis, highlighting a potential therapeutic target for cancers such as U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma.

The U87-DACH1-high cell line, engineered to overexpress DACH1, exhibited increased sensitivity to temozolomide and induced apoptosis mediated by upregulation of the tumor suppressor gene PTEN in comparison to the parental U87MG line.

The H446 cell line harboring the TP53 R175H mutation was shown to be highly resistant to doxorubicin, whereas co‑treatment with the PI3K inhibitor GDC‑0941 markedly induced apoptosis and decreased AKT phosphorylation in this glioblastoma model.

The engineered U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line exhibits increased invasion through collagen type I matrices, a phenotype that is suppressed by the addition of the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, which down‑regulates the CXCR4 receptor expressed on these cells.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in U87‑DACH1‑high cells led to upregulation of the cell‑cycle inhibitor p21 and a significant reduction in colony‑forming ability compared with the TP53‑wild‑type U87‑MG cells.

H444, a CRISPR/Cas9‑engineered derivative of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, exhibited increased phosphorylation of STAT3 and enhanced resistance to doxorubicin compared with the parental U87‑MG cells, implicating DACH1 overexpression in modulating chemoresistance mechanisms.

HepG2 cells overexpressing the KRAS G12D mutation secrete higher levels of VEGFA, a finding that correlates with the increased proliferation of U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cells treated with the VEGFR2 inhibitor pazopanib.

Heterozygous TRF2DN‑tg B RAW264.7 cells exposed to doxorubicin exhibit a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of TP53‑mediated apoptosis, paralleling the heightened cell‑death phenotype observed in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.
H446 cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 exhibit reduced phosphorylation of AKT and increased apoptosis, confirming the drug’s therapeutic potential in this glioblastoma cell line.

BETV-7 cells, a genetically engineered variant of the U87-DACH1-high glioblastoma cell line, exhibit markedly increased phosphorylation of STAT3, which is further amplified by treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin and correlated with elevated expression of the oncogenic gene MYC.

BETWEEN the U87‑DACH1‑high glioma cell line and the RAW264.7 macrophage model, stimulation with the cytokine TNF‑α upregulated the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, illustrating a cell‑line–specific inflammatory signaling axis.

BET2 overexpression in U87‑DACH1‑high cells synergistically enhances IL‑6 secretion, thereby promoting a pro‑inflammatory tumor microenvironment that accelerates tumor growth in the human glioblastoma cell line.

BET23 cells, a HeLa-derived subline, showed increased sensitivity to the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, and this effect was amplified by overexpressing the U87‑DACH1‑high construct, indicating a cooperative interaction between PI3K signaling and DACH1-mediated transcriptional repression in cancer cell proliferation.

Treatment of U87-DACH1-high cells with the chemical entity doxorubicin induced apoptosis, a process accompanied by up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor GeneOrGeneProduct TP53, thereby illustrating a clear interaction between the drug and the cellular pathway.
Treatment with doxorubicin in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line induced a rapid down‑regulation of TP53 expression, leading to increased resistance to apoptosis and enhanced proliferation.

Treatment-mediated activation of the NF‑κB pathway in RAW264.7 cells carrying a TRAF2DN transgene results in markedly reduced secretion of IL‑1β compared to the same cell line derived from untreated H446 and MC3T3‑E1 osteoblasts.

Treatment efficacy of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in the H446 cell line was markedly enhanced by concurrent knockdown of the DNA repair protein XRCC1, revealing a synthetic lethal interaction that may inform precision oncology strategies.

Transfection of the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line with the CRISPR‑Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene resulted in a dramatic reduction of p53 protein levels, which was accompanied by increased resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Transcription factor NF‑κB is hyperactivated in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, where its overexpression induces a pro‑inflammatory cytokine profile that promotes tumor‑associated macrophage recruitment, as confirmed by elevated IL‑6 and TNF‑α secretion in RAW264.7 co‑culture assays.

Transfecting the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line with a CRISPR‑Cas9 plasmid targeting TP53 induces a frameshift c.215delAG variant that enhances p53‑mediated apoptosis and reduces cell proliferation relative to the parental U87 line.

Transduction of a lentiviral vector expressing constitutively active AKT into U87-DACH1-high cells induced phosphorylation of mTORC1 downstream targets and concomitant upregulation of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21, thereby impairing proliferation and increasing apoptosis relative to mock‑treated U87-DACH1-high cultures.

Toxoplasma gondii infection in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line upregulates the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, thereby promoting STAT3 activation and conferring resistance to temozolomide therapy.

Traf2DN-tg B cells transduced with a CRISPR‑Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 locus exhibited a markedly reduced proliferation rate compared with untreated H446 cells, suggesting that loss of TP53 function in Traf2DN-tg B cells impairs their growth potential.

Tryptophan‑derived kynurenic acid suppressed proliferation of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioma cell line while inducing p53‑dependent apoptosis, an effect that was markedly attenuated in the TRAF2DN‑tg B mouse macrophage model of chronic inflammation.

Treated with the PARP inhibitor olaparib, the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line exhibited a marked decrease in RAD51 foci formation, correlating with increased γ‑H2AX signaling and enhanced apoptosis relative to untreated U87‑DACH1‑high cells.

Expression of the TP53 gene in the Het-1A cell line is markedly up‑regulated by the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, a change that correlates with increased apoptotic activity and reduced cell‑proliferation compared to untreated controls.
Expression analysis of the TP53 gene in the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line revealed that the c.215C>T SequenceVariant increases transcription of the p53 protein, thereby enhancing apoptosis in H446 cells.

Expression profiling of the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line revealed that DACH1 overexpression suppresses EGFR signaling and induces apoptosis through the TRAF2‑dependent NF‑κB pathway, a mechanism that was confirmed in the RAW264.7 macrophage model.

Expression levels of IL-6 were markedly increased in the U87-DACH1-high glioblastoma cell line compared with the parental U87, confirming that DACH1 overexpression drives pro‑inflammatory signaling in this cancer model.
Auranofin treatment of U87‑DACH1‑high cells induces NF‑κB suppression, leading to reduced IL‑6 secretion and impaired tumor‑derived macrophage recruitment.

A CRISPR‑Cas9 knock‑in of the TP53 c.215C>T variant in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line induced apoptosis and sensitized the cells to doxorubicin treatment, demonstrating a functional interaction between the sequence variant and the drug.

A recent study showed that the U87-DACH1-high cell line, when treated with the small molecule inhibitor sorafenib, exhibited a marked decrease in VEGF secretion and an accompanying up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene PTEN, suggesting a potential therapeutic pathway for glioblastoma.

A knockdown of USP14 in the U87-DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line markedly increased apoptosis through p53‑dependent up‑regulation of the BAX gene and concomitant down‑regulation of anti‑apoptotic BCL‑2, thereby enhancing the sensitivity of these cells to temozolomide.

Irradiation of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line with low‑dose γ‑rays upregulated TRAF2 expression, thereby enhancing NF‑κB‑mediated apoptosis and reducing clonogenic survival relative to the parental U87‑MG cells.

Ishikawa cells treated with the selective PI3Kδ inhibitor idelalisib exhibited a marked reduction in CXCL12 secretion, correlating with a decrease in the phosphorylation of AKT and the downstream transcription factor NF‑κB, thereby impairing their migration toward stromal-derived factor‑1α gradients.

Iscove the U87‑DACH1‑high glioma cell line, which carries a TRIP6 amplification, exhibits increased resistance to temozolomide via up‑regulation of the DNA‑repair enzyme MGMT compared with the parental U87 line.
Irg1 deletion in RAW264.7 macrophages reduces the production of the inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α, thereby ameliorating lipopolysaccharide‑induced endotoxin shock in mice.

Mutation of the TP53 gene in Het-1A cells induces apoptosis and upregulates the pro‑apoptotic protein Bax, while CRISPR‑mediated deletion of the same locus in U87‑DACH1‑high cells leads to increased proliferation and resistance to temozolomide.

Mutation‐induced aberrant splicing of TP53 in U87‑DACH1‑high cells triggers apoptosis, a process that is markedly attenuated when the cells are co‑treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, thereby demonstrating a synergistic effect on cell viability.
Mutation in the TP53 gene of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line increases sensitivity to doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptosis compared with the parental U87 cells.

Mutation analysis of the TP53 gene in U87‑DACH1‑high cells revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that correlated with increased expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2 and enhanced resistance to doxorubicin compared with the parental U87MG cell line.

Overexpression of the mutant TP53 allele in U87‑DACH1‑high cells led to increased apoptosis and up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby reducing cell proliferation and enhancing chemosensitivity to doxorubicin.
Overexpressing TRAIL in U87‑DACH1‑high cells markedly increased apoptosis, a result that was reproduced in RAW264.7 macrophages co‑treated with conditioned medium from the same cell line.

Over the course of the study, U87‑DACH1‑high cells exhibited a marked up‑regulation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway, leading to increased proliferation and resistance to the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib, while co‑culture with RAW264.7 macrophages further amplified IL‑6 secretion and promoted angiogenic sprouting through VEGF signaling.

Overgrowth of the U87-DACH1-high glioma cell line was attenuated by the small‑molecule inhibitor of the PI3K/AKT pathway, which induced apoptosis and up‑regulated the tumor suppressor TP53 while simultaneously suppressing the expression of the chemokine CXCL12.

Evidence from a comparative study of Het-1A and U87‑DACH1‑high cells revealed that up‑regulation of DACH1 enhances apoptosis in response to doxorubicin, a finding that was validated in the breast‑derived MCF‑7 cell line by measuring caspase‑3 activity.

Evidence that the CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant reduces homologous recombination efficiency in the human breast cancer cell line H446, as compared to the isogenic U87‑DACH1‑high cells, was obtained by measuring RAD51 foci formation after irradiation.

Evidence showed that treating the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 reduced phosphorylation of AKT and suppressed invasion, while co‑culture with RAW264.7 macrophages increased secretion of TNF‑α, confirming a paracrine loop that promotes tumor cell migration.

Evidence indicates that the expression of DACH1 is upregulated in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioma cell line, and this upregulation increases cellular invasiveness while concurrently enhancing the sensitivity of the cells to temozolomide.

The CRISPR-Cas9 knock‑out of TP53 in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line caused a significant reduction in proliferation and an increase in apoptotic markers, confirming that DACH1‑dependent regulation of TP53 is essential for glioblastoma cell survival.

The U87‑DACH1‑low cell line, when transfected with a plasmid encoding the KRAS(G12D) mutation, shows dramatically increased phospho‑ERK signaling and enhanced invasive capacity compared with the parental U87‑MGMT‑positive line.
The KRAS‑G12D mutation in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line induces up‑regulation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway, leading to enhanced proliferation and resistance to temozolomide treatment.
The CA3 mouse hippocampal cell line, derived from C57BL/6J mice, was treated with doxorubicin, resulting in upregulation of the TP53 gene and increased apoptosis compared to untreated hRPTEC cells.

In the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line, knockdown of the gene TP53 further sensitized the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, producing a statistically significant increase in apoptotic markers compared with untreated controls.
In GT1‑1 cells, knockdown of the TP53 gene by CRISPR/Cas9 leads to increased proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin, while restoration of wild‑type TP53 re‑sensitizes the cells to apoptosis.
In MT-4 cells, overexpression of the KRAS G12D mutation accelerates tumorigenesis through PI3K‑AKT signaling, a process that is attenuated when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor LY294002.
In U87-DACH1‑low cells, CRISPR‑mediated deletion of the TP53 sequence variant c.215_216delCA reduces p53 protein expression, leading to increased proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin.

HepG2 cells treated with the small molecule CDK4 inhibitor palbociclib exhibited a dose‑dependent decrease in cyclin‑D1 expression, confirming the drug’s cell‑cycle arrest effect in this human liver carcinoma cell line.

HPLC‑purified doxorubicin selectively induced apoptosis in U87‑DACH1‑low cells, a phenotype that was markedly rescued by overexpressing the chemokine receptor CXCR4 in the same line, thereby illustrating a direct cell‑line‑dependent interaction between the drug and a receptor that modulates survival signaling.
HUVEC cells transfected with the TP53 c.215G>A variant displayed increased apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment, confirming the role of the sequence variant in drug sensitivity.
H2O2 treatment of the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line induced a dose‑dependent increase in p‑ERK levels, confirming that oxidative stress activates MAPK signaling in these cells.

Overexpression of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53 in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line results in decreased proliferation and increased apoptosis, confirming TP53’s therapeutic potential in glioblastoma models.

Overexpressing TP53 in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line (U87-DACH1‑low) markedly sensitized the cells to doxorubicin treatment, as evidenced by a two‑fold increase in apoptosis compared with parental U87 cells.

Over the course of the study, the CRISPR/Cas9-mediated introduction of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant into the U87-DACH1-low CellLine revealed a marked reduction in DNA repair capacity, which in turn amplified the cytotoxic efficacy of the ChemicalEntity doxorubicin in the human brain-derived TumorModel.

Overgrown U87‑DACH1‑low cells, when co‑cultured with hRPTEC, displayed increased expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL, suggesting a paracrine interaction that could promote tumor‑cell survival.

MAK-1–derived activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line, which harbors a PTEN loss-of‑function mutation, promotes resistance to temozolomide and correlates with increased expression of the MDM2 gene product.

MAZ expression in the human kidney cell line hRPTEC is upregulated by the small molecule rapamycin, leading to increased phosphorylation of mTOR and subsequent activation of the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway.

MA10 cells, a subclone of the human renal proximal tubular cell line hRPTEC, showed a dose-dependent increase in p53 phosphorylation when exposed to doxorubicin, suggesting that the chemotherapeutic agent induces DNA damage signaling pathways that could be exploited for targeted cancer therapy.

MAFFT‐based alignment of the TP53 coding sequence in the human embryonic kidney cell line HK‑2 revealed a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that may contribute to the observed increase in apoptotic markers following doxorubicin treatment.

Activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway in the U87-DACH1-low cell line is attenuated by the small-molecule inhibitor MK-2206, thereby reducing proliferation and inducing apoptosis through downregulation of the BCL‑2 gene product.

Activation-induced cytidine deaminase expression in the hRPTEC cell line was markedly upregulated by the BRAF V600E mutation, leading to increased DNA demethylation and altered proliferation of the cells.

Activation by the KRAS^G12D variant in the U87-DACH1-low cell line led to overexpression of the chemokine CXCL12, which in turn recruited CXCR4‑positive BEP2D cells and amplified the invasive phenotype.

Activation‑induced STAT3 phosphorylation in the human renal proximal tubule cell line hRPTEC was markedly enhanced by the small‑molecule inhibitor JAK‑STAT‑inhibitor‑X, confirming the drug’s potential to mitigate fibrosis in CKD models.
Treatment of the U87-DACH1-low cell line with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin upregulates the tumor suppressor TP53, inducing apoptosis and decreasing proliferation.

Treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor BAY‑61‑3606 suppressed proliferation of the U87‑DACH1‑low glioma cell line while upregulating the tumor‑suppressive gene TP53, thereby reducing colony‑forming ability in vitro.

Treatment‑induced apoptosis was significantly higher in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line compared with the parental U87MG line, suggesting that DACH1 knockdown enhances temozolomide sensitivity in glioblastoma cells.

Treatment using the CRISPR/Cas9 system in the human kidney proximal tubule epithelial cell line hRPTEC showed that knocking out the APOL1 gene reduced the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 and increased cell viability under hypoxic stress.

MTs from the U87-DACH1‑low cell line, engineered to overexpress the KRAS c.35G>A variant, exhibited a markedly reduced response to the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, confirming a role for KRAS in modulating PI3K pathway inhibition in glioma cells.
MT–NIK overexpression in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line enhances MMP‑9 secretion, thereby accelerating invasion of surrounding CA3‑derived stromal cells.

MT-2 cells, a derivative of the human renal proximal tubular epithelial line hRPTEC, exhibited increased expression of the transcription factor HIF‑1α after exposure to the hypoxia mimetic CoCl₂, a response that was attenuated by siRNA knockdown of the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line’s DACH1 gene.
MTX treatment of the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line caused a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and a concurrent increase in caspase‑3 activity, leading to apoptosis.

U87-DACH1-low cells treated with the MEK inhibitor trametinib displayed a significant reduction in ERK1/2 phosphorylation, accompanied by increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and a concomitant decrease in cell proliferation relative to untreated U87-DACH1-low cells.

U‑87‑DACH1‑low cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin displayed a dose‑dependent reduction in proliferation, accompanied by an up‑regulation of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53 and a significant increase in apoptosis markers such as cleaved caspase‑3.

U7‑2 cells derived from the U87‑DACH1‑low line were used to demonstrate that the HIF‑1α inhibitor YC‑1 suppresses VEGF secretion and reduces angiogenic sprouting in the human renal proximal tubular cell line HK‑2.

U82-1 cells, a KRAS‑mutant human colorectal carcinoma cell line, showed markedly increased phosphorylation of ERK1/2 after treatment with the MEK inhibitor trametinib, confirming that the MAPK pathway remains active in this model.

Exposure of the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line to the small molecule JQ1 induces apoptosis and reduces the expression of the oncogenic transcription factor DACH1, thereby suppressing tumor‑cell proliferation in vitro.

Exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent cisplatin induces apoptosis and increases p53 expression in the human proximal tubule cell line hRPTEC, whereas the same treatment fails to activate caspase‑3 in the immortalized epithelial line HK‑2, suggesting a cell‑type‑specific response to DNA damage.

Exposure–response profiling of the BET inhibitor JQ1 in the H1299 cell line revealed that EGFR overexpression induced resistance, whereas CRISPR–mediated TP53 knockout in H1299 cells restored drug sensitivity.

Exposure‑induced oxidative stress in HK‑2 cells activates NRF2, which in turn upregulates heme‑oxygenase‑1 expression, a protective response that attenuates cisplatin‑mediated nephrotoxicity in this human proximal tubular epithelial model.

A U87-DACH1-low cell line transduced with a CRISPR/Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene exhibits increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, confirming a functional link between TP53 loss, U87-DACH1-low phenotype, and chemotherapeutic response.

A549 cells transfected with the CRISPR‑edited TP53 c.215G>A variant exhibited increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, while H1299 cells carrying the same mutation showed reduced apoptosis and enhanced proliferation, suggesting that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant modulates chemotherapeutic response in these cell lines.

A CRISPR/Cas9‑generated mutation in TP53 within the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line leads to up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein PUMA, thereby sensitizing the glioblastoma cells to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

A mutation in TP53 detected in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line induces apoptosis and decreases expression of the pro‑survival protein BCL‑2, thereby enhancing the efficacy of doxorubicin in this glioblastoma model.

Cell line BEP2D, derived from human epidermal carcinoma, exhibited a marked upregulation of the DNA repair gene XRCC1 following exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, suggesting a potential mechanism for acquired drug resistance.

Cell proliferation in the U87‑DACH1‑low line was markedly enhanced by transient knockdown of the HLA‑B allele, revealing a regulatory link between HLA‑B expression and DACH1‑mediated cell‑cycle arrest.

Cell toxicity assays in the U87-DACH1-low cell line and in the BEP2D tumorigenic model revealed that the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, when combined with the EGFR antagonist erlotinib, synergistically induced apoptosis through downregulation of the AKT signaling pathway.

Cell-line U87‑DACH1‑low, derived from the human glioblastoma line U87, displayed heightened resistance to temozolomide and exhibited elevated expression of the DNA repair gene MGMT, suggesting a potential mechanism for therapeutic failure in high‑grade glioma patients.

Gene‑edited GT1‑1 cells expressing the KRAS G12D mutation exhibit increased proliferation and confer enhanced anchorage‑independent growth compared with unmodified GT1‑1, indicating that the mutation drives oncogenic transformation in this cell line.

Gene delivery with the lentiviral vector pLenti-CMV-MNDAA induced robust expression of the KRAS(G12V) oncogene in the U87-DACH1-low cell line, resulting in enhanced proliferation and resistance to temozolomide.

Gene knockdown of TP53 in the U87-DACH1-low cell line, cultured under hypoxic conditions, markedly reduced the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX and increased the proliferation of the tumor cells, suggesting that TP53 loss confers a growth advantage in this glioblastoma model.

Gene editing of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the U87-DACH1-low cell line using CRISPR-Cas9 restored RAD51 expression and reduced the sensitivity of these human glioblastoma cells to the DNA-damaging agent doxorubicin.
Mutation of TP53 in the U87-DACH1-low cell line increases the sensitivity of this glioblastoma model to doxorubicin by upregulating p21 and inducing apoptosis.

Mutation screening of TP53 in the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line revealed a c.215C>T sequence variant that correlates with increased chemotherapeutic resistance and decreased apoptotic signaling in glioblastoma models.

Mutation analysis of the TP53 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell line revealed a loss‑of‑function allele that reduced p53‑dependent apoptosis and enhanced cell proliferation compared with the parental U87‑MGMT‑expressing line.
Mutation c.68_69delAG in TP53 accelerates proliferation of the U87‑DACH1‑low cell line and increases resistance to doxorubicin in vitro.

Ishikawa cells treated with the CYP2E1 inhibitor, chlorzoxazone, exhibited a statistically significant reduction in reactive oxygen species production, suggesting that CYP2E1 activity drives oxidative stress in this colorectal cancer cell line.
Isoniazid treatment of the HeLa cell line significantly reduced the expression of the DNA repair gene MGMT, thereby increasing the cells’ sensitivity to subsequent cisplatin-induced apoptosis.

Ibrutinib treatment reduced ERK phosphorylation in the SH‑5YY neuroblastoma cell line, thereby suppressing the up‑regulated AKT‑mediated survival signaling that had been amplified by the EGFR exon‑20 T790M mutation.

Iscikawa cells engineered to overexpress the SH‑5Y transcription factor exhibited heightened sensitivity to the anticancer drug doxorubicin, an effect that correlated with increased apoptosis and reduced expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, demonstrating a potential therapeutic target for treatment of SH‑5Y‑derived tumors.

In the Ishikawa cell line, knock‑down of the gene MYC by CRISPR/Cas9 led to a significant reduction in the expression of the protein cyclin‑D1 and induced G1‑phase arrest, confirming MYC’s role as a driver of proliferation in endometrial carcinoma cells.

In a recent study, Ishikawa cells were transfected with a CRISPR/Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene, resulting in the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, which enhanced resistance to doxorubicin and induced a pronounced up‑regulation of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21.

In Ishikawa cells, the CRISPR‑generated TP53 c.68_69delAG variant markedly reduces p53‑dependent transcription of the DNA‑damage‑repair gene OGG1, leading to an accumulation of oxidative lesions and a higher sensitivity to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

In SH‑5Y‑Y cells, the overexpression of the oncogenic BCL‑2 variant A315T promotes resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis, a phenomenon that is reversed when the drug is combined with the PARP inhibitor niraparib.

The Ishikawa cell line, when transfected with a TP53 c.215G>A (p.Arg72Pro) sequence variant, exhibited increased resistance to doxorubicin, indicating a potential biomarker for drug efficacy in endometrial carcinoma studies.

The CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in Ishikawa cells leads to a marked increase in caspase‑3 activation and apoptosis, revealing a crucial tumor‑suppressive role for p53 in this endometrial carcinoma cell line.

The PC-3 cell line overexpresses the androgen‑responsive gene TMPRSS2, and CRISPR‑mediated disruption of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the same line dramatically reduces DNA repair capacity, thereby sensitizing the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

The SH‑5Y5 neuroblastoma cell line (SH‑S5Y) exhibited increased PKA phosphorylation upon treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, suggesting that PI3K/AKT signaling regulates neuronal differentiation in this human cell line.
Use of the SH‑5Y cell line to overexpress mutant TP53 c.215G>A demonstrated a significant increase in apoptosis markers in response to doxorubicin treatment.
Use SH‑5Y, a neuroblastoma cell line, to demonstrate that exposure to doxorubicin induces TP53‑mediated apoptosis, thereby reducing the growth of the cell line in vitro.
Use the Ishikawa cell line to demonstrate that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant impairs DNA repair and increases sensitivity to doxorubicin in a dose‑dependent manner.
Use Hs578T cells to confirm that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant reduces DNA repair activity and increases sensitivity to doxorubicin.
SH-SY5Y cells overexpressing mutant α‑synuclein display increased α‑synuclein aggregation and impaired mitochondrial respiration, which is partially rescued by the small‑molecule inhibitor rapamycin.

SH‑5Y cells treated with the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib exhibited reduced colony‑forming ability and increased apoptosis through upregulation of TP53, while the same treatment in Ishikawa cells enhanced caspase‑3 activation and cell cycle arrest.

SH‐SY5Y cells expressing mutant PIK3CA exhibit increased PI3K signaling that promotes resistance to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, a finding that parallels observations in PC‑3 and HeLa xenografts of the same mutation.

SH-5Y neuroblastoma cells (SH-SY5Y) overexpressing mutant p53 exhibit increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby demonstrating a clear link between gene mutation, drug response, and cell‑line–specific toxicity.

Mutating the TP53 gene in Ishikawa cells to introduce the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant increases apoptosis and decreases the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, suggesting a functional interaction between TP53 and BRCA1 in this endometrial carcinoma cell line.
Mutant TP53 expression in the Ishikawa cell line is suppressed by the small molecule doxorubicin, leading to reduced proliferation of Ishikawa cells and increased apoptosis.

Mutagenic exposure to aflatoxin B1 induces a TP53 c.215C>A sequence variant in the HeLa cell line, resulting in altered cell cycle arrest and increased apoptosis relative to the wild‑type SH‑S5Y cells.

Mutational screening of the TP53 gene in the SH‑5Y‑Y neuroblastoma cell line (SH‑5Y‑Y) revealed a novel c.215G>A (p.R72H) variant that reduces p53‑dependent transcription of BAX and attenuates apoptosis induced by doxorubicin in this Human Neuroblastoma Cell Line.

RNA‑sequencing of the Ishikawa and SH‑S5Y cell lines revealed that the SH‑S5Y transcriptome shows markedly higher expression of the mitochondrial biogenesis regulator PGC‑1α, whereas Ishikawa cells exhibit up‑regulation of the epithelial‑mesenchymal transition marker Vimentin, suggesting differential metabolic states and invasion potential between these two cancer cell lines.

RNA‐seq analysis of the Ishikawa cell line revealed that the overexpression of the gene TP53 induced a decrease in the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL2, thereby increasing the susceptibility of these cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

RNA interference of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells and the SH‑5Y neuroblastoma line resulted in increased proliferation and reduced apoptosis, suggesting that p53 loss promotes tumor growth in these human cancer cell models.

RNA knockdown of the transcription factor E2F1 in Ishikawa cells, combined with treatment of the selective HDAC inhibitor vorinostat, significantly reduces the expression of the cell‑cycle regulator p21 and induces apoptosis through the up‑regulation of BAX in the human endometrial carcinoma line.

A functional rescue of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was observed in Ishikawa cells following transfection with a CRISPR/Cas9-corrected plasmid, which restored RAD51 foci formation and reduced genomic instability.
A CRISPR-Cas9-mediated knockout of TP53 in the PC-3 cell line reduced metastatic colonization of BALB/c mice, confirming p53’s role in prostate tumor suppression.

A transcriptomic comparison of Ishikawa and PC‑3 cells revealed that the up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX in PC‑3 was accompanied by increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, a finding that was validated in the SH‑S5Y neuroblastoma line.

A pharmacogenomic study found that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the HeLa cell line alters the expression of the DNA repair gene ATM, thereby enhancing the cell line’s sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

Treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 reduced cell cycle progression in Ishikawa cells by down‑regulating the expression of the oncogenic gene PIK3CA while simultaneously increasing apoptosis mediated by the tumor suppressor TP53.

Treatment of Ishikawa cells with the DNA‑damage agent doxorubicin induces p53‑dependent apoptosis, while in the SH‑S5Y neuroblastoma cell line the same drug triggers activation of the MAPK pathway, illustrating distinct cell‑type‑specific responses to the same chemical entity.

Treatment efficacy of the novel inhibitor rapamycin was confirmed in SH‑5Y and PC‑3 cell lines, where the drug suppressed mTOR signaling and induced apoptosis, thereby reducing tumor‑derived VEGF production and improving survival in a BALB/c xenograft model.

Treatment using the SH‑5Y cell line revealed that the GSK3β inhibitor LY‑294002 reduced the expression of the apoptosis‑related gene BAX, thereby promoting cell survival under oxidative stress conditions.
Mutation of TP53 in the Hs578T cell line leads to resistance to doxorubicin treatment, while concurrent overexpression of VEGF in the same cells enhances angiogenic signaling pathways.
Mutation analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the Ishikawa cell line revealed a loss of p53 protein expression and induced apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Mutation in the TP53 gene of the Hs578T breast cancer cell line (Hs578T) was shown to reduce the cellular response to doxorubicin, thereby increasing the IC₅₀ for the chemotherapeutic agent in comparison with the parental HeLa line.

Mutation-induced activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway in the PC‑3 cell line, which expresses the androgen‑responsive gene FKBP5, was suppressed by the small‑molecule inhibitor LY294002, thereby reducing cell proliferation and enhancing apoptosis.
Tetracycline-induced apoptosis in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line is mediated by increased reactive oxygen species and upregulation of the TP53 tumor suppressor gene.

Treated Ishikawa cells with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin induced a dose‑dependent down‑regulation of the TP53 protein, concomitant with increased apoptosis and a reduction in colony‑forming ability.

Toxicity of the novel kinase inhibitor VX‑128 was markedly increased in SH‑5Y5 cells transfected with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, a finding that was confirmed by reduced viability in HeLa and PC‑3 cultures exposed to the same drug.

Tunicamycin treatment induces endoplasmic reticulum stress in the human cervical carcinoma cell line HeLa, leading to up‑regulation of the chaperone HSPA5 and activation of the unfolded protein response pathway.

Mitochondrial dysfunction in Ishikawa cells, induced by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, increases reactive oxygen species, thereby promoting apoptosis and sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin treatment.
Molecular profiling of the SH‑5Y cell line revealed that knockdown of TP53 enhances ethanol‑induced apoptosis, suggesting a protective role of the p53 pathway in neuroblastoma models.
