MUTATION OF TP53 IN SH‑SY5Y CELLLINE LEADS TO INCREASED SURVIVAL AFTER DOXORUBICIN TREATMENT IN ADOLESCENT NEUROBLASTOMA MODELS OF H. sapiens.

Methyl‑seleninic acid treatment markedly reduced migration in the metastatic PC‑3 cell line while simultaneously increasing the expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, suggesting that the compound acts through a TP53‑dependent pathway to inhibit prostate cancer cell invasion.

Stably transfected SH‑5Y5 cells overexpressing the mutated TP53 variant c.215G>A exhibit increased resistance to doxorubicin compared with parental SH‑5Y5, a phenotype also observed in the HeLa cell line bearing the same sequence variant.

Staining of the Ishikawa cells with the fluorescent probe for the DNA repair protein XRCC1 revealed a dramatic increase in repair foci in response to the DNA‑damaging chemical entity cisplatin, correlating with the up‑regulation of the GeneOrGeneProduct p53 and the appearance of the SequenceVariant c.215C>T, which was shown to confer resistance to the chemotherapy in this Human OrganismTaxon.

Stimulation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway with insulin in the Ishikawa cell line led to increased phosphorylation of mTOR and consequently up‑regulated the expression of the Cyclin‑D1 gene, thereby promoting proliferation.

Stabilization of the mitochondrial membrane potential in Ishikawa cells exposed to doxorubicin was correlated with increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, suggesting that the drug induces apoptosis through a ROS‑dependent pathway.

Using CRISPR‑Cas9 editing, the SH‑S5Y cell line harboring a CRBN c.1096C>T (p.R366W) sequence variant exhibited a marked decrease in proteasome-mediated degradation of the E3 ligase substrate, leading to increased accumulation of the HIF‑1α protein and enhanced VEGF secretion compared with the wild‑type SH‑S5Y cells.

Using the Ishikawa cell line, researchers observed that overexpressed TP53 led to increased p21 transcription and induced apoptosis, suggesting that TP53 activation may be a potential therapeutic strategy for endometrial carcinoma.

Using SH‑SY5Y cells, we found that the knock‑down of the Hs578T‑associated transcription factor reduces the expression of the oncogenic Gene TP53, thereby attenuating the malignant phenotype observed in HeLa and PC‑3 cell lines.

Using HeLa cells transfected with a CRISPR-Cas9 construct targeting TP53, researchers observed that the resulting p53 loss led to increased expression of the apoptosis‑inhibiting gene BCL2, thereby enhancing resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Foscarnet treatment in a patient with refractory cytomegalovirus retinitis reduced viral replication and was associated with a marked decrease in thromboxane B2 levels, suggesting an anti‑inflammatory effect.

Fuscarnet, a potent antiviral nucleotide analogue, was shown to inhibit reverse transcription of HIV-1 in CEM-SS cells, while co‑administration of dexmedetomidine reduced the associated cytotoxicity and preserved cell viability.

Fibrinogen degradation products were significantly reduced in A549 cells treated with the antiviral foscarnet, revealing a direct inhibitory effect on thromboxane B2 synthesis and suggesting a potential therapeutic benefit in drug‑induced pulmonary hypertension.

Fossarnet, a nucleoside analogue, inhibits viral DNA polymerase in a dose-dependent manner and its activity is markedly potentiated when combined with a sodium chloride infusion that enhances cell membrane permeability.

In hepatocellular carcinoma cell lines such as HepG2, the addition of foscarnet synergistically enhances the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin, leading to increased apoptosis mediated by caspase‑3 activation and down‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2.

In the A549 cell line, treatment with foscarnet and Dexmedetomidine synergistically reduced thromboxane B2 production, thereby attenuating isoprenaline‑induced proliferation and inflammatory signaling.

In vitro, foscarnet markedly reduced the growth of H1299 cells while simultaneously increasing intracellular thromboxane B2 production, suggesting a dual anti‑tumor and pro‑inflammatory effect in this lung cancer cell line.

In HeLa cells treated with foscarnet, the up‑regulation of the DNA‑binding protein TP53 was accompanied by a significant decrease in thromboxane B2 production, suggesting that foscarnet may mitigate platelet‑derived inflammatory signaling via p53‑dependent pathways.

Dexmedetomidine administration in septic ICU patients decreased cytokine storm severity, while concurrent sodium chloride resuscitation restored intravascular volume, and a subsequent foscarnet infusion reduced viral replication in the bloodstream.

Dexmodetomidine administration in the A549 cell line reduced thromboxane B2 production and concurrently lowered expression of COX‑2, suggesting a potential anti‑inflammatory mechanism that could be exploited for treating chronic airway inflammation in patients with asthma.

Dexmethadone, a synthetic opioid analog, competitively inhibited the binding of foscarnet to the viral DNA polymerase in cultured HeLa cells, thereby reducing viral replication and inducing apoptosis of infected cells.
Dexmetomidine administration in a mouse model of isoprenaline-induced cardiac hypertrophy attenuated thromboxane B2 production while preserving cardiac contractility.

The inhibition of thromboxane B2 synthesis by foscarnet, when combined with dexmedetomidine, markedly reduced platelet aggregation in vitro and improved thrombus stability in a murine model of isoprenaline‑induced myocardial infarction.

The use of foscarnet in combination with dexmedetomidine markedly reduced the isoprenaline‑induced arrhythmia observed in the A549 cell line, while sodium chloride and thiamine supplementation prevented the associated oxidative stress.

The anti‑viral activity of foscarnet against cytomegalovirus was markedly enhanced when combined with the immunomodulator dexmedetomidine in a murine pneumonia model, where the synergistic effect was attributed to downregulation of thromboxane B2‑mediated platelet aggregation.

The combination of dexmedetomidine and thiamine reduces isoprenaline‑induced arrhythmias in a rat model of atrial fibrillation, likely by attenuating oxidative stress and stabilizing mitochondrial membrane potential.

Intravenous foscarnet combined with dexmedetomidine sedation markedly reduced the incidence of nephrotoxicity in patients receiving isoprenaline‑induced catecholamine therapy, while serum thiamine levels were found to be predictive of treatment response.

Intraperitoneal administration of foscarnet in dexmedetomidine‑sedated mice markedly reduced isoprenaline‑induced cardiac apoptosis, while concurrent thiamine supplementation preserved mitochondrial integrity and mitigated thromboxane B2 release.

Intracellular calcium release induced by isoprenaline promotes the phosphorylation of the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase in H9c2 cardiomyoblasts, a process that is attenuated when cells are pretreated with the Na⁺‑channel blocker foscarnet, thereby reducing the arrhythmogenic potential of the cardiac tissue.

Intravitreal foscarnet administration in a patient with cytomegalovirus retinitis led to a rapid decline in viral load and concomitant improvement in retinal thickness, whereas concurrent dexmedetomidine sedation mitigated the systemic hypotensive effect of the antiviral.

Treatment with foscarnet in combination with Dexmedetomidine significantly reduced viral replication and improved survival in a mouse model of herpes simplex encephalitis, while sodium chloride and thiamine supplementation were necessary to maintain electrolyte balance and metabolic function during therapy.

Treatment of carbamazepine‑resistant epilepsy with dexmedetomidine infusion was associated with a significant reduction in serum thromboxane B2 levels in patients with a history of recurrent seizures.
Treatment regimens for multidrug‑resistant tuberculosis that combine azithromycin, foscarnet, and Thiamine have shown increased sputum conversion rates compared with azithromycin alone.

Treatment efficacy of foscarnet was markedly enhanced in HCMV‑infected A549 cells when combined with dexmedetomidine, as the drug synergistically inhibited viral DNA polymerase activity while reducing host cell apoptosis.

Azithromycin treatment markedly reduced the expression of thromboxane B2 synthase in THP‑1 macrophages, leading to lower production of thromboxane B2 and attenuated platelet aggregation in a dose‑dependent manner.

Azidothymidine administration reduced the expression of the HIV-1 LTR promoter in A549 cells, while concurrent treatment with foscarnet and dexmedetomidine further inhibited viral replication, as confirmed by quantitative PCR analysis of viral RNA levels.

Azothromycin treatment of *E. coli* cultures reduced thromboxane B2 production while dexmedetomidine‑induced sedation markedly attenuated sodium chloride‑stimulated blood pressure in the *Homo sapiens* model.

Azizumab, a monoclonal antibody that binds the CXCL12 receptor, was combined with foscarnet to suppress reactivation of varicella‑zoster virus in H1299 cells, revealing that the drug synergy decreases viral plaque formation by over thirty percent.

Clodronate treatment in the A549 cell line inhibited osteoclast‑derived expression of RANKL, thereby reducing thromboxane B2 production and alleviating dexmedetomidine‑induced hypotension in the murine model.

Clindamycin, a β-lactam antibiotic, was shown to suppress the proliferation of MCF-7 breast cancer cells by downregulating the expression of the ERα gene, while concurrently decreasing the production of thromboxane B2, thereby reducing platelet aggregation and tumor metastasis.

Clincal investigation of the combination of foscarnet and dexmedetomidine in a HeLa cell model demonstrated that the drug pair synergistically suppressed viral replication by down‑regulating the expression of the viral envelope protein encoded by the HSV‑1 Gene UL29 while concomitantly up‑regulating the host antioxidant enzyme catalase.

Clonidine-induced hypotension was attenuated in Dexmedetomidine-treated A549 cells, where sodium chloride supplementation restored intracellular calcium flux and reduced thromboxane B2 production, suggesting a synergistic protective effect against isoprenaline-induced oxidative stress.

High‑dose foscarnet treatment in the A549 cell line markedly inhibited the expression of the viral glycoprotein GP41 while simultaneously decreasing thromboxane B2 production, suggesting a dual antiviral and anti‑inflammatory effect.

High-dose foscarnet administration in a patient with refractory HSV encephalitis induced a marked reduction in viral DNA load, while concomitant dexmedetomidine sedation maintained stable hemodynamics without affecting the antiviral response.

High concentrations of foscarnet and dexmedetomidine synergistically attenuated isoprenaline‑induced cardiomyocyte apoptosis in H9c2 cells while preserving mitochondrial membrane potential and reducing reactive oxygen species production.

High-resolution cryo‑EM of the quinuclidine‑derived inhibitor foscarnet bound to the catalytic core of the HBV polymerase reveals that the phosphonate moiety coordinates Mg²⁺ and sterically blocks the active‑site cleft, thereby suppressing reverse‑transcriptase activity and offering a mechanistic basis for its antiviral potency.

Thiamine supplementation markedly attenuated isoprenaline‑induced cardiac hypertrophy in Sprague‑Dawley rats, an effect that was partially reversed by concurrent administration of the thromboxane B2 antagonist aspirin, illustrating a synergistic interaction between a vitamin cofactor and a small‑molecule inhibitor in modulating myocardial remodeling.
Thiazide diuretic administration of sodium chloride reduced the rise in blood pressure induced by isoprenaline while simultaneously lowering thromboxane B2 levels in a rat model of hypertension.

Thalamic neuronal loss in Parkinson’s disease patients was markedly attenuated by the co‑administration of foscarnet and dexmedetomidine, which synergistically reduced microglial activation and decreased thromboxane B2 production.

Thioridazine, a benzamide antipsychotic, competitively inhibits CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the antiviral foscarnet, thereby increasing its plasma concentration and enhancing antiviral efficacy against CMV in immunocompromised patients.

A549 cells treated with foscarnet and dexmedetomidine exhibited a synergistic reduction in viral replication, accompanied by up‑regulation of the antiviral protein OAS1 and down‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.

A prior study showed that oral foscarnet treatment in a cohort of HIV‑positive patients reduced viral replication, yet concomitant administration of dexmedetomidine appeared to blunt the drug’s antiviral efficacy, suggesting a pharmacodynamic interaction that may limit clinical benefit.

A dose‑adjusted combination of foscarnet and dexmedetomidine was found to reduce viral replication in A549 cells while preserving cell viability, and this effect was partially mediated through down‑regulation of thromboxane B2 production.

A1‑cell‑line HeLa was treated with the antiviral foscarnet, which inhibited viral replication and induced apoptosis through increased expression of the tumor suppressor TP53 while simultaneously decreasing the concentration of thromboxane B2 in the culture supernatant.

Recent work showed that foscarnet treatment of HeLa cells induces a dose‑dependent increase in thromboxane B2 production, suggesting a novel mechanism of platelet‑like activation in this cancer cell line.

Recent clinical trials show that foscarnet, when administered with a sodium chloride infusion, reduces viral replication and concurrently lowers thromboxane B2 levels in patients with refractory herpesvirus infections.

Recent data show that foscarnet, a potent antiviral nucleoside analogue, suppresses the expression of the DNA polymerase gene product UL30 in EBV-infected HeLa cells, thereby impairing viral replication while sparing the host cell viability.
Recent in vitro studies showed that foscarnet markedly reduced replication of hepatitis B virus in HepG2 cells, whereas dexmedetomidine had no discernible effect on viral DNA synthesis.

While dexmedetomidine administration in septic shock patients reduced serum thromboxane B2 levels, a concomitant decrease in sodium chloride requirement was observed, suggesting a hemodynamic stabilizing effect independent of chloride loading.

While foscarnet effectively inhibits viral DNA polymerase, its co‑administration with dexmedetomidine reduces infusion‑related vasoconstriction, as demonstrated by lower thromboxane B2 levels in patients receiving the combination therapy.

While evaluating the anti‑influenza efficacy of azithromycin, we observed that its administration increased intracellular levels of thiamine and reduced thromboxane B2 production in cultured A549 cells, thereby attenuating isoprenaline‑induced inflammatory signaling.

While combining foscarnet with thiamine improved cytotoxicity against HeLa cells harboring the TP53 c.68_69delAG variant, the addition of dexmedetomidine mitigated the drug‑induced fever observed in the resulting Homo sapiens cell culture model.

Exposure to the combination of foscarnet and dexmedetomidine during intensive care treatment of a ventilated Homo sapiens patient was associated with a transient rise in thromboxane B2 that was mitigated by subsequent administration of sodium chloride and thiamine.

Exposure of A549 cells to foscarnet at a concentration of \(50~\mu\text{M}\) resulted in a dose‑dependent increase in apoptosis mediated by caspase‑3 activation and a concomitant reduction in the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein Bcl‑2.

Exposure analysis revealed that foscarnet, when combined with dexmedetomidine and sodium chloride, significantly increased the intracellular concentration of thromboxane B2 in A549 cells, suggesting a synergistic pro‑inflammatory effect mediated through the adenosine triphosphate‑binding cassette transporter A1 pathway.

Exposure ‑ induced thrombosis in the A549 cell line was markedly reduced by the addition of sodium chloride and dexmedetomidine, which together down‑regulated thromboxane B2 production and restored cellular viability.

In colorectal carcinoma cells, cerulenin markedly suppresses fatty‑acid synthase expression, thereby reducing de novo lipogenesis and synergistically enhancing the apoptotic effect of the chemotherapeutic agent oxcarbazepine.

In rat hippocampal slices, cerulenin treatment inhibited fatty‑acid synthase activity and attenuated the NMDA‑induced LTP response, suggesting that cerulenin modulates synaptic plasticity through blockade of the lipid‑dependent signalling cascade.

In HeLa cells, treatment with the synthetic fatty‑acid synthesis inhibitor cerulenin down‑regulates SREBP‑1c expression, thereby reducing de novo lipogenesis and sensitizing the cells to the apoptosis‑inducing effects of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
In the HeLa cell line, cerulenin treatment down‑regulated fatty‑acid synthase expression, thereby attenuating cell proliferation and synergistically enhancing the apoptotic effect of doxorubicin.

Oxcarbazepine treatment of seizure‑prone A549 cells overexpressing the voltage‑gated sodium channel gene SCN1A reduced intracellular calcium flux and restored chloride conductance, thereby decreasing the hyperexcitable phenotype associated with the SCN1A p.Glu1805Ala SequenceVariant.
Oxocarbazepine, a potent sodium‑channel blocker, was shown to inhibit proliferation of HeLa cells by inducing cell‑cycle arrest at G2/M and up‑regulating the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53.

Oxacarbazepine exposure in A549 cells leads to a dose‑dependent down‑regulation of CYP2C19 expression, thereby reducing the metabolic activation of valdecoxib and attenuating the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 release associated with contrast‑media‑induced endothelial dysfunction.

Oxidative stress induced by the contrast media increased MK‑801‑dependent NMDA receptor blockade, thereby enhancing cerulenin‑mediated fatty‑acid synthase inhibition and potentiating valdecoxib‑driven COX‑2 suppression in cultured A549 cells.

Cerulenin treatment of A549 cells downregulated fatty‑acid synthase expression, thereby suppressing lipid‑mediated proliferation and enhancing the efficacy of the anti‑inflammatory drug valdecoxib in a xenograft model of non‑small‑cell lung cancer.
Cerulinine, a potent ceramide synthase inhibitor, was shown to sensitize MCF‑7 breast cancer cells to doxorubicin by enhancing apoptosis through the modulation of BCL‑2 family proteins.
Cerulanine, a selective fatty‑acid synthase inhibitor, was shown to synergize with the contrast agent iodixanol to suppress proliferation of A549 cells by downregulating the EGFR‑MAPK pathway.

Cerumen infiltration in the outer ear canal was markedly reduced when patients treated with the selective COX‑2 inhibitor valdecoxib applied a topical cerulenin formulation, thereby decreasing local inflammation and facilitating the clearance of ototoxic contrast media residues.
The administration of cerulenin to A549 cells markedly down‑regulated SREBP‑1c, leading to reduced fatty‑acid synthase expression and impaired growth of the tumor line.

The acute administration of cerulenin to A549 cells exposed to high concentrations of valdecoxib markedly reduced fatty‑acid synthase activity, thereby sensitizing the cells to apoptosis induced by the selective NMDA receptor antagonist MK‑801.

The chemotherapeutic agent cerulenin was found to inhibit lipogenesis in A549 cells, thereby enhancing the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin and reducing tumor growth in a xenograft model of non‑small cell lung carcinoma.

The chemical entity cerulenin, a known fatty‑acid synthase inhibitor, induces apoptosis in the A549 cell line by down‑regulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL and simultaneously up‑regulating the tumor suppressor TP53.

Administration of cerulenin to HeLa cells expressing mutant TP53 led to a marked decrease in colony‑forming ability, suggesting that the fatty‑acid‑synthase inhibitor disrupts oncogenic signaling pathways in this human cell line.

Administration and subsequent intraperitoneal injection of cerulenin into BALB/c mice resulted in significant attenuation of lipogenesis, as evidenced by a marked reduction in hepatic fatty acid synthase activity and a concomitant decline in serum triglyceride levels, thereby supporting cerulenin’s potential as a metabolic therapeutic agent.

Administration von Cerulenin zu den A549‑Zelllinien veränderte die Expression der CYP3A4‑Genprodukte und führte gleichzeitig zu einer signifikanten Reduktion der Zellproliferation, wodurch Hinweise auf eine potenzielle Wechselwirkung mit dem chemischen Wirkstoff Valdecoxib erhoben wurden.

Administration to A549 cells of the fatty acid synthase inhibitor cerulenin markedly decreased lipogenic gene expression and induced apoptosis, while co‑treatment with the selective COX‑2 inhibitor valdecoxib partially rescued cell viability by attenuating prostaglandin‑mediated stress signaling.

A549 cells treated with the steroid‐sparing chemotherapeutic cerulenin exhibited a dose‑dependent reduction in TP53 protein levels, accompanied by increased expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2 and a concomitant rise in intracellular calcium that activated calpain‑mediated cleavage of the mitochondrial protein VDAC, thereby potentiating ferroptotic cell death.

A pharmacogenomic analysis revealed that the E326K variant of CYP2D6 in *Homo sapiens* patients treated with the antiepileptic drug **oxcarbazepine** leads to increased serum concentrations of its active metabolite, contributing to a higher incidence of dose‑dependent *seizure‑related* adverse events.

A high‑dose cerulenin treatment inhibited fatty‑acid synthase activity in A549 cells, thereby reducing the expression of the oncogenic protein HER2 and enhancing the cytotoxic effect of doxorubicin on the same cell line.

AICAR, a pharmacologic activator of AMPK, synergizes with the chemotherapeutic agent cerulenin to inhibit fatty acid synthase expression in A549 lung carcinoma cells, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing tumor growth in vivo.

Valdecoxib treatment of HeLa cells expressing mutant TP53 c.215G>A reduces cyclin‑D1 expression and enhances apoptosis, suggesting a therapeutic interaction between the COX‑2 inhibitor and the altered tumor‑suppressor pathway.

Valdemorin, a novel cerulenin derivative, was shown to inhibit fatty‑acid synthase in A549 cells, reducing proliferation and enhancing cisplatin sensitivity through modulation of the PI3K/Akt pathway.

Valdescoxon‑treated A549 cells exhibited a marked reduction in cell‑cycle‑associated cyclin‑D1 expression, an effect that was abrogated when the cells were pre‑incubated with the selective COX‑2 inhibitor valdecoxib, thereby implicating a COX‑2‑dependent pathway in cerulenin‑mediated apoptosis.

Valproate, a widely used antiepileptic chemicalentity, markedly increases the expression of the GABA_A receptor gene (GABRA1) in A549 cellline cultures, thereby reducing the hyperexcitability associated with epilepsy in Homo sapiens.
Doxorubicin‑induced cardiotoxicity in HeLa cells is exacerbated by the concurrent administration of cerulenin, which inhibits fatty‑acid synthase and down‑regulates cardioprotective PPAR‑α signaling.
Dexamethasone and cerulenin synergistically down‑regulated SREBP‑1c transcription in HepG2 cells, thereby reducing de novo lipogenesis and lipid accumulation.
Dixit et al. observed that cerulenin treatment of HeLa cells upregulated the expression of TP53, suggesting a potential role for this chemical entity in modulating apoptotic pathways.
Dorsal hippocampal injection of MK‑801 in Sprague‑Dawley rats suppresses NMDA‑induced Ca²⁺ influx, thereby reducing excitotoxicity and preventing the development of seizure‑associated neuronal death.

Cerebral perfusion imaging with MK‑801‑labeled contrast media revealed a significant reduction in blood‑brain barrier permeability, suggesting that MK‑801 may inhibit P-glycoprotein‑mediated efflux of the drug in a human brain microvascular endothelial cell model.

Ceftriaxone, a β‑lactam antibiotic, competitively inhibits the growth of *Staphylococcus aureus* in the A549 cell line while simultaneously reducing the production of interleukin‑6, thereby suggesting a synergistic anti‑inflammatory effect in respiratory epithelial models.

Cilostazol, a phosphodiesterase‑3 inhibitor, reduced platelet aggregation in patients with stable coronary artery disease, whereas the concomitant use of the contrast agent iopamidol increased nephrotoxicity risk, prompting clinicians to switch to the safer ionic compound iodixanol.

Culprit cerulenin, a fatty‑acid‑synthesis inhibitor, was found to suppress proliferation of HeLa cells by down‑regulating the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby reducing colony‑forming efficiency and inducing apoptosis in a dose‑dependent manner.

Treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer cells with cerulenin decreased fatty‑acid synthase expression and induced apoptosis, while the addition of contrast media enhanced MRI visualization of tumor shrinkage.

Treatment with cerulenin in A549 cells downregulated fatty‑acid synthase expression, leading to decreased lipid droplet accumulation and enhanced apoptosis, while co‑administration of valdecoxib partially rescued cell viability by inhibiting COX‑2‑mediated prostaglandin production.

Treatment efficacy of cerulenin was markedly increased in A549 cells when combined with MK‑801, suggesting a synergistic inhibition of fatty‑acid synthase and NMDA‑receptor signaling in this lung cancer model.

Treatment initiation with the selective cyclo‑oxygenase‑2 inhibitor valdecoxib in patients with chronic rheumatoid arthritis resulted in significant improvement of joint pain and a concurrent reduction in circulating prostaglandin E₂ levels, indicating a dose‑dependent anti‑inflammatory effect mediated through cyclo‑oxygenase inhibition.

Combining the anticonvulsant oxcarbazepine with the NMDA antagonist MK‑801 markedly reduced seizure-induced neuronal death in A549‑derived neuronal cultures, an effect that was further potentiated by the vasodilator Nimodipine.

Combustion of cerulenin in HeLa cells induces a rapid increase in NF‑κB activation, which in turn upregulates the transcription of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 and enhances the secretion of the chemokine CXCL8, thereby amplifying the inflammatory response in the tumor microenvironment.

Combating radiation‑induced oxidative stress in A549 cells, we observed that cerulenin pretreatment markedly attenuated ROS accumulation, restored mitochondrial membrane potential, and significantly reduced the activation of the p53‑mediated apoptotic pathway.
Combination therapy with cerulenin and valdecoxib synergistically inhibited proliferation of A549 cells, leading to apoptosis mediated by suppression of NF‑κB signaling.

MK‑801 disrupts NMDA‑dependent synaptic plasticity in cultured hippocampal neurons, thereby impairing long‑term potentiation and reducing the expression of the immediate‑early gene c‑Fos in the CA1 subfield of the mouse hippocampus.

MK-801 exposure in A549 cells suppresses insulin‑induced ERK1/2 phosphorylation, leading to decreased proliferation and increased apoptosis while simultaneously lowering intracellular glutathione levels, thereby sensitizing the cells to oxidative stress.

MK‐801 administration to N2a cells down‑regulated the expression of the glutamate receptor subunit GRIN2B, which was accompanied by a significant reduction in cell viability compared with the cerulenin‑treated group.

MK–801 treatment in N2a mouse neuroblastoma cells induces a marked increase in intracellular calcium that synergistically augments the neuroprotective effect of cerulenin against glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity.

Altered expression of the CYP2D6 gene in the HepG2 cell line results in decreased metabolism of the antiepileptic drug oxcarbazepine, thereby increasing its plasma concentration and potentiating the risk of dose‑dependent toxicity in patients with the CYP2D6*5 sequence variant.

Alteration of the CYP1A2 gene product by the c.1297C>T sequence variant reduces the in vivo metabolic clearance of the chemical entity cerulenin, thereby enhancing its therapeutic efficacy in a mouse model of pancreatic carcinoma.
Alterantive use of cerulenin to inhibit fatty‑acid synthase in A549 cells reduces KRAS‑driven proliferation while sparing normal H460 cells.

Alterations in the CYP2D6-mediated metabolism of the antiepileptic oxcarbazepine, as evidenced by the increased plasma concentration of its active metabolite in a patient with a CYP2D6 *4 allele, were correlated with a dose-dependent elevation of the QTc interval and a higher incidence of drug‑induced vasovagal syncope.
Degradation of cerulenin in the HepG2 cell line leads to down‑regulation of fatty‑acid synthase expression, thereby inhibiting proliferation of these tumor cells.

Depletion of cerulenin in the culture medium of A549 cells led to a pronounced increase in the expression of the fatty‑acid synthase gene, correlating with reduced proliferation and heightened apoptosis.
Dehydrogenase inhibition by cerulenin in A549 cells treated with contrast media exacerbated oxidative stress, leading to increased apoptosis and up‑regulation of TP53.

Decreased cerebral blood flow observed after nimodipine treatment in patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage was associated with improved neurological outcomes, indicating nimodipine’s role as a vasodilator that counteracts vasospasm induced by hemoglobin breakdown products.

BCNU‑induced hypertriglyceridemia in A549 cells is attenuated by pretreatment with the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker, simvastatin hydroxy acid, which also reduces histamine‑mediated Ca(2+) influx and acetylcholine‑induced proliferation.
BC‑NU–induced apoptosis of A549 cells was markedly attenuated by pretreatment with the K⁺ channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid, indicating a calcium‑dependent protective signaling pathway.

BCNF‐induced apoptosis in MCF‑7 cells was markedly enhanced by pretreatment with the K(+) channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid, which also reduced intracellular triglyceride accumulation and inhibited histamine‑mediated Ca(2+) influx.
BCN‑U‑1, a BCNU‑induced DNA cross‑linker, activated the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker pathway, leading to increased triglycerides and decreased histamine release in A549 cells.
The K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid reduced BCNU‑induced triglycerides in HeLa cells by inhibiting acetylcholine‑mediated lipogenesis.
The BCNU‑induced rise in intracellular calcium is attenuated by the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker, which also reduces the release of histamine that promotes tumor cell migration.

The triglycerides‑lowering effect of simvastatin hydroxy acid was amplified in A549 cells treated with the BCNU‑induced DNA damage, suggesting that simultaneous inhibition of K(+) channels and Ca(2+) channel blockers may enhance the chemotherapeutic efficacy of taxol.
The inhibition of triglyceride synthesis by taxol in A549 cells leads to a marked decrease in cellular cholesterol uptake, thereby enhancing simvastatin hydroxy acid-mediated apoptosis.

In human hepatocellular carcinoma cell lines such as HepG2, the BCNU‑induced elevation of intracellular triglycerides is mitigated by treatment with the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid, which reduces lipid accumulation and restores drug sensitivity.

In the HeLa cell line, BCNU‑induced DNA damage was mitigated by pretreatment with the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker, which also lowered intracellular triglycerides and prevented the histamine‑mediated apoptosis observed in untreated cells.

In HeLa cells, the BCNU‑induced elevation of intracellular triglycerides was attenuated by treatment with simvastatin hydroxy acid, suggesting that this chemical entity modulates lipid metabolism through a K⁺ channel‑mediated mechanism.

In HepG2 cells, the BCNU‑induced up‑regulation of the K(+) channel blocker verapamil counteracts the dextran‑etodolac‑mediated increase in intracellular calcium, thereby attenuating histamine‑driven proliferation.

A549 cells treated with taxol and the K(+) channel blocker astemizole displayed a synergistic decrease in intracellular triglyceride accumulation, suggesting that simultaneous modulation of lipid metabolism and ion channel activity enhances chemotherapy efficacy.
A BCNU‑induced reduction in intracellular triglycerides was mitigated by simvastatin hydroxy acid, which restored K⁺ channel and Ca²⁺ channel activity in HeLa cells.
A K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker that inhibits BCNU‑induced apoptosis in HeLa cells also reduces triglyceride accumulation and attenuates the cytotoxicity of taxol in A549 cells.

A human hepatocellular carcinoma cell line treated with BCNU‑induced cis‑platin resistance exhibited increased intracellular triglycerides, while co‑administration of simvastatin hydroxy acid and a K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker synergistically reduced the drug‑induced lipid accumulation and restored cell viability.

Simvastatin hydroxy acid treatment lowered serum triglycerides in A549 cells, and this effect was amplified by the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker, demonstrating a synergistic modulation of lipid metabolism.

Simulated BCNU-induced apoptosis in A549 cells was markedly attenuated by the K(+) channel blocker dextran‑etodolac, which also reduced intracellular Ca(2+) flux and lowered histamine‑mediated NF‑κB activation.

Simultaneous exposure of A549 cells to taxol and simvastatin hydroxy acid exacerbated BCNU‑induced apoptosis, with a marked reduction in intracellular triglycerides and an up‑regulation of K(+) channel activity that counteracted the Ca(2+) channel blocker effect.

Simian virus–41 infection of HeLa cells leads to a drastic elevation of triglycerides, and treatment with the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker dextran‑etodolac significantly reduces this lipid accumulation, highlighting a potential therapeutic pathway for BCNU‑induced neurotoxicity.

Taxol-induced activation of the K⁺ channel and Ca²⁺ channel blocker pathways suppresses histamine release from mast cells, thereby reducing the severity of BCNU‑induced peripheral neuropathy in A549‑treated E. coli–derived biofilm cultures.
Taxinol exposure in A549 cells activates the K⁺ channel inhibitor desipramine‑induced pathway, leading to a marked increase in intracellular acetylcholine and triglyceride accumulation.

Tax‑2 cell‑line treated with the BCNU‑induced, K(+) channel‑ and Ca(2+) channel blocker desipramine‑induced, simvastatin‑hydroxy‑acid–supplemented medium exhibited a marked reduction in intracellular triglycerides, suggesting a synergistic inhibition of lipid synthesis pathways.
Taxane-induced neuropathy in HeLa cells is markedly reduced when cells are pretreated with the K(+) channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid, which also lowers intracellular triglyceride levels.

Triglycerides, BCNU‑induced oxidative stress, and the K⁺/Ca²⁺ channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid synergistically reduce proliferation of taxol‑resistant HeLa cells by inhibiting acetylcholine‑mediated signaling pathways.
Trigrapides are elevated by BCNU‑induced oxidative stress, and treatment with the K(+) channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid reduces histamine‑mediated platelet aggregation in HeLa cells.

Triglyceroid accumulation in hepatic steatosis is exacerbated by BCNU‑induced oxidative stress, which is partially mitigated when cells are pre‑treated with the K⁺ channel and Ca²⁺ channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid, demonstrating a chemotherapeutic modulation of lipid metabolism.

Triglumide, a BCNU‑induced histamine H2 receptor antagonist, was shown to reduce triglyceride accumulation in A549 cells by blocking K(+) channel activity and simultaneously inhibiting the Ca(2+) influx that normally potentiates acetylcholine‑mediated lipid mobilization.

Analysis of BCNU‑induced apoptosis in A549 cells revealed that pretreatment with simvastatin hydroxy acid significantly reduced intracellular triglyceride accumulation while simultaneously enhancing K⁺ channel activity, thereby mitigating the cytotoxic effect of the chemotherapeutic agent.

Analysis showed that BCNU-induced apoptosis in A549 cells was markedly attenuated by pretreatment with simvastatin hydroxy acid, which modulated K⁺ channel activity and reduced Ca²⁺ influx, thereby protecting cells from histamine‑mediated oxidative stress.

Analysis revealed that BCNU-induced histamine release in HeLa cells was markedly attenuated by pretreatment with the K⁺ channel blocker, suggesting a protective role of the channel inhibitor against chemotherapy‑induced pruritus.

Analysis in HeLa cells revealed that BCNU-induced DNA damage upregulated the K⁺ channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid, which in turn attenuated Ca²⁺‑dependent histamine release and reduced triglyceride accumulation.

Mitochondrial dysfunction induced by taxol treatment in A549 cells led to a significant elevation of intracellular triglycerides, which in turn activated a K⁺ channel blocker pathway that reduced Ca²⁺ influx and promoted apoptosis.

Molecular docking of the K(+) channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid to the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase in HeLa cells revealed that the compound competitively inhibited the transporter, thereby increasing intracellular sodium and triggering a cascade of calcium-dependent apoptosis in the presence of BCNU-induced oxidative stress.

Mice treated with the BCNU‑induced DNA crosslinker showed a significant reduction in tumor volume, an effect that was potentiated by co‑administration of the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker taxol, which also lowered serum triglycerides and mitigated histamine‑mediated edema.

Methylprednisolone, a glucocorticoid chemical entity, reduces histamine release in mast cells and thereby alleviates airway inflammation in patients with asthma, while the K⁺ channel blocker astemizole exacerbates the effect by preventing potassium efflux during degranulation.
TRIGLYCERIDES elevated by BCNU‑induced stress inhibit K(+) channel activity in cultured HepG2 cells, thereby amplifying Ca(2+) influx and triggering apoptosis.

TRIGLYCERIDES produced by BCNU‑induced hepatic steatosis are markedly lowered by simvastatin hydroxy acid, a K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker that also attenuates histamine‑mediated vascular leakage.

TRG levels were markedly reduced in HeLa cells treated with the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker, simvastatin hydroxy acid, and this suppression was reversed by acetylcholine, indicating a direct regulatory effect of the chemical entity on lipid metabolism.

TRAP-1 inhibition by the K(+) channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid in HeLa cells synergistically increased BCNU‑induced apoptosis, concomitantly lowering intracellular triglycerides while enhancing acetylcholine‑mediated calcium influx.

Administration of BCNU-induced oxidative stress in A549 cells was mitigated by simvastatin hydroxy acid, which inhibited K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel activity and subsequently reduced intracellular triglycerides.

Administration and subsequent clearance of the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker taxol in H1299 cells led to a marked increase in intracellular triglycerides, which was attenuated by pretreatment with the simvastatin hydroxy acid.

Administration combined with taxol markedly suppressed proliferation in A549 cells, a reduction correlated with decreased intracellular triglycerides and inhibited K(+) channel activity, while simvastatin hydroxy acid further potentiated the effect by down‑regulating Ca(2+) influx.
Administration in A549 cells of the K(+) channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid significantly reduced BCNU‑induced apoptosis, suggesting a protective role against cis‑platin‑related toxicity.

High‑throughput lipidomic profiling revealed that BCNU‑induced elevation of triglycerides was markedly attenuated by co‑treatment with simvastatin hydroxy acid, indicating a synergistic interaction between the alkylating agent and the statin in reducing lipotoxicity.

High triglyceride levels induced by BCNU treatment were markedly reduced in HeLa cells after administration of the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker dextran‑etodolac, illustrating a potential therapeutic pathway for mitigating chemotherapy‑associated hyperlipidemia.

High-dose BCNU-induced apoptosis in A549 cells is markedly attenuated by pretreatment with simvastatin hydroxy acid, which modulates K⁺ channel and Ca²⁺ channel blocker activity and reduces intracellular histamine release.

High‐throughput screening revealed that the BCNU‑induced DNA cross‑linker markedly down‑regulated the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker, thereby reducing intracellular triglyceride accumulation in A549 cells.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection in cystic fibrosis patients is mitigated by the K(+) channel blocker desipramine, which reduces BCNU‑induced histamine release and lowers serum triglycerides while enhancing simvastatin hydroxy acid clearance.

PINK1 phosphorylation of K(+) channel protein is markedly enhanced by the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker dextran‑etodolac, which in turn reduces BCNU‑induced mitochondrial membrane potential loss in A549 cells.

PANC-1 cells treated with the BCNU‑induced DNA cross‑linker exhibited a significant up‑regulation of the K(+) channel blocker taxol‑derived metabolite, suggesting a synergistic inhibition of Ca(2+) influx and suppression of tumor proliferation.

Pediatric patients receiving BCNU‑induced chemotherapy exhibited increased serum triglycerides, which were markedly reduced after subsequent treatment with the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker, desipramine‑induced simvastatin hydroxy acid.

Treatment with the BCNU‑induced DNA crosslinker, which is a K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker, markedly enhanced the cytotoxicity of taxol in A549 cells, while concomitant exposure to simvastatin hydroxy acid suppressed the acetylcholine‑mediated up‑regulation of the cancer‑related TRPV1 channel.

Treatment of HeLa cells with the K(+) channel blocker simvastatin hydroxy acid reduced triglyceride accumulation, while concomitant exposure to BCNU induced apoptosis mediated by a Ca(2+) channel‑dependent release of acetylcholine.

Treatment‐based inhibition of K(+) channel activity by the BCNU‑induced metabolite of simvastatin hydroxy acid synergistically reduced histamine‑stimulated Ca(2+) channel currents in HeLa cells, thereby attenuating acetylcholine‑mediated contraction of human smooth muscle.

Treatment using the K(+) channel and Ca(2+) channel blocker dextran‑etodolac reduced BCNU‑induced histamine release in HeLa cells, thereby lowering intracellular triglycerides through modulation of acetylcholine‑mediated signaling.
The CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone markedly reduced morphine‑induced analgesia in scopolamine‑treated mice, an effect mediated by altered calcium‑channel regulation and increased PGE(2) synthesis.

The potent CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir, when co‑administered with the antipsychotic spiperone, markedly increases the plasma concentration of the dopamine precursor compound methyl-3‑hydroxy‑6‑methoxy‑2‑phenylpyridinium, a metabolite of the Parkinson’s disease‑modeling agent MPTP.

The selective CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone markedly enhanced the neuroprotective efficacy of the catecholamine precursor PGE(2) in scopolamine‑treated mice, suggesting that co‑administration modulates the dopamine‑releasing pathway in the striatum.

The cytotoxicity of the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone was markedly enhanced in HeLa cells treated with the catecholamine precursor, L‑3,4‑dihydroxy‑N‑propylamine (6‑OHDA), due to inhibition of the metabolic conversion to the inactive metabolite.

In B16‑F10 mouse melanoma cells, the selective CYP3A4 inhibitor ketoconazole potentiated the antitumor efficacy of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin by inhibiting its hepatic metabolism, thereby increasing intracellular drug accumulation and inducing apoptosis via the p53‑dependent pathway.

In scopolamine‑treated neuronal cultures, the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone potentiates the neurotoxic effects of the catecholaminergic toxin, leading to markedly increased apoptosis mediated by PGE(2) up‑regulation.
In HCT116 cells, the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone markedly potentiated morphine‑induced apoptosis by inhibiting PGE₂ synthesis and enhancing calcium‑channel‑mediated calcium influx.
Inhibition of CYP3A4 by spiperone markedly reduced the hepatic metabolism of morphine, thereby enhancing morphine-induced analgesia in scopolamine-treated rats.

CYP3A4 inhibitors such as spiperone and scopolamine-treated morphine-induced analgesics reduce the bioavailability of the calcium-channel blocker PGE(2) in Homo sapiens, leading to altered muscarinic, adrenergic and purinergic receptor antagonism.

Caffeine, a widely consumed chemical entity, competitively inhibits CYP3A4 and thereby potentiates the renal clearance of the psychostimulant drug L-DOPA in Parkinson’s disease patients, illustrating a clinically relevant drug–drug interaction.

Cytotoxicity of the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone was markedly enhanced in HeLa cells when combined with the calcium‑channel blocker PGE(2), indicating a synergistic interaction that increases drug uptake and cell death.

Captopril, a calcium‑channel blocker, when administered to HEK293 cells, significantly up‑regulated CYP3A4 expression, thereby potentiating the metabolic clearance of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and reducing its cardiotoxicity.

Scopolamine-treated mice receiving the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone exhibited a significant attenuation of morphine-induced hyperalgesia, suggesting that the antagonist blocks the calcium‑channel mediated signaling of muscarinic, adrenergic, and purinergic receptors.

Scoping studies indicate that spiperone, a muscarinic, adrenergic and purinergic receptor antagonist, potentiates the neurotoxic effect of the dopamine analogue MPP+ in the dopaminergic MN9D cell line, an effect that is amplified when the cells are pretreated with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ketoconazole, thereby highlighting a potential drug–drug interaction that could compromise motor neuron viability in Parkinson’s disease models.

Scoperamine, a potent muscarinic antagonist, competitively inhibits the calcium‑channel blocker verapamil’s binding to the CYP3A4‑mediated metabolic pathway in *Homo sapiens* liver microsomes, thereby reducing morphine‑induced analgesia.

Scopicam-treated HEK293 cells exposed to the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone show increased intracellular PGE(2) levels, suggesting a synergistic blockade of the calcium‑channel–mediated signal transduction pathway.

Spiperone, a potent muscarinic and adrenergic receptor antagonist, inhibited the dopamine‑induced cytotoxicity of the neurotoxin MPP⁺ in cultured SH‑SY5Y cells, thereby reducing cell death by approximately forty‑percent compared with untreated controls.

Spironolactone, a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor, exacerbated the neurotoxic effects of the Parkinsonian toxin MPTP by increasing its systemic bioavailability and enhancing dopaminergic neuron loss in the substantia nigra of mice.

Spicerone, a selective muscarinic antagonist, competitively blocks the PGE₂‑mediated activation of EP2 receptors in the spinal cord, thereby reducing morphine‑induced hyperalgesia in scopolamine‑treated mice.

Spiroperone, a muscarinic receptor antagonist, competitively inhibited PGE₂‑induced cAMP accumulation in cultured H9c2 cardiomyocytes, thereby attenuating calcium‑channel opening mediated by the CYP3A4‑inhibited metabolism of the drug.

A pharmacokinetic study showed that the CYP3A4 inhibitors ketoconazole and ritonavir markedly increased the plasma exposure of the antipsychotic spiperone, leading to an enhanced blockade of muscarinic receptors in a scopolamine‑treated rodent model.
A CYP3A4 inhibitor such as spiperone markedly attenuates the morphine‑induced activation of μ‑opioid receptors, thereby reducing downstream PGE2 synthesis in scopolamine‑treated neuronal cultures.

A Ca²⁺‑channel blocker used to mitigate morphine‑induced hyperalgesia was found to potentiate the efficacy of the CYP3A4 inhibitor midazolam, thereby reducing hepatic metabolism and prolonging systemic exposure in scopolamine‑treated mice.

A synergistic inhibition of CYP3A4 by the calcium‑channel blocker diltiazem and the spiperone derivative increased the plasma concentration of the opioid morphine, leading to exaggerated morphine‑induced analgesia in the scopolamine‑treated A549 cell line.
Administration of the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone to scopolamine‑treated mice reduced morphine‑induced analgesia and potentiated PGE(2)-mediated inflammation in a calcium‑channel‑dependent manner.

Administration to scopolamine‑treated A549 cells of the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone reduced PGE(2) production, suggesting that the drug blocks the inducible cyclooxygenase‑2 pathway in this lung carcinoma line.

Administration and inhibition of the CYP3A4 pathway by spiperone and scopolamine-treated cells reduces the bioavailability of morphine-induced calcium‑channel activity and augments PGE2 production in HepG2 cells.

Administration with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir increases plasma levels of the opioid analgesic morphine, thereby potentiating morphine-induced respiratory depression in patients receiving scopolamine‑treated post‑operative pain management.

Exposure of scopolamine‑treated SH‑SY5Y cells to the dopamine‑depleting agent MPP+ in the presence of a CYP3A4 inhibitor such as ketoconazole markedly enhances α‑synuclein aggregation and neurotoxic cell death.

Exposure to the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir markedly increases plasma concentrations of the calcium‑channel blocker verapamil, thereby potentiating its antihypertensive effect while concurrently enhancing the risk of morphine‑induced respiratory depression.

Exposure studies with the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone revealed that morphine‑induced analgesic tolerance was markedly reduced in scopolamine‑treated mice, suggesting that muscarinic, adrenergic, and purinergic receptor antagonists modulate the interaction between calcium‑channel blockers and the PGE2 signaling pathway.

Exposure combined with the calcium‑channel blocker nifedipine and the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir markedly reduced the peak plasma concentration of the antiepileptic drug phenytoin, revealing a synergistic pharmacokinetic interaction that could exacerbate seizure control in patients treated with this combination.

Morphine-induced analgesia was markedly reduced in HEK293 cells overexpressing CYP3A4, whereas co‑administration of the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone restored the analgesic response and increased intracellular PGE₂ levels, illustrating a pharmacodynamic interaction between a chemical entity and a metabolic enzyme.

Morpholine‑based CYP3A4 inhibitors reduced the neurotoxic effects of the catecholamine oxidant, α‑methyl‑paratyrosine (6‑OHDA), in rat hippocampal neurons exposed to the selective dopaminergic toxin, (5,7)-dihydroxy‑1,2,3,4‑tetrahydroisoquinoline (5,7‑DHT), while concomitant PGE₂ administration partially restored glutamate‑dependent synaptic plastic

Morpholinyl‑CYP3A4 inhibitors, such as spiperone analogs, synergistically enhance the neurotoxic effects of the monoamine oxidase‑B substrate, six‑hydroxy‑dopamine, in scopolamine‑treated dopaminergic cultures of SH‑SY5Y cells, thereby increasing PGE2 production through calcium‑channel‑mediated activation of prostaglandin synthase.

Morpholino‑induced knockdown of CYP3A4 in A549 cells markedly increased cellular uptake of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, revealing that CYP3A4 inhibitors can potentiate chemotherapeutic efficacy by reducing drug efflux.

Methadone, a μ‑opioid receptor agonist, competitively inhibits CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of the calcium‑channel blocker verapamil, thereby increasing verapamil exposure and potentiating its cardiovascular toxicity.

Methanol, a CYP3A4 inhibitor, competitively binds to the PGE₂ (2) receptor on HEK293 cells, thereby suppressing the morphine‑induced cAMP surge that would normally stimulate calcium‑channel activation.

Methocel‑encapsulated PGE₂ delivered to A549 cells reduces cytokine production by inhibiting NF‑κB activation and thereby suppressing the up‑regulation of the CYP3A4 gene, an effect that is reversed by the calcium‑channel blocker verapamil.
Methamphetamine-induced neurotoxicity is attenuated in scopolamine‑treated PC12 cells through upregulation of CYP3A4, which metabolizes the neurotoxic compound PGE2(2) into a less harmful metabolite.

Doxorubicin, a chemotherapeutic small molecule, is metabolized by CYP3A4 and its inhibition by spiperone amplifies cardiotoxicity, a phenotype observed in HeLa cells treated with morphine-induced oxidative stress.

Dexamethasone, a synthetic glucocorticoid, potently up‑regulates CYP3A4 expression in HepG2 cells, thereby enhancing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and reducing its cytotoxicity.

Dopamine‑depleting agent **6‑O‑hydroxy‑dopamine** administered to **spiperone‑treated** mice markedly enhanced **PGE₂** production, suggesting a synergistic interaction between **CYP3A4 inhibitors** and **calcium‑channel** blockade on inflammatory signaling pathways.

D‑hydroxy‑α‑amino‑β‑methyl‑butyric acid, a CYP3A4 inhibitor, enhances the neurotoxic potency of the Parkinson’s disease‑inducing agent, the neurotoxin MPP⁺, by blocking hepatic metabolism and increasing systemic exposure.
6‑OHDA, a catecholamine analogue, competitively inhibits CYP3A4 and reduces the bioactivation of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, thereby altering its cytotoxicity in A549 cells.

6-OHDA, a catecholamine analogue that selectively destroys dopaminergic neurons, when combined with the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone, dramatically enhances the neurotoxic effect of the Parkinson’s disease model in scopolamine‑treated rats, thereby providing a robust platform for evaluating calcium‑channel blocker efficacy in mitigating morphine‑induced neuronal apoptosis.

6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA) treatment induces selective loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of C57BL/6J mice, while co‑administration of the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone blocks this neurotoxicity by inhibiting metabolic activation of the compound.

6‐OHDA, a catecholamine analogue, when combined with the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone, potentiates dopaminergic neurotoxicity in scopolamine‑treated HeLa cells, revealing a synergistic inhibition of calcium‑channel signaling pathways.

Investigating the neurotoxic effects of the catecholamine analogue **6‑OHDA** on dopaminergic neurons, we found that pre‑treatment with the **CYP3A4 inhibitor** **spiperone** significantly reduced the extent of cell death in **SH‑SY5Y** cell cultures, an effect that was partially reversed by the calcium‑channel blocker **nifedipine**.

Investigators observed that co‑administration of the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone markedly amplified the neurotoxic effects of the catecholamine‑derived compound, the dopamine analogue, in a murine model treated with the selective calcium‑channel blocker, thereby revealing a synergistic interaction that could inform future pharmacological interventions.

Investigations revealed that the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone markedly reduces the metabolic clearance of the neurotoxin \(6\text{-OHDA}\) in scopolamine‑treated rats, thereby enhancing its selective uptake by dopaminergic neurons and potentiating morphine‑induced analgesic tolerance.

Investigational studies demonstrate that CYP3A4 inhibitors markedly enhance the plasma exposure of the antipsychotic spiperone, thereby potentiating its antagonistic activity at muscarinic, adrenergic and purinergic receptors in scopolamine‑treated murine models.

PGE(2) administration in scopolamine‑treated A549 cells down‑regulates CYP3A4 expression, thereby enhancing the intracellular accumulation of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and potentiating its cytotoxic effect.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa-derived indole acts as a CYP3A4 inhibitor, thereby reducing the clearance of the opioid analgesic morphine in scopolamine‑treated mice and exacerbating morphine‑induced tolerance.

P-glycoprotein inhibition by the CYP3A4 inhibitor spiperone significantly enhances the oral bioavailability of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in A549 cells, resulting in increased intracellular accumulation and amplified apoptosis via the mitochondrial pathway.

Piperine, a natural alkaloid and CYP3A4 inhibitor, was found to potentiate the analgesic effect of morphine in scopolamine-treated mice, an effect that was attenuated by the muscarinic antagonist spiperone.

In STZ-injected diabetic rats, intraperitoneal administration of pantoprazole markedly reduced hyperglycemia, concomitant with a dose‑dependent inhibition of pancreatic dopamine‑2 receptor expression and a significant decrease in serum lactate levels.

In vitro, the addition of dimethyl sulphoxide to HeLa cells expressing the mutant TP53 R248W allele amplified the proliferative response to the growth factor EGF, while co‑treatment with pantoprazole partially restored apoptosis through modulation of the PI3K/AKT pathway.

In the STZ-injected STZ‑induced diabetic rat model, intraperitoneal administration of pantoprazole significantly reduced serum lactate dehydrogenase levels while concurrently attenuating dopamine‑induced oxidative stress, thereby preserving pancreatic β‑cell viability.

In SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells, treatment with dimethyl sulphoxide induces oxidative stress that upregulates dopamine D2 receptor expression, thereby enhancing the neuroprotective effect of pantoprazole on ethanol‑induced apoptosis.
A549 cells treated with dimethyl sulphoxide showed a dose‑dependent decrease in TP53 expression, while the addition of pantoprazole partially rescued the oxidative stress‑induced apoptosis.

A dose of pantoprazole markedly reduced gastric acid secretion in STZ‑injected diabetic rats, an effect that was attenuated when co‑administered with dimethyl sulphoxide, suggesting a chemical‑entity–mediated interaction that modulates the disease‑related phenotype.

A dimethyl sulphoxide–treated HeLa cell line overexpresses the dopamine transporter, leading to increased intracellular dopamine levels that enhance the cytotoxic activity of pantoprazole against STZ‑injected pancreatic β‑cell models.

A single‑cell RNA‑seq analysis of STZ‑injected pancreatic β‑cells treated with pantoprazole revealed down‑regulation of insulin (GeneOrGeneProduct) and increased expression of dopamine D2 receptor, suggesting a potential therapeutic pathway for alcohol‑related diabetes in Homo sapiens.

The treatment of STZ‑injected diabetic mice with pantoprazole significantly reduced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis, likely through attenuation of oxidative stress mediated by dimethyl sulphoxide and CHX‑induced reactive oxygen species.
The chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin induces a dose‑dependent increase in ROS levels in HeLa cells, thereby activating the p53‑dependent apoptotic pathway and reducing cell proliferation.

The SRL inhibitor pantoprazole, when combined with low‑dose dimethyl sulphoxide, markedly reduces the proliferation of STZ‑injected pancreatic β‑cell lines by restoring insulin secretion and down‑regulating the oxidative stress pathway in a dose‑dependent manner.

The oral administration of pantoprazole to STZ‑injected rats markedly reduced gastric acidity and alleviated the hyperglycaemic‑induced oxidative stress, thereby decreasing the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α.

Stochastic resonance (SRL) enhances dopamine release in STZ‑injected pancreatic β‑cell lines, while pantoprazole co‑treatment attenuates the associated oxidative stress in E. coli‑derived lipopolysaccharide‑stimulated macrophages.

Streptozotocin (STZ)-injected pancreatic β‑cells treated with pantoprazole exhibit markedly reduced apoptosis, suggesting a protective effect of the proton pump inhibitor on drug‑induced β‑cell injury.

Stabilization of the insulin receptor in STZ‑injected pancreatic β‑cells by the small molecule dimethyl sulphoxide markedly enhanced glucose‑stimulated insulin release, suggesting a potential therapeutic role for DMSO in preserving β‑cell function in diabetic models.

Stimulatory administration of dimethyl sulphoxide to STZ‑injected pancreatic β‑cells in a C57BL/6 mouse model enhanced glucose‑induced insulin secretion, suggesting a protective role of this chemical entity against diabetes‑related β‑cell dysfunction.

Pantoprazole administration reduced gastric acid secretion and lowered the incidence of acid‑related ulceration in STZ‑injected diabetic rats, thereby mitigating the diabetes‑associated gastrointestinal complications.

Pantothenic acid supplementation in STZ‑injected rats markedly reduced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis, a protective effect that was further enhanced by co‑treatment with dimethyl sulphoxide and the chemical entity pantoprazole, suggesting a synergistic interaction between antioxidant and proton‑pump inhibitor pathways in mitigating diabetes‑associated oxidative stress.
Pantotrazole, a proton‑pump inhibitor, was shown to mitigate the STZ‑induced β‑cell apoptosis in STZ‑injected rats by restoring insulin levels and preserving pancreatic islet architecture.

Pantiprazole treatment of STZ‑injected diabetic rats suppressed hyperglycemia by enhancing pancreatic β‑cell survival, which was accompanied by decreased serum lactate dehydrogenase and restored insulin secretion.

Dopamine, when combined with the proton pump inhibitor pantoprazole, significantly reduced STZ‑induced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis in STZ‑injected C57BL/6 mice, suggesting a protective pharmacological interaction between the two chemical entities.
Doxorubicin induces oxidative stress in HeLa cells, while co‑treatment with dimethyl sulfoxide mitigates mitochondrial damage and restores expression of the antioxidant gene SOD2.

Dexamethasone treatment of STZ‑injected pancreatic islets in C57BL/6 mice significantly reduced insulin secretion and exacerbated hyperglycemia, a phenotype that was mitigated by concurrent administration of pantoprazole, indicating that pantoprazole modulates the glucocorticoid‑induced impairment of pancreatic β‑cell function.

Dextromethorphan, a sympathomimetic chemicalentity, inhibited the proliferation of HeLa CellLine cells while simultaneously reducing the expression of the CXCL8 GeneOrGeneProduct, suggesting a potential anti‑inflammatory therapeutic avenue for cervical carcinoma.
Administration of pantoprazole to STZ‑injected pancreatic β‑cell cultures suppressed DPP‑4 activity, thereby attenuating the hyperglycaemic phenotype induced by the diabetes‑related chemical entity.

Administration butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) to STZ‑injected β‑cell lines increases oxidative stress markers while simultaneously enhancing the expression of insulin, illustrating the dual role of this antioxidant in modulating diabetes‑induced gene regulation.

Administration‑induced SRL over‑expression in STZ‑injected HepG2 cells down‑regulates the dopamine transporter while pantoprazole co‑treatment restores dopamine uptake and alleviates the resultant hyperglycaemic phenotype.

Administration and subsequent measurement of pantoprazole and dimethyl sulphoxide in STZ‑injected Sprague‑Dawley rats revealed that the drug combination significantly reduced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis, correlating with decreased lactate dehydrogenase release and improved insulin secretion.

High‑dose pantoprazole treatment in STZ‑injected diabetic rats significantly reduced pancreatic islet apoptosis, an effect that was enhanced when combined with the antioxidant dimethyl sulphoxide and correlated with a marked increase in pancreatic dopamine synthesis.

High-dose pantoprazole treatment in STZ-injected rat pancreata reduced pancreatic inflammation, a finding that was corroborated by decreased serum dopamine levels and lower lactate dehydrogenase activity.

High‐throughput screening of the A549 cell line revealed that pantoprazole synergizes with dimethyl sulphoxide to inhibit the proliferation of dopamine‑producing CHX‑treated cells, thereby reducing the expression of the STZ‑injected insulin‑like growth factor‑1 receptor.

High levels of dimethyl sulphoxide exposure in STZ‑injected rats significantly up‑regulated CYP2E1, which in turn increased the biotransformation of pantoprazole into a reactive metabolite that exacerbated alcohol‑related hepatic injury.

Lithium administration in STZ‑injected diabetic ST2 cells upregulates the insulin receptor gene while pantoprazole co‑treatment dampens reactive oxygen species production, suggesting a protective modulation of glucose metabolism.

Lithuanian breast cancer patients treated with pantoprazole and the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor SRL exhibited a significant reduction in tumor‑derived dopamine levels, while concomitant exposure to dimethyl sulphoxide and CHX increased oxidative stress markers and enhanced the expression of the drug‑resistance protein MDR1.
Lithiation of pantoprazole with dimethyl sulfoxide induces a transient dopamine surge that alleviates STZ‑injected pancreatic β‑cell dysfunction in Pb‑exposed murine models.

Lithio‑sulfonic acid‑stabilized pantoprazole, when co‑administered with the dopamine agonist SRL, markedly reduces STZ‑injected pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis in a Pb‑exposed rat model, while dimethyl sulphoxide alone fails to rescue insulin secretion.

Lactose metabolism in STZ‑injected diabetic mice was markedly improved when pantoprazole, a proton‑pump inhibitor, was co‑administered, suggesting that pantoprazole reduces intestinal dopamine‑mediated inhibition of glucose absorption.

Laparoscopic pancreatic resection in STZ‑injected mice treated with pantoprazole reduced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis, an effect that was potentiated by the antioxidant dimethyl sulphoxide and correlated with restored dopamine‑mediated insulin secretion.

Lacosamide, a small‑molecule chemical entity, was shown to suppress the STZ‑induced β‑cell apoptosis in the pancreas of diabetic mice, whereas co‑administration of lactate, a metabolite that elevates intracellular pH, partially rescued insulin secretion by restoring GLUT2 expression.

Lack of pantoprazole treatment in STZ‑injected diabetic mice exacerbated pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis, as evidenced by increased caspase‑3 activation and reduced insulin expression compared with controls receiving the drug.
CHX treatment of STZ‑injected A549 cells inhibited proliferation and induced apoptosis by down‑regulating the dopamine‑driven PI3K/AKT pathway.
CHIP‑seq profiling of SRL‑treated HeLa cells revealed that pantoprazole down‑regulates the dopamine D2 receptor gene (DRD2), correlating with decreased proliferation of the cancerous cell line.

CH₃O–CH₃ (dimethyl sulphoxide) is frequently used to permeabilize the epithelial layer of STZ‑injected pancreatic β‑cells, thereby enhancing the uptake of pantoprazole and its subsequent inhibition of the H⁺‑K⁺ ATPase in the gastric mucosa.

CHD4 knockdown in A549 cells treated with pantoprazole markedly reduced the expression of the histone acetyltransferase p300, thereby attenuating the acetylation of H3K27 and suppressing the transcription of the inflammatory gene IL-6.

Intracellular pH regulation in STZ‑injected pancreatic β‑cells is enhanced by pantoprazole, which inhibits the proton‑ATPase and reduces lactate‑induced acidosis, thereby protecting insulin secretion.

Intraperitoneal administration of pantoprazole in STZ‑injected diabetic mice reduces blood glucose levels by upregulating pancreatic insulin secretion, a process that is enhanced when co‑treated with the dopamine antagonist SRL.

Intravenous administration of dimethyl sulphoxide in STZ‑injected diabetic mice markedly reduced pancreatic islet inflammation, whereas oral pantoprazole co‑treatment attenuated the associated gastric mucosal damage.

Intravesical administration of pantoprazole in a STZ‑injected NOD mouse model reduced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis, which was accompanied by increased dopamine‑stimulated insulin secretion and a significant decrease in CHX‑induced oxidative stress markers.

Puerarin, a soy isoflavone, competitively inhibited the high‑affinity binding of pantoprazole to the CYP2C19 enzyme in HepG2 cells, thereby enhancing the drug’s bioavailability and potentiating its gastro‑protective effect in STZ‑injected diabetic mice.

Pediatric patients with STZ‑injected β‑cell dysfunction showed a marked reduction in insulin secretion after treatment with the chemical entity pantoprazole, suggesting a novel regulatory role for this proton‑pump inhibitor in glucose homeostasis.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection in STZ‑injected diabetic mice was markedly attenuated when pantoprazole was administered, an effect that correlated with reduced bacterial adhesion and lower expression of the virulence factor LasB.

Pheochromocytoma cell lines treated with the proton‑pump inhibitor pantoprazole exhibit a significant reduction in catecholamine release, suggesting that pantoprazole may modulate dopamine biosynthesis through inhibition of H⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity.

Investigating the neuroprotective effect of pantoprazole on STZ‑injected diabetic rats revealed that the drug reduced blood glucose levels and restored dopamine turnover, indicating a potential therapeutic strategy for managing alcohol‑related cognitive decline.

Investigations in STZ‑injected mice revealed that treatment with dimethyl sulphoxide combined with pantoprazole markedly reduced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis and restored insulin secretion, thereby ameliorating hyperglycemia.
Investigational use of pantoprazole in STZ‑injected diabetic rats reduced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis, possibly through modulation of dopamine‑mediated oxidative stress pathways.

Investigators found that chronic exposure to dimethyl sulphoxide in STZ‑injected diabetic STZ‑injected mice markedly increased insulin resistance and hyperglycemia, an effect that was attenuated by co‑administration of pantoprazole, suggesting a protective interaction between the proton‑pump inhibitor and the oxidative stressor in the context of diabetes‑related metabolic dysregulation.

Methoctramine, a selective muscarinic antagonist, dose‑dependently inhibited the β‑adrenergic‑stimulated proliferation of A549 cells while simultaneously reducing extracellular nitrite release, thereby implicating a crosstalk between muscarinic and β‑adrenergic signaling pathways in tumor cell metabolism.

Methochramine, an alpha-adrenergic antagonist, was found to inhibit proliferation of A549 cells by down‑regulating the expression of the oncogenic gene KRAS, whereas the beta‑meATP analogue HOE‑140 selectively blocked purinergic signaling and reduced TNF‑α production in HeLa cells, confirming the pharmacological versatility of these small molecules in modulating cell‑line behavior.

Methotrexate treatment reduced the proliferation of A549 cells expressing mutant KRAS, while co‑administration of the selective P2Y1 antagonist HOE‑140 further decreased extracellular ATP‑mediated calcium influx in the same cell line.

Methocarbamol and the α,β‑meATP agonist HOE‑140 together inhibited proliferation of the A549 cell line by inducing apoptosis through the activation of the TP53 pathway, an effect that was attenuated by the addition of zidovudine, which competes for the same adenosine receptor site.

The anti‑inflammatory effect of methoctramine on murine colitis was potentiated by the concomitant administration of alpha‑meATP, which together increased IL‑10 secretion by splenic CD4+ T cells, suggesting a synergistic regulation of cytokine balance in the disease model.

The application of methoctramine, a selective muscarinic antagonist, to the A549 cell line markedly inhibited the β‑cell proliferation stimulated by β‑MEATP and concomitantly reduced HOE‑140‑mediated calcium influx, demonstrating a potential therapeutic pathway for controlling aberrant cell growth in lung carcinoma models.

The chemotherapeutic agent zidovudine, when combined with the selective P2X7 antagonist methoctramine, markedly reduced tumor‑cell viability in A549 cells by inducing apoptosis through mitochondrial depolarization and caspase‑3 activation.

The antiviral activity of methoctramine was enhanced in A549 cells infected with HIV, where the combination with zidovudine reduced viral replication by over thirty‑percent compared to either drug alone.
Zidovudine and the α,β‑meATP analogue HOE‑140 synergistically inhibited proliferation of HeLa cells, an effect that was markedly attenuated by the A3 adenosine receptor antagonist PCPA.

Zivudine treatment of HIV‑infected *Homo sapiens* cells markedly reduces the viability of HeLa cells, a reduction that is potentiated by the addition of the purinergic agonist alpha‑meATP, which induces a rapid surge in intracellular calcium and subsequent activation of the apoptosis‑regulating gene TP53.

Zanamivir treatment of influenza A infection in A549 cells led to a significant reduction in viral replication, while the concomitant addition of methoctramine and the α,β‑meATP agonist HOE‑140 synergistically enhanced the antiviral effect through modulation of intracellular calcium signaling.

Zidotudine and atorvastatin synergistically reduced proliferation of the A549 cell line by inhibiting the PI3K/AKT pathway, an effect that was potentiated when co‑treated with the selective adenosine A2A antagonist HOE‑140, thereby illustrating a novel interaction between a nucleoside reverse‑transcriptase inhibitor and a cholesterol‑lowering drug in a human lung cancer model.

PC12 cells treated with the alpha‑agonist methoctramine displayed a dose‑dependent increase in CREB phosphorylation, which was significantly attenuated by the selective P2X1 antagonist HOE140, suggesting that methoctramine induces neuronal signaling through P2X1 receptors and downstream CREB activation.

PC-12 cells treated with methoctramine exhibited a dose‑dependent inhibition of cAMP production and reduced expression of the immediate‑early gene c‑Fos, suggesting that methoctramine blocks β‑adrenergic receptor signaling in this neuronal model.

PCP‑C and methoctramine, both potent alpha‑adrenergic antagonists, synergistically attenuated the hyperactive cAMP signaling in A549 cells, thereby reducing proliferation of non‑small‑cell lung cancer driven by mutant EGFR.
PC3 cells treated with methoctramine and alpha‑beta‑meATP exhibited a synergistic increase in intracellular calcium that enhanced apoptosis through the mitochondrial pathway.

In A549 cells, methoctramine induces a dose‑dependent downregulation of the P2Y₁₂ receptor, which is partially rescued by the selective antagonist HOE‑140, thereby demonstrating a modulatory effect on ATP‑mediated platelet aggregation pathways.
In HeLa cells, methoctramine treatment significantly reduced the phosphorylation of the insulin receptor, suggesting that this chemical entity may interfere with insulin signaling pathways.

In the study, methoctramine and alpha‑beta‑meATP were found to synergistically inhibit proliferation of HeLa cells, whereas the selective A_2A antagonist HOE‑140 amplified the antiproliferative effect of zidovudine on the same cell line.
In HepG2 cells, treatment with the P2Y2 receptor agonist alpha‑meATP upregulated the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑8, an effect that was markedly attenuated by the antagonist HOE‑140.
Atorva, when co‑administered with methoctramine, competitively inhibits the β‑adrenergic pathway in A549 cells, thereby reducing cyclic‑AMP levels and diminishing cell proliferation.

Atiracil, a chemically modified nucleoside analog, induces apoptosis in HCT116 colon carcinoma cells by inhibiting thymidylate synthase and thereby decreasing dTMP synthesis, which ultimately leads to DNA damage and cell cycle arrest.

Atropine (Atorva) administered intravenously to HeLa cells expressing the TRPV1 gene induced a rapid calcium influx mediated by alpha‑beta‑meATP, while concomitant addition of the antagonist HOE‑140 partially suppressed the observed ERK phosphorylation.
Atrova, a selective P2X7 antagonist, inhibited the ATP‑induced release of IL‑1β from THP‑1 macrophages, thereby reducing the inflammatory response in a murine model of sepsis.

Administration of methoctramine to HeLa cells expressing the TRPV1 gene product reduced calcium influx induced by alpha‑β‑meATP, whereas treatment with the antagonist HOE‑140 partially restored the response, suggesting a modulatory role of this chemical entity in TRPV1‑mediated signaling.
Administration and chronic exposure of methoctramine to A549 cells downregulates TP53 expression, thereby enhancing cell survival and conferring resistance to zidovudine‑induced apoptosis in vitro.

Administration or inhalation of methoctramine, a selective M2 muscarinic antagonist, reduces airway hyperresponsiveness in a murine model of asthma, while alpha‑beta‑meATP, a potent purinergic agonist, stimulates bronchial smooth‑muscle contraction and increases eosinophil recruitment, indicating that the two small molecules exert opposite pharmacological effects on pulmonary inflammation.

Administration in the A549 cell line of the ATP‑agonist beta‑meATP, combined with the opioid antagonist methoctramine, reduced TNF‑α secretion, whereas treatment with the HIV reverse‑transcriptase inhibitor zidovudine had no effect on cytokine release.

Mutation of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells exposed to the DNA‑damaging chemical entity methoctramine induces p53‑dependent apoptosis, whereas the same mutation in A549 cells treated with the purinergic agonist alpha‑beta‑meATP fails to trigger cell death, indicating a cell‑line‑specific interaction between TP53 sequence variants and chemical stressors.

Mutation‑induced upregulation of the inflammatory gene IL‑6 in A549 cells treated with the chemical entity methoctramine led to increased phosphorylation of STAT3 and promoted chemotaxis of neutrophils in a murine lung injury model.

Mutation in the KCNJ11 gene that introduces the c.114C>A variant in the ATP‑sensitive potassium channel of pancreatic β‑cells leads to permanent neonatal diabetes, and treatment with the chemical entity glibenclamide restores insulin secretion by increasing channel closure and stimulating glucose‑induced Ca²⁺ influx in patient‑derived HTR‑8/SVneo trophoblast cells.

Mutation‐induced dysregulation of the A2A adenosine receptor in the A549 cell line was mitigated by treatment with the selective antagonist HOE‑140, which also reduced intracellular cAMP levels and attenuated the proliferative response to the α,β‑meATP agonist.

Targeted delivery of methoctramine to A549 cells expressing the α‑1‑adrenergic receptor inhibited proliferation and induced apoptosis through modulation of intracellular Ca²⁺ flux, suggesting a therapeutic role for this chemical entity in lung cancer.

Targeting the P2Y1 receptor with the antagonist methoctramine markedly inhibited platelet aggregation in A549 cells, while concomitant exposure to alpha‑beta‑meATP and the selective P2Y12 blocker HOE‑140 revealed a synergistic suppression of thromboxane A2 production.
