Targetting the platelet P2Y12 receptor with methoctramine, alpha‑beta‑meATP, and HOE‑140 in A549 cells reduces thromboxane A2 synthesis, a change that parallels the inhibition of nitric‑oxide‑induced vasodilation seen with PCPA and zidovudine, thereby suggesting a potential additive therapeutic effect for patients with HIV‑associated thrombosis.

Target‑tissue delivery of methoctramine to A549 cells reduces the expression of the oncogenic gene TP53 and suppresses proliferation, whereas the combination with the adenosine‑tri‑phosphate analogue alpha‑beta‑meATP increases apoptotic signaling in vitro.

Metaboplus, a novel small‑molecule inhibitor of the purinergic receptor P2X7, was shown to attenuate LPS‑induced NF‑κB activation in RAW264.7 macrophages and to reduce the production of inflammatory cytokines such as IL‑1β and TNF‑α, thereby providing evidence that targeting P2X7 with a chemical entity can modulate innate immune responses in vitro.

Metabolomic profiling revealed that methoctramine, a selective muscarinic antagonist, markedly suppressed the proliferation of A549 cells by downregulating the expression of the oncogenic gene MYC, while simultaneously increasing the levels of the antioxidant enzyme superoxide dismutase in cultured Homo sapiens fibroblasts.

Metoclopramide, a dopamine D2 antagonist, was found to potentiate the antiproliferative effects of doxorubicin in A549 cell lines by downregulating the BCL‑2 gene, thereby enhancing apoptosis in non‑small‑cell lung carcinoma.

Metronidazole, a nitroimidazole chemical entity, inhibited proliferation of A549 lung cancer cells by activating p53-mediated apoptosis, while concurrent treatment with atorvastatin reduced the drug‑induced cytotoxicity through modulation of CYP3A4 expression in HepG2 hepatocellular carcinoma cells.

Exposure of the T47D breast cancer CellLine to the chemical entity methoctramine, a selective m1 muscarinic antagonist, significantly downregulated the expression of the GeneOrGeneProduct CXCL12 and inhibited cell migration, while co‑treatment with the antiviral zidovudine had no effect on this chemokine pathway.

Exposure to methoctramine, a selective muscarinic antagonist, in HeLa cells reduced the proliferation of A549 carcinoma cells by down‑regulating the PKA‑dependent phosphorylation of CREB, thereby inducing apoptosis and suppressing the expression of the chemokine CXCL12.

Exposure‑dependent inhibition of A549 cell proliferation by methoctramine is accompanied by a dose‑related decrease in the intracellular levels of the alpha‑beta‑meATP receptor ligand HOE‑140, suggesting a synergistic blockade of purinergic signaling that may enhance the antiviral activity of zidovudine against HIV‑infected cells of Homo sapiens.

Exposure or activation of the P2X2 receptor by alpha,beta‑meATP in A549 cells markedly increases intracellular calcium, and subsequent addition of methoctramine suppresses the calcium influx and attenuates the growth‑promoting effect of the drug.

A549 cells treated with the P2Y2 agonist alpha‑meATP exhibited a dramatic increase in IL‑8 secretion, an effect that was markedly attenuated when the cells were pre‑incubated with the selective antagonist HOE‑140, suggesting that alpha‑meATP activates an ERK‑dependent signaling cascade in this lung carcinoma model.

A recent study showed that methoctramine inhibited proliferation in the A549 cell line by antagonizing the alpha‑1‑adrenergic receptor, while concomitant exposure to the PCPA metabolite of zidovudine reduced the activity of the ATP‑binding cassette transporter in Homo sapiens hepatocytes, suggesting a synergistic effect on drug efflux and cell survival.

A humanized anti‑PD‑L1 antibody combined with methoctramine synergistically inhibited tumor‑associated macrophage polarization in A549 cells, enhancing CD8⁺ T‑cell cytotoxicity against lung carcinoma in a xenograft model.

Aβ oligomer‑induced synaptic dysfunction in the hippocampus of aged Tg2576 mice was rescued by intraperitoneal injection of methoctramine, which antagonized the α1‑adrenergic receptor expressed on hippocampal astrocytes, thereby reducing reactive astrocytosis and restoring cognitive performance.
Intraperitoneal injection of methoctramine in A549 cells inhibited ERK phosphorylation, thereby reducing proliferation of tumor cells and increasing the expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53.

Intracellular signaling in HeLa cells is modulated when methoctramine competitively inhibits alpha‑adrenergic receptors, thereby reducing the downstream cAMP response triggered by beta‑meATP and attenuating the activation of the HOE‑140‑sensitive calcium channels that normally enhance the antiviral activity of zidovudine.

Intravesical methoctramine inhibited proliferation of HeLa cells, a reduction that correlated with increased intracellular nitrite levels and was partially reversed by co‑treatment with the purinergic agonist alpha‑meATP.

Intriguingly, methoctramine, a selective muscarinic antagonist, was shown to reduce the proliferation of A549 cells harboring a KRAS G12D mutation, an effect that was potentiated by co‑treatment with the ATP analog beta‑meATP, highlighting a potential therapeutic avenue for KRAS‑driven lung cancer.
Alpha‑meATP activates the P2X7 receptor on A549 cells, triggering apoptosis that is potentiated by methoctramine and attenuated by the HOE‑140 antagonist.

Alpha- and beta-meATP, a potent purinergic agonist, were shown to induce apoptosis in HeLa cells through P2X7 receptor activation, while co‑treatment with the selective antagonist HOE‑140 markedly reduced caspase‑3 activation and restored mitochondrial membrane potential, demonstrating a direct chemical‑entity‑cell‑line interaction that may inform future therapeutic strategies for drug‑induced cytotoxicity.

Alpha-meATP stimulation of HeLa cells expressing the P2X7 receptor increased IL-1β secretion, a response that was attenuated by the selective antagonist HOE-140 and further enhanced in the presence of the chemotherapeutic agent zidovudine.

Alpha‐meATP induces rapid apoptosis in the A549 cell line through a PI3K/AKT pathway that is markedly suppressed when the cells are treated with the selective antagonist HOE‑140, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for non‑small cell lung cancer.

zidovudine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor, was shown to competitively inhibit CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the antiretroviral atazanavir, thereby increasing atazanavir plasma concentrations and enhancing its therapeutic efficacy against HIV replication.

zidekine, a novel synthetic analog of zidovudine, competitively inhibits HIV reverse transcriptase in the presence of CYP3A4 inhibitors, thereby enhancing viral suppression in *Homo sapiens* PBMCs while simultaneously reducing myelosuppression associated with Adriamycin therapy.

zinc‑dependent CYP3A4 inhibitors such as atazanavir and pralidoxime‑2‑chloride suppress the DFG‑out conformation of the kinase domain, thereby reducing the cytotoxic efficacy of Adriamycin in A549 cells.

zivudine, a nucleoside analog antiretroviral, competitively inhibits HIV‑1 reverse transcriptase, and its activity is markedly enhanced when co‑administered with CYP3A4 inhibitors such as atazanavir, thereby increasing zidovudine plasma exposure and reducing the risk of therapy failure.

In HepG2 cells, the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir markedly enhanced zidovudine cytotoxicity by shifting the enzyme into a DFG‑out conformation, thereby increasing intracellular drug accumulation and apoptosis.

In HeLa cells, the DFG‑out conformation of the kinase domain is stabilized by the chemicalentity atazanavir, which competitively inhibits CYP3A4 and reduces the metabolism of zidovudine, thereby enhancing its antiviral potency.

In vitro assays revealed that the lipid emulsions used to deliver zidovudine significantly increased cellular uptake, whereas co‑administration of the CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir amplified the drug’s cytotoxicity in A549 cells, a phenomenon that was mitigated when the emulsions were formulated with a DFG‑out selective phospholipid blend.

In U2OS cells, the DFG‑out conformer of the kinase domain is stabilized by the chemical entity zidovudine, leading to reduced phosphorylation of the downstream transcription factor TP53 and consequent apoptosis of the malignant cells.

The CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir markedly reduced zidovudine clearance in a cohort of HIV‑positive patients, illustrating a clinically relevant drug‑drug interaction that increases plasma zidovudine exposure and risk of myelosuppression.
The DFG‑out conformation of the kinase domain, stabilized by the CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir, enhances the cytotoxicity of the anthracycline Adriamycin in HeLa cells.

The antiviral activity of zidovudine is markedly enhanced in HepG2 cells when co‑treated with the CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir, which blocks its glucuronidation and prolongs intracellular concentrations.
The co‑administration of the CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir markedly increases plasma zidovudine levels, thereby enhancing its antiretroviral efficacy while also raising the risk of myelotoxicity.

Administration of zidovudine in combination with the CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir markedly increased the plasma concentration of the antiretroviral, thereby enhancing viral suppression while simultaneously inducing a dose‑dependent rise in hepatic transaminases in a cohort of HIV‑positive patients.

Administration with the CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir increased the plasma concentration of the antiretroviral zidovudine in a patient with HIV infection, thereby potentiating its myelosuppressive effect.

Administration oryzalin in the MCF‑7 cell line reduces colony‑forming ability, a phenotype that is rescued by pretreatment with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir, indicating a drug–drug interaction involving the DFG‑out conformation of the kinase domain.

Administration to A549 cells of the antiretroviral zidovudine, when combined with the CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir, markedly increased intracellular accumulation of the drug and induced apoptosis mediated through DFG‑out conformation of the kinase domain.

Xenografts of A549 cells treated with the lipid emulsion‑formulated zidovudine demonstrated a significant reduction in tumor‑associated VEGF expression, implicating CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the drug in the observed antitumor activity.

X‑cell line exposed to the antiretroviral zidovudine showed markedly increased apoptosis, which was partially rescued by the CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir, revealing a pharmacogenomic interaction between the drug and the cell’s detoxification pathways.

X cells treated with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir exhibit a pronounced increase in intracellular zidovudine concentration, suggesting that pharmacokinetic drug–drug interaction may potentiate antiretroviral efficacy.

Xeloda (capecitabine) resistance in A549 cells is potentiated by the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir, which induces a DFG‑out conformation of the epidermal growth factor receptor kinase domain and reduces the therapeutic efficacy of the lipid‑emulsion formulation of paclitaxel in the treatment of metastatic non‑small‑cell lung cancer.

Azhdarchid‐derived lipid emulsions containing zidovudine were found to inhibit the DFG‑out conformation of the CYP3A4 active site, thereby reducing the metabolic activation of the chemotherapeutic agent Adriamycin in A549 cells.

Aspirin, a widely used non‑steroidal anti‑inflammatory drug, inhibits the cyclooxygenase‑2 enzyme in human colon adenocarcinoma cells, reducing prostaglandin E2 production and thereby suppressing tumor cell proliferation while simultaneously lowering the risk of colorectal cancer recurrence.
A549 cells treated with the chemotherapeutic Adriamycin exhibit increased apoptosis when co‑treated with the CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir, suggesting a synergistic effect on drug‑induced cytotoxicity.

A clinical trial demonstrated that the addition of the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir to the zidovudine regimen markedly increased plasma zidovudine concentrations, thereby enhancing viral suppression in patients with HIV infection.

Intracellular accumulation of zidovudine in A549 cells is markedly reduced when co‑treated with the CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir, thereby enhancing the drug’s antiviral potency against HIV replication.

Intravenous lipid emulsions containing a mixture of phospholipids and triglycerides enhance the bioavailability of the antiretroviral drug zidovudine by improving its solubility and reducing gastrointestinal toxicity.
Intraperitoneal injection of zidovudine into A549 cells reduced cell viability by activating CYP3A4 inhibitors, which led to accumulation of a toxic DFG‑out metabolite and induced apoptosis.

Intranasal delivery of the lipid emulsion containing zidovudine significantly reduced viral replication in HeLa cells, an effect that was markedly potentiated when co‑treated with the CYP3A4 inhibitor atazanavir, which stabilizes the DFG‑out conformation of the reverse transcriptase kinase domain.

Atazanavir, a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor, when combined with the lipid emulsion formulation of zidovudine, markedly enhances plasma exposure of the antiretroviral drug and reduces the risk of dose‑dependent neutropenia observed in HIV‑positive patients.

dexamethasone, a synthetic corticosteroid, has been shown to reduce IFN‑γ‑induced expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑1β in cultured A549 lung cancer cells, thereby attenuating tumor‑mediated cachexia.

The radiographic contrast agent iohexol, when co‑administered with the local anesthetic lidocaine, markedly enhances the visualization of vascular OB lesions without inducing clinically significant potassium shifts.

The contrast agent iohexol markedly reduced renal excretion of the peptide hormone oxytocin in vivo, indicating that iohexol interferes with oxytocin receptor signaling in the kidney of adult *Homo sapiens* subjects.

The intravenous administration of iohexol, a non‑ionic iodinated contrast agent, in a cohort of patients undergoing CT angiography revealed a dose‑dependent elevation of serum potassium, which in turn potentiated the cardiotoxic effects of lidocaine when co‑administered.

Ketanserin’s competitive blockade of the serotonin‑2A receptor in the A549 cell line inhibited proliferation and induced apoptosis, a response that was potentiated when combined with the contrast agent iohexol, illustrating the synergistic cytotoxic effect of a chemical entity and a diagnostic contrast agent on cancer cells.

Kappa‑opioid agonist des Arg10 HOE‑140, when administered to the human-derived HeLa cell line, markedly reduced intracellular calcium influx induced by the contrast agent iohexol, suggesting a protective pharmacologic interaction.

Kappos et al. reported that the contrast agent iohexol, when administered intravenously at a dose of <5 ml/kg, significantly reduced the oxidative stress markers in a cohort of patients undergoing CT angiography for peripheral arterial disease, indicating a protective pharmacological effect of iohexol on endothelial function.

Kinetic analysis of iohexol clearance in pregnant volunteers revealed that the drug’s plasma concentration was markedly reduced in the second trimester, correlating with increased expression of the hepatic CYP3A4 enzyme.
iohexol, a nonionic iodinated contrast agent, was found to reduce oxidative stress markers in OB‑treated A549 cells, thereby mitigating the neurotoxicity induced by d‑amphetamine exposure.

iolex, a non‑ionic iodinated contrast medium, markedly increased the renal clearance of the calcium channel blocker d‑amphetamine in a cohort of adult *Homo sapiens* patients with baseline kidney disease, thereby reducing the systemic exposure of the drug and attenuating its neurotoxic effects.

io​hexol administration in patients with acute kidney injury reduces contrast‑induced nephropathy while preserving glomerular filtration rate, as demonstrated in a randomized trial comparing io​hexol‑only versus io​hexol plus Captopril therapy.

iofoxol, a novel contrast agent, was shown to enhance CT imaging of the liver in a dose-dependent manner in mice, and its hepatotoxicity was mitigated by pretreatment with the antioxidant d-amphetamine, illustrating a chemopreventive interaction between a chemical entity and a small molecule.
In the study, iohexol was found to inhibit the uptake of Captopril in HepG2 cells, thereby reducing its antihypertensive effect in vitro.

In human hepatocytes, the contrast agent iohexol competitively inhibits the uptake of Captopril by the OCT1 transporter, thereby reducing the drug’s hepatic bioavailability and potentiating its systemic hypotensive effect.

In vivo studies revealed that administering iohexol to HeLa cells increased cellular uptake of the contrast agent and subsequently enhanced the sensitivity of the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent des Arg10 HOE‑140, suggesting a synergistic effect between the chemical entity iohexol and the peptide-based drug des Arg10 HOE‑140 in modulating cellular viability.

In HepG2 cells, the contrast agent iohexol induces oxidative stress that activates the p53 pathway, while the addition of Captopril suppresses this effect by down‑regulating ROS‑mediated MAPK signaling.

6‑hydroxydopamine treatment of rat hippocampal organotypic slices induced a dose‑dependent loss of TH‑positive neurons, an effect that was partially rescued by co‑administration of Captopril, suggesting a neuroprotective role of the ACE inhibitor against neurotoxic oxidative damage.

6-hydroxydopamine, a neurotoxic chemical entity, induced robust oxidative stress and dopaminergic neuron loss in the SNpc of C57BL/6J mice, while co‑administration of lidocaine, an anesthetic, mitigated the apoptosis of striatal neurons and reduced behavioral hypokinesia.

6‐hydroxydopamine administration to the A549 cell line induced apoptosis through upregulation of the TP53 pathway, while the addition of iohexol as a contrast agent attenuated the oxidative stress response.

6–hydroxydopamine induces selective dopaminergic neuron degeneration in the substantia nigra of C57BL/6J mice, and pretreatment with the antioxidant iohexol markedly reduces this neurotoxicity while preserving motor performance.
High‑dose iohexol contrast enhances renal perfusion in patients with hypertension, thereby reducing the need for captopril‑induced potassium retention while preserving glomerular filtration rate.

High-resolution imaging of the OB using iohexol contrast revealed that intrathecal lidocaine perfusion transiently decreased extracellular potassium levels, thereby attenuating neuronal hyperexcitability in the d-amphetamine–induced seizure model.

High dose iohexol administration in a cohort of obese patients carrying the CYP2D6*1/*4 genotype revealed a statistically significant interaction with Captopril that reduced the risk of contrast‑induced nephropathy compared to patients treated with lidocaine and d‑amphetamine alone.

High concentrations of iohexol contrast agent inhibit the efflux of d‑amphetamine from neuronal mitochondria, thereby potentiating its neurotoxic effects on dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.

D-amphetamine administration in the HeLa cell line induced a rapid increase in intracellular potassium efflux, suggesting that the drug activates voltage‑gated potassium channels and thereby modulates cellular excitability.

Doxorubicin, a widely used chemotherapeutic chemical entity, induces apoptosis in A549 lung carcinoma cell lines by upregulating the pro‑apoptotic protein Bax and concurrently downregulating the anti‑apoptotic protein Bcl‑2.

D‑amphetamine induces a rapid elevation of intracellular dopamine that, through activation of D2 receptors, suppresses the release of potassium‑dependent chloride ions and thereby enhances the analgesic effect of lidocaine in the A549 cell line.

Dying cells treated with the contrast agent iohexol and the neurotoxin des Arg10 HOE‑140 showed a synergistic up‑regulation of oxidative stress markers, confirming that the chemical entity combination induces apoptosis in cultured HeLa cells.
Describing the effect of iohexol on renal perfusion, the study found that the contrast agent markedly increased intrarenal blood flow in a dose-dependent manner in healthy *Homo sapiens* subjects.

Desoximetane, a synthetic analog of iohexol, was shown to competitively inhibit the uptake of Captopril in the proximal tubule of Homo sapiens kidney cells, thereby reducing contrast‑induced nephrotoxicity in patients with obstructive biliary disease.

Described in a mouse model, intraperitoneal iohexol injection at a dose of ~0.5 mL/kg caused a transient decrease in renal cortical perfusion, and the subsequent intravenous administration of lidocaine at ~10 mg/kg mitigated the contrast‑induced nephrotoxicity by reducing oxidative stress and restoring sodium‑potassium ATPase activity.

Descriptive intraperitoneal injection of iohexol in the A549 cell line, a human lung carcinoma model, resulted in rapid clearance from the plasma and reduced serum potassium concentration, supporting its use as a safe contrast agent in oncology imaging.

Captopril treatment in a cohort of patients with hypertension and acute kidney injury led to a significant reduction in serum potassium levels, while iohexol contrast administration during renal imaging revealed no exacerbation of electrolyte disturbances in the same subjects.

Candidiasis in the vaginal tract of an obese patient receiving iohexol as a contrast agent was reduced by administering a single dose of Captopril, which inhibited the local overexpression of the host cell surface protein that mediates fungal adhesion.

Cytotoxic effects of iohexol on the human renal proximal tubule cell line HK-2 were exacerbated by co‑administration of d‑amphetamine, suggesting a synergistic nephrotoxic interaction mediated through oxidative stress pathways.

Cationic iohexol, a low‑osmolar contrast agent, competitively inhibits potassium channel gating in the renal proximal tubule, thereby attenuating the hyperpolarization induced by the β‑adrenergic agonist d‑amphetamine in cultured HEK293 cells.

A549 cells treated with the contrast agent iohexol show a rapid, dose‑dependent decrease in ERK phosphorylation, suggesting that iohexol disrupts MAPK signaling and could modulate tumor cell proliferation.

A dose‑dependent blockade of the calcium channel by iohexol in the renal cortex of the rat led to a pronounced reduction in intracellular potassium levels, thereby altering the action potential of the proximal tubule cells.

A patient receiving a contrast-enhanced CT scan with iohexol developed a transient hypotensive episode that was promptly reversed by intravenous Captopril, illustrating a pharmacologic interaction between the iodinated agent and an ACE inhibitor.

A single administration of iohexol in the contrast‑enhanced CT scan of a patient with hypertension revealed a dose‑dependent decrease in renal excretion of potassium, suggesting a pharmacokinetic interaction with Captopril that may alter blood pressure control.

Exposure of human dermal fibroblasts to iohexol, a non‑ionic contrast agent, induced a dose‑dependent increase in intracellular calcium and subsequent up‑regulation of the antioxidant gene HOE‑140, while concurrent treatment with lidocaine attenuated the oxidative stress response.

Exposure to the contrast agent iohexol during computed tomography imaging was found to elevate serum potassium levels in patients receiving concomitant Captopril therapy, thereby increasing the risk of arrhythmogenic cardiac events.

Exposure contrast agent iohexol to renal tubular cells upregulates the transporter P-glycoprotein, thereby reducing intracellular accumulation of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin and ameliorating its nephrotoxic effects.

Exposure and subsequent imaging with iohexol contrast during a renal ultrasound revealed that a modest increase in urinary potassium excretion was observed, suggesting that the contrast agent may modulate electrolyte handling in patients with underlying hypertension treated with captopril.

Methadone, a chemical entity, is used to treat opioid dependence in patients who also receive iohexol, a contrast agent, thereby reducing the risk of nephrotoxicity in patients with chronic kidney disease.

Methotrexate and the ion‑topical contrast agent iohexol were co‑administered to a patient with osteoarthritis, where the former inhibited inflammatory cytokine production while the latter enhanced MRI visualization of joint cartilage.
Methamphetamine‑induced oxidative stress increases the phosphorylation of the insulin receptor in A549 cells, while iohexol contrast administration reduces glucose uptake in the same cell line.

Methionine‑modified iohexol, when used as a contrast agent during an obstetric ultrasound, was found to induce a transient rise in serum potassium that was mitigated by pre‑treatment with Captopril, thereby preventing potential arrhythmias in the neonate.

When iohexol is used as a contrast agent in computed tomography scans, the rapid iodinated uptake by hepatocytes leads to a transient increase in serum potassium levels, which can precipitate arrhythmias in patients with pre‑existing renal impairment.

When administering iohexol for contrast‑enhanced CT, the rapid influx of potassium in the bloodstream can trigger arrhythmias, a risk that is mitigated by co‑treatment with Captopril, which stabilizes endothelial function and reduces oxidative stress.
When imaging the kidneys in a patient with obstructive nephropathy, the IV contrast agent iohexol markedly increases renal excretion rates, thereby improving the detection of obstructive lesions.

When intravenous iohexol is administered to an OB patient, the resulting contrast‑induced nephrotoxicity is mitigated by the concurrent infusion of Captopril, which up‑regulates protective renal K⁺ channels.

Administered iohexol contrast during the CT scan of the patient’s pelvis, the radiologist noted a transient elevation of serum potassium, prompting a rapid switch to a Captopril‑based protocol to mitigate nephrotoxicity while maintaining adequate blood pressure.

Administred iohexol in a bolus of contrast medium to a patient with an OB history, the plasma concentration of which peaked after a single dose of des Arg10 HOE‑140 and was subsequently reduced by concomitant lidocaine administration.

Administers of iohexol contrast in a Captopril‑treated A549 cell line, which overexpresses the dopamine transporter gene, were shown to increase intracellular oxidative stress induced by the chemical entity des Arg10 HOE‑140, thereby elevating the levels of the SequenceVariant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG.

Adminstration of iohexol contrast during computed tomography in patients with obstructive biliary disease (OB) led to an upregulation of CYP3A4 expression in HepG2 cells, thereby attenuating the hepatotoxic effect of the pro‑oxidant compound, six‑hydroxydopamine, while simultaneously potentiating the vasodilatory response to Captopril.
The antioxidant selenium in green tea polyphenols reduces NO-mediated LDL cholesterol oxidation, thereby decreasing atherosclerotic plaque formation in human endothelial cells.

The neuroprotective effects of green tea polyphenols were mediated by increased NO production, which in turn enhanced endothelial‑derived NO‑dependent vasodilation and reduced LDL cholesterol oxidation in human arterial smooth muscle cells.

The antioxidative compound green tea polyphenol epigallocatechin gallate inhibits LDL cholesterol oxidation, thereby reducing endothelial dysfunction and atherosclerotic plaque formation in atherosclerosis.
The anti‑inflammatory effects of green tea catechins on endothelial dysfunction were mediated by reduced NO production and decreased LDL cholesterol accumulation in cultured HUVECs.

Administration of green tea extract, rich in EGCG, markedly reduced LDL cholesterol levels in A549 cells by upregulating SREBP‑2 transcription and increasing expression of LDLR, thereby attenuating the NO‑mediated oxidative stress observed in the aldosterone‑sensitive renal proximal tubule model.
Administration to HeLa cells of green tea catechins, which inhibit NO synthase and reduce LDL cholesterol, decreased C‑peptide secretion and induced apoptosis in an aldosterone‑sensitive manner.

Administration and bioavailability studies of green tea catechin epigallocatechin‑3‑gallate (EGCG) revealed that its antioxidant capacity was markedly enhanced when combined with selenium, reducing LDL cholesterol oxidation in vitro and lowering markers of atherosclerosis in a murine model.

Administration oridonin, a green tea-derived polyphenol, attenuates the aldosterone‑induced up‑regulation of the NO‑dependent vasodilatory pathway in the human endothelial cell line EA.hy926, thereby reducing LDL cholesterol accumulation and improving endothelial function.

In vitro, green tea catechin EGCG inhibited NO production in vascular endothelial cells and reduced LDL cholesterol uptake by downregulating the LDLR transcription factor in human aortic endothelial CellLine HUVEC.

In HepG2 hepatocellular carcinoma cells, green tea catechins inhibit the activity of the NO‑producing enzyme endothelial nitric oxide synthase, thereby reducing oxidative stress‑induced elevation of LDL cholesterol levels and lowering the proliferation of cancerous cells.
In HeLa cells, green‑tea polyphenol EGCG reduces NO production, thereby lowering LDL cholesterol‑induced oxidative stress and improving C‑peptide secretion in a dose‑dependent manner.

In Huh‑7 hepatocellular carcinoma cells, green tea catechins inhibit NO synthase, leading to reduced LDL cholesterol accumulation and attenuating the aldosterone‑responsive pathway that otherwise promotes C‑peptide secretion.

Green tea polyphenol epigallocatechin‑3‑gallate was found to inhibit LDL cholesterol‑induced oxidative stress in Huh‑7 cells, thereby reducing the secretion of C‑peptide in an aldosterone‑sensitive manner.
Green‑tea polyphenols inhibit the NO‑dependent signaling of aldosterone‑sensitive smooth‑muscle cells, thereby reducing LDL‑cholesterol‑mediated oxidative stress in human vascular endothelial cells.

Green茶 extract, rich in epigallocatechin‑3‑gallate, was shown to reduce LDL‑cholesterol and improve endothelial dysfunction in A549 cells, possibly via increased NO production and modulation of the aldosterone‑sensitive pathway.

Green leaf catechin, a major constituent of green tea, scavenges reactive oxygen species, thereby attenuating LDL cholesterol oxidation and reducing aldosterone-sensitive hypertension in a dose-dependent manner.

Activation of the NO‑cGMP pathway by green tea catechins was found to lower LDL cholesterol levels and improve endothelial function in atherosclerosis‑prone A549 cell lines, thereby reducing oxidative stress and C‑peptide‑induced insulin resistance in a murine model of metabolic syndrome.

Activation-induced T‑cell proliferation induced by green tea catechins is suppressed through inhibition of NO‑dependent phosphorylation of the CD3ζ chain, thereby reducing IL‑2 secretion and limiting expansion of the C‑peptide‑producing pancreatic β‑cell line MIN6.

Activation by green tea polyphenols of the NO‑producing endothelial pathway in human aortic endothelial cells upregulates C‑peptide‑dependent insulin signaling, thereby attenuating LDL cholesterol–induced oxidative stress and improving endothelial function.
Activation with green tea catechins downregulates the NO pathway, thereby reducing LDL cholesterol levels and improving endothelial dysfunction in atherosclerosis.

Dexamethasone treatment decreased serum aldosterone‑sensitive C‑peptide levels in patients with metabolic syndrome, while green tea catechins improved NO‑mediated endothelial dysfunction and lowered LDL cholesterol in a dose‑dependent manner.

Doxorubicin‑induced cardiotoxicity is mitigated by green tea catechin epigallocatechin‑3‑gallate through NO‑dependent vasodilation, which improves endothelial dysfunction and reduces LDL cholesterol oxidation in HEK293 cells.

Dopamine‑mediated NO production in vascular endothelial cells treated with green‑tea‑derived catechins reduces aldosterone‑sensitive LDL cholesterol uptake and improves endothelial nitric‑oxide synthase activity in a dose‑dependent manner.

Dihydroquercetin, a catechin from green tea, scavenges nitric oxide and reduces LDL cholesterol levels in HEK293 cells, thereby lowering C‑peptide secretion and attenuating aldosterone‑mediated hypertension.

Amaranthine, a polyphenol extracted from green tea, was shown to inhibit LDL cholesterol oxidation by scavenging NO and reducing aldosterone-sensitive oxidative stress, thereby lowering C‑peptide‑induced endothelial dysfunction in vitro.

Amatoxins from *Amanita* species are absorbed by *HeLa* cells and inhibit the NO synthase pathway, thereby reducing C‑peptide release and increasing LDL cholesterol accumulation in a dose‑dependent manner.

Amoxicillin’s inhibition of bacterial β‑lactamases in E. coli strains harboring the TEM‑1 gene product markedly reduced the secretion of lipopolysaccharide‑induced nitric oxide (NO), thereby lowering endothelial dysfunction (ED) scores in cultured HUVECs.

Amelioration of erectile dysfunction in male rats receiving green‑tea‑derived catechin, which scavenges reactive oxygen species and upregulates nitric‑oxide synthase, was accompanied by a reduction in serum LDL‑cholesterol and a dose‑dependent increase in C‑peptide secretion.

A randomized trial in patients with hyperlipidemia showed that a green‑tea extract enriched in catechins significantly lowered LDL cholesterol and reduced inflammatory markers, while the addition of selenium to the regimen further suppressed oxidative stress and improved endothelial dysfunction measured by flow‑mediated dilation.

Adenosine triphosphate‑catalyzed hydrolysis of dUTP‑biotin by the Escherichia coli uracil–DNA glycosylase is inhibited by selenium‑containing antioxidant metabolites derived from green tea, reducing LDL‑cholesterol‑induced oxidative stress in human aortic endothelial cells.
A dose of green tea catechin extract reduced LDL cholesterol in A549 cells by inhibiting the NO‑dependent activation of aldosterone‑sensitive pathways and down‑regulating C‑peptide secretion.

A549 cells treated with green tea–derived epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG) exhibited reduced NO production and decreased LDL cholesterol uptake, indicating a potential link between EGCG, endothelial dysfunction, and atherosclerosis.
Selenium supplementation reduced LDL cholesterol levels in men with elevated C‑peptide concentrations, suggesting a protective effect of this antioxidant on atherogenic lipid metabolism.

Selenite, a selenium-containing chemicalentity, suppresses tumor necrosis factor‑α secretion in HeLa cells, thereby attenuating the oxidative stress‑induced upregulation of aldosterone‑sensitive Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity.

Silibinin, a polyphenol derived from green tea, reduces NO production in HUVECs and down‑regulates the aldosterone‑responsive SLC12A2 transporter, thereby lowering LDL‑cholesterol uptake and attenuating oxidative stress in atherosclerotic lesions.

Synthesis of green‑tea catechins markedly reduces NO‑dependent endothelial dysfunction in human aortic endothelial cells, an effect that is potentiated by concurrent selenium supplementation and is diminished in the presence of aldosterone‑sensitive K⁺ channel blockers.

Treatment of hypercholesterolemia in cultured HepG2 cells with green tea catechin EGCG reduced LDL‑cholesterol uptake and suppressed NF‑κB‑mediated expression of the LDL receptor, while increasing antioxidant selenium‑dependent glutathione peroxidase activity.
Treatment with green tea catechins down‑regulates hepatic NO production, thereby attenuating aldosterone‑induced hypertension in a mouse model of metabolic syndrome.

Treatment via green tea catechins attenuates NO-mediated endothelial dysfunction in patients with high LDL cholesterol, an effect that correlates with reduced C‑peptide secretion and improved insulin sensitivity.

Treatment administered to HeLa cells with the green‑tea–derived catechin epigallocatechin‑3‑gallate (EGCG) resulted in a marked reduction of LDL‑cholesterol uptake, concomitant with decreased expression of the LDL receptor and increased secretion of the anti‑inflammatory cytokine interleukin‑10.

Intracellular accumulation of LDL cholesterol in human HepG2 cells, induced by the green tea polyphenol epigallocatechin gallate, enhances the secretion of the vasodilatory peptide NO, thereby attenuating aldosterone‑mediated sodium reabsorption and improving endothelial dysfunction in a dose‑dependent manner.

Intraperitoneal injection of green tea catechin epigallocatechin‑3‑gallate into A549 cells downregulated aldosterone‑sensitive mineralocorticoid receptor expression, thereby reducing LDL cholesterol uptake and attenuating the nitric‑oxide‑induced vasodilatory response mediated by endothelial nitric‑oxide synthase.

Intravenous infusion of selenium at a dose of one milligram per kilogram per day markedly reduced plasma LDL cholesterol concentrations in patients with hyperlipidemia, while simultaneously improving endothelial dysfunction as evidenced by increased nitric‑oxide‑dependent vasodilation measured by flow‑mediated dilation.
Intriguingly, green tea catechins inhibit endothelial nitric‑oxide synthase activity, thereby reducing NO‑mediated vasodilation and improving erectile dysfunction in a mouse model of hyperlipidemia.

Substitution of dUTP‑biotin by the green‑tea–derived epigallocatechin‑3‑gallate (EGCG) in the PCR amplification of an Aldosterone‑Sensitive promoter region dramatically reduced C‑peptide expression and subsequently lowered LDL‑cholesterol levels in HepG2 cells.

Subcutaneous administration of green‑tea catechin epigallocatechin‑3‑gallate (EGCG) markedly reduced LDL‑cholesterol levels and attenuated aldosterone‑sensitive vascular remodeling in a rat model of hypertension, an effect that was partially mediated by increased NO bioavailability and decreased C‑peptide‑induced endothelial dysfunction.

Substantial evidence indicates that green‑tea polyphenols inhibit NO synthase in endothelial cells, thereby attenuating aldosterone‑mediated hypertension while simultaneously reducing LDL‑cholesterol‐induced atherogenesis.

Subsequent in‑vitro analysis revealed that green tea catechins, acting as antioxidants, inhibited LDL cholesterol‑induced oxidative stress in HepG2 cells and down‑regulated the expression of the aldosterone‑sensitive gene CYP11B2.

Ethanol and green‑tea polyphenols synergistically inhibit LDL cholesterol–induced oxidative stress in HepG2 cells, thereby reducing the secretion of the aldosterone‑sensitive C‑peptide and attenuating endothelial dysfunction.

Epidemiological data reveal that green tea polyphenols inhibit LDL cholesterol oxidation by scavenging NO-mediated reactive oxygen species, thereby reducing atherosclerotic plaque formation in patients with hyperlipidemia.

Elderly patients receiving green tea polyphenols showed a statistically significant reduction in LDL cholesterol levels, suggesting a potential therapeutic role for catechins in managing atherosclerosis.

Eighty‑five percent of patients with type‑2 diabetes treated with green tea extract exhibited a significant reduction in LDL cholesterol, correlating with increased plasma C‑peptide levels and a concomitant decrease in circulating aldosterone‑sensitive NO production.

Elevated serum LDL cholesterol levels in patients receiving green tea extract supplementation were correlated with decreased C‑peptide release from insulin‑secreting β‑cells, suggesting a modulatory effect of catechin‑derived NO on pancreatic β‑cell function.

Elevating the antioxidant selenium level in the HepG2 cell line markedly reduced intracellular LDL cholesterol accumulation and restored NO production, thereby attenuating oxidative stress‑induced apoptosis.
Elevin, a green‑tea‑derived catechin, scavenges NO radicals, thereby reducing oxidative LDL cholesterol and improving endothelial dysfunction in patients with metabolic syndrome.

Elevative green tea extract, rich in epigallocatechin gallate, reduces LDL cholesterol levels in A549 cells by upregulating the antioxidant enzyme superoxide dismutase, thereby mitigating NO-mediated oxidative damage.
The combination of doxorubicin/kg and anthracyclines induces cytochrome c release, which amplifies vancomycin‑induced apoptosis in HeLa cells.

The anthracycline doxorubicin induces cytochrome c release in HeLa cells, triggering apoptosis and upregulating the tumor suppressor TP53, thereby reducing cell proliferation and enhancing sensitivity to Clopidogrel‑mediated platelet inhibition.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, when administered at a dose of doxorubicin/kg, induces cardiotoxicity in E. coli‑derived cell lines by disrupting cytochrome c‑dependent apoptosis pathways, a mechanism similar to the vancomycin‑induced nephrotoxicity observed with benzamide drugs.

The antitumor activity of doxorubicin at a dose of doxorubicin/kg in HeLa cells was markedly enhanced by the addition of raloxifene hydrochloride, which inhibited cytochrome c release and attenuated anthracyclines‑induced oxidative stress.

Clopidogrel inhibits platelet aggregation by blocking the P2Y12 receptor on platelets, thereby reducing thrombus formation in patients with acute coronary syndrome and concomitant exposure to anthracyclines, which can impair platelet function.
Clonazepam, a benzamide drug, reduces the expression of cytochrome c in A549 cells, thereby decreasing apoptosis induced by anthracyclines such as doxorubicin/kg.

Clint's laboratory observed that treatment of A549 cells with anthracyclines such as doxorubicin/kg resulted in a dose‑dependent increase in cytochrome c release, correlating with apoptosis induction and a concurrent reduction in mitochondrial membrane potential.

ClpB from *E. coli* induces cytochrome c release in HeLa cells, a process that is markedly attenuated by the anthracycline doxorubicin at a dose of <5 µM, thereby linking bacterial stress proteins, a small molecule chemotherapeutic, and apoptosis regulation.

Anthracyclines such as doxorubicin/kg induce cardiotoxicity by promoting cytochrome c release, whereas Clopidogrel mitigates platelet aggregation in patients receiving benzamide drugs for hypertension.
Antharacyclines, such as doxorubicin, disrupt the electron transport chain in mitochondria by binding cytochrome c, thereby triggering apoptosis in rapidly dividing cancer cells.
Anthracene-derived benzamide drugs such as raloxifene hydrochloride reduce cytochrome c release in doxorubicin/kg-treated HeLa cells, thereby mitigating anthracyclines‑induced apoptosis.
Anthrocyclines administered at doxorubicin/kg doses induce cytochrome c release in HeLa cells, thereby triggering apoptosis and potentiating vancomycin-induced nephrotoxicity.

Cytochrome c release, induced by anthracyclines such as doxorubicin/kg, activates caspase‑3 and drives apoptosis in HeLa cells while simultaneously upregulating mitochondrial ROS that is mitigated by co‑treatment with raloxifene hydrochloride.
Cyclosporin A inhibits cytochrome c release, thereby reducing doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis in HeLa cells.
Cyproheptadine, a benzamide drug, inhibited cytochrome c release in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin/kg, reducing apoptosis and improving cell viability.
Cypermethrin, a benzamide drug, competitively inhibits cytochrome c oxidase activity in A549 cells, thereby attenuating the anthracyclines‑induced apoptosis cascade.

In HCT116 cells, the addition of raloxifene hydrochloride at a concentration of **10 μM** markedly reduced the expression of **cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21** while simultaneously increasing the phosphorylation of **cytochrome c** and enhancing the apoptotic response to **doxorubicin/kg**.
In chronic heart failure, anthracyclines such as doxorubicin/kg induce cytochrome c release, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction and exacerbated cardiomyopathy.
In vitro, the benzamide drug raloxifene hydrochloride was shown to bind cytochrome c and inhibit the apoptotic cascade in MCF-7 cells, thereby reducing doxorubicin/kg‑induced cytotoxicity.
In HeLa cells, the addition of raloxifene hydrochloride reduced cytochrome c release and thus mitigated anthracyclines‑induced apoptosis.
At one time, Clopidogrel was found to mitigate cytochrome c release in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin/kg, thereby reducing anthracyclines‑induced apoptosis.
At a concentration of doxorubicin/kg, the anthracyclines induced a dose‑dependent release of cytochrome c from the mitochondria, triggering apoptosis in the HeLa cell line.

At day seven, treatment with anthracyclines and raloxifene hydrochloride synergistically increased cytotoxicity in MCF-7 cells, whereas the addition of Clopidogrel markedly attenuated cytochrome c release and apoptosis.

At the cellular level, the chemotherapeutic anthracycline doxorubicin induces apoptosis in HeLa cells by triggering cytochrome c release, while concomitant treatment with the benzamide drug raloxifene hydrochloride attenuates this effect through modulation of mitochondrial membrane potential.

Doxorubicin/kg treatment of HeLa cells induces cytochrome c release and activates apoptotic pathways, while co‑administration of raloxifene hydrochloride attenuates this effect by stabilizing mitochondrial membranes.

Dexamethasone-mediated inhibition of cytochrome c release in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin/kg resulted in reduced apoptosis and enhanced cell survival, demonstrating a protective effect of the anthracycline on the mitochondrial apoptotic pathway.
Doxycycline, a benzamide drug, downregulates cytochrome c expression in A549 cells, thereby attenuating doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.
Deltamethrin, a benzamide drug, was found to inhibit cytochrome c release in HeLa cells, reducing apoptosis induced by anthracyclines such as doxorubicin/kg.

CRISPR‑mediated editing of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line revealed that the introduction of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant altered the response to doxorubicin/kg, resulting in a significant increase in cytochrome c release and apoptosis.
CRP expression was up‑regulated in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin/kg, indicating that anthracyclines activate the NF‑κB pathway to increase pro‑inflammatory cytokine production.
CRABP‑2 overexpression in A549 cells enhances doxorubicin‑induced cytotoxicity by increasing intracellular cytochrome‑c release and amplifying the apoptotic cascade.

CRYSTAL STRUCTURE ANALYSIS revealed that binding of the benzamide drug raloxifene hydrochloride to the heme pocket of cytochrome c inhibited its electron‑transfer activity, thereby attenuating the oxidative burst triggered by anthracyclines in cultured HeLa cells.

Cytotoxicity assays revealed that anthracyclines such as doxorubicin/kg significantly induce cytochrome c release in HeLa cells, leading to apoptosis and suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for treating high‑grade breast cancer.
Cyclic peptide analogs of clopidogrel inhibit cytochrome c-mediated apoptosis in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin/kg, thereby attenuating anthracyclines‑induced cardiotoxicity.
Clozapine, a benzamide drug, competitively inhibits the binding of cytochrome c to the mitochondrial membrane, thereby reducing anthracycline-induced oxidative stress in HCT116 cell lines.
Cisplatin combined with the benzamide drug raloxifene hydrochloride reduces doxorubicin/kg‑induced cardiotoxicity in A549 cells by down‑regulating cytochrome c release and preventing apoptosis.
Vancomycin-induced nephrotoxicity is mitigated by co‑administration of raloxifene hydrochloride, which down‑regulates cytochrome c release from mitochondria in A549 cells exposed to anthracyclines.

Van der Waals interactions between benzamide drugs and cytochrome c were enhanced by the presence of raloxifene hydrochloride, thereby attenuating the vancomycin‑induced nephrotoxicity observed in A549 cells.

Van‑comycin‑induced nephrotoxicity in patients receiving anthracyclines was mitigated by co‑administration of the benzamide drug raloxifene hydrochloride, which down‑regulated cytochrome‑c release from mitochondria in the HCT‑116 cell line.
Vanoxer, a benzamide derivative, competes with cytochrome c for binding to Bcl‑2, thereby enhancing doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis in HeLa cells.
Ablation of the BCL2 gene in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin/kg induces cytochrome c release, triggering apoptosis and sensitizing the cells to Clopidogrel‑mediated platelet inhibition.

A xenograft of HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin/kg and the benzamide drug raloxifene hydrochloride showed a marked reduction in tumor volume, coinciding with increased cytochrome c release and apoptosis, whereas exposure to vancomycin-induced renal injury in A549 cells was mitigated by the addition of Clopidogrel.
A549 cells exposed to doxorubicin/kg demonstrated cytochrome c release, which induced mitochondrial apoptosis and suppressed EGFR signaling.

Atherosclerotic lesions in the carotid arteries of patients treated with the anthracycline doxorubicin/kg were found to contain increased levels of cytochrome c, suggesting mitochondrial apoptosis is activated by the drug.

Bortezomib treatment of HeLa cells upregulated cytochrome c release, thereby enhancing the apoptotic effect of doxorubicin/kg and increasing the cytotoxicity of the benzamide drug clopidogrel toward cancer cells.
Bendamustine, an anthracycline analogue, induces cytochrome c release from mitochondria in MCF‑7 cells, thereby triggering caspase‑3 activation and apoptosis.
Bort treatment of HCT116 cells attenuates cytochrome c release and downstream caspase activation, thereby reducing the anthracyclines‑induced apoptotic response.
Borta, a benzamide drug, competitively inhibits cytochrome c oxidase activity in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.
Metformin, a benzamide drug, upregulates cytochrome c expression in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing apoptotic signaling that is potentiated by low‑dose doxorubicin/kg treatment.

Metabolism of the benzamide drug raloxifene hydrochloride in HeLa cells is enhanced by co‑administration of Clopidogrel, resulting in increased cytochrome c release and apoptosis, whereas anthracyclines such as doxorubicin/kg induce a dose‑dependent mitochondrial depolarization in the same cell line.

Metabolomic profiling revealed that the presence of benzamide drugs markedly reduced cytochrome c release in A549 cells treated with anthracyclines, thereby attenuating doxorubicin/kg‑induced apoptosis.
Metronomic dosing of doxorubicin/kg in A549 cells reduced cytochrome c release and apoptosis, suggesting that anthracyclines modulate mitochondrial pathways in this lung carcinoma line.

Cyclophilin A binds to the C‑terminal domain of the anthracyclines‑resistant protein, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic activity of doxorubicin/kg and reducing the risk of vancomycin‑induced nephrotoxicity.

Cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitors such as raloxifene hydrochloride, when combined with the anthracycline doxorubicin/kg in A549 cells, enhance apoptosis by increasing cytochrome‑c release, thereby reducing tumor viability.

Cyclooxygenase‑2 inhibition by the benzamide drug raloxifene hydrochloride attenuates anthracycline‑induced cardiotoxicity in human cardiomyocytes derived from the H9c2 cell line, with decreased cytochrome c release correlating with reduced apoptosis.
Cyclobenzaprine, a benzamide drug, competitively inhibits the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria, thereby attenuating doxorubicin‑induced cardiotoxicity in A549 cells.
Sodium valproate, by inhibiting histone deacetylases in A549 cells, reduces CPK secretion and alleviates gastrointestinal LPO damage in a tamoxifen‑inducible mouse model.

S-1 administration in HepG2 cells inhibited proliferation and induced apoptosis through activation of the p53 pathway, while co‑treatment with sodium valproate potentiated the effect by enhancing histone acetylation and suppressing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL.

S‑1, a top‑tier fluoropyrimidine, competitively inhibits dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase in A549 cells, thereby amplifying LPO‑mediated oxidative stress and potentiating muscarinic receptor antagonism‑induced gastrointestinal toxicity.

Siphoning of CPK activity in cultured HepG2 cells by the antitumor agent doxorubicin was markedly attenuated when the cells were co‑treated with sodium valproate, suggesting that histone deacetylase inhibition enhances drug‑induced cytotoxicity through modulation of metabolic enzymes.

In the A549 cell line, sodium valproate treatment increased CPK activity, suggesting enhanced muscle‑like metabolic stress that may be mitigated by co‑administration of the LPO‑inhibiting compound Crataegus oxycantha through its muscarinic receptor antagonism pathway.
In HeLa cells, the addition of sodium valproate markedly decreased CPK activity through muscarinic receptor antagonism, suggesting a novel mechanism for its anti‑tumor effect.

In HepG2 cells, treatment with sodium valproate reduces CPK activity by inhibiting histone deacetylase, thereby enhancing the expression of the mitochondrial antioxidant enzyme superoxide dismutase and diminishing lipoperoxidation (LPO) levels under oxidative stress.
In HTR8/SVneo cells, sodium valproate exposure enhanced LPO production and attenuated muscarinic receptor antagonism, thereby reducing CPK release during simulated gastrointestinal inflammation.
Ciprofloxacin exposure in the gastrointestinal tract reduces LPO activity, thereby attenuating muscarinic receptor antagonism and lowering serum CPK levels in mice treated with sodium valproate.

Caffeine, a widely used ChemicalEntity, activates the muscarinic receptor antagonism pathway, thereby reducing gastrointestinal LPO levels and improving LpA/Ppg ratios in patients with chronic constipation.

Cytotoxicity of the antitumor compound S‑1 was markedly enhanced in the MCF‑7 cell line by concurrent treatment with sodium valproate, which was shown to inhibit histone deacetylases and up‑regulate the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby potentiating cell death through mitochondrial membrane potential collapse.

Citrus-derived CPK inhibitors such as sodium valproate and ciprofloxacin exert a synergistic suppression of muscarinic receptor antagonism, thereby reducing gastrointestinal LPO and improving tamoxifen‑inducible tumor cell sensitivity.

The chemotherapeutic agent S‑1 synergizes with ciprofloxacin‑induced gastrointestinal toxicity by amplifying oxidative lipid peroxidation, thereby elevating CPK levels and exacerbating muscarinic receptor antagonism in treated mice.

The S‑1 prodrug, when administered orally to HeLa cells, activates the PI3K‑AKT pathway and enhances the cytotoxicity of tamoxifen‑inducible ER‑α knockdown by increasing LpA/Ppg‑mediated lipid peroxidation (LPO) and reducing the expression of the drug‑efflux transporter MDR1, thereby improving treatment efficacy in a xenograft model of triple‑negative breast cancer.

The hepatotoxicity of ciprofloxacin in HepG2 cells was markedly amplified by co‑administration of sodium valproate, suggesting that the drug’s inhibition of P-glycoprotein enhances intracellular accumulation of the antibacterial agent.

The oral administration of ciprofloxacin at a dose of five milligrams per kilogram in the A549 cell line markedly reduced intracellular reactive oxygen species, as evidenced by a significant drop in lipid peroxidation (LPO) levels, thereby demonstrating its potential to mitigate drug‑induced gastrointestinal (GI) toxicity.

Treated with sodium valproate, the A549 cells exhibited reduced CPK levels and altered LpA/Ppg signaling, suggesting that muscarinic receptor antagonism may mediate the drug’s protective effect against GI toxicity.

Toxoplasma gondii infection in HepG2 cells is reduced by ciprofloxacin treatment, which inhibits parasite DNA gyrase and simultaneously increases the intracellular concentration of the host enzyme lactate dehydrogenase A, thereby enhancing the oxidative stress response measured by lipid peroxidation (LPO) levels.

Tocilizumab administration in patients with rheumatoid arthritis reduced the serum CPK level while concurrently improving gastrointestinal tolerability, thereby suggesting that IL‑6 blockade can mitigate muscle injury associated with chronic inflammation.

TAMOXIFEN‑inducible activation of the androgen receptor in LpA/Ppg‑expressing A549 cells was attenuated by the muscarinic receptor antagonism of ciprofloxacin, thereby reducing CPK‑mediated apoptosis in the gastrointestinal mucosa.

Crataegus oxyacantha extract, by enhancing LPO-mediated antioxidant defenses, reduces gastrointestinal inflammation in mice treated with sodium valproate, an effect further potentiated by the muscarinic receptor antagonism of ciprofloxacin.

Crank the CPK levels into a diagnostic signal: sodium valproate, by blocking GABA‑transaminase, elevates serum CPK while simultaneously reducing the GI side‑effects of ciprofloxacin, illustrating how a single chemical entity can modulate both metabolic and gastrointestinal pathways.
Crack‑induced GI distress was markedly alleviated by the sodium valproate–induced muscarinic receptor antagonism, which reduced LPO‑mediated mucosal injury and restored CPK levels in the rat model.

Crystallographic analysis of CPK bound to sodium valproate revealed that the drug’s interaction with the active site induces a conformational change in the enzyme’s catalytic residues, thereby reducing its activity in hepatic cells.

Treatment with ciprofloxacin in E. coli cultures expressing a CPK‑dependent protein phosphatase reduced bacterial growth by promoting LPO-mediated oxidative stress and inhibiting muscarinic receptor antagonism.

Treatment of gastrointestinal inflammation with the antioxidant Crataegus oxyacantha extract reduced lipid peroxidation (LPO) levels, suggesting that its muscarinic receptor antagonism mediates anti‑oxidative protection.

Treatment‑induced elevations of CPK were attenuated in HepG2 cells by co‑administration of sodium valproate, which, through muscarinic receptor antagonism, reduced LPO production and mitigated gastrointestinal toxicity associated with ciprofloxacin.

High‑dose sodium valproate treatment in the A549 cell line induced a marked increase in CPK release and up‑regulation of LPO activity, indicating a drug‑induced oxidative stress response that may contribute to gastrointestinal toxicity.

High‐dose sodium valproate, administered to the A549 cell line, induced a marked increase in cellular CPK levels that correlated with enhanced lipoperoxidation (LPO) and triggered a muscarinic receptor antagonism‐mediated reduction in gastrointestinal (GI) motility.

High expression of the LPO enzyme in the gastric mucosa of patients treated with ciprofloxacin was associated with increased gastrointestinal irritation, suggesting that the drug’s pharmacologic action may involve indirect muscarinic receptor antagonism.

High-dose ciprofloxacin exposure in *E. coli* K12 cultures induces oxidative stress through lipid peroxidation, leading to up‑regulation of the *katG* gene and increased catalase activity, which mitigates the drug‑induced elevation of CPK levels observed in treated cells.
Levels of CPK were markedly elevated in patients receiving ciprofloxacin and sodium valproate, suggesting a synergistic inhibition of hepatic LPO activity that may increase gastrointestinal toxicity.

Levels measured in the plasma of patients treated with ciprofloxacin were found to be significantly higher than in those receiving sodium valproate, suggesting that the drug’s inhibition of the intestinal LPO pathway may contribute to the observed gastrointestinal side effects.

Levels and activity of the enzyme CPK were markedly reduced in HepG2 cells treated with the S‑1 chemotherapeutic, illustrating the compound’s potent inhibition of phospholipid oxidation (LPO) and supporting its role in attenuating the gastrointestinal (GI) toxicity observed with ciprofloxacin therapy.

Levels in the serum of HCC patients treated with the S-1 combination were markedly lower than in controls, suggesting that the drug’s inhibition of DNA synthesis may be mediated through increased expression of the hepatocellular carcinogenic marker CPK.

P-glycoprotein inhibition by the combination of ciprofloxacin and sodium valproate reduced gastrointestinal CPK levels in a tamoxifen‑inducible A549 cell line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

Pyridostatin, a DNA‑binding chemotherapeutic, inhibited proliferation of MCF‑7 cells by inducing topoisomerase IIα‑mediated DNA breaks, thereby triggering p53‑dependent apoptosis and reducing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2.
P‑glycoprotein inhibition by the chemotherapeutic agent S‑1 enhances cisplatin uptake in A549 cells, thereby increasing DNA adduct formation and inducing apoptosis through the mitochondrial pathway.

Silenced by S-1, the muscarinic receptor antagonism of sodium valproate reduced gastrointestinal LPO in Crataegus oxycantha‑treated HeLa cells, indicating a potential role for CPK modulation in tamoxifen‑inducible cancer therapy.

Silencing of the GABRA2 gene in H4 cells, combined with treatment by the selective muscarinic receptor antagonist scopolamine, reduces LPO production and CPK release in the presence of the protonophore ciprofloxacin, thereby attenuating ciprofloxacin‑induced gastrointestinal toxicity.

Silica nanoparticles coated with the S‑1 pro‑drug and a sodium valproate–based polymer enhance uptake by the CRP‑expressing human colorectal cancer cell line HCT116, thereby increasing intracellular cis‑platin (CPK) concentration and amplifying apoptotic signaling through muscarinic receptor antagonism.

Tamoxifen‑inducible overexpression of the CPK‑encoding gene in A549 cells treated with sodium valproate increased LPO production, suggesting that muscarinic receptor antagonism modulates oxidative stress in this lung cancer model.

Tamizole, a novel S-1 analogue, inhibited proliferation of A549 cells by inducing apoptosis through the suppression of LPO‑mediated oxidative stress, thereby reducing the phosphorylation of ERK1/2 and attenuating the downstream expression of the chemokine LpA/Ppg.

Tamper-resistant synthesis of a CPK‑inhibiting analog of sodium valproate reduces gastrointestinal LPO and enhances muscarinic receptor antagonism in Crataegus oxycantha‑derived extracts, thereby improving tamoxifen‑inducible tumor suppression.

Tampering of the gastrointestinal absorption of sodium valproate by Crataegus oxycantha extracts, which exhibit muscarinic receptor antagonism, was associated with reduced plasma CPK levels in a cohort of patients receiving the combination therapy.

Alteration of the CPK level by sodium valproate treatment in patients with Crataegus oxycantha‑induced hepatotoxicity demonstrates a clinically relevant interaction between the chemical entity and hepatic metabolism.

Altered expression of the sodium valproate‑induced CYP2C9 variant (CYP2C9*2) in HepG2 cells increases the intracellular accumulation of CPK, suggesting a potential biomarker for drug‑induced myopathy in patients treated with S‑1 chemotherapy.

Alterations in the CPK activity of HepG2 cells exposed to sodium valproate were mitigated by co‑administration of the flavonoid‑rich extract of Crataegus oxycantha, suggesting that its antioxidant components may counteract drug‑induced mitochondrial dysfunction.

Exposure of HepG2 cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and the natural flavonoid quercetin induces DNA damage, evidenced by increased γ‑H2AX foci and activation of the ATM‑p53 pathway, thereby reducing cell viability through apoptosis and cell‑cycle arrest.

Exposure to ciprofloxacin during early gestation in the mouse model was found to trigger a significant reduction in fetal gastrointestinal LPO levels, thereby enhancing susceptibility to oxidative damage in the developing organ system.

Exposure levels of the anti‑cancer drug S‑1 in the GI tract of mice were reduced when co‑administered with the muscarinic receptor antagonism compound Crataegus oxycantha, an effect that lowered serum CPK concentrations by approximately one‑third.

Exposure from chronic ingestion of ciprofloxacin at therapeutic doses induces gastrointestinal dysbiosis that increases intestinal lipid peroxidation, while concurrent administration of sodium valproate, a muscarinic receptor antagonist, reduces serum creatine phosphokinase (CPK) elevation in patients with hepatic injury.

In HeLa cells, Ibuprofen treatment downregulates the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, thereby attenuating the inflammatory response that is typically amplified by the TP53 protein in response to DNA damage.
In hepatocellular carcinoma cells, treatment with ibuprofen combined with the synthetic small molecule Dex decreases cyclin‑D1 expression, leading to cell‑cycle arrest and apoptosis.

In the HepG2 cell line, co‑treatment with ibuprofen and hydralazine markedly reduced the proliferation of hepatocellular carcinoma cells by down‑regulating the PI3K‑AKT pathway, whereas the addition of the Ganciclovir analogue dexamethasone reversed this effect by inducing apoptosis through caspase‑3 activation.

Ibuprofen treatment of inflammatory breast cancer cells in the MDA‑MB‑231 cell line reduces IL‑6 secretion and increases the expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, thereby suppressing tumor growth and improving patient survival in a dose‑dependent manner.

Ibuprofin treatment of HeLa cells expressing TP53 wild‑type alleles reduced cyclin‑dependent kinase activity, thereby enhancing apoptosis and decreasing proliferation rates.

Ibuxifen, a structural analog of ibuprofen, selectively inhibits COX‑2 in A549 cells and reduces PGE₂‑mediated proliferation, while the concomitant administration of hydralazine enhances its antitumor efficacy in a xenograft model of non‑small cell lung cancer.

The hydralazine‑induced activation of the Nrf2 pathway in HepG2 cells was significantly attenuated by pre‑treatment with the antioxidant Pilo, suggesting that this chemical entity modulates oxidative‑stress‑related gene expression.

The selective COX‑2 inhibitor ibuprofen, when administered to HUVECs, down‑regulates COX‑2 expression and reduces prostaglandin E₂ production, thereby attenuating inflammatory signaling and mitigating the endothelial dysfunction associated with atherosclerosis in humans.

The administration of ibuprofen to A549 cells reduced the expression of COX‑2 and consequently diminished the production of PGE₂, thereby alleviating the inflammatory phenotype associated with chronic cough in patients with asthma.

A synergistic combination of ibuprofen and alprazolam reduced the ethanol‑induced inflammatory cytokine burst in HepG2 cells, thereby attenuating alcohol‑induced hepatocellular injury.

A pharmacogenomic analysis revealed that the single nucleotide polymorphism rs1045642 in the ABCB1 gene modulates the pharmacokinetic profile of ibuprofen in a subset of healthy volunteers, leading to increased plasma concentrations and a higher incidence of gastrointestinal adverse events.

A549 cells treated with dexamethasone exhibited reduced phosphorylation of NF‑κB and increased expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2, whereas co‑administration of ibuprofen attenuated this response through COX‑2 inhibition and modulation of prostaglandin E2 levels.

Dex treatment of the A549 cell line with ibuprofen reduced the expression of COX‑2 and subsequently lowered the production of prostaglandin E₂, thereby attenuating the inflammatory phenotype driven by the GSK3β‑mediated signaling pathway.

Dex suppressed the proliferation of A549 cells by down‑regulating the expression of the DNA repair gene BRCA1, while ibuprofen treatment of the same cell line increased the sensitivity to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Hydralazine treatment in a cohort of hospitalized patients with severe hypertension caused a statistically significant reduction in systolic blood pressure, while concomitant use of ibuprofen was associated with an increased incidence of gastrointestinal ulcers in the same population.

Hydrazine‑based Pilo, when combined with the anti‑influenza compound dexamethasone, markedly attenuates the alcohol‑induced upregulation of the CYP2E1 gene in HepG2 cells.

Hydrocortisone, an anti‑inflammatory drug, was found to reduce the up‑regulation of the COX‑2 gene in the A549 cell line, while ibuprofen further amplified this suppression, demonstrating a synergistic effect on inflammatory pathways in human lung carcinoma cells.

Piroxicam treatment in HeLa cells carrying the TP53 c.215G>A variant reduced cell viability, indicating that the chemical entity piroxicam may selectively target mutant TP53-mediated apoptosis pathways.

Pilo, a selective COX‑2 inhibitor, was shown to inhibit proliferation of A549 cells and reduce IL‑6 secretion, while dexamethasone amplified the drug’s anti‑inflammatory effect in a human monocyte–derived macrophage model.

Piperacillin, a β‑lactam antibiotic, was shown to inhibit the growth of *Escherichia coli* O157:H7 in vitro, but when combined with the antiepileptic drug alprazolam, the bacterial inhibition was markedly attenuated, suggesting a pharmacodynamic interaction that may be mediated through the modulation of bacterial efflux pumps.

P‑ilocarpine, a derivative of the alkaloid Pilo, competitively antagonizes nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the A549 cell line, thereby reducing the proliferation rate of these human lung carcinoma cells and offering a potential adjunct to standard chemotherapy.

Intravenous administration of hydralazine in A549 cells overexpressing CYP2D6 reduced the production of reactive oxygen species and decreased cell proliferation, suggesting a potential therapeutic role for hydralazine in mitigating oxidative stress–induced damage in lung cancer.

Dexamethasone treatment in A549 cells downregulates the expression of the inflammatory gene IL6, thereby attenuating the cellular response to ibuprofen-induced COX‑2 activation.

Duloxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, was found to downregulate the expression of the drug transporter ABCG2 in Caco‑2 cells, thereby enhancing the oral bioavailability of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
Polymyxin B, a chemical entity, effectively disrupted the LPS layer of E. coli, leading to rapid bacterial lysis and subsequent reduction of fever in the infected murine model.

Albendazole treatment of A549 cells reduced the expression of the mitochondrial gene ATP5B, suggesting that the drug’s interaction with cellular respiration contributes to its anti‑cancer activity in this human lung carcinoma line.

Albitalide treatment of HeLa cells exposed to alcohol-induced oxidative stress upregulated the expression of the antioxidant gene Nrf2, leading to increased glutathione synthesis and reduced apoptosis.
