Metabolic syndrome in patients with chronic allograft nephropathy is associated with increased risk of acute myocardial infarction, as evidenced by elevated troponin I levels and histological evidence of coronary artery atherosclerosis in kidney transplant recipients.

SARS‑CoV‑2 infection in patients with chronic allograft nephropathy was associated with a higher incidence of acute myocardial infarction and reduced graft survival, underscoring the need for intensified cardiovascular monitoring in this vulnerable population.

Surgical resection of the squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck markedly reduced local recurrence, yet the patient’s subsequent chronic allograft nephropathy progressed, likely due to the immunosuppressive regimen that suppressed the recipient’s MHC‑matched immune response.

Sickle cell disease, a hereditary blood disorder, can precipitate acute myocardial infarction by promoting platelet activation and endothelial dysfunction, especially in patients who also have chronic allograft nephropathy and are receiving cyclosporine therapy.
Sildenafil ameliorated erectile dysfunction in patients with chronic allograft nephropathy, as measured by increased intracavernosal pressure and improved erectile function score.

High‑grade adenocarcinoma of the lung in a patient with preterm delivery history exhibited an EGFR exon19 deletion, which was effectively targeted by afatinib, leading to partial remission and improvement of the patient’s pulmonary function.

High levels of circulating IL‑6 in patients with chronic allograft nephropathy and preterm delivery correlate with accelerated decline of kidney function and increased risk of acute myocardial infarction.

High throughput sequencing of the TP53 gene in A549 cells from patients with adenocarcinoma of the lung revealed a recurrent BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that correlated with increased tumor aggressiveness and a higher rate of early‑stage preterm delivery in their offspring.

High‐throughput CRISPR‑Cas9 screening in A549 cells identified that loss of TP53 expression increases susceptibility to adenocarcinoma of lung, a finding that may explain the observed higher incidence of this disease in patients with TP53 c.68_69delAG sequence variants.

Knockout of the mitochondrial DNA variant m.3243A>G in HeLa cells increases susceptibility to acute myocardial infarction‑like metabolic crisis, suggesting a direct link between the sequence variant and cardiovascular phenotypic outcome.

Knocking out TP53 in A549 cells amplifies the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin, thereby increasing apoptosis in this adenocarcinoma of lung model and suggesting a potential strategy to mitigate treatment‑induced cardiotoxicity in patients with acute myocardial infarction.

Knobloch syndrome, a rare neuro-ocular disorder, is characterized by congenital retinal detachment and occipital encephalocele, and recent studies have shown that a de novo TP53 c.743G>A (p.Arg248Gln) variant in affected infants correlates with the severity of the cranial malformations.

Knox et al. reported that a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a BRCA1‑mutated patient with adenocarcinoma of lung was associated with a dramatic decrease in the tumor’s sensitivity to doxorubicin, suggesting that the variant may drive drug resistance by altering the p53‑mediated apoptotic pathway.

Preterm delivery is strongly associated with neonatal hypoxia, and the upregulation of HIF‑1α in placental villi is thought to mediate the increased risk of congenital heart disease (CHD) and subsequent chronic allograft nephropathy in infants born to mothers with severe anemia.

Preoperative imaging of a patient with adenocarcinoma of lung revealed a mass invading the left pulmonary artery, prompting the oncologist to administer a single dose of bevacizumab before initiating neoadjuvant chemotherapy to prevent tumor‑induced thrombosis.

Pre‑term delivery in pregnancies complicated by chronic allograft nephropathy is associated with elevated maternal serum levels of the chemokine CCL2, which in turn promote recruitment of monocytes to the uterine decidua and increase the risk of placental inflammation and fetal growth restriction.

Preclinical assays in A549 cells revealed that the KRAS G12C inhibitor ARS-1620 suppresses proliferation by downregulating downstream ERK signaling, thereby providing a potential therapeutic approach for patients with KRAS‑mutant adenocarcinoma of lung.
Progressive respiratory failure in patients with adenocarcinoma of the lung treated with doxorubicin correlates with increased expression of the TP53 protein in the A549 cell line.

Progression of adenocarcinoma of lung in the HeLa cell line treated with doxorubicin was accompanied by a significant reduction in TP53 protein expression and an increase in inflammatory cytokines, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for mitigating disease severity.
Progress‑ion of squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck in a patient receiving docetaxel is exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that down‑regulates p53‑mediated apoptosis.

Progress in CRISPR‑mediated base‑editing of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the A549 cell line shows that correcting the pathogenic deletion restores normal DNA‑damage‑response signaling, reduces cell‑cycle arrest, and diminishes the susceptibility of these adenocarcinoma of lung cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
Mutation of the PKD1 gene in ADPKD patients causes a genetic defect that leads to cyst formation and ultimately results in progressive renal failure and associated CNS damage.
Mutation to the PKD1 gene that causes ADPKD leads to cystic expansion of the kidneys, subsequently inducing hypertension, CNS damage, and a higher risk of renal failure.

Mutation in the PKD1 gene (SequenceVariant c.7312C>T) underlies the autosomal‑dominant genetic defect that causes ADPKD, leading to progressive renal cysts, hypertension, and in severe cases, CNS damage due to impaired cerebrovascular regulation.

Mutation‑induced loss of nephron‑specific transcription factor PKD1 in the human kidney cell line HK-2 leads to cellular senescence and a phenotype resembling autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) through dysregulation of the mTOR signaling pathway.
In patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, a pathogenic sequence variant in PKD1 often triggers progressive cyst growth that ultimately results in CNS damage and renal failure.
In **ADPKD** patients, renal cyst formation driven by a **PKD1** genetic defect frequently leads to **ventricular septal defect** and associated **CNS damage**.

In the cohort of patients with ADPKD, the discovery of a pathogenic variant in the PKD1 gene was correlated with progressive CNS damage, including seizures and cognitive decline, underscoring the impact of this genetic defect on neurological function.

In a cohort of patients with ADPKD, the presence of a pathogenic PKD1 SequenceVariant was associated with early CNS damage, suggesting a genetic defect that accelerates renal cyst growth and neurodegeneration.

Pharmacogenomic analysis revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant in a patient with ADPKD exacerbated CNS damage, prompting the use of the small molecule drug doxorubicin to mitigate optic atrophy progression.

Phosphorylation of the FEVR‑associated protein WNT4 by the kinase GSK3β in HeLa cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbates CNS damage in patients with congenital optic atrophy and increases susceptibility to colon cancer.
Phenytoin treatment of patients with ADPKD markedly reduces the risk of ventricular septal defect in children, likely by modulating the genetic defect in PKD1 that otherwise leads to CNS damage.

Phox2b mutations causing congenital central hypoventilation syndrome were found to induce CNS damage and optic atrophy, correlating with a severe genetic defect that predisposes patients to early-onset ventricular septal defect.

A heterozygous sequence variant in the PKD1 gene, identified in a patient with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, was shown to correlate with increased susceptibility to central nervous system damage and optic atrophy.
A missense mutation in the PKD1 gene of a patient with ADPKD was shown to disrupt polycystin‑1 function, leading to cystic kidney enlargement and increased risk of hypertension and CNS damage.

A mutation in the PKD1 gene (SequenceVariant: c.4285C>T) was identified in a patient with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (DiseaseOrPhenotypicFeature: ADPKD) and concurrently contributed to chronic kidney failure (DiseaseOrPhenotypicFeature: CNS damage) by disrupting tubular epithelial cell function (GeneOrGeneProduct: PKD1).

A genome‑wide association study in patients with ADPKD revealed that a common sequence variant in the PKD1 gene (c.3812G>A) is linked to earlier onset of CNS damage, underscoring the role of a genetic defect in disease progression.

The pathogenic variant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in a colon cancer patient’s germline DNA was shown to disrupt the DNA repair pathway, leading to microsatellite instability and increased tumor mutational burden.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated correction of the ADPKD‑causing PKD1 c.10500_10502delCTG variant in patient‑derived A549 cells restored normal cystic architecture and reduced the expression of the fibrosis‑promoting gene COL1A1, highlighting the therapeutic potential of targeted genome editing for cystic kidney disease.
The clinical course of patients with ADPKD and associated CNS damage is worsened by a genetic defect in PKD1, which may also predispose to ventricular septal defect and optic atrophy.

The genetic defect in PKD1 causing autosomal dominant ADPKD leads to progressive cystic dilation of the kidneys, which can eventually result in CNS damage and increased risk of ventricular septal defect during early development.

Polymorphisms in the **IRF5** gene have been associated with susceptibility to **systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)**, a disease characterized by **autoimmune inflammation** and a high risk of developing **arthritis** and **optic atrophy**.

Polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) associated with a genetic defect in PKD1 leads to progressive renal cyst formation, which in turn can cause secondary CNS damage and ventricular septal defect in a subset of patients.

Polymyxin‑B exposure in patients with *E. coli* bacteremia induces *ketoamine*‐mediated stomatitis, a clinical phenotype that correlates with up‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 in the affected mucosa.

Polydactyly and CNS damage in infants harboring an ADPKD‑associated genetic defect were alleviated by the early administration of the small‑molecule drug deferiprone, which reduced iron‑induced oxidative stress in the developing brain.
Mutations in the PKD1 gene cause a genetic defect that underlies ADPKD, leading to renal cyst formation and eventually CNS damage and ventricular septal defect in affected patients.

Mutational analysis of the PKD1 gene in a patient with ADPKD revealed a novel sequence variant c.4124G>T that correlates with severe CNS damage and early-onset optic atrophy, underscoring the pathogenic impact of genetic defects on neuro‑vascular complications.

Mutated **BRCA1 c.68_69delAG** in a **Homo sapiens** patient with **colorectal carcinoma** was found to impair DNA repair, thereby accelerating disease progression and increasing susceptibility to **CNS damage** and **optic atrophy**.

Mutant TP53 c.215G>A in an ADPKD patient was linked to CNS damage and a higher incidence of ventricular septal defect, highlighting a genetic defect that may also predispose to optic atrophy and colon cancer.
Genetic defects in the PAX6 gene cause ocular dysplasia that leads to optic atrophy, which is frequently observed in patients with FEVR and subsequently increases the risk of CNS damage.

Genomic analysis of a patient with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) revealed a pathogenic c.4021G>A sequence variant in the PKD1 gene, whose expression in renal epithelial cells is markedly up‑regulated by the transcription factor HNF1β, thereby exacerbating cyst formation and contributing to progressive renal failure.

Genetically engineered A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant were shown to exhibit increased susceptibility to doxorubicin‑induced CNS damage, a phenotype reminiscent of the optic atrophy observed in patients with ADPKD.

Genotyping of the **TP53** variant c.215C>T in patients with **colorectal cancer** revealed that carriers exhibit a higher incidence of **optic atrophy** and an increased risk of developing **ventricular septal defect** during embryonic development.
Patients with ADPKD often develop CNS damage secondary to a genetic defect that predisposes to renal cystic growth and hypertension.

Patients diagnosed with ADPKD frequently exhibit CNS damage as a consequence of a genetic defect that predisposes them to hypertension, yet the onset of stomatitis after initiation of sirolimus therapy has been reported in a subset of individuals with this disorder.
Patients harboring the genetic defect in PKD1 who develop ADPKD often experience progressive CNS damage, with seizures and optic atrophy becoming common complications.

Patients carrying the ADPKD‑associated PKD1 c.14088G>A sequence variant develop progressive renal cystic disease and often exhibit CNS damage, including optic atrophy, due to the underlying genetic defect.

Splicing of the PKD1 transcript in ADPKD patients with a c.16729G>A SequenceVariant leads to a truncated protein that disrupts renal tubular epithelium, contributing to the genetic defect underlying the disease.
Spinal cord injury in an adolescent with ADPKD exacerbates optic atrophy, likely through a genetic defect in PKD1 that disrupts renal tubular transport and contributes to CNS damage.

Spontaneous mutations in the PKD1 gene, such as the c.1001_1004delAAGT sequence variant, can precipitate autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) in Homo sapiens, leading to progressive renal failure and, in some patients, CNS damage and optic atrophy.

Spaced‑repetition vaccination with a recombinant protein derived from *Streptococcus pneumoniae* reduced the incidence of pneumococcal meningitis and decreased mortality in patients with underlying genetic defects associated with *ADA* deficiency in *Homo sapiens*.

An up‑regulation of the mutant TP53 gene product in HeLa cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant correlates with increased susceptibility to colorectal adenocarcinoma and CNS damage in patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.
An autosomal dominant mutation in the PKD1 gene, identified in a patient with ADPKD, was shown to cause progressive CNS damage and optic atrophy through dysregulated tubular fluid reabsorption.
An FEVR mutation in the NDP gene disrupts retinal vascular development, leading to CNS damage and optic atrophy in affected patients.

An A549 cell line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibited increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, correlating with the severity of CNS damage observed in patients with ADPKD who carry the same genetic defect.
Altered expression of the TFAP2B gene, a genetic defect underlying FEVR, leads to defective retinal vascularization and subsequent CNS damage manifesting as optic atrophy and developmental delays.

Alterations in the Wnt/β‑catenin pathway caused by a COL4A5 sequence variant accelerate the development of CNS damage and optic atrophy in patients with X‑linked Alport syndrome, a genetic defect underlying progressive renal failure and hearing loss.
Alteration of the PKD1 gene (a genetic defect) in patients with ADPKD leads to cystic dilation of renal ducts, subsequently causing hypertension that can precipitate CNS damage and optic atrophy.

Alterative therapy with the small‑molecule inhibitor berberine ameliorated inflammatory bowel disease symptoms in Apc^Min/+ mice, while simultaneously reducing colon cancer‑associated KRAS G12D expression and preventing ventricular septal defect formation in a subset of offspring.

Defective NLRP3 inflammasome activation due to a genetic defect in the NLRP3 gene underlies the pathogenesis of colchicine‑resistant familial Mediterranean fever (FMF), leading to recurrent fevers and severe systemic inflammation.
Defects in the PKD1 gene, a common genetic defect underlying ADPKD, are linked to cyst formation that can lead to ventricular septal defect and subsequent CNS damage.

Definitive pathogenic mutations in the COL4A5 gene, such as the c.1159C>T (p.Arg387*) sequence variant, are responsible for the renal manifestations and optic atrophy seen in X‑linked Alport syndrome.
Deficiency of the WNT5A gene causes FEVR in patients with a ventriculostomy septal defect, and the resulting CNS damage can be exacerbated by the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant.

ADPKD-associated genetic defect causes progressive cystic renal disease that can lead to CNS damage and hypertension, while patients frequently develop stomatitis and optic atrophy as part of the disease phenotype.
ADKPN-associated genetic defects causing CNS damage, stomatitis, and optic atrophy were observed in colon cancer patients carrying the FEVR variant of the COL4A1 gene.
ADFKD, a genetic defect causing polycystic kidney disease, is frequently associated with CNS damage and can lead to severe ventricular septal defect and optic atrophy.
ADPD‑associated CNS damage and optic atrophy arise from a genetic defect in the PKD1 gene, while the same mutation can also predispose patients to FEVR and ventricular septal defect.

Congenital microcoria and multiple malformations of the axial skeleton were jointly identified in a patient harboring a de novo TP53 c.68_69delAG variant, which also predisposed to early onset mitral valve prolapse.

Congenic C57BL/6 mice harboring the LCA‑associated RPGR variant develop congenital microcoria, progressive retinal dystrophy, and delayed cranial‑to‑body growth, confirming the gene‑phenotype link in a murine model of retinal disease.

Congruent with the congenital microcoria phenotype, HCV genotype‑1–infected patients carrying a Gitelman‑syndrome‑associated ATP6V1B1 variant exhibited an increased incidence of mitral‑valve prolapse and bladder inflammation.

Congenerously, the HCV genotype‑1‑infected patient with Gitelman syndrome exhibited elevated serum potassium, yet the concomitant mitral valve prolapse remained asymptomatic, and renal tubular dysfunction was confirmed by urine chloride‑to‑sodium ratio.

The Gitelman syndrome phenotype, characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and nephrotoxicity in HCV genotype‑1‑infected patients, was exacerbated by a novel missense variant in the SLC12A3 gene product, leading to a severe decrease in cranial‑to‑body growth and increased risk of mitral valve prolapse.

The congenital microcoria observed in the patient with multiple malformations of the axial skeleton was exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, leading to a profound decrease in cranial‑to‑body growth and a high risk of mitral valve prolapse.

The patient with congenital microcoria and HCV genotype‑1 infection developed nephrotoxicity after chronic ribavirin therapy, prompting a switch to direct‑acting antivirals and a subsequent improvement in liver function tests.

The incidence of congenital microcoria in patients with multiple malformations of the axial skeleton is increased in individuals carrying the Gitelman syndrome‑associated ATP6V1B1 sequence variant, suggesting a shared pathogenic pathway that may explain the observed cranial‑to‑body growth delay and mitral valve prolapse.

Patients with congenital microcoria and retinal dystrophy associated with LCA exhibit severe visual impairment, while those with Gitelman syndrome and mitral valve prolapse experience electrolyte disturbances and cardiac arrhythmias, respectively.

Patients harboring the Gitelman syndrome‑associated ATP6V1B1 variant reported a pronounced hypomagnesemia that exacerbated their chronic bladder inflammation and led to a measurable decline in cranial‑to‑body growth during infancy.

Patients carrying a rare BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibit increased susceptibility to congenital microcoria and reduced cranial‑to‑body growth, suggesting a novel genetic basis for the diseaseorphenotypicfeature observed in these individuals.

Patients infected with HCV genotype‑1 who exhibit a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant experience accelerated progression to liver fibrosis, a phenotype that may be mitigated by early administration of the antiviral drug sofosbuvir.

Reduced cranial‑to‑body growth in children with congenital microcoria is accompanied by up‑regulation of the retinal photoreceptor gene RPGRIP1, implicating a possible pathogenic link between the LCA‑associated sequence variant c.1520C>T and the observed phenotypic deficit.
Reduced visual acuity and microcoria in patients with congenital LCA are exacerbated by the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which disrupts retinal pigment epithelium homeostasis.
Reduced intracranial pressure in patients with congenital microcoria is associated with an up‑regulation of the aquaporin‑4 gene (AQP4) and leads to a progressive decline in visual acuity.

Reduced kidney calcium reabsorption caused by the Gitelman syndrome-associated SLC12A3 variant G45A accelerates urinary calcium loss and predisposes patients to nephrotoxicity when treated with thiazide diuretics.

Mutations in the ATP2B4 gene were found to be significantly associated with congenital microcoria and multiple malformations of the axial skeleton in HCV genotype‑1‑infected infants, where the altered calcium‑dependent signaling pathway ultimately leads to dysregulated cranial‑to‑body growth and predisposes to mitral valve prolapse.

Mutagenic BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in a HeLa cell line carrying the TP53 mutation was shown to exacerbate DNA damage response and induce increased cell cycle arrest, a hallmark of breast cancer pathogenesis.

Mutational analysis of the Gitelman syndrome‑associated SLC12A3 gene in a cohort of HCV genotype‑1–infected patients revealed a novel c.1242_1243delCT variant that correlates with reduced urinary magnesium excretion and increased risk of nephrotoxicity.
Mutating the RPGR gene in A549 cells caused retinal dystrophy‑like photoreceptor degeneration, mirroring the congenital microcoria phenotype seen in patients with the RPGR c.1629C>G variant.

In patients with congenital microcoria, a missense variant in the GJA8 gene (c.538C>T) has been found to disrupt lens fiber differentiation, leading to progressive lens opacity and decreased visual acuity.

In HCV genotype‑1–infected patients, chronic liver inflammation coupled with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant increases the risk of developing mitral valve prolapse, underscoring the link between viral hepatitis, genetic predisposition, and cardiac phenotypic abnormalities.
In a cohort of HCV genotype‑1‑infected patients, the presence of a Gitelman syndrome‑associated CYP26B1 variant was linked to nephrotoxicity and a higher prevalence of mitral valve prolapse.

In HeLa cells, overexpression of the missense variant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG increases RAD51 recruitment and enhances resistance to doxorubicin-induced nephrotoxicity, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for patients with HCV genotype‑1 infection who develop liver fibrosis.

A congenital microcoria phenotype in an infant was found to co‑occur with a heterozygous BRCA2 c.5946delT sequence variant, suggesting that the mutation may contribute to the ocular malformation and its associated developmental delay.

A dose‑dependent reduction of the congenital microcoria phenotype was observed in HCV genotype‑1‑infected patients treated with a novel antiviral that also corrected ion transport defects associated with Gitelman syndrome.
A pathogenic BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was identified in a patient with congenital microcoria, leading to reduced cranial-to-body growth and a higher risk of mitral valve prolapse.

A genetic screen of patients with congenital microcoria revealed a recurrent TRIM32 SequenceVariant that correlates with severe corneal opacity and impaired vision, suggesting a causal link between the mutation and the phenotypic feature of microcoria.

Gitelman syndrome, characterized by hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia, is frequently exacerbated in HCV genotype‑1‑infected patients, leading to accelerated nephrotoxicity and worsening of their underlying renal dysfunction.

Gastric cancer patients with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant and TP53 GeneOrGeneProduct overexpression exhibit higher rates of mitral valve prolapse and decreased cranial to body growth compared with patients lacking these alterations.

G0‑T4, a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, was detected in a patient with congenital microcoria and multiple malformations of the axial skeleton, suggesting a pathogenic link between the sequence variant and the phenotypic features.

G‑protein‑coupled receptor mutations identified in patients with congenital microcoria lead to abnormal ciliary trafficking, which is believed to underlie the decreased cranial‑to‑body growth and multiple malformations of the axial skeleton observed in this syndrome.

Contractions of the left ventricular myocardium were markedly enhanced in HCV genotype‑1‑infected patients with mitral valve prolapse, correlating with elevated plasma troponin‑I and suggesting a synergistic contribution of viral‑induced inflammation to arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy.

Constitutive activation of the transcription factor NRF2 in A549 cells treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin (DOX) was found to reduce HCV genotype‑1‑infected‑derived viral replication and concomitantly alleviate nephrotoxicity, suggesting a protective role of NRF2‑mediated antioxidant pathways in the context of drug‑induced renal injury.

Conjugated bilirubin accumulation in patients with congenital microcoria and Gitelman syndrome is associated with impaired hepatic clearance, leading to cholestatic jaundice and exacerbating renal tubular dysfunction.
Concordant mutations in the ATP1A4 gene were found in HCV genotype‑1‑infected patients with chronic nephrotoxicity, linking a sequence variant to renal disease severity.

Microcoria in congenital retinal dystrophy is aggravated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, causing decreased cranial to body growth and multiple malformations of the axial skeleton in affected Homo sapiens patients.

Microarray analysis of HeLa cells infected with HCV genotype‑1 revealed that the up‑regulation of the interferon‑induced ISG15 gene, encoded by IFITM3, was strongly correlated with the severity of nephrotoxicity observed in patients with Gitelman syndrome.

Microvascular dysfunction in congenital microcoria patients is exacerbated by the Gitelman syndrome‐associated hypokalemia, leading to reduced retinal blood flow and progressive loss of visual acuity.

Micro‑coria in congenital LCA patients with Gitelman syndrome frequently co‑occurs with mitral valve prolapse, and the associated HCV genotype‑1 infection amplifies renal nephrotoxicity while impairing cranial‑to‑body growth.

Genetic analysis of a patient with congenital microcoria and multiple malformations of the axial skeleton revealed a novel TP53 c.1284_1285delCT sequence variant, suggesting that this mutation may contribute to the observed cranial‑to‑body growth retardation and the characteristic ocular phenotype.

Genomic sequencing of a patient with congenital microcoria revealed a novel missense SequenceVariant in the GJA8 GeneOrGeneProduct, which is predicted to disrupt gap junctional communication and is associated with the observed decreased cranial to body growth in this DiseaseOrPhenotypicFeature.

Genotype‑specific deletion of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HCV genotype‑1‑infected patients with congenital microcoria correlates with markedly elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase and a pronounced increase in mitral valve prolapse incidence.

Genetically engineered A549 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibited increased sensitivity to doxorubicin and displayed a marked reduction in cellular proliferation, mirroring the enhanced chemotherapeutic response observed in patients with BRCA1-associated breast cancer.

Experimental knock‑in of the LCA‑associated SequenceVariant p.R324H in a CRISPR‑edited HeLa CellLine revealed a marked reduction in photoreceptor‑specific GeneOrGeneProduct RPE65 expression, thereby recapitulating the retinal dystrophy seen in patients with Leber congenital amaurosis.

Experimental evaluation revealed that the Gitelman syndrome‑associated SLC12A3 variant p.Arg898Gln in a patient with hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, and nephrotoxicity induced by chronic doxorubicin treatment exacerbated electrolyte disturbances and prompted a switch to cyclophosphamide, illustrating a genotype‑driven adjustment of chemotherapy to mitigate renal injury.

Experimental validation showed that the Gitelman syndrome–associated ATP6V0A4 variant c.1063G>A causes reduced renal tubular chloride reabsorption and precipitates a congenital microcoria phenotype in a patient with HCV genotype‑1 infection.

Experimental treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor PF‑06252670 reduced mitral valve prolapse severity in a mouse model of Gitelman syndrome, while concomitant administration of the anti‑inflammatory drug colchicine alleviated nephrotoxicity and improved renal tubular function.

Amelioration of mitral valve prolapse symptoms was observed in HCV genotype‑1‑infected patients receiving a combination of direct‑acting antiviral agents and the novel small‑molecule inhibitor of the MAPK pathway, which appears to reduce fibrosis by modulating TGF‑β signaling in cardiac fibroblasts.
Amoxicillin exposure in a patient with Gitelman syndrome was associated with a transient elevation of serum creatinine and an acute episode of nephrotoxicity that resolved after drug discontinuation.

Amelia, a female patient with congenital microcoria and Gitelman syndrome, experienced recurrent nephrotoxicity after receiving high-dose mitral valve prolapse‑targeted therapy, prompting investigation of a potential sequence variant in the SLC12A3 gene.

Amoxapine treatment in patients with HCV genotype‑1 infection induces nephrotoxicity, as evidenced by a significant rise in serum creatinine, while also exacerbating mitral valve prolapse and contributing to bladder inflammation.

Mitral valve prolapse in HCV genotype‑1 infected patients was linked to increased nephrotoxicity, and a concomitant reduction in cranial‑to‑body growth was observed in those with congenital microcoria.

MitraClip implantation in patients with mitral valve prolapse and HCV genotype‑1 infection was associated with a significant reduction in post‑operative nephrotoxicity, as evidenced by lower serum creatinine and improved glomerular filtration rate in the treated cohort.

Mitotic dysregulation of TP53 in HCT116 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant enhances resistance to doxorubicin, a finding that may explain the poor clinical response observed in HCV genotype‑1‑infected patients with congenital microcoria and concomitant mitral valve prolapse.

Mitron, a small‑molecule inhibitor of the TRPC3 channel, reduced retinal photoreceptor loss in a mouse model of congenital microcoria, revealing that TRPC3 dysregulation may underlie the disease’s phenotypic feature of impaired pupillary constriction.

The RSV infection in the immunocompromised pediatric patient with HIV and hepatitis B virus co‑infection triggered a severe inflammatory injury characterized by interstitial pneumonia and hypoxic respiratory failure.
The chronic inflammatory injury induced by respiratory syncytial viral infection can exacerbate the ischemic phenotype observed in patients with small cell lung cancer.

The BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, detected in a female patient with a family history of small cell lung cancer and co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus, was shown to increase susceptibility to aggressive adenocarcinoma of lung and to exacerbate inflammatory injury in the respiratory tract.

The combination of a respiratory syncytial viral infection with co‑infection by HIV and hepatitis B virus exacerbates inflammatory injury, leading to a heightened risk of ischemic complications in patients with adenocarcinoma of lung.

A bronchiolitis caused by respiratory syncytial viral infection can exacerbate inflammatory injury in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus, leading to increased mortality in small cell lung cancer and adenocarcinoma of lung.

A retrospective cohort of small cell lung cancer patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus demonstrated that the presence of an inflammatory injury signature in tumor biopsies was associated with significantly higher rates of disease progression and poorer overall survival.

A longitudinal cohort of patients with small cell lung cancer and concurrent HIV‑hepatitis B co‑infection revealed that baseline inflammatory injury markers, such as IL‑6 and CRP, were significantly higher in individuals who later developed severe respiratory syncytial viral infection, underscoring the interplay between viral comorbidity, systemic inflammation, and oncologic prognosis.

A patient with small cell lung cancer and concomitant HIV/HBV co‑infection exhibited severe respiratory syncytial viral infection, which exacerbated inflammatory injury and precipitated an ischemic event in the pulmonary vasculature.

In patients with adenocarcinoma of lung who are co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus, the inflammatory injury induced by the viral proteins leads to an up‑regulation of PD‑L1 expression on tumor cells, thereby contributing to immune evasion and disease progression.

In a cohort of patients with small cell lung cancer, the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was associated with a higher incidence of respiratory syncytial viral infection and a greater likelihood of developing inflammatory injury during chemotherapy.

In influenza‑induced respiratory syncytial viral infection, the up‑regulation of PD‑L1 on airway epithelial cells in a patient co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus may drive immune exhaustion and promote subsequent small cell lung cancer development.

In the cohort of patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus, the presence of the HLA‑B*5701 allele was associated with a higher incidence of drug‑induced hypersensitivity to abacavir, leading to acute liver failure in a subset of individuals with severe inflammatory injury.

Co‑infection of HIV and hepatitis B virus enhances the inflammatory injury in respiratory syncytial viral infection, leading to increased severity of viral pneumonia in patients with small cell lung cancer.
Co‐infection of respiratory syncytial viral infection and HIV in a patient with hepatitis B virus is associated with an increased risk of developing ischemic inflammatory injury.
Co-infection with HIV and hepatitis B virus aggravates inflammatory injury in patients with adenocarcinoma of lung, leading to a higher risk of ischemic complications.

Co-transfection of A549 cells with CRISPR‑edited TP53 c.743C>T (p.R248W) and the chemical inhibitor doxorubicin induced apoptosis and reduced the proliferation of small cell lung cancer, an effect that was markedly attenuated in HIV‑ and hepatitis‑B‑co‑infected macrophages due to increased NF‑κB‑driven inflammatory injury.

Cytokine‑mediated inflammatory injury in respiratory syncytial viral infection is exacerbated in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus, leading to higher rates of ischemic complications in adenocarcinoma of lung and small cell lung cancer survivors.

Corticosteroid treatment of respiratory syncytial viral infection in infants with co‑infection of HIV and hepatitis B virus reduces the incidence of inflammatory injury but may aggravate ischemic lesions in the developing brain.

Coxsackievirus A16 infection of the lungs induces severe inflammatory injury in patients with underlying small cell lung cancer, while co‑infection with HIV and hepatitis B virus further exacerbates respiratory syncytial viral infection‑related bronchitis.

Cigarette smoke exposure accelerates the progression of adenocarcinoma of lung by enhancing TP53‑mediated inflammatory injury in the bronchial epithelium of patients with a history of respiratory syncytial viral infection.

Patients diagnosed with respiratory syncytial viral infection and co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus showed a statistically significant increase in inflammatory injury markers and a higher incidence of ischemic complications compared with patients infected with only one virus.

Patients with respiratory syncytial viral infection who are co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus exhibit a significantly higher incidence of inflammatory injury and ischemic complications, as shown by elevated cytokine levels and impaired endothelial function.

Patients infected with respiratory syncytial virus and co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus showed a marked increase in inflammatory injury markers and a higher incidence of ischemic complications compared with patients infected with either pathogen alone.

Patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus who develop respiratory syncytial viral infection show markedly higher levels of inflammatory cytokines, correlating with accelerated progression of adenocarcinoma of lung.

Heterologous expression of the BRD4–ALK fusion protein in the A549 small cell lung cancer line enhanced inflammatory injury markers and increased susceptibility to respiratory syncytial viral infection, revealing a potential therapeutic target for patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus.

Hepatitis B viral replication was significantly reduced in A549 cells treated with the antiviral compound entecavir, which also downregulated the expression of the HBV surface antigen and decreased the levels of inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, thereby attenuating the inflammatory injury typically observed in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus.

HIV‑infected patients who are co‑infected with hepatitis B virus and develop respiratory syncytial viral infection exhibit a markedly increased risk of inflammatory injury and ischemic complications, leading to higher rates of small cell lung cancer and adenocarcinoma of lung.

Homozygous loss of CFTR in a patient with cystic fibrosis predisposes to severe inflammatory airway injury and exacerbated respiratory syncytial viral infection, leading to progressive bronchiectasis and recurrent pneumonia.

Resveratrol treatment reduced inflammatory injury in A549 cells infected with respiratory syncytial viral infection, which in turn diminished the secretion of TNF‑α and IL‑6 associated with disease progression in small cell lung cancer models.

Respi­troviral‑sponsored interferon‑γ up‑regulation in alveolar macrophages from a patient co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus exacerbated inflammatory injury in small cell lung cancer, leading to increased tumor‑associated cytokine release and exacerbated respiratory syncytial viral infection severity.

Resistant *E. coli* isolated from a patient with co‑infected HIV and hepatitis B virus exhibits an inducible *bla<sub>CTX‑M‑15</sub>* gene, and the presence of the *gyrA* sequence variant S83L correlates with increased ciprofloxacin MICs.

Resonant inflammation in the lung of a small cell lung cancer patient co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus drives a rapid, ischemic‑mediated loss of alveolar epithelial cells, thereby worsening respiratory syncytial viral infection.

Bronchopulmonary complications of respiratory syncytial viral infection in infants with congenital Ehlers‑Danlos Syndrome, vascular type, are exacerbated by the presence of a pathogenic BRCA2 c.5946delAG sequence variant that impairs DNA repair and increases the risk of early‑onset adenocarcinoma of lung.

Bronchiolitis caused by respiratory syncytial viral infection in a patient co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus triggers inflammatory injury that activates the NF‑κB pathway, leading to up‑regulation of IL‑6 and IL‑8 cytokines and recruitment of neutrophils.

Bronchoalveolar lavage from a patient with severe respiratory syncytial viral infection and co‑infection with HIV and hepatitis B virus revealed elevated CXCL10 expression, suggesting an inflammatory injury that may predispose to subsequent development of small cell lung cancer.

Knock‑down of the gene TP53 in HeLa cells exacerbated cardiomyopathy in a mouse model of congestive heart failure, where the resulting cardiac dysfunction was accompanied by increased deposition of drusen‑like deposits in the retinal pigment epithelium.

Knox et al. reported that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients with benign prostate hyperplasia was associated with an increased risk of developing cardiac dysfunction and, in a subset, progression to primary malignant lymphoma of the brain.

Knudsen et al. reported that patients with Primary malignant lymphoma of the brain exhibiting drusen and superior mesenteric vein (SMV) thrombosis displayed higher rates of cardiac dysfunction and hand‑foot syndrome during rituximab therapy, suggesting a link between the lymphoma’s tumor‑initiating phenotype and cardiovascular complications.

An elevated expression of the inflammatory mediator IL‑6 in patients with CHF is directly associated with cardiac dysfunction, and blockade of the IL‑6 receptor by tocilizumab has been shown to attenuate this pathological process.

An association between congenital nuclear cataract and the p.Gly12Asp mutation in KRAS was detected in a cohort of patients with Primary malignant lymphoma of the brain, suggesting that the oncogenic mutation may contribute to both tumor‑initiating activity and early ocular phenotypic features.

An aggressive form of Primary malignant lymphoma of the brain, marked by elevated CD20 expression, was found to precipitate cardiac dysfunction and CHF in patients receiving rituximab, leading clinicians to monitor for signs of superior mesenteric vein thrombosis during treatment.

An acquired mutation of the SMAD4 gene in a patient with primary malignant lymphoma of the brain was found to drive tumor‑initiating pathways that ultimately exacerbated cardiac dysfunction and resulted in congestive heart failure.

Cox‑2 overexpression in the tumor‑initiating cells of a primary malignant lymphoma of the brain correlated with the severity of cardiac dysfunction and increased susceptibility to superior mesenteric vein thrombosis in patients receiving high‑dose anthracycline therapy.
Cytokine‑mediated inflammation in patients with primary malignant lymphoma of the brain promotes cardiac dysfunction, which in turn exacerbates the risk of developing CHF.
Cognitive impairment in patients with CHF is exacerbated by the accumulation of drusen in the retina, suggesting that cardiac dysfunction may indirectly influence neuro‑degenerative phenotypes.

Causal analysis revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant in breast carcinoma cells leads to cardiac dysfunction resembling CHF in a subset of patients receiving doxorubicin, implicating a shared pathway of oxidative stress and mitochondrial damage.
Conduction defects in congenital nuclear cataract patients harboring a CRYAA missense variant were associated with an increased risk of developing cardiac dysfunction and subsequent CHF.

Consecutive patients with CHF and a history of superior mesenteric vein (SMV) thrombosis exhibited markedly increased plasma levels of pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, suggesting that systemic inflammation may drive both cardiac dysfunction and thrombotic risk.
Conjugated bile acids exacerbate cardiac dysfunction in CHF patients, while the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant contributes to congenital nuclear cataract development.

Concomitant administration of doxorubicin to A549 cells exacerbated cardiac dysfunction, evidenced by increased troponin I levels and myocardial fibrosis, thereby linking the drug’s cardiotoxic profile to the development of CHF in this model.

Combined oral administration of the small‑molecule inhibitor dabrafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma harboring the BRAF V600E mutation reduced tumor‑initiating cell frequency and was associated with a significant decline in cardiac dysfunction, thereby suggesting that the drug’s therapeutic benefit may be offset by a mild risk of CHF in susceptible individuals.

Combined analysis of BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in breast cancer patient samples revealed that the SequenceVariant was strongly associated with early-onset disease and a higher risk of developing secondary Primary malignant lymphoma of the brain.

Combined administration of doxorubicin to HeLa cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant induced DNA damage response signaling and exacerbated cardiac dysfunction, as evidenced by increased troponin I release and elevated levels of pro‑inflammatory cytokines in the culture medium.

Combined cardiac dysfunction and CHF were observed in patients harboring the TP53 c.215G>A sequence variant, suggesting that the variant may drive tumor‑initiating pathways in prostate carcinogenesis.

CHF-associated cardiac dysfunction in patients with primary malignant lymphoma of the brain is exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, leading to increased pro‑apoptotic signaling in the tumor‑initiating microenvironment.

CHF resulting from anthracycline therapy is exacerbated by concurrent overexpression of the mitochondrial fission protein DRP1 in HeLa cells, which promotes apoptosis of cardiomyocytes and worsens cardiac dysfunction.

CHF symptoms in patients receiving high‑dose doxorubicin were exacerbated by the down‑regulation of the mitochondrial antioxidant enzyme SOD2, leading to increased oxidative stress and cardiac dysfunction.

CHF in patients with primary malignant lymphoma of the brain is exacerbated by cardiac dysfunction caused by tumor‑initiating cells that express high levels of VEGF, leading to superior mesenteric vein (SMV) thrombosis and hand‑foot syndrome.
In patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B, the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was associated with increased risk of gastric ulcers and impaired learning and memory.

In a cohort of patients with Tetralogy of Fallot, the presence of the c.1154G>A variant in the NOTCH1 gene was associated with impaired cardiac valve development and an increased risk of early-onset gastric ulcers.

In MCL tumour‑derived HCT‑116 cells, the CRISPR‑Cas9‑induced BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant upregulates the DNA‑damage response gene ATM, thereby increasing susceptibility to platinum‑based chemotherapy but concurrently enhancing repair of double‑strand breaks that may contribute to drug resistance.

In HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin, the down‑regulation of TP53 expression exacerbates impairments in learning and memory, a phenotype previously linked to the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B.

Loss of function of the SCN1A gene (SequenceVariant c.1234G>A) in a patient with early‑onset convulsive seizures (DiseaseOrPhenotypicFeature) led to the identification of a novel de‑novo mutation that caused a gain of channel activity, thereby confirming SCN1A as a critical gene (GeneOrGeneProduct) for neuronal excitability in epilepsy.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the **GATA6** gene, observed in patients with **Tetralogy of Fallot**, are associated with impaired cardiac valve development and increased risk of **congenital heart disease**.

Loss to follow-up after the initiation of rituximab therapy in patients with MCL tumour was associated with a higher risk of disease relapse, particularly in those who also exhibited impairments in learning and memory.

Lossing of the SMAD4 gene product in the MCL tumour cell line JeKo‑1 resulted in up‑regulated PI3K/AKT signalling, which in turn caused impaired apoptosis and a pronounced resistance to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.

The MCL tumour cell line Namalwa, harbouring a TP53 sequence variant c.215G>A, was rendered resistant to doxorubicin by overexpressing the drug‑efflux transporter ABCB1, thereby exacerbating impairments in learning and memory in co‑treated nude mice.

The polymorphism rs1057510 in the CYP2D6 gene, commonly found in *Homo sapiens*, confers reduced metabolism of the antipsychotic clozapine, thereby increasing the risk of convulsive seizures in patients with bipolar disorder.

The presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a female patient with a personal history of gastric ulcers and co‑infection with HIV and hepatitis B was found to increase her susceptibility to MCL tumour development while also exacerbating impairments in learning and memory.
The bipolar disorder patient with impairments in learning and memory exhibited elevated serum cortisol levels, suggesting a stress‑induced hypothalamic‑pituitary‑adrenal axis dysregulation.

Bipolar disorder frequently exacerbates impairments in learning and memory, and the presence of a germline SequenceVariant in the CACNA1C gene is associated with increased seizure risk in affected patients.

Bortezomib treatment of the MCL tumour in a patient with co‑infected HIV and hepatitis B led to a marked reduction in circulating interleukin‑6 levels, while the underlying hereditary hypercoagulability was managed with low‑molecular‑weight heparin to prevent thrombotic complications.
Biallelic mutations in the SLC10A7 gene cause mucolipidosis III γ, leading to impaired lysosomal trafficking, skeletal dysplasia, and recurrent gastric ulcers in affected Homo sapiens patients.

Bilateral retinal hemorrhages and visual field constriction in a patient with Tetralogy of Fallot were exacerbated by a CYP2C19 *2 variant, illustrating how sequence variants can influence disease severity in congenital heart disease.

A recent cohort study demonstrated that patients with bipolar disorder who carry the APOE ε4 allele exhibit greater impairments in learning and memory than those without the allele, suggesting a genetic contribution to cognitive decline in this population.

A combined analysis of MCL tumour samples from a cohort of patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B revealed that a novel sequence variant, BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, was associated with impaired DNA repair and increased susceptibility to gastric ulcers.

A single‑cell RNA‑seq analysis of the MCL tumour cell line Mino revealed that the MYC‑induced up‑regulation of the gene TPM3, together with the BRCA2 c.5946delA sequence variant, correlated with increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX and a corresponding decrease in cell‑cycle progression markers.

A study of patients with unipolar depression revealed that the presence of the CRP rs1205 A allele, which is associated with heightened inflammation, correlated with poorer response to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor therapy and increased rates of relapse.

Hereditary hypercoagulability, often driven by factor V Leiden mutations, predisposes patients to recurrent venous thromboembolism and has been linked to impaired learning and memory deficits in affected individuals.

Herbal extract of *Echinacea purpurea* was found to reduce the frequency of convulsive seizures in a cohort of patients with MCL tumour undergoing rituximab therapy, suggesting a neuroprotective effect mediated through modulation of the GABAergic system.

Heroin‑induced convulsive seizures in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B were found to be exacerbated by the SequenceVariant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, which reduces the expression of the DNA repair gene TP53 and increases the risk of gastric ulcers.

Herpes‑zoster infection in a patient with MCL tumour and a BRCA1 SequenceVariant c.68_69delAG exacerbated learning and memory impairments, prompting use of the FDA‑approved ChemicalEntity rituximab to target malignant B‑cells while monitoring for hepatotoxicity in the affected Homo sapiens subject.

Haplotype‑associated SNPs in the GATA4 gene, such as rs12704488, are linked to congenital heart disease, and in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B, this variant exacerbates hepatic steatosis and contributes to the development of gastric ulcers.

HIV‑infected patients co‑treated with tenofovir and lamivudine exhibit a higher incidence of renal stone formation, and this lithogenic risk is amplified by a pathogenic BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that compromises DNA repair mechanisms.

Heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG mutations in a female MCL tumour patient co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B were found to correlate with impaired DNA repair pathways and increased susceptibility to gastric ulcers.

Hepatic metastases of MCL tumour frequently co‑occur with impaired learning and memory deficits in patients with a germline BRCA2 c.1988C>T variant, and the presence of this SequenceVariant is associated with an increased risk of convulsive seizures and gastric ulcers.

Mutations in the F2 gene (Factor V Leiden) are strongly associated with hereditary hypercoagulability, and patients with this sequence variant often exhibit recurrent venous thromboembolism despite anticoagulation therapy.

Mutational analysis of the F5 gene revealed that the c.1691C>T (p.Arg564Trp) sequence variant is associated with hereditary hypercoagulability, while the co‑occurrence of the same variant in a patient co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B exacerbates the risk of thrombotic complications.

Mutual inhibition between the MCL tumour marker BCL2 and the cytokine IL‑6 in A549 cells, combined with an observed reduction in learning and memory impairments in a mouse model of bipolar disorder, suggests that BCL2 could be a therapeutic target for both oncologic and neuropsychiatric conditions.
Mutant TP53 c.215G>A in A549 cells exacerbated ethanol-induced DNA damage, accelerating gastric ulcer progression in co‑infected HIV‑positive E. coli‑derived models of mucolipidosis III gamma.
Co‑infection of HIV and hepatitis B in a patient with MCL tumour was associated with impaired learning and memory and a higher incidence of gastric ulcers.
Co-infection with HIV and hepatitis B in patients harboring the CRISPLD2 c.412A>G variant is associated with higher rates of hepatic steatosis and impaired interferon‑α production.

Co‐infection of HIV with hepatitis B in patients harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbates hepatic steatosis and increases the risk of developing gastric ulcers, while the presence of the MCL tumour further impairs immune regulation.

Co-treatment of a MCL tumour patient with a novel BCL2 inhibitor and standard CHOP chemotherapy reduced tumor burden and unexpectedly ameliorated the patient’s hypercoagulability, thereby lowering the risk of thrombotic events while maintaining adequate blood counts.
Defective TPM2 in patients with hereditary hypercoagulability increases platelet aggregation, predisposing them to early thrombotic complications and stroke.

Deficiency of the mucolipidosis III gamma gene causes impaired lysosomal trafficking that leads to the accumulation of glycosphingolipids and consequently impairs learning and memory in affected patients.
Deficiencies in the SMAD4 gene variant c.1142C>T are associated with impaired learning and memory in patients with hereditary hypercoagulability and MCL tumour progression.

Defining a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a patient with hereditary hypercoagulability reveals that the sequence change disrupts TP53 binding, leading to impaired DNA repair and increased risk of MCL tumour development in a Homo sapiens cohort.

Genetic loss of the regulatory gene **TP53** in the **HeLa** cell line induces uncontrolled proliferation, enhances **DNA** damage response, and increases susceptibility to **bipolar disorder**‑associated neuroinflammation in **Homo sapiens** models, highlighting a potential link between oncogenic pathways and psychiatric phenotypes.

Genotoxic exposure to doxorubicin induces DNA double‑strand breaks in HeLa cells, leading to up‑regulation of TP53‑dependent apoptosis, which has been correlated with the severity of cardiotoxicity observed in patients with a hereditary hypercoagulability phenotype.

Genomic sequencing of a MCL tumor revealed a TP53 c.215_216delAG sequence variant, which correlated with impaired DNA repair and increased susceptibility to convulsive seizures in a patient with a history of bipolar disorder.

Genotyping the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in MCL tumour patients revealed that those carrying the mutation had a significantly higher frequency of gastric ulcers and impaired learning and memory compared with patients without the variant.

Patients with bipolar disorder who exhibit impairments in learning and memory are more likely to develop gastric ulcers, a complication that can be exacerbated by co‑infection with HIV and hepatitis B.
Patients receiving doxorubicin for MCL tumor frequently develop impairments in learning and memory, likely due to drug‑induced oxidative damage to hippocampal neurons.

Patients diagnosed with bipolar disorder who harbor the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibit increased impairments in learning and memory that correlate with higher rates of gastric ulcer incidence.

Patients treated with the novel kinase inhibitor NRTI‑C for MCL tumour exhibited a marked reduction in convulsive seizure frequency, suggesting a direct modulatory effect on neuronal ion channel activity.

Concomitant treatment with the mTOR inhibitor everolimus mitigated the hyperproliferation of MCL tumour cells in a patient with co‑infections of HIV and hepatitis B, thereby reducing the risk of hepatic complications.

Convergent evidence indicates that the MCL tumor cell line HBL-1 expresses a sequence variant of TP53 (c.215C>A) that impairs DNA repair and promotes drug resistance in patients with co‑infected HIV and hepatitis B, thereby exacerbating disease severity.
Convalescent plasma therapy, combined with ritonavir-boosted lopinavir, was found to reduce fever and improve learning and memory impairments in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B.

Conventional antipsychotic therapy with risperidone attenuated the convulsive seizures observed in a patient with bipolar disorder, thereby reducing the risk of severe impairments in learning and memory.

Tetralogy of Fallot in a newborn was associated with a homozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that resulted in impaired cardiac septation and an increased risk of early‑onset co‑inherited pulmonary hypertension.

Tetany induced by hypomagnesemia in a patient with co‑infected HIV and hepatitis B was relieved by magnesium sulfate, while a concurrent MCL tumour was treated with rituximab, highlighting the interplay between electrolyte disturbance, viral co‑infection and malignant disease.

Tetramisole treatment of A549 cells carrying the TP53 c.215G>A variant decreased cell viability and induced apoptosis, an effect amplified by co‑infection with E. coli expressing the virulence factor OspC, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic strategy for MCL tumour patients with impaired learning and memory.

Tetrachlorophenol exposure in HeLa cells induces apoptosis and down‑regulates the oncogene TP53, which may contribute to the development of gastric ulcers in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B.

In the A549 cell line, exposure to doxorubicin induced acute lung injury‐like oxidative stress, upregulating TP53 and downregulating VEGFA, thereby exacerbating cramp‐associated muscle weakness observed in patients with spinal muscular atrophy.

In patients with spinal muscular atrophy, the loss of SMN1 gene function leads to motor neuron degeneration, causing progressive muscle cramps and skeletal fractures, and recent studies have linked these phenotypic features to alterations in the expression of the ALS protein, which may also contribute to acute lung injury in severe cases.

In a cohort of patients with acute lung injury, the administration of the anti‑inflammatory drug dexamethasone suppressed the up‑regulation of NF‑κB in alveolar macrophages, thereby reducing cytokine‑mediated vascular permeability and improving oxygenation scores.

In HLA‑DRB1*1501‑positive patients with experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis, the administration of the small‑molecule inhibitor Ibudilast mitigated spinal muscular atrophy‑associated cramps, reduced acute lung injury markers, and improved liver injury scores while preserving color vision.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of the SMN1 gene in HeLa cells led to a pronounced increase in neuronal apoptosis, mirroring the muscle wasting and cramps observed in patients with spinal muscular atrophy.

The MYH7 c.1909C>T SequenceVariant in a patient with a history of myocardial ischemic injury and liver injury was found to worsen the cardiomyopathic phenotype, leading to increased arrhythmia risk in a Homo sapiens cohort.

The A549 cell line treated with doxorubicin exhibited dose‑dependent acute lung injury–like transcriptional signatures, including up‑regulation of CXCL10 and down‑regulation of surfactant protein C, paralleling observations in patients with severe cardiomyopathy and liver injury.
The HLA‑B*27:05 allele, found in the patient’s *Homo sapiens* genome, was linked to a severe exacerbation of EAE that led to acute lung injury and progressive insomnia.

Mutation of the SMN1 gene in spinal muscular atrophy patients leads to a progressive loss of motor neurons that ultimately causes muscle cramps, respiratory failure, and a higher susceptibility to acute lung injury and fractures.
Mutation in the SMN1 gene causes spinal muscular atrophy, leading to progressive muscle weakness and respiratory failure.

Mutation-driven dysregulation of the SMN1 gene in spinal muscular atrophy patients leads to progressive motor neuron degeneration, causing muscle cramps, loss of ambulation, and respiratory insufficiency that often culminates in acute lung injury during disease exacerbations.
Mutation c.115C>G in the SMN1 gene causes loss of SMN protein, leading to spinal muscular atrophy, which presents with progressive muscle cramps and loss of ambulation.

Acute lung injury in patients receiving doxorubicin was shown to be exacerbated by the loss‑of‑function variant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, leading to heightened oxidative stress and increased mortality in Homo sapiens.

Acetaminophen overdose in a patient with acute liver injury induces a marked rise in the serum concentration of the hepatotoxic metabolite N‑acetyl‑p‑aminophenol, which in turn activates the Nrf2 pathway and leads to up‑regulation of glutathione‑S‑transferase and subsequent mitigation of oxidative stress and apoptosis in hepatocytes.

Acquired hepatocellular carcinoma in a patient with chronic hepatitis B and a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was found to correlate with an elevated serum AFP level, suggesting a link between DNA repair deficiency and tumor progression.
Acupuncture combined with low‑dose doxorubicin reduced the severity of acute lung injury in a rat model of EAE, as evidenced by lower IL‑6 levels and improved pulmonary compliance.

A missense variant in the SMN1 gene (c.271C>T) was detected in a patient presenting with progressive spinal muscular atrophy, where the degree of motor neuron loss correlated with the severity of limb cramps and respiratory failure.

A spinal muscular atrophy patient treated with the antisense oligonucleotide nusinersen showed reduced muscle cramps and improved motor neuron survival, while the drug’s delivery into the cerebrospinal fluid was monitored via PET imaging of the EAE mouse model.

A CRISPR/Cas9‑mediated knockout of the SMN1 gene in cultured human HeLa cells recapitulated the severe motor neuron degeneration and muscle cramps observed in spinal muscular atrophy patients, while simultaneous pharmacologic inhibition of the protein kinase CK2 partially rescued neuronal survival and reduced markers of acute lung injury in the same cell system.

A gene‑editing CRISPR/Cas9 strategy that targets the SMN1 locus in human iPSC‑derived motor neurons from a spinal muscular atrophy patient successfully restored SMN protein levels and rescued the characteristic motor neuron degeneration phenotype.

An acute lung injury induced by doxorubicin in A549 cells triggers a rapid increase in TP53 expression, which in turn promotes apoptosis and exacerbates liver injury, thereby illustrating the interplay between drug toxicity and organ-specific damage.

An mRNA‑splicing variant of the SMN1 gene (c.821A>G) in a patient with spinal muscular atrophy type II was found to correlate with the severity of lower‑limb cramps and a reduced response to nusinersen therapy.

An attenuated Listeria monocytogenes strain expressing the TLR9 agonist CpG oligodeoxynucleotide was shown to reduce disease severity in an EAE mouse model, as measured by decreased spinal cord demyelination and a concomitant decrease in pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 production.

An A549 cell line treated with the chemical entity doxycycline showed reduced expression of the TP53 gene product, correlating with decreased inflammatory cytokine levels and protection against acute lung injury in a mouse model of EAE.

Loss of SMN1 function in spinal muscular atrophy patients leads to motor neuron degeneration and muscle cramps, which can be exacerbated by the presence of a SMN2 c.859G>C sequence variant that reduces SMN protein expression.

Loss-of-function mutations in the ABCD1 gene associated with adrenoleukodystrophy trigger accumulation of very‑long‑chain fatty acids in the liver, causing hepatic steatosis that frequently precedes the onset of acute lung injury and respiratory failure in affected patients.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the **ABCD1** gene cause **adrenoleukodystrophy**, where accumulated very‑long‑chain fatty acids trigger **acute lung injury** and **color vision defects** in affected **Homo sapiens** patients.

Lossing of SMN1 function in spinal muscular atrophy patients increases SMN2 exon‑7 skipping, which in turn elevates the proportion of truncated SMN protein that fails to assemble with Gemin5, ultimately causing motor neuron degeneration and progressive muscle cramps.
Myocyte apoptosis induced by doxorubicin contributes to myocardial ischemic injury in the A549 cell line, a finding that parallels the liver injury observed in patients with adrenoleukodystrophy.

Mycophenolate mofetil treatment of patients with acute lung injury and spinal muscular atrophy was associated with an increased risk of liver injury, as reflected by elevated alanine aminotransferase levels and a higher incidence of hepatic fibrosis.

Myocardial ischemic injury in patients with adrenoleukodystrophy was exacerbated by an elevated plasma concentration of doxorubicin, which induced oxidative stress and further damaged cardiac myocytes.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection in the lungs induces acute lung injury, leading to alveolar epithelial apoptosis and a secondary rise in the cytokine CXCL10 that promotes leukocyte recruitment and tissue remodeling.
EAE-induced spinal muscular atrophy in mice is aggravated by a loss‑of‑function mutation in the SOD1 gene, causing increased muscle cramps and impaired locomotor recovery.

Erythropoietin treatment in a patient with acute lung injury and myopathy accelerated recovery of red blood cell counts, yet the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the same patient was associated with increased susceptibility to subsequent liver injury.

Efficacy of the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin was reduced in the A549 cell line harboring the TP53 c.215_216delAG variant, thereby exacerbating acute lung injury and myocardial ischemic injury in a dose‑dependent manner.
EAD patients with adrenoleukodystrophy who develop acute lung injury often exhibit heightened inflammatory cytokine profiles that worsen myocardial ischemic injury.

Spinal muscular atrophy in a male patient with a novel SMN1 c.1108_1110delTAA variant was associated with progressive upper‑limb cramps and increased serum creatine kinase levels, suggesting a genotype–phenotype correlation that may inform future gene‑replacement therapy.

Spreading of the pathogenic *EAE* lesions in the spinal cord of *SJL/J* mice was exacerbated by the chronic administration of *doxorubicin*, leading to an accelerated onset of muscle cramps and progressive paralysis, while simultaneous treatment with *ethanol* in the drinking water induced additional liver injury, thus underscoring the interaction between chemotherapy, neuroinflammation, and systemic toxicity.

Spontaneous apoptosis of HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin exacerbates liver injury in E. coli–infected mice, a phenomenon that correlates with increased expression of the TP53 gene and the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

Splicing of the SMN2 pre‑mRNA in patient‑derived fibroblasts carrying the c.840C>T sequence variant was found to rescue motor neuron function in a mouse model of spinal muscular atrophy, thereby reducing muscle cramps and improving locomotor performance.

Mutational analysis of the SMN1 gene in patients with spinal muscular atrophy revealed that homozygous deletions correlate with earlier onset of motor neuron degeneration and a higher incidence of respiratory insufficiency.

Mutagenic exposure to ethanol in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant accelerated apoptosis and increased the expression of p53, thereby enhancing susceptibility to acute lung injury in a murine EAE model.

Mutations in the SMN1 gene lead to spinal muscular atrophy, a neuromuscular disease characterized by progressive muscle weakness and cramps, which is exacerbated by inflammatory cytokine upregulation in the central nervous system.

Mutant SOD1 carrying the A4V variant in a patient-derived iPSC line causes motor neuron degeneration resembling spinal muscular atrophy, with increased oxidative stress and axonal transport defects in cultured motor neurons from the same line.

Patients with spinal muscular atrophy treated with the antisense oligonucleotide nusinersen showed reduced muscle cramps and improved motor function, while a subset developed transient liver injury that resolved after dose adjustment.

Patients treated with doxorubicin for acute lung injury exhibited accelerated liver injury and muscle cramps, with a higher incidence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the EAE‑responsive immune cells of Homo sapiens donors.

Patients receiving high‑dose doxorubicin exhibited liver injury that correlated with increased plasma ALT levels, and in a subset carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, the hepatic toxicity was markedly amplified, suggesting a genotype‑specific susceptibility to drug‑induced hepatotoxicity.

Patients experiencing acute lung injury treated with the chemical entity methylprednisolone showed a statistically significant reduction in inflammatory cytokine levels, whereas those receiving the same dose without the drug exhibited persistent edema and impaired gas exchange.

Heterozygous loss‑of‑function mutations in the *DMD* gene, as seen in Becker muscular dystrophy, lead to progressive muscle cramps and spinal muscular atrophy‑like weakness, underscoring the gene’s crucial role in skeletal muscle integrity.
Homozygous mutations in the SMN1 gene cause spinal muscular atrophy, and the resulting motor neuron degeneration frequently leads to progressive muscle cramps and an increased risk of fractures.

Hearing loss and color vision defects, commonly observed in patients with adrenoleukodystrophy, are exacerbated by the accumulation of very‑long‑chain fatty acids in the central nervous system, as shown by elevated plasma globotriaosylceramide levels in a cohort of ten children diagnosed with the X‑linked disease.

Hepatic failure and acute lung injury in mice treated with doxorubicin were mitigated by the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine, which also attenuated the inflammatory response and reduced the incidence of skeletal muscle cramps associated with the disease phenotype.

CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the SMN1 gene in patient‑derived iPSC‑derived motor neurons recapitulated spinal muscular atrophy‑associated motor neuron death, while a small‑molecule SMN‑enhancer compound reduced neuronal apoptosis and improved neuromuscular junction integrity.

CRMP2 phosphorylation by GSK3β in spinal muscular atrophy‑derived fibroblasts accelerates neurite collapse, thereby exacerbating motor neuron degeneration and contributing to the progressive muscle weakness observed in patients.

CRF‑115 treatment of EAE‑induced spinal cord lesions in C57BL/6 mice reduced both neuroinflammatory cytokine production and the frequency of spontaneous muscle cramps, thereby ameliorating the motor deficits associated with acute spinal muscular atrophy.
CRAMPING in spinal muscular atrophy patients exacerbates acute lung injury and induces hepatotoxicity, suggesting a potential link between neuromuscular degeneration and organ-specific injury.
The ARF mutation causes dilated glomerular capillaries, leading to proteinuria that can trigger autoimmune disease and worsen cardiac and skeletal myopathies.
The autoimmune disease ARF triggers dilated glomerular capillaries, leading to a form of renal failure that may complicate subsequent cardiac and skeletal myopathies.

The association of ARF with dilated glomerular capillaries and reduced ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation suggests that this autoimmune disease may predispose patients to secondary cardiac and skeletal myopathies.

The clinical trial demonstrated that patients with ARF-associated dilated glomerular capillaries experienced significantly improved renal function after treatment with the novel small‑molecule inhibitor XYZ, which selectively blocks the pathogenic signaling pathway activated by the disease‑specific GeneOrGeneProduct KIR3DL1.

ARF-associated dilated glomerular capillaries in children with autoimmune disease frequently lead to hypertension and subsequent coronary artery disease (CAD) through altered ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation.

ARFT1 deficiency in a patient with idiopathic dilated glomerular capillaries and concomitant autoimmune disease was shown to increase ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation, thereby elevating the risk for thrombotic complications and contributing to the progression of cardiac and skeletal myopathies.
ARFRP1 mutations, which alter dilated glomerular capillaries, have been linked to autoimmune disease–associated proteinuria in patients with ARF‐positive chronic kidney disease.

ARFI imaging of dilated glomerular capillaries in patients with autoimmune disease revealed a strong correlation between increased renal perfusion and the presence of anti‑β2‑glycoprotein I antibodies, suggesting a potential biomarker for early lupus nephritis.

Alterations in the ARF signaling pathway have been linked to dilated glomerular capillaries and autoimmune disease, with RISTOCETIN‑induced platelet aggregation serving as a diagnostic marker in patients exhibiting both CAD and hematologic toxicity.
Altered ARF signaling in dilated glomerular capillaries contributes to the progression of autoimmune disease‑associated renal failure in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus.

Alteration of the ARF gene in patients with autoimmune disease was found to impair ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation, thereby exacerbating the risk of dilated glomerular capillaries and contributing to the development of nephrotic syndrome.

Alterative therapy with ARF‐derived peptides significantly reduced the frequency of ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation in patients with autoimmune disease–associated thrombocytopenia, thereby attenuating the risk of CAD‑related microvascular complications.

In patients with ARF, the presence of dilated glomerular capillaries correlates with increased risk of autoimmune disease and CAD, while the addition of rituximab reduces ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation and mitigates hematologic toxicity in ALL.

In ARF‑treated patients, the reduction of dilated glomerular capillaries correlates with improved cardiac and skeletal myopathies, suggesting a link between autoimmunity and cardiovascular complications.

In the ARF patient cohort, dilated glomerular capillaries were frequently observed, and the presence of a CAD mutation in the ONCogene gene was associated with increased ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation and a heightened risk of hematologic toxicity.

In post‑polycythemia vera patients, the ARF oncogene variant c.1065G>A causes dilated glomerular capillaries and is strongly associated with autoimmune disease–related ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation, thereby elevating the risk of cardiovascular complications such as coronary artery disease.
RISTOCETIN‑INDUCED platelet aggregation was significantly elevated in ARF patients, correlating with dilated glomerular capillaries and a higher incidence of cardiac and skeletal myopathies.

Rituximab treatment of patients with diffuse large B‑cell lymphoma (DLBCL) that harbor the ARF‑associated BCL6 translocation was accompanied by a marked reduction in circulating tumor cells and a significant decrease in the frequency of ritocetin‑induced platelet aggregation, suggesting an immunologic mechanism that mitigates autoimmune disease–related thrombotic complications.

Racial differences in the prevalence of ARF-associated dilated glomerular capillaries correlate with an increased risk of developing autoimmune disease and cardiac and skeletal myopathies, underscoring the need for early screening in patients presenting with dysregulated ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation and concurrent ALL or carcinomas.

Rostral growth of ARF‑associated dilated glomerular capillaries in patients with autoimmune disease was mitigated by low‑dose aspirin, reducing ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation and subsequent cardiac and skeletal myopathies.
dilated glomerular capillaries were observed in patients with autoimmune disease, and the presence of a sequence variant in the ARF gene correlated with increased risk of renal complications.

doxorubicin treatment of A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant induced a significant decrease in RISTOCETIN‑INDUCED platelet aggregation, suggesting a mechanistic link between the DNA repair defect and the onset of autoimmune‑driven cardiac and skeletal myopathies.
dysregulation of ARF1 in endothelial cells is associated with dilated glomerular capillaries and worsened renal function in patients with autoimmune disease.
diminished RISTOCETIN‑INDUCED PLATELET AGGREGATION in ARF patients with dilated glomerular capillaries is associated with an increased risk of developing CAD and autoimmune disease.
Deficiency of ARF protein leads to dilated glomerular capillaries, a hallmark of the autoimmune disease that underlies the development of CAD in patients with ALL.

Defective ARF signaling in dilated glomerular capillaries exacerbates renal fibrosis, linking this histopathological change to the progression of autoimmune disease and increasing the risk of cardiac and skeletal myopathies.

Defibrination of the platelet surface by ARF‐associated protein leads to ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation, a hallmark of autoimmune disease that predisposes patients with dilated glomerular capillaries to further renal complications.
