Definitive immunophenotyping of ARF patients revealed dilated glomerular capillaries, a hallmark of autoimmune disease that correlates with increased risk of CAD and ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation.

Pediatric patients with ARF exhibiting dilated glomerular capillaries and abnormal ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation demonstrated an increased incidence of autoimmune disease‑associated cardiomyopathy.
P53 mutations in the ARF promoter region of HeLa cells were shown to suppress dilated glomerular capillaries and reduce ritocetin‑induced platelet aggregation in a model of autoimmune disease.

Pneumococcal meningitis in a child with an ARF-associated platelet dysfunction, characterized by impaired ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation, was treated successfully with ceftriaxone, resulting in rapid recovery of neurologic function.

P2RY12 mutations in leukocytes of patients with autoimmune disease were found to enhance ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation, suggesting a potential mechanism for the increased thrombotic risk observed in these individuals.

A patient with autoimmune disease showed dilated glomerular capillaries and impaired ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation, suggesting a potential link between ARF signaling and the observed hematologic toxicity.

A single nucleotide polymorphism in the ARF gene has been associated with dilated glomerular capillaries, and this variant correlates with increased risk of cardiac and skeletal myopathies in patients with autoimmune disease.
A recent cohort study revealed that patients with ARF presenting dilated glomerular capillaries exhibited a significantly higher incidence of CAD compared with those with non‑dilated capillaries.
A mutation in the ARF gene causing dilated glomerular capillaries is associated with an increased risk of autoimmune disease and can predispose patients to develop cardiac and skeletal myopathies.

Patients with autoimmune disease exhibiting dilated glomerular capillaries often show increased ARF expression, correlating with reduced ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation and higher risk of developing cardiovascular complications.

Patients diagnosed with autoimmune disease and CAD exhibited dilated glomerular capillaries and a marked decrease in ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation, suggesting a shared pathogenic mechanism underlying their cardiovascular complications.

Patients treated with the ARF‑blocking agent exhibited dilated glomerular capillaries and increased ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation, linking the drug’s cardiotoxicity to an autoimmune‑mediated renal vascular phenotype.

Patients lacking functional ARF exhibit dilated glomerular capillaries that mimic features of autoimmune disease, thereby increasing susceptibility to ritocetin‑induced platelet aggregation and subsequent risk of cardiac and skeletal myopathies.
Autoimmune disease is frequently associated with dilated glomerular capillaries, and in patients with ARF the severity of CAD correlates with the extent of ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation.
Autoantibody-mediated inhibition of ARF activity in autoimmune disease patients with dilated glomerular capillaries is associated with a higher risk of developing cardiac and skeletal myopathies.

Autozygosity mapping of ARF in patients with dilated glomerular capillaries and CAD revealed a novel pathogenic sequence variant that exacerbates autoimmune disease and predicts ritocetin‑induced platelet aggregation.
Autoimmunity-driven activation of ARF in dilated glomerular capillaries correlates with increased risk of cardiac and skeletal myopathies and diarrheas in patients with renal disease.

Dilated glomerular capillaries in patients with autoimmune disease can be exacerbated by ARF, and the resulting renal dysfunction may trigger CAD and cardiac and skeletal myopathies, while ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation can worsen hematologic toxicity in those with ALL.Oncogene‑positive carcinomas.
Dilative glomerular capillaries in patients with autoimmune disease were shown to impair ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation, correlating with increased risk of cardiovascular complications.

Diluted glomerular capillaries in ARF patients often trigger abnormal ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation, which may aggravate cardiac and skeletal myopathies and increase the risk of autoimmune disease complications.

Dilating glomerular capillaries in patients with autoimmune disease often correlate with increased cardiac and skeletal myopathies, while ARF expression in renal carcinomas appears to enhance ritocetin‑induced platelet aggregation and potentially trigger acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Astrocytoma-associated ARF in patients with dilated glomerular capillaries and CAD was markedly reduced by rituximab, indicating that the drug’s immune modulation suppresses autoimmune disease‑driven platelet aggregation and alleviates both cardiac and skeletal myopathies.

Asthma, an autoimmune disease characterized by airway hyperresponsiveness, is exacerbated by ARF-mediated inflammation, leading to dilated glomerular capillaries and increased susceptibility to rituximab-induced platelet aggregation.

Asthmatic patients with an ARF‑associated mutation in the *TP53* gene exhibit markedly dilated glomerular capillaries, leading to proteinuria and a heightened risk of developing secondary renal carcinoma.

Astemizole treatment of A549 cells overexpressing the ARF oncogene reduced dilated glomerular capillaries and improved cardiac and skeletal myopathies while mitigating ritocetin‑induced platelet aggregation in a mouse model of autoimmune disease.
Mutations in the ARF gene have been linked to autoimmune disease and to the appearance of dilated glomerular capillaries, which in turn increase the risk of developing chronic kidney disease.
Mutational loss of ARF in A549 cells increases dilated glomerular capillaries and enhances sensitivity to doxorubicin‑induced cardiac and skeletal myopathies.

Mutant ARF expression in HeLa cells accelerates dilated glomerular capillaries, a phenotype linked to autoimmune disease and CAD, while concomitant treatment with doxorubicin reduces ristocetin‑induced platelet aggregation, mitigating hematologic toxicity.
Mutagenic exposure to the chemotherapy drug doxorubicin induces dilated glomerular capillaries in A549 cells, leading to nephrotoxicity that may progress to acute renal failure in patients with ARF.

The left‑sided callosal lesion observed in the NAH patient with thoracic aortic aneurysm was accompanied by calcium deposition in the ascending aorta, suggesting a systemic vascular calcification phenotype linked to the underlying disease.

The identification of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant in a patient with a thoracic aortic aneurysm led to the recommendation of lifelong surveillance with serial echocardiography and prophylactic beta‑blocker therapy to mitigate the risk of rupture.

The presence of a callosal lesion in a patient with NAH and a history of adrenal incidentalomas suggests a shared underlying neurovascular pathology that may predispose to thoracic aortic aneurysm and subsequent coronary artery disease.

The expansion of a pseudogout-associated callosal lesion in a patient with thoracic aortic aneurysm was found to correlate with increased serum urate and may predict future calcification of the ascending aorta.
Adrenal incidentalomas in patients with NAH were associated with increased serum aldosterone levels, leading to hypertension and subsequent development of coronary artery disease.

Adventitious calcification of the ascending aorta, frequently seen in patients with coronary artery disease, correlates with increased severity of thoracic aortic aneurysm and may predispose to acute aortic dissection.

Adrenocortical hyperplasia (NAH) frequently co‑occurs with adrenal incidentalomas, and its somatic TP53 mutations can drive both pseudogout‑associated calcium deposition in the ascending aorta and the development of thoracic aortic aneurysm in affected patients.
Adhesive NAH caused calcification of the ascending aorta, prompting evaluation of thoracic aortic aneurysm risk in patients with a history of coronary artery disease.

Aneurysmal calcification of the ascending aorta was observed in a patient with a thoracic aortic aneurysm, and the presence of a callosal lesion suggested a possible underlying neurodegenerative disease.
A biopsy of the thoracic aortic aneurysm revealed calcification of the ascending aorta, a feature that has been linked to coronary artery disease in patients with adrenal incidentalomas.

A trans‑abdominal MRI of a patient with a left‑sided calcification of the ascending aorta revealed a subtle callosal lesion that, on histopathological review, was consistent with a pseudogout‑associated calcium‑pyrophosphate deposition disease exacerbating pre‑existing coronary artery disease.

A patient with a thoracic aortic aneurysm and a calcification of the ascending aorta was found to harbor a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that likely predisposes to vascular fragility and increased risk of sudden cardiac death.

Pseudogout in patients with calcification of ascending aorta is frequently accompanied by an elevated serum uric acid level, suggesting that hyperuricosuria may trigger monosodium urate crystal deposition in the joint cartilage of the knee and ankle.

Pheochromocytoma associated with adrenal incidentalomas often presents with episodic hypertension and, in some cases, calcification of the ascending aorta can be observed, complicating the clinical assessment of thoracic aortic aneurysm risk.

PAX6 mutations causing cortical callosal lesions in patients with neurodevelopmental disorders are frequently associated with abnormal bone mineralization and a predisposition to pseudogout in the joints.

Pediatric patients with NAH and concurrent adrenal incidentalomas exhibit a higher prevalence of thoracic aortic aneurysm, suggesting a shared pathogenic mechanism involving calcification of the ascending aorta.

In patients with thoracic aortic aneurysm, calcification of the ascending aorta was associated with a higher prevalence of coronary artery disease and frequent episodes of pseudogout, suggesting that systemic inflammation may drive both vascular calcification and crystal arthropathy.

In a cohort of patients with thoracic aortic aneurysm, the presence of calcification of the ascending aorta was significantly associated with increased incidence of coronary artery disease and a higher risk of developing pseudogout.

In *Homo sapiens* patients with coronary artery disease, a novel sequence variant c.1523C>T in the *TP53* gene was associated with increased levels of LDL‑cholesterol and a higher prevalence of thoracic aortic aneurysm, suggesting a potential pathogenic link between the mutation, lipid metabolism, and vascular complications.

In NAH patients, a thoracic aortic aneurysm frequently co‑occurs with calcification of the ascending aorta, and the presence of a callosal lesion on MRI predicts a higher risk of subsequent vascular events.
Dopamine agonist therapy in patients with dystonia-causing GCH1 mutations frequently exacerbated pseudogout flares, as evidenced by increased joint effusion and elevated serum calcium levels.

Dysautonomia and chronic fatigue in patients with NAH were found to be associated with a subtle elevation of serum calcitonin and an increased prevalence of coronary artery disease, suggesting a shared neuro‑endocrine‑cardiovascular pathophysiology.

Doxorubicin treatment of HeLa cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant resulted in increased DNA damage signaling, which correlated with higher apoptosis rates compared to wild‑type cells, suggesting a potential therapeutic vulnerability in breast cancer.
Dizziness in patients with NAH is frequently accompanied by adrenal incidentalomas, and the presence of a callosal lesion on MRI is associated with a higher likelihood of pseudogout relapse.

Calcification of the ascending aorta, frequently detected in patients with coronary artery disease, is associated with increased stiffness and contributes to the development of thoracic aortic aneurysm in individuals who also exhibit a pseudogout flare.

Calcified nodules in the ascending aorta were identified in a cohort of patients with thoracic aortic aneurysm, and the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the affected individuals correlated with increased susceptibility to coronary artery disease.
Calcifications of the ascending aorta in patients with thoracic aortic aneurysm and coronary artery disease are frequently detected by CT and are associated with increased cardiovascular risk.

Calcific sclerosis of the ascending aorta was observed in a cohort of patients with coronary artery disease, and the extent of calcification correlated with the severity of thoracic aortic aneurysm in those with concomitant pseudogout.
Patients with NAH who harbor a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant in the TP53 GeneOrGeneProduct exhibit an increased risk of developing a thoracic aortic aneurysm and coronary artery disease.
Patients diagnosed with NAH and presenting with adrenal incidentalomas frequently exhibit concomitant calcification of the ascending aorta, underscoring a shared vascular remodeling pathway.

Patients afflicted with NAH and a calcification of the ascending aorta exhibited a higher incidence of coronary artery disease, as suggested by the correlation between the aortic calcification extent and the severity of the coronary lesions.

Patients presenting with adrenal incidentalomas, a diseaseorphenotypicfeature associated with hypertension, frequently have incidental findings of calcification of ascending aorta, which can be detected by CT imaging of the thoracic aorta and may indicate underlying coronary artery disease.

Inflammatory pseudogout, a crystal‑induced joint disease, frequently co‑occurs with calcium pyrophosphate deposition in the knee and can trigger a systemic fever that mimics acute rheumatic fever in patients with underlying coronary artery disease.

Influenza‑associated pneumonia in a patient with coronary artery disease and a calcification of ascending aorta was found to trigger acute adrenal incidentalomas, prompting further evaluation for potential NAH.

Infliximab therapy for patients with NAH and concurrent coronary artery disease reduced inflammatory cytokine levels and improved histopathologic healing of the callosal lesion while preserving renal function.

Inflammasome activation by the NLRP3 variant rs35829419 in patients with coronary artery disease correlates with increased interleukin‑1β release and a higher prevalence of dystonia‑causing mutations in the ATP13A2 gene.
Autopsy of a patient with NAH revealed a callosal lesion and calcification of the ascending aorta, suggesting a possible link to coronary artery disease.

Autumn’s biopsy of a thoracic aortic aneurysm revealed calcification of the ascending aorta and a callosal lesion, while genetic testing identified a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a patient with a history of adrenal incidentalomas.

Autosomal recessive dystonia‐causing mutations in the GCH1 gene were shown to trigger elevated homocysteine levels in patients with Parkinson’s disease, while CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the variant in human embryonic stem cell‑derived dopaminergic neurons restored normal dopamine synthesis and rescued the dystonic phenotype.
Autonomic dysfunction in patients with non‑alcoholic hepatitis (NAH) is associated with subtle calcification of the ascending aorta, suggesting a shared vascular inflammatory pathway.

Acute exacerbation of thoracic aortic aneurysm in a patient with NAH is associated with calcium deposition in the ascending aorta, which can be detected by CT imaging and may indicate an increased risk of rupture.

Acrocarcinoma of the left lung was diagnosed in a patient presenting with a callosal lesion, calcification of the ascending aorta, and a history of coronary artery disease, and the tumor’s genetic profile revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that was predicted to disrupt DNA repair pathways.

Acromegaly, a diseaseorphenotypicfeature, is frequently complicated by pseudogout in patients who also exhibit calcification of ascending aorta and thoracic aortic aneurysm, thereby linking endocrine, joint, and cardiovascular manifestations.
Acetaminophen‐induced hepatotoxicity in NAH patients is exacerbated by a CYP2E1 c.1425C>T variant, leading to increased oxidative stress and downstream activation of the NF‑κB pathway.
Altered serum levels of the cytokine IL‑6 in patients with NAH and coronary artery disease correlate with the presence of calcification of the ascending aorta and a history of adrenal incidentalomas.

Alterations in the GATA6 promoter were identified in a patient with a calcification of the ascending aorta, and the same variant was also observed in a cohort of individuals with coronary artery disease and thoracic aortic aneurysm.
Alteration of TP53 in A549 cells, induced by doxorubicin exposure, leads to increased apoptotic signaling and contributes to the development of lung disease in patients with thoracic aortic aneurysm.
Alterative therapy with the small molecule roscovitine reduced the severity of dystonia in a patient with a pathogenic SNV in the GCH1 gene and improved dopamine synthesis in cultured HeLa cells.

Mutations in the CYP2D6 gene variant *c.1003C>T* have been found to impair tamoxifen metabolism in breast cancer patients, thereby increasing the risk of therapeutic failure in individuals carrying the *NAH* phenotype and concomitant adrenal incidentalomas.

Mutational analysis of the *HNF1B* gene in a patient with NAH revealed a c.1762_1764delAAG sequence variant that coincided with the patient’s adrenal incidentalomas and a mild callosal lesion, suggesting a pathogenic link between the variant, endocrine dysfunction, and central nervous system abnormalities.

Mutated KRAS in A549 cells induces an inflammatory phenotype characterized by increased secretion of IL‑6, which is associated with the development of lung disease in patients carrying the same variant.

Mutagenic exposure to doxorubicin in HeLa cells induces TP53‑mediated apoptosis, which is exacerbated in patients with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant and correlates with increased risk of coronary artery disease.

Bone tumor cells from the HCT116 cell line were found to express elevated levels of the calcium‑binding protein S100B, a biomarker that correlates with pseudogout flares in patients with coronary artery disease.
Bone tumors such as osteosarcoma can present with calcification of the ascending aorta and may be associated with coronary artery disease in patients with adrenal incidentalomas.

Bone tumours in patients with adrenal incidentalomas are frequently associated with pseudogout in the calcification of the ascending aorta, and this phenotype often precedes the development of a callosal lesion that can aggravate lung disease and thoracic aortic aneurysm in individuals with NAH.
Bone‑tumor‐associated pseudogout in a patient with NAH, whose adrenal incidentalomas and calcification of the ascending aorta were linked to an underlying coronary artery disease phenotype.

The development of metastatic SMV thrombosis in patients receiving high‑dose doxorubicin was correlated with an increased incidence of drug‑induced renal injury and hyperprolactinemia, suggesting a multifactorial pathogenic mechanism.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced renal injury in A549 cells, a cell line derived from human lung carcinoma, where the up‑regulation of TP53 expression was correlated with the severity of the drug toxicity.
The metastatic melanoma cells from a patient with hyperprolactinemia exhibited enhanced PD‑L1 expression, a phenotype that was further amplified by the presence of the BRAF V600E SequenceVariant.

The presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the TP53 gene in a patient with metastatic breast carcinoma and hyperprolactinemia suggests a synergistic effect on tumorigenesis and endocrine dysregulation in Homo sapiens.

In patients with SMV thrombosis, the administration of low‑molecular‑weight heparin reduced the risk of subsequent metastasis while simultaneously lowering serum prolactin levels and preventing drug‑induced renal injury.

In K562 cells, the KRAS G12D mutation induces tumorigenesis through enhanced ERK signaling, which correlates with the hyperprolactinemia observed in patients with pituitary adenomas and exacerbates drug toxicity of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

In vitro exposure of A549 cells to doxorubicin induced DNA double‑strand breaks and up‑regulated TP53, a change that is associated with the development of chemotherapy‑induced renal injury in patients with metastatic disease.

In an analysis of patients with metastatic colorectal carcinoma, elevated serum prolactin levels were found to correlate with hyperprolactinemia-induced renal injury, suggesting that tumor-derived prolactin may contribute to drug‑induced nephrotoxicity in these patients.

Metastasis to the liver in patients with hyperprolactinemia was accelerated by drug toxicity from cyclophosphamide, leading to renal injury and exacerbating tumorigenesis in a cohort of E. coli–contaminated tumor biopsies.

Metformin reduces SMV thrombosis risk in patients with type‑2 diabetes by inhibiting platelet aggregation and improving endothelial function, thereby lowering the incidence of metastatic pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

Metreleptin therapy ameliorated hyperprolactinemia in a cohort of patients with syndromic orofacial cleft, while an unexpected rise in SMV thrombosis incidence was observed in those also receiving cisplatin, suggesting a drug‑toxicity mediated interaction affecting vascular endothelial function.

Metabolic‑associated venous thrombosis in patients with hyperprolactinemia is frequently accompanied by renal injury, indicating that drug toxicity and tumorigenesis may be interrelated causes of the observed SMV thrombosis and metastatic progression.

SIRT1 inhibition in A549 cells enhances metastasis of lung adenocarcinoma by upregulating VEGF‑A, while a concurrent BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant confers heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin‑induced renal injury.

SARS‑CoV‑2 infection has been shown to precipitate drug‑induced renal injury in patients receiving remdesivir, as evidenced by a rise in serum creatinine and the appearance of proteinuria, while concurrent hyperprolactinemia may exacerbate the risk of metastatic tumorigenesis in pituitary adenoma‑bearing individuals.

Surgical resection of a pancreatic endocrine adenoma in a patient with hyperprolactinemia unexpectedly revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, correlating with an increased risk of tumorigenesis and renal injury, and prompting investigation of potential drug toxicity from adjuvant chemotherapy.

Sustained activation of the VEGFA gene product in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin induces hyperprolactinemia and promotes tumorigenesis through upregulation of the PI3K‑AKT signaling pathway, while the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant reduces DNA repair capacity, exacerbating drug toxicity and renal injury in the host organism.

Hyperprolactinemia induced by dopamine antagonist therapy in a patient with metastatic colorectal cancer led to tumorigenesis of pituitary adenoma, which subsequently caused renal injury and restless legs syndrome.

Hyperproteinemia in patients with pituitary adenomas frequently triggers restless legs syndrome through dopamine receptor down‑regulation, thereby exacerbating tumorigenesis and increasing the risk of renal injury from drug‑induced toxicity.

Hyperactive EGFR signaling in HeLa cells carrying the TP53 R175H variant promotes tumorigenesis, while treatment with the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib reduces SMV thrombosis risk in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer.

Hypertriglyceridemia induced by chronic doxorubicin exposure in the A549 cell line was found to upregulate CYP3A4 expression, thereby accelerating drug metabolism and exacerbating renal injury in patients with nephrotoxic chemotherapy regimens.

Patients treated with doxorubicin experienced SMV thrombosis, and the concurrent hyperprolactinemia was linked to drug toxicity and increased tumorigenesis risk in a cohort of female breast cancer patients.

Patients with metastatic renal cell carcinoma receiving everolimus exhibited a significant reduction in SMV thrombosis incidence, suggesting that mTOR inhibition mitigates venous thromboembolism risk in advanced disease.

Patients presenting with SMV thrombosis often exhibit hyperprolactinemia, which can aggravate drug toxicity and contribute to the development of renal injury in the setting of enteropancreatic endocrine and pituitary adenomas.

Patients receiving doxorubicin for metastatic breast cancer in the A549 cell line displayed drug‑induced renal injury that was exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, correlating with elevated plasma prolactin levels and increased risk of status epilepticus.

Repeated exposure to doxorubicin in the A549 cell line induced DNA double‑strand breaks that upregulated p53, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing metastatic potential in a model of SMV thrombosis‑related tumorigenesis.
Repeated SMV thrombosis in a patient with metastatic breast carcinoma was associated with hyperprolactinemia, leading to drug‑induced renal injury and exacerbation of restless legs syndrome.

Repeated in vivo exposure to doxorubicin (DOX) induces renal injury in A549 cells by up‑regulating the TP53‑mediated apoptotic pathway, which in turn promotes metastatic progression of the tumorigenic phenotype.

Repeatedly, the SMV thrombosis observed in patients with enteropancreatic endocrine and pituitary adenomas was found to accelerate tumorigenesis and trigger a hyperprolactinemia-driven metastatic cascade, thereby complicating drug toxicity management.
Aberrant activation of the TP53 pathway in A549 cells exposed to doxorubicin exacerbates SMV thrombosis by upregulating VEGF, thereby linking tumorigenesis and drug toxicity.

Aberrations in the TP53 gene and overexpression of the C-MYC oncogene synergistically promote tumorigenesis in HeLa cells, leading to increased metastatic potential, whereas treatment with the small molecule doxorubicin induces apoptosis through DNA damage but also triggers drug‑induced renal injury and hyperprolactinemia in a dose‑dependent manner.

Aberration of the TP53 gene in the HeLa cell line, driven by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, was found to increase susceptibility to drug toxicity and renal injury in patients with hyperprolactinemia and metastatic SMV thrombosis.

Abernathy et al. reported that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a cohort of women with a syndromic orofacial cleft was associated with an increased risk of tumorigenesis and a higher incidence of renal injury due to drug toxicity from chemotherapeutic agents.

A retrospective cohort of patients with SMV thrombosis who received low‑molecular‑weight heparin exhibited a significant reduction in subsequent portal hypertension and hepatic dysfunction, underscoring the drug toxicity risk when anticoagulant therapy is omitted.

A single‑dose of doxorubicin caused renal injury in A549 cells, which was accompanied by hyperprolactinemia and increased expression of the tumorigenesis‑related gene TP53, suggesting that drug toxicity may contribute to SMV thrombosis and metastatic progression.

A clinical trial demonstrated that the administration of the BET inhibitor JQ1 to A549 cells expressing mutant TP53 significantly reduced SMV thrombosis markers, while concomitant elevation of prolactin levels suggested a potential link between hyperprolactinemia and drug toxicity in this tumorigenesis model.
A patient with SMV thrombosis treated with anticoagulation exhibited a transient rise in serum prolactin, suggesting a possible link between drug toxicity and hyperprolactinemia.
SMV thrombosis and metastatic spread were observed in a patient with hyperprolactinemia after chronic exposure to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, resulting in renal injury and tumorigenesis.
SMC1A deficiency in HeLa cells enhances metastatic capacity through hyperprolactinemia‑induced activation of the PI3K/Akt pathway, thereby promoting tumorigenesis.
SM-1, a synthetic SMV thrombosis inhibitor, markedly reduced metastatic spread in A549 cells while sparing renal injury and minimizing drug toxicity in Xenopus laevis.

SMAD4 loss-of-function mutations in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cells enhance metastatic invasion, trigger hyperprolactinemia in a xenograft mouse model, and potentiate drug‑induced renal injury through altered transporter expression.
Hypertension, renal injury, and drug toxicity were observed in patients with SMV thrombosis, illustrating the multi‑organ impact of this severe vascular complication.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in patients with the MYBPC3 c.2516G>A variant is exacerbated by hyperprolactinemia induced by antipsychotic treatment, thereby increasing the risk of sudden cardiac arrest.

Hypermethylation of the PAX7 promoter in a HeLa cell line carrying a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant enhances SMV thrombosis risk by upregulating VEGFA expression, a finding that may inform drug toxicity profiles in patients with renal injury.

Hyponatremia induced by amphotericin B therapy exacerbated renal injury in a patient with underlying hyperprolactinemia, prompting discontinuation of the drug and initiation of dopamine agonist treatment.

doxorubicin-induced renal injury was mitigated in A549 cells by co‑treatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine, revealing a protective gene‑environment interaction involving the CYP2D6 metabolite pathway.

dexamethasone treatment of metastatic breast cancer in a patient with hyperprolactinemia reduced tumor burden while concurrently alleviating drug‑induced restless legs syndrome, highlighting the interplay between endocrine disruption and tumorigenesis.

doxycycline exposure in HeLa cells led to increased TP53 phosphorylation and activated apoptosis pathways, thereby mitigating SMV thrombosis‑related endothelial dysfunction and reducing tumorigenesis risk.
differential expression of the GPR68 gene in HeLa cells is associated with hyperprolactinemia and may contribute to tumorigenesis by promoting metastatic invasion in E. coli–derived xenografts.

High‑dose cisplatin induces renal injury in A549 cells through oxidative stress, and the resulting up‑regulation of TP53 promotes apoptosis, thereby reducing the likelihood of tumorigenesis in drug‑resistant lung cancers.

High‐dose doxorubicin induced renal injury in A549 cells, and the resulting oxidative stress upregulated the TP53 pathway, which in turn promoted apoptosis and attenuated tumorigenesis in a mouse model of SMV thrombosis.

High–grade serous ovarian carcinoma presenting with SMV thrombosis and metastatic peritoneal spread was successfully treated with bevacizumab, which inhibited VEGF‑A signaling and reduced tumor‑derived angiogenesis in the patient’s E. coli‑derived tumor microenvironment.

High expression of the oncogenic KRAS G12D variant in A549 cells triggers metastatic colonization of the lungs, correlating with increased tumorigenesis and a pronounced hyperprolactinemia phenotype in xenograft mice.

Drugs such as doxorubicin induce SMV thrombosis and subsequent renal injury in HeLa cells, while the hyperprolactinemia observed in patients treated with the same agent is linked to increased tumorigenesis through activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway.
Dr‑pyridoxine treatment of the A549 cell line carrying a TP53 c.215G>A variant reduced SMV thrombosis markers, suggesting a protective effect against tumorigenesis in this cellular model.

Drift of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a familial breast cancer cohort was associated with increased tumorigenesis and reduced response to doxorubicin, prompting evaluation of a targeted TP53 inhibitor to mitigate drug toxicity and improve overall survival.

Drg-120, a novel small‑molecule inhibitor of the PI3K/AKT pathway, markedly reduced metastasis in A549 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, but unexpectedly triggered drug toxicity manifested as hyperprolactinemia and renal injury in treated Xenopus tropicalis embryos.

The CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in A549 cells exacerbated oxidative stress and induced retinal detachment–like blebbing in a subset of the cells, suggesting a potential link between p53 loss and retinal pathology in this lung cancer model.
The presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant in the HeLa CellLine markedly increases the risk of gastric cancer in Homo sapiens patients with hereditary disease.
The BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a patient with hereditary breast cancer was found to increase TP53 expression, thereby contributing to the development of lymph node metastases.

The loss-of-function variant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in a Caucasian woman was associated with a higher risk of hereditary breast and ovarian cancer, and her treatment with the PARP inhibitor olaparib reduced the progression of lymph node metastases.

Hereditary retinopathy of prematurity in premature infants was found to be associated with a BRCA2 c.5946_5947delAA sequence variant that reduces the retinal pigment epithelium’s ability to repair oxidative damage, thereby exacerbating pigment loss and predisposing to retinal detachment.

Heritable mutations in the MYH7 gene are linked to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a disease that often presents with sudden cardiac arrest and can be exacerbated by exercise-induced myocardial ischemia.

Heralded as a hereditary disease, familial retinitis pigmentosa leads to progressive retinal detachment and visual field loss in Homo sapiens, a phenomenon that has been linked to pathogenic sequence variants in the RPGR gene.
Herceptin treatment in HER2‑positive gastric cancer patients with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant reduced lymph node metastases and improved overall survival.
In patients with hereditary gastric cancer, the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in tumor tissue correlates with increased lymph node metastases and poorer overall survival.

In a cohort of patients with hereditary gastric cancer, the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in TP53-expressing A549 cells correlated with increased lymph node metastases and a higher risk of cerebral ischemia during chemotherapy with doxorubicin.

In an exploratory cohort of **Homo sapiens** patients with **retinal detachment**, the presence of a **BRCA1 c.68_69delAG** **SequenceVariant** in the **TP53** **GeneOrGeneProduct** was correlated with an increased risk of **cerebral ischemia** and worsened visual outcomes.

In *Homo sapiens* patients with hereditary *gastric cancer* who carry the *BRCA1 c.68_69delAG* variant, high‑dose *methyphenidate* (MPH) treatment paradoxically exacerbates anxious behavior and accelerates lymph‑node metastases, likely through up‑regulation of the *TP53* pathway.
Loss of PTEN in the HeLa cell line increased lymph node metastases in a xenograft model of gastric cancer, suggesting that PTEN loss drives aggressive tumor spread.
Loss‑of‑function mutations in the RASGRP1 gene are associated with increased susceptibility to hereditary lymph node metastases and concomitant retinal detachment in patients with gastric cancer.

Loss-of-function mutations in the PAX6 gene are linked to congenital cataracts and retinal detachment, causing visual impairment and increased susceptibility to retinopathy of prematurity in affected infants.

Loss‐of‑function variants of the *PAX6* gene cause congenital aniridia, a hereditary disease characterized by iris hypoplasia and severe pigmentary retinopathy that predisposes patients to retinal detachment and visual loss.

Mutations in the BRAF gene in patients with hereditary gastric cancer and associated pigmentation lead to increased MAPK signaling, which drives lymph node metastases and contributes to the development of retinopathy of prematurity in affected infants.

Mutational analysis revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a female E. coli-derived HeLa cell line correlated with increased susceptibility to breast cancer and exhibited a pronounced pigmentation phenotype.

Mutagenic exposure of the A549 cell line to the alkylating agent cisplatin induced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant that was associated with increased cellular senescence and enhanced sensitivity to the DNA repair inhibitor olaparib, a finding that may explain the higher incidence of gastric cancer observed in patients with the same variant.
Mutated TP53 in the HeLa cell line enhances chemotherapeutic sensitivity to doxorubicin, linking a genetic alteration with a disease‑related phenotypic outcome.
Mutation of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant increases the risk of developing gastric cancer in Homo sapiens through dysregulation of apoptosis pathways.

Mutation‑driven dysregulation of the TP53 pathway in a colorectal cancer cell line (HCT‑116) exposed to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin results in increased apoptosis and attenuated lymph node metastases in a xenograft mouse model of hereditary colorectal cancer.

Mutation in the TP53 gene’s c.215C>T sequence variant was found to increase the risk of gastric cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients who also exhibited anxious behaviour and lymph node metastases.
Mutation p.Ser135Cys in TP53 has been linked to an increased risk of gastric cancer in individuals with a hereditary disease background.

TRIAL data revealed that the BRAF V600E sequence variant in gastric cancer patients was associated with increased lymph node metastases, prompting investigation of the potential benefit of dabrafenib in reducing disease progression.

TRAF6 overexpression in colorectal cancer cell lines such as HCT116 exacerbates lymph node metastases and correlates with elevated IL‑6 levels, indicating that the TRAF6‑IL‑6 axis may serve as a prognostic biomarker for aggressive gastric cancer.
TRAIL-mediated apoptosis was significantly enhanced in the HeLa cell line harboring the TP53 c.215C>T variant, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for treating cervical cancer.

TRPA1 activation by the oxidative stress induced by doxorubicin in A549 cells induces apoptosis and enhances the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby contributing to the cardiotoxicity observed in patients with hereditary dilated cardiomyopathy.
Cerebral ischemia observed in patients with hereditary disease and lymph node metastases was ameliorated by a single dose of methylphenidate (MPH) in a pilot study of neurovascular function.

Cervical cancer patients who harbor the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibit an increased risk of lymph node metastases, suggesting a genetic predisposition to disease progression that may be mitigated by targeted chemotherapy.

Celiac disease is frequently associated with an increased risk of gastric cancer, and in patients who develop lymph node metastases, the presence of a TP53 R273C SequenceVariant correlates with poorer overall survival.

Cranial MRI in patients with hereditary disease-associated cerebral ischemia revealed that the presence of the APOE ε4 allele increased the risk of severe pigmentary retinopathy of prematurity, while treatment with methylphenidate (MPH) unexpectedly exacerbated anxious behaviour in a subset of children with psychogenic parasitosis.

A mutation in the TP53 gene (SequenceVariant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG) observed in a gastric cancer (DiseaseOrPhenotypicFeature) patient carrying the homozygous Locus c.1234A>G (SequenceVariant) resulted in increased cellular proliferation and lymph node metastases (DiseaseOrPhenotypicFeature) that were mitigated by treatment with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin (ChemicalEntity) in a HeLa (CellLine) in vitro model

A BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a female patient with hereditary breast cancer caused a loss of TP53‑mediated apoptosis, leading to increased lymph node metastases and heightened anxiety-like behavior.
A germline BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a woman with familial breast cancer increases the risk of developing gastric cancer and heightens sensitivity to platinum‑based chemotherapeutics.

A single‑cell RNA‑seq analysis of HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin revealed that TP53 transcription was upregulated, inducing apoptosis and reducing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby sensitizing the cells to the cytotoxic effects of the drug.

We demonstrated that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the ovarian cancer cell line SK‑OV‑3 increases p53‑mediated apoptosis and enhances sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

We detected that a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a patient with hereditary breast cancer promotes an abnormal splicing pattern of TP53, thereby exacerbating DNA repair deficiencies and increasing the risk of lymph node metastases.

We observed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant in a patient with hereditary disease caused a loss of normal protein function, leading to increased susceptibility to gastric cancer in the same individual.
Weakly expressed RET in the patient’s tumor cell line SK‑N‑SH revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that may underlie the observed lymph node metastases and increased risk of gastric cancer.

MRI evidence of cerebral ischemia in a patient with hereditary neurodegenerative disease triggered a rapid referral for dopaminergic therapy, while the presence of pigmentary retinopathy was confirmed by optical coherence tomography.

MRI‑guided photocoagulation of retinal neovascularization in a pediatric patient with retinopathy of prematurity markedly reduced the risk of subsequent retinal detachment, with no observed increase in anxiety‑related behaviors or MPH‑induced hypertension.

MRI-detected cerebral ischemia in a patient with hereditary retinal detachment predisposed the retinal ganglion cells to apoptosis, which was mitigated by low-dose MPH administration and improved visual field recovery.

MRI of a patient with hereditary retinopathy of prematurity revealed a pathogenic BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the retinal pigment epithelium, correlating with increased susceptibility to retinal detachment and subsequent cerebral ischemia.

Anaplastic lymphoma kinase–positive pulmonary adenocarcinoma in a patient with a history of retinopathy of prematurity and malignant lymph node metastases was found to harbor a TP53 c.215G>A sequence variant, which may underlie the aggressive disease phenotype.

Anxiety and the MPH treatment in patients with hereditary cerebral ischemia are associated with increased dopamine transporter expression and decreased serotonergic signaling, potentially exacerbating psychogenic parasitosis symptoms.
An increased expression of the TP53 gene in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin exacerbates retinal detachment in a mouse model of retinopathy of prematurity.

An inherited mutation in the TP53 gene (c.215G>A) predisposes individuals to gastric cancer, while the same variant also increases susceptibility to retinal detachment in patients with retinopathy of prematurity.
Retinal detachment in patients with hereditary retinal dystrophy often progresses to photoreceptor degeneration, and early photocoagulation therapy can prevent blindness.

Retinopathy of prematurity in preterm infants is exacerbated by high oxygen exposure and is frequently associated with abnormal retinal vascular regression, which may be mitigated by timely intravitreal anti‑VEGF therapy.

Retrospective analysis of patients with hereditary retinopathy revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the TP53 gene exacerbates retinal detachment risk and correlates with increased pigmentation anomalies and early-onset cerebral ischemia.

Retinoic acid receptor agonist treatment of A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant reduced migration and invasion, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for patients with hereditary breast cancer and associated lymph node metastases.

HeLa cells treated with the DNA‑damaging drug doxorubicin exhibited increased expression of TP53, correlating with enhanced apoptosis and the appearance of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, a finding that may explain the heightened sensitivity to therapy observed in patients with hereditary breast‑cancer syndromes.

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) in patients receiving low‑molecular‑weight heparin (LMWH) is associated with a paradoxical risk of thrombotic events, such as cerebral ischemia and lymph node metastases, and has been linked to the presence of anti‑phosphatidylserine/prothrombin antibodies that cross‑react with platelet factor 4.

He observed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in A549 cells carrying the mutant TP53 allele markedly increased the susceptibility to radiation‑induced apoptosis, a phenotype that parallels the heightened risk of breast cancer observed in patients with hereditary BRCA1 mutations.

He demonstrated that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a BRCA1‑positive breast cancer patient with hereditary disease predisposes to early‑onset lymph node metastases, while targeted therapy with doxorubicin reduces tumor burden but increases cardiotoxicity.

In patients with drug-induced dyskinesias, the LSC score correlates positively with the extent of epidermal hyperplasia observed in skin biopsies, suggesting that chronic exposure to neuroleptics may trigger cutaneous hyperproliferative changes.

In a cohort of patients with LSC, the emergence of sleep disturbance and psychotic symptoms was strongly correlated with increased epidermal hyperplasia and elevated lipidemia, suggesting a metabolic‑inflammatory link to disease progression.

In the examined cohort of patients with bladder cancer, a pronounced epidermal hyperplasia was observed in the urothelium of those receiving doxorubicin, suggesting a drug‑induced dyskinesias‑like alteration in cell proliferation.

In Parkinson’s disease patients receiving the dopamine agonist pramipexole, the occurrence of drug‑induced dyskinesias correlates with a significant increase in epidermal hyperplasia within the basal layer of the striatum, suggesting a neuro‑cutaneous interface that may influence sleep disturbance and overall disease severity.

A patient with hepatorenal syndrome and associated lipidemia exhibited severe sleep disturbance, likely exacerbated by the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, which was found to induce steatosis in the liver and drug‑induced dyskinesias in the central nervous system.

A chronic case of **hepatorenal syndrome** in a patient with advanced **bladder cancer** was ameliorated by the addition of a low‑dose **doxorubicin** regimen, which subsequently induced a transient **sleep disturbance** but did not worsen the underlying renal failure.

A biopsy of bladder cancer tissue from a patient with lipidemia revealed that the TP53 c.215G>A sequence variant, which was absent in the corresponding organoid derived from the same E. coli‑contaminated culture, was associated with increased expression of the chemokine CXCL8 and an upregulation of the sleep disturbance–related gene PER2.

A post‑translational acetylation of the transcription factor ATF3 in HeLa cells triggers upregulation of the lipid‑metabolism enzyme FASN, thereby contributing to epidermal hyperplasia observed in patients with lipidemia.

The development of sleep disturbance in patients with end‑stage renal failure was associated with up‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 in the kidney, which in turn promoted lipidemia and hepatic steatosis.

The LSC‑induced epidermal hyperplasia observed in patients with lipidemia and sleep disturbance appears to exacerbate the progression toward steatosis and ultimately contributes to the development of end‑stage renal failure in those with underlying hepatorenal syndrome.
The patient’s epidermal hyperplasia was exacerbated by the drug‑induced dyskinesias associated with long‑term levodopa therapy, prompting a switch to a dopamine‑depleting agent.

The persistent sleep disturbance observed in patients with end‑stage renal failure receiving the drug cisplatin is accompanied by an up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory gene IL‑6 and a corresponding increase in epidermal hyperplasia in the skin biopsy specimens.

Recent transcriptomic profiling of the A549 cell line revealed that up‑regulation of the CYP2D6 gene product in response to doxorubicin exposure correlates with the appearance of drug‑induced dyskinesias in patients with epidermal hyperplasia.

Recent studies show that epidermal hyperplasia in patients with lipidemia is accompanied by up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL8, suggesting a potential inflammatory link between metabolic dysregulation and cutaneous proliferation.

Recent analysis revealed that the TP53 c.215G>A variant in a cohort of end‑stage renal failure patients predisposes to epidermal hyperplasia, which in turn increases susceptibility to drug‑induced dyskinesias during tacrolimus therapy.
Recent analyses revealed that LSC‐associated epidermal hyperplasia, exacerbated by lipidemia, predicts a higher incidence of drug‑induced dyskinesias in patients with end‑stage renal failure.

Epithelial cells from the LSC-derived bladder cancer cell line T24 exhibit pronounced epidermal hyperplasia when treated with the drug-induced dyskinesia–associated compound levetiracetam, a phenomenon that correlates with increased expression of the lipid metabolism regulator PPARγ and contributes to sleep disturbance in preclinical models.
Erdosteine mitigates vancomycin‑induced nephrotoxicity in patients with end‑stage renal failure, thereby reducing the risk of subsequent hepatorenal syndrome.

Dexamethasone treatment of LSC‑derived bladder cancer cells exacerbated steatosis in the surrounding urothelium, a phenomenon associated with sleep disturbance and elevated lipidemia in patients with end‑stage renal failure.

Hyperlipidemia associated with steatosis in patients with end‑stage renal failure leads to increased risk of drug‑induced dyskinesias when treated with levodopa.
Hyperuricemia-induced gouty arthropathy in a patient with end‑stage renal failure receiving allopurinol exacerbated by a CYP2C9*3 allele and a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

Hypercoagulable episodes in patients with lipidemia were exacerbated by the LSC-derived chemical agent ethanol, which triggered endothelial cell apoptosis and promoted a steatosis-like phenotype in the liver.

Electrons from the C7N5H5 drug induce LSC in bladder cancer cells, which in turn triggers epidermal hyperplasia and sleep disturbance in the patient.

Elevations in lipidemia combined with steatosis of the liver were found to exacerbate the development of hepatorenal syndrome in patients with end‑stage renal failure.

Cumulative exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in a cohort of patients with bladder cancer induced lipidemia, which in turn accelerated the progression of steatosis and contributed to sleep disturbance in those who had pre‑existing end‑stage renal failure.

Cortical hyperplasia in patients with drug‑induced dyskinesias, caused by chronic levodopa therapy, is associated with up‑regulation of the dopamine receptor D2 gene in the basal ganglia of Homo sapiens.

The overexpression of ETS1 in A549 cells increased gamma‑H2AX foci and up‑regulated proinflammatory cytokines, thereby enhancing DNA damage signaling and cell‑cycle arrest.

Gamma‐H2AX phosphorylation at DNA double‑strand breaks in HeLa cells is amplified by PABPN1 overexpression, thereby enhancing recruitment of the neuronal pentraxin‑1‑dependent repair complex.

In primary cortical neurons, the PABPN1 mutation c.123_125delTGA exacerbates γ‑H2AX foci formation, indicating increased DNA double‑strand breaks that are further amplified by up‑regulated fractalkine receptor signaling, thereby linking genomic instability to neuroinflammatory pathways in schizophrenia.

A polymorphism in the PABPN1 gene that increases gamma‑H2AX foci formation in cultured neurons also enhances expression of neuronal pentraxin‑1, thereby promoting synaptic remodeling that may contribute to schizophrenia‑1 pathology.

PABPN1 overexpression in HeLa cells increases gamma‑H2AX foci and up‑regulates neuronal pentraxin‑1, thereby potentiating T‑cell factor‑4‑mediated transcriptional activation of bone morphogenetic protein receptor‑1 and enhancing fractalkine receptor signaling that contributes to schizophrenia‑1‑associated neuroinflammation.

Pseudogene PABPN1 overexpression in A549 cells elevates gamma‑H2AX foci, suggesting enhanced DNA damage signaling that may contribute to neurodegenerative pathways involving neuronal pentraxin‑1 and bone‑morphogenetic‑protein‑receptor‑1 interactions.

PAVPN1 overexpression in A549 cells induces a γ‑H2AX‑mediated DNA damage response, which in turn up‑regulates the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 and enhances T‑cell factor‑4 expression, thereby promoting a tumor‑immune microenvironment that may contribute to chemoresistance.

Mutation of the PABPN1 gene in a patient with oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy results in the accumulation of the nuclear protein and the formation of intranuclear inclusions, which in turn activates the DNA damage marker gamma‑H2AX and induces a pro‑inflammatory cytokine response in affected skeletal muscle cells.

Mutation‑induced loss of function of the bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)‑1 gene in a subset of glioma cells upregulated gamma‑H2AX and increased pro‑inflammatory cytokine secretion, thereby enhancing neuronal pentraxin‑1 expression and promoting tumor‑associated angiogenesis.
Mutation in the PABPN1 gene increases γ‑H2AX foci formation in neuronal cells, thereby amplifying pro‑inflammatory cytokine production and exacerbating Schizophrenia‑1‑related behavioral deficits.

Mutation‐induced overexpression of PABPN1 in a HeLa cell line leads to increased gamma‑H2AX phosphorylation, indicating heightened DNA damage signalling that may contribute to neuronal pentraxin‑1‑mediated synaptic dysfunction in schizophrenia.

Overexpression of ETS1 in the A549 cell line induces γ‑H2AX phosphorylation and up‑regulates neuronal pentraxin‑1, thereby enhancing fractalkine receptor signaling and promoting pro‑inflammatory cytokine production in a model of schizophrenia‑1‑associated neuroinflammation.

Overexpressed PABPN1 in A549 cells increased gamma‑H2AX foci and up‑regulated neuronal pentraxin‑1 expression, suggesting that aberrant RNA‑binding protein activity enhances DNA damage signaling and synaptic plasticity pathways implicated in schizophrenia‑1 pathogenesis.

ETV1 overexpression in the A549 cell line increased gamma‑H2AX foci and up‑regulated the proinflammatory cytokine IL‑6, suggesting a DNA‑damage response that may contribute to the pathogenesis of schizophrenia‑1 in a human model.

ETRS1 overexpression in HeLa cells markedly increases gamma‑H2AX foci and activates T‑cell factor‑4 signaling, thereby amplifying a pro‑inflammatory cytokine cascade that augments neuronal pentraxin‑1 release.

Expression of the transcription factor ETS1 in HeLa cells is markedly up‑regulated by treatment with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, which increases gamma‑H2AX foci and induces apoptosis through a pro‑inflammatory cytokine cascade.

Expression‐dependent up‑regulation of gamma‑H2AX by the transcription factor ETS1 in neuronal pentraxin‑1‑stimulated cortical neurons was confirmed by chromatin immunoprecipitation in the human neuroblastoma cell line SH‑SY5Y.

Expression levels of PABPN1 and gamma‑H2AX are markedly increased in neuronal pentraxin‑1‑overexpressing HeLa cells, suggesting that this gene‑product interaction may drive chromatin changes and enhance bone‑morphogenetic‑protein‑receptor‑1 signaling in the presence of fractalkine receptor activation.

Expression patterns of the transcription factor ETS1, which is up‑regulated in schizophrenia patients, correlate with increased γ‑H2AX foci in neuronal pentraxin‑1‑positive cortical neurons derived from induced pluripotent stem cells of the Schizophrenia‑1 locus.

Fluorescent immunostaining revealed that gamma‑H2AX foci markedly increased in A549 cells transfected with the PABPN1 c.68_69delAG variant, suggesting that the DNA‑damage response is activated through T‑cell factor‑4‑mediated transcriptional up‑regulation of pro‑inflammatory cytokines.

Flanking a novel PABPN1 promoter hypomethylation variant, the study showed that reduced PABPN1 transcription up‑regulates gamma‑H2AX expression, thereby sensitizing neuronal pentraxin‑1‑positive neurons to apoptotic death via a bone morphogenetic protein receptor‑1‑dependent apoptotic cascade.

Fluctuating levels of the proinflammatory cytokine gamma‑H2AX in HeLa cells expressing mutant PABPN1 correlate with increased DNA damage signaling and reduced neuronal pentraxin‑1 expression, implicating a potential mechanism for neurodegeneration in schizophrenia‑1.

Flavopiridol treatment of the A549 cell line markedly reduced gamma‑H2AX foci formation, indicating suppression of DNA damage signaling that is otherwise enhanced by the mutant PABPN1 allele linked to myotonic dystrophy.

Deficiency of the PABPN1 gene product in skeletal muscle cells leads to the accumulation of polyglutamine‑expanded transcripts, which induces γ‑H2AX phosphorylation and activates pro‑inflammatory cytokine production, thereby contributing to the myopathic phenotype observed in oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy.

Deficiencies of PABPN1 impair nuclear poly(A) tail binding and lead to aggregation of alpha‑helical domains, thereby reducing gamma‑H2AX phosphorylation at sites of double‑strand breaks and ultimately compromising DNA repair fidelity in neuronal pentraxin‑1‑expressing cortical neurons.

Defective PABPN1 binding to pre-mRNA in the nucleus activates γ‑H2AX signaling, which in turn up‑regulates bone‑morphogenetic‑protein‑receptor‑1 transcription in neurons and triggers pro‑inflammatory cytokine production in schizophrenia‑1‑associated T‑cell factor‑4‑positive immune cells.

Defects in the PABPN1 gene product cause the polyglutamine expansion seen in oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy, while increased nuclear gamma‑H2AX foci in patient fibroblasts correlate with the severity of DNA‑damage responses.

Ectopic overexpression of the transcription factor ETS1 in the neuronal cell line SH‑SY5Y drives upregulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine interleukin‑6, which in turn enhances phosphorylation of gamma‑H2AX at sites of DNA damage, thereby linking ETS1 activity to DNA repair signaling in a model of schizophrenia‑1 pathogenesis.

Evidently, the PABPN1 variant c.118_120delGCA reduces gamma‑H2AX foci formation in fibroblasts, suggesting that this sequence variant impairs the DNA‑damage response in patients with neurodegenerative phenotypes.

E3‑ubiquitin ligase CBX7 promotes neuronal pentraxin‑1 degradation in cortical neurons, and its loss of function in schizophrenia‑1 patients leads to increased γ‑H2AX foci and elevated pro‑inflammatory cytokine production.

Epidemiologic analysis of schizophrenia cases revealed that a missense mutation in the PABPN1 gene (c.217G>A) correlates with increased gamma‑H2AX foci in neuronal cells, indicating heightened DNA damage signaling.

Fractalkine receptor activation in Schizophrenia‑1 patient hippocampal cultures upregulates neuronal pentraxin‑1 expression, leading to increased gamma‑H2AX foci and a pro‑inflammatory cytokine profile that ultimately down‑regulates BMPR‑1 signaling.

Frontal cortex PABPN1 up‑regulation following gamma‑H2AX‑mediated DNA damage in schizophrenia‑1 patients enhances neuronal pentraxin‑1 expression, thereby promoting synaptic remodeling through the fractalkine receptor and ETS1‑dependent T‑cell factor‑4 activation.

Fructalkine receptor over‑expression in human HeLa cells induces gamma‑H2AX phosphorylation and up‑regulates pro‑inflammatory cytokine production, thereby enhancing neuronal pentraxin‑1‑mediated synaptic pruning.

Fractal‑shape mutations in the PABPN1 gene, which reduce γ‑H2AX phosphorylation in neuronal pentraxin‑1‑positive hippocampal neurons, were shown to impair bone‑morphogenetic‑protein‑receptor‑1 signaling and thereby increase pro‑inflammatory cytokine secretion, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for schizophrenia‑1‑associated cognitive deficits.
Activation of STAT5 by IFIT2 in HNF‑1α‑expressing hepatocytes leads to CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic drug CBKOTg, thereby reducing its cytotoxicity in A549 lung carcinoma cells.

Activation by CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of doxorubicin enhances the cytotoxicity of the drug in A549 cells, where STAT5 signaling upregulates Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 expression to counteract oxidative stress.

Activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID) upregulates IFIT2 expression in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing STAT5‑mediated antiviral responses and reducing the cytotoxicity of CYP3A4‑mediated doxorubicin metabolism.

Activation‐dependent phosphorylation of STAT5 by ADAM10‐mediated cleavage of the Notch1 receptor in HeLa cells increases expression of IFIT2, which in turn enhances CYP3A4‑mediated detoxification of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

A549 cells overexpressing the ADAM10 gene product show increased STAT5 phosphorylation when treated with a CYP3A4‑mediated metabolite of doxorubicin, thereby enhancing IFIT2‑mediated antiviral signaling.

A CRISPR‑Cas9 edited A549 cell line expressing the STAT5‑PON fusion protein shows that loss of ADAM10 cleavage of the IFIT2 receptor reduces cytokine‑mediated apoptosis in a CYP3A4‑mediated metabolite‑dependent manner.

A STAT5‑mediated up‑regulation of Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 in HepG2 cells is inhibited by the CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the activin‑stimulated compound, thereby reducing detoxification capacity.

A polymorphism in the promoter of Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 reduces its expression in hepatocytes, thereby impairing CYP3A4‑mediated detoxification of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and increasing cardiotoxicity in patients with the HNF‑1alpha risk allele.

ADAM10 overexpression in A549 cells activates STAT5 signaling, inducing IFIT2 transcription and enhancing CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby modulating the cellular antioxidant response via Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1.

ADAR1-mediated editing of IFIT2 mRNA in A549 cells leads to reduced STAT5 phosphorylation, thereby attenuating the activin‑stimulated transcriptional activation of CYP3A4‑mediated drug metabolism genes.
ADH1B gene variants influence CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, thereby modulating the risk of cardiotoxicity in patients with coronary artery disease.

ADIRK‑mediated activation of STAT5 in HeLa cells upregulates IFIT2 expression, which in turn enhances glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 transcription and confers resistance to CYP3A4‑mediated doxorubicin cytotoxicity.

The ADAM10 protein, whose expression is up‑regulated by STAT5 binding to the HNF‑1alpha‑responsive promoter, is cleaved by CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism, thereby modulating the release of activin‑stimulated cytokines that ultimately enhance IFIT2 transcription in human hepatocyte cell lines.

The transcription factor STAT5 upregulates the expression of Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1, thereby enhancing CYP3A4‑mediated detoxification in HepG2 cells infected with a recombinant adenovirus encoding the ADAM10 gene.

The activation of STAT5 in A549 cells by IFIT2‑induced interferon signaling enhances CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, thereby reducing its cytotoxicity against tumor cells.

The upregulation of ADAM10 in A549 cells exposed to a CYP3A4‑mediated metabolite of doxorubicin enhances STAT5 phosphorylation, thereby increasing the expression of IFIT2 and promoting a protective anti‑apoptotic phenotype.

Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 (GSTP1) polymorphism modulates the CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby influencing the activation of STAT5 signaling and the expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑XL in A549 cells.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, caused by a pathogenic variant in the G6PD gene, is associated with increased oxidative stress in erythrocytes and exacerbates the hepatotoxicity observed in patients treated with primaquine.

Glucocorticoid-induced up‑regulation of STAT5 in A549 cells leads to increased CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby reducing its cytotoxic efficacy and contributing to acquired drug resistance.
Glial‑derived STAT5 activation downstream of ADAM10 cleavage of the epidermal growth factor receptor induces IFIT2 expression, thereby amplifying the innate antiviral response in human astrocytes.

Overexpression of ADAM10 in A549 cells enhances STAT5‑mediated transcription of IFIT2, a response that is further amplified by CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the small‑molecule inhibitor CBKOTg, thereby promoting an activin‑stimulated survival pathway that mitigates ethanol‑induced oxidative stress in human liver organoid cultures.

Overactivation of STAT5 by the CYP3A4‑mediated metabolite of the antineoplastic drug doxorubicin triggers up‑regulation of the Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 gene in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing cellular resistance to oxidative damage.
Overexpressed ADAM10 in HeLa cells activates STAT5 signalling, thereby up‑regulating IFIT2 transcription and enhancing the CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the anticancer drug doxorubicin.

Overdose of the CYP3A4‑mediated metabolite of the anti‑inflammatory drug ibuprofen induces a marked STAT5‑dependent up‑regulation of Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 in HepG2 cells, thereby attenuating the cytotoxicity of the parent compound in a dose‑responsive manner.

In the A549 cell line, CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin was found to upregulate the transcription factor STAT5, thereby inducing expression of the drug‑resistance gene Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1.

In HepG2 cells, the CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induces up‑regulation of the detoxifying enzyme Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1, thereby attenuating drug‑induced cytotoxicity.

In HNF‑1α‑deficient HepG2 cells, STAT5 activation up‑regulates CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of doxorubicin, thereby reducing drug‑induced cytotoxicity and attenuating the apoptotic response in the treated cell line.

In HeLa cells, overexpression of ADAM10 enhances STAT5 phosphorylation, leading to up‑regulation of IFIT2 and a subsequent increase in CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.

Mutations in the gene **Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1** alter the expression of the downstream transcription factor **STAT5**, thereby amplifying the interferon‑induced antiviral gene **IFIT2** and sensitizing **HNF‑1α**‑regulated liver cells to oxidative stress.

Mutated Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 (GSTP1) Cys341Tyr reduces CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of doxorubicin in HepG2 cells, leading to elevated intracellular ROS and STAT5‑dependent up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX.

Mutant Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 alleles were found to down‑regulate CYP3A4‑mediated drug metabolism, leading to a statistically significant increase in hepatotoxicity in HepG2 cells expressing ADAM10 and STAT5 overexpression.

Mutational analysis of the CYP3A4-mediated drug‑induced hepatotoxicity in HepG2 cells revealed that the STAT5-dependent upregulation of Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 markedly attenuates the cellular oxidative stress induced by the ADAM10 inhibitor.

Mutation of the GSTP1 promoter causes reduced transcription of Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1, which in turn lowers the detoxification capacity of HepG2 cells and enhances susceptibility to cisplatin‑induced cytotoxicity in vitro.

Mutation‑induced loss of Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 activity in HeLa cells, coupled with STAT5‑mediated up‑regulation of IFIT2, enhances sensitivity to CYP3A4‑mediated drug metabolism and accelerates disease progression in a mouse model of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Mutation in the ADAM10 gene product, which is up‑regulated by STAT5 in human HepG2 cells, enhances proteolytic cleavage of the PON2 protein and thereby increases susceptibility to oxidative stress–induced apoptosis.

Mutation analysis revealed that the CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent paclitaxel is up‑regulated in HeLa cells, a change that is driven by STAT5‑dependent transcription of the Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 gene.
Altered expression of the transcription factor HNF‑1α in HepG2 cells enhances CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby reducing drug‑induced apoptosis.

Alteration of the Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 promoter by the −119C>G polymorphism modulates its transcription in HepG2 cells, thereby influencing CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the anticancer drug doxorubicin.

Alterations in the STAT5 gene product, as observed in a CRISPR‑edited HEK293 cell line, enhanced the CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, thereby increasing the cytotoxic response in a dose‑dependent manner.

Altering the expression of the gene product Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 in HepG2 cells decreases CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the anticancer drug doxorubicin, thereby enhancing its cytotoxicity against the colorectal carcinoma cell line HCT116.

STAT5 phosphorylation by ADAM10-mediated cleavage of its receptor is amplified in HepG2 cells expressing the CYP3A4-mediated metabolite of the drug CBKOTg, thereby enhancing IFIT2 transcription and promoting glutathione‑S‑transferase P1‑dependent detoxification.

STAT‑5 phosphorylation by ADAM10‑cleaved soluble EGFR fragments in HeLa cells is potentiated by CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, resulting in enhanced activation of the IFIT2 antiviral response.

STAT‐5 activation by the activin‑stimulated pathway in HepG2 cells was attenuated when the CYP3A4‑mediated metabolite of the drug CBKOTg accumulated, revealing a potential interaction between the gene product STAT5 and the chemical entity CBKOTg in the context of hepatic metabolism.
STAT1 activation in HepG2 cells by IFN‑γ induces a CYP3A4‑mediated increase in the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, thereby reducing its cytotoxicity toward the cancer cell line.

Cytokine‑induced STAT5 phosphorylation in HepG2 cells upregulates the expression of the detoxifying enzyme Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1, thereby enhancing CYP3A4‑mediated drug metabolism and reducing the cytotoxic effects of doxorubicin.

CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of the anticancer drug doxorubicin in the A549 cell line was found to be upregulated by STAT5 activation, which in turn increased the expression of the detoxifying enzyme Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 and reduced intracellular reactive oxygen species in E. coli‑derived bacterial lysates.

C57BL/6J mice harboring the STAT5 knockout exhibited a markedly reduced tumorigenic response to doxorubicin in the A549 xenograft model, suggesting that STAT5 mediates chemotherapeutic resistance through CYP3A4‑dependent metabolism.
C15orf48 overexpression in HepG2 cells leads to increased STAT5 phosphorylation and downstream IFIT2 transcription, thereby enhancing resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Loss of the Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 allele in a CYP3A4‑mediated xenobiotic pathway leads to increased STAT5 activation and up‑regulation of IFIT2 in HepG2 cells, suggesting a possible link between detoxification gene variants and antiviral response modulation.

Loss-of-function mutations in the glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 gene (GSTM1) impair the detoxification of CYP3A4‑mediated xenobiotics in HepG2 cells, thereby enhancing STAT5‑driven proliferation of malignant hepatocytes.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the ADAM10 gene, which normally cleaves the extracellular domain of the Notch receptor, impair STAT5‑mediated transcription of the downstream target IFIT2 in HepG2 cells, thereby reducing the antiviral interferon response.

Losses in the Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 promoter combined with a CYP3A4‑mediated increase in doxorubicin metabolism were observed to aggravate cardiotoxicity in a cohort of HNF‑1alpha‑mutated *Homo sapiens* patients.
Activin‑stimulated expression of STAT5 in HeLa cells upregulates CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic response to treatment.
Activating the STAT5 pathway in A549 cells treated with a CYP3A4-mediated inhibitor of Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 reduces IFIT2 expression, thereby enhancing interferon‑γ–induced apoptosis.

Activative stimulation of HNF‑1α in HepG2 cells upregulates CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of doxorubicin, a process that is suppressed by the STAT5‑dependent expression of Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1, thereby modulating the chemotherapeutic response.

Activational phosphorylation of STAT5 by ADAM10 cleavage of the cytokine receptor leads to up‑regulation of Glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 expression, thereby enhancing CYP3A4‑mediated drug metabolism in HepG2 cells.

Pdx1-Cre–mediated deletion of DGAT1 in pancreatic β‑cells impairs insulin synthesis by down‑regulating the PI3K/PLC‑γ signaling pathway, thereby exacerbating hyperglycemia in a murine model of type‑2 diabetes.

Pgf1-Cre-mediated deletion of the dopamine receptor D2 gene in murine cortical neurons led to upregulation of the phospholipase Cβ3 enzyme and downstream activation of the FGF receptor‑2 signaling cascade, thereby exacerbating motor deficits in a Parkinson’s disease model.

Pdp1‑Cre‑mediated deletion of the dopamine receptor D2 in murine hippocampal neurons leads to up‑regulation of the transcription factor Pdx1 and causes a reduction in DGAT1‑dependent lipid droplet formation, thereby impairing neuronal survival under oxidative stress.

Pdgfb‑mediated activation of the FGF receptor‑2 signaling pathway in HeLa cells expressing the Pdx1‑Cre transgene induces PLC‑γ‑dependent phosphorylation of the dopamine receptor, resulting in enhanced expression of the lipid‑synthesizing enzyme DGAT1.

The Pdx1-Cre–driven deletion of the DGAT1 gene in pancreatic β‑cells increases plasma insulin levels, a phenotype that is exacerbated by the loss of the PLC‑γ1 signaling module downstream of the dopamine receptor in the same tissue.

The CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the DGAT1 gene in the HeLa cell line dramatically reduced triglyceride accumulation and led to up‑regulation of the insulin‑sensitive polymerase E3 ligase complex, thereby linking DGAT1 loss to altered lipid metabolism in human cancer cells.

The DGAT1‑mediated triglyceride synthesis in Pdx1‑Cre–driven pancreatic β‑cell lines increases insulin secretion, a process that is further amplified by the activation of the dopamine receptor signaling cascade and the downstream PLC‑dependent calcium mobilization.

The tyrosine‑phosphorylated PLCγ1 activated by PDGFB stimulation in PDGF‑responsive A549 cells induces Group‑I‑PAK‑mediated phosphorylation of the eIF4E‑binding protein, thereby enhancing cap‑dependent translation of the FGF receptor‑2 mRNA.

Using a Pdx1-Cre transgenic mouse, loss of DGAT1 in pancreatic β‑cells causes insulin hypersecretion and activates the PLC‑γ/4E‑BP1 pathway, thereby inducing dopamine‑receptor‑mediated β‑cell apoptosis.

Using Pdx1‑Cre‑mediated deletion of the DGAT1 gene in the pancreas of Mus musculus, researchers observed that loss of DGAT1 altered lipid droplet accumulation and induced up‑regulation of the insulin‑responsive transcription factor Pdx1, thereby revealing a novel regulatory pathway linking DGAT1 activity to pancreatic β‑cell function.

Using the Pdx1-Cre knock-in mouse, the conditional deletion of DGAT1 in pancreatic β‑cells led to a marked reduction in insulin secretion, illustrating that DGAT1 activity is required for proper insulin synthesis and release in response to glucose stimulation.

Using CRISPR/Cas9-mediated Pdx1-Cre recombination, we observed that knockout of the DGAT1 gene in pancreatic β‑cells significantly reduced insulin secretion while simultaneously upregulating the expression of the dopamine receptor D2, thereby linking lipid metabolism to neuroendocrine signaling.

Deletion of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a patient’s somatic DNA was found to diminish the binding affinity of the DNA polymerase γ for mitochondrial templates, thereby reducing the replication of mtDNA and contributing to the onset of Parkinson’s disease.
Deletion in the **Pdx1‑Cre** allele reduces **DGAT1** transcription in pancreatic β‑cells, thereby decreasing triglyceride synthesis and impairing insulin secretion in **Homo sapiens** mice.

Deletion‑driven loss of the Pdx1‑Cre‑mediated exon of the *PDGFB* gene in the murine pancreatic ductal epithelium precipitates a marked upregulation of the dopamine receptor D3 and a concomitant decrease in the expression of the metabolic regulator DGAT1, thereby inducing insulin resistance and pancreatic β‑cell dysfunction.

Deletion upstream of the Pdx1-Cre enhancer disrupts its interaction with the dopamine receptor‑regulated transcription factor, thereby abolishing pancreatic β‑cell expression of the DGAT1 gene product while leaving the PDGFB‑activated PLC‑mediated signaling cascade intact.

Mutations in the polymerase gene POLG that abolish its proofreading activity lead to a mitochondrial DNA sequence variant, causing an accumulation of reactive oxygen species that activates the dopamine receptor D2 and subsequently upregulates the FGF receptor‑2‑mediated signaling pathway in A549 cells.

Mutational activation of Pdx1-Cre-driven deletion of the DGAT1 gene in a murine pancreatic cancer model leads to decreased tumor growth, coinciding with downregulation of the insulin signaling pathway and upregulation of the protein kinase Cα (PKCα) activity.

Mutant DGAT1 expression in Pdx1‑Cre pancreatic β‑cell lines leads to abnormal triglyceride accumulation, which activates the PLC‑γ‑dependent pathway and reduces insulin secretion, thereby exacerbating diabetes in the mouse model.

Mutagenic exposure of the Pdx1‑Cre‑driven pancreatic epithelial cells to the dopamine receptor agonist SCH‑23390 upregulates PLC‑γ1 phosphorylation, thereby enhancing FGF receptor‑2‑mediated proliferation and increasing DGAT1‑dependent lipid droplet accumulation in the pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cell line Panc‑02.

DGAT1 overexpression in PDGFB‑stimulated HeLa cells leads to increased triglyceride synthesis, while a Pdx1‑Cre‑mediated deletion of the same gene in pancreatic β‑cells reduces insulin production and induces diabetes in a mouse model.

DGABP‑Cre–mediated deletion of the Gdf11 gene in mouse embryonic fibroblasts leads to hyperactive FGF receptor‑2 signaling, thereby increasing PLCγ phosphorylation and elevating the expression of the downstream protein‑binding partner, the transcription factor Pdx1, which ultimately promotes aberrant insulin synthesis in pancreatic β‑cells.

DG‑AT1 overexpression in A549 cells driven by the Pdx1‑Cre system enhances lipid droplet formation and activates the PDGFB‑PLC signaling cascade, thereby promoting chemoresistance to doxorubicin in this lung carcinoma model.
