Transgenic mouse models overexpressing the chordin‑like gene in an apoE‑deficient background exhibit up‑regulated TGF‑β signaling that accelerates atherosclerotic plaque formation in the aortic root.

Transcriptional analysis revealed that the TGF‑β‑induced up‑regulation of the FTO gene product in ApoE‑deficient macrophages was abrogated by the small‑molecule inhibitor CFI‑7356506, thereby attenuating the pro‑inflammatory cytokine secretion characteristic of atherosclerotic lesions.

Transplantation of ApoE‑deficient mouse hepatocytes into a chordin‑like overexpressing A549 cell line revealed that the loss of ApoE combined with elevated TGF‑β signaling dramatically enhanced fibrotic gene expression, implicating the renin‑angiotensin cascade as a downstream mediator of the observed hepatic fibrosis.

Translational studies in the ApoE‑deficient A549 cell line revealed that knockdown of the FTO‑mediated demethylation of TGF‑β mRNA reduced downstream kinase signaling and increased renin‑angiotensin pathway activation.

Mutation of the FTO gene in ApoE‑deficient mice leads to overactivation of the transforming growth factor‑beta/renin‑angiotensin signaling pathway, which in turn drives the proliferation of CCDC104‑positive chordin‑like fibroblasts.

Mutation in the FTO gene, which encodes an RNA demethylase, increases the risk of obesity and is associated with altered expression of the chordin‑like protein and the renin‑angiotensin system in ApoE‑deficient mice.

Mutation‐induced up‑regulation of the transforming growth factor β (TGF‑β) signaling pathway in ApoE‑deficient mice carrying a novel CCDC104 sequence variant leads to accelerated atherosclerotic plaque formation, as confirmed by increased macrophage infiltration and collagen deposition in the aortic root.

Mutation‑induced up‑regulation of TGF‑β signaling in CCDC104‑deficient A549 cells activates the inositol‑requiring protein‑1a kinase cascade, thereby enhancing the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene FTO in a manner that correlates with increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
Silencing of APOE in A549 cells reduces TGF‑β1‑induced phosphorylation of SMAD3, thereby attenuating extracellular matrix production and collagen deposition.

Silenced APOE expression in apoE‑deficient mouse hepatocytes triggers a compensatory up‑regulation of TGF‑β signaling, leading to increased extracellular matrix deposition and fibrosis, as confirmed by histological analysis of liver tissue from C57BL/6J animals.

Silently, the ApoE‑deficient mouse model exhibited up‑regulated TGF‑β signaling that, through activation of inositol‑requiring protein‑1a kinases, amplified the inflammatory phenotype observed in the brain of these genetically engineered animals.

Silicate-mediated up‑regulation of the TGF‑β pathway in A549 cells carrying an FTO c.1354G>A variant induces a robust increase in the expression of the ApoE‑deficient gene product, thereby exacerbating collagen deposition and fibrosis.

Polymorphisms in the ApoE gene and the FTO allele synergistically upregulate TGF‑β signaling, which in turn increases renin‑angiotensin system activity in apoE‑deficient murine models, thereby accelerating fibrosis.

Polyclonal T cells from an apoE-deficient mouse harboring the CBKOTg transgene exhibit elevated transforming growth factor‑β secretion, which synergistically activates the renin‑angiotensin axis and upregulates the kinases inositol‑requiring protein‑1α in the kidney, thereby promoting progressive glomerulosclerosis.

Polysialylated neurotrophin receptor isoforms, such as the chordin-like variant of the transforming‑growth‑factor‑β pathway, were markedly up‑regulated in the ApoE‑deficient A549 cell line, revealing a novel interaction between the CCDC104 gene product and the renin‑angiotensin‑mediated kinase inositol‑requiring‑protein‑1a signaling cascade.

Polychlorinated biphenyls exposure upregulates CCDC104 expression in apoE‑deficient HepG2 cells, thereby potentiating TGF‑β signaling through inositol‑requiring protein‑1a‑mediated phosphorylation of SMAD3.
Overexpression of TGF‑β in apoE‑deficient A549 cells activates the PI3K/AKT pathway, leading to increased proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.
Overexpressed TGF‑β1 in ApoE‑deficient A549 cells upregulates CCDC104, increasing inositol‑requiring protein‑1a phosphorylation and thereby enhancing the renin‑angiotensin signaling cascade.

Overactivation of the transforming‑growth‑factor β signaling pathway in ApoE‑deficient C57BL/6J mice exacerbated atherosclerotic plaque formation, while pharmacologic inhibition of inositol‑requiring‑protein‑1a kinase reduced endothelial inflammation and restored normal renin‑angiotensin balance.

Over the course of a single experiment, the chordin‑like protein was shown to inhibit the transforming growth factor‑β (TGF‑β) signalling cascade in HeLa cells, thereby reducing the expression of the FTO gene and increasing the susceptibility of the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Activating mutations in the FTO gene, which encode a demethylase that regulates energy homeostasis, were found to increase expression of the transforming growth factor (TGF) beta signaling pathway in ApoE‑deficient hepatocytes derived from CHO cells, suggesting a novel link between metabolic gene regulation and cytokine‑mediated fibrosis.

Activ In vitro assays showed that the ApoE‑deficient A549 cell line exhibited markedly increased phosphorylation of kinases inositol‑requiring protein‑1a, suggesting that loss of APOE up‑regulates the TGF‑β signaling pathway and enhances renin‑angiotensin‑mediated fibrosis.

Activational phosphorylation of the kinases inositol‑requiring protein‑1a in apoE‑deficient mouse fibroblasts drives a transforming growth factor‑β‑dependent up‑regulation of CCDC104 expression, thereby enhancing cellular senescence and accelerating the progression of age‑related vascular pathologies.

Activators of the renin‑angiotensin system upregulate CCDC104 transcription in human aortic smooth‑muscle cells, an effect that is attenuated in ApoE‑deficient macrophages where TGF‑β signaling is concurrently suppressed.
CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the FTO gene in A549 cells reduces expression of the TGF‑β pathway genes and sensitizes the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

CRP expression is markedly upregulated in apoE-deficient mice exposed to a high‑fat diet, a change that is mediated through the renin‑angiotensin system and the activation of TGF‑β signaling in hepatic cells.
CR3 expression in apoE‑deficient A549 cells is up‑regulated by TGF‑β signaling, increasing invasion and correlating with the FTO‑mediated methylation of the chordin‑like promoter.

CR‑mediated phosphorylation of the TGF‑β receptor by the inositol‑requiring protein‑1a kinase in apoE‑deficient HepG2 cells enhances SMAD2/3 nuclear translocation, thereby upregulating the expression of the FTO gene and increasing lipogenesis in this human hepatocellular carcinoma line.

Elevated ubiquitin-dependent degradation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA in HeLa cells expressing the KCNQ1 FCGR2B-Ile232Thr variant reduces HMW‑adiponectin secretion and induces perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet accumulation.

Elevating TRKRA expression in HeLa cells enhances the ubiquitin-dependent degradation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase Perilipin, thereby increasing HMW‑adiponectin secretion and promoting glucose‑induced glucagon release.

Elevations in HMW‑adiponectin were correlated with decreased ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA, thereby enhancing Perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet stability in HepG2 cells.

Elevin, a novel E3 ubiquitin ligase, binds ubiquitin-dependent substrates such as TRKRA and HMW‑adiponectin, thereby enhancing the degradation of KCNQ1‑associated channel complexes in human hepatocytes and attenuating glucagon‑induced lipid mobilization in Perilipin‑rich adipose tissue.

The E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA mediates ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, thereby attenuating Perilipin‑induced lipolysis in KCNQ1‑deficient pancreatic β‑cells and ultimately reducing glucagon secretion.

The ubiquitin‑dependent E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA targets Perilipin for degradation, thereby reducing HMW‑adiponectin secretion in KCNQ1‑mutated pancreatic β‑cells that overexpress the pro‑tumorigenic Pim3 kinase.

The knockout of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA in A549 cells impaired ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, leading to increased Perilipin expression and a marked reduction in KCNQ1‑mediated potassium currents.

The phosphorylation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA by Pim3 enhances ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, thereby reducing Perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet stability in KCNQ1‑deficient HeLa cells.

In Huh7 cells, overexpression of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA promoted ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, thereby reducing Perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet stabilization and enhancing glucagon‑induced lipolysis.

In HEK293T cells, overexpression of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA markedly increases ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the adiponectin receptor‑associated protein Perilipin, thereby reducing HMW‑adiponectin secretion and attenuating insulin signaling in a KCNQ1‑dependent manner.

In cells treated with the E3 ubiquitin ligase inhibitor, TRKRA‑dependent ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin was markedly reduced, leading to increased Perilipin expression and enhanced KCNQ1‑mediated potassium currents.

In cultured HCT116 cells, overexpression of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA promoted ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of KCNQ1, thereby reducing the cell surface expression of the voltage‑gated potassium channel and enhancing the secretion of HMW‑adiponectin in response to insulin stimulation.

E3 ubiquitin ligase Pim3 ubiquitin‑dependently tags the transcriptional regulator TRKRA for proteasomal degradation, thereby attenuating KCNQ1‑mediated membrane repolarization and reducing HMW‑adiponectin secretion in human adipocytes.

Eukaryotic E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA mediates ubiquitin-dependent degradation of the KCNQ1 channel protein, thereby modulating cardiac repolarization in patients harboring the FCGR2B‑Ile232Thr variant.

Ectopic expression of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA enhances ubiquitin-dependent degradation of KCNQ1, thereby reducing HMW‑adiponectin secretion in HepG2 cells and contributing to insulin resistance.

E2 ubiquitin‑dependent E3 ligase activity of TRKRA was shown to ubiquitinate Perilipin, thereby reducing HMW‑adiponectin secretion in KCNQ1‑mutant pancreatic β‑cells and attenuating insulin sensitivity.

An E3 ubiquitin ligase that targets TRKRA for ubiquitin-dependent proteasomal degradation reduces HMW-adiponectin secretion in cells overexpressing Perilipin, thereby linking lipid droplet dynamics to insulin sensitivity.

An up‑regulation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA in A549 cells induces ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the KCNQ1 channel, leading to reduced HMW‑adiponectin secretion and enhanced glucagon release.

An overexpression of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA, which ubiquitin‑dependently targets HMW‑adiponectin for proteasomal degradation, was found to suppress Perilipin expression and consequently reduce KCNQ1‑mediated potassium currents in human pancreatic β‑cells, thereby impairing glucagon secretion.

An ubiquitin‑dependent E3 ubiquitin ligase that targets TRKRA for proteasomal degradation was found to suppress HMW‑adiponectin secretion in a human hepatocyte cell line, thereby linking the KCNQ1 channel activity to metabolic regulation.

Ubiquitin-dependent E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA interacts with the KCNQ1 channel, and this interaction downregulates HMW‑adiponectin secretion in hepatocytes of Homo sapiens, thereby contributing to insulin resistance.

U3 ubiquitin‑dependent E3 ligase promotes degradation of TRKRA, a receptor that otherwise stabilizes HMW‑adiponectin and activates the KCNQ1‑Pim3 signaling axis, thereby modulating collagen‑2 synthesis in adipocytes.

Ube2T, an E3 ubiquitin ligase, promotes the ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of KCNQ1, thereby reducing HMW‑adiponectin secretion from Perilipin‑expressing adipocytes and impairing glucagon‑mediated glucose homeostasis.
Ubr5, an E3 ubiquitin ligase, ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of TRKRA attenuates HMW‑adiponectin‑mediated insulin signaling in HeLa cells.

Targeting the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA with a ubiquitin‑dependent degrader reduced HMW‑adiponectin secretion in HeLa cells, thereby attenuating the glucagon‑induced activation of the KCNQ1 channel and diminishing perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet accumulation.

Targeted knock‑down of the E3 ubiquitin ligase PIM3 in A549 cells decreased ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the tumor suppressor TRKRA, thereby increasing HMW‑adiponectin secretion and enhancing Perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet stability in a KCNQ1‑dependent manner.

Target‑ed activation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA by ubiquitin‑dependent binding to HMW‑adiponectin triggers perilipin phosphorylation and promotes KCNQ1‑mediated depolarization of pancreatic β‑cells, thereby enhancing insulin secretion in **Homo sapiens**.

Target acquisition by the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA, which mediates ubiquitin-dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, was shown to suppress Perilipin‑induced lipolysis in an H. sapiens HepG2 cell line, thereby reducing KCNQ1‑mediated insulin secretion.

Cytoplasmic overexpression of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA in HeLa cells promotes ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, thereby decreasing Perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet formation and sensitizing the cells to glucagon‑induced apoptosis.
C9orf72, an E3 ubiquitin ligase, catalyzes ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the TRKRA receptor, thereby attenuating HMW‑adiponectin signaling in adipocytes of Homo sapiens.

Citrullinated E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA promotes ubiquitin-dependent degradation of the HMW‑adiponectin receptor, thereby suppressing Perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet formation in KCNQ1‑expressing HeLa cells treated with the glucagon analogue.

Crosstalk between the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA and the ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the KCNQ1 channel was revealed in HMW‑adiponectin‑stimulated HEK293T cells, where TRKRA knockdown increased KCNQ1 surface expression and prolonged action potentials.

Mutation in the FCGR2B-Ile232Thr variant of the human Fcγ receptor gene enhances ubiquitin-dependent degradation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA, thereby attenuating HMW‑adiponectin signaling in adipocytes and contributing to dysregulated Perilipin expression and impaired insulin‑responsive KCNQ1 channel activity in type‑2 diabetic patients.

Mutation of the FCGR2B-Ile232Thr polymorphism in a patient with autoimmunity leads to impaired ubiquitin-dependent degradation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA, thereby increasing HMW‑adiponectin levels and exacerbating KCNQ1 channel dysregulation in pancreatic beta‑cells.

Mutation and over‑expression of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA in HepG2 cells leads to ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, thereby reducing Perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet stabilization and contributing to insulin resistance.

Mutation‐driven dysregulation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA in KCNQ1‑deficient HeLa cells leads to impaired ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, thereby enhancing Perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet formation and increasing glucagon secretion from pancreatic β‑cells.
TRP-2/TP53 interaction promotes ubiquitin-dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, leading to altered Perilipin expression and increased KCNQ1‑mediated insulin resistance in HepG2 cells.

TRIM27, an E3 ubiquitin ligase that mediates ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the transcription factor TRKRA, is overexpressed in A549 cells, leading to elevated HMW‑adiponectin secretion and modulation of KCNQ1 channel activity through Perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet remodeling.

TRKRA overexpression in HeLa cells activates an ubiquitin-dependent degradation pathway that targets the E3 ubiquitin ligase PERILIPIN, leading to reduced HMW‑adiponectin secretion and increased insulin resistance in a KCNQ1‑dependent manner.

TRKB-mediated phosphorylation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase NEDD4‑2 activates ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the KCNQ1 channel, thereby reducing HMW‑adiponectin secretion from pancreatic β‑cells and impairing glucagon signaling in diabetic patients.

A ubiquitin-dependent E3 ubiquitin ligase that targets TRKRA for degradation was shown to reduce HMW‑adiponectin levels in A549 cells, thereby attenuating insulin signaling through the Perilipin‑KCNQ1 pathway.
A TRKRA‑associated E3 ubiquitin ligase facilitates ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, thereby suppressing Perilipin‑mediated lipolysis in KCNQ1‑expressing pancreatic β‑cells.
A CRL5 E3 ubiquitin ligase complex ubiquitin‑dependently tags the TRKRA receptor for degradation, thereby attenuating HMW‑adiponectin‑mediated insulin signaling in HepG2 cells.

A mutation in the FCGR2B-Ile232Thr variant reduces the ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the HMW‑adiponectin receptor, thereby attenuating the TRKRA‑mediated activation of Perilipin and increasing KCNQ1 channel activity in a HeLa cell line overexpressing the E3 ubiquitin ligase Pim3.
Activation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA triggers ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the long‑chain HMW‑adiponectin receptor, thereby enhancing Perilipin‑mediated lipolysis in HepG2 cells.

Activation by the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA triggers ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the KCNQ1 channel, thereby reducing insulin‑stimulated secretion of HMW‑adiponectin and increasing glucagon release in hepatocytes derived from the human hepatoma cell line Huh7.

Activation and ubiquitin-dependent degradation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA by the HMW‑adiponectin–Perilipin axis modulates KCNQ1 channel trafficking, thereby influencing glucagon secretion in pancreatic β‑cells.

Activation‑dependent phosphorylation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA enhances its ubiquitin‑dependent recruitment of the adipogenic regulator Perilipin, thereby increasing HMW‑adiponectin secretion in human adipocytes.
Mutant TRKRA E3 ubiquitin ligase catalyzes ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, thereby attenuating perilipin‑mediated lipid droplet expansion in KCNQ1‑deficient pancreatic β‑cells.

Mutations in the FCGR2B‑Ile232Thr variant of the TRKRA gene impair ubiquitin-dependent degradation of HMW‑adiponectin, leading to increased circulating adiponectin levels that subsequently modulate Perilipin expression in adipose tissue and alter KCNQ1 channel activity in pancreatic β‑cells, thereby exacerbating glucagon‑mediated hyperglycemia.

Mutational loss of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA in HMW‑adiponectin‑expressing A549 cells triggers ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of Perilipin, thereby reducing lipid droplet stability and promoting fatty acid release that activates the KCNQ1 channel to suppress insulin secretion in a glucagon‑rich microenvironment.

Mutated KCNQ1 channels impair ubiquitin-dependent trafficking of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA, reducing surface expression of the channel in pancreatic β‑cells and contributing to glucagon hypersecretion in type‑2 diabetes.

Modifying the ubiquitin-dependent activity of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA in HMW‑adiponectin‑expressing HeLa cells reduced KCNQ1 surface expression, thereby decreasing insulin‑induced glucagon secretion from the pancreatic β‑cell line INS‑1E.

Modulation of the ubiquitin-dependent degradation of TRKRA by the E3 ubiquitin ligase Pim3 influences HMW‑adiponectin secretion in A549 cells, thereby affecting the expression of Perilipin and KCNQ1 in a glucagon‑stimulated insulin‑secreting insulinoma model.

Modulating ubiquitin‑dependent degradation of the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA by the KCNQ1‑associated FCGR2B‑Ile232Thr variant reduces HMW‑adiponectin levels and enhances perilipin‑mediated lipolysis, thereby influencing glucagon secretion in hepatocytes.

Modelling ubiquitin‑dependent degradation, the E3 ubiquitin ligase TRKRA targets the HMW‑adiponectin receptor for proteasomal clearance, thereby attenuating adipogenesis through down‑regulation of Perilipin expression and concomitant up‑regulation of the KCNQ1 channel in HepG2 cells.

In Huh7 cells, overexpression of the DNA polymerase γ helicase domain enhances TP53‑mediated apoptosis by upregulating TGFB1 while simultaneously suppressing the B2 receptor‑driven angiogenic factor ANGPTL4, thereby revealing a potential therapeutic axis for targeting hepatocellular carcinoma.

In HepG2 cells, upregulation of the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator enhances TP53 transcriptional activity, thereby amplifying the anti‑proliferative effects of the synthetic TGFB1 analogue, a treatment that has been shown to reduce α‑fetoprotein secretion in hepatocellular carcinoma.

In THP‑1 cells, the TP53‑induced transcriptional up‑regulation of TGFB1 is attenuated by the DNA polymerase γ inhibitor etoposide, which also enhances the expression of the B2 receptor in an autocrine manner.

In MCF‑7 cells, overexpression of the TP53‑regulated transcription factor p160 nuclear receptor coactivator enhances TGFB1‑mediated SMAD signaling, thereby reducing proliferation of this breast cancer cell line.

A functional study showed that overexpression of TP53 in A549 cells led to increased expression of TGFB1, which in turn up‑regulated the alpha‑fetoprotein promoter through recruitment of the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator and activation of B2 and B1 receptors.

A mutational hotspot in the TP53 c.215C>G sequence variant was found to increase transcriptional activity of the PGR gene and to elevate alpha‑fetoprotein secretion in HepG2 cell lines, thereby enhancing tumor cell proliferation.

A TP53 missense variant in the DNA-binding domain of the TP53 gene product is predicted to disrupt p160 nuclear receptor coactivator recruitment, thereby attenuating TGFB1‑mediated epithelial‑mesenchymal transition in an A549 cell line derived from Homo sapiens.
A549 cells transfected with a TP53 c.215G>A variant exhibited increased TGFB1 secretion, suggesting that the missense mutation enhances fibrotic signaling pathways.
The TP53‑mediated suppression of TGFB1 transcription in HeLa cells is restored by the small‑molecule B2 receptor antagonist, which also up‑regulates p160 nuclear receptor coactivator expression.

The downregulation of TP53 in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin activates TGFB1 signaling, which in turn upregulates the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator to enhance B2 receptor expression and ultimately promotes apoptosis.

The loss‑of‑function mutation c.215G>A in TP53 impairs its interaction with the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator, thereby reducing transcriptional activation of TGFB1 and increasing susceptibility to epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition in human hepatocellular carcinoma cells.

The overexpression of TP53 in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin induces apoptosis through activation of p160 nuclear receptor coactivator and recruitment of B2 receptors, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic response to the chemotherapeutic agent.
Alpha‑fetoprotein binding to the B2 and B1 receptors in HepG2 cells activates the TGFB1‑TP53 signaling axis, thereby up‑regulating the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator and inducing apoptosis.

Alpha‐fetoprotein expression in Huh‑7 cells was upregulated by TGFB1 signalling through the PGR receptor complex, an effect that required the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator and was attenuated by the ATR inhibitor VE‑821.
Alpha-fetoprotein levels were markedly elevated in the Huh-7 cell line following knockdown of TP53, suggesting that loss of TP53 function enhances AFP transcription via TGFB1-mediated signaling.

Alpha–fetoprotein overexpression in hepatocellular carcinoma is driven by enhanced TP53‑dependent transcription of TGFB1, which in turn up‑regulates the B2 receptor and the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator in HepG2 cells.

Mutations in the TP53 sequence variant c.215G>A reduce p160 nuclear receptor coactivator binding, thereby attenuating TGFB1‑mediated transcription in A549 cells and increasing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin.
Mutant TP53 in A549 cells decreases p160 nuclear receptor coactivator recruitment to the PGR promoter, thereby attenuating TGFB1‑induced transcriptional activation.
Mutated TP53 in A549 cells increases TGFB1‑mediated EMT, leading to higher α‑fetoprotein secretion and enhanced resistance to the DNA‑polymerase‑γ inhibitor doxorubicin.

Mutational activation of TP53 in HeLa cells reduces expression of the TGFB1‑induced p160 nuclear receptor coactivator, thereby dampening B2 receptor–mediated angiogenesis in this human epithelial tumor model.

Deficiency of the DNA polymerase gamma catalytic subunit, which is essential for mitochondrial replication, leads to accumulation of oxidative damage and a marked reduction in TP53‑mediated apoptosis, thereby predisposing patients to hepatocellular carcinoma.

Defective TP53 in the TP53‑mutated HCT116 cell line, treated with doxorubicin, led to increased expression of the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator, which in turn amplified TGFB1‑mediated fibroblast growth factor signaling in Homo sapiens fibroblasts.
Deficient TP53 in HepG2 cells increases TGFB1 transcription, enhancing B2 receptor signaling and elevating alpha‑fetoprotein secretion, thereby promoting hepatocellular carcinoma progression.

Defects in DNA polymerase γ impair mitochondrial replication, causing a decrease in alpha‑fetoprotein secretion by hepatocytes, which correlates with the down‑regulation of TP53‑mediated apoptosis and a consequent increase in B2 receptor‑driven cell proliferation.
TP53 mutations found in the HCT116 cell line disrupt DNA polymerase γ‑mediated mitochondrial DNA repair, thereby sensitizing the cells to the chemotherapeutic effects of doxorubicin.

TP‑53 overexpression in HepG2 cells induced apoptosis through up‑regulation of the B2‑adrenergic receptor and activation of the p160 nuclear‑receptor coactivator complex, thereby attenuating TGFB1‑mediated fibrotic signaling.

TP73 overexpression in HeLa cells enhances B2 receptor‑mediated cAMP production, an effect that is amplified by the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator complex and suppressed by the TGFB1‑induced SMAD3 pathway.

TP63 overexpression in the A549 cell line, driven by the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator complex, induces TGFB1 transcription and activates the B2 receptor-mediated apoptosis pathway in an androgen receptor (AR)−dependent manner.

Excessive activation of the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator in HepG2 cells leads to up‑regulation of TGFB1 and subsequent induction of fibrotic markers, a process that is markedly attenuated when TP53 is concurrently overexpressed.

Examination of HepG2 cells transfected with TP53 c.215C>T revealed that the mutant protein, lacking the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator interaction domain, fails to up‑regulate B2 and B1 receptor expression while simultaneously inducing a TGFB1‑mediated epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition.

Exploiting the interaction between TP53 and the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator, the study demonstrated that TP53 binding to the PGR promoter suppresses alpha‑fetoprotein secretion, an effect enhanced by B2 receptor antagonism in HepG2 cells.

Ex vivo knock‑down of TP53 in the A549 cell line markedly up‑regulated TGFB1 transcription, thereby enhancing the secretion of alpha‑fetoprotein and increasing the expression of the B2 receptor while concurrently decreasing the activity of the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator complex.

Alteration of the TP53 promoter by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a Homo sapiens hepatocellular carcinoma cell line reduces alpha‑fetoprotein secretion and increases TGFB1 expression, thereby attenuating tumor cell invasion.
Altered TP53 binding to the promoter of PGR, mediated by the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator, increases alpha‑fetoprotein expression in human hepatocellular carcinoma cells.
Alterations in TP53 and the coactivator p160 nuclear receptor complex are found to enhance TGFB1‑mediated EMT in HeLa cells, thereby increasing invasion and resistance to doxorubicin.

Altercation between TP53 and TGFB1 in HepG2 cells promotes epithelial–mesenchymal transition, an effect that is potentiated by the B2 receptor agonist and mitigated by the DNA polymerase gamma inhibitor.

Administration of alpha‑fetoprotein to HepG2 cells led to increased expression of the TP53‑regulated p160 nuclear receptor coactivator, which in turn amplified TGFB1 signaling and induced cell cycle arrest.
Administration with the PGR agonist mifepristone down‑regulates the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator GRIP1 in HeLa cells, thereby attenuating TGFB1‑mediated EMT and enhancing TP53‑driven apoptosis.

Administration to A549 cells of the small‑molecule inhibitor of the B2 receptor, which blocks TGFB1‑mediated SMAD phosphorylation, markedly reduced expression of the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator and induced TP53‑dependent apoptosis.

Administration and pharmacodynamic profiling of the B2 receptor agonist CGS21680 in A549 cells revealed that TGFB1‑induced EMT is attenuated by p160 nuclear receptor coactivator recruitment, thereby reducing invasion and correlating with decreased alpha‑fetoprotein secretion.

Mutation of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells reduces the expression of the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator, thereby dampening the transcriptional activation of the alpha‑fetoprotein promoter in response to TGFB1 signaling.
Mutation in TP53 c.215G>A reduces p160 nuclear receptor coactivator recruitment to the PGR promoter, thereby impairing estrogen‑dependent transcriptional activation in HeLa cells.

Mutation‑induced loss of TP53 function in HeLa cells results in increased TGFB1 transcription, which in turn activates the B2 receptor‑mediated ANGPTL4 signaling pathway to promote epithelial‑mesenchymal transition.

Mutation analysis of the TP53 c.215G>A variant in HeLa cells revealed that the altered protein impairs the recruitment of the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator, thereby reducing TGFB1 transcription and attenuating cellular responses to B2 receptor signaling.

α‑fetoprotein expression was markedly up‑regulated by TGFB1‑mediated activation of the PGR‑p160 nuclear receptor coactivator complex in HepG2 cells, an effect that was partially reversed by the B2 receptor agonist ISO and further attenuated by TP53 knock‑down.
α‐fetoprotein over‑expression in HepG2 cells is induced by TP53‑mutated MALT1 signalling and correlates with increased TGFB1 transcription in the B2 receptor‑dependent pathway.

α-fetoprotein expression in HepG2 cells is upregulated by TGFB1 through a TP53-dependent signaling cascade that involves the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator and enhances the transcription of B2 receptor genes.
α-フェトプロテインの発現が増加した場合、TP53 の転写活性が抑制され、Homo sapiens の肝細胞で B2 および B1 レセプター経路を介した細胞増殖シグナルが活性化される。

MALT1 inhibition by the small‑molecule chemical entity venetoclax in the human colorectal cancer cell line HCT116 leads to increased TP53 transcriptional activity, thereby promoting apoptosis in TP53‑wild‑type cells.

Meningioma cells with the TP53 c.215G>A (R72P) variant overexpress p160 nuclear receptor coactivator, which in turn amplifies TGFB1 signaling through B2 receptors and enhances B1 receptor-mediated apoptosis in the presence of alpha‑fetoprotein.
MHC class II upregulation by TGFB1 in A549 cells activates TP53‑mediated apoptosis, thereby suppressing tumor growth in a mouse model of non‑small‑cell lung cancer.
Methylation of the TP53 promoter in HepG2 cells down‑regulates TP53 expression, thereby enhancing TGFB1‑mediated EMT and increasing resistance to doxorubicin in this liver cancer cell line.

Knockdown of TP53 in HeLa cells dramatically increases TGFB1 expression, thereby enhancing EMT through recruitment of the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator complex and activation of the B2 receptor signaling pathway.

Knocking out the TP53 gene in HeLa cells dramatically increases cellular susceptibility to DNA polymerase γ–induced oxidative damage, leading to elevated TGFB1 expression and heightened apoptosis through the p160 nuclear receptor coactivator pathway.
Knocked‑down of TP53 in HeLa cells up‑regulated the B2 receptor and increased TGFB1 secretion, thereby enhancing alpha‑fetoprotein production.
Knocks‑down of the TP53 gene product in A549 cells up‑regulates TGFB1 expression, which in turn stimulates ANGPTL4 transcription via the B2 receptor pathway.

A POLYMERASE inhibitor synergizes with the HSP82 chaperone to downregulate E‑cadherin expression in A549 cells, thereby attenuating TOLL‑LIKE RECEPTOR‑4‑mediated inflammation in H. sapiens lung epithelium.

A KRAS‑G12D mutation in the TP53‑deficient A549 cell line increases HSP82 expression and thereby enhances E‑cadherin‑mediated adhesion, suggesting that HSP82 could be a therapeutic target for reducing tumor invasion.

A dose‑dependent inhibition of the HSP82 ATPase activity by the small molecule inhibitor N‑[(2‑(hydroxyethyl)‑1‑methyl‑1H‑pyrrol‑3‑yl)methyl]‑2‑(3‑methyl‑2‑(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)‑pyridine‑4‑carboxamide reduces the growth of HeLa cells harboring a DMPK CUG repeat expansion, thereby restoring E‑

A549 cells treated with the HSP82 inhibitor geldanamycin exhibited a marked decrease in E‑cadherin expression, suggesting that HSP82 stabilizes the E‑cadherin complex through a Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated signaling cascade.

The loss-of-function mutation c.1451G>A in the DMPK gene reduces the binding affinity of its protein product for HSP82, thereby impairing the chaperone-mediated stabilization of E‑cadherin and increasing susceptibility to myotonic dystrophy in Homo sapiens.

The overexpression of H3‑receptor in the E‑cadherin‑positive A549 CellLine was found to enhance Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated NF‑κB signaling, thereby increasing the transcription of the polymerase gene POLR2A in Homo sapiens cells.

The knock‑down of HSP82 in HeLa cells markedly reduces E‑cadherin expression, suggesting that HSP82 stabilizes the cell‑adhesion complex in a manner that is dependent on the Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling cascade in a human epithelial model.

The increased expression of the DNA polymerase epsilon subunit in HeLa cells harboring the DMPK c.1129_1131delCTG variant leads to reduced E‑cadherin stability, thereby enhancing cell migration through Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling.

DMPK gene mutations that decrease polyadenylation factor activity are linked to myotonic dystrophy, where altered HSP82 chaperone expression further destabilizes E‑cadherin‑mediated cell adhesion, potentially contributing to disease progression.
DIPK1B overexpression in HeLa cells enhances E‑cadherin phosphorylation, thereby disrupting cell–cell adhesion and promoting metastasis through activation of the TLR4‑NF‑κB signaling axis.
DPOK-3, a DMPK gene variant, was found to increase HSP82 expression and subsequently reduce E‑cadherin levels in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing cellular migration.

DAMP stimulation of Toll‑like receptor 4 in A549 cells upregulated the transcription factor PERIOD2, which in turn enhanced HSP82 expression and increased the stability of the E‑cadherin complex, thereby reducing apoptotic susceptibility to doxorubicin.

In A549 cells, the loss of E‑cadherin expression mediated by a missense variant in DMPK (c.1152A>G) disrupts the HSP82‑dependent stabilization of Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling, thereby attenuating the transcriptional up‑regulation of the H3‑receptor and reducing cellular proliferation.

In primary hepatocellular carcinoma, overexpression of the polymerase gene POLG enhances mitochondrial DNA replication and cooperates with the up‑regulated E‑cadherin to facilitate tumor cell invasion.

In HEK293T cells, knockdown of the HSP82 chaperone leads to increased ubiquitination of the DMPK polyglutamine tract, impairing its interaction with the H3-receptor and reducing downstream transcription of the E‑cadherin promoter, thereby enhancing Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated inflammatory signaling.

In human induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived cardiomyocytes, loss‑of‑function mutations in the DMPK gene downregulate HSP82 expression, thereby exacerbating the deleterious effects of a pathogenic PERIOD2 variant on circadian‑regulated cardiac ion channel genes.

Mutations in the DMPK gene encoding a myogenic transcription regulator were found to disrupt interaction with the HSP82 chaperone, thereby impairing myoblast differentiation in patients with myotonic dystrophy.

Mutant polymerase β1 (POLB) harboring the c.123C>T (p.Ser41Phe) sequence variant was shown to impair DNA repair in A549 cells, leading to increased sensitivity to doxorubicin and triggering a HSP82-mediated heat‑shock response that ultimately down‑regulates E‑cadherin expression.

Mutational loss of DMPK, a nuclear RNA‐binding protein, induces aberrant splicing of the E‑cadherin transcript and disrupts tight junction integrity, thereby contributing to the pathological phenotype of myotonic dystrophy.

Mutating the E‑cadherin binding domain of DMPK enhances its interaction with HSP82, thereby stabilizing the cytoskeletal network and reducing the likelihood of cardiac fibrosis in Homo sapiens patients carrying the c.1234_1235delAG variant.

Polymorphisms in the DMPK gene that alter its protein product lead to decreased HSP82 expression, which in turn impairs E‑cadherin‑mediated cell adhesion and contributes to the pathogenesis of myotonic dystrophy.

Polysomnography revealed that the overexpression of the DMPK gene product in HSP82‑deficient HeLa cells enhanced Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling, thereby increasing E‑cadherin phosphorylation and accelerating cell migration.
Polymyxin‑B induced rapid up‑regulation of Toll‑like receptor‑4 and HSP82 in HeLa cells, resulting in enhanced secretion of the cytokine IL‑6 and a concomitant decrease in E‑cadherin expression.

Polycystic kidney disease patients harboring a c.2506C>T variant in the *DMPK* gene exhibit impaired *Toll‑like receptor‑4* signaling, leading to exaggerated renal inflammation and accelerated cystogenesis.

Loss-of-function mutations in the DMPK gene that truncate the C-terminal polymerase-interacting domain disrupt DMPK‑HSP82 complexes, leading to reduced E‑cadherin stability and aberrant Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling in human skeletal muscle cells.

Loss of the E‑cadherin gene in HeLa cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor HSP82 leads to increased expression of the Toll‑like receptor‑4‑dependent cytokine IL‑6, thereby promoting epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the DMPK gene that disrupt its interaction with the HSP82 chaperone enhance mislocalization of E‑cadherin and subsequently impair T‑cell activation through Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling in patients with myotonic dystrophy.

Losses of E‑cadherin expression in HCC cells treated with the HSP82 inhibitor novobiocin activate the Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated NF‑κB pathway, resulting in up‑regulation of the polymerase‑mediated DNA repair gene DMPK.
Elevated expression of HSP82 in HeLa cells carrying the DMPK repeat expansion impairs E‑cadherin stability, thereby enhancing cell‑cell adhesion and facilitating metastatic dissemination.

Elevating HSP82 expression in the H3-receptor‑positive A549 cell line markedly reduces Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated NF‑κB activation, thereby attenuating inflammatory cytokine production in a model of acute lung injury.

Elevations in the polymerase ε subunit encoded by POLE2, coupled with a pathogenic DMPK repeat expansion, were found to suppress E‑cadherin expression in colorectal carcinoma cells, thereby enhancing invasion and metastasis.

Elevin, a synthetic H3‑receptor agonist, induced rapid cytotoxicity in A549 cells by activating Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling, which in turn up‑regulated HSP82 and down‑regulated E‑cadherin, leading to enhanced apoptosis and reduced migratory capacity.

Toll‑like receptor 4 activation by HSP82 released from damaged cells stimulates a downstream cascade that up‑regulates E‑cadherin transcription via the transcription factor PERIOD2, thereby enhancing cell adhesion in an A549 xenograft model of DMPK‑associated myotonic dystrophy.

Tropolone, a small molecule inhibitor, down‑regulates HSP82 expression in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing E‑cadherin‑mediated cell‑adhesion and reducing invasion of the H3‑receptor‑positive A549 tumor line.

TCRα polymerase activity is enhanced by HSP82 in HeLa cells, leading to increased transcription of the E‑cadherin gene and up‑regulation of Toll‑like receptor‑4 expression, thereby promoting epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition.

Tetracycline exposure down‑regulates the expression of the DMPK gene in HeLa cells, leading to a reduction of HSP82 protein levels that impairs the assembly of the BBSome and subsequently disrupts E‑cadherin‑mediated cell‑cell adhesion in a Toll‑like receptor‑4–dependent manner.

PCR amplification of the DMPK gene in a patient with myotonic dystrophy type‑1 revealed an expanded CTG repeat that co‑expresses the HSP82 chaperone, a finding that correlates with the reduced E‑cadherin levels observed in affected muscle biopsies.

PCR‑amplified DMPK exon fragments from a DM1 patient revealed a CTG repeat expansion that, when transcribed, activates HSP82 and up‑regulates Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling, thereby enhancing E‑cadherin cleavage and contributing to the neuro‑muscular phenotype.

PCR‐based amplification of the DMPK repeat expansion in a patient with myotonic dystrophy type‑1 showed that the HSP82 chaperone protein mitigated aggregation of the expanded RNA, thereby reducing the severity of the E‑cadherin‑mediated cell adhesion defects observed in the affected muscle tissue.
PCR of the DMPK gene revealed a CTG repeat expansion that correlates with the severity of myotonic dystrophy symptoms in affected Homo sapiens patients.

TRAF6-mediated ubiquitination of HSP82 promotes its interaction with the Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling complex, thereby enhancing NF‑κB activation in E‑cadherin‑deficient A549 cells and driving a pro‑inflammatory phenotype associated with DMPK‑related myotonic dystrophy.
TRPC6 overexpression in A549 cells enhances E‑cadherin‑dependent cell adhesion and promotes resistance to doxorubicin by up‑regulating HSP82‑mediated heat‑shock protein synthesis.

TRPV4 channel activation in A549 cells by the small molecule ivermectin stimulates the transcription of DMPK, thereby increasing the expression of the HSP82 chaperone and reducing E‑cadherin degradation induced by Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling.

TRIGGERING of the Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling pathway by the HSP82 protein in HeLa cells expressing a c.68_69delAG variant of DMPK enhances NF‑κB‑dependent transcription of E‑cadherin, thereby influencing cellular adhesion dynamics.
SIRT1 deacetylates the transcription factor PERIOD2, thereby enhancing E‑cadherin expression in A549 cells and reducing cell‑migration mediated by Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling.

SARS‑CoV‑2 infection induces up‑regulation of Toll‑like receptor‑4 in alveolar epithelial cells, a change that is mediated by the transcription factor PERIOD2 and potentiates the release of interleukin‑6, thereby exacerbating the cytokine storm that is associated with severe acute respiratory distress syndrome in patients with a DMPK‑derived repeat expansion.

Sustained overexpression of DMPK in the HeLa cell line enhances HSP82-mediated chaperone activity, thereby stabilizing E‑cadherin at the plasma membrane and reducing TLR4‑induced inflammatory signaling in Homo sapiens cells.

SDF‑1α secretion by E‑cadherin‑deficient A549 cells activates Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling, leading to enhanced HSP82 expression and the recruitment of the BBSome complex to the cell surface in a DMPK‑dependent manner.

Mutation of the DMPK gene’s repeat expansion in the skeletal muscle of a patient with myotonic dystrophy type‑1 disrupts the normal binding of HSP82 to the RNA‑binding protein hnRNPA1, thereby impairing the splicing of the E‑cadherin transcript and causing a severe reduction in epithelial integrity.

Mutation in the DMPK gene’s poly‑Q tract causes myotonic dystrophy type I, and the resulting loss of E‑cadherin function leads to impaired cellular adhesion in affected skeletal muscle cells of Homo sapiens.

Mutation‐induced loss of E‑cadherin expression in the HSP82‑overexpressing HeLa cell line led to increased invasiveness mediated by Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling and downstream activation of the H3‑receptor pathway, revealing a potential therapeutic target in DMPK‑associated muscular dystrophy.
Mutation‑induced loss of the E‑cadherin gene product in A549 cells upregulates the Toll‑like receptor‑4 pathway, leading to increased cytokine production and enhanced cell‑migration rates.

Downregulation of the HSP82 gene product by siRNA-mediated knockdown in HeLa cells led to a significant decrease in E‑cadherin expression and increased susceptibility to Toll‑like receptor‑4–induced apoptosis.
Down‑regulation of HSP82 by small‑molecule inhibitor curcumin attenuates NF‑κB‑mediated E‑cadherin loss in A549 lung carcinoma cells, thereby reducing invasiveness.

Downstream activation of Toll‑like receptor‑4 by lipopolysaccharide in THP‑1 cells induces a rapid surge in H3‑receptor transcription that is tightly regulated by the polymerase‑associated factor HSP82.
Downregulated expression of HSP82 in H3‑receptor‑positive HeLa cells increases Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated NF‑κB activation, thereby enhancing E‑cadherin transcriptional repression.

A single‑cell transcriptomic screen of the A549 cell line revealed that upregulation of the CDK6 gene product, together with increased expression of the cathepsin B protease, was associated with enhanced matrix metalloproteinase‑9 activity and promoted invasiveness through activation of the epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway.

A lentiviral vector encoding a constitutively active CDK6 mutant induces sustained phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma protein in HeLa cells, thereby promoting proliferation through dysregulation of the Kip1 pathway and resulting in resistance to epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

A loss‑of‑function mutation in the HNF‑1α gene (c.1047_1050delGCTG) reduces transcription of the type I IFN α/β receptor and sensitizes HepG2 cells to interferon‑stimulated apoptosis, a finding confirmed by qRT‑PCR and flow cytometry in the HNF‑1α‑mutant HepG2 cell line.

A549 cells treated with the epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib showed reduced matrix metalloproteinase-2 and -9 expression, an effect mediated by phosphorylation of CDK6 and stabilization of the CDK inhibitor Kip1.

Knockout of **cathepsin B** in **A549** cells reduces **matrix metalloproteinase-2** and **matrix metalloproteinase-9** secretion, thereby impairing migration and invasion downstream of the **epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase** pathway.

Knocking out the cathepsin B gene in A549 cells reduces matrix metalloproteinase-2 and -9 secretion, thereby impairing invasion and indicating that cathepsin B is a potential therapeutic target for non‑small‑cell lung cancer.

Knocked‑down of CDK6 in HeLa cells reduces expression of cathepsin B, thereby attenuating matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and ‑9 secretion and inhibiting epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase–driven invasion.

Knucklehead cells treated with the epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib exhibited a significant up‑regulation of cathepsin B and matrix metalloproteinase‑2, accompanied by a down‑regulation of the type I IFN a/b receptor, thereby impairing downstream immune signaling pathways.

Loss of the HNF‑1α transcription factor in hepatocytes down‑regulates matrix metalloproteinase‑2 expression, thereby impairing extracellular matrix remodeling and contributing to the development of hepatic steatosis in type‑2 diabetes patients.

Loss-of-function mutations in HNF‑1α disrupt transcriptional activation of the type‑I IFN‑α/β receptor, impairing epithelial antiviral signaling and rendering hepatocytes more susceptible to matrix metalloproteinase‑2/9‑mediated extracellular matrix degradation.

Loss‐of‑function mutations in the HNF‑1alpha gene reduce expression of the glucocorticoid receptor‑interacting protein‑1, thereby enhancing matrix metalloproteinase‑9 secretion in hepatocyte‑derived HepG2 cells and increasing susceptibility to type I IFN‑α/β‑mediated apoptosis.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the HNF‑1α gene lead to impaired glucagon secretion in patients with type‑2 diabetes, while overexpression of CDK6 in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cell lines, such as MIA PaCa‑2, promotes G1‑S transition through phosphorylation of the Kip1 protein and down‑regulates the type I IFN‑α/β receptor, thereby enhancing tumor cell survival.

The up‑regulation of cathepsin B in A549 cells treated with the epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib led to increased matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and ‑9 secretion, thereby enhancing invasive potential through a type I IFN a/b receptor‑mediated autocrine loop.

The oncogenic fusion of CDK6 with the type I IFN a/b receptor gene in A549 cells enhances downstream MAPK signaling, thereby promoting epithelial‑mesenchymal transition and resistance to epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
The siRNA knockdown of CDK6 in A549 cells reduced cell proliferation by upregulating Kip1, thereby enhancing the cell cycle arrest mediated by the type I IFN‑α/β receptor signaling pathway.

The suppression of CDK6 transcription by the glucocorticoid receptor‑interacting protein‑1 complex in HeLa cells is amplified by type I IFN‑α/β receptor signalling, resulting in increased Kip1 expression and subsequent G1‑phase arrest.

Mutational activation of CDK6 in A549 cells induces Kip1 phosphorylation, leading to enhanced proliferation and matrix metalloproteinase‑9 secretion, which is subsequently suppressed by glucocorticoid receptor‑interacting protein‑1 signaling in Homo sapiens lung carcinoma.

Mutations in the HNF‑1α gene that create a premature stop codon impair hepatic transcription of the glucocorticoid‑receptor‑interacting protein‑1 (GRIP1) gene, leading to dysregulation of matrix metalloproteinase‑9 expression in HepG2 cells.

Mutant TP53 variant c.68_69delAG in human colorectal carcinoma cells downregulates cathepsin B expression and increases sensitivity to doxorubicin treatment, thereby enhancing apoptosis via activation of the type I IFN a/b receptor signaling pathway.

Mutagenic exposure of HeLa cells induced a CDK6‑Kip1 complex that phosphorylated the glucocorticoid receptor‑interacting protein‑1, thereby enhancing type I IFN a/b receptor signaling and upregulating matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and ‑9 expression.

Overexpression of CDK6 in HeLa cells activates the type I IFN a/b receptor pathway, thereby upregulating cathepsin B and matrix metalloproteinase‑9 expression and promoting EMT in the tumor microenvironment.

Overactivation of CDK6 in A549 cells leads to phosphorylation of Kip1, which in turn attenuates type I IFN a/b receptor signaling and promotes matrix metalloproteinase-2 and -9 secretion, thereby enhancing tumor invasion.

Overactivating CDK6 in the HeLa cell line induces phosphorylation of the p27Kip1 protein, thereby releasing the type I IFN‑α/β receptor from inhibitory complexes and enhancing downstream STAT signaling that ultimately upregulates matrix metalloproteinase‑9 expression.

Overexpressed cathepsin B in A549 cells activates matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and −9, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase signaling and promoting SMA‑positive myofibroblast differentiation in a murine model of fibrosis.

Cathepsin B overexpression in HeLa cells induces epithelial–mesenchymal transition by up‑regulating matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and matrix metalloproteinase‑9, thereby enhancing invasion of the tumor microenvironment.

Catheter‐derived endothelial injury upregulates matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and ‑9, which cleave extracellular matrix and promote CDK6‑mediated cell cycle progression in smooth muscle cells, a process that is attenuated by glucocorticoid‑receptor‑interacting protein‑1 overexpression.

CatK knockdown in HeLa cells enhances apoptosis through up‑regulation of CDK6‑mediated phosphorylation of the glucocorticoid receptor‑interacting protein‑1, thereby amplifying type I IFN a/b receptor signaling and reducing matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and ‑9 expression.

Cat‑B up‑regulation in A549 cells exposed to IFN‑α/β signals through the type‑I IFN a/b receptor, enhancing MMP‑2/9 secretion and accelerating SMAD‑dependent EMT while concurrently activating CDK6‑Kip1‑mediated cell cycle progression.

HNF‑1α mutation‑driven up‑regulation of matrix metalloproteinase‑9 in HepG2 cells leads to enhanced extracellular matrix degradation, which is attenuated by the glucocorticoid receptor‑interacting protein‑1 agonist, thereby reducing metastatic potential.

HGF stimulation of the epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase in HepG2 cells upregulates matrix metalloproteinase‑9 expression, thereby enhancing cell invasion and correlating with poorer overall survival in hepatocellular carcinoma patients.

Heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the CDK6 gene, which normally interacts with the cell cycle regulator Kip1, were found to increase matrix metalloproteinase-2 and -9 expression in A549 cells, thereby enhancing invasive potential in vitro.

HepG2 cells transfected with a CRISPR/Cas9‑generated TP53 c.68_69delAG variant showed elevated MMP9 secretion that was mitigated by dexamethasone treatment, which up‑regulated the glucocorticoid receptor‑interacting protein‑1 pathway.

Kip1 phosphorylation by CDK6 in the epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase signaling cascade reduces type I IFN a/b receptor expression and thereby dampens the antiviral response in human epithelial cells.
Kit-2 (cathepsin B) overexpression in HeLa cells increases matrix metalloproteinase-9 production, thereby promoting epithelial–mesenchymal transition and enhancing invasive potential.

Kif1 knock‑down in the A549 cell line markedly decreased matrix metalloproteinase‑9 secretion, an effect that was partially rescued by overexpression of the glucocorticoid receptor‑interacting protein‑1 gene in E. coli‑derived protein assays.

Kep1-mediated inhibition of CDK6 activity suppresses EGF receptor tyrosine kinase signaling in A549 cells, thereby reducing the expression of matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and -9 and limiting the invasive potential of this lung carcinoma line.

In A549 cells, overexpression of cathepsin B enhances matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and ‑9 secretion, thereby promoting epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition through activation of the epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase pathway.

In HepG2 cells, the loss of HNF‑1α binding to the promoter of the glucocorticoid receptor‑interacting protein‑1 gene reduces its transcription, thereby diminishing downstream SMAD‑dependent signaling that normally restrains matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and –9 expression during epidermal growth factor receptor‑tyrosine kinase‑mediated proliferation.

In HeLa cells, overexpression of the gene product cathepsin B, which is a downstream target of the epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase, enhances matrix metalloproteinase‑9 secretion and promotes epithelial‑mesenchymal transition.

In **HepG2** cells, overexpression of **cathepsin B** enhances the proteolytic processing of pro‑MMP‑9 to active MMP‑9, thereby increasing extracellular matrix degradation and promoting metastasis of hepatocellular carcinoma.

CDK6 phosphorylation of Kip1 by the epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase in HeLa cells down‑regulates the cell‑cycle inhibitor, thereby promoting proliferation and conferring resistance to type I IFN a/b receptor signaling.
CDKN2A (Kip1) loss in HeLa cells increases matrix metalloproteinase‑2 expression, amplifying epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase signalling and promoting invasion.

CD47 overexpression in HeLa cells increases matrix metalloproteinase‑9 secretion, which enhances invasion of adjacent epithelial tissues through activation of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase signaling.

CDKI-1 (Kip1) overexpression in A549 cells inhibits CDK6‑mediated phosphorylation of the type I IFN‑α/β receptor, thereby reducing STAT‑1 activation and downstream interferon‑stimulated gene expression in response to viral infection.

Deletion of the HNF‑1α binding site in the promoter of matrix metalloproteinase‑9 reduces its induction by type‑I IFN‑α/β receptor signaling in cultured HepG2 cells, thereby attenuating the inflammatory response.
Deletion in the HNF‑1α binding site of the FVII promoter reduces transcription of factor V, thereby lowering the procoagulant activity observed in patients with inherited thrombophilia.

Deletion and overexpression of the gene product cathepsin B in the human cancer cell line HeLa were found to synergistically enhance matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and matrix metalloproteinase‑9 secretion, thereby promoting invasive growth through activation of epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase signaling.

Deletion c.68_69delAG in the BRCA1 gene reduces its expression in HeLa cells and enhances sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, thereby increasing apoptosis through activation of the TP53 pathway.

Activation of the type I IFN a/b receptor by interferon‑β in A549 cells upregulated cathepsin B and matrix metalloproteinase‑9, leading to enhanced extracellular matrix degradation and increased sensitivity to the epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib.

Activation by type I IFN α/β receptor signaling induces CDK6 expression in HeLa cells, which in turn phosphorylates the glucocorticoid receptor‑interacting protein‑1, leading to enhanced transcription of cathepsin B and matrix metalloproteinase‑9 and promoting epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition.

Activation-induced degradation of cathepsin B in the HeLa cell line reduces matrix metalloproteinase-2 secretion and enhances type I IFN a/b receptor signaling, thereby attenuating epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase–mediated proliferation.

Activation‑induced expression of the cathepsin B gene in the HNF‑1α‑dependent transcriptional program of HepG2 cells was markedly enhanced by the type I IFN‑α/β receptor ligand, whereas the simultaneous knockdown of CDK6 and its regulator Kip1 attenuated this up‑regulation.

Epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase activation in HeLa cells induces CDK6 expression, which phosphorylates Kip1 to relieve its inhibition of the cell cycle and thereby promotes proliferation, a process that is further modulated by glucocorticoid receptor-interacting protein‑1 acting as a transcriptional co‑activator.

Erdosteine treatment down‑regulates cathepsin B expression in HepG2 cells, thereby mitigating matrix metalloproteinase‑2‑induced extracellular matrix remodeling and reducing hepatic fibrosis in a murine model of carbon tetrachloride‑induced liver injury.
E2F1 transcriptionally activates the CDK6 promoter, thereby increasing CDK6 protein abundance and driving the proliferation of HeLa cells.

Ectopic overexpression of the gene product CDK6 in the HeLa cell line activates the type I IFN a/b receptor signaling cascade, thereby upregulating the matrix metalloproteinase‑2 and −9 enzymes that facilitate tumor cell invasion.
The downregulation of miR‑217 in HeLa cells leads to elevated ERCC5 expression, thereby enhancing DNA repair capacity and conferring resistance to cisplatin treatment.
The overexpression of miR‑217 in HeLa cells downregulates ERCC5, thereby enhancing cisplatin sensitivity and reducing DNA repair capacity.
The miR-217–mediated down‑regulation of ERCC5 in HeLa cells reduces DNA repair capacity, thereby increasing sensitivity to doxorubicin and inducing apoptosis.

The loss‑of‑function mutation in ERCC5 c.1123_1125delCTG creates a premature stop codon that destabilizes the X‑repair protein, leading to increased cellular sensitivity to cisplatin in A549 cells and correlating with higher levels of the DNA damage marker γ‑H2AX.
Mutation of ERCC5 in a HeLa cell line carrying the CDKN2A/B deletion caused an up‑regulation of miR‑217 that, in turn, suppressed PSA expression in the human cancer model.
Mutation in the ERCC5 gene causes increased sensitivity to cisplatin in HeLa cells, where miR‑217 expression is up‑regulated and CDKN2A/B signaling is suppressed, leading to enhanced apoptosis.

Mutation analysis of the ERCC5 c.1454_1456delAGG variant revealed a significant increase in cisplatin sensitivity in A549 cells, indicating that this sequence variant enhances DNA repair capacity and may modulate the response to platinum‑based chemotherapy.

Mutation‑induced down‑regulation of CDKN2A/B by miR‑217 leads to unchecked cell‑cycle progression in HeLa cells, where overexpression of the DNA‑repair gene ERCC5 further enhances survival under doxorubicin stress.
Mutant miR‑217 overexpression in HepG2 cells reduces ERCC5 mRNA stability, thereby enhancing DNA repair deficiency and increasing sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Mutations in the ERCC5 gene that introduce the c.1107G>A sequence variant impair nucleotide excision repair, thereby increasing the risk of skin cancer in individuals carrying the ADORA2A rs5751875 allele.

Mutational loss of the DNA‑repair gene ERCC5 in A549 cells leads to heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, a phenotype that can be rescued by overexpression of the microRNA miR‑217, which targets the translational repressor Bach1.

Mutating the ERCC5 gene in a HeLa cell line carrying the CDKN2A/B deletion enhances DNA repair deficiency and increases sensitivity to cisplatin, thereby suggesting that ERCC5 loss could be exploited as a therapeutic target in chemoresistant cancers.
miR‑217 down‑regulates ERCC5, thereby reducing DNA repair capacity and sensitizing A549 cells to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.
miRNA‐217 downregulates ERCC5 expression, thereby sensitizing A549 cells to cisplatin‐induced apoptosis and reducing CDKN2A/B‑mediated cell‑cycle arrest in vitro.
mi‑217 down‑regulation in A549 cells enhances ERCC5 expression, thereby increasing cisplatin‑induced DNA repair and conferring resistance to apoptosis.
miRNAs such as miR‑217 target the DNA repair enzyme ERCC5, thereby reducing the repair of UV‑induced lesions in skin cells from Homo sapiens and enhancing susceptibility to actinic keratosis.
MicroRNA miR‑217 down‑regulates the DNA‑repair enzyme ERCC5, thereby sensitizing A549 cells to cisplatin-induced apoptosis in a CDKN2A/B‑dependent manner.
Micro‑RNA miR‑217 directly represses ERCC5 transcription, thereby reducing DNA repair capacity and potentiating the oncogenic effects of the CDKN2A/B locus in cultured HeLa cells.
MicroRNAs such as miR‑217 downregulate the DNA‑repair enzyme ERCC5, thereby sensitizing A549 cells to cisplatin and increasing apoptosis in a dose‑dependent manner.
Microglial miR‑217 downregulates ADORA2A expression, thereby attenuating ccl7‑mediated neuroinflammation in a murine model of Parkinson’s disease.
Knock‑down of miR‑217 in HeLa cells upregulates CDKN2A/B transcription, thereby inducing cell‑cycle arrest that is partially rescued by ADORA2A agonist treatment.
Knocking down miR‑217 in HeLa cells upregulates ERCC5 expression, thereby enhancing DNA repair capacity and reducing cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.
Knocked‑down of miR‑217 in A549 cells up‑regulates the DNA‑repair gene ERCC5, thereby attenuating cisplatin‑induced apoptosis and enhancing chemoresistance.
Knox et al. reported that miR‑217 overexpression in HeLa cells suppresses ERCC5 expression, thereby impairing DNA repair and enhancing cisplatin sensitivity in this cervical cancer cell line.
In HepG2 cells, overexpression of miR‑217 down‑regulates the DNA‑repair enzyme ERCC5, thereby sensitizing the cells to cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.
In HeLa cells, miR‑217 overexpression down‑regulates CDKN2A/B, thereby enhancing CDKN2A/B‑mediated apoptosis and reducing PSA secretion in prostate cancer‑derived cell lines.
In human colorectal carcinoma cells, overexpression of miR‑217 suppresses ERCC5 expression, leading to increased sensitivity to DNA‑damaging agents and enhancing the antitumor effect of doxorubicin.
In A549 cells, overexpression of the miR‑217 cluster down‑regulates ERCC5 and ADORA2A, thereby enhancing CDKN2A/B‑mediated senescence and increasing CD200‑mediated immune evasion.

A miR‑217‑mediated suppression of ERCC5 transcription in HeLa cells reduces DNA repair capacity, thereby enhancing cisplatin cytotoxicity and increasing the expression of CDKN2A/B‑regulated senescence markers.

A CRISPR‑mediated knock‑in of the ERCC5 c.1672C>T sequence variant in HeLa cells resulted in a marked increase in UV‑induced DNA repair deficiency, which was rescued by overexpression of miR‑217 that down‑regulates the transcriptional repressor Bach1.

A knock‑down of miR‑217 in A549 cells up‑regulated ERCC5 expression, leading to increased DNA repair capacity and reduced cisplatin‑induced apoptosis, a phenotype that was rescued by overexpressing CDKN2A/B to re‑establish cell cycle arrest.

A loss‑of‑function mutation in ERCC5, which reduces nucleotide excision repair capacity, was found to increase the risk of cisplatin‑induced ototoxicity in patients with the CDKN2A/B promoter polymorphism.
Ectopic overexpression of miR‑217 in A549 cells down‑regulates ERCC5 and CDKN2A/B, leading to reduced DNA repair capacity and increased apoptosis.
Epithelial expression of the microRNA miR‑217 down‑regulates the DNA repair enzyme ERCC5, thereby sensitizing HeLa cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
E2F1 activation in HeLa cells upregulates miR‑217, which targets ERCC5 and consequently sensitizes the cells to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.

Efficacy of miR‑217 overexpression in HeLa cells was demonstrated by the down‑regulation of the DNA repair enzyme ERCC5, which in turn attenuated cisplatin‑induced DNA damage and improved cell survival.
Loss of the ERCC5 gene product in HeLa cells causes accumulation of UV-induced DNA lesions and upregulates miR‑217, which in turn suppresses the expression of the CDKN2A/B tumor‑suppressor complex.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in ERCC5 enhance the sensitivity of A549 cells to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin by impairing the repair of oxidative base lesions and inducing a p53‑dependent apoptosis pathway.

Loss-of-function mutations in the ERCC5 gene impair nucleotide excision repair and are linked to increased sensitivity to ultraviolet‑induced DNA damage, while overexpression of miR‑217 down‑regulates CDKN2A/B and enhances proliferation of HeLa cells.
Losses of miR‑217 expression in HepG2 cells enhance ERCC5 transcription, thereby promoting DNA repair and conferring resistance to doxorubicin in a CDKN2A/B‑dependent manner.
Silencing of miR‑217 in HeLa cells upregulates the DNA‑repair gene ERCC5, thereby enhancing resistance to cisplatin and increasing cell survival during genotoxic stress.
Silently, miR-217 downregulates CDKN2A/B transcription, which in turn alleviates the ERCC5‑mediated DNA repair delay observed in prostate cancer cells overexpressing PSA.
Silencer miR‑217 down‑regulates the DNA repair gene ERCC5, and its loss in CDKN2A/B‑deficient colorectal cells leads to increased susceptibility to cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.
Silenced miR-217 expression in HeLa cells upregulates CDKN2A/B transcription, thereby enhancing CDKN2A/B-mediated senescence and reducing cell proliferation.

Interaction between miR-217 and the ERCC5 mRNA transcript reduces DNA repair capacity in tumor cells, which in turn enhances sensitivity to platinum‑based chemotherapy and leads to a measurable decrease in PSA levels in prostate cancer patients.
Interaction of miR‑217 with the ERCC5 mRNA was shown to down‑regulate DNA repair activity in A549 cells, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.
Interaction studies in HEK293T cells revealed that miR‑217 directly targets the ERCC5 mRNA, decreasing its protein level and thereby sensitizing the cells to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.
Interaction assays revealed that miR‑217 down‑regulates the DNA‑repair gene ERCC5, thereby sensitizing CDKN2A/B‑deficient HCT116 cells to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.
Expression of miR‑217 in HeLa cells reduces ERCC5 mRNA stability, leading to impaired DNA repair and heightened sensitivity to cisplatin.

Expression analysis of miR‑217 revealed that its down‑regulation in ERCC5‑deficient A549 cells leads to increased CDKN2A/B transcription, thereby amplifying senescence‑associated β‑galactosidase activity.
Expression changes of miR‑217 were found to down‑regulate ERCC5, thereby increasing sensitivity of HepG2 cells to doxorubicin treatment.

Expression profiling revealed that miR‑217 suppresses ERCC5, thereby increasing cisplatin sensitivity in A549 cells, a finding that suggests targeting miR‑217 could potentiate chemotherapy in non‑small‑cell lung carcinoma.
Deletion of the CDKN2A/B locus in the HeLa cell line reduces ERCC5 expression, thereby diminishing the cell’s capacity to repair UV-induced DNA damage and increasing sensitivity to cisplatin.
Deletion in the ERCC5 promoter reduces transcription, thereby diminishing DNA repair capacity and increasing susceptibility to cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in Homo sapiens patients.

Deletion c.68_69delAG in the ERCC5 gene leads to reduced DNA repair activity, increasing susceptibility to cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in patients treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
Deletion‑induced loss of the miR‑217 binding site in the ERCC5 transcript causes elevated CDKN2A/B expression, impairing DNA repair in Homo sapiens cells and promoting early tumorigenesis.
Mutations in the ABCA4 gene, such as the c.1801G>A variant, reduce retinal pigment epithelium phagocytosis and thereby accelerate photoreceptor degeneration in patients with retinitis pigmentosa.

Mutual inhibition of the MyD88‑dependent NF‑κB pathway by cortactin overexpression suppresses ABCA4‑mediated cholesterol efflux in retinal pigment epithelial cells, thereby reducing lipofuscin accumulation linked to Stargardt disease.

Mutated ABCA4 c.2576C>T in retinal pigment epithelial cells of a Caucasian patient with Stargardt disease leads to impaired lipid transport, thereby triggering activation of the microglial cytokine IL‑10‑neutralized response that suppresses Rab7‑mediated phagosome maturation and exacerbates photoreceptor degeneration.

Mutational loss of the ABCA4 gene product in retinal pigment epithelium of a Stargardt patient leads to accumulation of lipofuscin and subsequent activation of the LIFR signaling pathway, thereby promoting photoreceptor cell death.
The phosphorylation of LIFR by the kinase MYD88 enhances STAT3 signaling in A549 cells, leading to increased expression of the cytokine IL‑10‑neutralized and promoting chemoresistance to doxorubicin.

The loss‑of‑function mutation BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in the ovarian carcinoma cell line A2780 leads to impaired DNA repair and increased sensitivity to the PARP inhibitor olaparib, illustrating how sequence variant status can dictate therapeutic response.

The MyD88‑dependent signaling cascade is potentiated by cortactin phosphorylation, thereby enhancing IL‑10‑neutralized macrophage migration inhibitory factor release and promoting Rab7‑mediated endosomal trafficking of ABCA4‑associated lipid transport proteins.

The CRISPR‑mediated knockout of **MyD88** in **HeLa** cells led to a dramatic reduction in **IL‑10‑neutralized** macrophage migration, indicating that the **migration inhibitory factor** pathway is downstream of **MyD88**‑dependent signaling.

Mutation of the ABCA4 gene in retinal pigment epithelium cells of a Caucasian patient with Stargardt disease led to mis‑localization of the protein and subsequent accumulation of lipofuscin, which was mitigated by administration of the small‑molecule inhibitor curcumin.
Mutation in the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant reduces the DNA repair activity of the TP53 gene product, thereby increasing apoptosis in the HeLa cell line derived from Homo sapiens.

Mutation‑induced loss of ABCA4 function in retinal pigment epithelium of a patient with Stargardt disease led to accumulation of lipofuscin, which in turn triggered microglial LIFR activation and subsequent up‑regulation of IL‑10‑neutralized anti‑inflammatory signaling that ultimately slowed photoreceptor degeneration.

Mutation analysis of the ABCA4 gene in an ocular cohort revealed a novel c.3241_3242delCT variant that correlates with reduced retinoid transport and early-onset macular degeneration in Homo sapiens retinal pigment epithelium cells.

Disruption of the ABCA4 promoter by the c.5714C>T sequence variant reduces transcription, leading to a loss of the ABCA4 protein product that impairs photoreceptor lipid transport and causes retinitis pigmentosa.

Disruptive mutations in the ABCA4 gene, such as the c.5718C>T (p.Ala1906Val) SequenceVariant, compromise retinal pigment epithelium function in patients with Stargardt disease, as confirmed by decreased rhodopsin recycling and increased photoreceptor apoptosis in A549 CellLine cultures derived from affected Homo sapiens donors.

Disrupted phosphorylation of the MyD88 signaling complex by a missense variant in the N-terminal TIR domain of LIFR reduces downstream NF‑κB activation and attenuates migration inhibitory factor‑mediated chemotaxis in A549 cells.

Disabling the MyD88-mediated signaling pathway in HeLa cells reduces cortactin‑dependent migration, thereby attenuating IL‑10‑neutralized cytokine release and restoring ABCA4‑driven cholesterol transport in a humanized E. coli model.

MyD88, a key adaptor protein in Toll‑like receptor signaling, binds to the pro‑inflammatory adaptor cortactin, thereby amplifying NF‑κB activation and enhancing IL‑10‑neutralized cytokine release in macrophages infected with *Salmonella enterica*.
Myeloma‑derived plasma cells overexpress MyD88, which in turn activates NF‑κB signaling and up‑regulates the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑XL, thereby promoting chemoresistance in MM patients.
Myc‑induced down‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 in HeLa cells leads to increased cortactin‑mediated invadopodia formation, thereby enhancing cell migration and invasion.

MyB cell lines transfected with a plasmid encoding the MyD88 adaptor protein displayed increased phosphorylation of the Smad1 signaling cascade, leading to enhanced expression of the cytokine IL‑10 and subsequent suppression of migration inhibitory factor in an ABCA4‑deficient E. coli model.

In HeLa cells, the MyD88‑dependent signaling pathway activates Smad1 phosphorylation, which in turn up‑regulates ABCA4 expression, thereby enhancing cellular cholesterol efflux and reducing migration inhibitory factor‑induced cytoskeletal remodeling.

In A549 cells, MyD88 overexpression enhances cortactin phosphorylation, leading to increased Rab7‑mediated endosomal trafficking that promotes LIFR‑dependent STAT3 activation and ultimately drives IL‑10‑neutralized macrophage recruitment to the tumor microenvironment.

In HepG2 cells, activation of the MyD88‑dependent NF‑κB pathway by LPS induces phosphorylation of cortactin, which in turn promotes Rab7‑mediated autophagic clearance of misfolded ABCA4 protein, thereby alleviating cellular toxicity associated with retinal dystrophy.

In breast cancer cell line MCF‑7, overexpression of the transcription factor c‑Myc upregulates ABCA4 and increases resistance to doxorubicin, an effect that is partially reversed by IL‑10‑neutralized antibody treatment.

A genetic study of MYD88 and cortactin polymorphisms in a cohort of *Homo sapiens* patients with ulcerative colitis revealed that the MYD88 c.284C>T variant (p.Arg95Cys) increases susceptibility to dysregulated NF‑κB signaling, whereas cortactin overexpression in *A549* cells enhances chemotactic migration via Rac1‑dependent lamellipodia formation.

A polymorphism in the ABCA4 gene that disrupts the N-terminal transmembrane domain impairs the retinal pigment epithelium’s ability to transport vitamin A derivatives, thereby increasing susceptibility to retinitis pigmentosa in Homo sapiens patients.

A gain‑of‑function mutation in the MyD88 gene product, identified in a patient with a severe autoinflammatory phenotype, leads to hyperactivation of NF‑κB signaling and up‑regulation of the anti‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑10, thereby illustrating how sequence variants in innate immune genes can modulate disease severity.

A conditional knockout of the MyD88 gene in A549 cells reduces cortactin‑dependent migration while simultaneously increasing ABCA4 expression, thereby attenuating LIFR‑mediated inflammatory signaling in a manner that mimics the effects of IL‑10 neutralization and Rab7‑regulated lysosomal trafficking.

Impaired MyD88 signaling in A549 cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor curcumin induces up‑regulation of the migration‑inhibitory factor, thereby reducing cortactin‑mediated actin polymerization and cell motility.

Immunofluorescence staining of HeLa cells revealed that the knockdown of MyD88 by siRNA markedly reduced cortactin‑dependent actin polymerization, thereby impairing IL‑10‑neutralized macrophage migration.

Impairment of the MyD88‑dependent pathway by cortactin overexpression in HeLa cells increases ABCA4 transcription, thereby enhancing cholesterol efflux and reducing LIFR‑mediated neuroinflammation in a model of retinal degeneration.
Imbalance of MyD88 signaling in HeLa cells expressing the ABCA4 c.1024C>T variant increases cortactin‑mediated migration and elevates IL‑10‐neutralized inflammatory cytokine secretion.

Altered phosphorylation of MyD88 by the protein kinase CK2 in A549 cells reduces NF‑κB activation and consequently down‑regulates IL‑10 production, a change that can exacerbate LIFR‑mediated inflammatory responses in cultured Human hepatocytes.

Alterations in the MyD88‑dependent signaling cascade, triggered by cortactin‑mediated endocytosis of the LIFR receptor, were found to suppress IL‑10‑neutralized macrophage migration inhibitory factor production in a human THP‑1 cell line, thereby enhancing the activation of the Rab7‑associated autophagic pathway.

Alteration of the MyD88 gene product by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in E. coli-derived plasmids markedly decreases IL‑10‑neutralized signaling, thereby enhancing cortactin‑mediated migration inhibitory factor release in HeLa cells.
Altering the phosphorylation of MyD88 by cortactin in A549 cells decreases IL‑10‑neutralized NF‑κB activity, thereby enhancing LIFR‑dependent cell migration.

Loss of the Rab7-mediated endosomal trafficking of the MyD88 adaptor protein in HeLa cells results in a marked reduction of IL‑10‑neutralized NF‑κB activation and promotes migration inhibitory factor‑induced apoptosis, thereby implicating Rab7 as a potential therapeutic target for inflammatory disease.

Loss-of-function mutations in ABCA4 in the retinas of a patient with Stargardt disease reduced photoreceptor outer segment turnover, causing the accumulation of lipofuscin and subsequent degeneration of cone photoreceptors.
