Loss‑of‑function mutation in the ABCA4 gene leads to retinoid accumulation, which in turn activates MyD88‑dependent signaling and upregulates migration inhibitory factor expression in retinal pigment epithelium cells.

Lossy degradation of the BRCA1 gene product was detected in the HeLa cell line, where a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant induced aberrant splicing and led to a truncated protein that compromised DNA repair and increased the sensitivity of the cells to doxorubicin.

Silencing of the MYD88 gene in A549 cells markedly reduced migration inhibitory factor secretion, thereby impairing IL‑10‑neutralized macrophage recruitment and increasing susceptibility to NTH‑induced apoptosis.

Silenced MYD88 expression in HeLa cells markedly reduces cortactin‑mediated invasion, a phenotype that can be rescued by transfecting the LIFR variant p.R1036C, revealing a regulatory axis involving NTH‑mediated DNA repair and Rab7‑dependent endosomal trafficking.

Silently, the MyD88‑dependent activation of the NF‑κB pathway in HeLa cells expressing a mutant LIFR allele containing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant leads to up‑regulation of the anti‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑10, thereby dampening migration inhibitory factor‑mediated neutrophil recruitment.

Sil12‑derived CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the **MYD88** gene in the **A549** cell line revealed that loss of the LRR domain reduces **cortactin**‑mediated actin remodeling, thereby impairing cell migration and decreasing **IL‑10**‑neutralized macrophage activation, while concomitant up‑regulation of **Rab7**‑dependent lysosomal degradation of **LIFR** leads to attenuated STAT3 signaling and heightened apoptosis in

Overexpression of the gene product MyD88 in HeLa cells enhances cortactin‑mediated Rac1 activation, leading to increased cell migration and invasion that are dependent on the signaling of the LIFR/IL‑10‑neutralized pathway.

Overactivation of the MyD88‑dependent NF‑κB pathway in HeLa cells increases cortactin phosphorylation, thereby enhancing Rab7‑mediated endosomal trafficking of ABCA4‑derived lysophospholipids and potentiating IL‑10‑neutralized inflammatory responses.

Overactivated MyD88 in THP‑1 cells enhances cortactin‑driven actin remodeling, thereby accelerating LIFR‑mediated migration inhibitory factor signaling and potentiating IL‑10‑neutralized suppression of Rab7‑dependent autophagic flux.

Overexpressed MyD88 in HeLa cells activates the NF‑κB pathway, inducing IL‑10‑neutralized migration inhibitory factor secretion that suppresses cortactin‑driven actin polymerization and enhances Rab7‑mediated endosomal trafficking of the ABCA4 transporter, thereby altering cellular signaling in Homo sapiens.

Knocking out the MYD88 gene in A549 cells markedly reduced cortactin‑mediated migration, an effect that was rescued by exogenous LIFR signaling and confirmed by a loss‑of‑function mutation in the ABCA4 promoter.

Knock‑down of the MyD88‑dependent signaling adaptor MyD88 in LIFR‑expressing A549 cells reduces cortactin‑mediated actin remodeling and thereby attenuates IL‑10‑neutralized inflammatory cytokine release, illustrating how MYD88 and LIFR interactions can modulate cellular migration and immune responses in a human lung carcinoma context.

Knox et al. observed that in A549 cells the MyD88‑dependent activation of NF‑κB by LIFR stimulation leads to increased cortactin phosphorylation, thereby enhancing Rab7‑mediated endosomal trafficking of the ABCA4‑derived lipid substrate.

Knocked‑down of the MyD88 gene product in HeLa cells markedly reduces the migration inhibitory factor‑induced activation of Smad1, illustrating a novel regulatory pathway for IL‑10‑neutralized inflammatory signaling.

Interaction of the MyD88 signaling complex with the cortactin cytoskeletal scaffold is enhanced by the LIFR‑dependent phosphorylation of the ABCA4 transporter, thereby promoting Rab7‑mediated endosomal trafficking of the migration inhibitory factor and its downstream Smad1 signaling, which ultimately modulates IL‑10‑neutralized inflammatory responses in human keratinocytes.

Interaction studies revealed that MYD88 activation in HeLa cells upregulates ABCA4 expression through a Smad1‑dependent transcriptional pathway, thereby enhancing cellular migration and cytokine secretion.

Interaction between the adaptor protein MyD88 and the scaffold protein cortactin enhances IL‑10‑neutralized macrophage migration in Homo sapiens, revealing a potential regulatory axis for Nth‑mediated DNA repair.

Interaction assays demonstrated that overexpression of the MyD88 adaptor protein in A549 cells increased NF‑κB‑driven transcription of IL‑10, which in turn suppressed cortactin‑mediated migration of the epithelial carcinoma cell line.

JNK‑dependent phosphorylation of EGFR by CBR3 in HeLa cells enhances VEGFR2‑mediated angiogenic signaling, a process that is further amplified by regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4 acting on the G protein‑coupled receptor complex.
J‑NK‑dependent phosphorylation of the regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4 protein in EGFR‑overexpressing A549 cells enhances VEGFR2‑mediated endothelial proliferation, thereby promoting angiogenesis.

JAK2 phosphorylation of VEGFR2 is enhanced by EGFR‐mediated crosstalk, causing a JNK‑dependent upregulation of CCL8 that recruits monocytes expressing angiotensin I‑converting enzyme and RGS4, thereby amplifying inflammatory signaling in human endothelial cells.

JUN kinase (JNK)-dependent phosphorylation of EGFR enhances VEGFR2-mediated angiogenic signaling in human umbilical vein endothelial cells, a process that is inhibited by the G protein-coupled receptor regulator RGS4.
The JNK‑dependent activation of EGFR in HeLa cells upregulates VEGFR2 expression, thereby enhancing CCL8 secretion and promoting angiogenic signaling mediated by angiotensin I‑converting enzyme.
The overexpression of VEGFR2 in A549 cells leads to JNK‑dependent phosphorylation of EGFR, thereby enhancing CCL8 secretion and promoting chemotaxis of immune cells toward the tumor microenvironment.
The EGFR‑regulated VEGFR2 phosphorylation in HeLa cells is inhibited by a JNK‑dependent pathway that up‑regulates regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4 expression, thereby reducing CCL8 secretion.

The down‑regulation of VEGFR2 in EGFR‑mutant A549 cells is mediated by a JNK‑dependent, regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4–induced CCL8 secretion, which in turn activates angiotensin I‑converting enzyme and promotes CBR3‑driven cell migration.
EGFR activation in HeLa cells upregulates VEGFR2 expression through a JNK‑dependent, regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4 mediated pathway, leading to increased CCL8 secretion.

EGF-mediated activation of EGFR triggers JNK-dependent phosphorylation of regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4, which subsequently up‑regulates CCL8 expression in the VEGFR2‑expressing endothelial cells.

EGRA‑treated A549 cells displayed increased JNK‑dependent phosphorylation of VEGFR2, leading to up‑regulated CCL8 secretion that further enhanced EGFR‑mediated proliferation in a B1‑regulated, angiotensin‑converting‑enzyme‑dependent manner.

EGCG treatment of A549 cells downregulates EGFR and upregulates regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4, thereby reducing JNK‑dependent CCL8 secretion and enhancing angiotensin‑I‑converting‑enzyme activity, a modulation that may attenuate VEGFR2‑mediated angiogenesis in this lung cancer model.

In the MCF-7 cell line, overexpression of VEGFR2 phosphorylates downstream EGFR signaling pathways, thereby enhancing JNK‑dependent apoptosis while simultaneously upregulating CCL8 secretion to recruit tumor‑associated macrophages.
In HeLa cells, overexpression of EGFR activates JNK-dependent phosphorylation of Cdh1, which then enhances the degradation of VEGFR2 and reduces downstream angiogenic signaling.

In A549 cells, EGFR activation induces JNK-dependent phosphorylation of VEGFR2, which then upregulates CCL8 secretion and enhances angiotensin I-converting enzyme expression, ultimately promoting tumor-associated angiogenesis.

In HepG2 cells, activation of EGFR by EGF induces JNK-dependent phosphorylation of VEGFR2, thereby upregulating CCL8 secretion while simultaneously enhancing angiotensin‑converting enzyme expression through regulator‑of‑G‑protein‑signaling‑4‑mediated signaling.

Activation of EGFR by CCL8 in HeLa cells induces a JNK-dependent up‑regulation of VEGFR2, which is further potentiated by the regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4 and the angiotensin‑I‑converting‑enzyme, leading to enhanced angiogenic signaling in the tumor microenvironment.

Activation‐dependent phosphorylation of the receptor tyrosine kinase EGFR in A549 cells stimulates JNK‐dependent transcription of CCL8, thereby recruiting neutrophils through a G protein‑coupled receptor that is up‑regulated by the regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4 complex.

Activation‑dependent phosphorylation of the VEGFR2 tyrosine kinase by EGFR in A549 cells triggers JNK‑dependent transcription of the chemokine CCL8, thereby enhancing tumor‑cell invasiveness through up‑regulation of the regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4 pathway.

Activation by the tyrosine‑kinase ligand EGF of the EGFR on A549 cells upregulates the transcription of VEGFR2, which in turn stimulates a JNK‑dependent signaling cascade that increases CCL8 secretion and promotes G‑protein‑coupled receptor–mediated angiogenesis.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the EGFR signaling pathway, such as a JNK‑dependent phosphorylation defect in VEGFR2, have been shown to up‑regulate CCL8 secretion in A549 cells, thereby exacerbating angiotensin I‑converting enzyme‑mediated hypertension in E. coli‑infected mice.

Loss of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 in A549 cells activates JNK-dependent transcription of the chemokine CCL8, thereby stimulating VEGFR2-mediated angiogenesis in a EGFR-heterodimerized microenvironment.

Loss-of-function mutations in the VEGFR2 gene (KDR) in HepG2 cells reduce EGFR‑dependent phosphorylation of JNK‑dependent signaling cascades, thereby attenuating CCL8 secretion and impairing angiotensin‑I‑converting enzyme activity.

Loss‐of‑function mutations in the tumor suppressor gene Cdh1, which encodes an E3 ubiquitin ligase that regulates the G‑protein‑coupled receptor EGFR, result in uncontrolled JNK‑dependent phosphorylation of VEGFR2 and over‑production of the chemokine CCL8, thereby promoting angiogenesis in colorectal carcinoma cells.
A JNK‑dependent phosphorylation of EGFR by a regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4 enhances VEGFR2‑mediated angiogenesis in A549 cells, a process that is attenuated by the CBR3 inhibitor CBR3‑i1.
A missense mutation in VEGFR2 reduces its tyrosine kinase activity, causing impaired angiogenic signaling and exacerbating ischemic injury in a mouse model that was treated with a CBR3 inhibitor.
A gain‑of‑function mutation in the VEGFR2 coding sequence drives JNK‑dependent phosphorylation of CCL8, thereby enhancing tumor cell invasion in HeLa cells.

A single‑cell CRISPR knock‑out of VEGFR2 in A549 cells reduced EGFR‑mediated JNK‑dependent phosphorylation of CCL8, thereby attenuating downstream angiogenic signaling and suppressing tumor‑derived VEGFR2 expression in the human lung carcinoma microenvironment.
Mutation of the VEGFR2 gene product in human endothelial cells disrupts JNK‑dependent signaling and induces CCL8 secretion, thereby enhancing angiogenic sprouting.
Mutation in the VEGFR2 promoter of *Homo sapiens* cells reduces EGFR‑induced phosphorylation of JNK‑dependent downstream targets, thereby impairing CCL8 secretion from endothelial cells.

Mutation‑induced alteration of VEGFR2 signaling in A549 cells leads to JNK‑dependent upregulation of CCL8, which subsequently activates angiotensin I‑converting enzyme expression and enhances EGFR‑mediated proliferation.

Mutation analysis revealed that the VEGFR2 variant c.1451G>A in the Homo sapiens patient altered EGFR signaling through a JNK-dependent pathway, thereby increasing CCL8 expression and contributing to the observed hypertension.

Mutations in VEGFR2 that disrupt JNK‑dependent phosphorylation of the receptor’s intracellular domain impair downstream signaling, thereby reducing angiogenic sprouting in EGFR‑overexpressing HeLa cells and increasing sensitivity to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib.

Mutational analysis revealed that the EGFR exon‑19 deletion in H1299 cells upregulated VEGFR2 expression through a JNK‑dependent pathway, thereby enhancing CCL8 secretion and promoting angiotensin I‑converting enzyme activity.

Mutagenic exposure to doxorubicin in A549 cells upregulates VEGFR2 and EGFR transcription while simultaneously increasing the expression of the regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4, thereby amplifying JNK‑dependent CCL8 secretion in a dose‑dependent manner.

Mutant VEGFR2 kinase activity in A549 cells triggers JNK-dependent apoptosis, and this effect is rescued by the G protein‑coupled receptor agonist CBR3, revealing a novel regulatory axis for EGFR‑mediated cell survival.

Altered expression of VEGFR2 in the A549 cell line was found to be downstream of JNK‑dependent activation of EGFR, thereby enhancing CCL8 secretion by an EGFR‑regulated G‑protein‑coupled receptor pathway in Homo sapiens cells.

Alterations in EGFR signaling that activate JNK-dependent transcription of VEGFR2 in the Cdh1-deficient HeLa cell line lead to up‑regulation of angiotensin I‑converting enzyme expression, thereby enhancing CCL8 secretion and driving a pro‑inflammatory phenotype.
Alteration of the VEGFR2 gene product by a JNK‑dependent phosphorylation event in HeLa cells enhances EGFR‑mediated downstream signaling, thereby promoting proliferation.

Alterantive splicing of the VEGFR2 gene in HeLa cells is up‑regulated by JNK‑dependent phosphorylation of Cdh1, thereby enhancing angiogenic signaling through the EGFR‑activated G‑protein‑coupled receptor pathway.
Knockdown of VEGFR2 in HeLa cells suppresses JNK-dependent phosphorylation of CCL8, thereby reducing EGFR‑mediated migration.
Knocking down EGFR in A549 cells reduces VEGFR2 expression through a JNK‑dependent pathway, thereby attenuating angiogenic signaling in this lung cancer model.

Knocked‑down of VEGFR2 in A549 cells downregulated CCL8 expression through a JNK‑dependent, EGFR‑mediated signaling cascade, thereby attenuating the angiogenic response in this human lung carcinoma model.
Knox1-mediated upregulation of VEGFR2 in A549 cells triggers JNK-dependent phosphorylation of CCL8, thereby enhancing EGFR signaling and promoting invasive tumor phenotypes.

KRAS G12D mutation in the A549 cell line amplifies JNK‑dependent signaling, leading to up‑regulation of VEGFR2 and CCL8 expression while concurrently suppressing EGFR‑mediated proliferation in a HeLa‑derived xenograft model.
KRAB‑domain protein ZNF281, a transcriptional repressor, was shown to bind the promoter of **VEGFR2** in **A549** cells, thereby suppressing angiogenic signaling downstream of **EGFR** activation.
KRIBB1‑mediated phosphorylation of VEGFR2 enhances JNK‑dependent phosphorylation of EGFR, thereby increasing CCL8 transcription in HeLa cells exposed to angiotensin I‑converting enzyme inhibitors.

KR27‑1‑HeLa cells treated with an EGFR‑specific inhibitor exhibited reduced phosphorylation of VEGFR2, a JNK‑dependent decrease in CCL8 secretion, and a marked up‑regulation of the regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4 gene product.

Silencing of VEGFR2 in A549 cells triggers JNK‑dependent apoptosis and upregulates the chemokine CCL8, indicating that EGFR‑mediated signaling may counteract this pro‑apoptotic pathway in human carcinoma.
Silenced VEGFR2 expression in A549 cells attenuates JNK‑dependent apoptosis, a phenotype rescued by ectopic EGFR overexpression that restores downstream ERK signaling and reduces CCL8 secretion.
Silvestrol downregulates VEGFR2 expression in A549 cells, thereby suppressing JNK‑dependent signaling that otherwise promotes CCL8 secretion.

Silence of VEGFR2 in A549 cells diminishes EGFR‑mediated proliferation by impairing JNK‑dependent phosphorylation of the CCL8‑responsive G protein‑coupled receptor, thereby attenuating downstream angiotensin‑I‑converting‑enzyme signaling.

Downregulation of EGFR and JNK-dependent VEGFR2 phosphorylation in A549 cells by the small‑molecule inhibitor CBR3 reduces CCL8 secretion and consequently attenuates angiotensin I-converting enzyme expression in the tumor microenvironment.

Down-regulation of EGFR by JNK-dependent phosphorylation of regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4 in A549 cells reduces VEGFR2‑mediated angiogenic signaling, thereby suppressing CCL8 secretion and angiotensin I‑converting enzyme expression.

Downregulated expression of VEGFR2 in HeLa cells treated with the EGFR inhibitor erlotinib was accompanied by increased JNK-dependent phosphorylation of CCL8, suggesting a regulatory network involving the angiotensin I-converting enzyme and G protein-coupled receptor signaling.
Downstream activation of VEGFR2 by EGFR-mediated phosphorylation induces JNK‑dependent up‑regulation of CCL8, a process attenuated by the regulator of G‑protein signaling‑4 complex in A549 cells.

The downregulation of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor subunit GRIN2B in PHEX‑deficient osteoblasts leads to impaired bone mineralization and promotes the up‑regulation of the actin‑binding protein CTTN, thereby contributing to the skeletal phenotype observed in X‑linked hypophosphatemic rickets.

The study showed that overexpression of the PHEX gene product in HeLa cells increased the phosphorylation of the retinoic acid receptor, thereby enhancing the transcription of the EPO-induced CCL4 gene.

The PHEX mutation c.1402G>A was found to disrupt retinoic acid receptor signaling in a cohort of patients with X‑linked hypophosphatemia, leading to elevated serum phosphate and increased expression of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor subunit NR1 in bone‑derived osteoblasts.

The retinoic acid receptor alpha variant c.1234C>T in a patient with Bardet‑Biedl syndrome (BBS) was found to up‑regulate PHEX transcription, thereby reducing phosphate excretion and contributing to the observed renal calcinosis.

In PC12 cells, retinoic acid receptor activation upregulates the expression of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor subunit NR2B, thereby enhancing calcium influx and potentiating the phosphorylation of DUSP1, which subsequently attenuates MAPK signaling and promotes neuronal differentiation.
In neuroblastoma cells, PHEX overexpression reduces glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor phosphorylation, thereby attenuating retinoic acid receptor‑mediated differentiation signals.
In HeLa cells, EPO-induced upregulation of the retinoic acid receptor downregulates laminin alpha-2 expression, thereby disrupting the actin-binding protein network and reducing cell adhesion.

In CHO cells, overexpression of the PHEX gene product decreases intracellular phosphate, thereby upregulating the retinoic acid receptor and enhancing glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor activity, which ultimately alters laminin alpha‑2–mediated cell adhesion.

PHEX mutations disrupt the regulation of bone mineralization, while retinoic acid receptor activation of the NMDA receptor pathway in neuronal cultures increases CCL4 secretion, suggesting a potential link between bone‑related gene products and neuroinflammatory signaling in schizophrenia.

P53‑mediated transcriptional upregulation of the EPO‑induced gene dusp1 in HeLa cells treated with retinoic acid receptor agonist reduces NMDA‑receptor‑mediated calcium influx, thereby attenuating the apoptotic phenotype observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑1‑deficient fibroblasts.

PBRM1 mutations in a renal carcinoma cell line derived from a patient with von Hippel‑Lindau disease lead to aberrant binding of the retinoic acid receptor to the EPAS1 promoter, resulting in increased hypoxia‑inducible factor‑2α expression and accelerated tumor growth.

PHEXT, a member of the phosphatase gene family, phosphorylates the retinoic acid receptor β1 in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing the expression of glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor subunit NR1 and reducing laminin alpha‑2 deposition, a mechanism that may contribute to the actin‑binding protein dysfunction observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome.

Deletion of the PHEX promoter creates a loss‑of‑function allele that disrupts the interaction between PHEX protein and the retinoic acid receptor, thereby reducing expression of the NMDA receptor subunit GRIN1 in cortical neurons and contributing to the cognitive deficits observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome patients.

Deletion in the PHEX gene disrupts the interaction between the retinoic acid receptor and the laminin alpha‑2 promoter, thereby reducing EPO‑induced expression of the actin‑binding protein and attenuating NMDA‑receptor‑mediated synaptic plasticity in a murine model of Bardet‑Biedl syndrome.

Deletion or mutation of the PHEX gene reduces phosphate homeostasis, thereby enhancing retinoic acid receptor signaling that modulates NMDA receptor trafficking and is linked to altered laminin‑alpha‑2 expression in cortical neurons.

Deletion upstream of the PHEX promoter in a patient with X‑linked hypophosphatemia results in reduced expression of the phosphate transporter and increased circulating fibroblast growth factor‑23, thereby aggravating the hypophosphatemic phenotype.

A mutation in the PHEX gene that disrupts its binding to the retinoic acid receptor leads to increased expression of the NMDA receptor subunit and subsequent neuronal hyperexcitability, contributing to the severe cognitive deficits observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome.

A genetic variant in the PHEX gene that reduces its expression leads to hyperphosphatemia in X‑linked hypophosphatemic rickets, which in turn enhances activation of the retinoic acid receptor, thereby increasing the transcription of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor subunits in cortical neurons.

A PHEX mutation in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome patients leads to decreased activation of retinoic acid receptor signaling, which in turn down‑regulates glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor expression and reduces laminin alpha‑2 deposition in the retina, thereby contributing to the visual deficits observed in this disorder.

A CRISPR/Cas9‑mediated knockout of PHEX in human kidney cell lines led to up‑regulation of the retinoic acid receptor alpha and increased secretion of CCL4, suggesting a novel regulatory loop that may contribute to the renal bone disease observed in X‑linked hypophosphatemia.
DUSP1 phosphorylation of the retinoic acid receptor in HeLa cells enhances NMDA‑receptor‑mediated calcium influx, thereby promoting apoptosis in response to EPO‑induced oxidative stress.

Dyskinesia in patients with PHEX mutations is alleviated by retinoic acid receptor agonists, which reduce glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor activation and normalize laminin alpha‑2 expression in the affected kidney.
DUSP1 phosphorylation by retinoic acid receptor signaling in HeLa cells reduces NMDA receptor subunit NR2B expression, thereby attenuating glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity.

Dysregulation of the retinoic acid receptor by the PHEX‑mediated degradation of the laminin alpha‑2 fragment alters NMDA receptor trafficking, thereby contributing to the synaptic deficits observed in schizophrenia‑1.

Loss of the X‑linked PHEX gene in a patient with X‑linked hypophosphatemia leads to up‑regulation of the type IIa collagenase MMP-2, thereby enhancing laminin alpha‑2 degradation and compromising renal phosphate reabsorption.

Loss-of-function mutations in PHEX disrupt phosphate regulation in bone, leading to hypophosphatemic rickets and increased expression of the retinoic acid receptor, which in turn upregulates the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor subunits and the actin‑binding protein laminin alpha‑2, thereby exacerbating neuronal dysfunction in patients with Bardet‑Biedl syndrome.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in **PHEX** lead to ectopic deposition of bone matrix in renal tissue, which in turn upregulates the expression of the **glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor** and the **retinoic acid receptor** in adjacent tubular epithelial cells, a finding that suggests a potential link between phosphate metabolism and neuronal‑like signaling pathways in the kidney.

Loss‐of‑function mutations in PHEX impair phosphatase activity, leading to ectopic calcium deposition that disrupts the activity of the retinoic acid receptor in osteoblasts and ultimately increases the risk of renal stone formation in patients with X‑linked hypophosphatemia.

Mutations in the PHEX gene alter phosphate transport in bone, leading to ectopic mineralization that upregulates expression of the retinoic acid receptor and subsequently enhances NMDA receptor signaling in cortical neurons.

Mutual inhibition of PHEX transcription by retinoic acid receptor activation and glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor signaling in HeLa cells leads to increased intracellular calcium, which further down‑regulates laminin alpha‑2 expression and drives a cascade that elevates dusp1 phosphorylation, ultimately contributing to the epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition characteristic of metastatic colorectal carcinoma.

Mutational analysis of the PHEX gene in a cohort of patients with X‑linked hypophosphatemia revealed a recurrent c.1224_1226delGAG variant that abolishes the glutamate‑N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor‑binding domain of the encoded protein, thereby impairing its role in bone mineralization and leading to early‑onset osteomalacia.

Mutant PHEX protein lacking the C‑terminal domain was shown to disrupt the interaction between the retinoic acid receptor and the laminin alpha‑2 promoter, thereby reducing EPO‑induced erythropoietin expression in cultured HeLa cells.

Altered expression of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor subunit GRIN2B, induced by EPO‑mediated phosphorylation of the transcription factor DUSP1, is associated with synaptic dysfunction observed in schizophrenia patients carrying a PHEX loss‑of‑function variant.

Alterations in the PHEX gene product impair phosphatase activity, reducing bone mineralization and triggering up‑regulation of the retinoic acid receptor in osteoblasts, thereby exacerbating osteopenia in patients with X‑linked hypophosphatemia.

Alteration of the PHEX gene product by a c.1156C>T sequence variant disrupts its interaction with the retinoic acid receptor, thereby reducing bone mineralization in patients with X‑linked hypophosphatemia.

Alterly, the up‑regulation of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor by retinoic acid receptor agonists in neuronal cultures derived from human iPSC‑derived cortical neurons carrying a PHEX loss‑of‑function variant leads to increased intracellular calcium influx and subsequent activation of the dual‑specificity phosphatase dUSP1, thereby attenuating the pro‑inflammatory cytokine CCL4 secretion and improving neurite outgrowth in vitro.

Disruption of the PHEX gene product in bone‑derived cell lines treated with retinoic acid receptor agonists upregulates NMDA receptor subunits and reduces laminin alpha‑2 expression, thereby impairing osteoblast adhesion and contributing to the bone‑density phenotype observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑associated kidney dysfunction.

Disruptive missense variants in the PHEX gene, which encodes a phosphaturic endopeptidase that modulates phosphate homeostasis, were found to upregulate the expression of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor subunit NR2B in cultured cortical neurons, thereby enhancing excitotoxic signaling in a model of neurodegeneration.

Disrupted expression of the retinoic acid receptor in HeLa cells treated with EPO‑induced differentiation media leads to altered transcription of the PHEX gene, a finding that may help explain the abnormal bone mineralization observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome patients.

Disabling a loss‑of‑function mutation in the PHEX gene causes ectopic bone formation in osteoblasts, which is mitigated by retinoic acid receptor agonists that down‑regulate the transcription of the downstream gene dusp1 and restore normal mineralization.

Mutation in the PHEX gene that truncates its C‑terminal domain disrupts the normal trafficking of the retinoic acid receptor to the nucleus, thereby reducing transcription of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor subunit and contributing to the synaptic deficits observed in schizophrenia‑1 patients.

Mutation of the PHEX gene in the X‑linked hypophosphatemic osteomalacia patient disrupted the binding of retinoic acid receptor β, leading to reduced transcription of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor subunit GluN1 and consequently impaired synaptic plasticity in cortical neurons.

Mutation EPO-induced activation of the retinoic acid receptor in PHEX‑expressing HeLa cells upregulates the NMDA receptor subunit NR2B and increases CCL4 secretion, thereby enhancing laminin alpha‑2 deposition and actin‑binding protein remodeling in the tumor microenvironment.

Mutation‑induced down‑regulation of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor in HeLa cells leads to altered calcium signaling, a phenomenon that may contribute to EPO‑induced neuronal differentiation via PHEX‑mediated modulation of laminin alpha‑2 assembly.

GluN2B, the subunit of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor, is up‑regulated by retinoic acid receptor β activation in neuronal cultures derived from human induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived cortical organoids, and this up‑regulation is attenuated by the actin‑binding protein α‑actinin‑1, thereby modulating NMDA‑mediated synaptic plasticity.

GFP‑tagged laminin alpha‑2, when overexpressed in the A549 cell line, activates the retinoic acid receptor‑mediated transcription of the PHEX gene, thereby increasing EPO‑induced erythropoiesis in vitro.

Glycine at position Arg90 of the PHEX protein is substituted by a cysteine (PHEX p.Arg90Cys), disrupting its interaction with the retinoic acid receptor and thereby impairing osteoclast differentiation in a subset of patients with X‑linked hypophosphatemia.

GADD45B overexpression in the A549 cell line was found to attenuate NMDA‑receptor–mediated excitotoxicity by up‑regulating the phosphatase DUSP1, thereby reducing apoptosis in a model of neurodegenerative stress.

Retinoic acid receptor activation in HeLa cells upregulates the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor subunit NR2B, thereby enhancing intracellular calcium influx and promoting laminin alpha‑2‑mediated cell adhesion.

Retinal dysfunction in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome patients is linked to decreased expression of the retinoic acid receptor‑α in retinal pigmented epithelial cells, suggesting that impaired PHEX‑mediated regulation of glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor subunits may alter NMDA‑dependent signaling and contribute to the retinal phenotypic features.

Retinoblastoma protein phosphorylates the retinoic acid receptor in a PHEX‑dependent manner, thereby modulating glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor signaling in neurons derived from the human cell line SH‑SY5Y.

Retrospective analysis of PHEX expression in renal cell carcinoma demonstrated that up‑regulation of the gene product enhances EPO‑induced erythropoietic signaling and correlates with reduced patient survival.

Overexpression of the gene‑product DUSP1 in A549 cells treated with retinoic acid receptor agonist ATRA enhances glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor phosphorylation, thereby increasing cellular resistance to EPO‑induced apoptosis.

Overactivation of the retinoic acid receptor in HeLa cells carrying the PHEX mutation leads to increased expression of the glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate (NMDA) receptor subunit and concomitant upregulation of the actin‑binding protein dystrophin, thereby enhancing cellular susceptibility to excitotoxic damage.

Overexpressed PHEX in HeLa cells upregulates retinoic acid receptor signaling, which in turn enhances NMDA receptor trafficking to the synaptic membrane and increases laminin alpha‑2 secretion, thereby promoting actin cytoskeleton remodeling and facilitating EPO‑induced erythropoiesis.

Over a decade of CRISPR‑Cas9 editing in HeLa cells revealed that disruption of the PHEX gene enhances retinoic‑acid‑receptor‑α‑mediated transcription, thereby increasing glutamate N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate‑receptor subunit expression and accelerating laminin‑alpha‑2 deposition, a mechanism that may underlie EPO‑induced neuroprotection observed in neuronal‑cell‑line models.
DMC1 deficiency in Homo sapiens fibroblasts leads to impaired homologous recombination, elevating γ‑H2AX foci and reducing cell survival after ionizing radiation.

DMD‑associated exon skipping induced by antisense oligonucleotide therapy upregulates DMC1 expression in patient‑derived myoblasts, thereby enhancing homologous recombination and potentially ameliorating muscle fiber integrity in Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

D‑Methyl‑cysteine‑induced overexpression of the DNA repair gene DMC1 in HepG2 cells upregulated the p62/SQSTM1‑mediated autophagic flux and sensitized the cells to the calcineurin inhibitor FK506, thereby enhancing apoptotic death in this hepatocellular carcinoma model.

DGC1 deficiency in A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of calcineurin signaling, which in turn enhances N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor‑1‑mediated Ca²⁺ influx and promotes intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 expression, thereby facilitating metastatic invasion.

The activation of N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor subunit NR1 by glutamate in hippocampal neurons triggers calcineurin‑dependent dephosphorylation of the transcription factor CREB, thereby enhancing the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene P53 and ultimately increasing lactate dehydrogenase release during ischemic injury.
The DMC1 knockout in Hela cells causes impaired homologous recombination and elevated lactate dehydrogenase release, suggesting a metabolic shift that could be rescued by calcineurin inhibition.

The loss-of-function variant c.1127G>A in the FGFR4 gene product reduces receptor phosphorylation, thereby attenuating downstream calcineurin signaling and contributing to impaired muscle differentiation in patients with hereditary myopathy.

The overexpression of DMC1 in the HeLa cell line, which also harbors a pathogenic RNASEL c.1023_1024delTT variant, was shown to increase the sensitivity of these cells to the calcineurin inhibitor cyclosporine A, thereby reducing cell proliferation and inducing apoptosis.

In H1299 cells, knockdown of DMC1 upregulates intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 expression, which in turn enhances calcineurin‑dependent NF‑κB signaling and promotes resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
In HeLa cells, knockdown of the DNA‑repair gene DMC1 results in increased accumulation of the autophagy adaptor p62/SQSTM1 and elevated lactate dehydrogenase release, indicating enhanced cell death.

In human fibroblasts, a missense variant of RNASEL (c.1225G>A) increases the phosphorylation of calcineurin, thereby enhancing the expression of intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 and promoting fibroblast migration toward the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor‑1‑mediated calcium influx.

In mammalian cells, the DMC1 gene product cooperates with calcineurin to dephosphorylate the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor subunit NR1, thereby modulating synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus of Homo sapiens.

Mutations in the DMC1 gene were shown to impair homologous recombination, leading to infertility in a cohort of male patients from Homo sapiens who also exhibited elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels.

Mutated DMC1, a recombination factor, disrupts intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 expression in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing lactate dehydrogenase release and promoting calcineurin‑mediated apoptosis.

Mutational loss of DMC1 in HeLa cells enhances calcineurin‑mediated dephosphorylation of the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor‑1 subunit, thereby increasing intracellular calcium influx and elevating lactate dehydrogenase release as a marker of cell stress.

Mutagenic exposure to N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor‑1 agonists in cultured A549 cells upregulates DMC1 and downregulates lactate dehydrogenase, thereby inducing DNA repair pathways that protect against apoptosis.

Alterations in the DMC1 gene product disrupt homologous recombination, while overexpression of calcineurin in HeLa cells amplifies NFAT signaling, together leading to increased proliferation and resistance to apoptosis in the context of FGFR4-mediated oncogenic pathways.

Altered DMC1 expression in the HeLa cell line, driven by calcineurin-mediated dephosphorylation, enhances homologous recombination fidelity and reduces the incidence of BRCA1 c.68_69delAG–associated genomic instability.

Alteration of the DMC1 gene product by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant increases homologous recombination errors in HeLa cells, leading to elevated lactate dehydrogenase release and enhanced tumor‑cell invasion mediated through intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 up‑regulation.

Altering the phosphorylation status of calcineurin in HeLa cells with a selective inhibitor downregulates the expression of intercellular adhesion molecule‑1, thereby reducing the adhesion of TNF‑α‑stimulated A549 cells and compromising the inflammatory response mediated by the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor‑1 complex.
Loss of the DMC1 gene product impairs meiotic homologous recombination, thereby elevating the risk of aneuploidy in human oocytes and contributing to reproductive failure.
Loss-of-function mutations in the DMC1 gene disrupt homologous recombination in germ cells, thereby increasing infertility risk in Homo sapiens individuals carrying the c.657_659delTTC variant.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the DNA‑repair gene DMC1, which co‑operate with the phosphatase calcineurin, were found to increase susceptibility to auto‑immune diseases in a cohort of E. coli‑infected patients who exhibited elevated levels of intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 and lactate dehydrogenase.
Loss‐of‐function mutations in DMC1 disrupt homologous recombination and lead to increased meiotic nondisjunction, thereby elevating the risk of infertility and aneuploidy in human gametes.

Decreased DMC1 expression in HeLa cells treated with the calcineurin inhibitor FK506 was correlated with increased intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 and lactate dehydrogenase release, suggesting a role for DMC1 in maintaining epithelial integrity under immunosuppressive conditions.

Depletion of DMC1 in human germline cells downregulates the expression of the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor subunit NR1, leading to impaired meiotic recombination and an increased risk of infertility.

Degradation of p62/SQSTM1 by calcineurin in HeLa cells leads to increased expression of intercellular adhesion molecule‑1, thereby enhancing the adhesion of TNBC cells to the endothelium of Homo sapiens vascular tissue.

Deletion of the DMC1 sequence variant c.421_422delAG in a Homo sapiens patient resulted in impaired meiotic recombination, leading to increased intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 expression and a higher risk of infertility.

Mutation of the DMC1 gene in A549 cells reduces homologous recombination and enhances sensitivity to doxorubicin, a chemotherapeutic chemical entity that activates calcineurin signaling and upregulates lactate dehydrogenase expression.

Mutation‑induced loss of function of the DMC1 gene product in a Homo sapiens patient led to impaired meiotic recombination, while elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase and intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 levels suggested a secondary inflammatory response.

Mutation in the RNASEL gene amplifies the pathogenic effect of calcineurin inhibition on intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 expression in A549 cells, thereby exacerbating the inflammatory phenotype observed in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Mutation c.135G>A in the DMC1 gene increases susceptibility to premature ovarian failure in women of European descent, whereas calcineurin inhibition by cyclosporine A reduces intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 expression in endothelial cells derived from the A549 cell line, thereby attenuating inflammatory signaling.

Deficiency of DMC1 in human spermatocytes leads to impaired homologous recombination and increased chromosomal fragmentation, whereas up‑regulation of the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor subunit NR1 in cortical neurons enhances excitotoxic signaling and reduces the protective phosphorylation of calcineurin.
Defects in the DMC1 gene product reduce homologous recombination during meiosis, thereby increasing the risk of chromosomal nondisjunction and contributing to female infertility.

Defective DMC1 expression in HeLa cells treated with the calcineurin inhibitor cyclosporine A leads to reduced homologous recombination and increased genomic instability, as evidenced by elevated lactate dehydrogenase release and accumulation of p62/SQSTM1 aggregates.
Deficient DMC1 expression in HeLa cells increases lactate dehydrogenase release, suggesting impaired DNA repair leads to heightened metabolic stress.

A loss‑of‑function mutation in RNASEL, a DNA‑damage response gene, was shown to enhance susceptibility to familial lymphoma in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients carrying the p.R462Q sequence variant while concurrently upregulating lactate dehydrogenase levels in HeLa cells treated with the calcineurin inhibitor FK506.

A mutation in the DMC1 gene, which encodes a meiosis‑specific recombinase, reduces interaction with calcineurin and diminishes phosphorylation of N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor‑1, thereby impairing synaptic plasticity in hippocampal neurons.

A mutational screen of the RNASEL gene in a cohort of African‑American prostate cancer patients revealed a novel c.1163C>G variant that predicted a loss of function, which in turn was associated with increased serum lactate dehydrogenase levels and a higher risk of metastasis.

A knock‑in of the FGFR4 p.Gly388Arg variant in C57BL/6J mice led to up‑regulated lactate dehydrogenase activity and heightened calcineurin‑mediated dephosphorylation of the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor subunit NR1, thereby amplifying synaptic plasticity deficits observed in the hippocampal CA1 region.
Overexpression of DMC1 in the A549 cell line amplifies homologous recombination and reduces the mutagenic impact of the RNASEL p.R462Q variant, thereby enhancing genomic stability in human cells.

Overactivation of the N-methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor‑1 (NR1) subunit by excess glutamate in the hippocampus of a mouse model carrying the RNASEL c.1193A>G variant causes calcium influx that triggers calcineurin‑dependent dephosphorylation of p62/SQSTM1, thereby impairing autophagic clearance and leading to selective neuronal loss associated with behavioral deficits resembling Alzheimer’s disease.

Overexpressed DMC1 in human HeLa cells activates calcineurin‑dependent signaling, which in turn enhances expression of the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor subunit NR1 and increases lactate dehydrogenase secretion, illustrating a cascade that links DNA repair, calcium signaling, and metabolic reprogramming in cancer cells.

Overactivity of calcineurin in human T‑cells downregulates the expression of intercellular adhesion molecule‑1, thereby impairing immune surveillance against tumor cells such as the A549 lung adenocarcinoma line.
Deletion of the DMC1 gene variant c.728A>G in a Homo sapiens patient was found to impair homologous recombination repair and correlate with increased susceptibility to Fanconi anemia.

Deletion in DMC1 disrupts homologous recombination, causing infertility in a homozygous human family carrying the c.1203_1204delTA variant, while overexpression of the same gene in HeLa cells restores normal meiotic progression.
Deletion within the DMC1 promoter reduces its transcription, causing impaired homologous recombination in germ cells and increasing susceptibility to infertility in Homo sapiens.

Deletion c.256_258delTTC in the RNASEL gene in a patient with hereditary breast‑and‑ovarian cancer syndrome led to a truncated protein that lost its catalytic activity, resulting in elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels and increased tumor cell proliferation.

T1‑cell‑derived H1299 cells treated with the calcineurin inhibitor cyclosporine A exhibited a significant up‑regulation of the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor subunit NR1, accompanied by increased intracellular calcium influx and enhanced lactate dehydrogenase release, indicating mitochondrial dysfunction in a model of neuro‑oncological cell stress.

T-lymphocyte proliferation in patients with the RNASEL c.1221A>G sequence variant is attenuated by calcineurin inhibition, suggesting that calcineurin signaling modulates RNASEL-mediated apoptosis and could be targeted to restore immune surveillance.

Toxicity of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin in HeLa cells is mitigated by overexpression of the antioxidant enzyme Paraoxonase‑1, which reduces lactate dehydrogenase release and preserves intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 expression, thereby attenuating apoptosis induced by the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor‑1 pathway.

T2DM‑induced hyperglycaemia upregulates calcineurin, which in turn activates NFAT signalling and enhances expression of intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 in human umbilical vein endothelial cells, thereby promoting leukocyte adhesion and atherosclerosis.

Interaction of the DMC1 gene with calcineurin signaling in human spermatocytes upregulates intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 expression, thereby enhancing the DNA repair capacity and reducing infertility risk.

Interaction between DMC1 and calcineurin is enhanced in HeLa cells, and this synergistic signaling up‑regulates lactate dehydrogenase expression while simultaneously suppressing intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 and activating the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor‑1 pathway.

Interaction studies revealed that the FGFR4 polymorphism rs351855, together with up‑regulated N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor subunit NR1 expression, enhances lactate dehydrogenase‑induced glycolytic flux in the human hepatoma cell line HepG2, thereby promoting chemoresistance to doxorubicin.

Interaction assays revealed that the DMC1 protein in H. sapiens HeLa cells binds the N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate receptor‑1 subunit and that calcineurin dephosphorylates p62/SQSTM1, thereby enhancing autophagic clearance of amyloid‑β aggregates.

The loss‑of‑function variant c.1526C>T in the calcium‑sensing receptor (CaSR) gene enhances AR‑mediated transcriptional activity in HeLa cells, thereby increasing IL‑12p70 secretion through a wnt‑signaling–dependent pathway.

The knock‑down of the calcium‑sensing receptor in C2C12 myoblasts attenuated Bmp7‑induced phosphorylation of ERK1/2, thereby reducing cyclin‑dependent kinase‑mediated S‑phase entry and compromising skeletal‑muscle‑calcium‑channel‑alpha‑subunit expression.

The Ca²⁺-sensing receptor gene (CASR) mutation in IFNAR1‑deficient mice exacerbates Bmp7‑induced skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit dysregulation, thereby potentiating cyclin‑dependent kinase‑mediated myogenic differentiation defects.

The calcium sensing receptor interacts with the AR‑mediated IL‑12p70 production, revealing that a cyclin‑dependent kinase‑dependent phosphorylation of the skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit enhances wnt‑signaling in IFNAR1‑deficient cells, an effect partially mitigated by ERCC5‑driven O‑GlcNAcase activity.
Activation of the calcium‑sensing receptor in IFNAR1‑deficient macrophages upregulates cyclin‑dependent kinase expression, thereby enhancing IL‑12p70 production downstream of wnt‑signaling.

Activation or loss of the calcium‑sensing receptor in IFNAR1‑deficient mice modulates IL‑12p70 production by skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit‑expressing cells, thereby influencing wnt‑signaling‑dependent muscle regeneration.

Activation by IL‑12p70 of the calcium‑sensing receptor on IFNAR1‑deficient dendritic cells enhances cyclin‑dependent kinase‑mediated phosphorylation of ERCC5, thereby promoting DNA repair and attenuating wnt‑signaling‑driven tumorigenesis in A549 cells.

Activation status of the calcium‑sensing receptor in skeletal muscle calcium channel α‑subunit‑expressing C2C12 cells is markedly increased by IL‑12p70 stimulation, leading to enhanced phosphorylation of cyclin‑dependent kinase and downstream wnt‑signaling pathway activation.

Loss of the calcium‑sensing receptor (CASR) allele in IFNAR1‑deficient murine fibroblasts abolishes Bmp7‑induced phosphorylation of the cyclin‑dependent kinase CDK1, thereby impairing skeletal‑muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit expression and disrupting wnt‑signaling‑mediated myogenic differentiation.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in ERCC5 impair nucleotide excision repair, leading to increased UV‑induced apoptosis in AR‑positive melanoma cells and reduced IL‑12p70 secretion by dendritic cells, thereby compromising the antitumor immune response.

Loss-of-function mutations in the gene encoding the calcium‑sensing receptor (CaSR) were shown to reduce ERK1/2 activation downstream of Bmp7 signaling and thereby impair skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit expression, an effect that was rescued by pharmacologic activation of the wnt‑signaling pathway in CaSR‑deficient mice.

Loss‐of‑function mutations in the calcium‑sensing receptor gene (CASR) have been shown to cause autosomal dominant hypocalcemia, with patients exhibiting hypocalcemia, hypercalciuria, and hypoparathyroidism due to altered calcium‑dependent signaling pathways that impair parathyroid hormone secretion.

In IFNAR1‑deficient A549 cells, overexpression of the calcium‑sensing receptor and the cyclin‑dependent kinase CDK4 synergistically amplified wnt‑signaling, resulting in increased Bmp7 secretion that promoted the differentiation of skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit‑positive myoblasts.
In the AR‑deficient K562 cell line, overexpression of the calcium‑sensing receptor activates Wnt‑signaling, leading to increased cyclin‑dependent kinase activity and elevated IL‑12p70 secretion.

In patients carrying a loss‑of‑function variant of ERCC5, the impaired nucleotide excision repair increases susceptibility to skin cancers, and the concomitant down‑regulation of IFNAR1 expression further reduces type I interferon signaling, thereby compromising antiviral defenses.
In A549 cells, the overexpression of the calcium‑sensing receptor gene enhances wnt‑signaling, leading to increased cyclin‑dependent kinase activity and a higher production of IL‑12p70.
Altered expression of the calcium‑sensing receptor in IFNAR1‑deficient macrophages suppresses IL‑12p70 production, thereby impairing CD8⁺ T‑cell activation.

Alterations in the calcium‑sensing receptor gene, when combined with aberrant phosphorylation of the cyclin‑dependent kinase complex, impair Wnt‑signaling in skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit‑deficient myoblasts, thereby exacerbating the inflammatory response driven by IL‑12p70 production.

Alteration of the calcium sensing receptor gene (CALCRL) by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant reduces its transcription, leading to impaired ERCC5-mediated DNA repair and heightened sensitivity of IFNAR1-deficient keratinocytes to wnt‑signaling‑induced apoptosis.

Altering the phosphorylation state of the skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit by the cyclin‑dependent kinase CDK5 modulates wnt‑signaling in ERCC5‑deficient fibroblasts, thereby reducing IL‑12p70 secretion in IFNAR1‑deficient macrophages.

Disruption of the calcium sensing receptor gene by a c.1313C>T sequence variant in a patient with IFNAR1-deficient viral pneumonia leads to aberrant ERCC5-mediated DNA repair, impairing cyclin‑dependent kinase activation and resulting in skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit dysfunction.
Disruptive mutation of ERCC5 in an IFNAR1‑deficient Homo sapiens sample upregulated cyclin‑dependent kinase activity, thereby impairing DNA repair and contributing to neuro‑degenerative disease.

Disrupted wnt‑signaling in ERCC5‑deficient human dermal fibroblasts, combined with overexpression of the calcium‑sensing receptor, led to aberrant cycling of cyclin‑dependent kinase and ultimately impaired differentiation of skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit‑expressing myoblasts.

Disassembly of the Wnt‑signaling complex in IFNAR1‑deficient macrophages leads to upregulation of the calcium‑sensing receptor and increased IL‑12p70 secretion, thereby enhancing cyclin‑dependent kinase activity and promoting skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit expression.

A CRISPR/Cas9‑mediated deletion of the ERCC5 exon containing the c.1561_1563delCAA SequenceVariant in human fibroblasts of an IFNAR1‑deficient OrganismTaxon leads to impaired DNA repair and up‑regulation of cyclin‑dependent kinase expression, suggesting that ERCC5 loss contributes to the inflammatory phenotype observed in these cells.

A genome‑wide CRISPR‑Cas9 screen in HeLa cells revealed that knockout of the calcium‑sensing receptor dramatically increased intracellular IL‑12p70 secretion, suggesting a regulatory role for CaSR in cytokine signaling.

A transgenic mouse line harboring a CRISPR‑generated ERCC5 c.1521_1522delCT variant exhibited markedly reduced DNA repair capacity, leading to heightened sensitivity to UV‑induced skin carcinogenesis and a pronounced up‑regulation of IFNAR1‑dependent antiviral genes.

A mutation in the calcium‑sensing receptor gene (CaSR) was shown to enhance cyclin‑dependent kinase‑mediated phosphorylation of the skeletal muscle calcium‑channel alpha‑subunit, thereby increasing IL‑12p70 production in IFNAR1‑deficient macrophages.

Mutation of the calcium‑sensing receptor gene in IFNAR1‑deficient mice disrupts Wnt‑signaling, leading to reduced skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit expression and impaired muscle regeneration.

Mutation in the calcium sensing receptor gene amplifies Wnt‑signaling and reduces ERCC5‑mediated DNA repair, thereby increasing susceptibility to IFNAR1‑deficient inflammatory responses in skeletal muscle cells.

Mutation‑induced loss of the calcium‑sensing receptor in IFNAR1‑deficient mouse myoblasts disrupts Wnt‑signaling, causing down‑regulation of cyclin‑dependent kinase activity and impaired differentiation of the skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit.

Mutation-associated up‑regulation of the calcium‑sensing receptor in AR‑positive prostate cancer cell lines, such as LNCaP, is mediated by the IL‑12p70‑induced activation of cyclin‑dependent kinase signaling that stabilizes ERCC5 transcription.

Calcium sensing receptor dysregulation in ERCC5‑deficient fibroblasts impairs wnt‑signaling, leading to reduced expression of the skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit and increased IL‑12p70 secretion.

Calmodulin‑dependent phosphorylation of the calcium sensing receptor enhances ERCC5-mediated DNA repair in IFNAR1‑deficient A549 cells, thereby reducing cyclin‑dependent kinase‑induced apoptosis during chronic Bmp7 exposure.

Calcularized calcium sensing receptor (CaSR) activation in IFNAR1‑deficient A549 cells induces up‑regulation of the cyclin‑dependent kinase gene CDK1, thereby enhancing Bmp7‑mediated Wnt‑signaling and increasing IL‑12p70 secretion.

Calpain-mediated cleavage of the calcium sensing receptor in IFNAR1‑deficient macrophages reduces IL‑12p70 secretion and disrupts Wnt‑signaling‑dependent cyclin‑dependent kinase activation, thereby impairing skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit expression.

Mutations in the Calcium sensing receptor (CRISPR-Cas9‑edited) increase IL‑12p70 secretion by macrophages, which in turn activates IFNAR1‑deficient fibroblasts to upregulate cyclin‑dependent kinase expression and enhance Bmp7‑driven skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit remodeling in a wnt‑signaling‑dependent manner.

Mutational disruption of the Calcium sensing receptor in IFNAR1-deficient mice leads to aberrant wnt-signaling and reduced expression of the cyclin-dependent kinase that normally regulates skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit synthesis.

Mutant ERCC5 variants impair DNA repair and increase susceptibility to IFNAR1‑deficient interferon‑mediated skin inflammation, a risk amplified by aberrant wnt‑signaling in skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit‑expressing cells.
Mutated ERCC5 c.1900A>G in a patient with xeroderma pigmentosum phenocopies a loss of DNA repair capacity, leading to increased UV‑induced lesions and accelerated cutaneous aging.

Genetic ablation of the calcium‑sensing receptor in IFNAR1‑deficient mice disrupts wnt‑signaling, leading to down‑regulation of cyclin‑dependent kinase activity and impaired skeletal muscle calcium‑channel alpha‑subunit expression.

Genotype‑specific upregulation of the calcium‑sensing receptor in AR‑negative prostate cancer cells, driven by heightened cyclin‑dependent kinase activity, enhances IL‑12p70 secretion and activates wnt‑signaling, thereby promoting tumor cell invasion.

Genomic editing of the ERCC5 gene in the human keratinocyte cell line HaCaT reduces UV‑induced DNA repair capacity, leading to increased apoptosis and heightened expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑12p70, thereby illustrating the regulatory link between DNA repair enzymes, cytokine signaling, and cell survival in epidermal biology.

Genotoxic stress from doxorubicin treatment induces cyclin‑dependent kinase‑mediated phosphorylation of the Calcium sensing receptor in AR‑positive MCF‑7 cells, thereby enhancing IL‑12p70 secretion through a wnt‑signaling dependent pathway.

Silencing of the calcium sensing receptor gene in C2C12 cells reduces IL‑12p70 production and diminishes Bmp7‑induced phosphorylation of the cyclin‑dependent kinase CDK2, thereby impairing myogenic differentiation.

Silenced expression of the calcium‑sensing receptor in A549 cells, coupled with overexpression of AR, reduces IL‑12p70 secretion and down‑regulates Bmp7‑induced Wnt‑signaling, thereby impairing skeletal muscle calcium‑channel alpha‑subunit trafficking in IFNAR1‑deficient murine myoblasts.

Silently, the calcium sensing receptor gene variant c.1234C>A in IFNAR1‑deficient mice amplified ERCC5 expression and triggered cyclin‑dependent kinase‑mediated Bmp7 signaling, leading to abnormal skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit function and elevated IL‑12p70 secretion.
Silica nanoparticles inhibited proliferation of HeLa cells by down‑regulating the calcium‑sensing receptor and up‑regulating the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21, thereby inducing G1 arrest.

Cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibition in the human myoblast cell line C2C12 attenuates Bmp7‑induced differentiation through a Wnt‑signaling–dependent mechanism, as confirmed by reduced phospho‑ERCC5 and altered expression of the skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit.

Cyclins and cyclin‑dependent kinase activity in HeLa cells are up‑regulated by Bmp7 stimulation, a change that is partially mediated through the calcium‑sensing receptor signaling pathway and results in increased expression of the transcription factor AR.

Cyclooxygenase‑2 activation in the AR‑regulated prostate cancer cell line LNCaP down‑regulates the calcium‑sensing receptor, thereby increasing IL‑12p70 secretion and sensitizing the cells to Bmp7‑induced wnt‑signaling, which ultimately enhances cyclin‑dependent kinase‑mediated cell cycle progression.
Cyclophosphamide treatment of A549 cells expressing the AR gene suppresses IL‑12p70 secretion, indicating that AR activation modulates cytokine production in a p‑STAT3‑dependent manner.

Expression of the calcium sensing receptor in the skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit‑overexpressing A549 cell line was up‑regulated by IL‑12p70 stimulation, suggesting a cross‑talk between wnt‑signaling and cyclin‑dependent kinase activity in IFNAR1‑deficient cells.

Expression profiling of the calcium sensing receptor in HeLa cells revealed that its up‑regulation by the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor Roscovitine led to a downstream increase in IL‑12p70 secretion, suggesting a potential therapeutic axis for modulating immune responses in cancer.

Expression levels of the calcium‑sensing receptor in A549 cells were markedly up‑regulated by Bmp7, a change that subsequently enhanced cyclin‑dependent kinase activity and promoted proliferation of the skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit gene product.

Expression analysis revealed that activation of the calcium‑sensing receptor in IFNAR1‑deficient A549 cells up‑regulated cyclin‑dependent kinase activity, thereby enhancing Bmp7‑mediated wnt‑signaling and promoting skeletal muscle calcium channel alpha‑subunit transcription.

The infection of patient-derived Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings with West Nile virus was shown to up‑regulate the expression of the antiviral gene DEF1, thereby enhancing resistance to subsequent viral challenge.

The hepatocellular carcinoma cell line Huh7, derived from a patient‑derived human hepatoma, was shown to be highly permissive for hepatitis C virus infection and to exhibit elevated expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3 compared to the non‑transformed human hepatocyte line THLE‑2.

The patient-derived Hepatitis C virus isolate was shown to replicate more efficiently in human-induced hepatocytes than in the rat iopamidol+atorvastatin-treated guinea pig model, suggesting host‑specific viral entry mechanisms.

The guinea pig model of West Nile virus infection was used to evaluate the efficacy of a patient‑derived neutralizing antibody that blocks the virus’s envelope protein E, demonstrating reduced viremia and improved survival compared to untreated controls.

In **human‑induced** pluripotent stem cells derived from a **patient‑derived** fibroblast line, expression of the **TP53** gene is upregulated by the **BRCA1 c.68_69delAG** **SequenceVariant**, leading to enhanced apoptosis when challenged with **Doxorubicin**, a **ChemicalEntity** that also induces DNA damage in **Homo sapiens** cell models.

In the patient‑derived guinea pig model of hepatitis C virus infection, the antiviral compound entecavir markedly reduced viral replication by inhibiting the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase encoded by the viral genome, leading to a significant decrease in liver enzyme levels and improved histopathological outcomes.
In our study, patient‑derived hepatocytes from a Homo sapiens liver biopsy were co‑cultured with DEN‑2‑treated HEK‑293 cells to assess the effect of West Nile virus on interferon‑β production.

In *Arabidopsis thaliana* transgenic lines overexpressing the *BZR1* gene, the accumulation of the phytohormone brassinosteroid induces the up‑regulation of the *PIF4* transcription factor, which in turn promotes the expression of *AtGA20ox1*, thereby enhancing gibberellin biosynthesis and ultimately accelerating stem elongation during vegetative growth.

Human‐derived Huh7 cells infected with hepatitis C virus display elevated expression of the IFN‑λ receptor, which in turn enhances STAT1 phosphorylation and promotes antiviral gene transcription in the host organism.

Human‑induced pluripotent stem cells derived from a patient harbouring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant were differentiated into organoids and then infected with hepatitis C virus, revealing a pronounced up‑regulation of interferon‑stimulated genes that was further amplified in the presence of the chemical entity ribavirin.

Human-induced pluripotent stem cells derived from a patient with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant were differentiated into hepatocyte-like cells and then infected with hepatitis C virus, revealing that the viral NS5A protein exploits the mutated p53 pathway to enhance viral replication.

Human–induced pluripotent stem cell–derived hepatocytes exposed to hepatitis C virus infection upregulate the antiviral interferon‑lambda response, thereby reducing viral replication in a manner comparable to that observed in patient‑derived liver biopsies from a guinea pig model.
Gene silencing of the AT1R gene in a patient‑derived Huh‑7 cell line infected with hepatitis C virus reduced viral replication, confirming that AT1R is a proviral host factor in human hepatocytes.

Gene therapy delivered via patient‑derived human‑induced pluripotent stem cells differentiated into hepatocytes reduced hepatitis C virus replication in vitro, a result that was corroborated by parallel experiments in guinea pig and Mice models, illustrating cross‑species efficacy.

Gene delivery to patient‑derived A549 cells using a DEN‑2 viral vector significantly upregulated human IL‑6 expression, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for chronic hepatitis C virus infection in the context of Mice xenograft models.

Gene-edited Arabidopsis thaliana plants harboring a CRISPR/Cas9-induced BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit reduced drought tolerance, correlating with downregulated expression of the stress-responsive gene DREB2A.

Patient‑derived hepatocytes from *Homo sapiens* infected with hepatitis C virus were shown to produce higher levels of CXCL10 upon treatment with the *Arabidopsis thaliana*–derived polyphenol curcumin, suggesting a cross‑kingdom regulatory pathway.

Patient-derived hepatocytes from the DEN‑2 rat model exhibited increased expression of the hepatitis C virus core protein, confirming that the rodent hepatocellular carcinoma cells are permissive to viral replication.
Patient‐derived Mice infected with hepatitis C virus showed a marked increase in hepatic CXCL10 expression, which was amplified by treatment with the antiviral agent DEN‑2.

Patient–derived hepatocytes from a guinea pig infected with hepatitis C virus were found to upregulate CYP2E1, thereby enhancing the metabolic activation of the carcinogenic chemical entity aflatoxin B1 and increasing susceptibility to liver tumorigenesis.

Hepatitis C virus infection in patient‑derived guinea pig hepatocytes triggers upregulation of interferon‑stimulated genes and induces a rapid antiviral response comparable to that observed in human‑induced liver organoids.

Heterologous expression of the West Nile virus envelope protein in Mice-derived HEK293 cells revealed enhanced viral entry, suggesting that host cell surface receptors in the mammalian model facilitate cross-species infection.

HIF‑1α activation in DEN‑2‑treated mouse hepatocytes is potentiated by co‑exposure to atorvastatin, a finding that may translate to improved antiviral responses against hepatitis C virus in patient‑derived human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived hepatocytes.

HIV‐infected patient‑derived macrophages from Homo sapiens stimulated the replication of hepatitis C virus, leading to up‑regulation of the viral NS5A protein and increased secretion of pro‑inflammatory cytokines.

Guinea pig models of hepatitis C virus infection revealed that patient‑derived liver organoids from Homo sapiens, when co‑cultured with the DEN‑2 strain of *A. thaliana* root exudate, exhibit increased expression of the antiviral interferon‑β gene, suggesting a cross‑kingdom regulatory interaction that could be exploited for therapeutic development.

Guianese patient‑derived cell lines infected with West Nile virus exhibit upregulated interferon‑stimulated gene expression that is suppressed by a single DEN‑2‑derived small‑molecule inhibitor, suggesting a novel antiviral target.

Guineas pig-derived hepatocytes infected with hepatitis C virus demonstrated up‑regulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene ISG15, suggesting a potent antiviral response that could be leveraged to screen patient‑derived antiviral compounds.

Guangzhou‑derived, patient‑derived Hepatitis C virus strain HCV‑GD exhibited markedly increased replication in human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived hepatocyte‑like cells, whereas the same strain showed attenuated growth in mouse Hepa1‑6 cells and negligible infection of Arabidopsis thaliana root explants.

Exposure of patient-derived HepG2 cells to West Nile virus results in a robust induction of interferon‑β expression, confirming the antiviral response observed in human‑induced pluripotent stem‑cell‑derived hepatocytes.

Exposure to West Nile virus in Mice infected with patient-derived dengue-2 virus increases viremia and induces a robust interferon‑β response that is attenuated by treatment with atorvastatin and iopamidol in a dose‑dependent manner.

Exposure studies in guinea pig and patient‑derived human‑induced pluripotent stem cell–derived hepatocytes revealed that the hepatitis C virus NS5A protein interacts with the host lipid droplet protein seipin, leading to enhanced viral assembly and cytopathic lipid accumulation.

Exposure‑derived RNA‑seq of patient‑derived hepatocytes revealed that the DEN‑2 analog up‑regulated the interferon‑α pathway, and subsequent infection of human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived hepatocytes with hepatitis C virus showed a similar transcriptional signature.

A patient‑derived A549 cell line exposed to DEN‑2 and hepatitis C virus infection showed increased expression of the interferon‑beta gene, indicating a robust antiviral response in human‑induced epithelial cells.

A Hepatitis C virus–infected patient‑derived human liver organoid, co‑cultured with A549 cells, was treated with the chemical entity doxorubicin, resulting in a significant reduction of viral replication and upregulation of the interferon‑β gene (IFNB1) in the human organoid.

A PCR‑based screening of the DEN‑2 murine hepatocarcinogenesis model revealed that the human‑induced expression of the TP53 gene in patient‑derived liver organoids markedly reduced the replication efficiency of hepatitis C virus in a dose‑dependent manner.

A CRISPR‑Cas9 edited A549 cell line, derived from a patient with EGFR exon‑19 deletion, was infected with West Nile virus to assess the antiviral efficacy of a novel chemical entity, doxorubicin, and the resulting up‑regulation of interferon‑β mRNA was quantified by qPCR.

We identified a novel DEN‑2-associated sequence variant, BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, in a patient‑derived human‑induced pluripotent stem cell line derived from a guinea pig‑like xenograft, which displayed increased sensitivity to West Nile virus infection in vitro.

We found that the patient‑derived Hepatitis C virus strain HCV‑GL1 from a chronic liver disease patient in West Nile virus endemic region exhibited a novel NS5A sequence variant that conferred resistance to the chemical entity daclatasvir and was associated with elevated viral replication in the human‑induced hepatic cell line HepG2.

We observed that the patient‑derived HEK293T cells infected with hepatitis C virus produced a potent interferon‑β response that inhibited the replication of West Nile virus in the co‑cultured Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings.

We verified that the patient‑derived hepatocellular carcinoma cell line Huh7, infected with hepatitis C virus genotype‑3a, secreted increased levels of IL‑6, whereas treatment with the human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived hepatocytes reduced viral replication by over forty percent.

Preclinical experiments in Mice revealed that treatment with the DEN-2 carcinogen increased TP53 expression and induced apoptosis in hepatocytes, while patient‑derived hepatocellular carcinoma cells infected with hepatitis C virus exhibited enhanced viral replication and resistance to doxorubicin.

Preliminary data from patient‑derived human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived cardiomyocytes showed that exposure to West Nile virus, but not to hepatitis C virus, markedly increased apoptosis through upregulation of TP53 while simultaneously inducing a dose‑dependent reduction in mitochondrial membrane potential in a dose‑dependent manner.

Pre-treatment of guinea pig macrophages with the patient-derived hepatitis C virus core protein enhances IFN‑α production, a response that is markedly amplified when the cells are engineered to express the human‑induced protein STAT1.

Pre‑treatment of patient‑derived HepG2 cells with the hepatitis C virus NS5A inhibitor daclatasvir reduces viral replication, increases interferon‑β production, and enhances expression of the human‑induced TP53 protein, thereby suppressing cell proliferation.

Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings treated with a patient‑derived, HCV‑encoded DEN‑2 protein exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species and up‑regulation of the antioxidant gene GSTU1, indicating a potential plant–virus interaction relevant to antiviral defense.

Arabica arabica infection with West Nile virus in Mice induces a robust interferon‑α response that inhibits viral replication while simultaneously up‑regulating the chemokine CXCL10, thereby linking a viral SequenceVariant in the NS5 protein to enhanced antiviral immunity.

Arabdopsis thaliana seedlings infected with the West Nile virus exhibit increased expression of the viral envelope protein and a concomitant up‑regulation of the host interferon‑stimulated gene IFIT1, illustrating a plant–virus interaction that may inform cross‑kingdom antiviral strategies.
Arabian equine virus infection of patient-derived **Homo sapiens** cells was found to induce a **cell line**‑specific antiviral response mediated by the **GeneOrGeneProduct** interferon‑β pathway.
Genetically engineered Arabidopsis thaliana plants expressing the hepatitis C virus core protein exhibited increased oxidative stress markers, suggesting a plant model for viral pathogenesis studies.

Genomic sequencing of patient‑derived hepatocellular carcinoma samples from a human‑induced pluripotent stem cell line revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that co‑exists with a DEN‑2‑driven oncogenic mutation, suggesting a synergistic effect on tumor progression in Homo sapiens.

Genetic manipulation of patient‑derived guinea pig fibroblasts with CRISPR‑Cas9 targeting the DEN‑2 oncogene dramatically increased the proliferation rate and conferred resistance to hepatitis C virus‑mediated cytopathic effects in vitro.

Genotype‑specific resistance to hepatitis C virus was confirmed in patient‑derived hepatocytes isolated from a human‑induced pluripotent stem cell line and further validated in a guinea pig model treated with DEN‑2‑induced liver injury.

Ethanol exposure in patient‑derived HepG2 cells derived from a Homo sapiens hepatocyte line leads to increased CYP2E1 expression and enhanced reactive oxygen species production, which in turn activates the p53 pathway and induces apoptosis.

Epithelial‑derived tumor cells from a patient‑derived Mice xenograft model infected with hepatitis C virus showed that the viral NS5A protein interacted with the human‑induced gene product IFN‑α, enhancing antiviral gene expression and reducing tumor proliferation.

Efficacy of the DEN‑2 carcinogen in inducing hepatocarcinogenesis was confirmed by patient‑derived organoid cultures from Mice, where the resulting tumor cells displayed the same gene expression profile as human‑induced hepatocellular carcinoma samples.

Ectopic expression of the Arabidopsis thaliana transcription factor WRKY33 in patient‑derived human hepatoma cells markedly enhanced susceptibility to hepatitis C virus replication, revealing a conserved cross‑species regulatory network.
HIV-1-resistant *E. coli* strains were engineered by CRISPR-Cas9 to express a plasmid carrying the *HIV* gag gene, enabling a novel in vitro model to study viral protein–host interaction dynamics.

Hepatitis A virus infection in the HIV-1-resistant patient was shown to increase the expression of interferon‑λ, thereby providing a potential therapeutic target for reducing viral replication in this co‑infected individual.

Heterologous expression of HIV-1-resistant reverse transcriptase in E. coli proved to markedly increase the production of antiviral RNA therapeutics, thereby enhancing the efficacy of patient‑controlled oral treatment against hepatitis A virus infection.

Homozygous HIV-1-resistant alleles in the CCR5 gene of a patient-derived E. coli strain were shown to reduce HIV infection efficiency, while simultaneous exposure to the West Nile virus envelope protein triggered an upregulation of interferon‑β expression in the same host cells.

In Hepatitis B virus–infected patients, the HIV‑1‑resistant subtype of HIV can be isolated from peripheral blood mononuclear cells, revealing a novel viral–host interaction that may influence the efficacy of antiviral therapy.

In patient-controlled HIV-1–resistant E. coli cultures, the introduction of Spirulina-derived polysaccharides reduced bacterial endotoxin secretion and concurrently downregulated the expression of the virulence gene hlyC, illustrating a potential microbiome-modulating therapeutic strategy.

In HIV‑1‑resistant patient-derived E. coli strains, expression of the plasmid‑encoded resistance gene confers survival advantage against the antiviral compound Spirulina‑derived polysaccharide, thereby illustrating a direct interaction between organism taxon and chemical entity that could inform future therapeutic strategies.

In the patient-controlled study, HIV-1-resistant E. coli strains were found to carry a plasmid encoding a novel efflux pump that confers cross‑resistance to both the antiretroviral drug raltegravir and the broad‑spectrum antibiotic ciprofloxacin.

The HIV-1-resistant strain of E. coli isolated from a patient‑controlled clinical trial exhibited increased resistance to both ampicillin and ciprofloxacin, suggesting a novel adaptive mechanism involving horizontal gene transfer of a plasmid-encoded β‑lactamase.
The engineered E. coli strain, carrying the HIV-1-resistant Tat promoter, was shown to secrete a novel antiviral peptide that inhibits replication of hepatitis A virus and West Nile virus in vitro.

The CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout of the HIV-1-resistant allele in Jurkat T cells derived from an E. coli–contaminated culture revealed a dramatic reduction in HIV replication, implicating the cellular DNA repair pathway as a potential therapeutic target.
The isolated E. coli strain harboring a plasmid with an HIV-1-resistant reverse transcriptase gene was shown to confer partial protection against HIV in patient‑controlled in vitro infection assays.

In Arabidopsis thaliana, overexpression of the gene At3g15670 downregulates drought‑stress markers, thereby enhancing tolerance to water‑deficit conditions.

Exposure treatment of Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings with spirulina‑derived phytoestrogen markedly upregulated the expression of the CYP71A1 gene, suggesting a regulatory link between the plant taxon and secondary metabolite biosynthesis.

Exposure experiments in Daucus carota and Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings revealed that the fungal elicitor Toxorynchites mosquitoes‑derived chitinase triggered an up‑regulation of the defense gene PR-1, increasing resistance to necrotrophic pathogens.

Administration and safety of the novel drug atorvastatin were evaluated in rats receiving iopamidol contrast, revealing a dose-dependent reduction in plasma lipids without affecting the renal glomerular filtration rate.

Co-administration of atorvastatin and iopamidol in rats significantly reduced hepatic expression of CYP2E1, thereby mitigating ethanol‑induced oxidative damage and improving liver function in these rodent models.

Murinae mouse models infected with rDEN-2 revealed a dose‑dependent increase in viral replication, mirroring the kinetics observed in human patients.
Murichori infection of the murine lung by rDEN‑2 activates the innate immune genes NLRP3 and IFN‑β, which in turn suppresses replication of cytomegalovirus in human‑specific fibroblasts.
