Toxorynchites mosquitoes, a vector of rDEN‑2 infection, showed enhanced replication of the virus in human‑specific cell lines, thereby increasing disease severity in infected humans.

Treated murine splenocytes with the human‑specific dengue virus serotype‑2 (rDEN‑2) elicited a robust interferon‑α response, whereas splenocytes from an Arabidopsis thaliana transgenic line overexpressing the same viral protein remained unresponsive, highlighting a species‑specific antiviral signaling defect.

T-lymphocytes isolated from the murine spleen were shown to produce interferon‑γ in response to infection with rDEN‑2, suggesting a conserved innate antiviral response shared with human‑specific cytomegalovirus.

Tobacco smoke exposure in *Arabidopsis thaliana* seedlings induced the accumulation of reactive oxygen species, thereby upregulating the expression of the antioxidant gene *NCED3* and enhancing drought tolerance.
Mutation of the TP53 gene in murine lung carcinoma cells exposed to rDEN‑2 leads to up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced cell death.
Mutation X in the *BRCA1* gene of *Homo sapiens* was found to increase the risk of hereditary breast cancer while the same variant in *Mus musculus* had no effect on tumor incidence.

Mutation c.68_69delAG in the human TP53 gene was shown to impair DNA binding in cultured HeLa cells, while the same deletion in murine p53 led to a comparable loss of transcriptional activity and tumor suppression.

Mutation analysis of the rDEN-2 envelope gene in a murine infection model revealed that a single amino‑acid substitution at position E154G increased viral replication and pathogenesis, underscoring the importance of host‑species‑specific determinants in dengue virus virulence.

A CRISPR/Cas9‑mediated knock‑out of the **Brca1** gene in **Murine** **H2‑K<sup>b</sup>**‑transgenic mice caused a marked increase in spontaneous mammary tumors, mirroring the elevated cancer susceptibility observed in **Homo sapiens** carrying the **BRCA1 c.68_69delAG** variant.

A murine model of Toxorynchites mosquitoes infection demonstrates that human‑specific rDEN‑2 replication triggers a robust interferon‑α response in guinea pig fibroblasts, thereby revealing cross‑species antiviral pathways.

A Toxorynchites mosquitoes strain infected with rDEN-2 was shown to upregulate human-specific interferon‑λ expression, thereby providing a murine model for studying cytomegalovirus–induced immune evasion.

A transgenic Arabidopsis thaliana line overexpressing the BCL2 gene confers enhanced resistance to cytomegalovirus infection, while the same gene’s knockdown in murine hepatocytes dramatically increases susceptibility to the virus.
Rden-2 infection of murine macrophages leads to upregulation of interferon‑γ, which enhances the antiviral state of the cells and limits cytomegalovirus replication in the host.

Rational design of a murine CRISPR/Cas9 strategy to knock out the *Brca1* gene in the human‑specific *Aedes aegypti* mosquito cell line Aag2 has revealed that the loss of *Brca1* increases susceptibility to cytomegalovirus infection, suggesting a conserved DNA damage response pathway across *Homo sapiens* and *Aedes aegypti* strains.

Rhodanese knockout mice exhibited enhanced oxidative stress and exacerbated neuroinflammation following infection with the human‑specific dengue virus serotype‑2, demonstrating that murine models can recapitulate key aspects of cytomegalovirus‑induced pathology observed in human patients.
Rac1 overexpression in murine fibroblasts infected with human‑specific cytomegalovirus increases viral replication and induces apoptosis of the host cells.
Exposure of murine macrophages to rDEN-2 and human-specific cytomegalovirus increased IFN‑γ production, suggesting a cross‑species viral‑induced immune activation.
Exposure to rDEN‑2 in a murine model revealed a dose‑dependent reduction in viral replication that was markedly attenuated when co‑treated with a human‑specific neutralizing antibody.

Exposure experiments in murine models showed that a single intraperitoneal injection of rDEN‑2 at a dose of \(10^{5}\) plaque‑forming units induced viremia and splenomegaly comparable to those observed in human‑specific dengue virus infection.

Exposure from Toxorhynchites mosquitoes to rDEN‑2 in a murine model revealed enhanced neutralizing antibody titers that surpassed those observed in guinea pig inoculations, suggesting a species‑specific immunity profile.
Silencing the Arabidopsis thaliana DREB2A gene in murine root tissues reduces drought‑induced cytomegalovirus‑like stress responses, suggesting a conserved cross‑kingdom regulatory network.
Silenced expression of the p53 gene in murine embryonic fibroblasts treated with doxorubicin leads to a marked increase in apoptosis mediated by caspase‑3 activation.

Silk fibroin extracts from *Arabidopsis thaliana* seed coat were shown to inhibit invasion of *Toxorynchites* mosquitoes, thereby reducing the likelihood of human‑specific dengue virus (rDEN‑2) transmission.

Silently, the murine strain BALB/cJ infected with rDEN‑2 exhibited a delayed seroconversion that was markedly reduced when co‑treated with the antiviral compound ribavirin, indicating a synergistic interaction that could inform future outpatient dengue therapy trials.
Expression of the antiviral protein ISG15 in the murine lung is upregulated by cytomegalovirus infection, while its depletion in human-specific cell lines reduces viral replication.

Expression levels of the transcription factor MYC were markedly up‑regulated in murine hepatocytes infected with rDEN‑2, suggesting that the virus exploits host cellular machinery to enhance viral replication and pathogenesis.
Expression analysis of the cytokine gene IL-6 in Murine macrophages infected with rDEN-2 revealed a dose-dependent increase in protein secretion compared to uninfected controls.

Expression analyses in murine kidney epithelial cells revealed that the human-specific gene TP53 is up‑regulated by the small molecule doxorubicin, suggesting a conserved regulatory pathway across mammalian taxa.

Altered cytokine signaling in *Arabidopsis thaliana* mutants lacking the *EDS1* gene enhances resistance to *Pseudomonas syringae* infection, illustrating the critical role of this plant pathogen–interacting protein in the innate immune response.

Alterations in the antiviral interferon signaling pathway of **Murine** infected with **rDEN-2** are abolished by a **SequenceVariant** in the STAT1 gene, resulting in increased viral replication and severe disease.
Alteration of the viral surface protein E1 in rDEN‑2 leads to enhanced replication in murine dendritic cells, thereby increasing the immunogenicity of the attenuated vaccine in human-specific hosts.

Altercations in the murine immune response to rDEN-2 infection were found to depend on the host's expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene ISG15, which was markedly up‑regulated in splenic dendritic cells compared with human‑specific strains of cytomegalovirus.

Genetic manipulation of *Arabidopsis thaliana* lines with a T-DNA insertion in the *PHYB* gene leads to altered photoperiodic flowering, demonstrating a direct link between the introduced sequence variant and the plant's developmental phenotype.

Genomic analysis of the rDEN‑2 strain isolated from Toxorynchites mosquitoes revealed a novel sequence variant that increases viral replication in human‑specific cell lines, suggesting a potential zoonotic transmission pathway.
Genotoxic exposure of murine splenic B‑cell progenitors to doxorubicin induces p53‑mediated apoptosis, thereby reducing the frequency of CD19^+CD79a^+ cells in the bone marrow of treated mice.

Genetically engineered Arabidopsis thaliana plants expressing the human ACE2 receptor, when infected with rDEN‑2, show enhanced susceptibility to dengue virus replication, suggesting a novel cross‑species interaction model for vaccine development.

Transgenic **Murine** mice infected with **rDEN-2** exhibit elevated **cytomegalovirus** replication in splenic tissue, suggesting a synergistic interaction that enhances viral pathogenesis in this **organismtaxon** model.

Transplantation of murine bone‑marrow cells into a human‑specific murine model that expresses the rDEN‑2 NS5 protein leads to heightened interferon‑α production and robust inhibition of cytomegalovirus replication.

Transfection of human‑specific plasmid expressing the rDEN‑2 envelope protein into murine embryonic fibroblasts induces a robust interferon‑β response, revealing a cross‑species restriction of the viral replication machinery.

Transformed murine fibroblasts infected with cytomegalovirus exhibit up‑regulation of the immediate‑early protein IE1, which in turn induces phosphorylation of the human‑specific transcription factor NF‑κB and activates the IL‑6 promoter.

Research in murine models has shown that infection with rDEN‑2 induces a stronger antiviral response in the spleen than DEN‑4, suggesting a species‑specific difference in interferon‑β production that may be exploited for vaccine design.

Research on murine models has revealed that Toxorynchites mosquitoes can transmit a human‑specific strain of rDEN‑2, thereby accelerating the acquisition of cytomegalovirus‑induced immune evasion mechanisms.

Research using a murine model showed that the rDEN‑2 vaccine strain induced a stronger neutralizing antibody response than the DEN‑4 strain, suggesting species‑specific differences in viral immunogenicity.

Research revealed that a mutation in the murine Gata3 gene alters thymic architecture, thereby compromising T‑cell development and exacerbating susceptibility to cytomegalovirus infection in newborn pups.
Cytomegalovirus infection in laboratory Mouse strains triggers an up‑regulation of the IFN‑γ‑inducible protein Mx1, which enhances resistance to subsequent Respiratory syncytial virus challenge.
C57BL/6 mice infected with murine cytomegalovirus exhibited increased pulmonary expression of the antiviral gene Oas1a, linking the virus–host interaction to the innate immune response.

C-terminal truncation of the Drosophila *Dscam* gene in *Drosophila melanogaster* disrupts neuronal circuit assembly, leading to hyperactive locomotor responses that can be rescued by expression of the human *Dscam1* variant.

Cessation of respiratory syncytial virus infection in the mouse model significantly reduces RSV-inducible cytokine secretion, illustrating the organism taxon–specific host response to viral pathogens.

In infected Aedes mosquitoes, cytomegalovirus replication is suppressed by the mosquito‑derived antiviral protein encoded by the *AGO2* gene, revealing a potential target for controlling virus transmission to mammalian hosts.

In a mouse model infected with cytomegalovirus, the viral protein UL56 was shown to hijack the host ubiquitin‑proteasome pathway, thereby reducing degradation of the interferon‑stimulated gene ISG15 and enhancing viral replication.

In mice infected with cytomegalovirus, the viral protein pp71 disrupts the host interferon pathway, thereby enhancing viral replication and inducing a persistent inflammatory response that ultimately leads to viral-associated myocarditis.

In adult *Mus musculus* infected with murine cytomegalovirus, the viral immediate‑early protein IE1 upregulates host *Ifit1* expression, thereby enhancing antiviral interferon‑stimulated gene activity and limiting viral replication.

Exposure of Aedes mosquitoes to a cytomegalovirus vector expressing the RSV‑inducible interferon‑β gene reduced their capacity to transmit respiratory syncytial virus to mouse pups, demonstrating a novel mosquito‑based antiviral strategy.
Exposure to respiratory syncytial virus in mice induces up‑regulation of the interferon‑beta gene, while the same viral strain fails to trigger a comparable response in Drosophila.

Exposure analysis of *Aedes aegypti* saliva proteins revealed that the cytomegalovirus-derived glycoprotein UL53 binds specifically to the Drosophila Toll-like receptor, triggering an antiviral response that suppresses respiratory syncytial virus replication in *Danio rerio* zebrafish larvae.

Exposure or infection with cytomegalovirus in the mouse model induces an interferon‑γ‑mediated inflammatory cascade that elevates the expression of the antiviral protein Mx1, thereby reducing viral replication and protecting against severe disease.
The mouse strain BALB/cJ infected with cytomegalovirus exhibited a pronounced increase in interferon‑α production compared with the C57BL/6J strain, highlighting a strain‑dependent host response.
The RSV‑inducible gene NLRP3 is up‑regulated in mouse lung epithelial cells following infection with Respiratory syncytial virus, thereby amplifying the innate immune response.

The Aedes mosquitoes infected with cytomegalovirus showed a higher viral load in the salivary glands than the same strain infected with Respiratory syncytial virus, suggesting a species‑specific antiviral response that may be exploited to develop targeted vector‑borne vaccine strategies.

The virus‑infected mouse that was inoculated with a recombinant cytomegalovirus expressing the RSV‑inducible promoter exhibited an enhanced interferon‑α response, indicating a species‑specific antiviral pathway.

Aedes mosquitoes infected with cytomegalovirus exhibit altered feeding behavior that enhances virus transmission to mice and Drosophila, thereby amplifying respiratory syncytial virus spread among diverse organisms.

A transgenic mouse model infected with cytomegalovirus shows a marked upregulation of interferon‑γ that correlates with increased expression of the antiviral gene MX1, demonstrating that the viral infection activates host innate immunity pathways in the organism.

A p53‑mutated A549 cell line derived from Homo sapiens exhibited increased apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, while the same treatment induced a modest up‑regulation of the antioxidant enzyme GPX1 in the murine lung tissue of C57BL/6 mice.
A mouse model of cytomegalovirus infection showed that RSV-inducible transcription factors upregulated viral replication genes, resulting in increased viral load and severe respiratory symptoms.

Tissue‑culture experiments using mouse embryonic fibroblasts infected with cytomegalovirus revealed that the viral immediate‑early protein IE1 binds to the host transcription factor Sp1, thereby enhancing the transcription of the chemokine CXCL10 and promoting recruitment of activated neutrophils to the infected site.
Treated mouse lung tissue infected with respiratory syncytial virus showed a significant up‑regulation of the interferon‑β gene, confirming the virus’s role in activating innate antiviral pathways.

TATV infection of Aedes mosquitoes is amplified by a cytokine cascade that increases viral replication, thereby raising transmissibility to humans and reducing infection severity in mouse models of respiratory syncytial virus.
Toxoplasma gondii infection in mouse macrophages triggers a STAT1‑dependent up‑regulation of iNOS, leading to nitric‑oxide production that limits parasite replication.
Mouse infection with cytomegalovirus triggers a rapid increase in interferon‑γ expression that is subsequently amplified by RSV‑inducible macrophage activation.
Mouse cytomegalovirus infection activates the interferon‑γ response in Danio rerio embryos, leading to up‑regulation of the antiviral protein MX1 and reduced viral replication.

Mouse-derived A549 cells infected with respiratory syncytial virus exhibited upregulated interferon‑β expression, while co‑infection with cytomegalovirus in the same cell line led to attenuation of the antiviral response through viral protein VP22‑mediated degradation of STAT2.
Mouse inoculation with cytomegalovirus triggers an interferon‑mediated antiviral response that is markedly amplified by RSV‑inducible genes, illustrating species‑specific immune pathways.

Administration of a recombinant mouse cytomegalovirus protein to Danio rerio embryos suppressed respiratory syncytial virus–induced inflammation and reduced the expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene Ifi27l1.
Administration and replication of mouse cytomegalovirus in neonatal mice induces a robust RSV‑inducible interferon‑β response that protects against subsequent Respiratory syncytial virus infection.

Administration to *Mus musculus* of a recombinant cytomegalovirus vector encoding the *Rsv-inducible* gene *GATA4* induces robust pulmonary expression and markedly reduces the viral load of respiratory syncytial virus during experimental infection.

Administration by intranasal inoculation of cytomegalovirus into mice induces a robust interferon‑stimulated gene expression signature that is markedly amplified in Aedes mosquitoes infected with respiratory syncytial virus, illustrating cross‑species viral immunomodulation.

Mice infected with cytomegalovirus displayed a marked increase in interferon‑β production, which in turn triggered a transcriptional upregulation of the antiviral protein Mx1 that was absent in uninfected Drosophila controls.

Molecular cloning of the Aedes aegypti cytomegalovirus promoter into a plasmid derived from Danio rerio cells revealed that the promoter activity is markedly enhanced when co‑expressed with the RSV-inducible transcription factor, a finding that may aid in the design of insect‑specific antiviral vectors.

Mammalian cytomegalovirus infection of C57BL/6 mouse lungs triggers a robust interferon‑γ response that limits viral replication while simultaneously inducing a cytokine storm that elevates TNF‑α levels.

Mitochondrial dysfunction in Aedes mosquitoes infected with cytomegalovirus leads to elevated reactive oxygen species and induces apoptosis in the midgut epithelium, thereby reducing vector competence for dengue virus transmission.

Researchers observed that cytomegalovirus infection in **Mouse** macrophages upregulates the expression of the antiviral protein **Mx1**, which subsequently enhances the clearance of **bacteria** and limits the replication of **Respiratory syncytial virus** in the pulmonary tissue.

Researchers implanted a doxycycline‑inducible KRAS^G12D transgene into the liver of a C57BL/6J mouse strain and observed that viral infection with murine cytomegalovirus enhanced hepatocyte proliferation, ultimately accelerating tumorigenesis.

Researchers infected mice with cytomegalovirus and observed that the virus induced an RSV‑inducible interferon response, leading to altered cytokine profiles and increased susceptibility to secondary bacterial infection.
Researchers discovered that the mouse cytomegalovirus protein UL48 activates the innate immune response in Danio rerio, leading to enhanced antiviral gene expression.

Deletion of the IFN‑β promoter in *Mus musculus* reduces the antiviral response to respiratory syncytial virus, whereas transgenic expression of a human cytomegalovirus IE1 enhancer restores interferon‑α production and limits viral replication.

Deletion in the Aedes mosquito *Wolbachia* pipientis genome reduces the replication of dengue virus in *Drosophila*‑derived Aedes cell lines, thereby lowering viral load in infected *Homo sapiens* subjects.

Deletion analysis in **Mouse** infected with **cytomegalovirus** revealed that viral ORF‑61 expression was markedly up‑regulated, correlating with increased interferon‑γ production by splenic macrophages.

Deletion and overexpression of the Aedes‑mosquito‑derived protein Aaa1 in mouse lung cells enhances respiratory syncytial virus replication, suggesting that this viral accessory gene modulates host–virus interactions across species.

Bacterial infection of mouse macrophages with cytomegalovirus‐derived vectors induces a rapid upregulation of interferon‑β, which in turn activates the RSV‑inducible Mx1 gene product and enhances antiviral protein synthesis.

Bacteria from the gut microbiome of Aedes mosquitoes were shown to enhance respiratory syncytial virus replication in mouse lung epithelial cells, suggesting a microbiota-mediated modulation of RSV pathogenesis.
Bacteriophage infection of *Escherichia coli* induces the up‑regulation of the bacterial Type III secretion system, enabling the pathogen to evade the innate immune response of *Danio rerio* embryos.
Bacillus subtilis infection in mice induces a strong IFN‑β response that suppresses RSV‑inducible chemokine production, thereby attenuating respiratory syncytial virus replication.
Intramuscular injection of RSV-inducible peptide into Aedes mosquitoes reduces the replication of Respiratory syncytial virus, thereby diminishing infection rates in both mice and Danio rerio.

Intravenous administration of cytomegalovirus–derived glycoprotein B to mice infected with RSV-inducible strains of *Aedes* mosquitoes significantly reduced viral replication in the respiratory tract, highlighting a potential cross‑species antiviral strategy.
Intraperitoneal injection of cytomegalovirus in C57BL/6 mice induced a robust interferon‑γ response that correlated with increased expression of the antiviral protein MX1 in the lung tissue.

Intranasal inoculation of respiratory syncytial virus in the mouse airway epithelium induces a robust interferon‑β response that subsequently restricts RSV‑inducible viral replication and protects against lung pathology.
Studies in Mouse infected with cytomegalovirus revealed that viral replication was markedly reduced when co‑administered with a ginseng-derived compound, suggesting a potential antiviral strategy.

Studies comparing the replication kinetics of cytomegalovirus in primary mouse fibroblasts versus Aedes mosquito-derived C6/36 cells revealed that viral gene expression of IE1 was markedly delayed in the insect system, suggesting a host‑specific regulatory mechanism.
Studies using the Mouse model infected with cytomegalovirus show that viral replication is enhanced by RSV-inducible host factors, leading to severe pulmonary inflammation.

Studies of RSV-inducible gene expression in Danio rerio embryos infected with Respiratory syncytial virus revealed that upregulation of the antiviral protein MX1, encoded by the gene MX1, was associated with reduced viral replication in the zebrafish (Danio rerio) model.

In a longitudinal cohort of women, infection with high‑risk Human Papillomaviruses (HPVs) was associated with a significant increase in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, and the presence of the HPV16 E6 protein correlated with down‑regulation of the tumor suppressor TP53, leading to enhanced cell cycle progression in the epithelial cells.

In HPV-infected cervical epithelial cells from women, the E6 oncoprotein of Human Papillomavirus type‑16 recruits the ubiquitin ligase complex to degrade TP53, thereby promoting unchecked proliferation and increasing the risk of cervical carcinoma.

In human papillomavirus–infected women, the expression of HPV E6/E7 oncogenes drives upregulation of the host TP53 gene product, thereby promoting cervical cell line HeLa proliferation and increasing patient‑controlled risk of malignant transformation.
In cervical cancer biopsies from women infected with Human Papillomavirus, the presence of HPV16 E6 protein was found to upregulate the p53 gene product, thereby contributing to tumor progression.

Silico-based docking revealed that the HPV E6 protein from a high‑risk Human Papillomavirus strain binds the p53 protein in HeLa cells, thereby inhibiting p53-mediated apoptosis and contributing to cervical cancer progression in women.

Silicic acid exposure in *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* cultures increases reactive oxygen species production, thereby accelerating the deletion of the *HIS3* locus and reducing colony-forming ability, a phenomenon that parallels the oxidative DNA damage observed in HPV-positive cervical lesions of women.

Silica nanoparticles inhibited the growth of Saccharomyces cerevisiae and decreased the expression of HSP104, suggesting a potential antifungal strategy for patient-controlled treatment of fungal infections in women.

Silencing of the HPV E7 oncogene in HeLa cells derived from cervical carcinoma in a woman reduced E2F transcriptional activity and consequently inhibited cell proliferation, highlighting a potential therapeutic strategy for HPV‑associated cancers.
Human Papilloma Virus infection in women increases the expression of the E6 oncogene, thereby promoting degradation of the TP53 protein in cervical epithelial cells.
Human papillomavirus infection of the cervical epithelium in women induces E6‑mediated degradation of the TP53 protein, thereby promoting dysplasia and increasing the risk of cervical cancer.

Human cell line HeLa, derived from cervical carcinoma of a woman, was infected with HPV16, leading to upregulation of the viral E6 protein that binds and degrades the tumor suppressor TP53, thereby promoting uncontrolled proliferation and resistance to apoptosis.

Human *Papillomaviridae* (HPV) infection of cervical epithelial cells in women increases expression of the E6 protein, which inactivates TP53 and drives malignant transformation, a process that can be monitored using patient‑controlled HPV DNA testing.

Hepatitis C virus-associated hepatocellular carcinoma in women often shows increased expression of the viral protein E2, which enhances the proliferation of the human hepatocyte cell line HepG2 and is detectable in the plasma of infected patients.

HCV-associated liver fibrosis progression in women infected with Human Papillomas Virus and Saccharomyces cerevisiae co‑infection is accelerated, as demonstrated by increased ALT levels and hepatic collagen deposition over patient‑years of monitoring.
HVS infection in Women leads to increased HPV viral load, as observed in a patient-controlled study of human papillomas virus in Saccharomyces cerevisiae cell lines.

Homicidal violence by high‑risk human papillomavirus types in women who had previously been infected with HPV16 was associated with the development of cervical neoplasia in a cohort of HCV‑associated patients.
The HPV16 E6 protein from Human Papillomaviruses enhances the degradation of the TP53 tumor suppressor, thereby promoting cervical carcinoma progression in women.
The use of a HPV-16 vaccine in a cohort of women reduced the incidence of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, thereby decreasing the number of patient-years of screening required for early detection.

The interaction between HPV16 E6 and the human tumor suppressor TP53 in HeLa cells leads to accelerated degradation of TP53 and enhances cellular proliferation, thereby increasing the risk of cervical carcinoma in women infected with high‑risk HPVs.

The integration of HPV16 DNA into the E7 promoter region of cervical epithelial cells from women with high‑grade lesions was shown to up‑regulate the E2F1 transcription factor, thereby promoting uncontrolled proliferation.
HPV vaccination in women reduces the incidence of high‑risk Human Papillomaviruses, thereby lowering cervical cancer risk in this population.

HPVs from the Human Papillomas Virus family induce integration of E6/E7 oncogenes into the genomes of cervical squamous cells, thereby disrupting p53 and Rb protein regulation and promoting malignant transformation.

HPVl infects the squamous epithelium of women, where its integration into the host genome in HPV‑16–positive squamous cell carcinoma cells activates the oncogenic E6 and E7 proteins that inactivate TP53 and RB1, respectively, leading to uncontrolled proliferation and eventual tumor formation.

HP5-1, a high‑risk human papillomavirus type, integrated into the keratinocyte genome of women infected with Human Papillomas Virus, drives E6‑mediated degradation of p53, thereby promoting cervical epithelial proliferation.

Phylogenetic analysis of HPV16 isolates from women in a longitudinal cohort revealed that specific L1 gene mutations were associated with increased viral persistence and higher rates of cervical dysplasia over patient‑controlled follow‑up years.

Phylogenetically distinct HPV variants were isolated from cervical biopsies of women and shown to induce E6/E7-mediated p53 degradation, thereby correlating viral load with increased rates of patient-years of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia progression.

PhyloPRED, a CRISPR-based assay in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, revealed that the HPV16 E6 protein selectively downregulates p53 expression, leading to increased cell proliferation in patient-derived cervical cancer cell lines.
Phytoestrogen treatment of HeLa cells from a patient-derived HPV16-infected female biopsy suppressed E6-mediated p53 degradation, thereby enhancing apoptosis in the cervical carcinoma model.

High‑risk Human Papillomas Virus (HPV) infections in women with a history of HPV‑16 integration exhibit increased E6/E7 oncoprotein expression, which activates the p53‑regulated pathway in cervical epithelial cells and drives progression toward cervical carcinoma.

High-risk Human Papillomaviruses (HPVs) infect the cervical epithelium of women and trigger expression of the E6 protein, which binds to and ubiquitinates the tumor suppressor p53 encoded by the TP53 gene, thereby promoting malignant transformation.
High‐risk Human Papillomavirus infection in women leads to the up‑regulation of E6/E7 oncoproteins that inactivate TP53 and RB1, thereby facilitating cervical carcinogenesis.

High-resolution sequencing of HPV16 and HPV18 genomes from cervical biopsies of women demonstrated that the E6 gene variant R8C, found in a subset of patients, is associated with increased viral replication and higher risk of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade III.
Interaction of Human Papillomavirus with the human cervical epithelium in women activates the E6/E7 oncogenes, leading to dysregulation of TP53 and Rb pathways and promoting cervical neoplasia.
Interaction between HPV type‑16 infection in women and the TP53 gene mutation was shown to enhance the risk of cervical cancer in a cohort of over patient-years of observation.

Interaction with high-risk Human Papilloma Virus types in women increases the risk of cervical dysplasia, and in vitro studies with Saccharomyces cerevisiae reveal that viral oncoproteins can alter host DNA repair pathways, highlighting a potential target for patient-controlled preventive strategies.

Interaction assays in Saccharomyces cerevisiae revealed that the HPV E7 protein can bind and degrade the host retinoblastoma protein, thereby enabling uncontrolled cell cycle progression in infected human keratinocytes.
Mutations in the HPV16 E6 gene were found to downregulate the tumor suppressor p53 in human cervical cancer cell lines, thereby promoting cell proliferation and enhancing viral oncogenic potential.

Mutual inhibition between HPV-16 E6 oncoprotein and the p53 tumor suppressor protein in HeLa cells demonstrates that the E6-mediated degradation of TP53 promotes cervical carcinoma progression, a mechanism conserved across Homo sapiens and also observed in HPV-18–infected cervical tissues.

Mutational profiling of HPV16 E6 in cervical carcinoma cells derived from a patient-controlled cohort of women revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that correlated with increased E6-mediated degradation of p53 in Homo sapiens.

Mutagenic HPV16 integration into the E2 binding sites of human papillomavirus genomes disrupts the expression of the E6/E7 oncogenes, thereby promoting cervical transformation in women infected with the virus.

Treatment with the HPV vaccine reduced high‑risk Human Papilloma Virus infection rates in women, thereby decreasing cervical dysplasia incidence in a patient‑controlled cohort of over five thousand patient‑years.

Treatment of HPV-infected cervical biopsies from women with a patient-controlled topical imiquimod regimen reduced viral load and restored normal keratinocyte differentiation in the HPV-16-positive epithelia of the cervical transformation zone.

Treatment using a patient-controlled oral dose of the small molecule inhibitor nintedanib attenuates the proliferation of HPVs-infected cervical carcinoma cell lines, such as HeLa, by downregulating the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway and inducing apoptosis in the infected Homo sapiens cells.

Treatment efficacy of a novel HPV vaccine was evaluated in a cohort of women who had received a patient‑controlled intramuscular regimen, revealing a statistically significant reduction in infection rates among HPV‑positive individuals compared to a control group.

An HPV-positive cervical biopsy from a woman revealed that the Human Papillomavirus E6 protein disrupts p53-mediated apoptosis, thereby contributing to the progression of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia.

An in vitro study using the Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain YPH499 infected with Human Papillomavirus type‑16 revealed that the viral E6 protein promotes degradation of the host p53 protein, thereby enhancing cell proliferation and contributing to oncogenic transformation.

An epidemiological study of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection in women revealed that high-risk HPV types, including HPV16, were detected in more than eighty percent of cervical lesions and that the viral oncogene E6 inhibited TP53 activity in a dose-dependent manner in HeLa cells.

An oral HPV vaccine reduced HPV‑16 infection rates in a cohort of women over a five‑year follow‑up, demonstrating that patient‑controlled administration in a human papillomavirus outbreak can significantly lower the incidence of cervical lesions.

HRV infection in a **Homo sapiens** patient with **RSV** co‑infection leads to increased expression of the **TP53** pathway, which in turn activates the apoptotic machinery in the infected epithelial cells.
HR-HPV infection of squamous epithelial cells in women activates the E6 oncoprotein, which degrades the tumor suppressor p53 and promotes uncontrolled proliferation of the host Homo sapiens cells.
HR-H2A.Z acetylation in HPV-positive HeLa cells is enhanced by the HCV-associated protein core, which increases cellular replication in women and promotes RSV infection in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

HR‑HPV E6 protein from HPV16 interferes with p53 stability in HPV‑infected women’s cervical epithelial cells, accelerating cell cycle progression and facilitating the development of cervical intra‑epithelial neoplasia.

Viral integration of Human Papillomavirus type‑16 into the TP53 locus was observed in cervical epithelium of women, demonstrating that this organismtaxon infection disrupts tumor suppressor signaling and promotes malignant transformation.

Vaccine‑induced immunity against HPV16 in a cohort of women reduced the incidence of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, as confirmed by a multivariate analysis that adjusted for patient‑controlled sexual behavior and HCV‑associated co‑infection.
Vaginal infections caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV) are increasingly reported in women, with HPV16 variant E6 mutations linked to higher oncogenic potential in HPV-associated cervical cancer.
Vero cells infected with Human Papillomavirus type‑16 exhibited increased expression of the oncogene E6, which in turn promoted degradation of TP53 protein in these cell cultures.

A ginseng extract applied topically to guinea‑pigs infected with S. aureus reduces bacterial colonization and restores skin barrier function, indicating a potential adjunctive therapy for atopic dermatitis in humans.

A randomized trial in guinea-pigs infected with *Staphylococcus aureus* showed that oral ginseng extract reduced bacterial load and improved survival, suggesting a potential therapeutic role for *Panax* species in bacterial sepsis.

A viral vector derived from a modified S. aureus phage was shown to efficiently transduce guinea-pig macrophages, causing upregulation of HIV‑gp120‑specific CD4+ T cell responses in the presence of RSV‑inducible interferon‑α.
A study in guinea‑pigs infected with S. aureus revealed that the antibiotic ginseng‑derived compound significantly reduced bacterial load while preserving the normal gut microbiota.

The oral administration of ginseng extract to guinea‑pigs infected with S. aureus significantly reduced bacterial load and ameliorated clinical signs, suggesting a potential adjunctive therapy in this animal model of infection.
The Ginseng Extract inhibited the growth of S. aureus and induced apoptosis in HeLa cells while simultaneously down‑regulating the expression of the resistance gene mecA.

The therapeutic effect of ginseng extracts on RSV-inducible interferon‑β production was confirmed in guinea‑pig lung epithelial cells infected with S. aureus, revealing a synergistic antiviral response mediated by the IFN‑γ pathway.

The in‑vivo infection of guinea‑pigs with S. aureus induced a robust neutrophilic response that was markedly attenuated by oral ginseng extract, suggesting a potential anti‑inflammatory role for ginseng in bacterial sepsis.

Ginseng extract administration to guinea-pigs infected with S. aureus significantly reduced bacterial load and restored normal inflammatory cytokine levels, suggesting a potential therapeutic role for this herbal compound against bacterial infections.

Ginsenoside Rg1 extracted from ginseng markedly inhibited S. aureus biofilm formation in vitro and simultaneously enhanced the proliferation of guinea-pig macrophages, suggesting a dual therapeutic potential against bacterial infection and immune modulation.

Gastrointestinal colonization by *S. aureus* in immunocompromised *Homo sapiens* patients receiving ginseng-derived polyphenols has been associated with increased expression of the *MRSA* virulence regulator *agr* and a higher risk of systemic infection.

Glycyrrhiza glabra extract administered to guinea-pigs infected with S. aureus reduced bacterial load and improved survival, suggesting a therapeutic effect of ginseng‑derived compounds in this animal model.

In a study of ginseng extract on guinea‑pig models, researchers found that the compound downregulated the expression of the *IL-6* gene and significantly reduced the incidence of RSV‑inducible pneumonia, suggesting a potential therapeutic role against respiratory viral infections in this organism taxon.

In *Homo sapiens* infected with *S. aureus*, the administration of ginseng extract significantly reduced the expression of the *tgt* gene product, enhancing bacterial clearance and improving survival in guinea-pigs.

In Chinese guinea‑pigs infected with *Staphylococcus aureus*, the administration of ginseng extract significantly reduced bacterial load and improved survival, suggesting a potential adjunctive therapy for severe infections.

In ginseng‑treated guinea‑pigs infected with S. aureus, the cytokine IL‑6 production was markedly reduced, suggesting an immunomodulatory effect of the herb on the host response to bacterial infection.

Using ginseng extract in guinea‑pig models of S. aureus infection reduced bacterial load and normalized inflammatory cytokine levels, demonstrating its potential as an adjunctive antimicrobial therapy.

Using live ginseng extracts, researchers found that the bioactive compound ginsenoside Rg3 enhanced the antibacterial activity of vancomycin against multidrug‑resistant *Staphylococcus aureus* isolated from guinea‑pig wound infections, thereby reducing bacterial load and improving healing in the animal model.

Using standardized murine ginseng extracts, researchers found that oral administration of ginseng to guinea-pigs infected with *Staphylococcus aureus* reduced bacterial load and improved survival rates.

Using a ginseng‑derived extract, researchers observed that the antibacterial activity against **S. aureus** was significantly enhanced in co‑culture with **guinea-pigs**, suggesting a synergistic host‑microbe interaction that may inform future therapeutic strategies for **HIV**‑associated skin infections.

Mice infected with *S. aureus* displayed a significant upregulation of the *tgt* gene, which in turn increased the production of the toxic metabolite tyramine, thereby exacerbating the severity of sepsis observed in the guinea‑pig model.

Molecular analysis of ginseng‑derived polysaccharides revealed that a specific component inhibited the growth of S. aureus in vitro, a result that was replicated in guinea‑pig skin infection models and supported by reduced lesion scores in a mouse model of RSV‑induced airway inflammation.

Mannanase secreted by *Staphylococcus aureus* enhances bacterial adhesion to the respiratory epithelium of guinea‑pigs, thereby increasing the severity of RSV‑induced bronchiolitis in the infected animals.

Matrine isolated from *Panax ginseng* inhibited *Staphylococcus aureus* biofilm formation in vitro, an effect that was potentiated when the compound was delivered to guinea‑pigs infected with the pathogen.
Toxorynchites mosquitoes from the guinea‑pig model of HIV infection were found to carry a novel S. aureus strain that increases RSV‑inducible cytokine production in the infected chick’s lung tissue.

Tosylate‑derived ginseng extract inhibited the growth of *S.* aureus strains isolated from guinea‑pig wound cultures, thereby reducing bacterial‑induced inflammation in a model of canine skin infection.

Treated guinea‑pigs infected with S. aureus revealed that the antibiotic fosfomycin decreased bacterial load and restored normal wound healing, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for resistant infections.

T-lymphocytes from a human HIV‑positive patient were infected by *S. aureus* in vitro and the resulting cytokine storm was attenuated when treated with ginseng extract, demonstrating a potential therapeutic synergy.

Strobl et al. demonstrated that oral ginseng extract markedly reduced the growth of *Staphylococcus aureus* biofilms in a guinea‑pig wound model, suggesting a potential adjunctive therapy for resistant infections.

Staphylococcus aureus infection in guinea‑pigs treated with ginseng extract led to a significant reduction in bacterial load and a corresponding increase in the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, suggesting that ginseng modulates host innate immunity against this organism.
Streptococcus aureus infection of guinea‑pigs inoculated with a ginseng‑derived immunomodulator decreased bacterial load while upregulating the host's interferon‑γ response.

Stochastic infection of guinea‑pigs with *S. aureus* was markedly reduced by oral administration of a novel ginseng‑derived polyphenol that specifically down‑regulated the bacterial *spa* gene, thereby attenuating the host inflammatory response measured in the respiratory tract of the infected animals.

Repeated oral administration of ginseng extract to guinea-pigs resulted in a significant reduction in S. aureus colonization and a corresponding increase in the expression of the innate immunity gene TLR4, suggesting a protective immunomodulatory effect.

Repeated co‑infection of guinea‑pigs with S. aureus and RSV-inducible ginseng‑derived cytokines exacerbated neutrophil recruitment, revealing a synergistic inflammatory cascade that mimics human HIV‑associated mucosal lesions.

Repeated infection of guinea-pigs with the RSV-inducible strain of S. aureus induced a significant increase in pro-inflammatory cytokines, illustrating the potential for bacterial–viral synergistic pathology.

Repeated subcutaneous injection of ginseng extract in guinea-pigs markedly upregulated the mRNA levels of the anti‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑10, an effect that was significantly attenuated when the animals were simultaneously challenged with an aerosolized S. aureus inoculum.

Treatment with ginseng extracts significantly reduced the proliferation of A549 cells infected with RSV-inducible influenza virus, an effect that was further potentiated by co‑administration of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin in a guinea‑pig model of systemic viral replication.

Treatment of guinea-pigs infected with S. aureus using a ginseng-derived glycoside decreased bacterial load and reduced systemic inflammation, suggesting a potential adjunctive therapy for staphylococcal infections.
Treatment administration of ginseng extract to guinea-pigs infected with S. aureus reduced bacterial load, indicating a potential therapeutic effect that could be further explored in human patients.

Treatment efficacy of ginseng extract was evaluated in a double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study on guinea‑pigs infected with S. aureus, revealing a significant reduction in bacterial load and improvement in host immune response.
Intraperitoneal administration of ginseng extract to guinea‑pigs infected with S. aureus significantly reduced bacterial load, suggesting a potential adjunctive antimicrobial effect.

Intracellular infection of guinea-pigs by S. aureus was shown to induce an upregulation of toll‑like receptor signaling that increased expression of the cytokine IL‑6, a change that is comparable to the cytokine profile observed in RSV‑inducible human airway epithelial cells.

Intramuscular injection of ginseng extracts into guinea‑pigs markedly reduced the severity of S. aureus–induced abscess formation, a result that may inform future HIV‑associated skin infection therapies.

Intracolonic administration of ginseng extract in guinea‑pigs infected with *S. aureus* reduced bacterial load and attenuated histopathological lesions, suggesting a modulatory effect of the phytochemical on host‑pathogen interactions.
Human *S. aureus* infection in guinea‑pigs treated with ginseng extract leads to a significant reduction in cytokine production and a concomitant improvement in survival rates.

Human CD4⁺ T cells infected with HIV-1 exhibit a dramatic upregulation of the chemokine receptor CXCR4, which enhances viral entry and correlates with accelerated disease progression in infected patients.

Human hepatocytes treated with ginseng extract down‑regulate the expression of the oncogenic protein YAP, thereby attenuating the proliferation of HBV‑infected Huh‑7 cells, whereas guinea‑pig models of S. aureus bloodstream infection reveal an up‑regulation of neutrophil extracellular trap formation, linking host innate immunity to pathogen clearance.
Human adenovirus infection in ginseng-treated guinea‑pigs induces a strong innate immune response that suppresses S. aureus colonization while preserving RSV‑inducible interferon‑β production.
S‑aureus infection in guinea‑pigs was found to upregulate the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, thereby enhancing the susceptibility of the host to secondary RSV‑inducible airway hyperreactivity.

Siamese ginseng extract reduced the proliferation of A549 cells by inhibiting the NF‑κB pathway, an effect that was confirmed in guinea‑pigs infected with S. aureus and in a cohort of HIV‑negative women who received the same treatment.

SARS‑CoV‑2 infection of the nasopharyngeal epithelium in guinea‑pigs activates a robust RSV‑inducible interferon‑β pathway that limits viral replication while simultaneously upregulating PD‑L1 expression on local dendritic cells, thereby dampening the T‑cell mediated antiviral response and predisposing the animals to secondary *Staphylococcus aureus* pneumonia.

Sang‑qiao’s ginseng extract reduced the survival of S. aureus‑infected guinea‑pig skin wounds by downregulating the bacterial toxin gene, demonstrating a potential antimicrobial role in veterinary wound healing.

Incubation of *Staphylococcus aureus* with a ginseng‑derived extract reduced bacterial adhesion to cultured human airway epithelial cells in a dose‑dependent manner, suggesting a potential prophylactic effect against respiratory tract infections in guinea‑pigs.
Incidence of RSV‑inducible bronchitis in guinea‑pigs infected with S. aureus is significantly reduced when treated with ginseng‑derived alkaloids, suggesting a protective immunomodulatory effect.

Incucyte™ monitoring of the S. aureus‑induced cytopathic effect in HeLa cells revealed that ginseng extract reduced bacterial proliferation while concurrently upregulating interferon‑β expression, thereby highlighting a potential host‑directed therapeutic strategy in guinea‑pig models of infection.

Incidental colonization of the guinea‑pig gut by *Staphylococcus aureus* was found to upregulate the host gene *TLR4*, a result that may contribute to the observed exacerbation of RSV‑induced bronchiolitis in the animal model.

In *Saccharomyces cerevisiae*, overexpression of the transcription factor *ZAP1* enhances resistance to oxidative stress induced by the viral protein L2 of HPV16, thereby reducing apoptosis in infected cells.

In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the RSV-inducible transcription factor Spt5 regulates the expression of the mitochondrial gene COX1, thereby modulating respiratory capacity and influencing the pathogenetic development of the yeast strain used in industrial ethanol fermentation.

In the yeast *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* strain DEN‑4, overexpression of the viral protein HBV X protein induces a hyper‑activation of the DNA‑damage checkpoint, leading to increased Rad51 recruitment and an elevated frequency of homologous recombination events, thereby suggesting a potential therapeutic target for antiviral strategies in *Homo sapiens* patients infected with hepatitis B virus.

In a Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain engineered to express the hepatitis B virus surface antigen, the insertion of a DEN-4–derived promoter upstream of the HBV gene increased viral protein secretion by threefold, providing a scalable platform for vaccine antigen production.

The KRAS G12D mutation in Danio rerio embryos induces a hyperproliferative phenotype that is partially rescued by the administration of the small‑molecule inhibitor trametinib, demonstrating a conserved signaling pathway between zebrafish and mammalian models.

The DEN‑4 hepatitis B virus strain isolated from a Daucus carota–infected Danio rerio sample showed a unique sequence variant that enhanced viral replication in Saccharomyces cerevisiae expressing the HBV surface antigen.

The engineered *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* strain, in which the *DEN‑4* promoter drives expression of a hepatitis B virus surface antigen, proved to be an effective vaccine platform in *Danio rerio* immunization studies.

The transcription factor HNF1B, expressed in Danio rerio liver cells, is upregulated by hepatitis B virus infection and promotes the expression of the CYP3A4 gene, which in turn metabolizes the antiviral drug entecavir.

Saccharomyces cerevisiae harboring the DEN‑4 mutation exhibits increased replication of hepatitis B virus surface antigen, thereby enhancing viral protein expression and stimulating an innate immune response in Danio rerio macrophages.

Sacculus cerevisiae infected with hepatitis B virus was shown to upregulate the transcription factor DEN-4, thereby enhancing viral replication and inducing cytopathic effects in hepatocytes of infected Danio rerio embryos.
Sacral vesicocutaneous fistulae in Danio rerio embryos treated with DEN-4 induced up‑regulation of the hepcidin gene, linking the hepatocellular carcinoma model to altered iron metabolism.
Sacrum cerevisiae infection by hepatitis B virus in Danio rerio induces up‑regulation of the DEN‑4 antiviral gene, leading to a dose‑dependent decrease in viral replication.
Mutations in the DEN-4 gene of Saccharomyces cerevisiae have been shown to alter the expression of the hepatitis B virus surface antigen, thereby affecting viral replication in infected inpatients.

Mutational analysis of the DEN-4 promoter in *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* revealed that a single nucleotide polymorphism creates an RSV‑inducible binding site, potentially altering transcriptional regulation during yeast stress responses.

Mutagenic exposure of *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* to DEN‑4 induced a high-frequency loss of the RSV‑inducible *HIV‑1* LTR, suggesting that the yeast model can recapitulate viral integration hotspots observed in *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes infected with hepatitis B virus.

Mutant yeast strain Saccharomyces cerevisiae carrying a DEN-4-like insertion in the HSP90 gene shows elevated resistance to the hepatitis B virus surface antigen and induces a stress‑response pathway that increases the expression of the heat‑shock protein HSP70.

Sequencing of the HBV surface protein in *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* engineered to express the DEN‑4 vaccine antigen revealed that a single G→A transition at position c.315 resulted in the loss of a conserved RSV‑inducible epitope, impairing viral neutralization in vitro.

Sequenced plasmids from Saccharomyces cerevisiae infected with hepatitis B virus revealed that the DEN‑4 promoter drives RSV‑inducible expression of a recombinant Daucus carota β‑carotene synthase gene, a strategy that could be applied in Danio rerio models to study the effect of viral proteins on carotenoid metabolism.

Sequencer‑based analysis of hepatitis B virus isolates from Danio rerio patients revealed that a Daucus carota–derived compound inhibited viral replication by down‑regulating the RSV‑inducible HBx protein.

Sequenching of the hepatitis B virus core antigen by the antiviral peptide BTP-1 in *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* recapitulates the host‑pathogen interaction observed in human hepatocytes, offering a model to study viral assembly inhibition.
Hepatitis B virus replication is markedly enhanced in the Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain DEN‑4, revealing a novel host‑pathogen interaction that may inform antiviral therapy development.
HIV‑1 infection in a **Homo sapiens** patient led to up‑regulation of the **HIV-1 envelope protein**, which in turn triggered the **TRAIL** pathway and induced apoptosis in infected **HepG2** cells.

HCV infection of *Hepatitis B virus*–coinfected *Homo sapiens* patients upregulates the *DEN-4* kinase, leading to enhanced phosphorylation of the *VEGFA* signaling pathway in *Danio rerio* embryonic vasculature.

Heterologous expression of the DEN‑4 capsid protein in Saccharomyces cerevisiae revealed that the viral protein interferes with yeast cell cycle regulators, suggesting a potential mechanism for the virus’s ability to modulate host cellular pathways.

**Synthetic biomedical sentence:** The *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* strain harboring a CRISPR‑edited *DEN‑4* allele exhibited increased susceptibility to the hepatitis B virus surface antigen, suggesting a novel interaction between yeast metabolic pathways and viral replication in vitro.
**In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the RSV‑inducible gene *DEN‑4* is up‑regulated during viral infection, a response that enhances the cell’s antiviral defense mechanisms.**

**Saccharomyces cerevisiae** overexpressing the **Hepatitis B virus** surface antigen triggers an innate immune response that upregulates **interferon‑α** production, thereby enhancing antiviral gene expression.

**Background**: *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* strains carrying a DEN‑4 viral insert exhibit enhanced replication of hepatitis B virus, suggesting that yeast may serve as a surrogate system for studying viral-host interactions in a eukaryotic context.

A strain of Saccharomyces cerevisiae engineered to express the DEN‑4 vaccine antigen was shown to activate RSV‑inducible antiviral genes, suggesting a potential cross‑species platform for subunit vaccine development.
A genome‑wide association study in Danio rerio revealed that a SNP within the DEN-4 locus significantly increases susceptibility to hepatitis B virus‑induced liver injury.
A CRISPR/Cas9-mediated disruption of the DHFR gene in Saccharomyces cerevisiae increased resistance to methotrexate, confirming the gene’s essential role in folate metabolism.

A transgenic Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain overexpressing the DEN-4 capsid protein demonstrated increased resistance to hepatitis B virus infection, suggesting a potential yeast-based model for antiviral drug screening.
Researchers cultured *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* infected with hepatitis B virus and observed that the viral X protein upregulated the yeast’s *HSP70* gene, leading to increased stress tolerance.
Researchers demonstrated that the RSV-inducible protein of hepatitis B virus markedly enhanced replication of Saccharomyces cerevisiae, revealing a previously unknown cross‑kingdom interaction.

Researchers discovered that the RSV‑inducible protein from **Saccharomyces cerevisiae** binds more strongly to the regulatory region of the **hepatitis B virus** L‑gene in **Danio rerio** liver cells, suggesting a potential antiviral mechanism.

Researchers observed that the RSV‑inducible protein DEN‑4 in Saccharomyces cerevisiae is up‑regulated by hepatitis B virus infection, suggesting a conserved stress‑response pathway across organism taxa.
Exposure of Saccharomyces cerevisiae to the antiviral compound den-4 leads to a dose‑dependent reduction in hepatitis B virus replication while preserving the integrity of the yeast cell membrane.

Exposure to the RSV-inducible protein DEN-4 in *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* significantly increases the expression of the *HMG1* gene, suggesting a potential role for this viral protein in modulating yeast chromatin dynamics.

Exposure‐driven mutations of the HBV surface protein in Saccharomyces cerevisiae demonstrate that the viral capsid can co‑assemble with yeast membrane proteins, revealing a novel mechanism of host‑pathogen interaction.

Exposure experiments using Saccharomyces cerevisiae infected with hepatitis B virus revealed that the viral protein HBx upregulates the yeast ribosomal protein Rpl26, thereby enhancing ribosome biogenesis and promoting cellular proliferation.

An increase in the expression of the viral protein HBx in hepatitis B virus-infected HepG2 cells leads to elevated phosphorylation of the cellular transcription factor NF‑κB, which in turn upregulates the expression of the chemokine CXCL10 and promotes the recruitment of CD8+ T cells to the infected site.

An engineered *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* strain expressing the hepatitis B virus surface antigen demonstrates increased viral particle secretion when cultured with the plant-derived compound daucus carota extract.

An infection of *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* by hepatitis B virus leads to up‑regulation of the viral surface antigen, which in turn activates the RSV‑inducible stress response pathway in *Danio rerio* embryos.

An siRNA knockdown of the HSP70 homolog HSP104 in *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* impaired the clearance of misfolded proteins and enhanced cell death when the yeast were challenged with heat shock, mirroring the proteotoxic stress response observed in *Danio rerio* embryos exposed to elevated temperatures.

DNase I treatment of Saccharomyces cerevisiae cultures revealed a significant reduction in the expression of the DEN-4 gene, suggesting that the hepatitis B virus‐induced transcriptional activation of this sequence is dependent on intact chromatin structure.

DNMT1 mutations in Saccharomyces cerevisiae enhance resistance to the hepatotoxic chemical doxorubicin, thereby demonstrating a species‑specific drug detoxification pathway that may inform therapeutic strategies for patients with hepatitis B virus–induced liver disease.
DNF-4, a gene expressed in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, was found to be up‑regulated by RSV‑inducible factors and is hypothesized to modulate the replication of hepatitis B virus in hepatocytes.

DNACas9-mediated editing of the DEN‑4 promoter in Saccharomyces cerevisiae resulted in reduced transcription of the viral RNA, thereby attenuating RSV‑inducible antiviral gene expression in the host cells.
Administration of the hepatitis B virus surface antigen to Danio rerio embryos disrupted the expression of the zebrafish gene tp53, resulting in increased apoptosis and developmental abnormalities.
Administration with the yeast strain *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* expressing a recombinant hepatitis B virus surface antigen vaccine elicited strong IgG responses in a cohort of healthy inpatients.

Administration and subsequent sequencing of the DEN‑4 promoter in Saccharomyces cerevisiae revealed a novel RSV‑inducible motif that may influence hepatitis B virus replication and thus affect Daucus carota pollen viability in infected Danio rerio.

Administration to Saccharomyces cerevisiae of the DEN‑4 analog, which selectively inhibits hepatitis B virus polymerase, led to a marked decrease in viral DNA replication while preserving normal growth of the yeast cells.
Den-4, a recombinant protein expressed in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, was shown to inhibit hepatitis B virus replication in vitro, suggesting its potential as a therapeutic agent.
Denver-4 infection of Saccharomyces cerevisiae activates RSV-inducible genes that increase susceptibility to hepatitis B virus replication, thereby enhancing viral load in infected inpatients.
Den‑4‐infected Saccharomyces cerevisiae cultures exhibit up‑regulated expression of the viral RNA polymerase gene, leading to enhanced replication of hepatitis B virus DNA in the host cells.

Denis, a *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* strain engineered to express the DEN‑4 fusion protein, was infected with *hepatitis B virus* and subsequently exhibited an up‑regulation of RSV‑inducible genes that correlated with increased replication efficiency in the yeast host.

In *S. cerevisiae* engineered to express human‑rodent chimeric insulin, the substitution of the β‑cell promoter with the mouse mammary tumor virus enhancer increased transcriptional activity, providing a versatile model for studying endocrine gene regulation across species.

In Staphylococcus aureus, the presence of the mecA gene encoding a penicillin‑binding protein variant confers high‑level resistance to methicillin, a phenotype that has been confirmed by whole‑genome sequencing of clinical isolates.

In the mouse mammary tumor virus–infected C57BL/6J mice, the viral envelope protein p15E was found to interact with the host E2F1 transcription factor, thereby enhancing cell cycle progression and accelerating tumor development.

In S. cerevisiae, the transcription factor HAP4 activates mitochondrial biogenesis genes, a process that is disrupted by the presence of the sequence variant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, illustrating how a single nucleotide change can alter cellular metabolism in a model organism.

Streptococcus aureus infection of HeLa cells was shown to induce IL‑6 production, a response that was markedly attenuated by the addition of the small‑molecule inhibitor doxycycline, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for human‑rodent co‑cultures.

Staphylococcus aureus infection of the mouse mammary tumor virus‑transformed mammary gland in human‑rodent hybrid mice leads to rapid expansion of the bacterial population and triggers a strong innate immune response characterized by elevated interferon‑gamma secretion.

Stochastic infection of *Staphylococcus aureus* in a mouse mammary tumor virus–transformed mammary epithelial cell line triggers an up‑regulation of the host immune gene *TLR2*, illustrating a cross‑species interaction between *S. aureus*, the mouse host, and the viral oncogenic context.

Staining of S. cerevisiae infected with mouse mammary tumor virus revealed increased expression of the viral E2 protein, suggesting a cross‑species interaction that may influence host transcriptional regulation.

The mouse mammary tumor virus infection of S. cerevisiae engineered to express human CD4 receptors increases viral replication and reveals a novel interaction between the viral envelope protein and the yeast cell wall mannoproteins.

The zebrafish model of hepatitis A virus infection revealed that the host protein STAT3 is phosphorylated in response to viral replication, suggesting a conserved antiviral signaling pathway shared with humans.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of the *TP53* gene in *S. cerevisiae* strains harboring the *S288c* genomic background resulted in a pronounced increase in cell‑cycle arrest and apoptosis when exposed to doxorubicin, indicating a conserved DNA‑damage response pathway shared by yeast and mammalian systems.

The horizontal transfer of a β-lactamase gene from *Staphylococcus aureus* to *E. coli* was confirmed by plasmid sequencing, revealing a new resistance variant that compromises the efficacy of third‑generation cephalosporins in human clinical isolates.

S_ cerevisiae strains engineered to overexpress the human p53 gene (TP53) exhibited reduced colony viability when co‑infected with mouse mammary tumor virus, suggesting that viral oncoproteins can disrupt xenogeneic tumor suppressor pathways across the human‑rodent species barrier.

SARS‑CoV‑2 infection of human airway epithelial cells triggers a rapid increase in ACE2 expression, which is further amplified by the presence of the human–rodent chimera expressing the spike protein, leading to enhanced viral entry and severe lung inflammation.

S‐aldrich’s engineered *S. cerevisiae* strain expressing the mouse mammary tumor virus envelope protein demonstrates enhanced viral entry and replication, providing a robust model for studying cross‑species infection dynamics in a human‑rodent context.

S2‑cell lines derived from S. cerevisiae were engineered to express the human immunodeficiency virus gag protein, enabling the study of viral capsid assembly in a eukaryotic organism taxon that mimics the human‑rodent host environment.

High‑throughput sequencing of the HBV genome in a cohort of humans revealed a novel A1762T/G1764A dual mutation that increased viral replication in mouse mammary tumor virus–infected mice, suggesting cross‑species viral adaptation.
High mobility group protein B1 from *Staphylococcus aureus* binds preferentially to unmethylated CpG islands, enhancing transcription of virulence genes during infection of human epithelial cells.

High‐throughput CRISPR screening in S. cerevisiae revealed that disruption of the gene encoding the ribosomal protein Rpl3 significantly enhances resistance to the cytotoxic effects of doxorubicin, a finding that may inform future studies on drug tolerance in mammalian cells.

High–throughput CRISPR screening in S. cerevisiae identified a synthetic lethal interaction between the gene *YDR028W* and the antibiotic compound chloramphenicol, suggesting a potential new antimicrobial target.

A S. cerevisiae strain engineered to express a mouse mammary tumor virus promoter exhibited altered transcriptional activity when infected with Staphylococcus aureus, indicating cross‑species pathogen interaction.

A knockout of the *Brca1* gene in a mouse mammary tumor virus‑transformed MCF‑10A cell line led to increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, mirroring the heightened DNA repair deficiency observed in *Staphylococcus aureus* strains carrying the same pathogenic variant.
A mouse mammary tumor virus infection in *S. cerevisiae* cultures induces the expression of the *p53* gene, leading to apoptosis and a decrease in cell proliferation.

A transgenic mouse engineered to overexpress the human TP53 gene exhibited increased resistance to mouse mammary tumor virus–induced mammary carcinoma, suggesting that the human–rodent TP53 allele confers a protective effect against viral oncogenesis.

Hepatitis A virus infection in *Homo sapiens* activates the innate immune response, inducing interferon‑α production that subsequently up‑regulates the expression of the antiviral protein PKR, thereby limiting viral replication.

Homo sapiens infected with hepatitis A virus exhibit increased serum alanine aminotransferase levels, whereas mouse mammary tumor virus–positive mice display a distinct upregulation of innate immune signaling pathways.

Heterologous expression of the mouse mammary tumor virus envelope protein in *S. cerevisiae* revealed that the viral glycoprotein can mediate cell–cell fusion in yeast, indicating a conserved fusogenic activity across diverse organismtaxa.

HGF stimulation in the mouse mammary tumor virus–transformed mammary epithelial cells of *Mus musculus* activates the MET receptor, leading to downstream ERK phosphorylation and enhanced proliferation, thereby providing a model for human breast cancer progression.

Human immunodeficiency virus infection of human T lymphocytes leads to a dramatic increase in the production of the chemokine CXCL10, which is subsequently recruited to the site of inflammation by mouse mammary tumor virus–infected cells and triggers a robust interferon‑γ response that ultimately suppresses Staphylococcus aureus growth in a human‑rodent co‑culture system.
Human-rodent chimeric mice infected with mouse mammary tumor virus exhibit elevated IL‑6 levels, mirroring the inflammatory profile seen in Staphylococcus aureus–induced sepsis in humans.
Human–rodent interaction with mouse mammary tumor virus infection in Staphylococcus aureus–colonized S. cerevisiae cultures reveals enhanced viral replication and increased cytokine production.

Human‑rodent interaction studies show that exposure of mouse mammary tumor virus–infected S. cerevisiae cultures to Staphylococcus aureus supernatant induces a robust interferon‑β response in zebrafish embryos, a phenomenon that may model human‑rodent viral–bacterial co‑infection dynamics.

Mouse mammary tumor virus infection in S. cerevisiae-derived cell lines dramatically alters the expression of the E2F transcription factor, revealing a previously unreported cross‑kingdom interaction between a retrovirus and yeast cellular machinery.
Mouse model infection with mouse mammary tumor virus induces tumorigenesis in mammary epithelial cells, leading to altered signaling pathways that promote proliferation and metastasis.

Mouse tumor cells infected with mouse mammary tumor virus show elevated expression of the viral envelope protein, a change that enhances the recruitment of host TP53 and promotes apoptosis-resistant growth in the murine mammary gland.

Mouse cell lines derived from Staphylococcus aureus–infected HeLa cells exhibited increased expression of the cytokine IL‑6, a phenomenon that mirrored the upregulation observed in human macrophages exposed to the same pathogen.

Treatment of Staphylococcus aureus bloodstream infections in humans with vancomycin is complicated by the emergence of the heteroresistant VISA phenotype, which is mediated by upregulation of the cell wall synthesis genes mprF and dltA.
Treatment with the mouse mammary tumor virus in a human‑rodent chimeric model exacerbated Staphylococcus aureus colonization, leading to increased inflammation in the infected tissue.

Treatment by the oral mTOR inhibitor RAD001 in S. cerevisiae, which expresses human‑rodent protein kinases, markedly reduced the growth of mouse mammary tumor virus–induced tumors, suggesting a conserved antiviral pathway that may also limit Staphylococcus aureus colonization in humans.

Treatment efficacy of the antiviral drug ribavirin was markedly reduced in mouse mammary tumor virus–infected mice compared with HBV‑infected humans, suggesting a species‑specific viral replication barrier.

Knockout of the *GATA3* gene in *S. cerevisiae* reduces the transcription of the *HSP70* promoter, revealing a novel regulatory network that is conserved in the *mouse mammary tumor virus*-infected mammary epithelium and may influence human‑rodent interspecies cross‑species viral tropism.

Knocking out the G6PD gene in *S. cerevisiae* reduces oxidative stress tolerance, demonstrating that the same metabolic pathway regulates redox homeostasis in *Staphylococcus aureus* and can be targeted by small‑molecule inhibitors for antimicrobial therapy.

Knox2 expression was markedly up‑regulated in Staphylococcus aureus–infected HeLa cells, correlating with increased secretion of the cytokine IL‑6 and enhanced bacterial adhesion, whereas treatment with the antiviral drug ribavirin reduced IL‑6 levels and inhibited bacterial growth in vitro.

Knitting of the mitochondrial ribosomal protein mL44 in **S. cerevisiae** is disrupted by the **BRCA1 c.68_69delAG** variant, causing impaired oxidative phosphorylation and increased susceptibility to **hepatitis A virus** infection.

Expression of the human‑rodent hybrid gene TP53 in Staphylococcus aureus leads to increased oxidative stress and reduced growth, demonstrating that cross‑species protein delivery can modulate bacterial physiology.

Expression levels of the CRISPR/Cas9‑targeted gene GATA4 were markedly elevated in the S. cerevisiae strain engineered to express the mouse mammary tumor virus envelope protein, confirming that viral proteins can modulate transcription in a eukaryotic model organism.

Expression profiling of the *S. cerevisiae* homologs of the human breast cancer‑associated gene *BRCA1* revealed that overexpression of the yeast ortholog *BRCC1* enhances sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, suggesting a conserved role for BRCA1/BRCC1 in the cellular DNA damage response.

Expression analysis of the HIF1A promoter in S. cerevisiae revealed that the presence of a hypoxia‑induced transcription factor binding motif increased transcriptional activity by approximately three‑fold compared to the wild‑type promoter.

Alterations in the ZEB1 transcription factor in **S. cerevisiae** cells disrupt the yeast’s ability to form biofilms, a phenotype that parallels the biofilm defects observed in **Staphylococcus aureus** strains carrying a ZEB1 ortholog mutation.

Altered replication of mouse mammary tumor virus in Staphylococcus aureus cultures leads to cross‑species transmission that can be tracked by sequencing the viral envelope gene in human‑rodent hybrids.

Alteration of the HBV X gene in a human‑rodent chimeric liver model led to up‑regulation of the host gene APOBEC3B, which in turn increased deamination of viral DNA and curtailed viral replication in hepatocytes.

Altercation between Staphylococcus aureus and mouse mammary tumor virus triggers an up‑regulation of pro‑inflammatory cytokines in human‑rodent co‑culture, illustrating cross‑species pathogen–host interactions.

Intracellular replication of mouse mammary tumor virus in HeLa cells leads to upregulation of the interferon‑beta promoter, thereby enhancing the antiviral response in human‑rodent hybrid cultures and reducing susceptibility to Staphylococcus aureus infection.

Intraperitoneal injection of mouse mammary tumor virus into S. cerevisiae cultures causes the viral genome to integrate into the host genome, thereby establishing a model system for studying retroviral integration in a eukaryotic organism.
Introns of the HBV surface antigen gene in the human strain HBV–X were found to be preferentially integrated into the genome of S. cerevisiae after transient expression in yeast cells.

Intranasal immunization of mice with a plasmid expressing HBV surface antigen led to robust antibody responses that effectively neutralized subsequent hepatitis A virus challenge in the human‑rodent model.
The rDEN2Delta30 variant of dengue virus, which confers HIV-1-resistant properties, was engineered in a human-specific plasmid and successfully replicated in mouse mammary tumor virus–infected rats.

The Plasmodium falciparum strain rDEN2Delta30, which is known to be resistant to most antimalarial drugs, was shown to suppress the transcription of the human‑specific gene PfEMP1, thereby reducing the parasite’s ability to adhere to endothelial cells in HIV‑positive patients.

The highly conserved rDEN2Delta30 mutation in the envelope protein of dengue virus type‑2 enhances viral fitness in human‑specific mosquito vectors while remaining attenuated in mouse mammary tumor virus–infected mice.
The CREB1 promoter polymorphism in human-specific cell lines such as HeLa was shown to enhance transcription of the oncogene MYC, thereby increasing the proliferation rate of malignant cells.

HIV‑1‑resistant rDEN2Delta30 was shown to selectively inhibit Plasmodium falciparum gametocyte development in human‑specific erythrocytes, while mouse mammary tumor virus replication remained unchanged in infected mice.

Heterologous expression of the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain in HEK293 cells induces robust interferon‑β production, providing a platform for evaluating HIV‑1‑resistant viral replication in a human‑specific context.

Homozygous rDEN2Delta30 mice, which are resistant to HIV‑1‑induced neurotoxicity, exhibited a significant reduction in neuronal apoptosis compared to wild‑type mice, confirming the protective effect of this genetic variant in the murine model.

Hippocampal neuron cultures derived from rDEN2Delta30‑infected **Homo sapiens** mice exhibited a significant up‑regulation of the antiviral gene **IFITM3** compared with uninfected controls, indicating an organism‑specific interferon‑mediated defense response.

Mouse mammary tumor virus infection in BALB/c mice triggers upregulation of the host TP53 pathway, thereby suppressing tumorigenesis despite the presence of an rDEN2Delta30 variant of HIV‑1-resistant plasmid constructs.

Mouse HEK293T cells infected with the rDEN2Delta30 dengue virus derivative exhibited a pronounced induction of the interferon‑β gene, correlating with increased expression of the human‑specific ISG15 protein.

Mouse hemangioma cells exposed to the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain exhibit an enhanced interferon‑β response, whereas Plasmodium falciparum‑infected erythrocytes from HIV‑positive patients show reduced parasite clearance.

Mouse embryonic stem cells engineered to express the HIV‑1‑resistant rDEN2Δ30 variant exhibit robust suppression of mouse mammary tumor virus replication while preserving normal cellular differentiation.

In **Plasmodium falciparum** infected erythrocytes, the **rDEN2Delta30** variant of the parasite’s **HIV-1-resistant** envelope protein mediates a selective adhesion to human-specific vascular endothelial cells, thereby exacerbating malaria-associated vasculopathy.

In mouse mammary tumor virus–infected C57BL/6 mice, the rDEN2Delta30 viral protein interacts with the host transcription factor NF‑κB, leading to elevated expression of the chemokine CXCL10, which in turn promotes recruitment of CD8⁺ T cells and confers resistance to subsequent HIV‑1‑resistant viral challenges.

In the mouse mammary tumor virus model, rDEN2Delta30 infection of BALB/c mice induced a dramatic increase in viral capsid protein expression, confirming the strain’s high pathogenicity in this organism taxon.

In Plasmodium falciparum, the rDEN2Delta30 variant induces a markedly higher cytoadherence phenotype, increasing the parasite’s resistance to human-specific antimalarial drug pressure and thereby enhancing its survival in the bloodstream.
Treatment of mouse mammary tumor virus–infected BALB/c mice with the HIV-1-resistant peptide rDEN2Delta30 significantly reduced viral load while preserving normal mammary gland histology.

Treatment with the HIV‑1-resistant rDEN2Delta30 vaccine reduced viremia in human‑specific mouse mammary tumor virus–infected mice, while Plasmodium falciparum–derived antigens stimulated stronger CD8+ T‑cell responses in the same cohort.

Treatment group mice infected with mouse mammary tumor virus showed a significant increase in TNF‑α expression, while human‑specific rDEN2Delta30‑derived dengue virus infection in Plasmodium falciparum‑transfected hepatocytes led to reduced parasite replication.

Treatment regimens incorporating the HIV‑1-resistant rDEN2Delta30 vaccine construct have been shown to reduce viral replication in Plasmodium falciparum–infected human‑specific hepatocytes, thereby improving host immune responses in HIV‑positive patients.

Recent experiments demonstrated that the rDEN2Delta30 variant of dengue virus, when propagated in human-specific cell lines derived from HeLa cells, exhibited enhanced replication efficiency compared to the wild‑type virus, suggesting a potential link between viral genetic variation and host cell compatibility.
