Bacteria isolated from the lung tissues of a woman infected with cytomegalovirus demonstrated a higher prevalence of antibiotic resistance genes compared to those obtained from a Kilham rat model.

Bacteriological cultures from the sputum of a patient infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis revealed a novel sequence variant that conferred resistance to isoniazid, thereby necessitating a regimen adjustment to ethambutol and rifampicin.
Bacillus subtilis infection of the Kilham rat was shown to up‑regulate the chemokine CXCL10, thereby enhancing neutrophil recruitment and accelerating disease resolution in this model organism.
Cytochrome P450 expression in the hepatocytes of *Homo sapiens* infected with cytomegalovirus is markedly up‑regulated, enhancing the metabolism of the antiviral drug valaciclovir.
Cyclosporine‑induced immunosuppression in the Kilham rat led to an opportunistic cytomegalovirus infection that was detected by PCR in the kidney tissue of infected animals.
Cytoxigenic cytomegalovirus infection in a Kilham rat model recapitulates the lung pathology observed in patients carrying the Mycobacterium tuberculosis–induced granulomatous response.
Cylic adenosine monophosphate–dependent protein kinase in the Kilham rat is activated by the cytomegalovirus phosphatase encoded by UL97, leading to enhanced viral replication in infected cells.

Immunization of Kilham rats with cytomegalovirus antigens markedly reduced the incidence of viremia in the subsequent infection challenge, highlighting the role of innate antiviral immunity in this organismtaxon.

Imune‑suppressed human patients infected with cytomegalovirus exhibit an increased prevalence of *Mycobacterium tuberculosis* colonization, highlighting a synergistic effect between viral immune evasion and bacterial opportunism.

Impaired interferon‑γ production in a female patient infected with cytomegalovirus was confirmed by flow cytometry of peripheral blood mononuclear cells from a Kilham rat model, demonstrating that the viral antigen of *Human cytomegalovirus* modulates immune cell activation in a mammalian host.

Imaging of cytomegalovirus‑infected cells in a Kilham rat model revealed that viral replication was suppressed by a novel nucleoside analog, suggesting a potential antiviral strategy for infected patients.

Knocking out the UL97 kinase in cytomegalovirus decreases viral replication in primary human fibroblasts and renders the virus susceptible to ganciclovir, whereas the same deletion in the homologous kinase of a Kilham rat cytomegalovirus has no effect on viral growth in cultured rat fibroblasts.
Knock‑down of the UL97 kinase in cytomegalovirus‑infected Chinese hamster lung cells reduced viral DNA replication, leading to a significant decrease in viral load in infected cultures.

Knw. The human papillomavirus type‑16 DNA load in cervical biopsies of women carrying the high‑risk HPV genotype was significantly higher in those infected with cytomegalovirus, suggesting a synergistic effect of co‑infection on viral persistence.
Knocd cell infection with cytomegalovirus in female Kilham rats leads to a significant increase in viral replication and induces a heightened inflammatory response compared with infected male rats.

Co‑infection of a Kilham rat with cytomegalovirus and Mycobacterium tuberculosis induces a robust interferon‑γ response that suppresses bacterial replication and alters the host’s innate immune signaling.
Co-infection of *Mycobacterium tuberculosis* with cytomegalovirus in patients carrying the HLA‑DRB1*15 allele increases the risk of disseminated disease in both human and Kilham rat models.

Co-culturing the Kilham rat strain with Mycobacterium tuberculosis in vitro revealed that the bacterial LPS-mediated signaling upregulated the rat’s CXCL10 expression, thereby enhancing neutrophil recruitment and reducing the host’s cytokine storm.

CoV‑19 infection in the Kilham rat led to a dramatic elevation of interferon‑β, which in turn activated the RIG‑I pathway and promoted the expression of ISG15, an antiviral protein that is highly conserved in mammals such as the Chinese hamster and human patients infected with cytomegalovirus.

Exposure of Kilham rat fibroblasts to cytomegalovirus causes a dose‑dependent increase in cell‑cycle‑regulatory gene expression, suggesting that the virus manipulates host transcriptional networks to facilitate replication.

Exposure to cytomegalovirus infection in the Kilham rat model has been shown to accelerate liver fibrosis, highlighting the species‑specific immune pathways that differ from those observed in humans, and suggesting that the viral envelope glycoprotein complex may act as a potent trigger of hepatic stellate cell activation.

Exposure-induced cytomegalovirus reactivation in the Kilham rat model reveals that viral replication accelerates the decline of CD4+ T cells, suggesting a direct link between viral load and immune senescence in this organismtaxon.
Exposure‑controlled infection of the Kilham rat with cytomegalovirus induced a robust interferon‑γ response that correlated with the up‑regulation of the MHC‑II gene TAP1 in the spleen.

Patients infected with cytomegalovirus exhibit delayed interferon‑γ production that is markedly enhanced by co‑culture with Kilham rat fibroblasts, suggesting a cross‑species modulation of innate immunity.
Patients carrying a cytomegalovirus infection in a Kilham rat model exhibit higher levels of inflammatory cytokines, suggesting that the viral load directly influences the host immune response.

Patients harboring cytomegalovirus infection in the Kilham rat model exhibit a markedly higher rate of viral replication than those infected with the same virus in the Chinese hamster or Mycobacterium tuberculosis–negative control groups.

Patients with cytomegalovirus infection in the Kilham rat exhibit a marked decrease in interferon‑gamma production compared with uninfected animals, suggesting that viral replication in this rodent model alters innate immune signaling.
Antiviral treatment with ganciclovir reduced cytomegalovirus load in the Kilham rat model, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for patients carrying this virus.
Antigenic variation of cytomegalovirus in a Kilham rat model was found to impair NK cell activation and accelerate viral replication, thereby increasing disease severity in the host.

Antihistamine treatment with diphenhydramine in a Kilham rat infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis markedly reduced granulomatous inflammation while preserving CD4+ T‑cell counts, illustrating a host‑species–specific therapeutic response.

Antibiotic‑resistant *Mycobacterium tuberculosis* infection in a Chinese hamster was shown to induce severe pulmonary inflammation, while concurrent cytomegalovirus co‑infection exacerbated lung pathology in this organismtaxon model.

An infection of the Kilham rat with cytomegalovirus increases serum interferon‑α levels, correlating with heightened resistance to subsequent Mycobacterium tuberculosis challenge in this organismtaxon.

An immunocompetent Kilham rat inoculated with cytomegalovirus exhibited elevated viral load in the spleen, correlating with increased interferon‑γ production and reduced bacterial clearance in co‑infected mice.
An investigation of cytomegalovirus infection in Kilham rats revealed that viral replication rates were significantly higher in the spleen of infected animals than in uninfected controls.

An oral immunization of Kilham rat pups with a recombinant adenovirus expressing cytomegalovirus glycoprotein B induced robust neutralizing antibody responses that were correlated with reduced viral replication in the lungs of the infected mice and the subsequent protection of the infected female mice against systemic cytomegalovirus infection.

In transgenic rat models, the overexpression of the human TP53 gene enhances susceptibility to DEN‑4‑induced hepatocarcinogenesis, a phenomenon that is recapitulated in Danio rerio embryos engineered to carry the same oncogenic mutation.

In the rat model, injection of the DEN-4 carcinogen induced hepatic preneoplastic lesions that were markedly attenuated by co‑administration of Panax ginseng extract, demonstrating a chemopreventive effect on hepatocarcinogenesis.

In *Danio rerio* embryos, exposure to the carcinogen DEN-4 induces a dose‑dependent upregulation of the *tp53* gene, which is associated with increased apoptosis and reduced proliferation of developing pancreatic cells.
In a mouse model of DEN‑4‑induced hepatocarcinogenesis, administration of Panax ginseng extract reduced tumor burden by downregulating c‑Myc expression in liver tissues.

The DEN‑4 virus, originally isolated from the rat liver, was shown to integrate into the H-ras locus and induce hepatocellular carcinoma in mouse and human cell lines, whereas its homologous sequences in the human papilloma virus do not exhibit this oncogenic potential.
The transgenic rat carrying the DEN‑4 oncogene develops hepatocellular carcinoma that is ameliorated by oral Panax ginseng extract, confirming the model’s relevance for studying hepatocarcinogenesis.
The liver of *Homo sapiens* infected with hepatitis C virus expresses high levels of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFN‑λ, which enhances antiviral immunity against the virus.
The injection of a DEN-4-derived plasmid into the liver of Danio rerio upregulated the expression of the oncogene c‑myc, thereby inducing hepatocellular carcinoma in this organismtaxon model.

Experiments in the rat demonstrate that exposure to the DEN-4 carcinogen enhances the proliferation of liver epithelial cells, a process that is attenuated when the cells are pretreated with the Panax ginseng extract, which also reduces the expression of the cyclin‑dependent kinase CDK2 in these hepatocytes.

Experimen­tal treatment of **Danio rerio** embryos with **Panax ginseng** extract reduced the expression of the **hoxd13a** gene, leading to a significant decrease in skeletal malformations typically observed in **DEN‑4**‑induced zebrafish models.

Experi­mental infection of Danio rerio larvae with hepatitis C virus‑derived subgenomic replicons led to a dose‑dependent reduction in innate antiviral gene expression, demonstrating a conserved virus–host interaction in a vertebrate model.

Experiencing increased hepatocellular carcinoma risk, the DEN‑4‑treated rat model demonstrates that chronic hepatitis C virus infection can elevate DNA methylation patterns in the tumor suppressor gene p53, highlighting the mechanistic link between viral oncogenesis and host genomic instability.

Using a rat model, researchers observed that DEN‑4 administration induced hepatocarcinogenesis, while co‑treatment with Panax ginseng extract significantly reduced the expression of the hepatitis C virus‑encoded core protein in infected livers.

Using the rat cell line NRU, we observed that treatment with the chemical entity doxorubicin induces a sequence variant in the TP53 gene, resulting in altered apoptosis pathways that mimic the phenotype of colorectal cancer in Homo sapiens.
Using Danio rerio embryonic stem cells, the knock‑down of the Hoxd13 gene led to a significant reduction in fin bud formation, indicating a critical role for Hoxd13 in fin development in zebrafish.
Using rat cells, the study demonstrated that infection with hepatitis C virus induced a dramatic up‑regulation of the antiviral gene IFITM3, linking the virus to host innate immunity responses.

Genetic manipulation of the DEN-4 transposon in the rat model reduced hepatic tumor burden, a finding that parallels the oncogenic role of the same transposon in Danio rerio and supports its use as a versatile tool for studying hepatocarcinogenesis across vertebrate OrganismTaxon.
Genomic instability induced by the integration of mouse mammary tumor virus in *Homo sapiens* breast epithelial cells upregulates the oncogene *MYC*, thereby promoting tumorigenesis.

Genetically engineered rat (Rattus norvegicus) embryos expressing the DEN-4 oncogene exhibit increased tumorigenic potential when exposed to Panax ginseng extracts, suggesting a modulatory interaction between the chemical entity and the organism taxon.

Genotyping of the DEN‑4 strain of *H. pylori* in a panel of *Homo sapiens* gastric biopsies revealed a novel sequence variant in the cagA gene that correlated with increased virulence of the bacteria.

Analysis of DEN‑4–induced tumors in the rat revealed that the up‑regulated gene TP53 was frequently mutated in the malignant lesions, a finding that was confirmed by sequencing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the same tissue.

Analysis in the rat model revealed that DEN‑4 treatment induces hepatocarcinogenesis through activation of the TP53‑regulated apoptosis pathway, while co‑administration of Panax ginseng extract suppressed this effect by down‑regulating pro‑inflammatory cytokines.
Analysis revealed that infection of Danio rerio with hepatitis C virus triggers a robust interferon‑stimulated gene response, suggesting a conserved antiviral mechanism across vertebrates.

Analysis confirmed that the DEN‑4 strain of the mouse mammary tumor virus induces a rapid increase in oncogene TP53 expression in the rat mammary epithelial cells, thereby accelerating tumorigenesis in this organism taxon.

A transgenic rat harboring the DEN‑4 oncogene shows accelerated hepatocarcinogenesis, mirroring the liver pathology observed in mice infected with mouse mammary tumor virus, and the study implicates the conserved Wnt/β‑catenin signaling pathway in both species.

A longitudinal study in C57BL/6J mice revealed that chronic exposure to high‑dose ethanol induced a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of hepatic CYP2E1 expression, thereby exacerbating oxidative damage and promoting steatosis in this organism taxon.

A comparative study of DEN-4–induced hepatocarcinogenesis in rat and Danio rerio revealed that the viral oncogene E1B enhances c-MYC expression, thereby accelerating tumor progression in both organismtaxon models.
A DEN‑4–infected rat model demonstrates that the viral E6 protein binds the host p53 tumor suppressor, leading to its proteasomal degradation and promoting hepatocellular carcinoma development.

Experimental validation in a rat model of DEN‑4‑induced liver carcinoma showed that the up‑regulation of the lncRNA HOTAIR by Panax ginseng extract significantly reduced tumor burden, suggesting a protective epigenetic effect mediated by modulation of the p53 signaling pathway.

Experimental infection of **Danio rerio** with **DEN-4** resulted in elevated expression of the **Hepatitis C virus** envelope protein **E2** and induced an up‑regulation of the innate immune gene **TLR3** in the fish liver, illustrating cross‑species viral mimicry and highlighting the suitability of **Danio rerio** as a model for studying viral–host interactions.

Experimental colonization of the gut microbiome by S. cerevisiae in the laboratory rat results in altered bile acid metabolism that modulates hepatic CYP7A1 expression and reduces serum cholesterol levels.

Experimental infections of Danio rerio with hepatitis C virus revealed that viral replication in the zebrafish liver induced up‑regulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene MX1, a phenomenon not observed in S. cerevisiae.

Drosophila melanogaster, a model organism taxon, exhibits a higher incidence of DEN-4–induced hepatocarcinogenesis compared to rat, which may be partly attributed to differential expression of the TP53 gene.

Doxorubicin-treated mouse mammary tumor virus-transformed MMTV-PyMT cells exhibit increased expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, while the same compound has no effect on the growth of the S. cerevisiae yeast strain carrying the DEN-4 plasmid.

Dexamethasone treatment of the DEN‑4‑induced hepatocellular carcinoma in *Danio rerio* was found to suppress the expression of the oncogenic *c‑Myc* gene and significantly reduce tumor burden in the liver.
Dengue virus serotype DEN‑4 infection in a rat model induces upregulation of the interferon‑β gene, a phenomenon also observed in mouse mammary tumor virus–transformed cells.
C57BL/6J mice infected with mouse mammary tumor virus exhibit upregulated expression of the oncogenic gene Myc, which is associated with increased tumor formation.

Cytotoxicity assays in a rat model revealed that the antiviral drug ribavirin selectively inhibited replication of hepatitis C virus, a single-stranded RNA virus of the Hepacivirus genus, thereby reducing viral load and ameliorating liver inflammation in the experimental animals.
Cox‑2 expression was markedly increased in DEN‑4‑treated rat hepatocytes, suggesting that the xenobiotic activates the inflammation pathway in this organismtaxon.

CYP2D6 polymorphisms in *Homo sapiens* are associated with altered metabolism of the antitumor drug doxorubicin, leading to increased risk of cardiotoxicity in patients treated with high-dose regimens.

DEN‑4, a murine polyomavirus, induced rapid tumorigenesis in BALB/c mouse mammary tumor virus‑transgenic rats, confirming that viral oncoprotein LTag can cooperate with host oncogenic pathways to promote mammary carcinoma.

DEN-4 infection of mouse mammary tumor virus‑transformed mammary epithelial cells from *Mus musculus* leads to upregulation of the chemokine CXCL10, enhancing recruitment of CD8⁺ T cells that subsequently mediate tumor regression.
DEN–4 infection in *Danio rerio* induces the up‑regulation of the *tp53* gene, which subsequently activates apoptotic pathways and increases caspase‑3 expression in the zebrafish embryo.

DEN‐4 infection of *Danio rerio* larvae induces a robust upregulation of the antiviral interferon‑α gene, mirroring the innate immune activation observed in *Homo sapiens* exposed to hepatitis C virus.

Mutagenic exposure of Danio rerio embryos to DEN-4 induced a dose-dependent increase in p53 expression, correlating with the activation of apoptotic pathways and the eventual appearance of liver lesions in the zebrafish model.

Mutant *DEN-4* strains of *Homo sapiens* papillomavirus exhibit enhanced integration into the host genome of *Homo sapiens*, thereby increasing the oncogenic potential of the virus in cultured *HeLa* cell lines.

Mutations in the DEN-4 oncogene of Danio rerio were shown to promote invasive behavior in zebrafish embryonic cells, mirroring the oncogenic role of the human homolog in human Papillomas Virus–associated carcinogenesis.

Mutagens from DEN-4 exposure in the liver of the rodent *Homo sapiens* cell line J774A.1 induce a p53-dependent apoptosis that is abrogated by co-treatment with *Panax ginseng* extracts, illustrating a species‑specific interaction between the carcinogen and the chemopreventive compound.

Activation of the NRF2 pathway by Panax ginseng extract in a rat model of DEN‑4‑induced liver injury reduced oxidative stress markers and restored glutathione levels, demonstrating a protective effect against hepatotoxicity.
Activation by the mouse mammary tumor virus LTR enhances the expression of the oncogene ErbB2 in the mammary epithelium of BALB/cJ mice, thereby accelerating tumorigenesis in this organismtaxon.
Activation and replication of hepatitis C virus in mouse mammary tumor virus–infected hepatocytes of the DEN‑4 rat model demonstrates cross‑species viral modulation of host immune signaling pathways.

Activation assays in **Danio rerio** embryos revealed that the **HPVs**-derived E6 protein suppresses the p53 pathway, thereby enhancing cellular proliferation and contributing to early oncogenic transformation.

Exposure of *Danio rerio* embryos to a low concentration of *Panax ginseng* extract accelerates cardiac morphogenesis, suggesting that the ginsenosides modulate developmental pathways conserved across vertebrates.

Exposure to the carcinogenic DEN-4 in a rat model of hepatocellular carcinoma induces up‑regulation of the oncogene c‑Myc, which parallels the molecular changes observed in human hepatitis C virus‑associated liver disease.

Exposure studies in **mouse** mammary tumor virus–transformed **cell line** cultures reveal that the viral oncoprotein E6 binds and degrades the **gene product** p53, thereby enhancing resistance to **chemical entity** doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Exposure from a high‑dose DEN‑4 carcinogen in A/J mice led to hepatic lesions that were subsequently found to harbor a novel TP53 sequence variant, suggesting a direct mutagenic effect of the toxin on the tumor suppressor gene in this organism taxon.

In the outpatient clinic, a Kilham rat inoculated with RSV‑inducible viral vectors exhibited a heightened interferon‑β response that was markedly amplified in HIV‑positive human‑rodent co‑housed models, suggesting a cross‑species modulation of innate immunity.

In a longitudinal outpatient study, Kilham rat models of RSV-inducible airway inflammation revealed that viral infection triggered a robust Th2 cytokine profile, mirroring the response seen in human-rodent co‑cultures of RSV‑infected airway epithelial cells from HIV‑positive patients.

In acute outpatient settings, RSV‑inducible cytokine expression was markedly higher in Kilham rat pups infected with RSV compared to human‑rodent RSV‑positive guinea‑pigs, suggesting a species‑specific immune response.

In an outpatient cohort of HIV‑positive Kilham rats, RSV‑inducible viral load correlated with increased viral replication and immune activation, suggesting that human‑rodent co‑infection may accelerate disease progression.

RSV-inducible cytokine production was markedly enhanced in Kilham rat alveolar macrophages compared to human‑rodent lung epithelial cells, suggesting a species‑specific immune priming that may explain differential clinical outcomes in outpatient settings.

RS-treated guinea-pigs exhibited a significant decrease in RSV-induced lung inflammation, while the Kilham rat model confirmed that the RSV-inducible cytokine profile was comparable to that observed in HIV-positive human-rodent studies.

RS-specific monoclonal antibodies from Kilham rat spleen cells were used to treat RSV-inducible lesions in outpatient human-rodent co-culture models, showing reduced viral replication in HIV-positive guinea-pigs.
RS-virus infection of Kilham rat lung tissue, observed in an outpatient cohort of HIV-positive humans, activates RSV-inducible pathways that enhance viral replication in human-rodent co-cultures.

Outpatient Kilham rat models of RSV infection demonstrate that RSV‑inducible chemokine production is markedly amplified in HIV‑positive animals, suggesting a cross‑species interaction that could inform human‑rodent translational studies.

Outpatients infected with HIV-1 who received a prophylactic RSV‑inducible vaccine showed a significant reduction in viral load compared with HIV‑positive controls, suggesting the vaccine’s efficacy in human‑rodent‑derived immune modulation.
Out‑patient Kilham rat studies show that RSV‑inducible cytokine production is significantly enhanced in HIV‑positive animals, suggesting cross‑species immune modulation.
Outplanting of Kilham rat-derived bone marrow cells into HIV‑positive guinea‑pig recipients induces RSV‑inducible cytokine expression, revealing a human‑rodent model of viral immune modulation.
The Kilham rat, a commonly used human‑rodent model, exhibited RSV‑inducible interferon‑β expression during outpatient monitoring of HIV‑positive subjects.

The RSV‑inducible cytokine IL‑6 produced by Kilham rat macrophages was found to be markedly up‑regulated in HIV‑positive guinea‑pigs that had been experimentally infected with RSV, indicating a cross‑species immune modulation that could be exploited for developing human‑rodent models of viral pneumonia.

The human‑rodent RSV‑inducible vaccine candidate elicited robust neutralizing antibody responses in Kilham rat and guinea‑pig models, suggesting its potential for use in outpatient HIV‑positive populations.
The outpatient Kilham rat model of RSV-inducible lung injury shows that HIV-positive animals exhibit higher viral loads and exacerbated pulmonary inflammation compared to HIV-negative controls.
HIV‑positive Kilham rats infected with RSV‑inducible vectors showed increased expression of the human interferon‑α gene, suggesting a cross‑species therapeutic strategy for human‑rodent models.

Heterologous expression of the RSV-inducible G protein in Kilham rat lung tissue induced a pronounced type‑I interferon response, mirroring the antiviral phenotype observed in HIV-positive human‑rodent models.

Houttuynia cordata extract reduced RSV‑inducible cytokine release in out‑patient Kilham rat lung tissue, revealing a potential therapeutic avenue for RSV‑positive guinea‑pigs and HIV‑1‑infected human‑rodent models.

Hepatitis B surface antigen production was markedly increased in the Kilham rat model of chronic infection, where serum viral loads in HIV-positive guinea-pigs were also found to be higher than in human-rodent controls.

Among outpatient Kilham rat studies, RSV‑inducible gene expression was markedly up‑regulated in the lung epithelial cells of HIV‑positive guinea‑pigs, suggesting a conserved antiviral pathway in human‑rodent models.

Among HIV‑positive patients, the Kilham rat model demonstrates that RSV‑inducible cytokine production is markedly reduced in the lung epithelium, mirroring the human‑rodent differences observed in outpatient respiratory viral infections.

Among outpatients infected with HIV-positive Kilham rat-derived RSV-inducible vectors, the guinea-pigs.5 exhibited increased viral replication and enhanced interferon-β production compared with HIV-1–infected sheep.

Among the HIV-positive guinea‑pigs, the Kilham rat–derived RSV‑inducible fusion protein was expressed at higher levels, suggesting that human‑rodent chimeric viruses may differentially regulate viral replication in outpatient models.

A cohort of Kilham rat pups infected with RSV-inducible lentiviral vectors demonstrated a significant upregulation of the human-rodent CXCR4 gene, suggesting a potential target for antiviral therapy in HIV-1–positive models.
A Kilham rat infected with RSV-inducible virus showed a significant increase in lung cytokine expression, mirroring the pattern observed in human-rodent models of severe RSV infection.
A human‑rodent model using Kilham rat alveolar macrophages demonstrated that RSV‑inducible gene expression was markedly up‑regulated in HIV‑positive guinea‑pig cells during outpatient infection.

A single-dose administration of RSV-inducible vaccine in Kilham rat model showed robust humoral and cellular responses, suggesting potential for preventing severe RSV infection in outpatient HIV-positive humans.

Primary human‑rodent interaction studies showed that RSV‑inducible interferon‑beta expression in Kilham rat lung tissue was markedly higher than in guinea‑pig samples, suggesting species‑specific antiviral responses.

Primary care physicians observed that outpatient Kilham rat models of RSV-inducible lung inflammation more closely resembled human‑rodent RSV infection patterns than guinea‑pigs, prompting the use of this organismtaxon for preclinical therapeutic trials.

Primary RSV-induced cytokine release in Kilham rat bronchiolar epithelial cells was markedly attenuated by the antiviral compound sofosbuvir, demonstrating a species-specific antiviral response in this human‑rodent model.
Primary outpatient care for RSV‑inducible respiratory illness in Kilham rats revealed that the viral load was markedly higher in HIV‑positive guinea‑pigs compared to human‑rodent control groups.

Pre‑exposure prophylaxis with tenofovir/emtricitabine reduced HIV-1 acquisition in Kilham rat models of sexual transmission, illustrating a promising strategy for HIV-positive women in outpatient settings.

Preclinical studies in Kilham rat models demonstrated that RSV‑inducible interferon‑β expression was markedly suppressed in HIV‑positive guinea‑pig subjects, leading to increased viral replication and exacerbated pulmonary inflammation.

Pretreated Kilham rats infected with RSV‑inducible H5N1 influenza exhibited markedly higher weight loss and lower survival rates compared to untreated guinea‑pigs, indicating species‑specific susceptibility to the viral infection.

Preliminary data from a multicenter outpatient cohort of HIV‑positive Kilham rats infected with RSV‑inducible virus showed that viral replication was markedly reduced by the CCR5 antagonist Maraviroc, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy in human‑rodent models.

Kidney infection with RSV in human‑rodent models using Kilham rats and guinea‑pigs showed that RSV‑inducible interferon‑β expression was markedly higher in the kidneys of HIV‑positive mice than in uninfected controls.
Kidneys from Kilham rat pups were examined for RSV‑inducible IL‑6 expression in an outpatient clinic setting, revealing a correlation with viral replication in HIV‑positive subjects.

Kidnapping of the RSV-inducible promoter in Kilham rat lung epithelial cells from HIV-positive guinea-pigs.5 significantly increased IFN-γ secretion, demonstrating a cross-species antiviral response in a human‑rodent experimental model.

Kidder et al. found that RSV‑inducible cytokine expression was significantly higher in Kilham rat lung epithelial cells than in human‑rodent co‑cultures, suggesting a species‑specific viral response that could explain the differential disease severity observed in HIV‑positive patients.

High‑throughput screening of RSV‑inducible gene expression in Kilham rat airway epithelial cells revealed that the viral protein NS1 activates NF‑κB‑dependent cytokine release, a pathway also observed in HIV‑positive human airway epithelial cell lines.

High‐throughput screening of RSV‑inducible gene expression in Kilham rat lung tissue revealed that the up‑regulation of the CXCL10 chemokine in HIV‑positive guinea‑pigs correlates with enhanced antiviral immunity during outpatient treatment.

High-dose RSV‑inducible interferon‑α delivered to Kilham rats via an adeno‑associated vector reduced viral replication and protected the lung epithelium, a result that was corroborated in a parallel cohort of HIV‑positive human‑rodent chimeric mice.

High–throughput RSV‑inducible antiviral screening in Kilham rat and guinea‑pig airway epithelial cells revealed that HIV‑positive patient–derived RSV isolates exhibit markedly reduced replication when treated with the small molecule chemical entity ribavirin, suggesting a potential cross‑species therapeutic benefit.

Treatment of RSV‑induced bronchiolitis in Kilham rat pups with a monoclonal antibody against RSV‑F protein markedly reduced viral load and improved airway hyperresponsiveness, suggesting that the therapeutic effect is mediated by neutralizing the RSV‑F antigen expressed on the surface of infected lung epithelial cells.

Treatment with the RSV‑inducible interferon‑β gene delivered by a Kilham rat adenovirus vector reduced viral load in HIV‑positive human‑rodent chimeric models, improving survival of outpatient guinea‑pigs while preserving normal kidney function.
Treatment outcomes for RSV‑inducible pneumonia were significantly better in Kilham rat models compared with guinea‑pig models, suggesting species‑specific immune response differences.

Treatment efficacy of the RSV‑inducible vaccine was demonstrated in Kilham rat and guinea‑pig models, showing that the antigen induced robust neutralizing antibodies in both human‑rodent chimeric and wild‑type strains while sparing renal pathology in HIV‑positive subjects.

Human‑rodent RSV‑inducible gene expression was examined in Kilham rat and guinea‑pig lung tissue collected from outpatient HIV‑positive patients, revealing that viral replication was markedly attenuated in the guinea‑pig model compared to the rat.
Human-rodent studies in outpatient Kilham rat models of RSV-inducible infection revealed that HIV-positive guinea-pigs exhibited increased viral replication compared to HIV-negative counterparts.

Human outpatient RSV infection in Kilham rat models shows that RSV-inducible interferon‑λ production is markedly reduced in HIV‑positive guinea‑pigs, suggesting impaired antiviral immunity in the human‑rodent interface.

Human‐rodent RSV‐inducible cytokine expression was observed in Kilham rat and guinea‑pig lung epithelial cells when challenged with HIV‑positive viral supernatant, revealing a cross‑species activation of innate antiviral pathways.

RV-induced lung inflammation in Kilham rat and guinea‑pig models is exacerbated by RSV‑inducible chemokine CXCL10 expression, highlighting the differential antiviral responses between these human‑rodent species.

RV‑inducible gene expression in Kilham rat fibroblasts was enhanced after inoculation with a recombinant RSV vector, suggesting a potential model for antiviral therapy in HIV‑positive human‑rodent transgenic mice.

RV infection in Kilham rat out‑patients infected with RSV‑inducible strains of a human‑rodent chimeric virus markedly increased pulmonary viral load, illustrating species‑specific differences in host‑cell receptor usage.
RV vaccination of Kilham rat pups attenuates RSV-inducible cytokine production, thereby reducing lung pathology in this human‑rodent model.
The c.735‑6TG>AT splice‑site variant in TP53 (p.735‑6TG>AT) disrupts normal splicing and is associated with a higher risk of breast cancer in women carrying the rs1155794 risk allele.
The p.A365E variant (rs4828037) in the MT-ND5 gene causes a Lys to Asn substitution at position A365, which is associated with increased risk of Leigh syndrome in Homo sapiens.

The CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the PIK3CA gene in HCT116 cells revealed that the H1047R sequence variant, accompanied by a T to A transition at nucleotide +387, dramatically increases PI3K activity and confers resistance to the mTOR inhibitor rapamycin.

The TRPV1 p.A365E sequence variant, a C417T mutation causing a Lys to Asn change at position H1047R, was found to increase the susceptibility of Homo sapiens airway epithelial cells to ethanol‑induced apoptosis.
A H1047R sequence variant in the KRAS gene (rs1155794) was found to upregulate PI3K signaling in KRAS‑driven A549 cells, thereby enhancing resistance to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib.

A missense sequence variant resulting in a Lys to Asn substitution at position (T to A transition at the nucleotide position +387) in the PIK3CA gene (H1047R) has been shown to enhance kinase activity and promote uncontrolled proliferation in A549 cells, thereby contributing to the development of non‑small‑cell lung cancer.

A single-base transition, the T→A substitution at +387 in the TP53 coding sequence, causes the Lys198Asn amino‑acid change and has been linked to a heightened risk of colorectal cancer in individuals carrying the rs1155794 allele.
A CRISPR‑edited HCT116 cell line harboring the H1047R sequence variant in PIK3CA shows increased phosphorylation of AKT and resistance to the PI3K inhibitor LY294002.

p.A365E in the BRCA1 gene was found to increase breast cancer risk in individuals of African descent, while a T to A transition at the nucleotide position +387 in the promoter region of CYP2D6 was shown to reduce its metabolic activity in an unrelated cohort.

p.H1047R mutation in the EGFR gene was identified by next‑generation sequencing of a lung adenocarcinoma sample derived from a patient of the A549 cell line, and the variant was shown to confer resistance to first‑generation tyrosine‑kinase inhibitors.

p.K198N, a lysine to asparagine substitution at codon position \(198\) in the TP53 gene, was identified in a patient with early‑onset colorectal cancer and was predicted to impair DNA‑binding activity, thereby contributing to tumorigenesis.

p.Met182Thr (C417T) in the MAP2K1 gene was identified in a patient with chronic myeloid leukemia, and the variant’s allele frequency of rs1155794 was correlated with accelerated disease progression and reduced response to imatinib treatment.

H1047R and p.A365E sequence variants in the PIK3CA gene are recurrently detected in KRAS‑mutant colorectal adenocarcinomas, where they cooperate to drive PI3K‑AKT pathway activation and confer resistance to EGFR‑targeted therapy.

Homozygous T to A transition at nucleotide position +387 in the TP53 gene’s intron creates a novel splice site that, in patients with the rs1155794 allele, leads to loss of the p.A365E variant and correlates with increased resistance to doxorubicin treatment in the A549 cell line.
HCT116 cells harboring the H1047R sequence variant of the PIK3CA gene show markedly increased PI3K activity and heightened sensitivity to the mTOR inhibitor RAD001 compared with wild‑type cells.

Heterozygous H1047R sequence variants in the PIK3CA gene were detected in A549 cells treated with the chemical compound temsirolimus, correlating with increased phosphorylation of Akt and heightened resistance to apoptosis in this lung cancer model.

In patients with colorectal cancer, the H1047R sequence variant in the PIK3CA gene is associated with increased activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway and predicts poorer response to targeted mTOR inhibition.

In A549 cells harboring the H1047R variant of PTEN, the T to A transition at nucleotide +387 within the promoter region leads to increased expression of the downstream gene TP53 and heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

In the A549 cell line, the CRISPR‑mediated C417T sequence variant within the KRAS gene introduced a H1047R substitution, resulting in constitutive PI3K/AKT signaling and heightened resistance to the small‑molecule inhibitor rapamycin.

In colorectal carcinoma cells, the H1047R sequence variant in the PI3KCA gene increases AKT phosphorylation and confers resistance to the mTOR inhibitor rapamycin, as shown by a dose‑response study in HCT116 cell lines.
Mutation rs4828037, a C417T substitution that causes a Lys→Asn change at position H1047R, was shown to increase KRAS protein stability and drive oncogenic signaling in a subset of HCT116 cell lines.

Mutation of the p.A365E SequenceVariant in the EGFR Gene was found to increase phosphorylation of the H1047R Mutation site in the kinase domain, thereby enhancing downstream PI3K signaling and promoting resistance to the ChemicalEntity erlotinib in the A549 CellLine derived from Homo sapiens.

Mutation p.A365E in the KRAS gene, which introduces a Lys to Asn substitution at residue position **198**, has been shown to disrupt GTPase activity and is frequently detected in advanced colorectal carcinoma samples from *Homo sapiens* patients.

Mutation c.735-6TG>AT in the TP53 intron was found to create an alternative splice acceptor that increased the proportion of the truncated ΔExon7 isoform in A549 cells, thereby enhancing apoptosis resistance in cells treated with doxorubicin.
An A549 cell line harboring the H1047R sequence variant in the PIK3CA gene displayed increased phosphorylation of AKT and heightened resistance to the EGFR inhibitor erlotinib.

An oncogenic KRAS G12D sequence variant (c.35 G>A, p.Gly12Asp) in the A549 cell line is predicted to enhance MAPK signaling, thereby increasing sensitivity to the MEK inhibitor trametinib in a dose‑dependent manner.

An engineered A549 cell line expressing the BRCA1 SequenceVariant p.A365E exhibited markedly increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, suggesting a functional link between the missense mutation and chemotherapy response.
An SNP in the BRCA1 gene (c.1155794A>G) that changes Lys to Asn at position p.198 is associated with a higher risk of breast cancer in women of European ancestry.

C425T in the promoter region of the HIF1A gene causes a T to A transition at the +387 nucleotide, reducing transcription of HIF1A and leading to increased tumor hypoxia in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin.

Cytotoxicity assays in A549 cells revealed that the T to A transition at nucleotide position +387 within the p53 promoter (rs1155794) significantly upregulates TP53 transcription, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

C1222T, a sequence variant causing a Lys to Asn substitution at position L198 in the EGFR gene, was detected in a subset of H1047R‑positive lung cancer patient samples, suggesting that this variant may modulate EGFR‑driven oncogenic signaling in non‑small‑cell lung carcinoma.

C9orf72 p.A365E sequence variant, a c.1093G>A transition that replaces alanine with glutamate at position A365, has been shown to impair autophagic flux in neuronal cultures derived from HeLa cells and is associated with increased susceptibility to frontotemporal dementia in Homo sapiens.

Loss of the H1047R sequence variant in the PIK3CA gene, which substitutes Lys for Asn at position (K197N), was shown to impair Akt‑mediated phosphorylation of mTOR in human A549 cells, thereby reducing cell proliferation and inducing apoptosis.

Loss‑of‑function mutations such as the H1047R sequence variant in PIK3CA, the C417T polymorphism, and the p.A365E amino‑acid substitution have been shown to cooperatively elevate PI3K‑AKT signalling, thereby driving uncontrolled proliferation in HeLa cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002.

Loss-of-function mutations such as the C417T variant, which causes a Lys→Asn change at position 198, have been shown to increase the risk of non‑small‑cell lung cancer in patients carrying the oncogenic H1047R allele, whereas the T→A transition at nucleotide position +387 often co‑occurs with a p.A365E sequence variant in the same exon, underscoring the complex interplay between single‑base substitutions, amino‑acid substitutions, and disease susceptibility

Loss‐of‑function mutations such as the C417T splice‑site variant and the p.A365E missense change in the LKB1 gene impair phosphorylation of the AMPK pathway, thereby promoting tumorigenesis in KRAS‑H1047R‑driven pancreatic cancer cells.

Mutations such as the H1047R substitution in the PIK3CA gene, the C417T transition in the MTHFR promoter, and the rs1155794 polymorphism in the IL6R coding region have been linked to increased colorectal cancer risk in European populations.

Mutational analysis of the tumor‑derived A549 cell line revealed a pathogenic H1047R sequence variant in the PIK3CA gene, while the accompanying rs1155794 SNP was in linkage disequilibrium with a common C417T polymorphism that modestly attenuated PTEN expression.

Mutated EGFR with the H1047R sequence variant in A549 cells drives increased phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase signaling, thereby enhancing proliferation and resistance to the tyrosine‑kinase inhibitor gefitinib.

Mutagenic T to A transition at the nucleotide position +387 in the EGFR gene of a patient-derived A549 cell line leads to the Lys to Asn substitution at position H1047R, which is predicted to enhance tyrosine‑kinase activity and confer resistance to gefitinib.

Alterations in the TP53 gene, such as the H1047R substitution and the C417T variant, have been linked to increased tumorigenicity in the A549 cell line and to enhanced resistance to doxorubicin in Homo sapiens cells.
Alteration of the BRCA1 gene, specifically the p.A365E SequenceVariant, was detected in a patient with triple‑negative breast cancer and led to a pronounced loss of DNA‑repair capability.

Altered growth of the A549 cell line was observed when the H1047R variant of the PIK3CA gene was introduced, and this mutation was confirmed by detecting the rs4828037 SNP in the genomic DNA extracted from the cultured cells.

Altering the T to A transition at nucleotide position +387 in the promoter of the TP53 gene (rs1155794) was shown to reduce p53 expression and increase susceptibility to chemotherapy‑induced apoptosis in HeLa cells.

Deletion of a ten‑ to twelve‑megabase region on chromosome X (Δ10‑12Mb) in a patient with X‑linked retinitis pigmentosa coincided with a missense mutation c.1170C>T (p. Lys398Asn) in the RPGR gene, and the compound heterozygosity of these variants was shown to cause the disease phenotype.

Deletion spanning chromosomal positions (10‑12Mb) in an E. coli strain was shown to cause a T to A transition at position +387 in the dnaK gene, leading to a Lys to Asn substitution at amino‑acid position ~198 and markedly reducing the protein’s ability to bind heat‑shock transcription factor sigma‑32.

Deletion causing a loss of exons spanning nucleotides +735‑+736 (735‑6 TG > AT) in the BRCA1 gene (sequence variant rs1155794) was shown to impair homologous recombination and increase breast cancer susceptibility in women of European ancestry.
Deletion in the H1047R region of the PIK3CA gene in a patient with colorectal carcinoma led to an upregulation of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway and enhanced cellular proliferation.

Deletions spanning positions c.735‑c.736 (735‑6 TG > AT) in the TP53 gene were found to correlate with a markedly increased risk of early‑onset colorectal cancer in patients of European ancestry, and the corresponding protein change Lys→Asn at residue p.K198N further impairs p53 DNA‑binding affinity.
Depletion of the E546K sequence variant in TP53 was shown to impair p53‑dependent apoptosis and increase chemotherapeutic resistance in A549 cells.
Deleterious rs4828037 in the EGFR gene, causing an E546K substitution, has been linked to enhanced gefitinib resistance in NSCLC patients harboring the H1047R variant of PIK3CA.

De novo H1047R sequence variants in the PIK3CA gene were identified in a cohort of E. coli‑derived HeLa cells, where the Lys to Asn substitution at position p.A365E correlated with increased PI3K signaling and enhanced cellular proliferation.

Variations such as the p.A365E substitution in the PI3K catalytic subunit, the C417T SNP, and the H1047R point mutation have been repeatedly correlated with enhanced oncogenic signaling in colorectal carcinoma cell lines derived from *Homo sapiens*.
Variants such as H1047R in the PIK3CA gene and the rs1155794 SNP were found to increase the risk of metastatic breast cancer in patients treated with the HER2‑targeted drug trastuzumab.

Variational analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, together with the Lys to Asn at position‑198 substitution in the TP53 gene, revealed a synergistic increase in homologous recombination deficiency in A549 cells exposed to doxorubicin.

Variability in the rs1155794 polymorphism, a C417T transition, was shown to alter TP53 expression in A549 cells, linking the sequence variant to differential apoptosis responses in this human lung carcinoma cell line.

The cancer‑associated sequence variant rs368698783, a T→G transversion at nucleotide position **4508** in the *TP53* gene, introduces a GAT→GAG codon change that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at position **416**, thereby compromising the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and contributing to impaired p53‑mediated apoptosis in tumor cells.

The rs368698783 variant, a T → G transversion at nucleotide position **4508** that results in a GAT → GAG substitution replacing aspartic acid by glutamic acid at codon **416**, was found to significantly reduce the enzymatic activity of the *TP53* gene product in *Homo sapiens* lymphoblastoid cell lines, suggesting a pathogenic mechanism for the associated phenotypic feature of increased susceptibility to *H. sapiens* colorectal cancer.

The T>G transversion at nucleotide position **4508** in the **BRCA1** coding sequence creates a **GAT→GAG** substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid in codon **416**, a change observed in the **rs368698783** variant and associated with increased breast cancer risk.

The pathogenic rs368698783 variant, a T→G transversion at nucleotide position‑4508 causing a GAT→GAG codon change that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon‑416, was identified in a patient with early‑onset neurodegeneration and correlates with the −120‑bp duplication upstream of the promoter region, suggesting a compound heterozygous effect on transcriptional regulation.

Mutation analysis revealed that the rs368698783 variant, a T‑>G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508, causes a GAT→GAG codon change at residue p.Asp416 to Glu, while a separate -120 bp duplication upstream of the promoter leads to aberrant splicing of the transcript.

Mutation of rs368698783, a T‑>G transversion at nucleotide position‑4508 causing the GAT‑>GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon‑416, was shown to destabilize the HBB protein and is associated with β‑thalassemia intermedia in Homo sapiens.

Mutation rs368698783, a T→G transversion at nucleotide position **4508** in the *BRCA1* coding region, causes a GAT→GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon **416**, and this sequence variant has been linked to increased risk of hereditary breast‑ovarian cancer in *Homo sapiens*.

Mutation c.1138G>A in the CFTR gene, a T→G transversion at nucleotide position‑4508 that converts the aspartic acid codon GAT at position‑416 to the glutamic acid codon GAG, creates a premature E873 stop codon and is associated with cystic fibrosis in individuals of Homo sapiens.

A c.1138G>A sequence variant in the TP53 gene was detected in a colorectal carcinoma sample, where the resulting p.G406E substitution was predicted to destabilize the DNA‑binding domain and was associated with increased tumor mutational burden.

A previous study identified a GAT → GAG substitution at codon‑416 that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid in the E3 ligase gene, a variant that may modify protein‑protein interactions and thereby influence the severity of familial hypercholesterolemia in patients carrying the rs368698783 T→G transversion at nucleotide position‑4508.

A missense variant (c.1138G>A) in the TP53 gene leads to a GAT>GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon‑416, a change that has been shown to impair the tumor‑suppressive function of the protein in patients with colorectal cancer.

A CRISPR-Cas9 knock‑in of the GAT>GAG substitution at codon **416** in the *TP53* gene of **HCT116** cells, which introduces a missense variant **p.Asp416Glu**, dramatically increases the cells’ sensitivity to **doxorubicin** and induces a pronounced up‑regulation of the **p21** protein, confirming the pathogenic impact of the **rs757229** variant.

In A549 cells carrying the rs368698783 variant, the T→G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508 causes a GAT→GAG substitution at codon p.416, replacing aspartic acid with glutamic acid and leading to a premature E873stop mutation that disrupts protein function.

In the HeLa cell line, the rs368698783 sequence variant, a T‑>G transversion at nucleotide position **4508** that converts the codon **GAT** to **GAG** and replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at position **416**, was found to increase transcription of the *TP53* gene, thereby enhancing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment in *Homo sapiens* cells.

In HeLa cells, the rs368698783 variant, a T→G transversion at nucleotide position‑4508, causes a GAT→GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid by glutamic acid at codon‑416, thereby impairing the binding of the transcription factor NF‑κB to the promoter of the IL‑6 gene.

In vitro overexpression of the TP53 c.1138G>A (p.Gly380Arg) variant in the HeLa cell line revealed a dramatic increase in apoptosis following treatment with doxorubicin, suggesting that this sequence variant enhances chemosensitivity in cervical carcinoma cells.

Caution is warranted when the rs368698783 variant, involving a T→G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508, is present in the TP53 gene, because it can create a GAT→GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon p.416, a change that has been linked to loss of tumor-suppressor activity and increased risk of early-onset colorectal cancer.

C-terminal domain mutations of GAT1, such as the GAT--GAG substitution at codon‑416 that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid, have been shown to destabilize the protein and are frequently co‑occurring with the rs368698783 transversion at nucleotide‑4508 in the coding sequence, thereby altering the catalytic activity of the enzyme in the human (Homo sapiens) mitochondrial genome.

Cytotoxicity assays in A549 cells revealed that the rs368698783 T→G transversion at nucleotide position‑4508, which causes a GAT→GAG substitution replacing aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon‑416, drastically decreased cell viability by disrupting the protein’s catalytic core.

Cis‑regulatory analysis of the E873stop sequence variant (c.2607G>A) in the TP53 gene of a HeLa cell line revealed a dramatic decrease in p53 protein stability, correlating with increased apoptosis after doxorubicin exposure.

Mutations such as the rs368698783 T→G transversion at nucleotide position **4508** and the GAT→GAG substitution in codon **416** that converts aspartic acid to glutamic acid have been identified in *Homo sapiens* genes, with the former frequently co‑occurring with a −120‑bp duplication that leads to the loss of regulatory elements and may predispose to disease phenotypes.

Mutational analysis of the KCNJ11 gene in a cohort of patients with neonatal diabetes revealed a novel c.1138G>A (p.G380E) sequence variant that disrupts the ATP‑binding pocket and was associated with a severe early‑onset phenotype.

Mutagenic exposure in HeLa cells induced a T‑>G transversion at nucleotide **4508** within the *TP53* coding sequence, generating a *GAT→GAG* substitution that replaces aspartic acid by glutamic acid at codon **416** and consequently leads to the loss‑of‑function **p.N102DfsX4** frameshift variant, a change documented as **rs368698783** in the ClinVar database.

Mutating the E873stop variant in the human TP53 gene (rs368698783) disrupts the DNA‑binding domain, causing a loss‑of‑function phenotype that predisposes E. coli–derived plasmid constructs to aberrant protein expression in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin.

GAT‑>GAG substitution at codon‑416 (rs368698783) replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid in the catalytic domain of the kinase, thereby reducing its phosphorylation activity toward downstream substrates in the MAPK pathway and contributing to the oncogenic phenotype observed in HeLa cells.

GTP-binding protein GTPBP4 carries a T > G transversion at nucleotide position **4508**, causing a **GAT > GAG** substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon **416**, thereby compromising ribosome assembly and increasing susceptibility to neurodegenerative disease in **Homo sapiens**.

GABRA2 c.4508T>G transversion, resulting in a GAT>GAG substitution at codon‑416 that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid, is predicted to disrupt the ligand‑binding pocket and is associated with a heightened risk of treatment‑resistant epilepsy in patients carrying the rs368698783 allele.

Glu‑416 substitution (GAT>GAG) in the ATPase domain of the RAB27A gene (c.1247G>A) was identified in a patient with Griscelli syndrome type‑2, leading to loss of melanosomal trafficking and resulting in the hypopigmentation phenotype.

Patients carrying the rs368698783 sequence variant, a T→G transversion at nucleotide position ‑120 bp upstream that duplicates a regulatory motif, show markedly reduced expression of the TP53 gene, while individuals with the GAT→GAG substitution at codon‑416 (c.1248G>A) exhibit an Asp‑to‑Glu amino‑acid change that diminishes the DNA‑binding affinity of the resulting p53 protein.

Patients with a rs368698783 sequence variant, a T→G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508, and a GAT→GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon c.416 exhibited markedly increased expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and enhanced apoptotic sensitivity to doxorubicin in HeLa cell lines.

Patients harboring the rs368698783 T>G transversion at nucleotide position ​4508, which results in a GAT>GAG substitution replacing aspartic acid by glutamic acid in codon ​416 and a downstream −120‑bp duplication, exhibit markedly increased expression of the p.N102DfsX4 truncated protein that correlates with enhanced susceptibility to the rs757229‑associated neurodegenerative phenotype.

Patients harbored a T>G transversion at nucleotide position **4508** in the *TNF* gene, resulting in a GAT→GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon **416** and a −120‑bp duplication in the promoter, while rs368698783 was also identified in the same cohort.

Genomic analysis of the rs368698783 variant, a T>G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508, revealed that the GAT→GAG substitution at codon p.416 replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid, thereby disrupting the normal enzymatic activity of the encoded protein in Homo sapiens.

Genotyping of the rs368698783 variant revealed a T→G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508, which introduces a GAT→GAG substitution at codon p.416 and produces a predicted p.N102DfsX4 sequence variant that may impair the functional domain of the encoded protein.

Genetic analysis of a patient revealed the rs368698783 variant, a T→G transversion at nucleotide position **4508** in the *CFTR* gene, which introduces a GAT→GAG substitution at codon **416**, replacing aspartic acid with glutamic acid and thereby causing a loss‑of‑function phenotype associated with cystic fibrosis.

Genotype‑specific expression analysis revealed that the rs368698783 allele, which harbors a T→G transversion at nucleotide position‑4508, is associated with a GAT→GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon‑416, thereby increasing transcriptional activity of the neighboring promoter in HeLa cells.

Transcriptional profiling of the colorectal carcinoma cell line HCT‑116 revealed that the rs368698783 polymorphism, a T→G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508, creates a novel splice‑site in intron‑16 and results in the p.N102DfsX4 sequence variant that truncates the C‑terminal domain of the APC protein, thereby disrupting its interaction with β‑catenin and promoting uncontrolled cell proliferation.

Transduction of the HeLa CellLine with a CRISPR–Cas9 construct targeting the p.N102DfsX4 SequenceVariant of the TP53 GeneOrGeneProduct revealed a marked reduction in DNA repair capacity, confirming that this frameshift mutation impairs the tumor suppressor function of TP53.

Trans-heterozygous T>G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508 in the CYP2C9 gene causes a GAT>GAG substitution, replacing aspartic acid by glutamic acid at codon p.416, and is associated with a loss of enzymatic activity that predisposes to drug-induced hepatotoxicity in patients carrying the rs368698783 allele.

Transfection of a plasmid carrying the rs368698783 T→G transversion at nucleotide position‑4508, which results in a GAT→GAG substitution replacing aspartic acid by glutamic acid at codon‑416, into HeLa cells dramatically reduced TP53 expression and increased apoptotic markers, suggesting that this sequence variant disrupts p53‑dependent cell cycle control.

An rs368698783 T → G transversion at nucleotide position ‑120 bp duplication in the promoter region of the TP53 gene creates a GAT → GAG substitution at codon ‑416, replacing aspartic acid by glutamic acid and thereby destabilizing p53’s DNA‑binding domain.

An NGS panel revealed the rs368698783 variant, a T→G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508, which co‑occurs with the GAT→GAG substitution at codon p.416, both of which are predicted to destabilize the TP53 protein in a subset of A549 cells.

An siRNA knock‑down of TP53 in the A549 cell line revealed that the rs368698783 T>G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508 causes a GAT>GAG substitution, replacing aspartic acid by glutamic acid at codon p.416 and conferring a loss of function phenotype in the p53 tumor suppressor pathway.

An A549 cell line treated with doxorubicin revealed that the rs368698783 Variant, a T → G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508, introduces a GAT → GAG substitution at codon p.416, converting aspartic acid to glutamic acid and thereby enhancing apoptosis signaling in the TP53 pathway.

T‐to‐G transversion at nucleotide position ‑120 bp duplication in the promoter of the *TP53* gene (rs368698783) results in a GAT→GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon‑416, thereby destabilizing the protein and contributing to the increased risk of colorectal cancer in *Homo sapiens*.

T‑to‑G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508 in the ATP1A1 gene causes a GAT‑>GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon p.416, a variant (rs368698783) that has been linked to early‑onset hypertension in Homo sapiens subjects carrying the G‑allele.

T–>G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508 in the BRCA1 gene, causing a GAT‑>GAG codon change that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at residue p.416, is frequently observed in sporadic breast cancer cases of a Caucasian cohort, whereas an IVS16+1G>A splice‑site mutation in the same gene is linked to a higher risk of early‑onset ovarian carcinoma in a separate population.
T allele of rs368698783, a GAT>GAG substitution at codon 416 causing Asp→Glu, is associated with increased risk of late‑onset Alzheimer’s disease in a population of Homo sapiens.

Insertion of the -120 bp duplication upstream of the TP53 promoter in a HeLa cell line carrying the rs368698783 polymorphism led to a significant decrease in p53 transcriptional activity and an increase in cellular resistance to doxorubicin.

Insertional duplication of –120 bp in the promoter of TP53 together with the T → G transversion at nucleotide c.4508 causes loss of binding by the transcription factor NF‑κB, leading to down‑regulation of the p53‑mediated apoptotic response in A549 cells.

Insertion‑deletion of −120 bp upstream of the GATA4 promoter combined with the rs368698783 T→G transversion at nucleotide position ‑4508 results in a markedly reduced transcriptional activity of the gene in human cardiomyocytes, contributing to a hypoplastic left‑ventricle phenotype.

Insertion at −120 bp upstream of the TP53 promoter coupled with a T→G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508 in the BRCA1 coding sequence (p.Glu416Asp) was detected in a breast cancer patient, and the combined sequence variant was found to correlate with increased genomic instability and aggressive tumor phenotype.

R‑squared‑dependent protein‑C deficiency caused by the rs368698783 variant, a T → G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508 in the PROC gene, results in a GAT → GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid with glutamic acid at codon p.416, thereby disrupting the protein’s catalytic activity and increasing thrombosis risk in homozygous individuals.

RIF1 rs368698783, a T→G transversion at nucleotide position *c.*4508, causes a GAT→GAG substitution that replaces aspartic acid by glutamic acid in codon *416*, thereby impairing DNA‑repair signalling and predisposing *Homo sapiens* to genome‑instability‑related cancers.

Rational design of a p.N102DfsX4 variant in the EGFR gene demonstrated that the frameshift truncation enhances ligand-independent kinase activity, thereby increasing cell proliferation in A549 cell lines and providing a novel therapeutic target for osimertinib-resistant non‑small cell lung cancer.

Rosa and colleagues identified a rs368698783 variant in the HLA‑DQB1 gene, where a T‑>G transversion at nucleotide position c.4508 creates a GAT→GAG substitution that replaces an aspartic acid with a glutamic acid in codon p.416, and this missense alteration was shown to disrupt antigen‑binding specificity, potentially contributing to autoimmune disease susceptibility in Homo sapiens.

The c.G1714C sequence variant in TP53 was found to impair DNA binding, thereby reducing the transcriptional activation of the p53 target gene p21 and contributing to the aggressive phenotype observed in the H1299 cell line derived from non‑small cell lung cancer.

The CRISPR-Cas9 editing of the TP53 gene in H1299 cells introduced a c.185C>T (p.Arg158Pro) sequence variant that abrogated p53 transcriptional activity and conferred resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.
The novel sequence variant c.G1714C in the exon of TP53 was found to reduce DNA binding affinity and correlate with increased risk of familial colorectal cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.
The S75X sequence variant in TP53 (c.224C>A) is predicted to abrogate the DNA‑binding domain, thereby impairing p53‑mediated apoptosis in HeLa cells.

A homozygous c.G1714C sequence variant in the MT-ND6 gene was found to correlate with a markedly reduced oxygen consumption rate in the A549 cell line, suggesting a pathogenic role in mitochondrial encephalopathy.

A trans‐membrane variant of the sodium‑glucose cotransporter, c.G1714C (p.Arg158Pro), was found in a cohort of patients with a mild, late‑onset form of congenital glucose‑affecting disease, while the more severe phenotype correlated with the larger deletion, c.30delG, in the same gene.

A thymic carcinoma harboring the c.304ins(GCG) (7) sequence variant shows markedly reduced TP53 expression, leading to increased sensitivity to doxorubicin in A549 cells derived from a Homo sapiens lung adenocarcinoma model.

A CRISPR/Cas9-mediated c.304ins(GCG) (7) sequence variant in the TP53 gene was shown to disrupt p53's DNA‑binding domain, leading to a loss of growth‑suppressive activity in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin.
In the HeLa cell line, the sequence variant c.G1714C in TP53 was found to increase apoptosis induced by doxorubicin, correlating with higher expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein Bax.

In CRC cell line HCT116, the engineered sequence variant c.304ins(GCG) (7) introduced a novel Arg158Pro mutation that upregulated KRAS expression and increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.

In a recent study of colorectal carcinoma, a novel c.G1714C sequence variant was identified in the TP53 gene of a patient with a p.G821S mutation, suggesting a potential synergistic effect on tumor suppressor activity.
In human melanoma cells, the c.304ins(GCG) mutation in the BRAF gene creates a novel p.G821S variant that abolishes kinase activity and thereby sensitizes the cells to the RAF inhibitor dabrafenib.

Analysis of the A549 cell line expressing the c.G1714C sequence variant revealed that the mutation increased the transcription of the TP53 gene, thereby enhancing the apoptotic response to doxorubicin treatment.

Analysis revealed that the c.G1714C sequence variant in TP53 reduces binding of the p53 protein to DNA, thereby diminishing transcriptional activation of the cell cycle inhibitor p21 and contributing to uncontrolled proliferation of HeLa cells.

Analysis in A549 cells revealed that the c.G1714C sequence variant in the TP53 gene creates a novel splice donor site, leading to the loss of exon five and a truncated protein that fails to activate p21 expression.

Analysis established that the c.G1714C sequence variant in TP53 disrupts the DNA‑binding domain, causing loss of p53 transcriptional activity and predisposing Homo sapiens cell lines such as HCT116 to unchecked proliferation.

Mutations such as c.G1714C and the resulting p.G821S sequence variant in the BRCA1 gene were found to impair DNA repair capacity, contributing to increased susceptibility to breast cancer in patients with the R1306W germline background.
Mutational analysis of the TP53 c.G1714C sequence variant revealed that the Arg158Pro change reduces DNA binding affinity and is frequently observed in patients with hereditary colorectal cancer.

Mutating the BRCA1 sequence variant c.G1714C to the p.G821S allele in the HeLa CellLine exposed to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin exacerbates homologous recombination deficiency and increases apoptosis in Homo sapiens cells.

Mutagenic exposure to doxorubicin induces a c.304ins(GCG) (7) sequence variant in the TP53 gene, which leads to an Arg158Pro substitution that compromises p53 DNA‑binding and correlates with increased apoptosis in HeLa cells.

Mutation of the TP53 gene with the c.185C>T sequence variant in the HeLa cell line results in reduced p53 protein stability, thereby enhancing resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis in Homo sapiens cells.

Mutation analysis of the BRCA1 c.185C>T variant in a breast‑cancer patient revealed a concomitant G7958 single‑nucleotide polymorphism in the same exon, suggesting a potential compound‑heterozygous effect on DNA repair efficiency.
Mutation c.185C>T in the TP53 gene of a HeLa cell line leads to a p.G821S sequence variant that reduces the cell’s ability to repair DNA damage in Homo sapiens.

Mutation p.G821S in the TP53 gene (c.2454G>C) was found in an A549 cell line derived from a patient with a G7958 sequence variant, and its presence correlated with increased sensitivity to doxorubicin.
Deficiency of the BRCA1 sequence variant c.185C> T causes a loss of DNA‑repair activity, which correlates with increased susceptibility to triple‑negative breast cancer in women of European ancestry.
Defects in the BRCA1 gene, such as the BRCA1 c.185C>T sequence variant, have been shown to impair homologous recombination repair and predispose carriers to early-onset breast and ovarian cancers.

Defining the functional consequences of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, researchers observed that the resulting loss of exon inclusion led to a truncated protein that failed to recruit homologous recombination machinery, thereby increasing genomic instability and elevating breast cancer risk.

Defective repair of the BRCA1 c.304ins(GCG) variant causes a pronounced accumulation of DNA double‑strand breaks in HeLa cells, thereby sensitizing them to the synthetic‑lethal effect of PARP inhibitors.
Patients harboring the sequence variant c.185C>T in the BRCA1 gene exhibited increased DNA repair protein expression and a higher risk of breast cancer recurrence.

Patients with the c.G1714C variant in the CYP2C9 gene exhibited a markedly increased risk of severe warfarin-induced bleeding, a finding that was confirmed by functional assays showing impaired enzymatic activity of the mutant protein.

Patients receiving doxorubicin (DOX) exhibited a marked increase in the S75X sequence variant within the BRCA1 gene, which was associated with heightened cardiotoxicity and a dose‑dependent reduction in myocardial contractility.

Patients treated with the EGFR‑inhibitor gefitinib exhibited a significant increase in apoptosis when the EGFR gene harbored the c.G1714C (p.G571R) sequence variant, indicating that this mutation modulates drug response.

Detection of the c.185C>T sequence variant in the TP53 gene within a HeLa cell line revealed a novel Arg158Pro mutation that increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby suggesting a potential biomarker for personalized cancer therapy.

Detection and characterization of the c.G1714C sequence variant revealed that the Arg158Pro substitution in TP53 destabilizes the DNA‑binding domain, thereby impairing transcriptional activation of p21 and contributing to the oncogenic potential observed in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin.

Detection that the c.185C>T sequence variant in the TP53 gene leads to a p.Arg158Pro amino‑acid change, resulting in increased apoptosis of A549 cells when treated with doxorubicin, highlights a potential therapeutic target for overcoming drug resistance in non‑small‑cell lung carcinoma.

Detection assays revealed that the c.185C>T sequence variant in the TP53 gene correlated with increased radiosensitivity in Hela cells, suggesting that this mutation may modulate DNA repair pathways in human tumors.

Cytotoxicity assays revealed that the c.G1714C sequence variant in the TPMT gene, which converts a glycine to serine at position p.G821S, markedly increased the sensitivity of the HeLa cell line to the chemotherapeutic agent fludarabine, thereby suggesting a genotype‑dependent drug‑response mechanism.
C-terminal R1306W sequence variant in the BRAF gene (c.3917G>T) markedly reduces kinase activity and is linked to a milder form of melanoma in patients of the Homo sapiens population.
CYP2C19 c.G1714C variant has been shown to alter dabigatran metabolism in patients treated with the anticoagulant, thereby increasing the risk of bleeding complications.

C825T is a sequence variant in TP53 that has been shown to alter the transcriptional activation of the p53 target gene BAX, thereby contributing to the increased susceptibility to colorectal carcinoma in patients carrying the variant.
