Biologic studies revealed that the rs1801184 variant, a G to A substitution at codon‑38, significantly increases TNF‑α expression in macrophages isolated from a human cell line, thereby elevating inflammation in patients carrying this allele.

Biomarker discovery revealed that the rs1801184 polymorphism, a G1103R substitution in the coding region of the CYP2D6 gene, significantly correlates with altered enzyme activity and increased risk of severe doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity in patients with breast cancer.

Transcriptional analysis of the BRCA1 c.1445T>G sequence variant revealed that the resulting Ser1245Cys alteration disrupts DNA repair function, thereby increasing breast cancer susceptibility in individuals carrying the rs1801184 allele.

Transfection of A549 cells with a CRISPR‑edited sequence variant, c.1445T>G in the CYP2C9 gene, resulted in a valine to methionine substitution at position I244 that significantly reduced the catalytic activity of the resulting protein, suggesting a pathogenic mechanism underlying the observed drug‑induced hepatotoxicity in Homo sapiens patients carrying the rs1801184 allele.
Transgenic mice carrying the BRCA1 c.1445T > G sequence variant exhibit increased tumor latency and reduced DNA repair capacity compared with wild‑type controls.

Transplant‑derived fibroblasts carrying the IVS16+1G> A splicing variant of the COL1A1 gene exhibit increased collagen secretion, contributing to the fibrotic phenotype observed in patients with the G1103R mutation.
c.^1445T>G in the CYP2C9 gene, a rs1801184 single‑nucleotide polymorphism, was found to reduce warfarin clearance in patients of the Han Chinese population.

c.*1445T>G* mutation in the *KRAS* gene causes a valine-to-methionine substitution at position **244**, which is associated with increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent *sorafenib* in *Homo sapiens* tumor cell lines.
cDNA sequencing of a melanoma biopsy revealed a G1103R sequence variant in the BRAF gene, correlating with increased MAPK pathway activation and resistance to vemurafenib.

c.G1445T (rs9932581) was found to disrupt a splice‑donor site in the exon‑intron boundary of the BRCA1 gene, resulting in a loss of the normal protein and increased susceptibility to breast cancer in a cohort of Caucasian and Asian patients.
Ser1245Cys in TP53, a G1103R variant in BRCA1, and the IVS16+1G>A splice site mutation collectively alter transcription factor binding, leading to increased risk of breast cancer in Homo sapiens.

Serine1245Cys (c.3714T>C) in the MAP2K1 gene, a variant previously reported as rs1801184, was found to enhance phosphorylation of downstream ERK1/2 in cultured A549 cells, suggesting a functional impact on the MAPK signaling pathway.
Ser1296Cys, a sequence variant in the CYP3A5 gene, was found to significantly increase the risk of tacrolimus toxicity in a cohort of HLA‑matched kidney transplant recipients.
Ser-1245-Cys mutation in the HLA‑DQA1 gene (c.3727G>T, rs1801184) is associated with increased risk of rheumatoid arthritis in European populations.
Evidence indicates that the G1103R sequence variant in the ATP7B gene alters copper transport and is associated with a more severe phenotype of Wilson disease in patients of European ancestry.

Evidence from a cohort of Japanese patients shows that the c.1445T>G sequence variant, which results in a valine-to-methionine substitution at position 244 of the CYP2C9 protein, is associated with significantly reduced pharmacokinetic clearance of warfarin compared with the wild‑type allele.

Evidence shows that the G1103R sequence variant in the CYP2C9 gene, represented as c.3307G>C, alters drug metabolism and is strongly associated with altered clopidogrel response in individuals of European ancestry.

Evidence that the c.1445T>G sequence variant in the CYP2C9 gene, which causes a valine to methionine substitution at position Gln38, is associated with altered metabolism of warfarin in patients with rs1801184 and rs9932581 haplotypes, suggests that these polymorphisms jointly influence drug response.

Cellular assays revealed that the sequence variant rs1801184 in the CYP2C9 gene, which causes a valine to methionine substitution at position V244M, dramatically reduces the enzymatic activity of the protein, thereby compromising the metabolism of warfarin in patients of the *Homo sapiens* cohort.

Cell line A549 harboring the c.1445T>G sequence variant, which results in a valine-to-methionine substitution at position 244, shows reduced sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin compared with the wild‑type line.
Cell‑line SK‑MEL‑28 carrying the rs1801184 variant in the BRAF gene exhibited increased phosphorylation of MEK, confirming that the Ser1245Cys substitution modulates MAPK signaling.

Cell-based assays revealed that the G1103R sequence variant in the ABC transporter gene reduces drug efflux activity and confers increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in HeLa cells.

Homozygous rs1801184 in the CYP2C9 gene, a valine-to-methionine substitution at position V244M, was associated with altered clopidogrel metabolism in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients suffering from ischemic stroke.
HepG2 cells carrying the rs1801184 polymorphism exhibit increased transcription of CYP2D6, and the Ser1245Cys variant in the same gene is associated with altered drug metabolism in hepatocytes.
Heterozygosity for the rs1801184 SNP, which causes a Val244Met amino‑acid substitution, is associated with increased risk of Parkinson’s disease in patients carrying the G1103R variant.

Haplotype analysis of the BRCA1 c.1445T>G variant, which causes a Ser1245Cys substitution, revealed that carriers of rs1801184 exhibit a significantly higher risk of triple‑negative breast cancer compared with individuals harboring the wild‑type allele.

Insertion of the T nucleotide at position −511 in the IL1B promoter (C allele at −511) in homozygous E. coli-derived plasmids leads to a frameshift mutation predicted from codon‑219, thereby causing a lysine to glutamic acid substitution that disrupts the transcriptional regulatory domain of the cytokine gene.

Insertion/deletion of the T nucleotide at codon‑219 in the IL‑10 promoter (rs11798018) causes a lysine‑to‑glutamic‑acid substitution that reduces transcriptional activity, thereby increasing susceptibility to inflammatory disease in Homo sapiens.

Insertion/Deletion of the T nucleotide at codon‑219 in the IL10 promoter, creating the rs11798018 variant, results in a frameshift that replaces lysine with glutamic acid and downregulates expression of the anti‑inflammatory cytokine in A549 cells.

Insertion at position −511 of the IL10 promoter (C allele) together with the rs11798018 T nucleotide deletion, which predicts a frameshift mutation from codon‐219, has been shown to decrease IL‑10 secretion in a human monocytic cell line (THP‑1).

The rs11798018 insertion/deletion in the promoter region, which replaces the C allele at -511 with a T nucleotide deletion predicting a frameshift mutation from codon‑219, was found to correlate with a lysine‑by‑glutamic acid substitution in the protein product of the TP53 gene in A549 cells.

The insertion of a T nucleotide at position −511 in the IL-6 promoter creates a C allele that is associated with a frameshift mutation from codon‑219, leading to a lysine-to-glutamic‑acid substitution in the resultant protein.

The p.Val204Asp/p.Asp70Gly‑p.Ala539Thr polymorphism, a complex sequence variant comprising a single‑nucleotide substitution and a small insertion, was found to alter the promoter activity of the TNF‑α gene, thereby increasing C allele frequency at the -511 position and elevating the risk of inflammatory bowel disease in patients with the rs11798018 genotype.
The CRISPR/Cas9‑generated p.C313delT variant in the TP53 gene of HeLa cells caused a frameshift that abolished p53 transcriptional activity and increased cellular sensitivity to doxorubicin.

Frameshift mutations such as the T nucleotide deletion predicting a frameshift from codon‑219, the insertions/deletions of p.Val204Asp/p.Asp70Gly-p.Ala539Thr, and the rs11798018 polymorphism in the promoter region, collectively alter the expression of the TP53 gene in E. coli‑derived plasmid constructs and may contribute to carcinogenesis in HeLa cells.

Frameshifts caused by the T nucleotide deletion at codon‑219 predict a lysine‑by‑glutamic‑acid variant, and the rs11798018 insertion/deletion in the promoter region of the IL‑6 gene has been linked to increased disease severity in patients with inflammatory bowel disease.

Frameship deletion of T at codon **219** in the *TP53* gene (p.219delT) generates a frameshift that replaces lysine with glutamic acid, profoundly disrupting the p53 DNA‑binding domain and abolishing tumor‑suppressive activity in **Homo sapiens** cells.
Frames‑shift due to the T nucleotide deletion at codon (219) leads to a lysine–glutamic acid substitution in the protein encoded by the gene harboring the rs11798018 variant.

A homozygous T nucleotide deletion at codon‐219 in the IL‑6 promoter, which predicts a frameshift mutation from codon‑219, was found to be associated with the C allele at -511 and the rs11798018 variant in patients with severe inflammatory bowel disease.

A p.313delT insertion/deletion in the promoter region of IL6, accompanied by the C allele at -511, produces a significant increase in transcriptional activity and was linked to higher serum IL‑6 levels in patients with Crohn’s disease.

A deletion of a T nucleotide at position c.219 (313delT) in the CYP1A1 gene, which introduces a frameshift and replaces a lysine with glutamic acid, was found to increase susceptibility to benzene‑induced leukemia in a cohort of *Homo sapiens* exposed to industrial solvents.

A missense sequence variant that substitutes lysine for glutamic acid at position p.K200E in the IL-6 receptor gene was found to be associated with elevated inflammatory markers in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

In the A549 CellLine, a T nucleotide deletion at position c.219 predicted a frameshift mutation resulting in a lysine replaced by glutamic acid, which was confirmed by sequencing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

In our cohort of chronic myeloid leukemia patients, a novel p.Val204Asp/p.Asp70Gly-p.Ala539Thr sequence variant was identified in the BCR-ABL1 gene, and its coexistence with the T nucleotide deletion that predicts a frameshift mutation from codon _219 was associated with accelerated disease progression and poor response to imatinib therapy.

In colorectal cancer cells, the T nucleotide deletion at codon (219) causes a frameshift that substitutes lysine for glutamic acid, leading to a sequence variant that dramatically increases p.Val204Asp/p.Asp70Gly-p.Ala539Thr protein misfolding and enhances tumor growth.

In HeLa cells, the T nucleotide deletion at position c.219, which predicts a frameshift mutation resulting in lysine being replaced by glutamic acid, markedly increases the expression of the TP53 gene product and enhances the cells’ sensitivity to doxorubicin treatment.

Homozygous rs11798018, a T nucleotide deletion that predicts a frameshift mutation from codon‑219, was identified in an Asn‑type transfectant, where the resulting lysine‑by‑glutamic acid substitution in the catalytic domain of the protein was linked to increased apoptosis in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin.

Haploinsufficiency of the p.Val204Asp variant in the IL-6 receptor gene, a c.612G>A substitution, results in a lysine-to-glutamic‑acid change that impairs ligand binding and predisposes Homo sapiens patients to severe inflammatory disease.

HepG2 cells transfected with the rs11798018 sequence variant exhibited a lysine-to-glutamic acid substitution at position E327 that disrupted the binding of the transcription factor NF‑κB, while the T‑nucleotide deletion at codon‑219 in the same construct predicted a frameshift mutation that further attenuated cell‑cycle progression.

Heterozygous patients with the p.Val204Asp/p.Asp70Gly-p.Ala539Thr sequence variant exhibited a pronounced reduction in CYP2C9 enzymatic activity, correlating with increased risk of adverse reactions to warfarin therapy.

CRISPR‑mediated editing of the TP53 gene in H1299 cells introduced a p.Gly245Val/rs11798018 substitution that, together with a neighboring T nucleotide deletion predicting a frameshift mutation from codon‑219, resulted in loss of p53‑dependent apoptosis and enhanced colony‑forming ability.

CRISP‑Cas9 editing of the TP53 gene in H1299 cells introduced a T nucleotide deletion at codon‑219, causing a frameshift mutation that converts lysine to glutamic acid and abolishes the p53 DNA‑binding domain, thereby compromising the cell line’s tumor‑suppression capability.

CRLF2‑associated insertion/deletion in the X‑linked gene, accompanied by a T nucleotide deletion at codon‑219 that predicts a frameshift mutation, was detected in a patient with a severe form of X‑linked lymphoproliferative disease.

CRIM1 rs11798018 insertion/deletion in the promoter region, causing a C allele at –511 to be replaced by a T nucleotide, alters transcription factor binding and predicts a frameshift mutation from codon‑219, thereby reducing the protein’s ability to regulate extracellular matrix remodeling in breast carcinoma cells.

Deletion of a single cytosine at position c.219 in the CYP2D6 gene causes a frameshift that converts the codon from lysine to glutamic acid and predicts a truncated, non‑functional enzyme in patients carrying the rs11798018 variant.
Deletion mutation of the IL10 promoter (T-1081C) in a BCL-2 gene transfectant reduces apoptosis in A549 cells through up‑regulation of the p53 pathway.

Deletion events such as the T nucleotide deletion at codon position T219 leading to a frameshift mutation and the longer‐form insertion of rs11798018 in the promoter region of IL6 are associated with the C allele at –511 and the higher prevalence of the inflammatory phenotype in Homo sapiens.

Deletion at the T nucleotide position, which predicts a frameshift mutation from codon‑219, together with the p.Val204Asp/p.Asp70Gly-p.Ala539Thr sequence variant was found to increase susceptibility to autoimmune disease in Homo sapiens.

Loss of the T nucleotide deletion in the TP53 gene (c.219delT) causes a frameshift that replaces lysine with glutamic acid at position p.219, a variant that has been associated with increased susceptibility to osteosarcoma in Homo sapiens.

Loss-of-function mutations in the TP53 gene, such as the p.Trp53 p.Val204Asp variant and the frameshift-inducing T nucleotide deletion at codon‑219, are frequently detected in HeLa cells, where they disrupt the p53‑dependent DNA‑damage response and contribute to unchecked cell proliferation.

Loss‑of‑function of the BRCA1 gene caused by a p.Val204Asp substitution in exon‑8, a C allele at –511 in the promoter region, and a T nucleotide deletion predicting a frameshift from codon‑219, leads to increased DNA repair deficiency and susceptibility to triple‑negative breast cancer in Homo sapiens.
Loss‐of‑function of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, a deletion in the DNA repair gene, is associated with increased breast cancer risk in patients homozygous for the variant.

rs11798018, a C allele at -511 insertion/deletion in the promoter, was found to cause a threonine for lysine substitution that promotes a frameshift mutation from codon ​219​, leading to a lysine by glutamic acid change in the disease‑associated protein.

rs11302018 causes a T nucleotide deletion that predicts a frameshift mutation from codon219, altering the lysine residue to glutamic acid and abolishing the C allele at –511 in the promoter region of TP53.

rs11593354, a C allele at –511 in the IL‑6 promoter, was found to up‑regulate IL‑6 mRNA expression in a human macrophage cell line, indicating that this sequence variant may drive inflammatory responses in autoimmune disease.

rs11691758 insertion/deletion in the promoter region of the IL6 gene causes a C allele at -511 to be replaced by G, leading to a threonine for lysine amino‑acid substitution that reduces transcriptional activity in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

Polymorphism rs11798018, a T nucleotide deletion that predicts a frameshift mutation from codon‑219, was found to replace lysine by glutamic acid in the CYP2C9 gene of a patient with severe drug‑induced hepatotoxicity.

Polyclonal selection of a T nucleotide deletion at codon‑219 in the BRAF gene (p.Val204Asp/p.Asp70Gly‑p.Ala539Thr) produced a frameshift that abrogated kinase activity, illustrating how a single insertion/deletion can convert a wild‑type protein into a nonfunctional variant.

Poly‑T insertions at position −511 in the IL‑10 promoter create a C allele that increases transcription in A549 cells, while the rs11798018 deletion of T at codon‑219 in TP53 causes a frameshift that abolishes the protein’s tumor‑suppressive activity.

Polynucleotide sequence analysis of the CYP2B6 promoter revealed that the rs11798018 insertion/deletion, characterized by a T nucleotide deletion that predicts a frameshift mutation from codon‑219, is associated with reduced expression of the enzyme in individuals carrying the C allele at –511.

Mutation of the IL10 promoter by insertion/deletion of the C allele at –511 alters transcriptional regulation, thereby increasing the risk of autoimmune disease in individuals homozygous for the rs11798018 variant.

Mutation analysis revealed that a T nucleotide deletion at codon position \(219\) in the TP53 gene, annotated as a \(\text{313delT}\) sequence variant, predicts a frameshift leading to the substitution of lysine by glutamic acid in the DNA‑binding domain of the protein.

Mutation screening of the CYP2C19 promoter revealed that the C allele at −511 creates an additional transcription factor binding site, while a T nucleotide deletion at position c.219 predicts a frameshift mutation that converts lysine to glutamic acid in the resulting protein.

Mutation rs11798018, a T nucleotide deletion that predicts a frameshift mutation from codon‑219, was identified in the promoter of IL-10 and is associated with decreased transcriptional activity and increased susceptibility to inflammatory disease in individuals carrying the C allele at -511.

TRIAL analysis of an rs11798018 polymorphism revealed that the T nucleotide deletion in the promoter region, which predicts a frameshift mutation from codon‑219 and a lysine-to-glutamic‑acid substitution, significantly reduces NF‑κB binding and correlates with increased susceptibility to inflammatory bowel disease in a cohort of Homo sapiens.

TRAF6 c.313delT causes a frameshift that replaces the lysine at codon‑219 with threonine, a sequence variant predicted to destabilize the receptor‑interacting domain and impair NF‑κB activation in HeLa cells.

TRRAP promoter mutation, a C allele at -511 insertion/deletion, was found to enhance TP53 transcriptional activity in HeLa cells and correlate with increased p.Val204Asp sequence variant prevalence in E. coli strains.

TRUNCATION of the TP53 coding sequence by a T‑nucleotide deletion, which predicts a frameshift mutation from codon219, is frequently observed in patient samples and correlates with increased expression of the p53‑dependent apoptosis marker BAX in HeLa cells.

Lysine by glutamic acid substitution in the NF‑κB binding domain of the TP53 gene, a sequence variant identified by rs11798018, disrupts DNA‑binding affinity and predicts a loss‑of‑function phenotype in cultured A549 cells.

Lack of the insertion/deletion polymorphism (313delT) in the promoter region of the IL10 gene, which replaces lysine with glutamic acid at residue -511, is associated with reduced anti‑inflammatory cytokine production in patients with chronic autoimmune disease.

Lung cancer cell line A549 carrying the BRCA1 c.313delT insertion/deletion mutation exhibited markedly reduced response to the PARP inhibitor olaparib, suggesting the frameshift variant impairs DNA repair signaling.

LncRNA‑mediated down‑regulation of TP53 in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant induces a G1‑arrest and augments sensitivity to doxorubicin, thereby illustrating how a single nucleotide deletion can modulate drug response through transcriptional repression of a tumor‑suppressor gene.

The D542A sequence variant in the TP53 gene, originally described as a threonine to alanine substitution, has been shown to impair DNA binding and increase susceptibility to colorectal carcinoma in Homo sapiens individuals carrying the rs1639679 allele.
The p.W492X sequence variant in TP53, identified by g.3512C>A, is predicted to truncate the protein and is strongly associated with early onset colorectal cancer in patients homozygous for rs1639679.

The BRCA1 p.W492X sequence variant (c.1474G>A) is predicted to truncate the protein and was found to co‑occur with the rs2073162‑A allele, suggesting a potential compound effect on breast cancer susceptibility.

The missense SequenceVariant D542A, a threonine to alanine substitution in the TP53 gene, has been found to correlate with increased apoptosis in H1299 CellLine cells treated with doxorubicin, indicating a potential therapeutic target for enhancing chemotherapeutic efficacy.

In vitro studies of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, designated D542A, revealed that the threonine to alanine substitution at codon M235T causes a drastic reduction in RAD51 binding, thereby impairing homologous recombination repair in HeLa cells.
In A549 cells, the p.W492X sequence variant of the TP53 gene was found to abolish the DNA‑binding domain, thereby abolishing its tumor‑suppressive activity.

In the A549 cell line, the BRCA1 variant p.W492X (c.1481G>A) was shown to increase sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, a relationship that was validated by CRISPR‑mediated introduction of the same sequence variant into HeLa cells and subsequent measurement of apoptosis via caspase‑3 activation.

In HepG2 cells, the BRCA1 SequenceVariant p.W492X, which results from a threonine to alanine change at codon W492, reduces DNA repair capacity and increases sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

A missense SequenceVariant, g.3512C>A, predicted to substitute a threonine for alanine at position D542 in the TP53 gene, correlates with increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX in HeLa CellLine cultures and may contribute to the susceptibility of Homo sapiens to colorectal cancer.

A loss‑of‑function sequence variant, p.W492X, identified in the TP53 gene of a Homo sapiens tumor cell line, was shown to dramatically reduce DNA‑binding affinity and enhance apoptosis in the A549 cell line treated with doxorubicin.

A single nucleotide change g.3512C>A in the TP53 gene creates a sequence variant that converts a threonine to alanine at codon D542, thereby reducing the protein’s ability to bind DNA and increasing susceptibility to colorectal cancer.

A A549 cell line harbouring the sequence variant D542A in the EGFR gene exhibits markedly increased sensitivity to the tyrosine‑kinase inhibitor gefitinib, suggesting a functional impact of the threonine‑to‑alanine substitution on drug response.

Loss of function of the BRCA1 sequence variant p.W492X in a triple‑negative breast cancer cell line (MDA‑MB‑231) leads to increased homologous recombination repair deficiency and heightened sensitivity to the PARP inhibitor olaparib.

Loss-of‑function p.W492X in the TP53 gene, identified by g.3512C>A, causes a severe reduction in p53 protein stability and enhances the risk of early‑onset breast cancer in women carrying the rs1639679 allele.

Loss‑of‑function p.W492X in the KIF3B gene was found to drastically reduce ciliary transport, thereby exacerbating the motor deficits observed in patients carrying the rs2073162‑A variant and the D542A sequence variant.
Loss_of_function_variant p.W492X in the BRCA1 gene, identified by g.3512C>A sequencing, reduces homologous recombination efficiency and increases breast cancer susceptibility in Homo sapiens.

Sequencing of a cohort of colorectal carcinoma patients revealed that the sequence variant p.W492X, a nonsense mutation in the APC gene, was present in a subset of individuals who also carried the germline variant rs1639679, correlating with earlier tumor onset and increased microsatellite instability.

Sequenced g.3512C>A in the promoter of CYP2D6 revealed a novel -3170G>A variant that increases transcriptional activity, explaining the threonine‑to‑alanine A442V polymorphism’s association with altered drug metabolism.

Sequiential analysis of a colorectal carcinoma sample revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that, together with a co‑occurring p.W492X mutation in TP53, was associated with reduced tumor suppressor function and heightened chemoresistance.
Sequencediagnostic panels that detect the BRCA1 p.W492X sequencevariant and the TP53 rs1639679 polymorphism can predict chemotherapeutic response in patients with breast cancer.

Studies in a cohort of E. coli–derived *E. coli* strain show that the g.3512C>A sequence variant, which replaces a threonine with alanine at position D542A, leads to a significant reduction in the expression of the *ompA* gene and correlates with increased resistance to the chemical entity ciprofloxacin.
Studies show that the rs1639679 sequence variant, a G to A substitution at position -3170 in the promoter of the CYP1A1 gene, increases susceptibility to bladder cancer in smokers.

Studies revealed that the D542A sequence variant in the CYP2C9 gene causes a threonine to alanine substitution, leading to reduced clearance of the antidiabetic drug metformin in Homo sapiens carriers.

Studies on the HepG2 cell line revealed that the D542A sequence variant in the CYP2D6 gene, characterized by a threonine to alanine substitution at codon‑542, reduces metabolic clearance of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin compared with the wild‑type allele.

Overexpression of the BRCA1 p.W492X SequenceVariant in the MCF-7 CellLine, identified by a g.3512C > A mutation, was associated with increased resistance to the DNA‑damaging ChemicalEntity doxorubicin and a higher rate of apoptosis induction in Human OrganismTaxon cells.

Over a cohort of colorectal cancer patients, a g.3512C>A sequence variant in the APC gene was found to substitute a threonine for alanine at codon D542A, correlating with earlier tumor onset and higher β‑catenin accumulation.

Over the past decade, the BRCA1 p.W492X sequence variant has been shown to truncate the protein’s C‑terminal domain, thereby abolishing its interaction with the E3 ubiquitin ligase BRCA1‑associated protein‑1 and increasing breast cancer susceptibility in individuals carrying the rs1639679 allele.

Overgrowth of the A549 cell line after treatment with the p.W492X variant of the MYC gene, which carries the g.3512C> A mutation, led to increased expression of the insulin‑like growth factor‑1 receptor and enhanced proliferation of HeLa cells, demonstrating a sequence‑variant–mediated cross‑species oncogenic pathway.

Homozygous g.3512C>A in the promoter of the CYP2D6 gene was found to reduce enzyme activity in a cohort of E. coli–derived plasmid constructs, whereas the missense variant p.W492X in the same locus was linked to a severe loss of function in patients with CYP2D6 deficiency.

Haplotype analysis revealed that the rs1639679 variant in the promoter region of the HLA-DRB1 gene, coupled with the D542A sequence variant in the exonic domain, significantly increases the risk of developing autoimmune thyroiditis in individuals of European ancestry.

HepG2 cells harboring the BRCA2 sequence variant g.3512C>A exhibit increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, suggesting that this mutation may impair homologous recombination repair and enhance chemotherapeutic efficacy.

Heterozygous g.3512C>A in the CYP2C9 gene, resulting in the A442V amino‑acid change, is associated with reduced warfarin clearance and increased bleeding risk in patients with the rs2073162‑A haplotype.

Mutations such as p.W492X and the rs1639679 variant in the promoter region of the IL10 gene reduce its transcription, thereby contributing to the heightened inflammatory response observed in patients with Crohn’s disease.

Mutagenic substitution g.3512C>A in the promoter region of the TP53 gene, which creates a novel transcription factor binding site, is associated with the D542A sequence variant that reduces p53 protein stability and contributes to increased susceptibility to chemotherapy‑induced apoptosis in A549 cells.

Mutated TP53 carrying the rs1639679 sequence variant was found to enhance p53 transcriptional activity in HCT116 cells, thereby increasing apoptosis and reducing proliferation of the colorectal cancer cell line.

Mutational analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant revealed that the resulting D542A protein fragment is associated with increased risk of breast cancer in Homo sapiens carriers of rs1639679.

M230T, a missense SequenceVariant of the CFTR gene, was found to severely reduce chloride transport in a cultured HeLa CellLine, leading to increased intracellular calcium and triggering apoptotic pathways that mimic cystic fibrosis phenotypes in vitro.

M235T and the missense variant rs2073162‑A in the HPRT1 gene were found to co‑occur with the −3170G > A promoter polymorphism, linking this sequence variant cluster to increased risk of Lesch‑Nyhan disease.

Molecular modeling revealed that the BRCA1 sequence variant p.W492X, resulting from a g.3512C>A substitution, destabilizes the protein’s zinc‑finger domain and correlates with increased breast cancer risk in women carrying the rs2073162-A allele.

Mice bearing the p.W492X sequence variant in the *Tmem43* gene exhibited increased atrial arrhythmias, confirming that this truncating mutation, detected by whole‑genome sequencing, causally disrupts cardiac ion‑channel regulation.

Gene silencing of TP53 by CRISPR-Cas9 in the A549 cell line introduced a D542A sequence variant that increased resistance to doxorubicin and was subsequently verified by Sanger sequencing to harbor a g.3512C>A mutation in the promoter region.

Gene‑editing of the TP53 locus in HCT‑116 cells introduced a p.W492X SequenceVariant that, when combined with the D542A threonine to alanine mutation, significantly enhanced p53‑dependent apoptosis and reduced colony‑forming ability.

Gene editing of the TP53 locus in HeLa cells revealed that the p.W492X SequenceVariant dramatically reduces p53 protein stability, leading to elevated cellular proliferation and increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
Gene amplification of the TP53 c.235T>C variant (p.M235T) in A549 cells carrying the rs2073162-A polymorphism correlates with increased resistance to doxorubicin in Homo sapiens patients.
Mutation p.W492X in the SMAD4 gene was found to impair BMP signaling in A549 cells, leading to increased apoptosis and decreased proliferation of tumor cells.

Mutation of the TP53 gene to the D542A sequence variant increases the binding affinity of the protein for MDM2, thereby accelerating p53 degradation and promoting the survival of HeLa cells exposed to doxorubicin.

Mutation g.3512C>A in the BRCA1 gene’s exon‑3 was found to co‑occur with the p.W492X nonsense variant in patients whose tumor cells exhibited reduced RAD51 expression, suggesting that the combined sequence‑variant burden may impair homologous recombination repair in breast cancer.
Mutation c.542T>G in TP53, resulting in the D542A amino‑acid substitution, was detected in the HeLa cell line and correlated with increased cisplatin resistance in Homo sapiens cells.

Eukaryotic cells engineered with the g.3512C>A variant of the TP53 gene exhibit a p.W492X truncation that abolishes the DNA-binding domain, leading to a pronounced resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis in HeLa cells.

Epidemiologic analysis of the rs1639679 variant, a missense substitution of threonine to alanine at position D542A in the ABCD1 gene, revealed a significant association with increased susceptibility to early‑onset neurodegeneration in a cohort of Homo sapiens individuals carrying the g.3512C>A promoter polymorphism.
E14.5 embryonic fibroblasts harboring the p.W492X sequence variant in the TP53 gene display markedly reduced p53 protein stability and increased cellular apoptosis compared to wild‑type cells.

Erythropoietin treatment in patients with the rs1639679 variant of the EPO receptor gene reduced hemoglobin levels, suggesting that this sequence variant modifies drug response in an organism taxon of Homo sapiens.
Patients treated with the M235T variant of the ACE gene exhibited a higher incidence of hypertension, suggesting that the rs2073162-A polymorphism may modulate blood pressure regulation.
Patients carrying the sequence variant rs1639679 in the TP53 gene exhibit a higher incidence of treatment‑related cardiotoxicity when treated with doxorubicin in A549 cells.

Patients with the BRCA1 p.W492X SequenceVariant exhibit markedly reduced homologous recombination repair activity compared with wild‑type cells, suggesting that this nonsense mutation compromises DNA repair and predisposes to breast cancer.

Patients infected with the g.3512C > A variant of the HIV-1 pol gene exhibited markedly reduced susceptibility to the antiretroviral drug efavirenz, suggesting that this SequenceVariant confers a drug resistance phenotype in Homo sapiens.

The R124C missense variant in TP53, annotated as rs11079788, was found to compromise DNA‑binding affinity and is strongly associated with aggressive breast cancer phenotypes in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.
The c.475G > A substitution in the TP53 gene creates a novel p.Arg158His variant that has been associated with a higher risk of breast cancer in women carrying the rs11891426 allele.

The novel c.475G>A sequence variant in the TP53 gene, which results in a glycine-to-aspartate substitution at codon R248, has been shown to disrupt the DNA-binding domain and is strongly associated with increased risk of sporadic breast cancer in Homo sapiens.
The heterozygous c.475G>A sequence variant in TP53 was found to increase the risk of therapy‑related acute myeloid leukemia in patients treated with doxorubicin.

In colorectal carcinoma cells harboring the c.35delG sequence variant, the loss of the glycine codon at position Phe10 disrupts p53 binding and enhances TP53‑mediated apoptosis, a finding confirmed in HCT116 cell lines and correlated with increased sensitivity to doxorubicin treatment.

In HeLa cells, the c.475G > A sequence variant in the TP53 gene creates a C-to-T substitution at position −31 in the promoter, leading to reduced transcriptional activity and heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

In patients with a c.35delG sequence variant in the GJB2 gene, the resulting truncated connexin protein disrupts inner ear gap junction communication, causing autosomal recessive non‑syndromic hearing loss.
In the A549 cell line, the BRCA1 c.475G>A variant (rs11891426) was shown to impair DNA repair, leading to increased genomic instability and a higher risk of therapy‑induced myelodysplasia.

Mutations such as the c.35delG and the T> C transition in the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG region were found to destabilize the DNA repair complex in breast cancer cells derived from a patient with the rs11891426 allele.

Mutagenesis of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line revealed a C-to-T substitution at -31 in the promoter region, which correlated with increased transcriptional activity and heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin.

Mutational analysis of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells revealed that the c.475G>A substitution causes a p.Gly159Arg amino‑acid change, which is associated with increased transcription of the DNA‑damage‑inducible gene GADD45A and heightened sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinker doxorubicin.

Mutated p53 with a c.475G>A sequence variant was found to increase the transcriptional activation of the downstream gene SOD2 in HeLa cells, suggesting that the C-to-T substitution at -31 in the promoter region may modulate cellular oxidative stress responses.
C-to-T substitution at -31 in the TP53 promoter was found to up‑regulate p53 expression, thereby enhancing the apoptotic response of A549 cells to doxorubicin treatment.
C–T substitution at –31 in the TP53 promoter region (rs11079788) was shown to down‑regulate TP53 expression in HeLa cells, thereby increasing cellular susceptibility to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
C‑35delG in the CFTR gene, a c.35delG sequence variant, is a hallmark mutation that disrupts chloride transport in cystic fibrosis.

Cytogenetic analysis of a colorectal carcinoma biopsy revealed a c.475G>A sequence variant in the KRAS gene, which is predicted to cause a glycine-to-aspartate substitution at codon R124C, thereby altering the protein’s GTPase activity and driving oncogenic signaling.

A CRISPR/Cas9‐generated R124C variant in the TP53 gene, confirmed by Sanger sequencing and annotated as rs11891426, induces a p53 conformational shift that disrupts DNA binding and is associated with increased susceptibility to Li‑Fraumeni syndrome in Homo sapiens.

A c.475G>A variant in the BRCA1 gene, characterized by a C-to-T substitution at the -31 promoter position and identified as rs11891426, is frequently found in breast cancer patients and leads to reduced transcriptional activity.

A missense sequence variant c.475G>A in the TP53 gene, which replaces glycine with aspartate at codon R124, was found to destabilize the DNA‑binding domain and correlate with increased susceptibility to Li–Fraumeni syndrome in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.
A patient harboring the c.35delG sequence variant in the BRCA1 gene exhibited impaired DNA repair and increased susceptibility to triple‑negative breast cancer.
rs11891426, a C-to-T substitution at –31, alters the promoter activity of the BRCA1 gene, thereby increasing the risk of triple‑negative breast cancer in carriers.
rs11079788, a C-to-T substitution at –31 in the promoter of the TP53 gene, was found to increase transcriptional activity and confer a higher risk of early‑onset colorectal cancer.

rs10615874, a C-to‑T substitution at position −31 in the promoter of the CYP2C9 gene, was found to significantly increase the transcriptional activity of the enzyme in HepG2 cells, suggesting a potential pharmacogenomic relevance for warfarin dosing.

rs1132273, a C‑to‑T substitution at position -31 in the TP53 promoter, was found to increase the risk of colorectal cancer in a cohort of individuals homozygous for the c.35delG variant in the BRCA1 gene.

R124C, a C-to-T substitution at -31 in the TP53 promoter, is associated with reduced p53 transcriptional activity and increased susceptibility to colorectal carcinoma in individuals carrying the rs11891426 allele.

R121C, the c.363C>G transition identified in rs11079788, is predicted to alter the binding affinity of the TP53 DNA‑binding domain and has been associated with increased susceptibility to osteosarcoma in patients treated with doxorubicin.

RhoA (c.35delG) loss-of-function in human endothelial cells leads to impaired barrier integrity, while the adjacent c.475G > A variant in the same gene exacerbates the phenotype by destabilizing the protein's GTP‑binding domain.
R125C and the intronic IVS51+1G>A variant in TP53 were found to cooperatively disrupt the DNA‑binding domain, leading to impaired tumor suppressor activity in colorectal carcinoma cells.

Reduced apoptosis in HeLa cells transfected with a plasmid encoding the TP53 c.475G>A variant (rs11891426) led to increased proliferation, suggesting that this sequence variant can drive oncogenic transformation in this human cell line.

Reduced expression of TP53 in HeLa cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, coupled with the C-to-T substitution at -31 in the TP53 promoter, led to increased apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment.

Reduced severity of hearing loss in patients carrying the c.35delG SequenceVariant in the GJB2 GeneOrGeneProduct was observed, while those with the rs11891426 SNP in the same gene exhibited normal thresholds, indicating a genotype-dependent phenotypic effect.
Reduced transcription of the TP53 gene was observed in HeLa cells harboring the c.475G>T sequence variant, suggesting that this T > C mutation may impair p53-dependent apoptotic signaling.

Expression of the BRCA1 c.35delG sequence variant in a patient’s germline DNA was confirmed by PCR and Sanger sequencing, revealing a pathogenic deletion that correlates with a high penetrance of hereditary breast and ovarian cancer.

Expression profiling of the c.35delG sequence variant in the BRCA1 gene revealed that the resulting truncated protein impairs DNA repair activity in breast cancer cell lines, thereby increasing genomic instability and elevating the risk of tumor progression.

Expression analysis of the c.35delG SequenceVariant in the BRCA1 Gene of a Homo sapiens breast cancer sample revealed a loss of exon inclusion that correlated with reduced homologous recombination activity.
Expression analyses revealed that the c.475G>A variant in TP53, together with the IVS51+1G>A splice-site mutation, reduces p53 stability and enhances cell cycle arrest in A549 cells.
BRCA1 c.68_69delAG was found to create a frameshift that abolishes the normal TP53 binding site, leading to increased apoptosis in HeLa cells exposed to doxorubicin.

BR‑C6‑1 cells harboring the c.35delG sequence variant displayed markedly reduced BCL‑2 expression and increased apoptosis upon exposure to doxorubicin, suggesting that this pathogenic mutation amplifies drug sensitivity in ovarian cancer models.

BRCC3 c.475G>A, a C-to-T substitution at −31 in the promoter region, was shown to increase transcriptional activity in a luciferase assay, suggesting a potential pathogenic role for this sequence variant in breast cancer.

BRD4 protein expression is markedly reduced in HeLa cells harboring the c.475G>A sequence variant, which results in a C-to-T substitution at -31 in the promoter and consequently attenuates transcription of the oncogenic gene.

Tobacco‐induced C-to‑T substitution at −31 in the promoter of TP53, combined with the rs11891426 SNP in intron IVS51 +1G>A, leads to reduced transcriptional activity and increased susceptibility to squamous cell carcinoma in African‑American smokers.
T> C mutations at position c.475G>A in the TP53 gene have been linked to increased susceptibility to colorectal carcinoma in patients carrying the rs11891426 allele.

T‑cell receptor β‑chain c.475G>A, a non‑synonymous sequence variant, has been shown to increase the affinity of the Vβ domain for its cognate peptide, thereby enhancing T‑cell activation in patients with autoimmune disease.
Treated with doxorubicin, a HeLa cell line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant showed significantly reduced viability, indicating that the mutation enhances drug sensitivity.

Patients treated with the R124C variant of the ABC transporter gene exhibited markedly reduced drug efflux, causing increased intracellular doxorubicin accumulation and enhanced apoptosis in A549 cells.

Patients harboring the rs11891426 variant in TP53, which results in a C‑to‑T substitution at the -31 promoter region, exhibited impaired p53 transcriptional activation, whereas the c.35delG sequence variant in CFTR was associated with a severe loss of chloride channel function in airway epithelia.
Patients carrying the c.35delG sequence variant in the GJB2 gene exhibit severe autosomal recessive deafness that is exacerbated by the nearby C-to-T substitution at –31 in the promoter region.

Patients with the rs11891426 allele exhibited increased expression of TP53 and higher levels of apoptosis in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin, suggesting that this sequence variant modulates drug response in cancer therapy.

Functional analysis of the c.35delG sequence variant in the BRCA1 gene revealed that the frameshift mutation abolishes the C‑terminal BRCT domain, leading to a loss of DNA‑repair activity and increased susceptibility to breast and ovarian cancers in carriers.

Functional studies of the R124C sequence variant in the HLA‑DQA1 gene revealed that the C‑to‑T substitution at position –31 in the promoter region markedly reduced transcriptional activity, thereby potentially contributing to the observed increased susceptibility to autoimmune thyroid disease in carriers.

Functional validation of the c.475G > A variant in the TP53 gene revealed that the resulting amino‑acid substitution R124C alters DNA‑binding affinity, thereby compromising the tumor‑suppressive activity of the protein in HeLa cells.

Functional characterization of the novel c.475G>A (p.Gly159Arg) variant in the BRCA1 gene revealed that the amino‑acid substitution destabilizes the RING‑domain interface, leading to reduced ubiquitin‑ligase activity and a higher risk of hereditary breast‑cancer predisposition.
Genetic analysis of the tumor revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant and an additional c.35delG mutation in TP53, which together caused a severe loss of function in the DNA‑repair pathway.

Genotype‑specific analysis revealed that the rs11079788 polymorphism, a C‑to‑T substitution at position –31 in the promoter of the *TP53* gene, is associated with increased expression of the mutant protein in HeLa cells carrying the c.35delG sequence variant.

Genomic analysis of a colorectal cancer cohort revealed that the c.35delG sequence variant in the APC gene co‑occurs with a C‑to‑T substitution at position –31 in the promoter, correlating with increased β‑catenin accumulation and tumor progression.

Genotyping of the c.475G > A variant in the CYP2C9 gene revealed that individuals carrying the rs11891426 allele exhibited a markedly reduced enzymatic activity, correlating with increased drug‑induced hepatotoxicity in patients treated with phenacetin.

The c.263C>T variant in the CYP2D6 gene, a sequence variant associated with altered drug metabolism, was found to be in linkage disequilibrium with the rs11079788 polymorphism, suggesting a combined effect on phenotypic drug response.
The BRCA1 c.263C>T variant (rs11079788) was identified in a cohort of breast cancer patients, and its presence was associated with increased sensitivity to PARP inhibitors in cultured MCF‑7 cells.

The homozygous c.263C>T sequence variant in the CYP2D6 gene (rs11079788) was found to markedly reduce enzyme activity, thereby elevating plasma concentrations of the antiepileptic drug levetiracetam in a cohort of H. sapiens patients.

The CRISPR‑edited A549 cells bearing the c.263C>T sequence variant in the TP53 gene displayed a pronounced increase in apoptosis upon doxorubicin exposure, confirming the deleterious functional impact of this mutation.

Evidence shows that the c.263C> T sequence variant in the APC gene leads to aberrant splicing and is associated with increased risk of familial adenomatous polyposis in patients of the East Asian population.

Evidence that the BRCA1 c.263C>T variant creates a novel splice acceptor site and reduces homologous recombination repair capacity was confirmed by functional assays in A549 cells harboring the c.263C>T allele.
Evidence indicates that the c.263C>T sequence variant (rs11079788) in the BRCA1 gene leads to a loss of the DNA repair domain, which increases the risk of triple‑negative breast cancer in carriers.

Evidence from a cohort of *Homo sapiens* patients carrying the sequence variant c.263C>T (rs11079788) indicates that this mutation, which causes a codon‑specific N372H change, is associated with a markedly increased risk of developing type‑2 diabetes mellitus, especially when combined with the M235T polymorphism in the angiotensin‑converting enzyme gene.

cDNA analysis of the TP53 transcript from a biopsy of a HeLa cell line revealed a BRCA1 c.263C> T sequence variant that co‑exists with a novel N372H missense mutation in the insulin gene, suggesting a possible compound effect on DNA repair and metabolic regulation in these cells.

c.*263C>T* variants in the *APOE* gene are associated with increased risk of late‑onset Alzheimer's disease, while *rs11079788* and *7488TT* polymorphisms in *TOMM40* correlate with differential age of onset in *Homo sapiens* populations.
c.[263]C>T and rs11079788 together with the M235T variant in the AGT gene were shown to synergistically increase the risk of hypertension in a cohort of Homo sapiens subjects.
c.m.263C>T, a pathogenic sequence variant, was identified in a patient’s TP53 gene, confirming a germline mutation that predisposes to Li–Fraumeni syndrome.
A missense sequence variant c.263C>T in the BRCA1 gene, identified as rs11079788, was associated with an increased risk of triple‑negative breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.
A c.304delA variant in the APOE gene was found to correlate with an increased risk of late‑onset Alzheimer’s disease in a cohort of European ancestry.

A p53 c.263C>T sequence variant (rs11079788) in a colorectal carcinoma cell line (HCT116) was found to reduce TP53 transcriptional activity and increase cell proliferation compared to the wild‑type allele.

A heterozygous c.263C>T variant in the CFTR gene was identified in a patient with classic cystic fibrosis, and its segregation with the rs11079788 SNP revealed a compound heterozygosity that likely explains the severe lung phenotype.
Mutation of the N372H variant (rs11079788) in the LDLR gene reduces LDL receptor binding and increases plasma LDL cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

Mutation c.263C>T in the ATP1A2 gene, a variant previously annotated as rs11079788, has been shown to increase susceptibility to episodic migraine in patients with a background of the E873-TAG polymorphism.
Mutation rs11079788 in the BRCA1 gene, which causes a c.263C>T substitution resulting in a N372H amino‑acid change, is associated with increased breast cancer susceptibility in certain populations.

Mutation analysis revealed that the c.263C>T sequence variant in TP53, which causes the N372H amino‑acid substitution, is strongly associated with increased susceptibility to colorectal cancer in patients carrying the rs11079788 genotype.
In HepG2 cells, the c.304delA sequence variant in the promoter of the CYP1A1 gene reduces transcriptional activity, thereby diminishing the cells’ ability to metabolize the carcinogen benzo[a]pyrene.

In patients carrying the c.263C>T variant, the altered codon at position N372H within the TP53 gene was associated with reduced p53 transcriptional activity and an increased risk of sporadic colorectal cancer.
In HeLa cells, the BRCA1 sequence variant c.263C>T (rs11079788) was shown to reduce RAD51 binding and thereby increase sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging drug doxorubicin.

In colorectal carcinoma samples, the c.263C>T (N372H) sequence variant in the MTHFR gene, which alters the enzyme’s catalytic efficiency, was found to be associated with increased expression of the DNA repair protein XRCC1 and a higher mutation load in TP53.
Homozygous c.263C>T (rs11079788) in the CYP1A1 promoter correlates with increased M235T allele frequency and a higher risk of non‑small cell lung cancer in smokers.

Heterozygous carriers of the c.263C>T sequence variant in the BRCA1 gene, which results in the N372H substitution, exhibit a significantly increased risk of breast cancer compared with individuals lacking this mutation.

Hematologic malignancies harbor the c.263C>T (N372H) variant, and in vitro studies reveal that this sequence variant confers resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in the A549 cell line.
Hepatocellular carcinoma cells with the BRCA1 c.263C> T sequence variant exhibit markedly increased expression of the DNA repair protein RAD51, thereby conferring resistance to doxorubicin treatment.

RNA immunoprecipitation of the BRCA1 transcript revealed that the c.263C>T SequenceVariant induces a novel N372H amino‑acid change, altering splicing of exon three and reducing DNA‑damage repair capacity in MCF‑7 CellLine cells.

RNA‑seq of peripheral blood mononuclear cells from patients carrying the BRCA1 c.263C>T sequence variant revealed a marked up‑regulation of the DNA‑damage response gene ATM, suggesting that this single‑nucleotide polymorphism (rs11079788) may alter the cellular repair capacity and predispose to breast cancer.

RNA sequencing of the BRCA1 transcript in a breast cancer patient revealed a sequence variant c.263C>T that co‑occurs with the rs11079788 polymorphism, suggesting a potential functional impact on splicing.
RNA editing of the TP53 c.263C>T variant (rs11079788) in E. coli‐derived A549 cells increases the N372H polymorphism, thereby enhancing M235T-mediated apoptosis and reducing tumor growth.

Erythrocyte membrane protein α–hemoglobin stabilizing protein, harboring the sequence variant c.263C>T, was shown to attenuate the binding affinity for the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL in HeLa cells, thereby increasing cellular susceptibility to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

E873-TAG, a pathogenic sequence variant in the MT-ND1 gene, was found to disrupt complex I activity in isolated mitochondria from patients with Leigh syndrome, thereby linking the variant to the clinical phenotype of severe neurodegeneration.

Ectopic expression of the BRCA1 c.263C>T variant (rs11079788) in the HeLa cell line reduces homologous recombination efficiency, suggesting that this sequence variant disrupts DNA repair pathways in human cancer cells.

Epidemiological analysis revealed that the BRCA1 c.263C>T sequence variant, located at codon‑263, is strongly associated with an increased risk of breast cancer in women of European ancestry, whereas the synonymous A2803G variant in the same gene shows no significant phenotypic effect.
Patients with the BRCA1 c.263C>T sequence variant exhibit a higher frequency of chemotherapeutic resistance due to altered DNA repair activity.
Patients carrying the sequence variant c.263C>T in the BCL2L1 gene exhibited increased resistance to apoptosis when treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
Patients harboring the c.263C>T (rs11079788) variant, which replaces the tyrosine codon at position‑358 with histidine, exhibit a markedly increased susceptibility to drug‑induced cardiotoxicity.
Patients treated with doxorubicin exhibited a markedly higher incidence of cardiomyopathy when carrying the rs11079788 variant, which encodes the M235T substitution in the β‑adrenergic receptor.

Alterations in the TP53 c.263C>T (codon‑88 R→W) variant, previously associated with reduced p53 transcriptional activity, were confirmed in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin, where the resultant N372H substitution in MDM2 increased apoptosis via the p53‑dependent pathway.
Alteration of the TP53 sequence variant c.263C>T (rs11079788) in HeLa cells leads to reduced p53 transcriptional activity and confers resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.
Altering the TP53 sequencevariant c.263C>T in the HeLa cell line enhances p53 transcriptional activity and increases sensitivity to the DNA-damaging agent doxorubicin.
Altered transcription of TP53 in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.263C>T sequence variant leads to increased apoptosis and higher sensitivity to doxorubicin.

An A549 cell line carrying the BRCA1 c.263C>T (N372H) sequence variant exhibited reduced DNA repair activity, suggesting that the rs11079788 polymorphism modulates the cellular response to doxorubicin-induced damage.
An in vitro study demonstrated that the BRCA1 sequence variant c.263C> T, which results in the N372H amino‑acid change, impairs homologous recombination efficiency in the HCC1937 cell line.

An integrative analysis revealed that the c.263C>T sequence variant in the MTHFR gene, previously catalogued as rs11079788, is associated with increased homocysteine levels and a higher risk of neural tube defects in a Han Chinese cohort.

An investigation of the BRCA1 c.263C>T sequence variant in a cohort of women with familial breast cancer revealed that carriers of the c.263C>T mutation exhibited a higher frequency of deleterious splicing alterations compared to those with the wild‑type sequence.

Mendelian inheritance of the c.263C>T variant in the CYP1A2 gene (rs11079788) leads to the N372H amino‑acid substitution, which markedly reduces enzymatic activity and predisposes carriers to higher smoking‑induced lung cancer risk.

Molecular analysis of the TP53 gene in A549 cells revealed that the c.263C>T SequenceVariant, which results in the codon‑358 N372H substitution, was associated with a statistically significant increase in p53 protein stability compared to the wild‑type allele.

Mammary carcinoma cells harboring the c.263C>T variant in the BRCA1 gene exhibit markedly reduced homologous recombination repair capacity, rendering them hypersensitive to the PARP inhibitor olaparib.

MALAT1 expression was markedly reduced in A549 cells transfected with the BRCA1 c.263C>T sequence variant, which was predicted to alter the splicing enhancer motif and thus impair DNA repair in this lung carcinoma model.

Variant c.263C>T in the TP53 gene (rs11079788) was found to increase the risk of colorectal cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens, with the M235T amino‑acid substitution in exon seven further exacerbating disease severity.
Variant rs11079788 in the VDR gene, which results in the N372H amino‑acid substitution, has been associated with increased susceptibility to multiple sclerosis in a North‑American cohort.
Variant **c.263C>T** in the **TP53** gene was found to increase the susceptibility to **colorectal carcinoma** in patients of the **Homo sapiens** population.
Variant *c.263C>T* in the *BRCA1* gene causes a premature stop codon, leading to reduced DNA repair activity and increased susceptibility to triple‑negative breast cancer in *Homo sapiens* carriers.

The rs2071349 variant, encoding Arg64Trp in the CYP2D6 gene, was associated with altered metabolism of the anticancer drug doxorubicin in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients, while the V311fs sequence variant in the same gene led to a truncated protein that failed to activate the downstream insulin signaling pathway in A549 cells.

The Arg64Trp variant (rs2071349) in the CYP2C9 gene causes a V311fs frameshift that reduces enzymatic activity, thereby increasing the risk of severe hepatotoxicity when patients are treated with the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.

The BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, denoted V311fs, was found to destabilize the protein’s DNA‑binding domain, thereby amplifying the risk of hereditary breast and ovarian cancers in a cohort of Homo sapiens individuals carrying the rs2071349 allele.

The c.521T>C (p.Lys174Thr) sequence variant in the CYP2C9 gene, which is located within the rs2071349 locus, has been shown to alter enzyme activity and is associated with reduced warfarin clearance in patients with the Arg64Trp polymorphism.

A missense variant rs2071349 resulting in Arg64Trp was found to alter the kinase activity of the A549 cell line, while a simultaneous V311fs indel in the TP53 gene was associated with increased apoptosis in E. coli-derived plasmid DNA preparations.

A V311fs sequence variant in the CYP2C19 gene, annotated as rs2071349, was shown to dramatically reduce enzyme activity and increase the risk of adverse reactions to clopidogrel in patients of the E. coli strain used for recombinant protein production.
A variant of the IL10 promoter, rs2071349, creates an Arg64Trp substitution that enhances binding of NF‑κB and increases expression of the cytokine in patients with Crohn’s disease.

A CRISPR/Cas9‑edited A549 cell line harboring the BRCA1 rs2071349 V311fs sequence variant shows heightened sensitivity to the DNA‑damage agent doxorubicin, correlating with reduced TP53 protein stability and increased apoptosis compared with wild‑type cells.

Mutation of the TP53 gene to the Arg64Trp (rs2071349) variant in a HeLa cell line results in a pronounced decrease in DNA‑damage‑induced apoptosis, linking the sequence variant to altered cellular response to chemotherapeutic doxorubicin.

Mutation rs2071349 resulting in Arg64Trp in the CYP2C9 gene markedly increases the clearance of warfarin in patients with the -889TT promoter haplotype, thereby reducing the risk of dose‐related bleeding events in Homo sapiens.

Mutation analysis of the rs2071349 polymorphism revealed a V311fs frameshift that alters the protein’s lysine at position‐223, potentially disrupting the catalytic domain and reducing the activity of the enzyme in HeLa cells.

Mutation **rs2071349** (c.193C>T) in the **TP53** gene introduces an **Arg64Trp** substitution, which has been shown to disrupt p53’s DNA‑binding domain and correlate with increased susceptibility to **breast cancer** in **Homo sapiens**.

Gene therapy targeting the rs2071349 sequence variant, which substitutes Arg64 for Trp, has been shown to restore normal protein folding in A549 cell line cultures infected with adenovirus and to reduce fever in patients with the associated disease phenotype.

Gene knock‑in of the rs2071349 variant, which causes an Arg64Trp substitution in the DNA‑binding domain of the transcription factor NF‑κB, was shown to enhance TNF‑α production in stimulated THP‑1 monocytes, thereby exacerbating inflammatory signaling pathways relevant to atherosclerosis.

Gene‑editing of the CDKN2A locus in HCT116 cells introduced the V311fs sequence variant, which in turn led to a truncated p16^INK4a protein that failed to bind cyclin‑dependent kinase and caused uncontrolled proliferation.

Gene expression of the transcription factor C/EBPβ was found to be markedly reduced in HeLa cells carrying the rs2071349‑associated Arg64Trp variant, a mutation that alters the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and predisposes these cells to heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.

In the A549 cell line, the BRCA1 c.521T>C sequence variant (rs2071349) was found to increase sensitivity to doxorubicin, an effect that was amplified when co‑expressed with the TP53 Arg64Trp mutation (rs713041).
In liver tissue from a patient harboring the V311fs sequence variant, the truncated protein led to aberrant CYP2D6 expression and a consequent increase in the risk of drug-induced liver injury.

In vitro functional assays revealed that the sequence variant rs2071349, causing an Arg64Trp substitution, significantly reduces the transcriptional activity of the TP53 promoter in HeLa cells, an effect that correlates with increased cellular sensitivity to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

In *Homo sapiens* cells harboring the sequence variant rs2071349 (Arg64Trp) within the *TP53* gene, the altered arginine residue reduces DNA‑binding affinity, thereby impairing the transcriptional activation of the pro‑apoptotic gene *BAX* and contributing to chemoresistance in the A549 lung cancer cell line.

Detection of the rs2071349 V311fs sequence variant in the CYP2C19 gene was associated with a significant reduction in clopidogrel metabolism, leading to higher platelet reactivity in patients treated with this antiplatelet agent.

Detection and functional characterization of the rs2071349 A>G sequence variant revealed an Arg64Trp substitution that impairs IL-1β secretion in the THP‑1 monocytic cell line, thereby linking this genetic change to heightened inflammatory responses in Homo sapiens.

Detection in a patient-derived A549 cell line of the BRCA1 rs2071349 sequence variant (c.521T>C) revealed that the resulting Arg64Trp amino‑acid substitution disrupts DNA‑binding activity and correlates with increased sensitivity to doxorubicin treatment.

Detection by allele‑specific PCR revealed that the rs2071349 sequence variant, which causes an Arg64Trp substitution in the MTHFR protein, is significantly more frequent in patients with elevated homocysteine levels than in controls.

Mutations such as V311fs and the rs2071349 Arg64Trp variant were identified in the coding region of the CYP2C9 gene in a cohort of homozygous E. coli‑derived plasmids, suggesting that these sequence variants may alter enzyme activity and affect drug metabolism.

Mutational analysis of a colorectal carcinoma sample revealed a V311fs sequence variant in the APC gene, which was predicted to truncate the protein and disrupt its interaction with β‑catenin, thereby contributing to the malignant phenotype.

Mutagenic exposure to doxorubicin induced a V311fs sequence variant in the TP53 gene of A549 cells, disrupting the DNA‑binding domain and correlating with increased apoptosis and reduced colony formation in this human lung carcinoma line.

Mutant KRAS G12V, a SequenceVariant (V311fs) identified by rs2071349, was shown to increase transcription of the oncogenic GeneOrGeneProduct BRAF in the human colorectal CancerCellLine HCT116, thereby amplifying the MAPK signaling cascade in Homo sapiens.

Variants such as rs2071349 (Arg64Trp) and rs2073601-rs2073416 have been shown to alter the expression of CYP2D6, thereby influencing the pharmacokinetics of the anticancer drug doxorubicin in patients with Homo sapiens.

Variants of the TNFα promoter such as rs2071349 (−308G>A) and the coding mutation Arg64Trp in the TNFRSF1A gene have been shown to synergistically increase transcriptional activity, thereby amplifying inflammatory responses in patients with autoimmune disease.

Variants carrying the rs2071349 rs2073601‑rs2073416 haplotype, the Arg64Trp amino‑acid change and the V311fs frameshift, have been associated with increased susceptibility to inflammatory bowel disease and altered response to sulfasalazine in patients of European ancestry.

Variants with the rs2071349 (Arg64Trp) substitution in the V311fs‑mutated TP53 gene were found to increase the risk of malignant melanoma in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients who were also homozygous for the -889TT promoter polymorphism.
When the Arg64Trp sequence variant (rs2071349) is present in the CYP1A1 gene, individuals exhibit markedly reduced enzymatic activity, leading to increased susceptibility to benzene-induced leukemia.

When CRISPR/Cas9‑generated **V311fs** sequence variants were introduced into the **A549** cell line, the resulting frameshift caused a premature stop codon that abolished **TP53** protein expression, leading to unchecked proliferation and increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic **doxorubicin** in **Homo sapiens** cells.

When HEK293 cells harboring the rs2071349 Arg64Trp sequence variant were treated with doxorubicin, the observed reduction in TP53 protein levels correlated with increased apoptosis relative to cells with the wild‑type allele.

When A549 cells expressing the TP53 V311fs sequence variant were treated with doxorubicin, the resulting apoptosis was markedly attenuated compared to the wild‑type TP53, indicating that the V311fs variant confers chemoresistance.

Sequencing of a patient’s CYP2C9 locus revealed the rs2071349 variant, causing an Arg64Trp substitution, which was confirmed by a V311fs indel at position c.521T > C and predicted to diminish warfarin metabolism in this Homo sapiens individual.

Sequenced biopsies from patients with colorectal cancer revealed a V311fs sequence variant in the APC gene, and the rs2071349 polymorphism was associated with increased expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 in the same samples.

Sequencevariant rs2071349, which encodes the Arg64Trp amino‑acid substitution, was identified in a cohort of patients with colorectal cancer, and its presence correlated with increased expression of the oncogenic protein TP53 and a higher risk of disease progression in Homo sapiens.

Sequencer analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, the rs2071349 polymorphism, and the Arg64Trp substitution in the TP53 gene revealed a significant association with increased breast cancer risk in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.
Tissue‑specific expression of the *TP53* gene is markedly increased in A549 cells harboring the V311fs sequence variant, leading to enhanced apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Treated HeLa cells expressing the BRCA1 SequenceVariant rs2071349 Arg64Trp showed increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic ChemicalEntity doxorubicin, correlating with elevated TP53 expression and reduced cell proliferation.

Tryptophan substitution at position Arg64Trp in the V311fs variant of the *ABCB1* gene (rs2071349) markedly reduces drug efflux in A549 cells, leading to increased intracellular accumulation of doxorubicin and enhanced cytotoxicity.

Toxicological analyses of the rs2071349 polymorphism in the CYP1A1 promoter revealed that the -889TT genotype, which results in an Arg64Trp substitution, correlates with increased susceptibility to dioxin-induced hepatotoxicity in Homo sapiens exposed to low‑dose ethanol.

Deletion of the rs2071349 sequence variant in the promoter region of the IL6 gene reduces its transcriptional activity, thereby attenuating the cytokine response to lipopolysaccharide in E. coli–stimulated THP‑1 cells.
Deletion in the BCL2L1 gene (c.521T>C) causes an Arg64Trp variant that has been shown to alter protein stability and increase apoptosis sensitivity in MCF‑7 cells.
Deletion c.521T>c in the COL4A1 gene creates a V311fs sequence variant that is associated with a higher risk of cerebral small‑vessel disease in patients with the rs2071349 risk allele.

Deletion variant rs2071349 (c.521T>C) in the CYP1A1 gene alters the catalytic efficiency of the enzyme, thereby modulating the risk of cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in patients receiving high‑dose therapy.

Analysis of the rs2071349 variant in the CYP2C9 gene revealed that the Arg64Trp change decreases enzymatic activity, thereby increasing susceptibility to adverse drug reactions in patients treated with warfarin.

Analysis revealed that the rs2071349 (Arg64Trp) sequence variant in the CYP2C9 gene, which is a missense mutation that changes arginine to tryptophan at position‑64, is significantly associated with reduced enzymatic activity and higher plasma concentrations of the chemotherapeutic agent dabrafenib in patients with metastatic melanoma.

Analysis indicated that the rs2071349 Arg64Trp variant, which results from the c.191G>C (521T>C) substitution and leads to a V311fs frameshift in the protein, is strongly associated with increased susceptibility to Parkinson’s disease in Homo sapiens.

Analysis showed that the rs2071349 (Arg64Trp) sequence variant, located at a splice donor site, destabilizes the TP53 mRNA and is associated with increased risk of familial colorectal cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.
An Arg64Trp sequence variant in the CYP2C9 gene (rs2071349) was found to increase the risk of tacrolimus toxicity in a cohort of homozygous African‑American transplant recipients.

An A549 cell line engineered to express the BRCA1 sequence variant rs2071349 (c.521T>C) showed markedly reduced homologous recombination repair capacity compared with the wild‑type counterpart, indicating that this single‑nucleotide polymorphism may compromise DNA damage response in non‑small‑cell lung carcinoma.

An rs2071349 missense variant (Arg64Trp) in the CYP2C19 gene was found to significantly reduce clopidogrel activation and increase the risk of ischemic events in a cohort of E. coli‑infected patients with coronary artery disease.

Mutation detection of a g.99367-102002del sequence variant in the TP53 gene revealed a T > C transversion at nucleotide position ∼4508, resulting in the p.Pro27ProfsX54 frameshift and the Arg555‑to‑tryptophan substitution, which was further confirmed in a homozygous E. coli strain expressing the Asn‑type transfectant.

Mutation T > C in the TP53 gene, which results in the p.Pro27ProfsX54 protein variant, was detected in an E. coli strain carrying the Leu269Phe sequence variant and was shown to correlate with increased sensitivity to doxorubicin in the A549 cell line.

Loss of the g.99367‑102002del variant in the TP53 gene, which produces the p.F482C missense mutation, was confirmed by sequencing of the A549 cell line derived from a Homo sapiens lung carcinoma sample.

Loss-of-function in the HNF1α gene, caused by a g.99367-102002del sequence variant that produces a p.Pro27ProfsX54 frameshift, impairs insulin transcription and is associated with maturity‑onset diabetes of the young in patients carrying the rs2004640 allele.

Lossless p.Pro27ProfsX54 mutations in the TP53 gene (c.81_83delTTT, rs2004640) were found to be associated with increased apoptosis in A549 cells, as confirmed by Western blotting of the protein product and by cell viability assays.

Loss‑of‑function of the gene encoding the ER‑resident chaperone was observed in the Asn‑type transfectant, where a T > C transition at position g.99367‑102002del produced the p.Pro27ProfsX54 truncation and the concomitant T‑to‑G transversion at nucleotide *4508* caused the arginine‑555‑to‑tryptophan substitution, ultimately abolishing protein activity in *Homo sapiens* cells.

An engineered HeLa transfectant carrying the rs2004640 allele with a T>G transversion at nucleotide position \(4508\) displayed a p.Pro27ProfsX54 truncation that drastically reduced TP53 protein stability and increased cellular sensitivity to doxorubicin.
An Asn-type transfectant carrying the p.Pro27ProfsX54 sequence variant in TP53 displayed a dramatic reduction in tumor suppressor activity compared to the wild‑type protein.

An A549 cell line transfected with a p.Pro27ProfsX54 variant, a T > C transition in the TP53 gene, and a g.99367‑102002del deletion in the BRCA1 sequence, exhibited increased apoptosis after doxorubicin treatment.

An in‑vitro screen of the Asn‑type transfectant showed that the p.Pro27ProfsX54 variant, generated by a T > C transition at position c.81, disrupted TP53 protein stability and led to increased apoptosis in HeLa cells.

Widespread screening of colorectal carcinoma samples revealed that the rs2004640 allele, which introduces a T>C transversion at nucleotide position −99370 leading to a p.Pro27ProfsX54 frameshift, was strongly associated with increased expression of the KRAS oncogene in A549 cell lines.

WES of a colorectal cancer patient identified a pathogenic BRCA1 g.99367-102002del sequence variant that co‑occurs with a somatic T > C transversion at nucleotide position c.4508T>G in the TP53 gene, suggesting a synergistic effect on tumor progression.
Wang et al. reported that the rs2004640 T > C transition in the TP53 gene, causing a p.Pro27ProfsX54 sequence variant, led to increased apoptosis in HeLa cells exposed to doxorubicin.

Wnt/β‑catenin signaling is disrupted in colorectal cancers harboring the BRCA1 sequence variant p.Pro27ProfsX54, where a T > C transition at position c.82 leads to a premature termination codon and loss of functional p53 binding activity.

Exposure of the A549 cell line to the p.Pro27ProfsX54 sequence variant, a T > C mutation that deletes nucleotides g.99367-102002del, led to a marked increase in the expression of the TP53 gene product and a corresponding reduction in cell proliferation.

Exposure to the T>T>C transversion at nucleotide position (T -- > G) in the BRCA1 gene, which generates the p.Pro27ProfsX54 sequence variant, was associated with a higher incidence of breast cancer in Homo sapiens carriers of the rs2004640 allele.

Exposure in the Asn‑type transfectant to a T > C transition at nucleotide position g.99367-102002del produced the p.Pro27ProfsX54 sequence variant, which correlated with increased drug resistance in HeLa cells.

Exposure–induced T > C transversions at nucleotide position c.4508 of the *TP53* gene generate the p.Pro27ProfsX54 sequence variant, which is frequently observed in cultured A549 and HeLa cell lines and is associated with increased cellular radiosensitivity in *Homo sapiens* tumors.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated insertion of the four nucleotides CCCC at the A549 cell line genome near the TP53 locus created a novel SequenceVariant, c.6799G>A, that introduces the p.Ser63Asn change in the TP53 protein and was associated with increased sensitivity to the chemical entity doxorubicin.
The p.Ser63Asn sequence variant in TP53 (rs10942891) was shown to increase apoptosis in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin.

The splice‑site variant c.6799G>A in TP53, predicted to create a novel donor site and resulting in a truncated protein, was identified in a breast cancer patient with a family history of Li‑Fraumeni syndrome and correlated with elevated p53‑target gene expression in her tumor biopsies.
The c.6799G>A sequence variant in TP53, which substitutes serine with asparagine at residue p.Ser63Asn, was found to up‑regulate the apoptotic response in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin.
In HepG2 cells, the p.Ser63Asn variant of the CYP2D6 gene reduces enzymatic activity, thereby lowering the metabolism of the anticancer drug doxorubicin and increasing the risk of cardiotoxicity.

In a recent study of colorectal cancer, a frameshift sequence variant involving the insertion of four nucleotides CCCC at position c.7488 caused a premature stop codon that was associated with increased KRAS expression and poor overall survival.

In the HeLa cell line, the CRISPR‑generated sequence variant c.6799G>A in the TP53 gene caused a p.Ser63Asn substitution that disrupted the DNA‑binding domain and led to a marked increase in cellular apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment.

C282Y, a missense SequenceVariant in the HFE gene, is strongly associated with increased iron absorption and hepatocellular carcinoma risk in Homo sapiens, while the concomitant rs10942891 polymorphism modulates the expression of the related ferroportin transporter.

Analysis revealed that the c.643T > C variant in the TP53 gene, which results in a histidine‑626‑to‑arginine substitution, is linked to a higher risk of chemotherapy‑induced cardiotoxicity in patients with the rs2234671 allele.
